title: LONDON BEING 'BULLIED' BY ULSTER UNIONISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR TAXES TO OFFSET LOSS FROM TAPES
description: The American music industry is being harmed by home taping of records. That harm is likely to worsen, to the detriment of music lovers as well, unless Congress acts to compensate creators and copyright owners for the copying of their works by legislating a reasonable royalty on blank tape and on recording equipment.

title: AMERICAN PLANE CRASHES IN SPAIN
description: A United States Air Force transport plane crashed in a snow-covered mountain range in northeast Spain Tuesday night, killing all 17 Americans and a Spanish officer on board.

title: U.S.F.L. LOSES ANTITRUST SUIT ON ELIGIBILITY
description: A Federal judge in Los Angeles ruled yesterday that the United States Football League's college eligibility rules violated antitrust laws.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $1,211,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $2,577,000 for the year. c-After a special charge of $1,545,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $4,103,000 for the year.

title: ZANY, 50'S THEMES AT NEW GIFT SHOW
description: -scale exhibitions where houseware and furniture companies introduce their products to retailers, used to offer a cornucopia of products. Companies selling what have been considered classics of modern design, often referred to as museum merchandise, were side by side with concerns showing more commercial items.

title: Test-Tube Birth in Israel
description: A 29-year-old Israeli woman gave birth today to this country's first ''test tube'' twins, the fifth such twin birth in the world, doctors said. The twin girls, weighing four pounds and five and a half pounds, were delivered at Tel Aviv's Sheba Medical Center.

title: FREUD'S SEDUCTION THEORY: ARRIVAL AND DEPARTURE
description: To the Editor:

description: THE Mercantile Safe Deposit and Trust Company of Baltimore has been moving a bit of its

description: b-Including a tax credit of $286,000. c-Including a credit of $244,000 representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Rosebush Ruth Planted

title: COMPUCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'SEVERAL' SHOW INTEREST IN GULF
description: Preliminary negotiations are under way between the Gulf Corporation and representatives from ''several'' companies - understood to be eight - regarding a ''possible merger,'' Gulf said yesterday. It would not identify any of the companies and did not restrict the list to oil companies, but noted that it could give no assurances that any agreement would be reached.

title: Aquino's Widow Urges Filipinos to Vote
description: Corazon Aquino, widow of the slain opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., urged the Filipino people today to choose a peaceful solution to the political crisis gripping the country by taking part in the May 14 elections.

title: Stereotypes in Toys
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: DEVELOPER IS DISMISSED BY THE CITY
description: The Koch administration removed a Manhattan real-estate company yesterday as the developer of a proposed $159 million waterfront project on the Brooklyn side of the Brooklyn Bridge. The city said it would advertise for new developers for the site.

title: PRINCETON FINALLY TO GET BIG BURGER CHAIN OUTLET
description: For years, this proper college town has been without a big fast-food chain restaurant. But by late spring, with no complaint from local officials, a Burger King is expected to open on Nassau Street, the main street here, across from the main entrance to Princeton University.

title: ZORBA THE MANAGER
description: When Robert W. Creamer began writing about sports in 1954, one of his very first assignments was an old-timers' day at Yankee Stadium. In those less-regimented days, the writers were able to congregate in the dugout while Carl Hubbell began nibbling with his screwball on the outside part of the plate to Joe DiMaggio.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Switch on Cable

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sweatshirt to Sweatshirt

title: HOLLYWOOD HONORS MISS GISH
description: Sitting in a hotel room six floors above the ballroom where she is to be given the American Film Institute's Life Achievement Award tonight, Lillian Gish wears pearls and red lipstick. Her long forehead slopes down to amazingly bushy eyebrows, two thick crayon strokes in an unlined face.

title: FAMILY FURNISHINGS: A CONTINUUM OF MAGIC
description: WHAT is a room - some version of which will accompany us all of our lives? Even as we hunt it or build it we seldom halt to examine further this companion to human consciousness, omnipresent as sleep or dream.

title: Delmed Sees Loss And Courts Suitor
description: Delmed Inc. said it expected to report a loss for 1983 and is holding talks with an unidentified company relating to the possible acquisition of Delmed.

title: STOCKS ARE MIXED AS THE DOW LISES 2.51
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday in heavier trading following their sharp selloff on Tuesday.

title: The U.N. Today March 1, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bangladash President Vows To Lift Political-Activity Ban
description: President H. M. Ershad said today a ban on political activity would be removed March 26 as a step toward returning Bangladesh to democracy.

title: NEW-FOUND VIRUS SHOWN TO CAUSE AIDS-LIKE ILLNESS IN LAB MONKEYS
description: Scientists have isolated a previously unknown virus and used it to infect monkeys with a disease that closely resembles acquired immune deficiency in humans.

title: O'NEILL HOPES TO RETIRE SOON, TO ANOTHER JOB
description: Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, said today that he would like to retire from Congress at the end of the year and become Ambassador to Ireland ''or some place like that.''

title: SENATE BACKS EMBARGO CURB
description: The Senate today approved a measure, strongly opposed by the Reagan Administration, that would sharply reduce Presidential authority to declare any new embargoes on food exports to the Soviet Union or any other country.

title: Granada TV Rental Fills Top U.S. Post
description: Granada TV Rental, the British company that wants Americans to rent television equipment rather than buy it, has named a new president for its United States operation.

title: NOLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
People
description: * Nancy Kroll Margolis appointed associate publisher/advertising director at Hadassah magazine.

title: TRUDEAU DECLARES HE'LL STEP DOWN AS PRIME MINISTER
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced today that he had decided to resign after more than 15 years as head of the Canadian Government. He said it was ''the appropriate time for someone else to assume this challenge.''

title: STATE COMPTROLLER CALLS FOR A TAX CUT
description: The State Comptroller said today that Governor Cuomo's proposed $35.4 billion state budget was in balance, but he called upon the state to cut spending and reduce taxes.

title: Diasonics Posts Loss
description: Diasonics Inc. reported yesterday that it lost $56.3 million in the fourth quarter, contrasted to net income of $5.4 million, or 12 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Wincorp Group May Block Sale
description: A group of investors told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it believed it controls enough shares of Wincorp Realty Investments Inc. to block Wincorp's sale.

title: Embezzler Agrees To Repay $73,000
description: A former senior account clerk with the Port Washington School District will sell her home to pay back $73,000 she has admitted embezzling, it was disclosed today in Nassau County Court.

title: AMERICAN AIR'S LOW-COST PROGRAM
description: Robert L. Crandall, the president and chief operating officer of American Airlines, said yesterday that the airline would use its new McDonnell Douglas Super 80 aircraft to build a low-cost carrier inside the old high- cost airline that could compete with other low-cost carriers.

title: NETWORKS REPORT THEY HELD BACK ON REPORTING POLL DATA ON HART
description: At 7 P. M. Tuesday, with 20 percent of the New Hampshire polling places still open, CBS News reported in its national newscast that Senator Gary Hart would win the Democratic Presidential primary there ''by a comfortable margin.''

title: Article 022862 -- No Title
description: A group of developers, medical leaders and health care industry officials said yesterday that it would participate in the construction of a $2 billion facility near Fort Lauderdale, Fla., intended as a trade mart for health care products, an educational facility for doctors and nurses and a medical convention center.

title: AN INTERNATIONAL SAMPLING OF SAMPLERS AT THE COOPER-HEWITT
description: TO many people, samplers mean quaint renditions of the alphabet and simple motifs usually done in this country by young women in the 17th and 18th centuries, according to Gillian Moss, assistant curator of textiles at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum.

title: Ogilvy and Karaban Getting Roles at FMR
description: Ogilvy & Mather Partners will be doing print advertising for subscribers, and Karaban, Labiner Advertising will be trying to attract advertisers for the latest addition to the coffee tables of the wealthy - the American edition of FMR, The Magazine of Franco Maria Ricci, a publication started in Italy two years ago. It is dedicated to ''showing art in an organized fashion.''

title: QUEENS MAN IS HELD
description: A woman standing on a Manhattan subway station platform was slain during the evening rush hour yesterday when she was pushed under the wheels of an onrushing Lexington Avenue IRT train and decapitated, the police said.

title: HANNAFORD BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

HOUSE AGREES ON ROAD FUNDS WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) - The House, ending a long stalemate on Federal highway funds, voted today to free long-awaited money to continue interstate highway construction and emergency money for roads damaged by 1983 floods.
description: A compromise bill was approved by voice vote and sent to the Senate after agreement was reached to omit disputed projects that stalled an earlier bill.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
description: Ex-U.S. Antitrust Head To Counsel Law Firm

title: MUSIC: THE VIENNA PHILHARMONIC
description: PERIODICALLY in the course of the New York musical season, an event comes along of such iincontestable significance that everyone associated with music in this city seems to turn up without a second thought. Such is this year's visit of the Vienna Philharmonic, which is concluding an eight-city American tour under Leonard Bernstein's direction with three concerts at Carnegie Hall, the first of which took place last night.

title: Debt Ratings
description: * Mission Insurance Group had its rating on $75 milion in senior debt lowered to Baa3 from single-A3 by Moody's.

title: Muse Cuts Fares
description: The Muse Air Corporation said it is reducing fares from Los Angeles and Ontario, Calif., to five cities in Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma by as much as 30 percent, or $55 one way.

title: MUELLER, PAUL, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JAPAN'S SOCIALISTS CONCEDE ARMED FORCES DO EXIST
description: Japan's Socialists, frustrated after decades as the No. 2 political party and concerned about their future, have altered a rigidly held precept that the country's armed forces are unconstitutional.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: Sipe to Be Tested For Swollen Knee
description: Brian Sipe, the New Jersey Generals' 34- year-old quarterback, reported a swelling on his right knee today and flew to New Jersey to be examined by the team's orthopedic surgeon, Dr. Mark Schottenfeld. The team described the examination as ''a precautionary measure.''

title: Apple Is Sued By 3 Holders
description: Three shareholders of Apple Computer Inc. have sued the company, charging that some Apple executives reaped $84 million from sales of their own shares before the price of Apple's stock plunged last fall.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PHOTO OPPORTUNITY There are few loftier places on earth to aim a camera at than Tibet, the hidden, mountain theocracy of the Himalayas. For all its remoteness, however, Tibet has long attracted explorers, naturalists, scientists and missionaries with cameras in their luggage. The photographs of what they saw is now on view in the heart of Manhattan.

title: Olmedo Trial Jury Still Deliberating
description: A jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn deliberated for a second day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the corruption trial of City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo of Brooklyn and two co-defendants.

title: A DIVIDED PANEL CALLS FOR SENDING CHEAP UPSTATE HYDOPOWER DOWNSTATE
description: A divided gubernatorial commission recommended today that large amounts of inexpensive hydroelectric power be shifted from upstate to homes and businesses downstate and that some power be reserved for business to help promote jobs.

title: West German Prices
description: The cost of living in West Germany rose 3 percent in February from a year earlier and was up three-tenths of 1 percent from January, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The year-to-year increase in February compared with a 2.9 percent rise in January.

title: EMCO LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Atom Panel Faults U.S. Guide
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today it would not go along with the Energy Department's guidelines for selecting the nation's first high-level radioactive waste dump unless there were major improvements in the plan.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: UEBERROTH SAID TO BE SUCCESSOR TO BOWIE KUHN
description: Peter V. Ueberroth, president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, will be named baseball's next commissioner at a meeting of the 26 club owners Saturday, a source close to the Executive Council said today.

title: BANK DEREGULATION PROPOSALS ATTACKED
description: Representative Fernand J. St Germain, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, today attacked Administration-backed proposals to further deregulate the banking industry and hinted that he was reluctant to pass any major legislation this year.

Utility Pleads Guilty To Nuclear Violation
description: A Federal district judge today accepted a guilty plea from the operator of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant to charges of violating reactor testing requirements.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Dayco Names Chief For New Venture
description: The Dayco Corporation of Dayton, Ohio, traditionally an industrial company, is getting into the service business. Dayco, which makes rubber and plastic components for industrial, transportation and consumer businesses, said it would create a new business to administer employee benefit plans for other companies.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Senate Would Narrow Scope Of Law on U.S. Information
description: The Senate approved legislation Monday that would give the Federal Bureau of Investigation and other Federal law-enforcement agencies broader powers to deny access to records under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Woman Is Slain In Queens Home
description: A woman was stabbed to death and her mother seriously wounded at their home in Queens yesterday by an unknown assailant, the police said.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $76,000. c-After tax credits of $80,000 for the quarter and $1,195,000 for the year. d-After a tax credit of $51,000.

title: Cessna Cutbacks
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company, citing sluggish sales of piston-powered planes, said it will suspend the production of the aircraft for three months, idling about 750 workers. Cessna's president, Bill Van Sant, said production at the Pawnee Division here would be suspended beginning April 1. The layoffs, representing about half of the Pawnee Division's payroll, would include 107 workers at the division's branch plant at Strother Field near Winfield.

title: No Headline
description: As Goes New Hampshire . . . The Franklin, N.H., ''sub station'' on Gary Hart's schedule Saturday was not, it turned out, a base for ships but the home of Brenda McGinnis's submarine sandwiches. The stop nonetheless attracted a mob of reporters and townspeople, for the Hart campaign in fact seemed to be turning into a kind of submarine. The S.S. Mondale was making stately waves on the surface, but the torpedoes were already in the water.

title: Selling Stock to Back Gaming Is Assailed
description: A corporation and a political action committee have been ordered to stop soliciting people to buy stock to support a drive to legalize casino gambling in Florida.

title: Ohio Edison Sets Long-Term Bonds
description: The Ohio Edison Company is offering $50 million of 14 1/2 percent bonds due in 2014 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The bonds carry the lowest investment-grade ratings: Baa-3 by Moody's and BBB- by S.& P.

title: 2 Nursing Home Units Can Merge
description: The Justice Department agreed today to settle its suit against the merger of the nation's largest and 17th-largest nursing home operators because the companies have agreed to sell eight properties in Alabama and Georgia.

title: PRICES TO FARMERS FALL
description: Prices farmers get for raw products dropped 1.4 percent in February, after rising for three consecutive months, but February prices still averaged 7.6 percent higher than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

description: A Tulsa, Okla., bank holding company once headed by the new president of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission today with publicly exaggerating its earnings by underestimating its likely loan losses by millions of dollars in mid-1982.

title: UNUSUAL SPEED CITED IN JETLINER ACCIDENT AT KENNEDY AIRPORT
description: The jetliner that ran out of runway and rolled into tidal waters at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday was flying at an abnormally high speed when it leveled off for a landing, Government officials said yesterday.

title: Utah Regents Chairman To Run for Governor
description: Kem Gardner, chairman of the Utah Board of Regents, has become the first Democrat to say he will definitely run for the governorship this year.

title: Walter Fei Dies in Accident; Former Taiwan Finance Chief
description: Walter H. Fei, an American-educated member of Taiwan's Cabinet, was killed today when he was struck by a bus while walking in a residential suburb of Taipei, the police reported.

title: $100,000 Award
description: Jim Peterson , a former pro football player whose career ended after he suffered knee injuries, has won a jury award of $100,000 from the National Football League Players Association, which he says mishandled his attempts to gain payment for the last two years of his contract with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Joseph Yablonski , the lawyer representing the players association, has filed a motion with Judge Leland Nielsen of the United States District Court for a March 12 hearing seeking to have the Feb. 10 jury verdict set aside.

title: WITNESS'S TESTIMONY IMPLICATES TWO MEN IN TAVERN RAPE CASE
description: The bartender on duty at Big Dan's Tavern the night a woman says she was raped testified in court today that while two men pulled the woman's pants off, two other men stood by shouting, ''Do it! Do it! That's it! That's it!''

title: PACINO QUITS STUDIO POST
description: Al Pacino has resigned as co-artistic director of the Actors Studio, it was learned yesterday.

title: GORBACHEV'S HIGH RANK IN SOVIET IS AFFIRMED
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the youngest member of the ruling Politburo and the one considered closest to Yuri V. Andropov before the Soviet leader's death, seemed to affirm his high standing in the hierarchy today when he addressed voters only two days before Konstantin U. Chernenko, the party leader.

title: FOR MEN LARGELY
description: To the Editor:

title: Marshall Is Out of Hospital
description: Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court, recovering from viral bronchitis, was released today from the Naval Medical Center at Bethesda, Md., a Court spokesman said. Mr. Marshall, 75 years old, is resting at home and his physician says the bronchitis, an inflammation in the windpipe, is ''no problem,'' the spokesman said.

title: STEPPING AHEAD INTO THE PAST
description: Secretaries of State are not apprised in advance that they are expected to do a bit of huckstering in behalf of Clement E. Conger, the department's curator, who over the years has raised more than $10 million in cash and three times that amount in gifts of porcelain, paintings and 18th-century furniture for the refurbishing of the State Department's eighth-floor diplomatic reception rooms. But when pressed into action, they embrace that duty cheerfully.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the Federal Budget misidentified the member of Congress leaving the White House with Senator Mark O. Hatfield. He was Senator Pete V. Domenici.

title: NOVAR ELECTRONICS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in August 1983.

title: Islanders Beat Jets On Late Score, 4-3
description: The newest Islanders, Pat Flatley and Pat LaFontaine, made their points. In fact, Flatley made two points, a goal and an assist, helping the Islanders to a 4-3 victory tonight over the Winnipeg Jets.

title: Wrestler, 16, Had A Rare Ailment
description: Gregory Coleman, a 16-year-old Westchester high school sophomore who collapsed and died during a wrestling match on Feb. 10, was suffering from chronic bronchitis, an inflammation of the heart and pancreas, and a type of ''walking pneumonia,'' according to the County Medical Examiner.

title: A COLLEGE PROUD OF ITS INDEPENDENCE
description: It seemed the unlikeliest place to attract national attention for an adamant stand against Government authority.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alba-Waldensian Inc. a Valdese, N.C., knitwear producer, said it had acquired the assets of Electric Sok Corporation, a hosiery marketer based in Charlotte, N.C. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Milwaukee Rail Bid Up
description: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company today increased its offer to acquire the 3,100 miles of the Milwaukee Road rail line that are still in operation.

title: DR. SAMUEL E. SINBERG
description: Dr. Samuel E. Sinberg, a retired New York radiologist, died last Friday at South Miami Hospital in Florida after surgery following a stroke.

title: VARIED TRACKS IN HART'S ' 'NEW IDEAS'
description: Senator Gary Hart, the upset winner of the Presidential primary in New Hampshire, describes himself as the candidate of ''new ideas.''

title: RAPE TRIAL COVERED LIVE BY CABLE NETWORK
description: A RAPE trial in Fall River, Mass., that has attracted national attention is being televised in part over the Cable News Network. Whatever the prurient may find interesting in this may be overshadowed by an opportunity to see the judicial process at work. At the same time, a viewer may wonder about the propriety of cameras in a courtroom. It is a sensitive issue.

title: Sun Ends Its Bid
description: Sun Banks Inc. said it had withdrawn its proposal to acquire Florida Commercial Banks Inc. Sun Banks' offer of $27 a share, or $86 million, had been rejected earlier. Sun Banks said it had withdrawn its offer because it only sought to acquire other concerns on a friendly basis.

title: A Realistic Jackson
description: Is Reggie Jackson 's career over because he had a horrible season last year? That, according to Jackson, is the question that reporters covering the California Angels' training camp in Mesa, Ariz., seem almost afraid to ask.

title: 2,000 Truckers Lift Brenner Pass Blockade
description: More than 2,000 protesting truckers ended an eight-day blockade today at the Brenner Pass, the main link between Italy and northern Europe, after meetings with Austrian and West German Government officials.

title: Dome Plans Big Write-Off
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said today that it planned to write down the value of its assets by as much as $980 million (Canadian) in 1983.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch yesterday from Amritsar, India, on unrest among Sikhs misstated the role of Hinduism. India has no state religion.

description: New York City is reviewing its telephone bills after an outside consultant found inadvertent overcharges of $150,000 at two city agencies.

description: Organization, money, endorsements and an aura of inevitability are not enough, after all, to assure victory in a primary. That is the news from New Hampshire, and even some supporters of Walter Mondale must feel it is good news. Elections with real live voters are still different from landslides in the press.

description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said it had proposed to acquire Vulcan Inc. for $12 a share for all the shares it did not already own, or a total of about $22 million.

title: PRESERVE MILITARY PART OF ISRAEL-LEBANON PACT
description: The May 17 Israeli-Lebanese withdrawal agreement is clearly a dead letter. President Amin Gemayel has reportedly decided to abandon the accord, but it would be a mistake to renounce it entirely. Instead, the two countries should take steps to separate its crucial military provisions from the political sections that have offended Lebanese Moslems and their Syrian allies.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks, it will be written by Phyllis Rose, a professor of English at Wesleyan University and the author of ''Parallel Lives: Five Victorian Marriages,'' recently published by Knopf.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS $6 BILLION TAX RISE
description: The effort on Capitol Hill to formulate a major deficit reduction package inched forward again today, as the Senate Finance Committee approved nearly $6 billion more in tax increases over three years, and some Republican leaders began to discuss the outlines of a package worth roughly $150 billion.

title: SCORN FOR U.S. IN ISRAEL
description: Israeli policy makers, looking back on their failure to win Lebanon from the Syrians, say they are finding a good deal to criticize in the tactics of the Reagan Administration. Formally, the Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is not criticizing United States policy. But the collapse of much of the Lebanese Army, the eroding strength of the Lebanese Government and President Amin Gemayel's current move toward Damascus are viewed by officials as products of a disturbing series of American mistakes. These, the Israelis say, compounded the problems inherent to Lebanon's internal feuds and factions.

title: TV NOTES: ROLE OF WEATHERCASTERS
description: THE weather has been one of the bigger news makers this season, but at the hands of local television stations it more often than not provides an entertaining shelter from the downpour of daily events that floods the screen during the rest of the program.

title: MANY COACHES CALL DECISION DAMAGING
description: The door may have been opened yesterday to underclassmen who want to play professional football. When a Federal judge decided that the United States Football League's rule barring underclassmen was in violation of antitrust law, some college coaches said the door could also be opened to:

title: 2 Kenyan Officials Make Massacre Charge
description: Two local officials charged today that soldiers and policemen shot, bludgeoned and burned to death at least 300 people among more than 5,000 forced to lie naked outdoors for five days without food or water,
