title: Massachusetts Offering$127 Million of Bonds
description: A $127 million bond issue of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts was offered with yields ranging from 5.5 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.75 percent in 1994 and 9.7 percent in 2003 and 2004, through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Mayor Questions Loans by Officials
description: Mayor Koch, commenting for the first time on personal loans that Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado disclosed he had taken from a subordinate, said yesterday that such actions were ''very bad policy.''

title: SAMPLING OF BROADCAST BARBS IN PERSIAN GULF
description: With reporters rarely allowed to visit the front in the war between Iran and Iraq, the official radio broadcasts of those countries are a source of news. Here is a sampling of broadcasts today from the Iraqi and Iranian Government radio stations, as transcribed and translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service of the Central Intelligence Agency. Iraq

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Quadrennial Rite

title: PLUCKY PARIS ART CENTER DREAMS OF SOHO OUTPOST
description: -AMERICAN relations have been a shade brisk this last week or two, thanks to the controversial plan to build a pavilion by I. M. Pei in the three-sided forecourt of the Louvre. But on the exhibition front the collaboration between France and this country has never been more effective.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago net loss includes charge of $22.7 million for future costs resulting from permit denials for the Marco Island Community.

title: Bridge:Common Bidding Delusion Will Probably Stay Around
description: There is one delusion about bidding that has been around for half a century and is likely to be around for a long time to come. It is that a player who has passed a near opening bid should jump when his partner opens the bidding.

title: AT FLOWER SHOWS, PROMISES OF SPRING
description: MARCH brings on the flower shows. Broad sweeps of tulips and daffodils along with banks of azaleas and primroses - forced to bloom in greenhouses by exhibitors - should offer a promise of spring.

title: SANTA ANITA COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $85,000 for the quarter and $1,016,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $774,000 for the quarter and $1,466,000 for the year.

title: AMERICA NEEDS A SINGLE PRIMARY DATE
description: To the Editor:

title: TONY LAMA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Credit Card Bill Changes
description: The House approved today an amended version of a Senate-passed bill to restore until May 15 the expired Federal law that had prohibited merchants from charging higher prices to customers making purchases with credit cards.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Brands Inc., a diversified packaged goods and services company, has appointed George L. Theophilos to the post of president and chief executive officer of its American Cigar Company division, succeeding Felipe Silva, who is retiring.

title: SIDNEY BIELFIELD
description: Sidney Bielfield, founder of Where magazine and for many years a public- relations executive, died of heart disease last Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 80 years old.

title: SCOUTING
description: Tennis History

title: CONCERT: BRUCKNER 4TH LED BY MUTI
description: ANOTHER orchestra from Philadephia played Carnegie Hall Tuesday night. That ''other'' ensemble was the Philadelphia Orchestra itself, which followed the appearance the previous night of the Symphony Orchestra of the Curtis Institute of Music.

title: Japan Video Recorders
description: Japan exported one million videotape recorders in January, up 38.9 percent from a year earlier but down from December's record high, the Electronics Industries Association of Japan said today. Production of the recorders in January rose 55.6 percent from a year earlier but fell 22.8 percent from the previous month, to 1.5 million units.

title: PRAIRIE OIL ROYALTIES COMPANY LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
2 Held in Heineken Affair
description: The French police said today that two Dutchmen, Cornelis Van Hout, 26 years old, and Willem Holleeder, 25, suspected of kidnapping Alfred H. Heineken, the brewing magnate, in Amsterdam last November had been detained here. Three suspects are already being held in the Netherlands. A police spokesman in Amsterdam said Dutch and French police had found more of the ransom paid before Mr. Heineken was freed after three weeks in captivity.

title: INDIANA UPSETS PURDUE, 78-59
description: Stew Robinson, a reserve, scored 22 points, including 16 in the second half, to lead Indiana to a 78-59 upset of Purdue in a Big Ten Conference game tonight.

title: Kohl Schedules China Visit
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany will visit China on Oct. 8-14 at the invitation of Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: CONTINENTAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SETS A RECORD
description: The United States trade deficit hit a record $9.47 billion in January, the Commerce Department reported today. One analyst called the figure an ''economic disaster'' as a flood of foreign imports and increased demand for oil darkened an already gloomy trading picture.

title: DR. JOEL A. BERNHARD
description: Dr. Joel A. Bernhard, former chief anesthesiologist of the Orange (N.J.) Memorial Hospital Center, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Monday in Morristown, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: MCGRAW-HILL RYERSON LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
South Africa Gold View
description: South Africa's gold production will peak at about 792 tons a year at the end of the 1980's, according to Clive Knobbs, vice president of the Chamber of Mines. He told an investment conference on Tuesday that output would drop to 670 tons at the turn of the century and to 560 tons by the year 2005. South Africa produced about 750 tons of gold last year, three-quarters of the non-Communist world's output.

title: CENTURY FACTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUT ROSES AT VALENTINO GRAVE
description: Ditra Flame, who said she was the original ''Lady in Black'' who for decades made an annual pilgrimage to leave a rose at the grave of Rudolph Valentino, has died. She was 78 years old.

title: Key Rates
ADVENTUROUS CITY DWELLERS MAKE ODD SPACES LIVABLE
description: CERTAIN kinds of people, with a nose for the arcane and the knack of making even the most daunting spaces charming, always seem to stumble on unusual places to live. Remaining relics of an earlier age, carriage houses, back houses and firehouses, are seized upon by these courageous spirits, who prefer to cope with crumbling walls and unstable floorboards rather than face less interesting, spic-and-span spaces.

title: Nettles Asks Trade Over Platoon Plan
description: On baseball's official reporting date for spring training, Graig Nettles arrived at the Yankee camp today, learned he would be platooned at third base with Toby Harrah and said he wanted to be traded.

title: 2 MANHATTAN MEDICAL UNITS SET BROOKLYN-QUEENS LINKS
description: New York Hospital and Cornell University Medical College said yesterday that they would begin training medical students and young physicians at the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens.

title: DeWitt Opens a Shop To Help Audit Media
description: Seeking broader horizons, Eugene A. DeWitt, media maven, has left the Interpublic Group of Companies where he discovered that he is not made for a staff job.

title: PYRO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,126,000 from the sale of certain properties. c-Including a tax credit of $13.5 million and a gain of $13,802,000 from the sale of certain properties.

title: I.R.S. Extends Tip Deadline
description: With nine hours to go until the deadline, the Internal Revenue Service today granted a month's extension to restaurant, bar and hotel employers for their first report on newly taxable tip income.

title: VIEWS ON ISSUES COMPARED
description: Senator Gary Hart's victory over Walter F. Mondale in the New Hampshire Democratic primary has focused national attention on differences between the two. They agree on most issues, but there are key areas in which they appear to disagree, according to statements by the candidates and their aides.

title: HART SEEKING TO EXPLOIT GAIN IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Senator Gary Hart sought today to exploit his surprising victory in the New Hampshire Presidential primary Tuesday amid expectations that his campaign's financial problems might end soon.

title: ON SALVADOR HUSTINGS, TWO OLD FOES IN REMATCH
description: Two years after their last head-to-head campaign confrontation, the front-runners in El Salvador's presidential election race are ready for a rematch.

title: MINNETONKA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $9,752 for the quarter and $99,301 for the 9 months. c-After a tax credit of $90,000. The latest quarter results include the operations of Technical Design Force Inc. and one-half the operations of a start-up company, Hytek Amplifier Inc., both of which were purchased in August 1983.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: LEFTIST LABORITE RUNNING IN LOW KEY
description: The campaign to fill a seat in Parliament from this old market town in the north of England has been as twisted as the famous church steeple rising out of the town's center, a landmark that over the centuries has buckled ever so slowly into a crooked shape.

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of the limited partnership interests in 22 limited partnerships acquired last November.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in 1983 and to include results from Tops Business Forms Inc., acquired in February 1983.

title: Garbage Pollutes Lake in Jersey
description: Liquid seeping from garbage at a sanitation company has polluted Danherts Lake in Garfield and may have contributed to a recent fish kill there, Bergen County officials said.

title: Glenn Draws Top Spot On Ballot in New York
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio drew the top spot today on the ballot for New York State's April 3 Democratic primary.

title: Virginia Financing For Rapid Transit
description: A $21.2 million issue of Arlington County, Va., general obligation bonds is offered with yields ranging from 5.5 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.2 percent in 1994 and 9.4 percent in 2004 through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: C.D. Rates Rise Again
description: Interest rates on six-month certificates of deposit continued to rise in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 1, 1984 International
description: Pierre Elliott Trudeau plans to resign after serving as Canada's Prime Minister for more than 15 years. Iona Campagnola, president of the Liberal Party, said Mr. Trudeau would remain in office as leader of the party and head of Government until a successor is chosen in a national convention. (Page A1, Column 6.) Moscow vetoed a French proposal in the United Nations Security Council that would have sent an international peacekeeping force to Lebanon. The proposal was backed by 13 members of the 15-member Council. (A1:3.)

title: RANGERS LOSE ON 2 BY DERLAGO
description: Coach Herb Brooks of the Rangers is concerned that a sputtering offense could prove costly as the New Yorkers enter the stretch drive for first place in the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League.

title: PENNEY, J C, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $31 million for the quarter and $38 million for the year.

title: POWER AGENCY AID TAKEN UP IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives began debate today on legislation to shore up the shaky finances of the Rural Electrification Administration amid assertions that the bill was a multibillion- dollar ''bailout'' of an agency that had outlived its usefulness.

title: United Brands
description: The United Brands Company is selling $100 million of 14 3/4 percent sinking fund debentures due in 1999 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert. Proceeds of the debentures, which have speculative grade ratings of B-1 by Moody's and B- by S.& P., will be used to repay bank debt.

title: AGENCY CALLS WEAPON TEST REPORTS DEFICIENT
description: Top Army policy makers complain that the officials who evaluate the results of tests of major weapons do not provide enough information for sound decisions on whether to produce or scrap a weapon system, according to a General Accounting Office report.

title: CRANSTON QUITS DEMOCRATIC RACE
description: Gary Hart, eager to capitalize on his upset victory in the New Hampshire Presidential primary, made plans today to step up his challenge against a wounded front-runner, Walter F. Mondale, in a series of early contests in Maine, Vermont and Wyoming.

title: CROWN FOREST INDUSTRIES LIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'83 G.N.P. Up 3% in Canada
description: The Canadian economy grew by 3 percent last year, in a broadly based recovery, reversing the 4.4 percent decline of 1982, Statistics Canada said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COMMISSION'S REPORT ON HYDROELCTRIC POWER IN THE STATE
description: Following are excerpts from the report of the Temporary Commission on the Allocation of Power Authority Hydroelectric Power:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 1, 1984

title: Regina Girls Win
description: Maria Regina of Uniondale, L.I., won 9 of 12 events and scored 84 points to take the team title yesterday in the sixth Catholic High Schools girls' track and field championships, at Pratt Institute. Twenty-one schools from eight counties participated.

title: Imprisoned Armenian Dies
description: Gourgen Migirdic Yanikian, an Armenian author and engineer who killed two Turkish consular officials in California in 1973, died Monday in prison of natural causes. He was 88 years old. He was sentenced to life in prison in July 1973 for first-degree murder.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TechnologyAndrew Pollack ; A Document That Can Talk
description: like films. Whenever someone started reading a

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $22,958 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $15,144 from discontinued operations.

title: REAGAN CRITICIZES HOUSE DEMOCRATS
description: President Reagan patiently worked on his own political agenda today, criticizing House Democrats on the issues of crime and school prayer and joking to a group of elderly people that he intended ''to campaign in all 13 states.''

title: Grenade Kills 3 In Punjab City
description: A hand grenade was tossed into a procession of Hindus in the Sikh holy city of Amritsar today, killing 3 people, wounding 35 others and touching off a riot, the police said.

title: Hicksville Rejects Moment of Silence
description: By a 4-to-3 margin, the Board of Education decided tonight to end the practice of beginning the day with a 30-second period of silent meditation at some district schools.

title: COURT DENIES RETROACTIVE USE OF 5TH AMENDMENT PROTECTION
description: The Supreme Court refused today to apply retroactively a 1981 decision enhancing a criminal suspect's constitutional protection against self-incrimination.

title: Financial Corp.
description: The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara said shareholders had approved the sale of between 3,570,000 and 3,725,000 new shares of stock to Vagabond Hotels Inc. at $9.50 a share.

title: Briton Plans a Rival To People Express
description: - Richard Branson, a record company executive, said today that he plans to start a low-fare airline to rival People Express for trans-Atlantic business.

title: Accounts
description: * New York City Fair Housing Administration to Avrett, Free & Ginsburg, for its 1984 public service campaign.

title: ITEMS THAT CAN ASSIST
description: MANY of the items suggested for improving kitchens for the elderly or disabled are available in department stores and houseware shops. Many special devices for the disabled are available through catalogues.

title: DANCE: A GRAHAM PREMIERE
description: A FEW months short of her 90th birthday, Martha Graham continues on her creative course with her usual febrility as an image-maker. And as last night's program at the State Theater proved, the staging of her earliest works remind us how wide- ranging that creativity has been for nearly 60 years.

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
REPAIRING RACKS CALLED CANTERBURIES
description: THE canterbury, a small stand with a drawer and openwork divisions, was first thought of early in the 19th century. It was actually a filing system to contain both bound and sheet music and was a most useful piece of furniture to be placed by the piano in fashionable drawing rooms. It is said to have been named for an Archbishop of Canterbury, who used a model made around 1806.

title: POWER LINE FAILURE CAUSES ELECTRICITY LOSSES IN 5 STATES
description: About three million homes and businesses in five Western states were without electricity yesterday for periods ranging from a few minutes to several hours as a result of the failure of a power line in northern California.

title: ABERFORD RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a special gain of $1,213,000. Year-ago results are for the 8 months through Dec. 31, 1982.

title: O'Neill Says Mondale Hit 'Heartbreak Hill'
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that Walter F. Mondale ''ran into his Heartbreak Hill'' in the New Hampshire primary but was still ahead in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: FRENCH ASSAIL SOVIET ON ETHNICITY
description: Georges Marchais, the French Communist leader, has denounced a Soviet book because it extends to the French nation the ethnic differences applied to the varied population of the Soviet Union.

title: A GAMBLE ON SUGAR IN HAWAII
description: Francis S. Morgan has become a hero in Hawaii. In January, with the state's sugar growers expressing fear about the health of their $423 million industry, Mr. Morgan bought Hamakua Sugar Company, the state's second-largest sugar plantation, from Theo H. Davies & Company for $69.6 million.

title: FROM CERAMICS TO SILK: SHOWS AROUND THE CITY
description: Decorated ceramic pieces, sculptured glass and weaving are a few of the items to be found around the city at craft exhibitions and sales this month.

title: Jackson Explains Remark About Jews
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that his remark about Jews going to concentration camps ''silently'' had been misunderstood.

title: Ex-Jail Guard Gets 9 Years for Bribery
description: A former guard at the Federal jail in Manhattan was sentenced to nine years in prison yesterday for accepting bribes to smuggle drugs and other contraband into the jail.

title: ALOHA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The 1983 results included a pre-tax gain of $19.6 million, reflecting a U.S. Supreme Court ruling for the reversal of tax interest expense for the years 1974 through the third quarter of 1983. The 1982 loss included a pre-tax gain of $6.5 million from the sale of tax benefits and a foreign currency loss of $770,000. The 1982 quarter included a $2.1 million pre-tax foreign currency loss. The latest share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend declared in December 1983.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $72,000 for the quarter and $323,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $3,564,000 from discontinued operations.

title: PRAIRIE PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Air Safety Agency Plans Major Inspection
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is getting ready to begin a three-week check of the nation's airlines to see whether they are following safety regulations.

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
5 in Tennis Hall
description: Pancho Segura, Neale Fraser, Manuel Santana and the doubles team of John Bromwich and Adrian Quist were named yesterday to the International Tennis Hall of Fame.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Advertising; The Birth Of Apple's Ad Insert
description: THE ad campaign for Apple Computer's new Macintosh model, especially the outstanding 20- page magazine insert, has received some high marks from some aficionados of the language. But more important, it has had a major impact on consumers, and a rush to buy is reported.

title: ROCKAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STANHOME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HBO TO PARODY THE OSCARS
description: The crew responsible for Home Box Office's acclaimed ''Not Necessarily the News'' comedy show is preparing its first special to premiere on March 17, a sendup of the upcoming Academy Awards.

title: KNICKS BEAT CELTICS WITH A LATE SURGE
description: Ray Williams gave the Knicks the lead for good at 99-98 tonight on a field goal with 45 seconds to play, and with 38 seconds to go he was credited with blocking the shot that protected the lead. Those two plays helped to provide a 102-98 victory over the Celtics before a capacity crowd of 14,990 at Boston Garden.

title: EXPERTS SEE POTENTIAL DANGER IN POWDERED DIET FORMULAS
description: Very-low- calorie diet formulas sold in supermarkets are dangerous and should be more closely regulated, nutrition experts warned today.

title: RESTRICTIONS ON SMOKING SPREADING ACROSS U.S.
description: Gone are the days when the Marlboro man, dragging on a cigarette and gazing into a limitless horizon, symbolized the don't-fence-me-in side of the mythic national character. Today smokers in America face a corral of laws and attitudes curbing the freedom to smoke.

title: Bid Made for RSR
description: The RSR Corporation said it had received a proposal to be acquired by a group of investors led by its chairman, Howard M. Meyers, for $9 a share. RSR, which is involved in recylcing lead material and making lubricants, said it will have an independent board committee and Bear, Stearns & Company review the proposal. In over- the-counter trading today, RSR was bid at $8.25, up $1.75 from Tuesday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John McEnroe , Ivan Lendl and Jimmy Connors , the top-ranked tennis players in the world, have entered the $500,000 Mercedes Tournament of Champions to be held at Forest Hills from May 6 to May 13, officials of the event announced. . . . Don Curry , the World Boxing Association's welterweight champion, has agreed to meet Nino La Rocca of Italy in a title bout in June, possibly in Monte Carlo, according to the fight's promoter, Rodolfo Sabbatini , who said the contracts would be signed later this month after La Rocca fights a 10- round bout against Felipe Canela in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Oil Quota Plea By Lagos Seen
description: Nigeria will formally request a

title: Lakeside Games
description: Some of the troops from Scott Lancaster Mills Atha, a Los Angeles ad agency, were in town for the Toy Fair, since they service Tyco Industries and Gund Inc., maker of stuffed toys.

title: DIRECTOR OF BELLEVUE IS DISMISSED AFTER INVESTIGATION OF TOP DEPUTY
description: The executive director of Bellevue Hospital Center was dismissed yesterday on the ground that she had misrepresented information about her top deputy when he was hired.

title: CATALOGUE FOR OLD BOOKS
description: A new catalogue of out-of-print books, part of an experiment to extend the commercial life of those volumes, is being mailed free this week to more than 1,000 libraries and 1,000 bookstores across the country. More than 450 authors are represented, including Stephen Birmingham, John D. MacDonald, Norman Podhoretz, Evan Hunter and the poet Donald Hall.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table of company earnings in Business Day on Monday included incorrect data for Combustion Engineering Inc., a machinery company. In the fourth quarter of 1983, the company had sales of $887,020,000, a decline of 3.5 percent from a year earlier. Net income fell 89.4 percent, to $5,614,000.

title: WEINBERGER FAULTS MARINE MISSION
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger visited the marines aboard ship today and told them that they had been given ''one of the most miserable jobs ever assigned.''

title: NOTE AND BOND PRICES CLIMB
description: Note and bond prices rose yesterday, but the gains were not large enough or sustained enough to indicate any significant improvement in investor demand, securities dealers said.

title: CONGRESS TO SEND TEAM TO STUDY UNESCO
description: The director general of Unesco has agreed to let the United States Congress send investigators to examine the workings of his organization, which the Reagan Administration has said it will leave at the end of the year unless major changes are made.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: COVERING a kitchen or bathroom counter with ceramic tile will give it a durable surface that is scrubbable and nearly impervious to scratching, staining and scorching. Most do-it- yourselfers can handle the project.

title: WEAK 'DOUBLE TALE OF WOE' ABOUT TAX COLLECTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: BEYOND A THRIVING CASINO RESORT, POVERTY AND A BITTER RECALL ELECTION
description: Politics takes some odd twists in this city of 40,000 people. Mayor Michael J. Matthews, who was elected to a four-year term 20 months ago, will be on the ballot again March 13 for a rare recall election. And the midwinter campaign activity has enlivened the streets of the troubled residential sections of the city. But it hardly compares to the frenzy in the Boardwalk casinos.

title: LEADING INDICATORS CLIMB 1.1%
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators, the gauge it uses to estimate economic activity six months to a year hence, rose 1.1 percent in January from the December level. It was the strongest gain since October and twice as big as the average monthly gain during the last half of 1983.

title: SOME PAINKILLERS MAY CAUSE DAMAGE
description: A panel of experts convened by the National Institutes of Health urged today that ''serious consideration'' be given to banning nonprescription use of painkillers that contain two or more active compounds.

title: DIASONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The losses for the latest quarter and year are after a pre-tax provision of $23,005,000 for discontinued product line. The 1982 results have been restated to reflect certain acquisitions which were made in 1983 and accounted for on a poolings-of-interest basis.

title: Jazz on TV Series Set
description: Beginning today, videotaped performances by noted jazz musicians will be shown weekly on Channel C of the Group W and Manhattan Cable television systems as part of the ''Expressions in Music'' series sponsored by Columbia Television, a student- run organization at Columbia University. Most of the programs, which will be broadcast at 9 P.M., have been taped at the studios of Columbia Television.

title:
GARDENING;
SHAPING TREES FOR APPEARANCE OR UTILITY
description: IN a typical suburban landscape

title: FRANCIS R. PEMBERTON
description: Francis Rawle Pemberton, a former partner in the Wall Street securities firm of Noel, Berman & Langley and a flier in both world wars, died Monday at New York Hospital.

title: Colts' Fate Pending
description: Robert Irsay , the owner of the Colts, has told Mayor Donald Schaefer of Baltimore that he is continuing his efforts to move the National Football League team to another city but that he could still be persuaded to keep the team in Baltimore.

title: Condec Settlement
description: The Condec Corporation said it had settled its arbitration and litigation proceedings with Kaiser Aluminum and Chemicals Inc. and, as a result, will report a $23.3 million gain for its second quarter, ended Jan. 31.

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
description: b-Net loss.

title: PENNEY ACHIEVES 28.1% GAIN
description: The J. C. Penney Company reported yesterday that earnings in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Jan. 28, rose 28.1 percent while sales increased 10.6 percent.

title: Tonight's Schedule
description: 6 O'Clock - Barbara Potter

title: NETS TOP LAKERS BY 102-92
description: In perhaps their finest defensive display of the season, the Nets trapped and harassed the powerful Los Angeles Lakers tonight into a season-high of 33 turnovers and posted their fourth straight victory, 102-92.

title: TRUDEAU: ONE CANADIAN OF UN-CANADIAN TRAITS
description: In a country where modesty and conservative behavior have been paramount virtues, Pierre Elliott Trudeau has been publicly flamboyant, wearing rakish hats to international conferences, dating movie stars, offering impromptu citations of Racine or Lao-tze and going off to discoth eques. But in his commitment to compromise and his faith in reason he has been quintessentially Canadian, dedicated to domestic and international policies that stress reasoned discourse and conciliation.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FLIGHT FROM SORROW. The Life and Death of Tamara Wall. By Felicity Barringer. 280 pages. Illustrated. Atheneum. $15.95.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SPACE-SAVING SINKS
description: WHEN small kitchens are being remodeled to make them more efficient, a space-saving sink can add room. Some small sinks have optional insert baskets, drainers and chopping boards that fit over the sink to double as counter space.

title: 26TH ANNUAL GRAMMYS
description: IT was certainly the musical

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS: TASKS FACING TAYLOR
description: There is no quick or simple solution to the serious predicament faced by the Continental Illinois Corporation and its flagship bank, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust.

title: FOR 2D STRAIGHT YEAR, CITY SHOWS A DROP IN REPORTS OF MAJOR CRIME
description: Reports of major crime in New York City fell 9 percent last year, with almost every police precinct registering declines, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Helter-Skelter on 57th St.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS ; AIRING UNESCO'S CLOSETS
description: Unesco's wily Director General, Amadou Mahtar M'Bow, has agreed to let the United States Congress investigate his woefully mismanaged, boondoggling organization.

title: No Headline
description: Judge Sees Query Need In Debate Papers Case

title:
PLAYERS;
SON FOLLOWS FATHER TO PITCHING MOUND
description: He has the size of a catcher, a 6-foot, 205-pound frame that was developed after many early morning hours in a weight room at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas. Long before he arrived at college two Septembers ago, he had already possessed both the disposition and the inclination to catch. He had once been a very successful pitcher on an American Legion team, but that was not for him. He was going to be a catcher.

title: FABERGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $197,855 for the quarter and $249,731 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,720,910. The 1983 year net also includes a charge of $884,000, or 16 cents a share, after taxes, in connection with the cancellation of an executive officer's contract and a loss of $3,720,910, after taxes, relating to the discontinued Tip Top operations. The 1982 net income included losses from devaluation of the Mexican peso totaling $1.7 million, or 30 cents a share, after taxes, and a provision for plant closing and relocation costs of $870,000, or 15 cents a share, after taxes, which occurred in the fourth quarter.

title: Swift Replacement
description: Connie Swift , the undefeated California lightweight champion, will replace the injured Gene Hatcher as the opponent for Howard Davis Jr . in a nationally televised fight Saturday from Atlantic City.

title: U.S.-SAUDI DISPUTE ON LEBANON CITED
description: The United States said today that it would not alter its opposition to scrapping of the Israeli-Lebanese agreement of May 1983 despite a new plea from Saudi Arabia that the Americans endorse the apparent decision of President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon to yield to Syria and cancel the accord.

title: Arafat Wants U.N. Council To Resolve Palestinian Issue
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, was quoted today as having proposed that the United Nations Security Council try to solve the Palestinian problem.

title: Home
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: CRAFTS CLASSES: DECORATIVE FINISHES
description: For those wishing to learn the techniques used in applying decorative finishes, there are several craft classes that will begin this month.

title: WRITER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POLLS OUTLINE BASES OF HART'S VICTORY
description: Senator Gary Hart put together his surprising upset in New Hampshire Tuesday by working on an electorate that a New York Times/CBS News Poll showed to be younger, better educated, better off, more liberal, more white, more critical of President Reagan and more politically independent than likely Democratic primary voters elsewhere in the nation.

title: ; U.S. EMBASSIES ARE NOT U.S. TERRITORY
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I wish to inform you of my decision to resign from the leadership of the Liberal Party.

title: Pinpoint the Export Controls
description: The cold warrior and the free-marketeer in Ronald Reagan collide head on in the matter of strategic exports to the Soviet Union. One part of the President wants to avoid helping an adversary. The other wants American industry freed of regulation. Neither absolute makes good policy.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: WEST SIDE RAIL LINE
description: The Fight to Save Manhattan's Forgotten Railroad , Municipal Art

title: IRAN CALLS U.S. SHIPS IN GULF AN ACT OF AGGRESSION
description: Iran said today that the United States military presence in the Persian Gulf was ''an act of aggression and blackmail.'' It said the United States would have to take responsibility for any incident in the area.

title: Envoy to Grenada Named
description: Loren E. Lawrence has been appointed head of the American diplomatic mission in Grenada, the State Department announced today. He will replace Charles A. Gillespie as charge d'affaires. Mr. Gllespie will become Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Latin America.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
THE AGE OF LEANER INVENTORY
description: If the customary rhythms of the business cycle held sway today, manufacturers and retailers would be ordering more materials than they need just yet and turning out more widgets than they can sell right away. Inventory building, a stage of economic recovery that usually follows closely behind revived consumer spending, would be rolling into high gear.

title: For Day Care
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: HOME BEAT
description: ALBERT PENSIS, above left, Iris Karp and Alan Stolz felt that it was time for them to put together an array of antique reproductions - English and French tables, chairs and cabinets in styles that include Regency and Sheraton, Hepplewhite and Queen Anne, Louis XV and XVI - and a sprinkling of Empire. The finely detailed pieces, available through designers, include, clockwise from lower left: a marble urn, $775 list, atop a Biedermeier pedestal, $1,920 list; a 19th- century mahogany desk, $2,615; a Regency side chair, $1,045; below, a Queen Anne chest, $7,870 list. The concern, KPS, is at 200 Lexington Avenue (32d Street).

title: REAGAN'S HOUSING SECRETARY ASSAILS RACIAL QUOTAS
description: The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., today sharply denounced racial quotas, saying that those who demanded such a remedy ''demean those they are purported to help.''

title: KITCHEN HELP FOR ELDERLY AND DISABLED
description: AWKWARD kitchen layouts and disorganized storage systems are problems for any cook, but they can be serious obstacles for the older or the disabled person. If poor work habits are involved as well, food preparation becomes an ordeal.

title: DRANETZ TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The 1982 share earnings figure was restated to give retroactive effect to 50 percent stock dividend paid in March 1983 and 50 percent stock dividend paid in October 1983.

title: Korea Venture for G.E.
description: The General Electric Company has agreed to set up a $9 million joint venture in South Korea with the Samsung Group to produce and market sophisticated medical instruments such as diagnostic imaging, X-ray and ultra- sound systems, Samsung said today.

title: Soviet Maritime Zone Of 200 Miles Defined
description: The Soviet Union today announced the establishment of an offshore economic zone of 200 nautical miles with sovereign rights to all mineral and maritime resources. A decree said the measure would take effect Thursday.

title: Military Contracts
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won two Navy contracts worth a total of $1.14 billion, the Defense Department said today.

title: REICHHOLD LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,004,000 from discontinued operations and a special gan of $237,000. c-Net loss including income from discontinued operations of $298,000.

title: LOUD SPEECHES AND QUIET ACTIONS ON ARMS
description: Now that Congress has begun work on President Reagan's proposed $305 billion military budget for the next fiscal year, Capitol Hill rings with declarations that the arms bill must be cut by $10 billion or $20 billion or more.

title: Eastern Cuts Loss in Month
description: Eastern Airlines Inc. said today that it had a net loss of

title: MRS. LLOYD SURVIVES OPENER
description: Chris Evert Lloyd survived a scare from Kathy Jordan last night at the Virginia Slims championships on a day when three other seeded players fell in first-round action.

title: SOVIET VETO BARS A U.N. PEACE FORCE TO SERVE IN BEIRUT
description: The Soviet Union vetoed a French proposal in the Security Council today that would have sent an international peacekeeping force to Beirut.

title: LEBANESE AND SYRIAN PRESIDENTS CONFER
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon arrived here today and conferred with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria over the fate of Lebanon.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: RATHER than following ''Sophie's Choice'' with another literary adaptation, Alan Pakula will return to the ''Klute'' genre in his next film, ''Dream Lover.'' ''It's a melodrama in the way 'Klute' was, in that it's another attempt to combine melodrama with character study,'' Mr. Pakula said by telephone from London, where he is choosing locations for the new film. Shooting will begin there next month, and most of the drama will be set in England, though Mr. Pakula will also film several weeks' worth of material in New York in June.

title: 2 Held in Firebombing Of Jesse Jackson Office
description: Two youths accused of taking a $15 dare have been arrested in the firebombing of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign office here, the police said today.

title: Columbia Crafts Fair
description: There will be a crafts fair the next two weekends in Ferris Booth Hall at Columbia University, Broadway and 115th Street.

title: Esmark Up Sharply In Quarter
description: Esmark Inc., citing the positive impact of its acquisiton of Norton Simon Inc., reported yesterday that net income in its first fiscal quarter of 1984 nearly tripled, as sales soared 81.4 percent.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: After seven consecutive weeks of large increases, money fund assets declined nationwide in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Market Place
description: Magellan Fund And Its Record

title: Ecuador's Army Guards Oilfields in Strike
description: Ecuador has sent troops to protect oilfields and pipelines in its eastern jungle after a strike raised fears of sabotage, oil industry and military sources said today.

title: FORDHAM AND IONA ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: Jerry Hobbie, who blamed himself for his team's 1-point loss to LaSalle last month, hit a 23-foot jump shot with 2 seconds remaining to give the Rams a 62-60 upset victory over the Explorers tonight and a place in the final of the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: NUCLEAR POWER NEEDS A REFINANCING AGENCY
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLISHING: ART OF CREATING DEMAND
description: A COUPLE of years ago, Jack Dreyfus, a wealthy businessman, spent about $2 million of his own money publicizing his book, ''A Remarkable Medicine Has Been Overlooked.'' But even that sum, much of it spent on full-page ads in newspapers and magazines, did not prevent tens of thousands of unsold copies from ending in the publisher's warehouse.

title: MOSCOW IS SAID TO TIGHTEN CURBS ON RELIGION
description: The Rev. Michael Bourdeaux, a specialist on religion in Communist countries, said Wednesday in New York that there had been ''an absolute decline in degree to which religious liberty is permitted'' in the Soviet Union.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES Radice's Offering Postponed
description: The Radice Corporation, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., real estate developer, said yesterday that it had postponed an offering of at least 500,000 shares of common stock because of market conditions, but proceeded with an offering of sinking fund debentures.

title: SEA GALLEY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,652,000 for the quarter and $7,654,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $1,015,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $40,000 from the effect of an accounting change. d-After a loss of $1,307,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $432,000 from the effect of an accounting change. Year-ago results are for the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, 1982.

title: HOWLAND SARGEANT, STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL FROM 1947 TO 1953
description: Howland Hill Sargeant, a former Assistant Secretary of State, died in his sleep Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: ARCO NEARS EXPECTED BID FOR GULF
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank and 70 other lenders putting together a loan package of as much as $12 billion for the Atlantic Richfield Company are expected to have it ready by today, banking officials said yesterday.

title: FIRST AMERICAN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. AIMS IN THE IRAQ-IRAN MESS
description: The real war in the Middle East, where the stakes are very high, is still the 40-month-old Iran-Iraq war. The very length of the war - and its inconclusiveness - has dulled our senses to its real potential for disaster.

title: Tennis Challenge For Garden Crew
description: The best-of-five set final Sunday at the Virginia Slims championships could be more of a test for the Madison Square Garden maintenance crew than for the contestants. With a consolation singles match at noon, the longer-than-usual final to follow, and a Ranger game at 8:30 P.M., an expanded crew of 80 workers will have to convert the arena from tennis to hockey in far fewer than the normal four or four and a half hours.

title: People
description: * Lee Pratt named executive vice president of Ohlmeyer Advertising.

title: Beneficial Issue
description: A $75 million issue of Beneficial Corporation 12.6 percent notes due in 1994 are offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The yield on the notes, rated A-3/A, was 56 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Youngman in Queens
description: A night of comedy with Henny Youngman is planned tomorrow at 9 P.M. in the Student Union Ballroom at Queens College, Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard.

title: 'FEN' WITH AN AMERICAN CAST
description: Actors commonly enter into other people's lives. But can the bleak, inbred world of the farm laborers of the Fens, a swampy area north of London, be recreated by American actors, as it will be for the first time when ''Fen'' reopens at the Public Theater on Sunday with an American cast?

title: AVANTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LUMEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 results were restated to include the loss from operations of Eagle Performance Systems acquired in April 1983.

title: School Van Crash On L.I. Injures 4
description: A school van collided with a car at an intersection today, skidded into another auto, struck a third car and then overturned, injuring three high school students and the van's driver, the police said.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES CURBS ON AID TO SALVADOR
description: A House subcommittee, saying it wanted to ''send a message'' about human rights to the Reagan Administration and governments in Central America, voted major restrictions today on military and economic aid for El Salvador.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Danske Olie & Naturgas, as Denmark's oil and gas company, said it was issuing $100 million of 15-year floating-rate notes through Goldman Sachs International Corp. The notes, guaranteed by Denmark, mature in April 1999 and offer interest fixed monthly, paid quarterly, at 1/8 percentage point above the London interbank offered rate for 3-month dollar deposits subject to a 5 1/4 percent minimum rate.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Apple Computer Inc. , Cupertino, Calif., and Businessland Inc. announced an agreement under which Businessland will sell the Apple 32 Supermicro product line. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Amdahl Models
description: The Amdahl Corporation said it is introducing two models in its 580 series of large-scale processors and said it is reducing prices on selected 580 models by 3 percent to 14 percent. However, the computer company is raising lease prices on some 580 models. In addition, the company expanded the capacities of most 580 models.

title: Kill That Convention
description: A creeping campaign to petition Congress for a convention to amend the Constitution is nearing its goal. The amendment would demand a balanced Federal budget every year. Petitions from 32 states are on file in Washington. Two more could trigger a procedure of mischievous potential. New York's Senate may vote next week to approve a petition. California has put the issue on its November ballot. Legislatures in Kentucky, Michigan, West Virginia and Vermont are also under pressure to vote.

title: Japanese Jetliner Deal
description: Japan's All Nippon Airways said today that it had sold six of its 17 Lockheed L-1011 Tristars to the Boeing Company, for $8.6 million each, and would lease them back for 15 months.

title: AUCTIONS
description: AN extremely rare, painted terra-cotta relief of the Virgin and Child by Donatello will be auctioned at 2 P.M. today at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street, and may bring more than $1 million. The work has been out of public view for decades. Dating from the mid-15th century, it is modeled in half-relief and depicts a noble Mary with bittersweet expression, her eyes lowered in thought, her aristocratic hands holding a swaddled child with a compelling gaze, puffy cheeks and protruding lower lip.

title: 'BUGS' THAT MAKE CHEMICALS
description: Imagine masses of tiny creatures that not only consume wastes, thus eliminating disposal and pollution problems, but excrete commercially valuable products as well. In effect, living chemical factories.

title: Two Sides of a Staff
description: President Reagan's staff, according to current White House cartography, is divided between ''pragmatists'' led by James A. Baker 3d, the chief of staff, and ''movement conservatives,'' who will lose their top leader if Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, is confirmed as Attorney General by the Senate. In this context, either faction is relieved when a leading member refuses to accept a job offer that would require leaving the White House.

title: EX-BOSTON AIDE SAYS HE SET UP POLITICAL GIFTS
description: A former city official says he arranged regular meetings in a hotel room between contractors and Mayor Kevin H. White to collect political contributions.

title: REVUEW: SECOND CITY COMES TO FIRST CITY
description: ''ORWELL THAT ENDS WELL'' is the latest - and 65th - revue to be mounted by Chicago's fabled Second City Company. It's a pleasure to report that this improvisational comedy troupe, which is now visiting the Village Gate, has lost none of its spunk. ''Orwell'' is an uneven but jolly little show that delivers a few belly laughs, a lot of chuckles and, at times, the rude social satire that has all but vanished from the American stage.

title: PRESIDENT'S CAMPAIGN ON DISCIPLINE: 3 EDUCATORS REFLECT
description: In recent speeches, President Reagan has announced a campaign against ''unruly behavior'' in schools. And he has said that improving discipline and reducing school violence will be a key issue during the Presidential election.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Better Than in Vienna'

title: SOUTH ARICA FREES NAMIBIAN NATIONALIST AFTER 16 YEARS' DETENTION
description: South Africa released a prominent black nationalist today after almost 16 years in detention.

title: Mason 9-1 Victor In N.H.L. Debut
description: Bob Mason, a member of the United States hockey team in the Winter Olympics last month, made a sparkling debut in the National Hockey League tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 2, 1984

title: Stepping Up
description: Isabelle Carmichael , a 34-year-old New York bank executive, clambered the 1,575 steps to the 86th floor of the Empire State Building yesterday in 13 minutes 32 seconds, finishing ahead of eight other women in the annual ''Run Up'' at the Manhattan skyscraper.

title: 'JAZZ AMERICA'S FESTIVAL, WINTER HOT SPOT IN BRONX
description: -weather answer to New York's summertime Kool Jazz Festival is taking shape in the Bronx. After a trial run of three days in January last year, the ''Jazz America'' festival at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts is now in its second season, continuing through Sunday.

title: Police Promote 'One-Man' Force
description: A 36-year-old detective, Ronald Peragine, who has made 1,000 arrests in 15 years, was among 94 uniformed and civilian members of the Police Department who were promoted yesterday. Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward described Mr. Peragine as ''a one-man Police Department.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Guarnerius Rescued

title: Jazz Coalition
description: The tenor saxophonist Billy Harper will lead a quartet tonight at the Universal Jazz Coalition's Jazz Center of New York (924-5026), 380 Lafayette Street, at Great Jones (East Third) Street. Tickets are $5; $4 for students and the elderly.

title: WILSON, H.J., CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $3,107,000 for the quarter and $6,015,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: 38 Are Arrested In Drug Raids
description: Thirty-eight people were arrested today on drug and weapons charges, and large amounts of marijuana, cocaine and LSD were confiscated in what the police called the largest drug raids ever conducted in Fulton County.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CAESAR' IN WASHINGTON

title: SUZANNE PLESHETTE, ACE REPORTER
description: AFTER six years of starring as the beautiful wife on ''The Bob Newhart Show,'' and after a string of made-for- television movies (in one she played a lusty madam giving up her prostitutes for salvation with a group of adorable nuns), Suzanne Pleshette is finally being given a situation comedy of her own. ''Maggie Briggs'' or, as the official billing would have it, ''Suzanne Pleshette Is Maggie Briggs,'' makes its debut on Channel 2 on Sunday at 8 P.M.

title: Time Inc. Names 3 To Executive Posts
description: Time Inc. announced yesterday the promotion of Gerald M. Levin, Nicholas J. Nicholas Jr. and Kelso Sutton to executive vice presidents. The title was last held by Clifford J. Grum, who left to become head of Temple- Inland Inc. when Time spun off the forest products operation to its shareholders in January.

title: IOWA SOUTHERN UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WATCH YOUR STEP; MCLITTER
description: Princeton students welcomed the news that Nassau Street is getting a Burger King this spring: it will offer a change from the campus dining hall. Local businessmen were happy too: they think the fast-food restaurant will give the town more of a middle-class image.

title: Fed Will Accept Florida Bank Plan
description: The Federal Reserve Board said it would not challenge a revised agreement under which the Florida National Banks of Florida would be acquired by the Chemical New York Corporation, the banking companies said. The merger could not be achieved, however, until such interstate acquisitions are allowed by law.

title: A DEAF PERSON'S RIGHT TO SERVE AS A JUROR
description: To the Editor:

title: FORMER LEGAL ADVISER TO SOLIDARITY FACING A TRIAL
description: A criminal case was started today against a onetime legal adviser to the Solidarity union who had written an open letter to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski that criticized the treatment of a fellow lawyer.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
ART: BRYSON BURROUGHS, WORK INSPIRED BY MYTH
description: BORN in 1869, Bryson Burroughs lived 65 years, working for the last 28 of them at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. There, he began as assistant to Roger Fry and, when the British scholar and critic left in 1909, assumed his position as curator of paintings, doing much to further the museum's collection. Calvin Tomkins, in his ''Merchants and Princes,'' reports that Burroughs's coups included the first Cezanne to enter a public collection, ''La Colline des Pauvres,'' Bruegel's ''Harvesters'' and Van Eyck's ''Crucifixion and Last Judgment.'' The curator didn't neglect native talent either, organizing shows by Albert Pinkham Ryder and Thomas Eakins, as well as buying their works.

title: ART: TRACING THE FLOWER IN AMERICAN PAINTING
description: FLOWERS, those ethereal yet earthly symbols of fertility and hope, are one of art's most abiding cliches. Even the most austere and intellectual of painters have found it hard to resist the challenge of capturing on canvas their delicate charms. Yet, though they blossom profusely throughout art history, their easy appeal and lack of dialectical provocation (after all, as Gertrude Stein said, ''a rose is a rose is a rose'') gave flower painting lowly status in the past. The 18th- century English artist Sir Joshua Reynolds, for example, dismissed it as no more than a training exercise for neophytes. Even today, some die- hards think that flowers are too decorative for art and should stay where they belong, in gardens.

title: Sports of The Times; The Lure of the Pros
description: When college football coaches recruit a high-school player, they must think he's smart enough to appreciate their point of view, otherwise why bother.

title: ZYMOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KILLING THE PAROLE SOLVES NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: EARTHLY FOLLY IN SPACE
description: Last Jan. 21, the U.S. Air Force successfully tested the two-stage rocketry of a new anti-satellite weapon (ASAT). That signaled, said the Union of Concerned Scientists, ''a United States commitment to a dangerous new phase of the arms race which, if continued, could only decrease U.S. security.''

title: THE HIT CHEMISTRIES OF NEW EDITION AND SHANNON
description: particularly in the volatile zone of dance music, where a singer can be unknown one week and have a massively popular record the next. But in one respect, the music business hasn't changed since the days when sheet-music publishers hired song pluggers to get their tunes heard. Then, as now, songwriters looked for singers who looked for songs, trying to find the unpredictable chemistry that makes a hit.

title: Workers Rejects Cuts; Steel Plant to Close
description: Union employees of the United States Steel Corporation's Johnstown fabricating plant today rejected proposed contract concessions, killing any hope of survival for the century-old facility.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MANUFACTURED HOMES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HASH WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: ONCE upon a time, hash was something to anticipate with glee. It was made with a sharp knife and some leftover corned beef, ham or turkey, fresh vegetables and lots of spices. Individual patties were slapped on a hot griddle and cooked until crispy. Served with a pair of sunny sides up, it made a memorable breakfast. Today, the so-called hash served in most restaurants is a gloppy mass from a can with a striking resemblance to canine fare.

title: EL TORITO RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FILM: ' THIS IS SPINAL TAP,' A MOCK DOCUMENTARY
description: ''THEY are treading water in a sea of retarded sexuality and bad poetry,'' says one fictitious rock critic of the equally fictitious Spinal Tap, a British heavy-metal band. ''That's just nit picking, isn't it?'' is one band member's calm rejoinder, but he's wrong. Spinal Tap

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA, MISS POTTER GAIN
description: Five years ago, Barbara Potter deferred admission to Princeton University to discover what she could learn in professional tennis. Now she says she has learned two important things: One is to enjoy playing tennis. The other is to watch Martina Navratilova.

title: HOUSE VOTES $8 BILLION FOR RURAL ELECTRIC AGENCY
description: The House today overwhelmingly approved an $8 billion measure designed to assure the solvency of the Rural Electrification Administration, a New Deal agency that lends money at subsidized interest rates to rural electric power cooperatives.

title: Kentucky Triumphs by 76-57
description: Sam Bowie scored 20 points to equal his season high and had 19 rebounds as Kentucky defeated Mississippi, 76-57, in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.

title: THREE GENERATIONS ADJUST TO FRANCO'S SPAIN
description: MANUEL GUTIERREZ ARAGON'S ''Demons in the Garden'' (''Demonios en el Jardin''), a 1982 Spanish film that has won awards at European festivals, is not very long (100 minutes), but it has the generous scope of a large novel, being about three generations of a small- town family in the years immediately after the Spanish Civil War.

title: IMMIGRATION REFORM TOO TOUGH ON REFUGEES
description: To the Editor:

title: 'DEVIL' TO FACE STRONGEST ADVERSARY
description: More than 35,000 thoroughbred horses were foaled in 1981, the best of them destined to run in the 1984 Kentucky Derby. That race is still 65 days off, but already two horses, Devil's Bag and Dr. Carter, have asserted themselves as the best of their crop. Either would tower over his generation if the other weren't around. Instead, they are headed for a showdown here Saturday in the $365,000 Flamingo Stakes.

title: TALKS ON LEBANON END IN DAMASCUS
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon conferred today for nearly four hours with Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, on the fate of Lebanon. The Syrian Government described the talks as ''positive and fruitful.''

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS
description: Cocoa Futures Soar; Grains, Soybeans Up

title: London Delay For Citibank
description: Citibank and the Standard Chartered Bank have agreed to defer temporarily their applications to become members of the Bankers Clearing House until it can review its procedures, the clearing house said today.

title: No Headline
description: John Fales Dies at 72; Scientist and Inventor

description: b-After a gain of $59.6 million from discontinued operations. c-After a $67.1 million gain from discontinued operations and a $4.9 million extraordinary gain. The share earnings are after preferred dividends.

description: Educators at a national conference here on independent schools were urged yesterday to oppose tuition tax credits and government attempts to control hiring and curriculum.

THE FREE-FOR-ALL ON THE BANKRUPTCY EXPRESS

title: WARWICK INSURANCE MANGERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SENATE VOTES MORE EXPORT POWERS
description: The Senate by a voice vote tonight approved a bill giving the President greater authority to halt exports of sensitive products and technology to the Soviet Union and other countries found to be undermining American national security or foreign policy goals.

title: Deere in Mexico
description: Deere & Company said its Mexican affiliate had acquired a dormant tractor factory in Saltillo, Mexico, from the International Harvester Company. Terms were not disclosed. Deere said John Deere S.A., its Mexican affiliate, would begin operations at the Saltillo factory ''at a pace commensurate with increased economic activity in Mexico.''

title: WELLS-GARDNER ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Irate Padres
description: When George Steinbrenner was saying the other day that he had no intention of trading Graig Nettles, he brought up the San Diego Padres, Nettles's hometown team. ''I would be surprised,'' Steinbrenner said, ''if San Diego and Graig haven't had some conversations.''

title: C.B.A. Players Eligible
description: Players in the Continental Basketball Association, a minor league, will be given consideration for the United States Olympic basketball trials because of the ''great uncertainty'' of Olympic eligibility rules, according to Bill Wall , executive director of the Amateur Basketball Association- United States of America. ''The implications of the International Olympic Committee's action will have a significant effect on the sport of basketball,'' Wall said, citing the I.O.C. ruling last month at the Olympic Winter Games that made five hockey players ineligible because they had played in the National Hockey League. Players who had signed N.H.L. contracts but never played in the league and players who played in the minor professional leagues were not affected by the ruling.

title: SILENT MEDIATION TIME BANNED AT SCHOOL ON L.I.
description: For the first time in 22 years, students at Hicksville Junior High School were not asked to observe 30 seconds of silent meditation at the start of classes today.

title: TECH-SYM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to account for the acquisition of Tecom Industries in November 1983 under the pooling-of-interests method.

title: Chrysler Financial Files Note Sale
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $200 million of senior notes due in 1991 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes would be nonrefundable for five years.

description: A 39-year-old man who officials say was about to be removed from his Brooklyn teaching job was charged yesterday with killing a young woman by shoving her into the path of a subway train.

description: A Newark man pleaded guilty today to supervising a statewide narcotics network that authorities said disguised its operations behind a bogus charity for the handicapped.
