description: b-Net income including extraordinary credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $73,000 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $40,000.

title: Fraser to Leave Board
description: Douglas A. Fraser, the first labor leader to hold a seat on the board of directors of a major American corporation, said today that he would step down as a director of the Chrysler Corporation at the end of his term in June.

title: Chile's 3 Main Cities Are Rocked by Bombs
description: A total of 16 bombs exploded in Chile's three main cities overnight, wounding three people and damaging electricity facilities, police sources said today.

title: Hart Beats PresidentIn Write-In Percentage
description: President Reagan received a smaller percentage of write-in votes in New Hampshire's Democratic primary than Senator Gary Hart of Colorado, the winner of the Democratic primary, received from Republicans, Mr. Reagan's write- in total, however, was higher,

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE VOTES $49 BILLION OF TAX INCREASES
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today approved $49.3 billion in tax increases over the next four years, including additional revenues from liquor, cigarettes and telephones.

title: GOLDEN SAYS CITY 'SABOTAGED' PROPOSED PROJECT IN BROOKLYN
description: The Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, attacked the Koch administration yesterday for removing a real-estate company as developer of a key Brooklyn development project.

title: WIFE OF REPUTED AQUINO KILLER REPORTED MISSING
description: The son and the stepdaughter of the Filipino who is said to have killed the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. last summer testified today before an inquiry commission that their mother was taken away a month ago by armed men.

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BUILDING SPENDING RISES 1.4%
description: Spending for new construction rose 1.4 percent in January from December, with advances in the housing industry and revived industrial development offsetting a small decline in Government building projects, the Commerce Department said today.

title: SIPE HAS KNEE SURGERY AND WILL MISS 3 WEEKS
description: Brian Sipe, the starting quarterback for the New Jersey Generals, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee today to remove torn cartilage and will be lost to the team for a minimum of three weeks. Gene Bradley will be Sipe's replacement and will start his first game Sunday in Jacksonville against the Bulls.

title: AIR FORCE WHISTLE-BLOWER TESTIMONY BALKED
description: Pentagon officials prevented the military's best known whistle-blower from testifying in Congress today. But his report, saying the Defense Department's chief auditing agency and an Under Secretary had thwarted efforts to uncover unreasonable charges, was made public by the committee anyway.

title: THERE'S NOTHING BASHFUL ABOUT A FEB. 29
description: ''Hey, it's leap day - I can ask you to marry me,'' said Patricia Booton to James J. Sullivan. She was wearing a frilly white dress and holding a bouquet of roses and baby's breath. ''Hey, you already did,'' Mr. Sullivan reminded her. He was wearing work boots, blue jeans, a T-shirt and a carnation on his vest.

title: Utility in Indiana
description: A settlement in an emergency rate case will mean higher monthly bills for customers of the Public Service Company of Indiana, but not as high as initially requested by the owner of the abandoned Marble Hill nuclear plant.

title: POLORON PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $5,536,000. c-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $461,000.

title: SOLUTION HINTED IN GERMAN STANDOFF
description: The niece of East Germany's Prime Minister and her family left the West German Embassy in Prague today and returned home, officials said. The officials said the five did so on the understanding that they would eventually be allowed to emigrate to the West.

title: U.S.I.A. ASKS ADVICE ON DESTROYED LIST
description: Charles Z. Wick, director of the United States Information Agency, said today that he had asked the Justice Department to determine whether his agency's general counsel acted improperly when he destroyed lists of speakers considered too much at odds with Reagan Administration policy to represent the United States abroad.

title: SCREEN: CORPORATE PRESSURE
description: IF George Orwell were alive,

title: FEDERAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. WON'T BAN USE OF EDB ON FRUIT, BUT WILL SET LIMIT
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will announce maximum safe levels for the pesticide ethylene dibromide in fruit similar to those set for grain products last month, agency officials said today.

title: FRANCE DECLARES IT CANNOT STAY IN BEIRUT BY ITSELF
description: The Foreign Ministry said today that France ''cannot alone bear the responsibility of the international community in Lebanon.''

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
White Sox Sign 3
description: The White Sox signed three players yesterday who were essential to Chicago in winning the Western Division title in the American League last year, but none came cheap. One was the league's Cy Young Award winner, LaMarr Hoyt , who won 24 games and received a six-year deal reported to be worth a little over a million dollars a year.

title: UNITED CANSO OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Boston, Philadelphia, Pacific, Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: VEGA BIOTECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
POLICY TO CHANGE ON OCEAN DUMPING
description: The Environmental Protection Agency indicated today that it would seek to bar New York City and other municipalities from dumping sewage sludge 12 miles off the New Jersey coast.

title: Death Squad in El Salvador Threatens to Kill Journalists
description: A right-wing death squad threatened today to kill journalists who ''collaborate'' with leftist Salvadoran guerrillas.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're in for a long, tough fight that could well go to the convention.'' - Walter F. Mondale. (A1:2.)

title: G.M. in Pact With Daewoo
description: F. James McDonald, president of the General Motors Corporation, said today that G.M. and the Daewoo Motor Company had agreed to build a new small car in South Korea that could eventually be exported to the United States.

title: Convict Is Guilty In a Drug Case
description: A 60-year-old man serving a 25-year sentence for being a wholesale heroin supplier was convicted in Manhattan yesterday of attempting to arrange heroin deals from prison.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, has named Henry H. Weitz president of its Desks and Furnishings Inc. subsidiary.

title: TACTIC BY BELZBERGS BACKFIRES
description: The bitter fight for the Gulf Oil Corporation has backfired for one group of the oil company's pursuers, the wealthy Belzberg brothers of Canada.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $3.1 million for the quarter and $3.5 million for the 9 months.

title: CONCERT: SCHNABEL PIANO DUO
description: FOR keyboard duos, the choice is clear: there is music for two pianos, and music for one piano, four hands. At the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night, the Piano Duo Schnabel offered an attractive program made up of selections for one piano, four hands.

title: CONCERT: SECOND VIENNA PROGRAM
description: LAST night's second concert of the Vienna Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall started off like the first on Wednesday, but at an even higher level of achievement. All the virtues of the first concert were in evidence during Mozart's Symphony No. 40 in G minor (K. 550), but the playing was even more exquisite. Leonard Bernstein shaped the first three movements in the full- bodied yet gracious manner that seems to accord with Viennese tradition. And then, in the finale, he upped the energy, just as he had on Wednesday in Haydn's Symphony No. 88 and Beethoven's ''Eroica.''

title: Ash-LeDonne-Fisher Picks Up 3 Accounts
description: Ash-LeDonne-Fisher, whose clients already range from the Broadway play ''La Cage aux Folles'' to First Jersey Securities, an investment concern, said yesterday that it was chosen as the agency for three new accounts: The Sands Hotel in Atlantic City, Garden State Park Race Track in Cherry Hill, N.J., and the Keystone Race Track in Pennsylvania.

title: LUMONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split last December.

title: DON U. BRIDGE
description: Don U. Bridge, a former general manager of the Gannett Rochester Newspapers, died in his home in Lakeland, Fla., today after a long illness.

title: 2 MEN CHARGED IN A PLOT TO SHIP ARMS TO POLAND
description: Customs officials in New York said yesterday that they had arrested two businessmen and seized 500 rifles, 100,000 rounds of ammunition and a cache of paramilitary police equipment that were to have been shipped illegally to the Polish Government in Warsaw.

title: Reagan Sets New York Trip
description: President Reagan will travel to Columbus, Ohio, to address the National Association of Evangelicals on Tuesday and attend a Republican fund-raising reception in New York City the same day. In announcing the trip today, Larry Speakes, the President's spokesman, said the Ohio visit was considered official, meaning that it would be at the expense of taxpayers. The New York stop will be financed by the Republican National Committee, Mr. Speakes said. Mr. Reagan will be accompanied by his wife, Nancy.

title: Impostor Professor Is Sentenced to Jail
description: Paul Crafton, who has been accused of impersonating a professor at two central Pennsylvania colleges, was sentenced Wednesday to three to nine months in jail.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DEMOCRATS' WRONG STRATEGY
description: The latest national polls put President Reagan about 12 points ahead of Walter F. Mondale - still the strongest Democratic contender - suggesting that the Democrats had better start planning some fairly radical changes in their strategy or face humiliating defeat in November.

title: Wind Tunnel
description: The wind gusted to 40 miles an hour and then would settle back to its steady 30 miles an hour all day Wednesday during the pro-am preview to the Honda Classic on the new Tournament Players Club course at Eagle Trace, Coral Springs, Fla. The holes into the wind were severe, such as the 470-yard par-4 18th where some of the world's finest golfers could not reach the green with a driver tee shot followed by a driver fairway shot.

title: STOCK PRICES RISE MODERATELY IN SLOWER TRADING
description: Stock prices finished moderately higher yesterday in slower trading, with merger candidates and stocks responding to specific news developments making the biggest moves.

title: EVEREST & JENNINGS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-Includes unrealized currency translation loss from foreign operations of $94,000. c-Includes unrealized currency translation loss from foreign operations of $232,000.

title: CANADIAN GENERAL ELECTRIC CO LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MONDALE SEES 'LONG, TOUGH FIGHT'
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings and former Gov. Reubin Askew withdrew from the Democratic Presidential campaign today, narrowing the field of major contenders for the nomination to five.

title: SLAVERY CHARGES UPHELD ON 9
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, reversing a lower court ruling, said today that nine Los Angeles residents may be tried on charges they held a group of Indonesians in involuntary servitude. The appeals court said the use of force is not an essential element in holding a person in slavery.

title: U.S. Steel Units
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it had sold its Alside division and its tire cord and electric cable operations to Associated Materials Inc. of Dallas for about $140 million.

title: L.I. CONDOMINIUMS ARE DRAWING FIRST-TIME BUYERS
description: Developers of condominiums near the south shore of western Nassau County are finding that new housing can be produced at costs that will make it affordable to households with incomes as low as about $40,000 a year.

title: MANY WHO SEE FAILURE IN HIS POLICIES DON'T BLAME THEIR AFFABLE PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan's ability to deflect his challengers' attacks and escape blame for his policies appears to be emerging as a key factor in the 1984 Presidential campaign. A New York Times/CBS News Poll and follow-up interviews with a few dozen respondents illuminates the President's skill, even among Americans who consider his policies to be failures,

title: WESTGROWTH PETROLEUMS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MIDLAND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $177,000. c-Net loss.

title: Nominee For Fed Governor
description: Martha Romain Seger, a professor of informational systems analysis at Central Michigan University, will be nominated by President Reagan to be a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, Congressional and Administration sources said tonight. The nomination could be announced Friday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Campaign Notes column on Monday misidentified the departing chairman of George McGovern's Presidential campaign. He is George Cunningham.

title: SCREEN: 'AGAINST ALL ODDS'
description: THERE is plenty of evidence to support the idea that ''film noir,'' the late 1940's genre marked by shadow and duplicity, cannot successfully be updated for the 80's. There is also reason to wonder why the task would even be attempted, since modern characters who deliver the genre's dated dialogue or espouse its notions of evil can't help but seem mannered and false. Despite all that, Taylor Hackford's ''noir''-ish ''Against All Odds'' has a lot of appeal. If Mr. Hackford has done nothing more than make a steamy, sinister, great-looking detective film cum travelogue, he's still managed to come up with something fast-paced and eminently entertaining.

title: AIRBUS WINS SUPPORT FROM BRITISH ON A230
description: The last piece needed for Airbus Industrie to formally commit itself to building the A320, a new 150-seat aircraft, fell into place today when Britain announced it would provide $370 million in loans toward British Aerospace's initial costs in the project.

title: TOP KIRKPATRICK AIDE RESIGNS FROM U.N. JOB
description: Charles M. Lichenstein, the United States deputy representative at the United Nations, announced today that he was resigning his post, effective Friday.

title: ARAFAT AND HUSSEIN FINISH TALKS ON WEST BANK FUTURE
description: King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, ended a series of discussions today in which they said they agreed on ways of coordinating policies toward regaining the occupied West Bank from Israel.

title: UNIVERSAL TELEPHONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Nixon Staying in Jersey

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in April 1983.

title: SAN FRANCISCANS ADJUST TO CITY CURB ON SMOKING
description: The Victorian mansion where Linda Servis works has about as many nooks and crannies as an English muffin, and so, when she and the rest of the staff of Evans Pacific Realty reported for work today, they already had it worked out.

title: U.S. POST NEAR BEIRUT DRAWS SHELLS
description: This mountain town, from which Syrian and Druse artillery positions can clearly be seen, came under two shelling attacks on Wednesday, with four or five shells landing close to a military position occupied by a small group of Americans.

title: Snead Leads by 1 on a 68
description: J. C. Snead recalled that when he walked up to the first tee today, he said to himself: '' 'I wonder where this thing is going.' I've darn near been having the yips with the driver and that isn't exactly right. You hear of the yips with a putter but not a driver. I have just not been hitting drives.''

description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $4.5 million.

title: Advertising
description: Finesse: Expensive Marketing

title: IRAQ SAYS IT SANK 7 IRANIAN SHIPS IN GULF
description: Iraq said today that its air and naval forces had sunk seven Iranian ships in the Persian Gulf.

title: Deal Reported Set on Rights to Dupree
description: The Generals and the New Orleans Breakers came to terms yesterday on a deal that would give the Breakers the rights to sign Marcus Dupree, according to the Breakers' owner, Joseph Canizaro, who was still awaiting clearance from the United States Football League to sign the former Oklahoma running back.

title: IMMUNE TO THAT POTOMAC FEVER
description: The view from Austin, Tex., of the legislative going-ons in the nation's capital has led one former member of Congress to conclude that people in Washington do not really know what the rest of the country feels and thinks.

title: Foreign Affairs Unit Refuses To Block Unesco Withdrawal
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee defeated a move today that would have blocked the United States plan to withdraw from Unesco.

title: SUBSIDIZED HOUSING WINS RULING ON CONVERSIONS
description: A judge has ruled that the owners of certain subsidized apartment buildings designed for moderate-income families in New York City do not need approval by the Board of Estimate to convert them to cooperatives or condominiums.

title: Express Package
description: The United States Football League could have another premier player by this weekend. Steve Young, the outstanding quarterback from Brigham Young, has been offered a handsome contract by the Los Angeles Express, a package that Young's agent, Leigh Steinberg, called ''a Moon-like deal.''

title: BROADWAY
description: Williams Theater to open in April with Gurney play.

title: 3 STATES DENY EDB PACT WITH CUOMO
description: Officials of three Northeastern states said today that Governor Cuomo had mistakenly announced a six-state agreement last week that established uniform guidelines for the presence of EDB in food.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Monday about the New York Lung Association's ''aerobic dance-a-thon'' misidentified the program that benefited from the fund-raising event. It was the Christmas Seal Campaign.

description: FOR celebrity seekers it was undoubtedly the bargain of the

title: SHULTZ DECLARES DEBATE HARMED LEBANON EFFORT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that debate over the War Powers Act had made it impossible to conduct a ''sensible'' policy in Lebanon.

title: U.S. ALPINE EVENTS MAINTAIN TRADITION
description: In Alpine ski racing, the Olympics

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE VALLEY OF THE FOX. By Joseph Hone. 309 pages. St. Martin's. $13.95. FLOODGATE. By Alistair MacLean. 369 pages. Doubleday. $15.95. JOSEPH HONE'S ''Sixth Directorate,'' which was published in 1975, is one of the best suspense novels of the last 10 years. It has elegance, wit, sympathy, irony, surprise, action, a rueful love affair and a melancholy Decline of the West mood. Only the crimes in its pages separate the book from what is known as serious novels.

title: Jackson Needs 10% Of the Vote in Vermont
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson faces the loss of Federal matching funds if he fails to win at least 10 percent of the vote in Vermont's primary Tuesday.

title: Paving Concern Guilty In Bid-Rigging Case
description: New Hampshire's largest paving company has been convicted of rigging bids on millions of dollars worth of Vermont highway projects over six years.

title: WATCH YOUR STEP; Winter Green Those who find the winter landscape unrelievedly dreary these days don't keep their eyes close enough to the ground.
description: Like skiers, daffodils have got their tips up and everywhere wild garlic has got its tufts up - bright shoots of late-winter green.

title: REAGAN DENOUNCES RIVALS AS 'PROFESSIONAL PESSIMISTS'
description: President Reagan, showing a hearty appetite for the 1984 campaign, today denounced his Democratic opponents as ''cyncial professional pessimists'' who had turned themselves over to ''the trendy politics'' of special-interest pleading. He said that at the same time they overlooked their own ''awful immediate past'' of incumbency.

title: Key Rates
'I NEVER LIED!'
description: Earlier this week the Senate Foreign Relations Committee staff issued a report on the 30 months of secret taping perpetrated by the U.S.I.A. Director, Charles Wick, containing this damaging revelation: that Mr. Wick had taped a caller in California, where state law forbids most secret taping.

title: A Seaboard of Stunted Trees
description: Throughout the Eastern Seaboard of the United States, forests are in serious decline. Several species of tree are growing more feebly than usual, and along the Appalachians' tallest peaks, from Camels Hump in Vermont to Mount Mitchell in North Carolina, the trees are dead or dying. The causes of this massive disaster are not known for sure, but the circumstantial evidence is compelling: only air pollutants, such as acid rain, could damage forests over so wide a range.

title: JACKIE COOGAN, CHILD STAR OF FILMS, DIES AT 69
description: Jackie Coogan, who in 1919 became the first major child star in American movie history as the sad-eyed foundling in ''The Kid,'' died after a heart attack yesterday at the Santa Monica (Calif.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Palm Springs, Calif.

Alby is a diabetic, has a Jewish mom (Shelley Winters), a rich uncle in the garment district (Sid Caesar) and lives with a beautiful, Philadelphia- born WASP named Elizabeth (Margaux Hemingway).

Violent Soccer Fans
description: It was just an exhibition soccer match between England and France, but to many English fans who went to Paris for the game Wednesday night, it was apparently an invitation for mayhem. According to British and French officials, unruly English fans caused serious damage to the cross- channel ferry that took them to France and then went on rampages at the match at Parc des Princes Stadium and afterward through the streets of Paris.

title: A RENAISSANCE FOR TAP, NEW AND OLD STYLE
description: WHEN Hinton Battle, who had trained as a ballet dancer since the age of 10, auditioned for the Broadway production of ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' he managed to fudge a soft-shoe routine even though he didn't know how to tap dance at all. But then he learned he had been cast to understudy Gregory Hines, the virtuoso tap dancer whose dazzling numbers stopped every show.

title: HART PLANS STRONG EFFORT IN NEW YORK RACE
description: Senator Gary Hart's supporters in New York said yesterday that the state's Democratic primary April 3 would be a two-candidate affair and began making plans to try to defeat former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.

title: STATE CAN AFFORD A TAX CUT,SENATE REPUBLICANS ASSERT
description: Leading Republicans in the State Senate said today that New York would have enough money in the next fiscal year to pay for ''a substantial tax cut.''

title: U.S. TO INSPECT CITY SUBWAY RAILS
description: The Secretary of Transportation agreed today to a request from the New York City Transit Authority to have Federal inspectors examine the city's subway tracks.

description: Lambsdorff's View of U.S.

title: Interim Rule For Baseball
description: With Bowie Kuhn's departure as commissioner today, the Executive Council begins running baseball Friday. The council, though, could be in charge for only one day.

title: 'New' Braniff's Big Start-Up
description: Braniff Inc. emerged from bankruptcy today, beginning service to 18 markets in the largest one-day start-up in aviation history.

title: Concert in TriBeCa
description: Brian Smith will present a program of compositions with improvisation for bass, violin, woodwinds and percussion tomorrow at the Alternative Museum (966-4444), 17 White Street in TriBeCa. Mr. Smith will play string bass and the 12-foot-tall Euterpe contrabass; he will be joined by John Purcell on woodwinds, Leroy Jenkins on violin and Warren Smith on percussion. Tickets are $7, or Theater Development Fund voucher plus $2.50.

title: METS HELP MARTIN TAKE 'FIRST STEP'
description: One week after he was released from Federal prison, Jerry Martin joined the Mets today in an attempt to restore his baseball career and said: ''This is the first step.''

title: MRS. ROOSEVELT AND HER FACIAL TISSUES

title: A TIDAL WAVE OF GERMANS IS SWEEPING WESTWARD
description: Joachim Gehler proclaimed his disloyalty in 1980. A machine-tool operator in the East German city of Plauen, Mr. Gehler announced that he was resigning from the state-run Communist trade union out of sympathy with the Solidarity movement in neighboring Poland.

title: CONCERT: A PROGRAM BY ARMIN LOOS
description: -1971) only heard one of his compositions played in his lifetime. It won second prize in a national competition, sponsored by the Works Progress Administration in 1938, whose other winners included William Schuman, David Diamond and Elliott Carter. Unlike his colleagues, however, Loos, did not go on to musical fame and fortune. Instead, he managed his father-in-law's curtain shop in New Britain, Conn. There, this largely self-taught son of a German banker continued to write music, dutifully placing it in the proverbial drawer that holds the works of all unplayed, undiscovered and neglected composers.

title: WOMEN IN ELECTRONICS FIND SILICON VALLEY BEST AND WORSE
description: Delicate northern light filtered through the blinds, painting the office with soft colors. Behind the wooden desk, topped with a vase of fresh carnations, sat Carolyn J. Morris, a 39-year-old Texan who was trained as a girl to sit quietly with hands in lap and not argue.

Paine Webber
description: A $75 million issue of Paine Webber Inc. 13 3/8 percent subordinated notes due in 1994 is offered at a price of 99 3/4 to yield 13.42 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The notes are not callable for seven years and were priced with a yield of 133 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, above the yield on 10- year Treasury notes.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: SINCE March 1978, when Parioli Romanissimo was given a two-star rating in The New York Times, the owner, Rubrio Rossi and his three chefs have continued to refine their cooking and to search out the finest ingredients: they have seemingly discovered the best butcher, fishmonger and greengrocer in town. With such impeccable raw materials, the kitchen turns out an unusual array of appetizers not often found in an Italian restaurant: first-class veal and seafood dishes, and tender, perfectly sauced pastas. A few lapses aside, patrons of the restaurant today are assured of a three-star meal.

title: SPECULATION INTENSIFIES ON TEXACO
description: Speculation intensified last night that Texaco Inc., which has just completed the $10.1 billion acquisition of the Getty Oil Company, may itself have become the target of a takeover plan. This conjecture, outlined by Wall Street sources close to Texaco, was based on an unconfirmed report that the Bass family, an oil-rich, acquisition-minded group of Texas investors, had acquired a huge block of Texaco shares.

title: BENN, LABOR LEFTIST, IS VICTOR IN ELECTION FOR PARLIAMENT SEAT
description: Tony Benn, leader of the opposition Labor Party's left wing, easily won a special parliamentary election Thursday in this central England mining town.

title: 'A CENTURY OF BLACK PHOTOGRAPHERS'
description: After more than 100 years and protracted development in the darkroom of history, traces of James Presley Ball's story emerge. In 1851, Ball's Cincinnati gallery was the largest in the ''West.'' He made photographs up and down the United States from Mississippi to Canada. He also practiced his craft in frontier Montana, and he was black.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Comings and Goings
description: Monte Irvin , the 65-year-old former New York Giant outfielder who recently retired as a full-time member of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn 's staff, has been retained as a part-time consultant, the commissioner's office announced. . . . Ralph Houk , the 64-year- old manager of the Boston Red Sox, was sent home from the team's spring camp with what the Red Sox physician called ''a bug that's going around,'' after Houk nearly collapsed during a photo session for the Boston coaching staff. . . . Al Oliver , making his first appearance at the San Francisco Giants' camp in Scottsdale, Ariz., since being being acquired from the Montreal Expos in a trade earlier in the week, complained that the Expo management had always treated him superficially and had never tried to find out about him. ''They never took time to talk with me,'' he said.

description: b-Net income.

title: JUDGE LAMBASTES COMPANY IN SUIT ON INTRAUTERINE DEVICE
description: Calling the Dalkon Shield ''an instrument of death, mutilation and disease,'' a Federal judge accused three top officials of the A. H. Robins Company of putting profits above the health of women who used the intrauterine birth-control device.

title: SOVIET VETO: A BLESSING IN DISGUISE?
description: Diplomats here said today that the Soviet veto of a proposal to send United Nations forces to Beirut had had the curious effect of resolving a difficult problem for the United States. On Wednesday the American delegation voted with the large majority in the Security Council in favor of a French proposal to replace the American and European forces with a United Nations contingent. The resolution would also have required that American warships withdraw from Lebanese waters, a measure that would have restricted the use of United States military power in Lebanon.

title: Soviet Attache Rejected
description: The State Department has rejected the visa request for the Soviet Union's attache to the 1984 Olympic Summer Games, the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee

title: Exodus for a Twice-Lost Tribe
description: Ethiopia is both a country and a living museum. Christian since the fourth century, its people speak 70 languages and 200 dialects. Ethiopia also boasts, or should boast, an ancient Jewish community called the Falashas. A saner world would celebrate this human link to an epic past - a lost tribe that has kept its identity for more than 2,000 years in a remote corner of Africa.

title: SONESTA INTERNATIONAL HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $581,000 for the quarter and $1,459,000 for the year and a loss of $2,065,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of food product operations. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-4 reverse stock split paid in 1983.

title: Merrill Wins Its Bank Suit
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. has won $1.3 million by suing the biggest bank in Arkansas and the founder of Comex Inc.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Venerable Voice

title: Article 025523 -- No Title
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank has agreed to provide $10 million to New York City for reduced-rate loans to rehabilitate about 100 apartment buildings in ''higher risk'' areas, city officials said yesterday.

title: Martial Law Is Ended In 13 Turkish Provinces
description: The Government said today that it had decided to lift martial law in 13 of Turkey's 67 provinces.

title: Seabrook Unit Backed
description: The owners of the Seabrook nuclear power plant voted down a move today to cancel its second reactor, and rejected a new $9 billion cost estimate for the project.

title: Man Gets 1 Year In Auto Homicide
description: A 21-year-old Dix Hills man today became the first defendant to be sentenced in Nassau County under a new state vehicular-homicide law.

title: FOR POTVIN, QUICK CHOICE LEADS TO GOAL
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba

title: German Train Crash Kills 3
description: Three people were killed and 43 injured on Wednesday when a passenger train hit a locomotive at Hohenthurm station near Halle, the East German press agency said. It said the train had struck a locomotive that was being coupled to a Berlin-Saarbr"ucken express.

title: U.S. VOWS GRENADA AIRPORT AID
description: President Reagan has sent personal assurances to officials on Grenada that the United States would help complete the island's airport, a prime objective of the United States invasion last October.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Dollar Retreats in U.S. As Gold Drops by 75/

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest Rates Fall Modestly

title: ART: PICASSO SURVEY, THE LATE PAINTINGS
description: PICASSO'S late work may never be more welcome than it is in New York now. During the last years of his life, living with his wife, Jacqueline Roque, in Mougins, near the Mediterranean that was a source of comfort and inspiration to him all his life, Picasso created a body of work that now seems as fully human as any he ever produced. In their doubt, ambition and total lack of inhibition, the late paintings also provide a perspective on Expressionist painting of the last 30 years. After ''Picasso: The Late Years, 1963-73,'' which is at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum through May 6, Willem de Kooning and the Italian, German and American Neo-Expressionist painting around us are not likely to look the same.

title: Owners to Discuss Colt Plans
description: Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of the National Football League, and executives from the league's 28 teams are scheduled to meet today in Chicago to discuss several issues, including the possible relocation of the Baltimore Colts to Indianapolis.

title: Calet, Hirsch & Spector Gets Thermos Carafe
description: Thermos, a subsidiary of the Household International Corporation that has made its name in picnic products, has annouced a $6 million marketing program for a new brand of coffee carafes. James E. Freeman Jr., vice president for marketing, said the move would ''bring the company inside after 75 years.''

title: RAYMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Including income of $355,000 for the year from discontinued operations and a loss of $130,000 for the quarter and a gain of $4,150,000 for the year on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,751,000 for the quarter and $10,986,000 for the year and a loss of $16,173,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of discontinued operations.

description: Accounts

title: Pepper Endorses Mondale
description: Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, an influential spokesman for the nation's elderly, today endorsed Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

description: b-Including a special gain of $480,000. c-Including a gain of $6.6 million. d-Net loss.

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 2, 1984 International
description: The War Powers Act was assailed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He said that debate over use of the law had made it impossible for the United States to conduct a ''sensible'' policy in Lebanon, and he urged Congress to consider an alternative approach to avoid setbacks to American interests. (Page A1, Column 5.) A withdrawal of French troops from Lebanon was considered likely. The Foreign Ministry said that France ''cannot alone bear the responsibility of the international community in Lebanon,'' but Paris said a pullout was not imminent. (A10:1-3.)

title: 4 Students Hurt In Lab Explosion
description: Four students were injured, one of them seriously, in an explosion last night in a chemistry laboratory at La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens, the police said.

title: PIERCE, S.S. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net loss

title: MEESE ENCOUNTERS SHARP CHALLENGES AT SENATE HEARING
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee opened confirmation hearings today on the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d to become Attorney General, focusing on his finances, his commitment to civil rights and his readiness to be independent of the White House.

title: Pentagon Says News Reports Endanger Troops in Lebanon
description: The Defense Department said today that reports by news organizations had endangered United States personnel in Lebanon by disclosing the location of a group of observers who were directing artillery fire.

title: BRIEFS
description: * General Foods Corp . said it had completed the sale of its Mexican Foods of America Inc. unit, which operates Guadalaharry's Mexican restaurants, to Greenwich Mexican Foods Group Inc., which is owned by Ramosa Inc., a private investment company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: TROUBLED PAST OF TEACHER IN SLAYING
description: The teacher accused of killing a woman by pushing her into the path of a subway train injured a third-grade student about a month ago, school officials said yesterday. Before that, the officials said, he had taken five long leaves of absence related to his mental health.

title: STUDENTS FLOCK TO AMERICAN UNIVERSITY OF BEIRUT
description: Despite the recent violence in the Lebanese capital, almost 2,000 students have registered for the spring semester at the American University of Beirut, a university official reported in New York yesterday.

title:
PATENTS;
A Monitoring System For Nuclear Reactors
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation received a patent this week for a new monitoring and control system for nuclear reactor power systems.

description: b-After a charge of $601,000 for the quarter and year from a plant closing.

title: SALVATION ARMY LOSING CITY PACTS FOR STAND ON HIRING HOMOSEXUALS
description: Mayor Koch told the Salvation Army yesterday that its contracts with the city to provide day care and other services would not be renewed until it adopted an unbiased hiring policy toward homosexuals.

title: WHY A POLITICAL NOD IN CHICAGO IS NOT A BACKSLAP
description: On the surface it looked like a fairly simple event. Mayor Harold Washington, a Democrat, went on television to urge the defeat of President Reagan in November and to say that he preferred the Rev. Jesse Jackson as the Democratic Presidential candidate.

title: TV: SINGING THE PRAISES OF POP-SONG LYRICISTS
description: The elevation from relative obscurity of those who write the lyrics for popular songs, which began a decade ago with the still continuing ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series at the 92d Street Y, has reached a point at which the wordsmiths can now serve as the focus for a television fund-raising program.

description: A former Salvadoran military official has implicated high-ranking Salvadoran officials and civilians in acts of terrorism, including Roberto d'Aubuisson, a leading candidate for El Salvador's presidency.

title: REAGAN COURTS CONSERVATIVES
description: President Reagan tonight rallied conservative supporters with a call for four more years in office and a denunciation of Democratic opponents as ''spendthrifts who mangled America.''

description: Walter F. Mondale earned almost $1 million in the two years after leaving the Vice Presidency in 1981, giving him a solid personal financial footing before he announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination last year.

description: Two Queens men were captured yesterday fleeing a holdup of a Chase Manhattan Bank branch at 156-02 Cross Bay Boulevard in Howard Beach, Queens. The men, Dennis Peterson and Gregory Dickens, both of Ozone Park, were charged with bank robbery. . . . Three Manhattan residents were arrested and heroin with a street value of $1 million was confiscated in an apartment at 85-87 Pitt Street. The suspects were identified as Orlando Torres, Carmen Torres and Piedro Castro.

title: CONFERENCE ON SCHOOLS: IDEAS AND JOBS
description: It's kind of a small, little world unto itself,'' said Lawrence D. Bailey, a history teacher from Florida. ''You get to catch up on the gossip and occasionally you hope you'll strike it rich with just the right job at just the right school.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Rangers sent Mark Morrison , a center, to their Tulsa farm club in the Central League. Morrison played in one game after joining the Rangers when he was declared ineligible for the Canadian Olympic team because he previously played nine game for New York. . . . The National Hockey League has suspended Jim Kyte of the Winnipeg Jets for four games as the result of a match penalty the defenseman received during a game against the Edmonton Oilers Monday night. The suspension includes one game that Kyte served while awaiting the league's review.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: JAZZ UPTOWN The nightclub that runs to jazz often seems a permanently endangered species, with only a few able to boast a score of years in the business. Costs rise, talent becomes more expensive and closing is always a possibility. Even Mikell's, which has for 15 years been an after-dark anchor of Upper West Side living, at 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864- 8832), is feeling a pinch. Next week, it starts a benefit for itself.

title: Lottery Gains in Mississippi
description: The Mississippi House, by a 75-to-37 vote, today approved a proposed constitutional amendment to authorize a state lottery. The plan must win support from two-thirds of the Senate and then be ratified in a statewide vote if it is to take effect.

CREDIT MARKETS ;
 But Experts Doubt Trend
description: Prices of U.S. Securities Gain

title: No Guatemalan Medal For Exiting U.S. Envoy
description: Guatemala's chief of state has broken with tradition by not awarding the country's highest civilian medal to the departing United States Ambassador, saying the envoy ''did nothing'' for the country.

title: AN OLD MIDTOWN HOTEL
description: The hotel has seen better days. Situated in the Times Square area, it has struggled to hold up its head respectably above the mire of porn film houses, sex shops and human jetsam that surround it. Once it was a landmark, patronized by theater people, the top acts of vaudeville and the stars of legit. But that was in the 20's, 30's and 40's. My father, who spent much of his life in the restaurant business around Times Square, and who was a kind of a Broadway character, told me about the old hotel: the fine dining room, the parties, the elegance of the lobby. He recalled the celebrities who were picked up by limos, hauling them just a few blocks to a theater or a night club.

title: KUHN REPORTEDLY TO STAY IN POST UNTIL SEPT. 30
description: Bowie Kuhn, who supposedly stepped down as baseball commissioner Thursday, will actually remain in that office until Sept. 30, a source close to baseball's Executive Council said tonight. By that time, Peter V. Ueberroth will officially become commissioner.

title: DOUGLAS M. M'AVITY
description: Douglas Malcolm McAvity, a former assistant treasurer for corporate finance with the United States Steel Corporation, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Reagan Riposte
description: In denouncing his Democratic opponents for seeing only the negatives in his performance in office, President Reagan drew on his show business past in a speech Thursday and told a story of a steely, hard-bitten theatrical agent and a young performer trying to get into vaudeville.

title: Woman Stays in Shack With Brother's Body
description: A reclusive woman with $350,000 in assets who lived four weeks in a tin-roofed home with her dead brother's body is undergoing medical and mental evaluation, the authorities said today.

title: IRAQ WARNS ANEW ON IRANIAN PORTS
description: Iraq warned foreign shipping again tonight not to approach Iranian ports in the Persian Gulf. But it said it did not intend to attack the main Iranian oil terminal on Kharg Island at present.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 39.

U.S. Agencies Halt Spraying
description: The Government today halted herbicide spraying on United States Forest Service land in Oregon and Washington after a Federal district judge threatened to jail officials if they failed to comply with his ban.

title: Jersey to Parole Imprisoned Judge
description: A suspended Superior Court judge described by a State Parole Board official today as having ''suffered enough'' is to be paroled in June after serving one year of a five-year sentence for bribery.

title: BARTENDER TESTIFYING IN RAPE CASE SAYS HE SENSED TROUBLE AT TAVERN
description: A bartender who testified today in trial of six men charged with aggravated rape said that he had a ''bad impression'' of the woman when she was in Big Dan's Tavern last March and had considered having the police throw her out.

title: CUOMO SAYS JUST MAINE IS NOT IN EDB PACT
description: Governor Cuomo today defended his announcement last week that New York and a group of other Northeastern states had agreed to limits on EDB in food products, but confirmed that one of the states - Maine - is not part of the agreement.

title: Bitter Parting
description: Jim Kern , the Chicago White Sox relief pitcher who sat out the 1983 season with an injured elbow, has been waived by the club, and Kern is not happy about it. He blamed the club for ''destroying my arm and then shucking me off like last year's shotgun shells.''

title: Kenyans Assail Press For Massacre Reports
description: The official newspaper of Kenya's ruling party said today that some local politicians and the foreign press had exaggerated and distorted reports of a purported massacre by security forces in northeast Kenya.

title: CONVICT RECANTS HIS GUILTY PLEA RICHMOND, March 2 (AP) - A man who pleaded guilty to murder just before a jury decided he was not guilty contends in a lawsuit challenging his conviction that he changed his plea because he feared execution.
description: -day trial and four and a half hours of jury deliberation, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in exchange for a sentence of 40 years in prison.

title: SUFFOLK SENDS PATROLS AFTER WOOD THIEVES
description: People are stealing the woods here.

description: A smoky two-alarm fire caused moderate damage yesterday to a partly occupied factory building in Brooklyn near the Manhattan Bridge and forced the closing of the bridge for about half an hour.

'LEMON LAWS' FOR USED CARS: PRO AND CON
description: Since 1982, 19 states have enacted ''lemon laws'' that allow buyers to demand refunds or replacements for new cars with serious defects. Now the Federal Trade Commission and several state legislatures are considering whether some kind of buyer protection should also be required for used cars.

title: DRUMMOND MCCALL METALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JUSTICE DEPT. OPEN TO NEW RIGHTS BILL
description: A senior Justice Department official says he will not object to legislative proposals to expand the reach of a civil rights law forbidding sex discrimination by schools and colleges that receive Federal aid. Such proposals are a reaction to a decision issued Tuesday by the Supreme Court.

title: JOB JURISDICTION IS AN ISSUE IN NETWORK WRITERS' DISPUTE
description: A dispute over union jurisdiction and job security is threatening the news departments at CBS and ABC with a strike early Monday morning by 600 employees who write copy and design the pictures and charts that illustrate television news.

title: Western Union's Easylink Outlay
description: The Western Union Corporation said its board had approved plans to accelerate expansion of its Easylink network service that call for spending of about $70 million this year.

title: CHERNENKO URGES U.S. TO TAKE STEPS TO HELP RELATIONS
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko urged the United States today to take actions that could signal ''the start of a real drastic change in Soviet-American relations.''

title: Congress Frees Road Money
description: Congress voted today to free more than $5 billion in highway funds that had been tied up for almost five months because of regional disputes over state road projects.

description: b-Net loss including income of $328,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $981,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated for an accounting change.

description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: GRAHAM REVIVAL
description: Martha Graham's comedy of manners, ''Embattled Garden,'' which has not been performed in many years, was revived Thursday night in the State Theater. The program by the Martha Graham Dance Company also included the season's first performance of her recent ''Andromache's Lament,'' now transferred to a larger stage with unexpected and blazing operatic dimension that delighted an enthusiastic audience.

title: A Way Out
description: Zola Budd , the 17-year-old distance runner who has excited the track world with several performances that have produced unofficial world records, may get a chance to compete in the 1984 Olympic Games after all. As a South African, she is barred from racing at Los Angeles because of her homeland's apartheid policies. But British officials are said to be trying to get her citizenship through her paternal grandfather.

title: WHAT WENT WRONG?
description: The abrupt decline of American influence in Lebanon has produced a sense of gloom and foreboding at the higher levels of the State Department and recriminations about what went wrong. Some Middle East experts here say that the more dire predictions about the aftereffects of the Marine pullback from Beirut may turn out to be overdrawn and that the United States may yet resume playing an important role in the region, including Lebanon.

title: 7 Jerseyans Held On Drug Charges
description: The police said today they had broken up what they described as a major heroin ring in southern New Jersey and had arrested seven suspects.

title: AUTO WORKERS TO STATE GOALS FOR NEW PACTS
description: ''This seat was made for you on the day shift by Team 7 at Fisher Body, Flint,'' reads a small sticker attached to the rear ashtray of some new Buick automobiles.

title: IN CHINATOWN FACTORY, A WORKER IS MOURNED
description: The young Chinese women were at their sewing machines, making summer dresses on a winter day in Chinatown, when the news came over the factory radio. The new worker had been killed, in a way so terrible as to be nearly unbelievable: A man had pushed her into the path of an oncoming subway train during the evening rush hour.

title: SIDE BY SIDE, STRIDE FOR STRIDE
description: Before Diane Dixon was a champion, she was a talented runner from Brooklyn, but not always a happy one. ''They say I'm a spoiled brat,'' she said the other day, and there was a time, not so long ago, when those close to her did not disagree.

title: City Closes a Lane Of Bridge at Night
description: Because of recent nighttime head- on collisions on the Queensboro Bridge, the city's Transportation Department yesterday began closing the center lane on the lower level of the bridge to traffic at night.

The share earnings and shares outstanding reflect 2-for-1 stock split of December 1983.

title: AT CROSSROADS OF WEST, SENTIMENT VS. PROGRESS
description: Joseph Foutz and his three wives followed other Mormon settlers into the San Juan Valley at the turn of the century, and Loyd Foutz took over his grandfather's Indian trading business in 1948. In between, there was little change in this remote region. The road to Farmington was still unpaved, the Navajo reservation economy was still based on barter and the tall volcanic sails of Shiprock mountain rose in the desert 30 miles away in untroubled skies.

title: CONDEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,042,000 and an extraordinary charge of $1,876,000 c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $3,384,000 for the quarter and $6,074,000 for the 6 months. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $29,365,000 and an extraordinary charge of $2,390,000. The latest quarter and 6 months results include a pre-tax unusual credit of $25,383,000 of which $23.3 million is primarily a result of the settlement of on-going disputes with Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Sales Inc., as previously announced. title: SNEAD KEEPS LEAD BY A STROKE AT 139
description: Like many other PGA Tour golfers, J. C. Snead has holed out from the fringe of many greens in his career. He has even blasted out of the sand into holes now and then.

description: The vice chairman of the Walter F. Mondale campaign has said he doubts that the Rev. Jesse Jackson will be the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee because he does not fit ''the qualities that you expect to find in the President.''

description: The New Jersey Insurance Commissioner submitted his resignation today to Governor Kean, blaming ''demagogic behavior'' by the State Legislature for his decision.

description: Nelson Doubleday, the chief owner of the Mets, said today that the most urgent issues facing baseball were drugs and the danger of another strike by the players. And he predicted sweeping changes in the role of the new commissioner in dealing with them.

title: FEW CHEMICALS TESTED FOR HAZARDS, REPORT FINDS
description: Tens of thousands of commercially important chemicals have never been adequately tested for potential health hazards, a committee of experts assembled by the National Research Council to advise the Government reported today.

title: Texaco Stake By Bass Level
description: The Bass brothers, a group of Texas investors holding 9.8 percent of the shares of Texaco Inc., have not reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission an increase in their Texaco stake.
