The company also said that the latest year results included expenses of $757,000 related to the anticipated merger with a subsidiary of Consolidated Freightways Inc. which was terminated in August 1983

title: RIO CARNIVAL: HARD TIMES CROWD THE GOOD TIMES
description: Rio de Janeiro's legendary carnival is a more serious affair than usual this year. It is taking place during Brazil's worst economic crisis in decades, with both the sacrifice of buying the glittering ''fantasy'' costumes and the need for release from the hardship of daily routine greater than ever.

title: Women's League Being Organized
description: Bill Byrne, who founded the Women's Basketball League, which began in 1977 and lasted three seasons, is trying again to create a professional league for female basketball players. On Tuesday in Columbus, Ohio, an organizational meeting of the Women's National Basketball Association will be held.

title: CAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,333,000 on the sale of fixed assets for the quarter and year.

title: Democrats Say Reagan Is Aided by Rightists
description: The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is asking the Federal Election Commission to investigate the relationship between President Reagan's campaign committee and the National Conservative Political Action Committee.

title: WARSAW DENIES ROLE IN PLOT TO SMUGGLE GUNS FROM U.S.
description: Poland yesterday ridiculed United States charges that the Government in Warsaw had tried to buy an illegal shipment of $1 million in arms, ammunition and paramilitary police equipment from two American businessmen arrested by Customs agents in New York Thursday.

title: B.P. Offers to Sell Back Its Holdings in AMAX
description: The British Petroleum Company has offered to sell to AMAX Inc. the 4.3 million common shares of AMAX it owns, the American metals concern announced yesterday. B.P. is required to dispose of its stake under a September 1981 consent decree with the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Kissinger to Get New Post
description: President Reagan announced today that he would appoint former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board.

title: LaROUCHE FIELDS JERSEY SCHOOL SLATES
description: A conservative group headed by Lyndon H. LaRouche says it has mobilized a campaign throughout New Jersey to field candidates in the state's normally nonpolitical local school board elections next month.

title: U.S. TEAM STUDYING LATIN ARMS PACTS
description: The State Department has sent a team of technicians to Central America to consult with governments on how to verify compliance in arms limitation treaties, according to a United States Embassy official here.

title: Winn Is Opposed
description: The International Controls Corporation said it had rejected an offer from Winn Enterprises to be acquired for $21 a share.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Two-Way Block On a One-Way Street

title: Judicial Activism in Grove City
description: In the case of Grove City College, a coeducational liberal arts school in Pennsylvania, the Supreme Court had to decide a basic but simple issue: Is the college subject to Federal laws against sex discrimination because some of its students receive Federal scholarships? The Court resolved that issue correctly, but went on to render an unnecessary and injudicious interpretation of the law.

title: W. MELVIN CROOK
description: W. Melvin Crook, a leading authority on powerboat racing and a columnist for Yachting magazine, died of congestive heart failure on Tuesday at the Naples (Fla.)

title: Polish Primate Quoted As Criticizing Solidarity
description: Josef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic primate of Poland, was quoted today as saying that the outlawed union Solidarity was no longer acting in the interests of workers.

title: SAVING BONDS AS AN ANNUITY
description: UNITED STATES Savings Bonds, rejuvenated 16 months ago when the Government for the first time tied them to market-based interest rates, have traditionally been sold as a means of easily accumulating funds on a tax-deferred basis. But an additional way for individuals to make use of these bonds is as a self-created annuity, with none of the sales or administrative charges that may be tacked onto commercial annuities.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-Net loss.

title: Men Lead Cheers
description: For the last month, spectators at Columbia basketball games have noticed something new - five male cheerleaders, including four members of the Columbia football team.

title: G.M. Callback Set
description: The General Motors Corporation's G.M. assembly division said it will recall 1,200 temporarily idled workers on Monday at its plant in Orion Township that makes luxury cars. It said output of new luxury front-wheel-drive Cadillac DeVille and Oldsmobile 98 cars will resume after a three-week halt caused by lack of quality parts.

title: OLMEDO AND CO-DEFENDANT GUILTY IN EXTORTION PLOT
description: Luis A. Olmedo, who has represented a northern Brooklyn district in the City Council for 10 years, was convicted yesterday of attempted extortion and criminal conspiracy.

title: Chinese Says U.S. Ties Hinge on Taiwan Issue
description: Deputy Prime Minister Wan Li of China, looking ahead to President Reagan's visit here late next month, today ruled out any substantial improvement in relations with the United States until the Taiwan issue is resolved.

title: BORGHILD M. DAHL
description: Borghild M. Dahl, a blind author of children's stories, died Feb. 24 in Burnsville, Minn.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: First-Night Freeloader

title: JOHN O'MELVENY
description: John O'Melveny, retired senior partner of the Los Angeles law firm of O'Melveny & Myers, died Thursday at his home in Los Angeles after a long illness.

title: Former Oriole Testifies
description: The use of cocaine was ''very prevalent'' by some Oriole players around the time of the 1979 World Series with Pittsburgh, Billy Smith told a Federal District Court in Baltimore.

title: U.S. IMPOSES CURBS ON EDB IN FRUIT
description: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency today announced rules to curb the use of EDB on fruit and warned that the nation faced a broad problem from many other pesticides put into use before strict health standards were imposed.

title: HIALEAH STRIVES TO KEEP UP
description: HIALEAH, Fla.

title: Iona Forward to Play
description: Troy Truesdale , the Iona forward who was ejected Thursday night from a semifinal game with St. Peter's for throwing an elbow at an opposing player in what was ruled a flagrant foul, will be allowed to play in today's Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference championship basketball game against Fordham. After watching tapes of Iona's 59-56 victory over St. Peter's with the conference disciplinary committee, Jim McDermott , the commissioner, ruled that Truesdale's foul was a ''spontaneous reaction to a push and there was no reason to disqualify him.''

title: Evidence Inconclusive, Mrs. Kirkpatrick Says
description: Some Administration officials believe there is real but inconclusive evidence linking a right-wing Salvadoran politician, Roberto d'Aubuisson, with death squads in El Salvador, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, said today.

title: BRINCO LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,216,000 and a$14,440,000 writedown of assets. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,860,000 and $19,835,000 writedown of assets.

title: CITY'S MOBILE PHONE BATTLE
description: The high-stakes competition began yesterday for a new type of mobile telephone system in the New York area that will allow thousands of people to have telephones in their cars for the first time.

title: A Sound New Plan for Schools
description: New York State's Education Department has wisely retreated from its expensive and unrealistic first proposal for new school standards. After regional conferences attended by 10,000 persons last fall, it has composed a promising new plan for the Regents' approval this month.

title: Cook United Inc. Closing 41 Stores
description: Cook United Inc. said it would close 41 of its 94 stores within the next eight weeks, laying off some 2,300 employees. The Cleveland-based merchandising company said it would also close two warehouses in Cincinnati and one in Columbus.

title: POISED BETWEEN SIDES
description: Monday morning last I awoke with the terrifying suspicion that I had slept for an entire year. This was caused by the newspaper. It's my habit, immediately after rising, to rummage quickly through the paper in search of the obituary page. If I'm there, I have the perfect excuse for not reading the political news and the latest stories about gunplay in the Middle East.

title: ROFFLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $176,000.

title: KNICKS WIN AS KING GETS 39
description: Bernard King, the hottest shooter in the National Basketball Association over the last six weeks, continued his scoring spree tonight with 39 points as the Knicks beat the Detroit Pistons, 117-102, at the Silverdome.

title: JEWISH PRESS IS DIVIDED ON INFLUENCE OF CHARITIES
description: The publishers of privately owned Jewish newspapers here and elsewhere are accusing Jewish charities of trying to take control of much of the nation's Jewish English- language press in an effort to enhance their fund raising.

title: Rizzo Leaves Job As Gas Works Guardian
description: Former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo, under fire from the news media and consumer critics, left his job as a security consultant with the Philadelphia Gas Works today, a day after he moved into his new office, a utility spokesman said.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: DUPRESS SAID READY TO SIGN
description: Marcus Dupree, the former Oklahoma star running back, has agreed to terms with the New Orleans Breakers of the United States Football League, a team official said last night.

title: WHAT THE SMALLPOX VIRUS CAN DO FOR US
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: 3D BY VIENNESE
description: Leonard Bernstein and the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra concluded their eight-city United States tour, and their three-concert New York visit, with a really wonderful program last night in Carnegie Hall. The music-making was not only gorgeous, but it served to put the seal on all three concerts, reminding us once again what a remarkable ensemble this is.

title: KOHL AIDES WORRY ABOUT U.S. TALKS
description: On the eve of a visit to the United States by Chancellor Helmut Kohl, there are signs that senior officials in his Government are growing increasingly apprehensive about the political implications of their strained relations with Israel.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the expected nomination of Martha Romain Seger to the Federal Reserve Board misstated her position at Central Michigan University. She is a professor of finance.

title: DONATELLO WORK FAILS TO SELL
description: A rare painted terra-cotta relief of the Virgin and Child by Donatello was withdrawn from sale yesterday when it failed to attract a buyer at Sotheby's auction house.

title: At Sixes and Sevens on EDB
description: State and Federal regulators are bungling the effort to rid the nation's food supply of EDB, the cancer-causing pesticide that taints grain products and citrus fruits. A crazy quilt of different Federal and state standards threatens to cause a nightmare for food manufacturers and consumers as cake mixes and oranges judged safe in one state are banished from the supermarkets of another.

title: Colts to Stay, for Now
description: The Baltimore Colts are staying in Baltimore, at least for the time being. That was the message that their owner, Robert Irsay, delivered to owners and executives of the other 27 National Football League teams at a meeting today.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 1:30 P.M. First exhibition game of the season. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.). Basketball Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden, 8:30 P.M. (Television - MSG cable, 8:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW 1130, 8:30 P.M.)

title: Key Rates
SATURDAY, MARCH 3, 1984 International
description: Lebanon's President and Syria reached an understanding on a plan to resolve Lebanon's violent political crisis, Lebanese officials said. The terms of the proposed agreement would mark a sharp shift in Lebanon's diplomatic orientation, away from Israel and toward Syria, the Soviet Union's closest ally in the Middle East. (Page 1, Column 6.) Amin Gemayel's resignation was no longer demanded by Syria's key Lebanese allies, a move that officials in Damascus say clears the way for carrying out an accord between President Gemayel and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. The demands by the Druse and Shiite Moslem leaders for Mr. Gemayel's resignation had been regarded as a major obstacle to agreement on the basis of a Lebanese peace accord. (1:5.)

title: A CHARACTER ACTOR 55 YEARS
description: Roland Culver, a British actor who played the role of an impeccable gentleman in more than 40 plays in Britain and more than 50 British and American movies, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at his home in London. He was 83 years old.

title: Air Force Irish Contract
description: The Air Force today awarded a $150.8 million contract to Short Brothers Ltd. of Belfast, Northern Ireland, to supply and maintain for 10 years 18 cargo planes to move engines and other spare parts among United States bases in Western Europe.

title: IRAN AND THE STRAIT: THREAT IS DISCOUNTED
description: United States and Atlantic alliance intelligence officials say they doubt that Iran, now in its 42d month of war with Iraq, will make good on its repeated threats to close the Strait of Hormuz, through which much of the oil for Japan and Western Europe is shipped. But if Iran tries, the officials say, its ability to block the waterway physically is limited, especially in view of the professed American determination to keep it open and the naval task force the United States has in the area. Iran has warned that it will close the strait if Iraq tries to block Iran's oil-transport system.

title: 120 Are Sworn In For Fire Academy
description: Fire Department officials yesterday swore in 120 probationary firefighters and promoted 33 members of the department at the Fire Academy on Randalls Island.

title: A PARTY TO 'APPLAUD ALL IMMIGRANTS'
description: New York jumped all week with parties uptown and down.

title: I.B.M. PRICE CUTS BEGIN IN EUROPE
description: The International Business Machines Corporation slashed prices for its Personal Computer today to begin a price offensive throughout Western Europe that caught many in the industry off guard.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

PATENTS;
Process for Enzymes Permits Their Re-use
description: A method of collecting enzymes or other biological materials that serve as catalysts has been invented for the Genex Corporation, a genetic engineering company in Rockville, Md.

title: Judy Clark Leads by 3
description: Judy Clark shot a four-under- par 67 today and took over the lead midway through the $300,000 Uniden Invitational.

title: Reagan to Seek Funds Under Matching Law
description: Officials of President Reagan's re-election campaign have decided to apply for $10.1 million in matching funds from the Federal Government for campaign expenses before the Republican National Convention in August. The President signed a document today that authorizes the committee to pursue such funds.

title: VEDIOTAPE SERVICES FOR HIRE
description: THE lights are out. There is muffled giggling, then total silence.

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP BY 1.2%
description: Stronger demand for steel pushed up orders to United States factories by 1.2 percent in January from December, the Commerce Department said today.

title: REFINEMET INTERNATIONAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. TELLS WHY IT BARRED SOVIET OLYMPIC OFFICIAL
description: The State Department said today that it had refused to grant a visa to a Soviet Olympic official for reasons of ''internal security.''

title: PATENTS
description: Producing Antibody Factories

title: Bridge: Challenge Match Is a Way To Enliven the Club Scene
description: Bridge clubs in North America are a long way behind their European counterparts in establishing club identity. One popular idea on the other side of the Atlantic is a challenge match between clubs, generating loyalty, training and selection, and perhaps a sociable meal provided by the hosts.

title: ADVERTISING WOES FACE USA TODAY
description: For USA Today, booming airport sales and bright white and blue sidewalk news boxes have not been enough. The publication that calls itself ''the Nation's Newspaper'' has found that to overcome skeptical advertisers, it must capture many more home and office subscribers.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CHERNENKO'S SPEECH AT KREMLIN
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: MR. CHOI, SUBVERTER
description: I face a prickly moral dilemma. It's the kind that makes you feel you must take sides if you are to live with yourself. I refer to the ''case'' of Bernstein et al. v. Choi.

title: Missile Fuel Plant In Utah Swept by Fire
description: A flash fire today swept through a plant where solid-fuel propellant is placed in missile rockets, slightly injuring 13 workers who rushed out just ahead of the flames, officials said.

title: SOUTH AFRICA AND MOZAMBIQUE IN SECURITY ACCORD
description: South Africa and Mozambique announced tonight that they had agreed on the principles of a treaty of ''nonaggression and good neighborliness'' and would set up a joint commission to oversee it.

title: HE TOOK SMITHSONIAN OUT OF ATTIC
description: When the head of the search committee announced recently that Robert McCormick Adams would become the ninth secretary of the Smithsonian Institution next Sept. 1, the eighth secretary corrected him.

title: LEBANON REACHES AN UNDERSTANDING WITH THE SYRIANS
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon has reached an understanding with Syria on a plan to resolve his country's political crisis, Lebanese officials said today.

title: DRG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEESE IS PRESSED BY SENATE PANEL ON DEALINGS WITH BUYER OF HOME
description: Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General, was challenged today over the sale of his California home, his views on civil rights and the Reagan Administration's record on appointing members of minority groups to the Federal bench.

title: PARK AVENUE PIQUE
description: Most neighborhoods in this city will mobilize against prostitution on the streets, against gambling dens, against porn shops and video arcades. On upper Park Avenue, they are mobilizing against a fruit and vegetable store that a Korean man is trying to open there.

title: New Airbus Jet Gets Go-Ahead
description: Airbus Industrie today announced the formal go-ahead for its A320 150-seat jet following the British Government's decision on Thursday to back the project. Airbus's chairman and chief executive officer, Bernard Lathiere, said at a news conference that the financing for further research and development, put at $1.7 billion in 1983 prices, was now secure. Airbus has already received 51 firm orders in addition to 45 options for the plane, which is due to enter commercial service in the spring of 1988. Mr. Lathi ere said that it was necessary to sell 600 to break even.

title: Appeals Court Nomination
description: President Reagan said today that he would name Robert Beezer, a Seattle lawyer, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. Mr. Beezer, who is 55 years old, would succeed Judge Eugene Wright.

title: Cuomo Nominee Withdraws Name
description: An aide nominated by Governor Cuomo to a seat on the State Board of Parole has withdrawn his name from consideration because he has no college degree.

title: Japan-China Nuclear Talks
description: Japan and China opened the way today for the first sale of a Japanese-built nuclear power plant component to China, a Foreign Ministry official said.

title: Mystery Bidder Befogs Auction of Hellenic Ship
description: With bids well over $1 million and a grizzled mystery bidder, yesterday's auction of the Greek freighter Hellenic Star to satisfy creditors turned into a murky sea story that has yet to be unraveled.

title: No Headline
description: 1. A ceremony marking the dedication of an old Jewish cemetery in Tombstone, Ariz., that had been restored.

title: PATENTS
description: Correction

title: RUINING TIMES SQUARE
description: The developer George Klein and his architect, Philip Johnson, recently announced their plans for the reconstruction of Times Square. Although these plans, including a proposal to demolish what people still call the Times Tower, have been widely reported, New Yorkers seem to have very little awareness of what really is at stake. The plans mean the end, after 80 years, of the public space we know as Times Square. More importantly, they mean the loss of a vital part of our city's history.

title: GREAT AMERICAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $298,000 for the quarter and $438,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $4,007,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Boys and Girls Edges Lincoln
description: Boys and Girls High School came from behind for the second consecutive game last night, stunning Lincoln, 66-65, on a shot by Robert Gilmore in the Public Schools Athletic League playoffs.

title: DOW JUMPS 12.04 IN WIDE RALLY
description: Buoyed by encouraging economic developments, stock prices rose sharply yesterday in heavier trading, with all three major market indicators posting impressive gains.

title: MADISON GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chicago Loan Delayed by Japan Bid
description: The Chicago City Council today postponed a $259 million short-term borrowing plan, thus extending weeks of haggling over the participation of Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. of Tokyo, which bid to guarantee the debt by issuing a letter of credit. Dissident aldermen wanted a local bank to get the business.

title: MRS. LLOYD GAINS SEMIFINALS
description: They are doubles partners, bridge partners and close friends, but today Pam Shriver and Martina Navratilova will find themselves on opposite sides of the net at Madison Square Garden, facing off in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims Championships.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Washington Talk article yesterday gave an incorrect number for the Article of the Constitution that gives most Federal judges lifetime tenure. It is Article III.

title: MET OPERA DEFICIT MAY BE $4 MILLION
description: The Metropolitan Opera is expecting a deficit of up to $4 million for the fiscal year ending July 31, the first time since 1976 that the company will be markedly in the red during a season not disrupted by a labor dispute.

title: French Fugitive In Drug Ring Held
description: Lucien Rene, believed to be one of the last remaining fugitives from the French Connection drug syndicate of the 1960's, was held without bond yesterday in a prison in Dade County, Florida, authorities said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Syrian withdrawal is like the Loch Ness monster. Everyone has talked about it, and no one has seen it.'' - Naoum Farah, the foreign relations director of the Phalangist militia. (6:6.)

title: PATENTS
description: Laser Communications

title: AUDIT DISCOVERS NO IMPROPRIETIES ON 'RIPLEY' SHOW
description: A Columbia Pictures TV audit has found no evidence of financial improprieties by Jack Haley Jr. and Mel Stuart, executive producers of the television show ''Ripley's Believe It or Not,'' a Columbia spokesman said today.

title: Democrats Will Delay House Vote on Tax Bill
description: The Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives plans to hold up floor action on a $49 billion tax bill until agreement is reached with the Reagan Administration on a broad deficit-reduction strategy.

title: RESTAURANT ATTITUDES ON WOMEN WITHOUT MEN
description: Do restaurants still discriminate against women?

title: MONDALE ATTACKS HART ON HIS VIEWS
description: Walter F. Mondale, campaigning here and in Maine, delivered free-swinging attacks on Senator Gary Hart's record on arms control and the economy today, and Mr. Hart told a college audience in Massachusetts that his campaign now had ''genuine momentum.''

title: BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Locomotive Deal
description: The Canadian National Railway Company said it had awarded contracts for 48 locomotives, valued at a total of $80 million, to General Motors of Canada and Bombardier Inc. G.M. Canada, a General Motors Corporation subsidiary, will build 29 locomotives and Bombardier 19. The locomotives will be delivered by the first quarter of 1985, Canadian National said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Music for New Americans

title: 53 Missing After Attack On Boat From Vietnam
description: Bands of pirates attacked a boat carrying refugees from Vietnam, robbing, raping and kidnapping the women and forcing the men overboard, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS
description: Cotton Futures Rally; Grain and Soybeans Up

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Dollar Off as Yen Soars; Prices of Gold Increase

title: Unesco to Be Asked Not to Destroy Papers
description: The United States Congressman who obtained Unesco's consent to a Congressional investigation said today that he would ask the agency head to insure that documents needed for the inquiry will not be destroyed.

title: Slight to Vegas Women Angers Nevada Officials
description: Angry Nevada officials said today the Governor of Colorado should go to Las Vegas and find out that he was wrong when he asserted that one in every eight women under 45 in that gambling spa was a prostitute.

title: L. Marion Gressette Is Dead; Ex-Segregationist in South
description: State Senator L. Marion Gressette, who led South Carolina's fight against school desegregation, died of cardiovascular disease here Thursday night. He was 82 years old.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Canadian Imperial Bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Jockey Seeks Hearing
description: Jacinto Vasquez will ask the State Racing and Wagering Board to rescind his one-year suspension for attempted bribery on the basis of new evidence that he believes will prove that a fellow jockey, Eddie Maple , lied before a grand jury investigation into race-fixing. Ronald Fischetti , a lawyer for the Panamanian rider, said yesterday that ''we have newly discovered evidence - witnesses, among other things - that will prove to the board's satisfaction that Maple lied in his testimony.''

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LUNN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $203,000 for the latest year and $98,000 for the 1982 year.

title: WOR Radio to Replace Arlene Francis Show
description: ''The Arlene Francis Show,'' a daytime fixture on WOR radio for the last 23 years, will be replaced by news, commentary by Paul Harvey and food features, Robert Biernacki, vice president and general manager of the station, said yesterday.

title: BANKS SAY ARCO CREDIT IS READY
description: Arrangements for a $12 billion credit for the Atlantic Richfield Company were completed yesterday and banks are scheduled to sign the agreement on Monday, according to banking sources in New York and other cities. It would be the largest commercial loan ever made, and the proceeds would be used by Arco in its expected bid to acquire the Gulf Oil Corporation.

title: Nigeria City Summons Army To Quell Renewal of Rioting
description: The Nigerian Army was called in today to quell pockets of resistance from fundamentalist Moslem rioters in the northeastern city of Yola, where 137 people have died in violence this week, a senior police official said.

title: SALES OF NEW HOMES FELL BY 8% I JANUARY
description: Sales of new homes dropped 8 percent in January from December, the Government reported today, but most analysts said the decline was due more to a statistical quirk than any sign that the nation's economic recovery was being threatened.

title: ROBERTSON EXPECTED TO START
description: Manager Yogi Berra, noting that the weather had warmed sufficiently, said today that Andre Robertson would start at shortstop in the Yankees' opening exhibition game against Baltimore Saturday. It will mark the first game appearance for Robertson since he was injured in an automobile accident last Aug. 18.

title: Ivy Title Won By Princeton
description: Princeton won the Ivy League title last night, defeating Brown by 65-57 at Princeton, N.J., while Dartmouth was beating Cornell, 82-66, at Hanover, N.H. The victory gave Princeton a 10-4 Ivy League record, and Cornell closed its league season at 9-5.

title: NO PRIZE ROLES FOR AMERICAN MEN
description: L et's talk about actors. That four out of the five Oscar nominees for best actor of 1983 are British must tell us something, though exactly what is open to interpretation. It could be that the members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences are feeling especially One Worldish this year, or that British actors really are better than American.

title: No Headline
description: Mental Illness Linked To Threats to President

title: Dr. Jamie Lyn Hoffman Marries Paul Rosenfeld
description: Dr. Jamie Lyn Hoffman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Hoffman of Oreland, Pa., was married yesterday to Paul Charles Rosenfeld, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney M. Rosenfeld of East Williston, L.I. Rabbi Sidney Greenberg and Rabbi Elyse Goldstein performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in Dresher, Pa.

title: Public Rating of Reagan Lags on Separate Issues
description: President Reagan is given higher ratings for his handling of the Presidency in general than for his handling of any of seven important components of the job, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: BOARDWALK LOSING PLAYBOY BUNNIES
description: LAWRENCEVILLE ONE OF the first things that visitors to Atlantic City see is the Playboy symbol and trademark - the outline of a bunny's head and ears on a huge sign at the top of the 21-story Playboy Hotel-Casino. And if they go into the slim glass building, there is no missing the 316 dealers and cocktail waitresses dressed as Playboy bunnies.

title: GARDEN RESOLUTIONS GO QUICKLY ASTRAY
description: IN our household, the great debate has finally wound down. It concerned a colorful nest of seed catalogues accumulated on the kitchen table between the toaster and the napkin holder, and it had raged here since last fall.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Man of Many Courses If the notoriously tight market in academic jobs is looser this year, it could be because Paul Arthur Crafton is no longer in it. The authorities charged Mr. Crafton last year with teaching at two Pennsylvania colleges under assumed names while he was teaching at George Washington University under his real one.

title: DEBATE GROWS ON WETLANDS DEVELOPMENT
description: THREE years ago Ben Heller, a wealthy New York art dealer, paid $265,000 for about two and a half acres of prime undeveloped shorefront property in East Hampton. The site offered a magnificent view of Georgica Pond, and Mr. Heller and his wife, part-time residents of the area for 30 years, planned to build a new vacation home overlooking the water.

title: KNICKS FALL TO SURGE BY BUCKS
description: The Knicks, who thrived by the jump shot in the first half, lost to the Milwaukee Bucks last night when the jumper failed them in the second half, particularly in the final 2 minutes.

title: Abbe Schneider Is Wed
description: Abbe Sue Schneider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Schneider of Belle Harbor, Queens, was married yesterday to Russell Brian Gittle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Gittle of Brooklyn.

title: NEW POWERS, NEW POLITICS
description: Theodore White's article was an excellent analysis of current political trends; he ignored one important group, however - the elderly.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: No Headline
description: Faound Dead in His Car

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE PLAGUE OF SPECIAL INTEREST GROUPS
description: UNLESS Congress enacts legislation to prevent it, on April Fool's Day, the nation's bankruptcy court will cease to exist. And indeed we all may be the fools, victims of extraordinary lobbying efforts by special interest groups that have held up legislation that would establish a new court because of their selfish demands for unrelated bankruptcy amendments. How did the bankruptcy court system come to be so threatened?

title: Figure Skating Truly Olympian
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Richard Engaged To Kenneth J. Weiller
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jack Richard of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Richard, to Kenneth J. Weiller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Weiller of Hartsdale, N.Y. The wedding is to be in September.

title: SINGLE AGAIN AT 50
description: Martin Gottfried's article was sensitive and beautifully written. Except for this jarring note: ''I learned that a woman could come for a sleep-over while my daughter was there and I didn't have to feel guilty about it.''

title: Dying Man Denied Wish To Disconnect Device
description: A judge has refused to permit a hospital to grant a dying patient's request to be disconnected from a respirator.

title: NOT TWINS, JUST FRIENDS
description: While the fad for dressing twin children alike has faded from the scene, a new breed of dress- alikes who are just friends has blossomed into a sort of double take.

title: THE HAUNTING SPECTER OF TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: Several suicides by teen-agers in affluent suburban New York communities over the last few weeks have drawn attention to a phenomenon that is both frightening and baffling.

title: 7A Buildings
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCOS TO ALLOW REVIEW OF POWERS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, in a new gesture to his political opponents, said this week that he would submit his powers of decree to a review and possible abolition by the new Parliament to be elected in May.

title: ANTI-VATICAN PLAN REPORTED IN HANOI
description: Church officials here report that Vietnam is pressing to bring its three million Catholics under its direct control and isolate them from the Vatican.

title: Malone Under Fire
description: Harold Katz, the owner of the Philadelphia 76ers, is accompanying the team on its latest trip to get a first- hand look as to why the defending National Basketball Association champions are struggling, and he doesn't like what he sees. In an interview in yesterday's Philadelphia Inquirer, Katz said that Moses Malone, the league's most valuable player last season, was not earning his $2.2 million annual salary and that he lacked the intensity he showed last season, his first with the club.

title: IOWA WRESTLER IS ON A STREAK
description: IOWA CITY

title:
GARDENING;
SPRING FLOWER SHOWS ARE STARTING UP
description: NOW that the worst that winter has to offer is behind us, the time has arrived for spring flower shows to pop up here and there, almost like spring flowers themselves. After months of shoveling snow and battling icy streets, what could be more pleasant than to spend a few hours surrounded by fragrant, colorful spring flowers?

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTTER;
IN THE SHOES OF THE PATIENT
description: MOUNT KISCO THE man on the hospital bed was on his back, staring alternately out the window at a rain-heavy sky and a television attached to the wall. From the television speaker came the sounds of soap opera dialogue - words were overshadowed by the voice of a woman who swept swiftly into the room.

title: LUST, REVENGE AND REVOLUTION
description: -BONED DEMON

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
HARRY, THE NEW ATHENS, THE DAY OF THE PANCAKES
description: WHEN I was just a lad, back in the early 1930's my best friend for several months was Harry, a man in his late 60's. Harry, it seemed to me then, lived a wonderfully happy, prosperous, indolent life. Harry was a bookie.

title:
ART;
GRACEFULLY BLENDING WESTERN AND ORIENTAL TRADITIONS
description: -person shows by Japanese painters in East End galleries, and the artists' affinities go beyond the mere fact of shared nationality. Both are abstractionists and subtle colorists who use line with a grace and invention that owe as much to Western precedents as to Oriental tradition.

title: EUROPE, COMING AND GOING
description: PAUL LEWIS is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The New York Times.

title: No Headline
description: Youth Shoots Himself After Viewing Movies

title: STAGE: BILINGUAL 'O.K.' BY PUERTO RICAN GROUP
description: ''O.K.,'' a play by Isaac Chocron, a Venezuelan playwright, opened Wednesday night in its American premiere at the hands of the commendable Puerto Rican Traveling Theater. If effort were all, this talkative drama would rate an A. But effort is not all, and the grade must be dramatically reduced, lowering progressively as the plot unfolds in a format that is much too long for what it has to say.

title: Future Events
description: Dinners, Shows and Art

title: NEW BOOK: WORLD ACCORDING TO PRINCE PHILIP
description: Horses, sacred cows and targets of the two-legged kind are the main subjects of a newly published collection of the speeches and essays of Prince Philip.

title: THE ROBOT MAKERS STUB THEIR TOES
description: THE American robot industry was to be a star of the 80's, even the savior of smokestack America. The advanced billing attracted an avalanche of companies over the last five years, newcomers that hoped to make money by building machines that could do some of the dangerous, dirty and dreary jobs now done by humans.

title: ALMOST IRRESISTIBLE STELLA
description: MRS. PAT

title: Coroner to Remove Corneas
description: The coroner's office will routinely remove corneas from the eyes of corpses to ease a shortage for eye transplant patients as allowed under law, Dr. Boyd Stephens, head of the office, said Friday.

title: BLIND UROLOGIST DISCIPLINED FOR PERFORMING SURGERY
description: Six months after Dr. John R. Bongiovanni was blinded in an automobile accident in March 1980, he was back at his urology practice, making diagnoses, prescribing treatments and even performing minor surgery.

title: REFUGEE-AID EFFORT TROUBLED
description: CITING ''burnout,'' the Rev. Oden Woodward 2d of the Community Bible Church - a small evangelical group in Lawrence - says that a four-year, prodigious program for sponsoring and resettling hundreds of Southeast Asian refugees has just about flickered out.

title: IN TOKYO, OMOTE-SANDO IS A SYNONYM FOR STYLE
description: TERRY TRUCCO is a writer based in Tokyo.

title: CHINA SAYS CHERNENKO'S CALL FOR CLOSER TIES ISN'T ENOUGH
description: China today criticized a speech in Moscow by Konstantin U. Chernenko, saying that the remarks by the new Soviet leader had ignored Peking's conditions for improved ties.

title: INVESTOR RELATIONS: A HARD-SELL BOOM IN THE WOOING OF SHAREHOLDERS
description: IN an unusual move last month, the United States Steel Corporation called together a group of Wall Street analysts and money managers to announce its plan to acquire the National Steel Corporation. Company officials were worried about how the news of the merger would influence the company's stock price.

title: 'THE SHOW-OFF' AT THE PAPER MILL
description: MILLBURN THE Paper Mill Playhouse isn't showing off George Kelly's stock staple, ''The Show- off,'' with flying colors.

title: DRUNKEN-DRIVING LAW: PRO AND CON
description: Although I am a supporter and friend of MADD, I have to take issue with its contention that harsher penalties will be as effective a deterrent as roadblocks.

title: U.S. IS OPTIMISTIC ON MOSCOW SPEECH
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that remarks by the new Soviet leader, Konstantin U. Chernenko, seemed to reflect increased interest in exploring President Reagan's call for a more constructive dialogue.

title: HAVE A HART?
description: The big winner in the New Hampshire Presidential primary election was not Senator Gary-Have-A-Hart, but President Ronald Reagan.

title: THE REGION
description: A Longer Trudge For the Sludge

title: CONCERT: VIENNA PHILHARMONIC CONCLUDES SERIES
description: Leonard Bernstein and the Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra concluded their eight-city United States tour, and their three-concert New York visit, with a really wonderful program Friday night in Carnegie Hall. The music-making was not only gorgeous, but it served to put the seal on all three concerts, reminding us once again what a remarkable ensemble this is.

title: CIVIL DEFFENSE IS ACT OF LIFE IN GUATEMALA
description: It is the lines of men in military formation in small town squares that make weekend afternoons in the Guatemalan countryside different from those in most other Central American countries.

title: SOME U.S. AND SOVIET MISSILES JUDGED EQUAL
description: A Defense Department report to Congress asserts that the United States and the Soviet Union are now equal in the technological advancement of medium-range ballistic missiles.

title: Straw Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Adjusting Your Life To Avoid Overpaying
description: FOR working Americans, especially those in the higher-income brackets, any major move involves taxes - whether it's getting married or divorced, planning for the children's education or for retirement, scheduling a bonus or even donating to one's favorite charity. Therefore, while accountants advise against basing major life decisions on tax considerations, they do urge individuals to adopt financial strategies and tactics that will reduce their income taxes as much as possible, while letting them follow the lifestyle they have chosen.

title: Susan.., Specialists in Real Estate, Are Married
description: Susan Lee Stupin, the daughter of Mrs. Matthew Allen and the late Paul Alex Stupin of Bel Air, Calif., was married yesterday to Theodore Robert Gamble Jr., the son of Mrs. Gamble of St. Louis and the late Mr. Gamble. The Rev. John G. B. Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: RAPE TRIAL KEEPS MASSACHUSETTS AREA ON AN EMOTIONAL EDGE
description: The cold weather has cast a chill through the old gray-stone courthouse, but that has not discouraged the crowds that have filled the halls and stairways to wait for a chance to be admitted to a rape trial that has mesmerized this community.

title: FLOWER SHOW TIME: SPRING IS COMING
description: MORRISTOWN EVERY March for the last 18 years, the New Jersey Flower and Garden Show has been a harbinger of spring.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM GOSPEL SINGERS FO 'MARIENBAD'
description: Biographies of Two Souther Singers

title: TAXES AFTER DEATH CAN BE PLANNED
description: ESTATE planning is something that many people shirk. Its uneasy association with mortality makes it a subject to avoid, and many people fail to recognize that it is an integral part of practical financial responsibility. But what you do or do not do about arranging your estate can dramatically affect how much money eventually gets through to your heirs after taxes have been deducted. It is, therefore, imperative to arrange for the disposition of your assets after death just as carefully as you manage your finances during your lifetime.

title: WANTED: MUSEUM ON MILLS
description: FOR several years, the State Department of Economic Development has been trying without success to find someone interested in establishing a textile museum in northeast Connecticut, where woolen mills were once common along the myriad rivers and streams.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: 454 POTENTIAL BRINK'S JURORS EMERGE
description: THE first phase of jury selection in the Brink's robbery and murder trial, one of the most complex and controversial criminal cases to be heard in the county, ended last week with the selection of 454 potential jurors. They were selected from 2,598 residents whose screening process began in mid-February.

title: Leora Avital to Marry Dov Abramowitz in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. Moshe Avital of Whitestone, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter Leora Avital to Dov Abramowitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Abramowitz of Jerusalem, formerly of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: CHIEF'S VIEW ON BLACK CRIME ROILS MILWAUKEE
description: Police Chief Harold A. Breier, who at 72 has said he has no plans to retire, has touched off an uproar with his comments linking school busing to crime among black youths. His detractors call him a racist; his supporters say his ''tough-guy'' stance has helped keep Milwaukee safe.

title: Panthers Top Maulers On a Field Goal, 27-24
description: Novo Bojovic, who kicked a last- second field goal to give Michigan a 20-18 victory in its first game, kicked a 19-yarder with 32 seconds left tonight to help the Panthers overcome four turnovers for a 27-24 victory over the Pittsburgh Maulers.

title: Pinpoint Cause Of Ratings Drop
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TAX SHELTERS BOOM AS SOPHISTICATES SEEK RELIEF
description: ROSCOE L. Egger Jr., the Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service, when asked recently to list four factors that would likely enhance a taxpayer's chances of being audited, replied: ''Tax shelter, tax shelter, tax shelter'' and ''tax shelter.'' Mr. Egger was only half-joking.

title: Parker and Hegarty Set Records for IC4A Meet
description: John Parker of George Mason and Declan Hegarty of Boston University broke meet records in winning the only two finals today in the IC4A indoor track and field championships at Princeton.

title: WHEN 'GARF' SPEAKS, BASKETBALL LISTENS
description: T HE GARF was making a house call. It was midafternoon one day in late February and Howard Garfinkel, known generally as The Garf - age 54, black thinning hair combed flat on his head in the manner of a 1940's matinee idol, wearing glasses and blue sport jacket and red tie but no coat on this wintry day - had been picked up in a car by a companion from Garfinkel's apartment in Manhattan and they drove to a private school in Brooklyn.

title: More Is Needed to Stem Suicides by Youths
description: I would like to thank the teachers and staff of the Putnam Valley schools for their immediate and sensitive response to the recent tragedy in our town. I have one child in the elementary and a second in the junior high school. In each school, there was a sincere attempt to help children deal with the bewildering shock and confusion as the result of the suicide of a schoolmate.

title:
DINING OUT;
NOUVELLE MODE GROWS IN ARMONK
description: COVINGTON is as chic as ever. Upstairs, intimately lighted and pastelled to a peachy pink, charming alcoves give the feel of dining in private rooms. Downstairs, an imported English bar, all dark woods and sparkling cut glass is for all the world a pub, which, we hear, assuages homesickness in Englishmen transplanted to this vicinity. Service, given our memory of haughty hostesses and smarmy waiters, was notably friendly and gracious at the door and efficient, knowledgeable and concerned at the tables.

title:
GARDENING;
2-ACRE DISPLAY GIVES PREVIEW OF SPRING
description: IT isn't necessary to purchase an airplane ticket to some far-off wonderland where the weather is always balmy to enjoy a preview of spring. All one needs to do is to visit the Long Island Flower Show, which begins today and runs through March 11 at Nold Hall at the State University of New York at Farmingdale.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about share prices gave an incorrect stock quotation for the Charter Company.

title: MUSIC VIDEO LEAVES ITS MARK ON THE FILM 'FOOTLOOSE'
description: T he movie ''Footloose'' and its peppy soundtrack of high gloss junk-food songs (Columbia JS 39242) represents a crossroads in the romance between Hollywood movies and pop records that began six years ago with ''Saturday Night Fever.'' That romance has recently been given a fresh jolt of energy by the rise of music video. Suddenly, records, movies and video software have found themselves interrelated configurations of the same basic product.

title: Linden on Thurow
description: To the Editor:

title: 'DARLING, DARLING, HOLD TIGHT TO ME'
description: AUSTIN AND MABEL

title: STUD CITES $4.6 BILLION CUT IN U.S. AID IN STATE
description: Federal assistance to New York State and local governments in the state dropped by $4.6 billion in the last three years, according to an analysis of the impact of the Federal budget by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SHANGHAI
description: CHRISTOPHER S. WREN is The Times bureau chief in Peking.

title: UNIONS QUESTION WAGE STUDY
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH Governor Kean created a task force last December to investigate sex-based wage discrimination by the state government, two state employee unions have questioned his commitment and at least one legislator has said that the Governor could do more.

title: RECITAL: BISHOP SINGS LIEDER GROUP
description: Some singers are not given the voices they deserve, and Mahon Bishop is one of them. A baritone who made his New York debut in 1967 singing lieder, followed it with two more recitals and then disappeared from the New York concert scene after 1970, Mr. Bishop reappeared Wednesday night to sing songs by Brahms, Mahler, Wolf and Strauss in Alice Tully Hall.

title: THE HUNT FOR AN AFFORDABLE MORTGAGE
description: YOU are young and struggling to make ends meet, but you'd like to buy a home. If you are like most young people you probably can't qualify for a loan - particularly in New York City, where real estate prices have put home ownership out of reach for most first-time buyers.

title: A Heartening Summation
description: The general upturn in the economy did not fool the nearly 13,000 individuals who, in the past three months, contributed with unprecedented generosity to the 72d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. They realized that, even as unemployment declined and the recession faded, an intolerable number of unfortunate people were still left in the cold.

title: ON BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: SMART PLANNERS CAN CUT THEIR TAXES
description: IT is one of the milestones of any year, a date that is uniquely American and, for most of us, it is stamped on the memory as indelibly as the Fourth of July or Washington's Birthday. Unlike those holidays, however, April 15 is observed rather than celebrated, But it is never ignored. It is the day income taxes are due.

title: No Craftsmanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Glenn Raises Questions About Maturity of Rivals
description: Senator John Glenn said today that he would be a ''safe President'' and questioned whether his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination had the experience and maturity to act decisively in a nuclear emergency.

description: Bertha Harris is a novelist and critic who is completing her fourth novel, ''Living in the Past.'' GREAT EXPECTATIONS

title: AIR CRASH FATAL TO 4 TIED TO PILOT ERROR
description: -engine plane shortly after it took off from Lincoln Park Airport in Morris County was probably a result of pilot error after engine failure, say both veteran pilots who saw the crash and sources within the aviation industry.

title: UPSTATE PLATEAU IS NORTHEAST'S SNOWIEST AREA
description: People in this Lewis County hamlet did not consider the 16 inches of snow that they received this week a big deal.

title: VAN-POOL COMPANY EXPANDS
description: -based, nonprofit ride-sharing company, entered its third year of operation Friday.

title: Soviet Bloc War Games End
description: Five days of Warsaw Pact maneuvers involving Soviet, Polish and East German armies in western and northwestern Poland ended Friday, the official Polish press agency reported today. ''Socialist states must maintain their alertness and strengthen the defensive power of the coalition community,'' the agency's dispatch quoted Poland's Deputy Defense Minister, Gen. Eugeniusz Molczyk, as saying.

title: Headliners
description: Walter Polovchak, Cont. It's hardly unusual for adolescents to disagree with their parents, but when Walter Polovchak did so it was an international incident.

title: GETTING THE ITCH TO TRAVEL AGAIN
description: IN late winter the symptoms recur. Our disease, in remission since last summer, strikes us yet again with the appearance of the latest vacation brochures. We suffer alone, forgotten, understood only by fellow-victims of peregrine mania, the compulsive urge to travel.

title: Miss Moore Has Nuptials
description: Carroll Flippin Moore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Moore of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to William Eugene Spears 3d, the son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Spears Jr. of Beaufort, S.C. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich assisted by the bridegroom's father, who is pastor of the Baptist Church of Beaufort.

title: Gold Defeats Outlaws On Overtime Field Goal
description: Brian Speelman kicked a 17-yard field goal after 31 seconds of overtime to give the Denver Gold a 17-14 victory over the Oklahoma Outlaws in a United States Football League game today before a crowd of 24,917 at Skelly Stadium.

title: THE IMPACT OF JESSE JACKSON
description: Ronald Smothers, a Times reporter, has been covering the Jesse Jackson campaign. THE REV. JESSE JACKSON STOOD QUIETLY in the rear of his chartered campaign plane, his hands pushing lightly against the cabin's ceiling. For the moment, the campaign was at rest and the plane sat on the runway waiting to take off into the foggy February night from Manchester, N.H., for Providence, R.I. It was a rare moment of calm in Jackson's frenetic campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but the calm was deceptive. The day before, Jackson had decided to go to Rhode Island. The state hardly figures prominently in the Presidential primaries, but Jackson wanted to pick up Frances Crowe, a white, 64-year-old peace activist from Northampton, Mass., who is co-founder of one of his support committees in Massachusetts. Mrs. Crowe, a popular figure in New England's antiwar and antinuclear movements, was being released from a Rhode Island state prison after serving 30 days for painting, along with other protesters, ''Thou Shalt Not Kill'' on Trident missile casings in Quonset.

title: DON'T FEAR PALESTINIAN TALKS
description: It has recently been revealed that an intermediary of the Reagan Administration held exploratory talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1981 and 1982. Instead of saying that it was performing a useful service by mediating between Israelis and Palestinians, the White House acted guilty of some wrongdoing. This was a mistake.

title: A Glossary of Tax Jargon
description: If you could deduct a dollar for every word of jargon on your tax return, chances are, you would owe a lot less tax. Experts may or may not help. Worse still, you can pay dearly for their advice.

title: SPORTING WAYS TO SURF FISH
description: A RECENT halcyon day moved me to think of angling, an urge that centered on surf fishing when I reached for a froe in my workshop and caught my sleeve on a saltwater casting plug I had hung there last fall because it needed new hooks.

title: DEVIL'S BAG IS 4TH
description: At the top of the stretch, it was clear that the spell was broken, that the undefeated and untested sensation named Devil's Bag had been tested and had failed.

title: POLISH PRIMATE SAYS REMARKS ON WALESA WERE MISUNDERSTOOD
description: The head of Poland's Roman Catholic Church, who was quoted by a Brazilian newspaper as saying that the Solidarity union ''no longer defends the working class,'' said today that the paper had misinterpreted his comments.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE PONDERS NEW HAMPSHIRE'S MESSAGE
description: The new turmoil in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination brought delight to President Reagan's re-election campaign. But it also provided some sobering reminders that Mr. Reagan cannot count on an easy re-election campaign himself.

title: PLANT GROWERS EXPECT GAIN
description: WITH energy costs lowered by new technology, Long Island's plant and flower industry expects to flourish this spring as never before, according to wholesale growers and their spokesmen.

title: Miss Whipple, Schoolteacher, To Be Married
description: Mrs. Edward F. Swift 3d and Jay N. Whipple Jr., both of Lake Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Cox Whipple, to David Marinan McKenna, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. McKenna of Fairfield, Conn.

title: 81 WESTPORT UNITS
description: Hoping to appeal to buyers looking for the space of the single- family house along with the convenience of condominium communities, a Westport, Conn., developer has broken ground for an 81-residence project in that town's Carriage Hill section. It will have condominium units ranging in size from 1,780 to 2,550 square feet.

title: COMPLEX FOR SALE
description: When the American Can Company, one of the nation's largest producers of metal containers, left Manhattan in 1970, it moved into new headquarters built to its specifications in Greenwich, Conn. Now the 181-acre complex is up for sale for $192 million.

title: BEHIND THE DEINDUSTRIALIZATION DEBATE
description: Fugitive Industry: The Economics and Politics of Deindustrialization, by Richard B. McKenzie. Ballinger Publishing Company, Cambridge, Mass. 312 pages. $35.

title: THE REVIVAL OF GOD
description: RELIGION IN THE SECULAR CITY

title: Catherine Copp, C. E. Colley Plan Summer Nuptials
description: -1-18, 3 lines cut Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Copp of Glen Cove, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Kent Copp, to Cornelius Eugene Colley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Omer Colley of North Salem, N.Y., and Southampton, Bermuda. A summer wedding is planned.

title: LEARNING TO LIVE WITH GRIEG-AND LOVING IT
description: T he Norse are moving into Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow night, even if the orchestra is the American Symphony conducted by Yuri Krasnapolsky. Arve Tellefsen, considered Norway's premier violinist, will play the Shostakovich Concerto. Kjell Baekkelund, Norway's top pianist, will be heard in - what else? - the Grieg Concerto. And the Grieg C minor Symphony will also be heard in this concert, which is sponsored by a group of Norwegian businessmen.

title: WHO PAYS FOR EXECUTIVE SINS?
description: THE Securities and Exchange

title: 1st Soviet High-Speed Train
description: The Soviet Union's first high-speed train has gone into operation between Moscow and Leningrad, cutting travel time from eight hours to five, Moscow newspapers report. They said the ER-200 Express completed its first round trip Friday traveling at speeds of up to 112 miles an hour on the 440-mile journey. The new train, which carries 380 passengers, travels on a conventional track and tickets cost the same as for the regular overnight sleepers.

title: Patterson Betters 1,000 Mark
description: Maurice Patterson, who holds the Catholic High School indoor championship mark for 1,000 meters, became the Public Schools Athletic League's indoor championship record-holder in the event as well yesterday.

title: TEACHING: LEGISLATURE JOINS FRAY
description: TRENTON THE State Legislature has joined the dispute over the Kean administration's proposal to let teachers be certified without their having taken traditional teacher-training courses.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Supreme Court Limits Law on Discrimination

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Brain Power

title: MCGOVERN BANKING ON MASSACHUSETTS
description: George McGovern is telling Massachusetts audiences the fate of his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination is in the hands of the voters in their primary election March 13.

title: PRIDE TAKES SHAPE FROM BLOCKS OF WOOD
description: WHAT has wings and a tail, is painted gold, and takes exactly two hours to produce? Answer: a handmade wooden airplane from Michael J. Brennick's after-school carpentry workshop in Larchmont.

title: INVESTING WITH AN EYE ON THE AFTER-TAX RETURN
description: ALTHOUGH Benjamin Franklin's remark that ''in this world nothing is certain except death and taxes'' has been accepted for two centuries, careful investors today can choose from a variety of tax-advantaged instruments that whittle down the size of the tax bite or defer it for years.

title: 'Curves of Pursuit'
description: To the Editor:

title: New Frontier or Familiar Fringe?
description: There's a familiar ring to Gary Hart's win over Walter Mondale in New Hampshire last week - or, rather, two familiar rings.

title: RECORD NOTES ; WANTED: A BETTER PACKAGE
description: A s the newer recording mediums - cassettes and Compact Disks - make their way into our consciousness and take up more and more time away from LP listening, a number of irritations are becoming evident, irritations that just weren't there with the LP.

title: Luci Baines Johnson Marries at the Ranch
description: Luci Baines Johnson, the younger daughter of Lyndon B. Johnson, married Ian Turpin today at the Johnson Ranch.

title: THE FUTURE OF STATE OWNERSHIP
description: Nationalized Companies: A Threat to American Business, by R. Joseph Monsen and Kenneth D. Walters. McGraw-Hill, N.Y. 178 pages. $17.95.

title: GREENMARKET HELD IN UNION SQUARE BRIGHTENS A GRAY SEASON
description: A biting wind was blowing through Union Square yesterday, but at the square's southern end, in a parking lot near 14th Street, scores of Saturday morning shoppers shrugged off the chilly weather to buy and browse at the open-air greenmarket.

title: Dirk Morgan Van Doren, Janet H. Wakana Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Minoru T. Wakana of Caribou, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Harue Wakana, to Dirk Morgan Van Doren, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester A. Van Doren of Ridgewood, N.J.

title: MISS IMA'S LEGACY OF AMERICANA
description: Houston might seem an unlikely place to look for one of the finest collections of early American decorative arts in the entire nation - and least of all to find there a permanent display of the material culture produced in Colonial New England, New York and Pennsylvania. Nevertheless, just such a collection does exist in a remarkable ''house museum'' in Houston. Moreover, the museum is both an expression of one woman's esthetic enthusiasm and an extension of her personality.

title: Dewey and Lehman
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN TO REQUIRE BUDGET BALANCE FOR U.S. FALTERS
description: Despite the record Federal budget deficit and polls showing increased public concern about it, a national drive to petition Congress to call a convention to draft a constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget appears to have run out of steam this year.

title: IS THERE AN AUDIENCE FOR SERIOUS DRAMA?
description: To the Editor:

title: PRAYER CAMPAIGN GOING TO CAPITOL
description: The Presidential election campaign will come to Capitol Hill Monday as the Senate begins a major debate over a proposed constitutional amendment that would permit organized prayer in the public schools.

title: IONA EARNS BERTH WITH 72-61 VICTORY
description: Iona became the first team to gain official admittance to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament today as Steve Burtt, the school's leading career scorer, had 33 points to lead a 72-61 victory over Fordham.

title: ALLURING OFFERINGS
description: THE cultural calendar in the county is crowded with events of every description over the next fortnight, including several that have the added attraction of being free. This afternoon, for example, no tickets are needed for the 3 P.M. concert by the Yonkers Civic Philharmonic at Saunders High School on Palmer Road, where the Riverdale pianist Edith Cornfield will play the Beethoven Third Concerto and Jerome Sala will conduct popular classics of Rossini, Tchaikovsky and Richard Rodgers.

title: Defending the Poor: Two Questions
description: In reply to the article ''Private Lawyers Offer to Defend the Poor'' (Jan. 22), it appears that the second half of the title should read ''Who's kidding whom?'' The article basically revolves around two questions:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am interested in leisure in the same way that a poor man is interested in money. I can't get enough of it.'' - Prince Philip. (10:4.)

title: Many States' Recovery Slow ;
description: Recovery of Economy Slow in Many States

title: SUZUKI MUSICIANS PERFORM IN 'PLAY-IN'
description: ANY parent contemplating (with trepidation) a birthday party for 2- and 3-year- olds might look with awe on Lisa Barca-Hall's accomplishments. Mrs. Barca-Hall has been known to gather 100 youngsters together, enticing them not with cake and ice cream, but with promises of making wonderful music together.

title: USING LANDMARKS
description: After more than two years of negotiating with the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission and local community groups, a Long Island developer has received approval for a 13-story office project on West 55th Street that will incorporate two landmark buildings on 54th Street informally known as the Rockefeller town houses.

title: GEORGETOWN BEATS SYRACUSE, TAKES BIG EAST TITLE
description: Pat Ewing produced 16 points and 6 of his Georgetown teammates scored in double figures today as the Hoyas beat Syracuse by 88-71 to win the Big East regular-season championship.

title: FRESH SEAFOOD WITH SIMPLICITY
description: FISHTALES in Manhasset looks like a typical neighborhood pub or gathering place, but from the name you can correctly assume the emphasis on seafood rather than burgers and fried zucchini. What this restaurant may lack in atmosphere and elegance (tables are bare wood set with paper napkins and place mats that double as menus) is more than offset by its straightforward honesty, fresh food and very reasonable prices.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Low Marks for Export Controls

title: ART ; PROMINENT COLLECTION IS IN ATHENEUM'S SPOTLIGHT
description: THE news from Hartford is of the Tremaine Collection, which is being exhibited for only the second time, at the Wadsworth Atheneum. The first time was in 1947 and that, too, was at the Atheneum.

title: SAUSAGE: PLEASANT TO BOTH THE POCKETBOOK AND THE TASTE BUDS
description: THINK of fresh pork sausage for savory meals that do not ruin the food budget for the week. The rich spiciness of well-made sausage is so satisfying that relatively small portions of the meat, mixed with other ingredients, can be calculated when planning the cooking.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: AN ENVIRONMENTAL organization in Cape May has recommended that the county's Planning Board provide a regular accounting of lands that would be available for preservation, either by the county itself or by private conservation groups.

title: PORTUGUESE PRESS OPPOSES NEW LAW
description: Portuguese journalists have expressed strong opposition to a proposed new press law, calling it ''the most violent attack on the freedom of the press'' since the 1974 revolution.
