title: Boggs Put on Probation
description: Tommy Boggs, the former pitcher for the Atlanta Braves, has pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor gambling charge and has been sentenced to a year's probation and a $1,000 fine in Decatur, Ga. The plea was in connection with an alleged sports gambling ring broken up in DeKalb County last fall.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In ''What's Doing in Montreal'' (Travel, Feb. 12) an incorrect room rate was given for the Four Seasons Hotel. The hotel charges $74 (United States dollars) a night for a double room on weekends and from $117 on weeknights.

title: DISMISSAL SPURS BIAS CHARGES
description: DURING the two years that Sally Thompson was principal at Northeast Elementary School in Amityville, students' scores on achievement tests in mathematics and reading reached their highest level in four years.

title: A REPRIEVE FOR AN OLD FAVORITE
description: THERE are many people who remember the Red Barn when it was one of the few good culinary spots in Fairfield County and when its starched white linen and fresh flowers made it a favorite for Mother's Day and special occasions.

title: India and Pakistan To Discuss Peace Treaty
description: India and Pakistan, which have fought each other in three wars over 35 years, will discuss proposals for detente in May, the Indian Government announced today.

title: A $12 BILLION LOAN TO BUY GULF OIL?
description: Atlantic Richfield, with the help of Chase Manhattan and some 70 other banks, put together the biggest line of credit ever amassed - $12 billion for the purchase of Gulf Oil. Wall Street professionals estimated that the offering price could range from $72 a share to $80. And while Arco and perhaps others were pursuing Gulf in earnest, Gulf was earnestly trying to avoid the clutch of T. Boone Pickens. The No. 6 oil company opened its books and confidential financial data to serious suitors, said to include Arco, Standard Oil of California and even Kohlberg, Kravis & Roberts, the leveraged-buyout firm. A formal bid, most likely from Arco, is expected soon. Meanwhile, Texaco shares continued to rise on the New York Stock Exchange in response to speculation linked to the Bass family of Texas, which currently holds nearly 10 percent of the stock. While the Basses have said nothing, rumors of some sort of move against Texaco have helped support the stock. But analysts estimated it would take about $20 billion to buy Texaco.

title:
CAMERA;
CLUBS AND ASSOCIATIONS FOR THE PHOTOGRAPHER
description: Regardless of whether your involvement with photography is as a casual snapshooter or as a serious practitioner of the art,one of the best ways to get more pleasure from photography, and enlarge your horizons in this field, is by joining a camera club or a photographic association of some kind. Fortunately, there are a number of different types of membership organizations available that can prove helpful to those who want to explore new interests and improve their abilities.

title: Federal Program
description: Connecticut will offer a new group of low-cost mortgages tomorrow, but they will be the last because Federal authorization for states to issue tax-free bonds to finance such mortgages for homebuyers has expired. New York and New Jersey already have made their last offerings backed by tax-free bond issues.

title: CHOOSING A FITNESS REGIME
description: If a woman wants to lose weight and strengthen her cardiovascular system, should she walk, run or swim? She would like to strengthen and shape her legs. Should she cycle, do calisthenics or take aerobic dance? She needs to increase her flexibility. Should she take a gymnastics class or study yoga?

title: CANDIDATES IN SALVADOR WATCHING THEIR BACKS
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Roberto d'Aubuisson, the presidential candidate for the far-right National Republican Alliance (Arena), and Hugo Barrera, his running mate, drove up to the marketplace in Chalatenango in a covered jeep. Men with pistols and submachine guns jumped out in front of them to circle the stand from which Mr. d'Aubuisson would speak.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
WANTED: MORE JUDGES FOR SWIFTER JUSTICE
description: IF you were to write an employment advertisement for a judge

title: Judo, a Sport For Everyone
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHERE'S THE SECRET INGREDIENT?
description: THE wail of a househusband is nothing new anymore. But I've come to know something that everybody else in the world has forgotten, even mothers: the value of food. I don't mean its nutritional value, which we sometimes pay attention to. I mean food's intrinsic value, which falls on deaf ears.

title: SHOULD WOMEN DRESS LIKE MEN?
description: It is surprising, especially to those who can still muster surprise about anything these days, that one of the most commercially successful fashion images this year, and last, was and is one that employs a psychosexual subtext purely androgynous in nature. The image in question is that used by Calvin Klein to advertise his new underwear for women, underwear directly derived in shape and spirit from men's briefs. The advertisement, a black-and-white photograph that has appeared in everything from national magazines to bus stops to Times Square billboards, has become imprinted on the urban mind with all the semi-permanence of a catchy jingle for chewing gum.

title: FORMER PROSECUTOR TO PAY COUPLE IN SEDITION CASE
description: A former District Attorney of Pike County, Ky., has agreed to pay what was described as ''a substantial part'' of a $1.2 million judgment against him for violating the civil rights of two antipoverty workers who were arrested for sedition in 1967 in the remote Appalachian mountain region.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CLEANUP ON EVEREST, A WORKING VACATION ABROAD
description: Four Treks To Everest

title: Michaels and Robinson Meeting Again
description: The United States Football League is the league of the second chance for some and a first chance for others.

title: Patricia Morrison Weds in Garden City
description: -2-18 Patricia Gray Morrison, a daughter of Justice Henderson William Morrison of the New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Morrison of Garden City, L.I., and Long Eddy, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew John De Joseph, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph De Joseph of Howard Beach, Queens, and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Edward McGinnis and the Rev. Vincent Hagan performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City.

title: WELSH PURITAN MEETS BOHEMIAN JEW
description: Ronald Varney is a freelance writer who lives in New York City. AN AMERICAN SAGA

title: ARTISTS IN SURVEY, SAY THEY HEAR SPACE CALL
description: Astronauts and scientists should be joined in orbit by poets, painters and other creative people, say hundreds of people in the arts who responded to a questionnaire.

title: NATURE WATCH
description: KITTIWAKE

title: JERSEY PROTESTS DUMPING BY CITY
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey came to New York yesterday to lodge a familiar complaint against the city's daily dumping of millions of gallons of raw sewage into the Hudson River.

title: JOURNEY THROUGH PATAGONIA
description: EDWARD SCHUMACHER is chief of The New York Times bureau in Buenos Aires.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HIKING AGENDA
description: Although the calendar says ''early March,'' signs of spring are in evidence throughout the Island. To find out just how far the seasonal transition has gone, the hearty may want to venture out on some of the nature walks available this week.

title:
ANTIQUES;
IT'S PRINCETON SHOW'S 25TH YEAR
description: PRINCETON SPRING, the most popular season for antiques shows, is still more than two weeks away, but that has not stopped the scheduling of many such events.

title: FIVE PEOPLE GIRD UP FOR THE ANNUAL TAX GAME
description: like sports - can be a year-round occupation, a profession with skills to be honed, sharpened and perfected. But for the great majority, the income-tax marathon, like the New York City or Boston Marathon, is a once- a-year event. Some taxpayers view the Internal Revenue Service with fear and trepidation, while others look forward to their annual encounter with the service - like a match to be won, the college all stars' chance to beat the pros. Here are five of the players in the game. The taxpayers, not surprisingly, asked that pseudonyms be used, but there is no shield of anonymity for the pros.

title: Hospitals Will Test 3 Drugs To Prevent Cardiac Deaths
description: Three new drugs will be tested on 900 heart attack victims considered to be at high risk in an effort to prevent sudden cardiac deaths.

title: READING THE PRESIDENT'S MIND
description: RONALD REAGAN

title: CONGRESS AGENCY QUESTIONS NEW WARSHIP'S ROLE
description: A recent report from the Congressional Budget Office questions whether the Arleigh Burke class destroyer, a billion-dollar Navy warship that is to enter production later this year, is suitable for future naval warfare.

title: Peter A. Levitan to Wed Tracy Young, AssistantDistrictAttorneyinBrooklyn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Winthrop Young Jr. of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mr. Young's daughter, Tracy Winthrop Young, to Peter Allen Levitan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Jules Levitan of Jamaica, Queens. Miss Young is the daughter also of Mrs. David Smith of Hastings, England.

title: RESOLVING CONTRACT DISPUTES
description: WHEN a homeowner deals with a remodeling contractor, a dispute between the parties can leave thousands of dollars worth of construction work unusable until it is resolved.

title: FILING THE RETURN
description: AT first glance, the 1983 Federal income tax forms appear little changed from last year. But closer examination will disclose some major changes that, while they promise to reduce the overall tax burden, produce unpleasant surprises for individuals who try to take advantage of certain traditional tax breaks.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM GOSPEL SINGERS TO 'MARIENBAD'
description: The Last Sailors

title: Laurel Gross Is Engaged
description: Laurel B. Gross, the entertainment and television editor of The New York Post, and Steven D. Alschuler, press secretary to State Senator Roy M. Goodman, plan to be married May 20. The future bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Gross of Bayside, Queens, graduated from the Packer Collegiate Institute and Bard College. Mr. Alschuler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Alschuler of the Bronx, is an alumnus of the Bronx High School of Science and Queens College.

title: AMMUNITION FOR COIN CRITICS
description: Many players shy away from tournaments because they ''don't understand all those new-fangled conventions.'' But it is a reason that does not hold water.

title: International
description: Heavy fighting in Beirut between Lebanese Army troops and anti-Government militiamen along the line dividing east and west in the capital dashed hopes for a quick cease-fire guaranteed by Syria. The intense clashes occurred as President Amin Gemayel held another day of negotiations with Lebanese Christian and Moslem leaders in an effort to win support for his understanding with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria on a framework for a settlement of Lebanon's political strife. Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Tax Lawyer Is Fiance Of Aphrodite Mavricos
description: A May wedding is planned by Aphrodite Mavricos, an industry analyst for the Mobil Oil Corporation in New York, and Bruce Dwight Garrison, who is a tax lawyer for Mobil. Mr. and Mrs. Marius Mavricos of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter to a son of Carrie Wallach Garrison of Ossining, N.Y., and the late William Hart Garrison.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find paticularly appealing.

title: Changing Times
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS March 4, 1984Fiction
description: 1 1984, by George Orwell. (NAL/Signet, $2.95.) The classic 1949 novel about life in a society where Big Brother watches.

title: THE SIXTH MAN
description: Alex Ward is editor of The New York Times Living Section. MICHAEL COOPER IS 6 FEET 7 inches tall, with long, thin legs, a narrow waist and an upper body that fans out like a V into a pair of shoulders so acutely angular they might be supported by a crossbeam. Cooper running at full speed is a picture of graceful efficiency: He seems simply to glide, feet never touching the ground. When he jumps, we're talking serious levitation. Like a Mirage jet, he is built to soar.

title: GREECE'S CLAIM TO THE ELGIN MARBLES
description: T HE

title: Tim Page Weds Vanessa Weeks
description: Vanessa Marie Weeks, the daughter of Mary Zoe Phillips and Alan Ray Weeks, both of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Tim Page, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Batten Page of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. David B. Rickey performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Episcopal Church in New York.

title: WALL STREET TOUTS BANK STOCKS
description: MILLIONS of Americans save in banks, and now, if you believe the reports that Wall Street is churning out, it may be time to invest in them, as well. To many analysts, the big money center banks are a buy, as their stock prices have been depressed by loan exposures to developing countries. But these shares may not be for the weak of heart, since their purchase is a sizable bet on whether the banks will ever be repaid the billions lent to developing countries. And that may be unknown for years.

title: Sports of The Times; Ueberroth Finds His 'Disaster'
description: P ETER UEBERROTH was once asked what he planned to do after his presidency of the 1984 Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, and he replied: ''Most likely I'll try to find a major corporation that's in trouble. That's the fun of doing something. The bigger the company and the more disastrous its position, the more it would interest me.''

title: DANCE: MOULTON'S 'VARIETY SHOW'
description: Charles Moulton's dances are like pinwheels, casting off bright complete fragments as they spin. Mr. Moulton, a former Merce Cunningham dancer, is one of the most acclaimed of the younger modern-dance choreographers. A program presented Wednesday in the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater was packed with those bright fragments. And if the three new pieces weren't Mr. Moulton at his most incisive, they offered the considerable simpler pleasures of his dance.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: In article in The Magazine today quotes the Rev. Jesse Jackson as saying that it was ''not true'' that he had referred to Jews as ''Hymies'' and to New York as ''Hymietown,'' and that he had ''no recollection'' of doing so. After The Magazine went to press, Mr. Jackson acknowledged making the remark and expressed regret for it.

title: CLOTHING DESIGNS CARRY A MESSAGE
description: -painted clothing business two years ago, her designs were pretty and popular. Now they are becoming political as well, as the 31-year-old Chilean-born artist turns to her past for inspiration.

title: ARMY'S CHAPLAIN'S ARE AT CENTER OF LEGAL DEBATE
description: When Capt. Jay Romans, an Army chaplain, is faced with young soldiers too frightened to jump out of a military plane flying high above this sprawling base, he stops for a moment and whispers a little prayer. Then he walks to the door of the airplane and leaps out.

title: SOME SECOND THOUGHTS ON MOMENTS OF SILENCE IN THE SCHOOLS
description: Roger Baldwin, the founder of the American Civil Liberties Union, frequently said that ''no fight for civil liberty ever stays won.'' That dictum was demonstrated here last week. Twenty-two years after the Supreme Court appeared to put the matter of prayer in the public schools to rest by declaring it unconstitutional, a school board and a community are divided over the question. The mother of a seventh-grade student, backed by the Nassau County chapter of the New York Civil Liberties Union - which brought the landmark case in 1962 - contended that schools are again sponsoring prayer by beginning each day with a moment of silence.

title: MYSTERY GROWS OVER SEIZURE OF ARMS LINKED TO WARSAW
description: In the predawn darkness of Feb. 21, as a pilot and two other men loaded scores of heavy wood crates into a private jet in a remote area of Kennedy International Airport, a car carrying armed customs agents roared out onto the airfield and drew up at the plane.

title: IN THE NATION'S FARM BELT, IT'S A CASE OF USE IT OR LOSE IT
description: Gary Lamb stopped his car on a gravel road overlooking the Iowa River and trudged into a weed-choked field marred by wind and water erosion.

title: Jennifer M. Engel Is Wed at Cornell
description: -1-18, 2 lines Jennifer Margaret Engel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gehrels Engel of New York and Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J., was married in Ithaca, N.Y., yesterday to Lawrence Paul Young, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Paul Milton Young Jr. of Rochester. The bridegroom's father, retired pastor of the Lutheran Church of the Resurrection in Rochester, performed the ceremony in the Sage Chapel at Cornell University.

title: On Balance
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine Ellen Lehman to Marry Robert Gursha
description: -2-14 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Charles Lehman of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Catherine Ellen Lehman to Robert Gursha, a son of the late Col. Alvin Gursha, U.S.A., retired, and the late Mrs. Gursha of Elkton, Md., and Pittsburgh.

title: Opera in Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRE DAMAGES HOMELESS GROUP'S INTENDED SHELTER
description: Mishaps and miracles have always seemed to characterize life at Emmaus House, a small community of homeless men and women in Harlem led by the Rev. David Kirk, a Catholic priest of the Eastern Rite.

title: Miss Wilcox Plans to Wed
description: Mrs. James Simpson Wilcox Jr. of Charlotte and Blowing Rock, N.C., has announced the engagement of her daughter Cordelia Penn Wilcox to Francis Sunfield Branin Jr., the son of Mrs. Branin of Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Branin. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Mr. Wilcox.

title: Zoning for Good Chocolates
description: Mrs. Shirley Bernstein lives at Park Avenue and 75th Street, an expensive New York address, and she does a public service in urging officials to make a new delicatessen across the street from her conform to building, zoning and landmark laws. But she leaves the law behind when she also demands a store selling Swiss and Belgian chocolates but not fruit and American cheese to unwelcome people.

title: RATE FEARS SPUR BUILDING AND BUYING
description: ''NINETEEN EIGHTY-FOUR is going to be a super, super year for builders and home buyers,'' said Saul Muchnick, a Long Island builder of single-family houses. ''But 1985 is imponderable. There is so much uncertainty about the Federal deficits and the 1985 economy, I am rushing to get two new jobs going before next year.''

title: ROBERTSON IMPRESSES IN PLAYING 5 INNINGS
description: The key thing was, Andre Robertson said, ''I had fun. I liked it.''

title:
GARDENING;
2-ACRE DISPLAY GIVES PREVIEW OF SPRING
description: IT isn't necessary to purchase an airplane ticket to some far-off wonderland where the weather is always balmy to enjoy a preview of spring. All one needs to do is to visit the Long Island Flower Show, which begins today and runs through March 11 at Nold Hall at the State University of New York at Farmingdale.

title: ONLY SMALL TAX CHANGES ARE ON THIS YEAR'S AGENDA
description: THIS election year is not the time for major tax increases or major tax changes. But it is a year, tax writers on Capitol Hill and in the Reagan Administration agree, for many little tax changes--ones that will catch the attention of special interests from local governments to the life insurance industry and from T. Boone Pickens Jr. to airline employees.

title: Miss Navratilova, Mrs. Lloyd in Final
description: Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert Lloyd had markedly different warm-ups yesterday for their three- of-five-set final today in the Virginia Slims Championships, with Miss Navratilova surviving a testing semifinal against Pam Shriver and Mrs. Lloyd cruising to victory over Barbara Potter.

title: 14 Journalism Awards Announced by L.I.U.
description: Fourteen George Polk Awards, including two for reporters of The New York Times, have been announced by Long Island University.

title: THE TRENCH-COAT MYSTIQUE
description: One of the first men's- wear styles to be adopted by women was the trench coat. And of all the items of men's clothing that women have borrowed for their own wardrobes, it continues to be a favorite.

title: THE CHOICE OF ACCESSORIES
description: Because they are the punctuation points of fashion, accessories-hats, golves, shoes, jewelry or belts-often set the look of a style or outfit. So it is not surprising that, in this spring season when some designers are offering decorative ''decked out'' looks and others are espousing the minimal line, accessories take the same routes.

title: ELUSIVE QUEST FOR NEW IMAGE MAKER
description: It would seem a Madison Avenue advertising agency's dream. The commodity is already popular in the marketplace. The advertising budget is almost $25 million and the client is President of the United States.

title: MOSCOW'S AIRPORT: SOVIET TO THE CORE
description: JOHN F. BURNS is the Moscow bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: ADMINISTRATION TALKS FREE TRADE, ACTS TO PROTECT INDUSTRY
description: The Reagan Administration, facing an unprecedented trade deficit of more than $100 billion this election year, has found itself on the defensive, caught between mounting demands for protection and charges that its economic policies are causing a decline in American competitiveness.

title: Dr. Stacy Nerenstone to Marry in June
description: Dr. Stacy Ruth Nerenstone, a clinical instructor at Harvard Medical School, and Dr. Paul Jay Cohen, a researcher at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, plan to be married in June.

title: No Headline
description: Marjorie Heller Is Wed

title: SHEDDING LIGHT ON DIAGHILEV AND GRAHAM
description: T wo exhibitions of photographs and other materials that are dance-related are of special interest this month and should not be overlooked. One includes documents that are as fascinating as Serge Diaghilev's contract regulations for his dancers in the Ballets Russes where they are warned not to carry canes or wear hats and coats at rehearsals. Nor are they allowed to object to any role or to be absent from home for more than two hours without making known, in writing, where they can be reached!

title: IRISH LORE AND AMERICAN MARRIAGE
description: EACH year, Theater Three in Port Jefferson presents one world premiere, and this year it's ''Irish Legacy'' by Chick O'Brien. Mr. O'Brien uses the device of telling his tale through a man fresh off the plane from the Emerald Isle.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THURSDAY is International Women's Day, celebrated worldwide to commemmorate women's strikes for better working conditions and the right to vote, and to protest child labor.

title: U.S. READY TO START THIS ELECTION YEAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxing Social Security
description: LIKE it or not, a lot of Americans may find that they are not the only ones benefiting from their Social Security benefits. For the first time, the Federal Government will be getting a cut as well. Starting with 1984 returns, recipients may have to declare up to one half of their benefits as taxable income. The very well-to-do will have little escape, but those on the margin, may be able to shift income from municipal bonds into other investments, such as higher yielding corporate bonds.

title: CABLE OPERATORS TAKE A BRUISING
description: LAST month, Cox Cable Communications, the nation's fourth-largest cable operator, stunned Baltimore officials with the news that it was dropping out of the bidding to cable the city. At the same time, Cablevision of Boston raised subscriber rates for some services - and withdrew other proposed increases only after the Mayor threatened court action.

title: 'GIGI': STILL PLENTY OF LIFE
description: IN America, ''Gigi'' has traveled

title: HITTING THE BEACH WITH GRANDMA
description: CATHLEEN SCHINE is the author of ''Alice in Bed'' (Knopf).

title: THE REGION
description: Building a New Building Code

title: ENOUGH WITH THE FREEDOM, THANK YOU
description: In the last few years, the fashion business has changed from a dictatorship into a democracy and it's not working.

title: Work and Family
description: To the Editor:

title: MAY NUPTIALS PLANNED BY JUDITH L. GOLDMANN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Goldmann of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Lynn Goldmann, to Dennis Paul Novick, son of Frances Novick of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Jerry Novick. A May wedding is planned.

title: MAYOR KOCH'S MEMOIR
description: After reading Edward I. Koch's article, ''The World According to Koch'' (Feb. 5), I've come to the conclusion that the Mayor should use the proceeds of his book to cover his re-election campaign next year.

title: The Criteria for Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: LITTLE CIRCUS. By Rodney Peppe. The Viking Press.

title: Davis Stops Swift in 9th
description: Howard Davis Jr., ranked the No. 2 lightweight by the World Boxing Association, moved up in weight class today and capitalized on hand speed and a six-inch reach advantage to stop Connie Swift in the ninth round of a scheduled 10-round junior welterweight bout.

title: HASTINGS PUPILS PRODUCE ORIGINAL OPERA
description: WITH help from musical allies from the Metropolitan Opera, 36 Hastings sixth graders wrote, performed and produced a highly professional full-scale operetta in their school last week.

title: Headliners
description: Not to Their Taste Residents along Park Avenue are trying their best to make short order of Kyu-Sung Choi and the 24-hour deli he wants to open at the corner of 75th Street. They have enlisted the support of the local Community Board and the Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts, complained to the Buildings Department and the Landmarks Preservation Commission, sent engineers, architects and lawyers to pore over zoning laws and plumbing blueprints and raised funds to battle Mr. Choi at city hearings and in the courts.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic.1 Index: 1967 -100 2 Index: December 1982 -100

title:
NUMISMATICS;
FRESH AMMUNITION FOR OLYMPIC COIN CRITICS
description: None of the three United States Olympic coins will win any prizes for beauty and all have received negative reviews from coinage critics, but it appears that in terms of artistic merit Uncle Sam has saved the worst for last: The 1984 Olympic silver dollar, last coin in the set to be produced, is not only the ugliest of the three but quite possibly, one of the ugliest coins in U.S. history.

title: Dr. Celeste Pociask To Marry a Broker
description: -1-14, 2 lines Dr. Celeste Pociask, a dermatologist and an attending physician at the Stamford (Conn.) Hospital, and Edward Franklin Romig 2d, a stockbroker with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, plan to be married April 7. Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Pociask of Union, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Romig of Chardon, Ohio.

title: THE HIDDEN COSTS OF THE CASHLESS SOCIETY
description: For the first time in 10 years, it became legal last week for merchants to charge customers an extra fee if they wanted to make purchases with their credit cards, but there were no reports that any merchants had. The ban on such surcharges lapsed on Tuesday - leading to what a Congressional aide described as a probably temporary venture into a true laissez-faire approach to the credit card business - because the Senate and the House couldn't agree on terms to extend the prohibition.

title: THE WORLD
description: The Gulf War Grows Hotter

title: HOLLY FLANDERS WINS
description: -ANNE-DE-BEAUPRE, Quebec, March 3 (AP) - Holly Flanders of Deerfield, N.H., won her first World Cup event in two years today, capturing the final women's downhill of the seaosn in 1 minute 29.50 seconds. Marie-Luce Waldmeier of France was second in 1:30.20 and Sylvia Eder of Austria was third in 1:30.21.

title: MONDALE REBUKES HART OVER A VOTE
description: Walter F. Mondale and labor leaders bitterly attacked Senator Gary Hart today, accusing the Colorado Democrat of supporting the hospital lobby and President Reagan's economic programs.

title: REPORT AVOIDS TOUCHY ISSUE
description: IN MANY respects, a report on teacher certification to be presented to the State Board of Education Wednesday should elicit more questions than give answers.

title: EFFORTS TO TIGHTEN SUPPORT PAYMENTS DRAW SOME CRITICISM
description: DIVORCED women with children have been cited in recent studies as the fastest- growing segment of the population living below the poverty level.

title: THE NATION
description: Defectors Try A Wrong Exit

title: BEAN LEADS BY 2 AFTER 82-FOOT PUTT
description: Andy Bean sank an 82-foot putt on the final green today to complete a string of four consecutive birdies and take a two-shot lead after three rounds of the $500,000 Honda Classic.

title: TRI-STATE TAXPAYERS DIFFER, WHO PAYS LOWEST RATES?
description: Mangold, a senior vice president of a large New York bank, expressed the bitterness that many commuters feel about being taxed by both New York City and their home areas. ''As a New Jersey resident working in New York I'm not clear as to the necessity of paying a New Jersey income tax when my income is virtually derived entirely from New York sources,'' he said. ''I am paying local school taxes, property taxes, sales taxes on purchases within the state and high commuter fares on New Jersey transit. Even though New Jersey gives credit for taxes paid to other localities, it seems inherent in the system that New Jersey assumes that all income not taxed by New York must be taxed by New Jersey.''

title: STAGE: GOTHIC 'FACE BOX'
description: In Wakako Yamauchi's ''Face Box,'' two women, girlhood friends and rivals, meet in middle age to refuel an old fight over the man one of them married. Recently deceased, he has left bitter memories - for both his wife and the other woman (Natsuko Ohama in the play's central role). The air is overcast with acrimony as Miss Yamauchi tries to depict a domestic battlefront of jealousy and retribution.

title: CHARGES CAST A CLUD OVER GEORGIA POLITICS
description: It has been less than four years since Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, was forced out of office by voters amid allegations of financial improprieties. But the state's Democratic establishment is once again facing charges of political corruption in an election year.

title: WHAT TO DO IF YOU ARE AUDITED
description: TO a young architect in Chicago, being called for an audit by the Internal Revenue Service was scary, even though he was not worried about having done anything dishonest. ''For two days, I was a little panicked,'' he said. ''Then I spent the next four days digging out my old receipts.''

title: LAFONTAINE STARS AS ISLANDERS WIN
description: Pat LaFontaine, playing his second National Hockey League game, scored three goals and had two assists tonight as the Islanders defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 11-6.

title: GADGETS, GIZMOS AND THE ART OF AUDIO MAINTENANCE
description: T hey may seem like a trivial side dish to the main course of music, but audio accessories can help bring out the right flavor. They enable a stereo system to do its best and keep doing its best. The notions counter - if that's the proper word - of most audio stores is usually glutted with quite a mixed lot of such gadgets and gizmos, and while some are eminently useful, others are ineffective and a few are downright harmful. So it pays to be picky in their choice.

title: SHOWY HELLEBORES ARE A STANDOUT IN EARLY SPRING
description: Bertha Reppert is a specialist in the lore and culture of herbs.

title: No Headline
description: 31 Food Places Listed For Health Violations

title: SHOULD THE PAROLE BOARD BE SCRAPPED
description: Two brutal crimes in recent weeks have drawn attention to the Cuomo administration's effort to revamp New York State's parole system. First, a man on parole after a prison term for manslaughter was accused of murdering a police officer; a week later, another ex- convict on parole was charged with shooting an undercover officer. For many people, the incidents reinforced the need to alter the system by which inmates leave prison. Instead of judges dispensing flexible sentences - with the state parole board deciding when inmates should be released - Mr. Cuomo has proposed fixed sentences. Others said the shootings demonstrate a failure to prepare prisoners to return to their communities. The Week in Review last week asked Lawrence T. Kurlander, the Governor's Director of Criminal Justice, and David P. Rothenberg, executive director of the Fortune Society, a self-help program for ex-convicts, how the parole system should be reformed. Excerpts follow.

title:
STAMPS;
THE U.N. FOCUSES ON WORLD FOOD PROBLEMS
description: Insuring an adequate supply of food

title: JERSEY CITY FIGHTS FOR WATERFRONT
description: ALTHOUGH the big clock on the Colgate-Palmolive Company plant and the buildings of this city are clearly visible from downtown Manhattan, the ''gold'' cannot be seen.

title: REMEMBERING 'MAMA' WITH LIZA MINNELLI
description: D aughters grow up faster than most mothers like to admit. All too soon, it seems, they are no longer protegees but equals - maybe even competition. Few, however, saw the change as dramatically as Liza Minnelli did on Nov. 8, 1964. Judy Garland had asked her 18-year-old daughter to guest-star with her at the London Palladium, and suddenly, in a single instant, as the two women stood there on stage, everything between them changed.

title: CITY IS URGED TO PROTECT MANUACTURING LOTS
description: The City of New York should act to limit the conversion of Manhattan's manufacturing lofts to offices because failure to do so will threaten jobs in the garment and printing industries, according to a new report.

title: TEXAS, AND NOTHING ON THE HORIZON
description: Evan S. Connell, the novelist, is the author of a forthcoming nonfiction book about General George Custer, titled ''Son of the Morning Star.'' THE HIGHLAND PARK WOMAN

title: HART STRATEGISTS SAY MONEY AND BACKERS ARE COMING IN
description: Senator Gary Hart, scrambling to flesh out a largely skeletal campaign organization in several key states, has signed up more than 100 delegate candidates from fallen rival candidates, his strategists say. He is also moving to raise $500,000 in cash for a nine-state political test on March 13.

title: O'NEILL MAKES CASE FOR NATIONAL NEEDS
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. SINCE last June 28, when a section of the Connecticut Turnpike collapsed and fell into the Mianus River at Greenwich, Governor O'Neill has focused his administration's attention on the deteriorating roads and bridges in Connecticut.

title: U.S. Spending Freeze Urged
description: Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, saying Congress must get the budget deficit under control this year, called today for a freeze on Federal spending in the fiscal year 1985, followed by two years of spending growth at 1 percentage point less than the rate of inflation. The Kansas Republican said the deficit in the third year of her plan would be $120 billion, as against $233 billion under President Reagan's budget.

title: PROTEST DRAMA CAN BE THE CUTTING EDGE OF THEATER
description: Ascene from ''Cinders'' at the Public Theater. The deputy head of a Polish reform school tells his pupils that the song they've just composed is very, very good, but might be improved if the odd word were changed. Why not ''cheery'' for ''gloomy,'' and ''I shed my fears for future years'' instead of ''I shed my tears for wasted years?'' Suddenly the girls' lament for their lives is a celebration of socialism, performed in the style of a military march, with hand clapping and pin-on smiles.

title: BEST SELLERS March 4, 1984Fiction 1118
description: PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. 254 SMART WOMEN, by Judy Blume. (Putnam, $15.95.) Three divorcees, their love affairs and their kids in trendy Boulder, Colo. 3227 WHO KILLED THE ROBINS FAMILY?, created by Bill Adler and written by Thomas Chastain. (Morrow, $9.95.) The publisher offers a $10,000 prize to the reader who submits the best answer. 4327

title: Philippines Promotes One of Aquino Guards
description: A promotion to second lieutenant has been announced for a Philippine Air Force sergeant who was guarding the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. when he was assassinated at the Manila airport last August.

description: IN THE aftermath of recently disclosed statistics showing that infant mortality in Jersey

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: MORE than 100 Hofstra University accounting students are visiting 38 Long Island public libraries to provide free tax help to the disabled, the elderly and the needy. The service is offered seven days a week through April 15, with different hours at different locations. Robert Katz, associate professor of taxation and director of the tax preparation program, said that in 1983 ''our students prepared in excess of 2,500 income tax returns, all free of charge.''

title: THE UNCERTANTY OF CAPITAL PUNISHMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW MALL BRINGING CHANGE TO A REGION
description: SOMETIME in August southeastern Connecticut's first regional shopping mall is to open in Waterford, just across the town line from New London. The large, $70 million center, the Crystal Mall, on Interstate 95, will have four major stores and about 130 smaller shops. It will be the only regional mall in an area stretching from New Haven and West Hartford to Warwick, R.I.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Healthy Rise for Retailing

title: Making a Point With a Smile
description: I have just finished reading the article on Dr. Peter H. Gott (''Censors to Review a Doctor's Satires,'' Feb. 12).

DINING OUT;
GOODBYE, GOTHAM, HELLO, RUMSON
description: IT WAS wonderful news indeed that the owners of Manhattan's late and much-lamented

title: APPRAISING AMERICAN SPORTSWEAR
description: This spring, sportswear design is racy and, increasingly, free- form. But the principle upon which it is based remains: the concept of interchangeable separates that can make a woman's wardrobe seem larger than it is. The flexibility of this concept makes it adaptable to changing needs and life styles. As women demand clothes that do not inhibit their movements and, once on the body, do not require additional attention, sportswear designers are becoming more assured. These, after all, are the clothes they do best.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
IF JERSEY(SIC)'S GOT IT, WHY NOT FLAUNT IT
description: -favorite football team has opted for the Meadowlands and clean restrooms, it's time to cast off this official statewide paranoia with our name and go for the obvious.

title: FOOD FOR ETHIOPIA BRINGS U.S. DISPUTE
description: A dispute has arisen between the Reagan Administration and Congress over Administration assertions that food donated by the United States and other countries to fight famine in Ethiopia is being diverted by that country's leftist Government to commercial markets.

title: Estimated Taxes
description: For taxpayers with significant income that is not subject to withholding, the Internal Revenue Service requires quarterly payments of estimated taxes, and those who fail to make them face stiff penalty and interest charges.

title: JACKSON WOULD TALK TO P.L.O. AGAIN
description: Before heading north for a fence-mending meeting Sunday with Jewish leaders, the Rev. Jesse Jackson told reporters here that he would be willing to meet again with the Palestine Liberation Organization in the pursuit of a ''comprehensive'' peace in the Middle East.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
AN OLYMPIC SKATER LOOKS AHEAD TO '88
description: AFTER watching my friends Peter and Kitty Carruthers win the Silver Medal in pair skating, I knew I was going to commit myself to another four years of training for the next Olympic Games.

title: MOROCCO ENDS TAXES ON FARMERS UNTIL 2000
description: King Hassan II announced today that Morocco's farmers, hard hit by years of drought, would be exempted from paying taxes until the end of the century.

title: REAL MONEY
description: I called on a Manhattan real-estate agent. ''You want to buy an apartment? What price do you have in mind.''

description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: THEY MOVE THE MASSES
description: Bruce Mazlish is a professor of history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. His book ''The Meaning of Karl Marx'' will be published this fall. THE SPELLBINDERS

title: THE NATION
description: Striking a Deal At 3-Mile Island

title: A Correction
description: A map of India in The Week in Review of Feb. 26 was in error. The state identified as Haryana was in fact Rajasthan.

title: Karin Enke Captures 2 Races in Title Skating
description: Karin Enke of East Germany, who won two gold medals last month at the Winter Olympics, won both the 500- and 1,000-meter races for women in meet-record times today.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: For years, it was a fairly standard wisecrack in New Haven: ''Watch out, your phone is being tapped.'' After investigating, the City Board of Police Commissioners, a civilian body that oversees the Police Department, said in 1978 that the department had routinely tapped the phones of residents from 1964 to 1971, ostensibly to monitor radical political activity.

title: PRINCETON COACH LOOKS TO THE OLYMPICS
description: PRINCETON WITH the recently concluded Winter Olympics now only memories and statistics, attention is turning to the Summer Olympic Games to be held in Los Angeles. And among those to whom those games are of the utmost importance is Lawrence T. Ellis, the track and cross- country coach at Princeton University.

title: 'ECHOES' OF THE OLD DAYS
description: A TOURING troupe from England will make a sweep through northeast Connecticut this week, performing in a play that depicts the life of 19th- and early 20th-century textile workers.

title: ALCOHOLISM COUNSELING ON RISE
description: ON Friday nights, while revelers on the Island stream into bars and discos, a group of about 40 men and women assemble in a second-floor meeting room in Sayville to talk about alcohol and the problems this drug has caused for them, their families and their friends.

title: POLITICAL UNREST STIRS BRAZIL'S MILITARY
description: Brazil's armed forces, in power without interruption for 20 years, are displaying growing nervousness at the strength of the opposition campaign calling for direct elections to pick the country's next President.

title: SHAPING UP A MIXED-USE PARCEL
description: OBSOLETE zoning dies hard. Many planners would agree in principle that Manhattan has a surplus of underutilized and mostly vacant land zoned for manufacturing use. But new construction for manufacturing at regionally competitive prices is not generally feasible in Manhattan.

title: AT HOME IN THE KITCHEN
description: LABELING A GROUP OF recently renovated urban kitchens is difficult; they fall somewhere between American country and hi-tech. No antique baskets dangle from the ceilings; no rag rugs are scattered on the floors. No matter. The result is a comfortable environment. That harsh combination of antiseptic white walls, white tile floors, stainless-steel counter tops and commercial hardware that was de rigueur not so very long ago seems, at long last, to have become passe.

title: Welcome Home, Best Seller
description: Right now you're probably the country's most famous mayor. To a lot of Americans, in fact, you're not just the Mayor of New York. You are So far you're having a terrific 1984: a book on the Best Seller List, no fiscal crisis, a well-earned holiday in Europe. We understand you even made your presence felt at the Berlin Wall. ''I'm here,'' you told East German border guards snapping your picture. ''It's me. It's me.''

title: ADVICE ON THE SEASON'S ESSENTIALS
description: A new wardrobe each season is not in the cards for too many women. But it is possible to perk up a wardrobe or to update it by making a few judicious purchases. In fact, one of the best fashion strategies has always been to buy clothes that are classic enough to last for several years, and add one or two things each season that are of the moment. Last year's blouse, for example, will look just fine under this year's big jacket, especially with the addition of a man's necktie. And a two-year-old cotton sweater will have a whole new look this season if it's worn with a below-calf-length skirt.

title: LIFE IN BEIRUT: RANDOM SHELLNG, UNRANDOM FEAR
description: The most terrifying moments here come by surprise.

description: GAINSBOROUGH WORKS

title: CAN THE THREE MIAMI'S PULL TOGETHER
description: A few weeks ago, the Dade County tourism department faced an embarrassing problem. It had trouble finding any black residents to say good things about Miami, a snag that delayed completion of a promotional film it was making.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: TEN public schools in the state are vying for selection as successful schools in the National Secondary School Recognition Program.

title: NEW POWERS, NEW POLITICS
description: As a gay male, I was offended at Theodore White's trivializing our role in the changing political scene.

title: AFTER LEBANON, U.S. SEEKS SOME PLUSES
description: Is there hope yet for President Reagan's 1982 plan for a Middle East settlement? In the midst of a testy subcommittee hearing last week, Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, called the plan a failure. ''I don't agree with you that it is a failure,'' Secretary of State George P. Shultz shot back.

title: Future of Public Land: Officials Need to Care
description: Over the years, Westchester County has been particularly fortunate in having leaders who recognized the value of open space and the need for county lands to protect the quality of life and meet future public needs. Their concern for preservation led to the gradual acquisition of invaluable lands and today we are a county rich in parks and lands, which are an invaluable resource not just for today but for future generations who will live in Westchester. Our precious resources must be treasured and protected. It is the particular responsibility of our elected officials to oversee and ensure this protection.

title: No Headline
MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Trudeau Says He's Quitting

title: NETS DEFEAT BULLETS BY 100-90
description: On the scoreboard at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, it said the Nets beat the Washington Bullets, 100-90. What it didn't say was that the cost of victory was high: one split lip, a twisted ankle and a mild case of tendinitis.

title: DEEP IN PIES
description: OVER THE years, we have been intrigued by the simple, or not so simple, blending of elements that come to the table as pie, one of the oldest forms of ''assembled'' foods.

title: IN SHORT
description: FICTION

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Over the past few years, the elusive boundary between classical ''new music'' and avant-garde jazz has been stretched to the point of invisibility. This week brings three solo performances by improvising musicians, in places that are not usually on New York's ''jazz'' circuit.

title: Software for Doing Your Own Return
description: D O personal computers help in figuring income tax? The answer appears to depend on how complicated one's taxes are, what kind of advice is needed and how much time the taxpayer wants to spend. And, inasmuch as there are almost as many different types of tax software packages as there are tax forms, choosing the right one may be no easy task.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS

title: RIVER GROUP WILL RESTORE A LIGHTHOUSE
description: The red-brick lighthouse on the Hudson River stands empty, its windows boarded and roof leaking.

title: CAPITALS GET 4 IN 2D, TO RANGERS BY 5-1
description: The Rangers are so far down these days their only solace is that the National Hockey League playoffs are still a month away. Maybe they still have time to find some offense - and some answers.

title: SUDAN WARNS LIBYA AND ETHIOPIA
description: The President of the Sudan said today that he was prepared to go to war against Libya and Ethiopia if both countries continued to support rebels fighting for the independence of the southern part of the country.

title: Postal Worker Admits Theft
description: A postal worker accused of stealing more than 121,000 letters containing donations for the evangelist Oral Roberts has pleaded guilty to 10 counts of mail theft. Prosecutors said Terry Lee Osborne, 37 years old, pleaded guilty Thursday and Federal District Judge H. Dale Cook set a March 30 sentencing date. Mr. Osborne admitted that he had stolen the evangelist's mail for more than two years.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Everyday Chemicals

title: SALVADORANS DENY CHARGES ON KILLINGS
description: El Salvador's Defense Minister, Gen. Eugenio Vides Casanova, denied today that he had covered up evidence in the slaying of four American churchwomen.

title: THE WEDDING GUEST WINS THE SWIFT STAKES
description: While some of the fastest New York-based colts were at Hialeah to showcase their Kentucky Derby credentials in the Flamingo, a Florida horse slipped away to seek a northern route to Louisville.

LONG ISLAND OPINION;
EVERYTHING THAT WAS MINE
description: I'LL never forget that summer of '73. Most

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: '' LOTS of people don't know it's a tidal river,'' Drew Gorman explained about the Hudson, ''but they learn quickly.'' Mr. Gorman, a river aficionado, sailor and area businessman, is vice president of the Ferry Sloops organization, which has sent its gaff-rigged Sojourner Truth on some tedious voyages on the ''river that flows both ways.''

title:
GARDENING;
SPRING FLOWER SHOWS ARE STARTING UP
description: NOW that the worst that winter has to offer is behind us, the time has arrived for spring flower shows to pop up here and there, almost like spring flowers themselves. After months of shoveling snow and battling icy streets, what could be more pleasant than to spend a few hours surrounded by fragrant, colorful spring flowers?

title: Comings and Goings
description: The University of San Francisco plans to offer Jim Brovelli, the coach at the University of San Diego, the job of restarting the Dons' basketball program in 1985, according to a report in The San Diego Union. . . . Six days after he had been traded by San Francisco for Al Oliver, Fred Breining reported to the Montreal camp with an inflammation of the muscle in his pitching shoulder, an injury he said he incurred during his last start in September. John McHale, the Expos president, said he was told by Giant management that Breining had experienced spring training soreness, but that McHale had not been informed of a carry-over injury.

title: Nix Sets Mark in 440
description: Sunder Nix of Indiana ran the fastest indoor 440-yard dash ever today at the Big Ten Conference indoor track and field championships, when he recorded a time of 46.40 seconds. Nix ran a 46.66 in this meet last year, which had been the fastest time. His performance also helped push Indiana to the meet championship, with 104 points, ahead of second-place Michigan's 98.

title: YONKERS TAX PLAN GOES ON
description: COUNTY tax warrants were mailed last week with good news for Yonkers, Mount Vernon and New Rochelle. The the so-called Yonkers Plan of tax tradeoffs between the county and the cities will continue to function for the present.

title: Burgess's Best
description: To the Editor:

title: BONN LEADER VISITS WASHINGTON FORTIFIED WITH VICTORY ON MISSILES
description: One year after his electoral triumph, Chancellor Helmut Kohl leads a nation becalmed from a stormy debate over the deployment here of new medium-range American missiles.

title: CITY GETS MORE FLOOD-INSURANCE COVERAGE
description: NO ONE rows up Fifth Avenue after a heavy rainstorm. Nor does anyone row up Flatbush Avenue, Fordham Road, Union Turnpike or Hylan Boulevard. Those dramatic pictures of flooded streets always seem to come from somewhere outside the five boroughs. And that, perhaps, is why New York City's homeowners do not seem to worry much about flood damage.

description: STATE education officials and some school administrators are questioning whether the trips high school students take on school time are valuable learning experiences, and thus qualify as educational sessions under state regulations, or are just ''joy rides.''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
GAMBLING AS AN 'AID' TO EDUCATION? DON'T BET ON IT
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO has been advocating the legalization of sports betting in New York State for several months. His rationale is that the revenues raised by sports betting, a projected $300 million for fiscal 1984, could help pay for some badly needed programs on the elementary and junior high school levels in the state, and, I presume, improve the quality of education at these levels.

title: PLAZA SPRUCE-UP
description: White Plains Plaza, the largest mixed-use office and retail complex in downtown White Plains and among the first to be built in Westchester County, will undergo a $2 million facelift.

description: A woman's contention that she sold her baby daughter for $3,500 has focused attention on the lack of laws barring child selling in South Carolina and on the adoption regulations and may lead to tougher new laws.

title: Uganda Accident Drowns 11
description: A boat crowded with wedding guests capsized on Lake Kwania in central Uganda and 11 people drowned, the Uganda radio reported today.

description: ''W HY?'' I'm not sure I can count the number of times I've heard that word in the last few weeks. But I do know that I've made a lot of decisions in 27 years as head coach, and I've never had one questioned like this one.

title: TAX COLLECTORS-NEW POLICIES, NEW LAWS
description: ARMED with an investment of millions of dollars in new computers, as well as significantly expanded legal powers, the Internal Revenue Service seems equipped at last to reverse years of erosion of its once-unchallenged reputation as the world's most efficient tax collector.

description: In his introduction to the article by Mayor Koch, Sam Roberts notes that William Rauch, Mayor Koch's press secretary, who collaborated with his boss on ''Mayor,'' speculates that a sequel to the controversial book should be entitled ''Koch 2.''

title: CHINA TURNING BACK TO ITS EDUCATED FOR HELP
description: As a Deputy Governor of Heilongjiang Province, An Zhendong is responsible for developing industry and communications in the strategic northeastern corner of Manchuria.

title: Conservative Leader Criticizes Miss Reagan
description: John T. Dolan, head of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, won applause from fellow conservatives Saturday by suggesting that ''we muzzle'' President Reagan's outspoken daughter, Maureen.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A LITTLE MORE THAN KIN, by Ernest Hebert. (Penguin, $5.95.) ''We may be in on the creation of a northern Yoknapatawpha County here,'' according to our reviewer, Nicholas Delbanco. Once again setting his story in Darby, N. H. - the scene of his acclaimed first novel, ''The Dogs of March'' - Ernest Hebert moves black- toothed, shambling Ollie Jordan, head of the decrepit Jordan clan, and his idiot son, Willow, to center stage. ''The landscape is compelling, the dialogue has perfect pitch, and the action is both fierce and swift.'' GOD'S PLAYGROUND: A History of Poland: Vol. I, The Origins to 1795; Vol. II, 1795 to the Present, by Norman Davies. (Columbia University Press, $30.) Both ''a biography of Poland and a work of art,'' this ''superbly readable'' two-volume work ''gives an account of almost every important event and person in Poland's history,'' Leszek Kolakowski said in his review. Chapters that present the country's history chronologically through 1978 alternate with sections on crucial aspects of Polish life, and several pages at the end of Volume II deal with the rise of the Solidarity movement.

title: Aide Says Costa Rica Seeks Arms from U.S.
description: A Government official said today that Costa Rica had asked the United States, Venezuela and other Western nations for arms so its Civil Guard can better defend its northern border with Nicaragua.

title: WEARY, AND A SEMESTER LATE, RUSIANS ARRIVE AT STATE U.
description: It was 2 A.M. when seven Russian college students finally set their suitcases down in a dormitory at the State University campus here one night last week.

title: STATE PLAN IRKS SOME SCHOOLS
description: THE parents of children who attend the Waldorf School of Garden City received a letter last month from the school's faculty chairman, George Rose, urging them to respond with letters to the New York State Board of Regents' proposed action plan.

title: WHERE TO GET HELP FROM FILING TO AUDITS
description: ''IF all of your income comes from a W-2 form and some interest and dividends, and you have the normal deductions, then there's no reason'' not to prepare your own return, said Alexander Gurevitch, a Pearl River, N.Y., tax lawyer and president-elec t of the American Association of Attorney Certified Public Accountants.

title: CRIME
description: Lesley Egan, who has written CRIME FOR CHRISTMAS (Doubleday, $11.95), is a dash lady. She uses the dash as a feature of dialogue. There has been nothing like it since Mr. Jingle in the ''Pickwick Papers.''

title: CANAL THAT BECAME A PARK TO MARK SESQUICENTENNIAL
description: ON A SUMMER day in 1834, Gov. Peter Vroom and 30 guests celebrated the opening of the Delaware and Raritan Canal to commerce with a barge trip to New Brunswick, where they were greeted with a 24-gun salute and regaled by a military band.

title: IT ALL ADDS UP, VIOLINIST FINDS
description: A FEW weeks ago, while preparing the Brahms Violin Concerto that she will perform Friday and next Sunday with the Eastern Suffolk Community Orchestra, Erica Kiesewetter took time out from working on the score to do a little simple arithmetic.

title: YOUTH ORCHESTRA SETS ITS SIGHTS HIGH
description: WESTFIELD THE New Jersey Youth Symphony will celebrate its fifth anniversary season here Saturday night with a program that its music director and conductor, George Marriner Maull, describes as ''the most challenging we have programmed to date.''

title: Tanzania Party Extends Power Over Zanzibar
description: A special session of the House of Representatives has approved constitutional changes giving Tanzania's central party organization more power in the affairs of Zanzibar, a semiautonomous island.

title: SEX ADVISERS GET ADVICE ON ADVISING
description: PRINCETON KATHRYN MEIER used to be embarrassed to ask questions about sex. Now, as a health advocate at Rutgers College in New Brunswick, where she is a sophomore, she conducts seminars at which students ask her about contraception and other subjects related to sex.

title: NEW POWERS, NEW POLITICS
description: Theodore White does not mention the real battles going on among factions of American women - battles that may determine the tenor of their power once they do obtain it: the rise of conservative women's groups that successfully mobilized politicians to defeat the E.R.A., for example. Those women work for ''gains'' that many women activists would call losses, but they are, nonetheless, politically potent.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the article on Portugal, ''What's Doing in the Algarve'' (Travel, Jan. 22), an incorrect telephone number was given for the Hotel La Reserve in Santa Barbara de Nexe. The number is 089-91234.

title: CONCERT: MASTIK PLAYS GUITAR WORKS

title: Candace Rosaen Wed To Richard C. Renfro

Renfro, the son of Mrs. Oswald R. Renfro of Little Rock, Ark., and the late Mr. Renfro. The Rev. Jan Fullerwieder performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Lutheran Church.

description: TOKYO

title: Amy Shepherd Bride in Tenafly
description: Amy Marie Shepherd, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Shepherd of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to John S. Weinberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Weinberg of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. John Croneberger of the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly performed the ceremony in the bride's home there.

title: ; U.S. READY TO START THIS ELECTION YEAR
description: T o the Editor:

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Quality Wearables Up to 50% Off Carrig Isle in Bronxville is a quality women's sportswear and men's accessories shop, not a discount retailer, but at sale times prices can be as much as 50 percent off the original charges. The post-holiday sale still has limited quantities marked down of the shop's own and other labels until March 17 and the next price-cutting period is the Better Buy Bronxville Chamber of Commerce sidewalk sale June 23. Sizes are 4 to 12 and new spring items are not included in the present markdowns.

title: THE UNSUNG SPLENDORS OF FLORENCE
description: SUSAN LUMSDEN is a writer who lives in Italy.

title: TAINTED WELLS LEAD TO TAX RELIEF
description: CARL HECK of Durham has had to drink bottled water for the past year because his well is contaminated. As a result of the pollution, he says, his home on historic Main Street has dropped in value.

title: PARENTS RESIST SHIFT IN CATHOLIC SCHOOLS
description: WHEN Ethel Connell looked for a school for her only child, she wanted an all-boys parochial school steeped in tradition and taught by members of Roman Catholic religious orders. She found exactly what she wanted in 50-year-old St. Anthony's High School in Smithtown.

title: LAND NEAR JERSEY COMMUNITYWILL BE SET ASIDE FOR SNAKES
description: The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and a developer have agreed to allow snakes and the residents to coexist at an Ocean County retirement community, officials said.

title: PHILHARMONIC: THE SOUND OF BRASSES
description: The most interesting aspect of last week's New York Philharmonic program is not the music, but the seating arrangements. Zubin Mehta is reportedly dissatisfied with the sound of the orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall - welcome to the club - and is experimenting with ways of making the brass less blatant. What he came up with last week hardly solves the problem.

title: HEALTH AND THE BODY POLITIC
description: REFORMING MEDICINE

title: MAYOR KOCH'S MEMOIRS
description: Mayor Koch's portrayal of an incident he describes as having taken place at a church in Harlem in 1978 effectively smears Basil Paterson, one of the city's principal civic leaders and spokespersons for the black community, as being silent in the presence of anti-Semitism. This is not the first time a public official's comments have had the effect of setting blacks against Jews and Jews against blacks.

title: Death Toll Put at 300 In Nigerian Violence
description: About 300 people have been killed in religious violence in the northeast city of Yola, and fighting continued on Friday, it was reported here today.

title: THE NATION
description: The Missing Blacklist Memos

title: EVENING ALLURE
description: No matter what a woman does or how she dresses when she gets herself together for the evening-and particularly for a gala one-she wants to look her most attractive. Designers understand this and, although their general styling and silhouettes may shift a bit from season to season, they almost always make evening clothes that are long on allure.

title: RECITAL: MICHAEL SMITH, GUITARIST
description: Michael Cedric Smith centered his guitar recital in Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night on the new and the recent. The program began and ended with music by Bach and Johann Kasper Mertz (a 19th-century virtuoso and composer); between them, however, came the premiere of Robert Starer's Six Preludes, the first New York performance of William Brook's ''Cotton'' and 20th-century pieces by Britten and Villa Lobos.

title: Athletics Require Full Attention
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 2 Bombings in Colombia
description: A bomb destroyed the local headquarters of Colombia's opposition party on Friday, nine days before elections that Marxist guerrillas have threatened to disrupt.

title: DEBATE OVER 99-YEAR LEASE GROWS AS BOARD VOTE NEARS
description: -acre wooded hill on the edge of the county's Grasslands Reservation has become one of the hottest countywide issues in many months, pitting Democrats against Republicans, and the League of Women Voters, environmentalists and taxpayer groups against the construction industry and officials of Mount Pleasant.

title: 8 GUARDS PLEAD GUILTY IN BRIBERY AT U.S. JAIL IN CITY
description: A two-year investigation has uncovered extensive corruption by several guards who took bribes to smuggle cocaine and other contraband to inmates in the Federal jail in Manhattan.

title: THE LITTLE BLACK DRESS
description: It is the witching hour. In a dimly lit room in South Kensington in London, a group of ultrachic women, dressed alluringly in black, appears to be mingling at a fashionable party. The floor is strewn with glitter; and against their black dresses can be seen the glint of cut crystal or the gleam of pearls. Time stands still. But ageless as the various dresses may seem, each one is from a specific year, from 1912 to the present, for the party and its mannequin guests are encased in glass as part of the Victoria and Albert Museum's exhibition on the 20th-century fashion phenomenon known as ''The Little Black Dress.'' (The exhibition began June 8, 1983, and continues through the end of next month.)

title: NEW LIFE FOR OLD UNIROYAL COMPLEX
description: ''IT'S one heck of a China egg,'' said C.

title: FITZGERALD PACKS A BAG OF TROUBLES
description: He is called ''Garret the Good'' here, which in the rough-and-tumble world of Irish politics is not meant to be particularly respectful. Fifteen months after putting together his Government, Ireland's fourth since 1981, Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald is still seen in some corners as an idealistic dreamer trying to heal age-old Irish problems - the hemorrhaging economy and a divided country.

title: April Is Anticancer Month
description: President Reagan has proclaimed April as Cancer Control Month and said the best way to prevent the disease was to avoid smoking. Mr. Reagan said research indicated that two-thirds of all cancer in the United States was linked to the way Americans lived.

title: STATE'S PEACE GROWERS EXPECT ANOTHER POOR CROP
description: THE peach crop in Connecticut this year will probably be a poor one because of the frigid temperatures this winter, orchard owners say.

title: Rumania Campaigning For Rise in Birth Rate
description: Rumania, concerned over a stagnating birth rate, announced a campaign today to urge citizens to have more children.

title: CAUCUSES IN MAINE TEST 2 CANDIDATES
description: The caucuses Maine Democrats hold on Sunday have become a closely watched battleground as the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination enters a volatile new phase.

title: JULIO CORTAZAR, 1914-1984: THE SIMON BOLIVAR OF THE NOVEL
description: Carlos Fuentes's novel ''Terra Nostra'' has just been reissued with an afterword by Milan Kundera. He has newly completed a novel about the disappearance of Ambrose Bierce in revolutionary Mexico.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: SYOSSET-WOODBURY
description: WITHIN sight of the intersection of Picquets Lane and Woodbury Road in Syosset-Woodbury are three structures that exemplify the community: a farm, an office park and a condominium development.

title: CITY OPERA TRIES A BOLD NEW TACK
description: W ith the recent announcement of the New York City Opera's first, full- scale, combined summer-fall season starting on July 6, Beverly Sills, the general director since 1979, has suggested that at long last she may be taking the measure of the artistic side of her mandate. As a piece of planning, the 1984 season looks promising indeed - full of fresh ideas, fascinating trends and welcome reaffirmations of aspects of the company's historical mission that have too long lain dormant.

title: SEEKING OTTINGER'S SEAT, A DOZEN TAKE TO THE ROAD
description: They have been meeting in town halls and municipal buildings, in a library, a restaurant, a golf club and even a bank - anywhere, in fact, that Westchester County's Democratic and Republican leaders will gather to look them over.

title: THE REGION
description: New York Crime: The Odds Are Easier to Beat

title: No Headline
description: Heavy fighting broke out today between Lebanese Army troops and anti- Government militiamen along the dividing line between East and West Beirut. The fighting dashed hopes for a quick cease-fire guaranteed by Syria.

title: RUST CAN BE RESISTED WITH THE RIGHT METHODS AND PRODUCTS
description: iron and most steel alloys - are in constant danger of being attacked by rust, a form of corrosion in which air and moisture combine to form a coating of reddish-brown oxide that eats into the surface of the metal and changes it completely into an unstable, chemical compound that is continually seeking to spread and grow. Allowed to progress long enough, rust will greatly weaken the strength of the orginal base metal, until it finally destroys it all together.

title: DANCE: GRAHAM TROUPE
description: The image of a man with a yoke on his neck, and in a bull-headdress, jumping straight up and down behind a convulsive woman might appear odd in some quarters. But this would hardly be the case for anyone familiar with the dance idiom invented by Martha Graham and her stage conventions.

title: REPORT FROM EUROPE: DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS
description: The world of fashion and its top designers are almost always attuned in some respects, for certain trends usually emerge each season in attitude, silhouette and color. But within these general confines, designers, wherever they may be - Rome, London, Milan, Paris, New York or Tokyo - also espouse their own personal viewpoints. This makes for refreshing diversity as well as offering a range of looks - all equally valid - for the many different lives women pursue today.

title: ON YAWNERS AND SLEEPERS
description: Target: the new word yawner . The earliest citation churned out by Nexis, a computerized newspaper morgue run by Mead Data Central that makes life easier for new-word hunters, was dated Jan. 14, 1983: ''Normally, the Continental Basketball Association's all-star game is a midseason yawner.'' That was the lead of a New York Times sports story by Neil Amdur and Michael Katz.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
WHERE SOME FINE TUNING COULD HELP
description: THE consumer finance industry has contributed heavily to the stalemate over resolution of the bankruptcy court crisis - as well as to the campaigns of numerous House members who have co-sponsored the industry's bill, H.R. 1800. In one sense, it is understandable because the 1978 law substantially affected this industry and added to its losses. At the same time, its current actions can be seen as going too far based on the evidence from a number of very credible studies of consumer bankruptcy.

title: GUIDE TO 13 MAJOR WAY STATIONS
description: Following is a guide to 12 major airports in Western Europe, plus Israel's Ben Gurion. The material is intended to help the arriving or departing traveler get through, shop at or stay over at each airport as easily as possible. Not all categories apply to each airport; features characteristic of the individual terminals have been stressed. London Heathrow Airport ARRIVAL Passport and Customs: Heathrow is divided into three terminals. Terminal 1 basically serves British and Irish airlines, although British Airways flights to Chicago and Miami also go through it. Terminal 2 has all the European airlines, and Terminal 3 the intercontinental flights and the Concorde. If you have any problems with walking ask for a wheelchair, since the corridors are very long and the moving walkways are split into various sections with a short walk between each section. Luggage: Baggage is slow to arrive at Heathrow. There are plenty of baggage carts and porters in brown uniforms around. A 20-pence (30-cent) tip per bag is usual although their services are technically free of charge. Currency Exchange: At Terminal 3 in the arrivals lounge there is a branch of Barclays bank open 24 hours every day. In the departures lounge it is open only from 6:30 A.M.-9:30 P.M. Terminals 1 and 2 have branches of the Midland bank open from 8 A.M.-11 P.M. every day. The airport banks charge about one percent higher commission than the city banks.

title: RETAIN TAX INDEXING
description: The temptation is great. Congress, by one simple amendment to the tax law, can raise billions of dollars without increasing tax rates or imposing any new taxes. The key is this: Just repeal the indexing provision scheduled to take effect in 1985.

title: THE NATION
description: Meese Under The Microscope

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Miami. Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Basketball Virginia vs. Maryland, at College Park. Coach Terry Holland, who played for Maryland's Lefty Driesell at Davidson holds an 11-10 advantage over his former coach since coming to Virginia. The Terrapins won the first meeting this season in Charlottesville, 67-66. (Television Channel 4, 1 P.M.)

title: THE REGION
description: Sharing Power Is Never Easy

title: THE MANY MOODS OF SPRING
description: One of the refreshing things about fashion is that it is always on the move. No sooner does one get used to certain silhouettes or concepts, or even hemlines, when it all starts shifting around. This spring season, however, is different. For the shifts are many and often contradictory, and they are happening simultaneously.

title: The Sauna
description: To the Editor:

title: LENKA PETERSON REFLECTS ON CAREER
description: THE setting of ''Levitation,'' a new play at Off Broadway's Circle Repertory Company, is the front porch of a Middle Western house. Family members and their friends come and go all through the night, looking at the moonlight and waiting for a meteor. To the actress Lenka Peterson, who plays the aging wife and mother, the play represents the perpetuation of life and recalls the patterns of her own, from an Omaha upbringing, replete with star-watching, community sings and hayrides, to the 25 years she lived in a 13-room, four-story house in New Rochelle.

title: Shellie Ruston to Marry Alan Grayson on April 29
description: Shellie Ruston, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hadley Ruston of Englewood, Colo., and Alan M. Grayson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Franklin Grayson of New City, N.Y., plan to be married April 29.

title: FLUID STRATEGIES
description: REYKJAVIK If there were an overall strategy

title: U.S.F.L. APPROVES DUPREE'S PACT WITH BREAKERS
description: The United States Football League's quest to sign two former outstanding college players ended with success in one case yesterday but continued with uncertainty in the other.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The stage is a panoramic swirl of festive villagers and gypsies in Mikhail Baryshnikov's ''Don Quixote,'' which airs Monday at 8 P.M. on Channel 13 and at 9 P.M. on Channel 49, in the ''Dance in America'' series. But the production, created for and performed here by the American Ballet Theater, also focuses on the company's most interesting younger dancers.

title: NEW ROCHELLE: A DECADE OF RENEWAL
description: LOTS lay empty, stores were deserted and offices went unrented. Ten years ago, New Rochelle's downtown commercial and business center fit the pattern of decay that was afflicting many American urban and suburban communities' central areas. It appeared that nothing could stop this downward trend.

title:
THEATER;
NEW LIFE FOR A LONG-NEGLECTED ODETS CLASSIC
description: Foster Hirsch is the author of ''A Method to Their Madness: The History of the Actors Studio,'' to be published next September by W. W. Norton.

title: TV Is to Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: LEARNING FAST ON A CRUISE
description: Mention the word ''cruise'' and most Americans think of a week or two of sybaritism or sloth. But the British may conjure other images. In 1955, a classics professor at the University of London approached R.K. Swan, an operator of a large British tour agency, with the idea of taking his students to the sites of ancient Greece and Rome. Mr. Swan was interested and, to cover the costs, opened the tour to the public. Within three weeks, all 300 places were sold. The idea of the educational cruise was born.

title: IRAN SAYS IT HAS DRIVEN 6 MILES ON KEY IRAQI PORT
description: Iran asserted yesterday that its forces had driven six miles closer to the key Iraqi port of Basra in fighting over the last three days. Iraq said its troops had ''crushed'' the Iranians in a fierce battle, but did not specify where it had taken place.

title: Why There Are So Many Deer
description: Two letters (Feb. 12) by biologists offering opinions about Connecticut deer meld together to say something like this: Deer populations, larger now than when Europeans first arrived here, are basically well-managed by biologists whose concern is to help the animals, which is fortunate, for the deer are too stupid to manage their own lives. In their stupidity, in fact, the deer seem wont to commit suicide by jumping in front of moving vehicles.

title: SURPRISES ABOUND IN 19TH-CENTURY ILALIAN REPERTORY
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently about recordings.
