description: BURL IVES IN MADISON

title: A WOMAN'S DISTINCTIVE SIGNATURE
description: For centuries, from the ancient Egyptians, perfume has been a distinctive signature for women. Shakespeare, in describing Cleopatra's royal entrance on her barge, noted that ''the poop was beaten gold, purple the sails, and so perfumed that the winds were lovesick with them.''

title: Yastrzemski in Camp
description: Carl Yastrzemski showed up at the Boston Red Sox training camp a day late and nobody cared because for the first time in 25 years, he is not a player. Tanned and appearing younger than his 44 years, Yastrzemski is now a part-time broadcaster for a Boston television station, and he is trying to adjust to life off the field.

title: 4 CIGARETTE BRANDS RATED LOW IN 3 RISK CATEGORIES
description: Tobacco companies are making more cigarette brands with low ratings for nicotine and carbon monoxide but the number of low-tar brands is about the same as last year, the Federal Trade Commission has reported.

title: BEACH READIED FOR BIRDS
description: SOME noteworthy summer residents of Short Beach in Smithtown will return in late April or mid-May to a renovated beach. It is expected to make a more comfortable home for them as town and state officials try to protect them from beachgoers and other predators.

title: MINNOWS ENLISTED IN MOSQUITO WAR
description: AIDED by some unusual auxiuliary forces, the Suffolk County Department of Health Services plans to reduce significantly its reliance on chemical pesticides in its 1984 antimosquito campaign. Among those joining the fight will be legions of fresh-water minnows, which feed on mosquito larvae.

title: Caro Dellenbaugh Engaged to Arthur Dempsey Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Dellenbaugh 3d of Vero Beach, Fla., and Bremen, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Caro Larocque Dellenbaugh to Arthur Donald Dempsey Jr., the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dempsey of Watertown, Mass. The wedding is planned for July.

title: MUSIC: SI ZENTNER BAND
description: Si Zentner holds a special position among big band leaders of the post 1950's. He is the only leader in the last 25 years who became a ''name'' leading a big band that was not a concert style jazz band like those of Maynard Ferguson, Buddy Rich and Mel Lewis.

title: BASEBALL NAMES UEBERROTH TO REPLACE KUHN OCT. 1
description: Peter V. Ueberroth, as expected, was elected the sixth commissioner of baseball today, but he will not take office until Oct. 1, after his work on the Summer Olympics at Los Angeles has ended. Until then, Bowie Kuhn will remain in the job, which he has held for the last 15 years.

title: NEW POWERS, NEW POLITICS
description: Surely, no one would argue with Theodore White's thesis that the electorate is changing; indeed, the process might even be called democracy at work.

title: IS THE NUCLEAR THREAT MANAGEABLE?
description: Leslie H. Gelb is the Times's national security correspondent based in Washington. A NEW AND HEIGHTENED FEAR OF nuclear war seems to be gripping Americans and Europeans. It is there in a movie about accidental war, in a television movie about Armageddon itself, in peace marches and the nuclear-freeze movement, in the superpowers' placing their missiles closer to the other's homeland, in the likelihood that nuclear strategy will emerge as a major issue in this year's Presidential campaign.

title: Drunken-Driving Law: Pro and Con
description: Lieut. Robert Herb of the Bergen County Police Department, and all those who participate in the county's D.W.I. (Driving While Intoxicated) Strike Force and other such forces, are to be commended. There is no question that police visibility and the number of arrests made at check points are deterrents.

title: Data Bank; March 4, 1984
SOVIET PRODUCTON OF OIL SHOWS AN UNUSUAL DROP
description: The output of oil in the Soviet Union, the world's largest producer, has started an unusual downward trend in the last five months, according to official statistics. But Western experts are divided on whether this represents a temporary dip or a long-expected peaking of production.

title: DRIVEWAYS AT ISSUE IN TRAILER PARK
description: THE construction of 30 new driveways in the East Hampton Mobile Home Village is the issue in the latest dispute among the East Hampton Town Board, the Suffolk County Department of Consumer Affairs, the trailer park's owner and its residents - many of whom are elderly.

Rothschild, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernst Rothschild of Deerfield Beach, Fla. Miss Kirshner is a senior at Adelphi University. Her fiance, who graduated from the State University at Albany, is a certified public accountant with Rosenbluth & Feuerstein in Garden City, L.I.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND ENDS 72d APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended its 72d annual appeal last Wednesday with a record total of $2,540,501.56 in donations from 13,001 contributors.

title: WPIX TO JOIN 'SUPERSTATIONS'
description: W hile the growth of cable TV has been marked by the emergence of dozens of services tailored especially for the new medium, it has also spawned a phenomenon known as the superstation: a local independent station's broadcast signal transformed into a de facto network by means of satellite distribution to cable systems. Until the advent of satellite program delivery in 1975, such hybrid station-networks could not have existed. But after Home Box Office decided to fly on ''the bird,'' it occurred to Ted Turner, the Atlanta-based entrepreneur, that by following HBO's example he could enrich the fortunes of his low-rated UHF outlet by relaying its signal to a satellite and thereby reach a nationwide audience - especially for the Atlanta Braves, the baseball team also owned by Mr. Turner. Thus, ''SuperStation WTBS'' was born.

''I only want you to answer one important question before I decide whether to use Block or not,'' he said, according to Mrs. Novick. ''Whose side are you on - mine, or the I.R.S.'s?''

They saw the future as something that came upon them from behind their backs, with the past receding away before their eyes.

title: Q&A 'Inheriting' an Apartment Question:
description: We own a small house with one rent-controlled tenant. The tenant is elderly and has been hospitalized for more than a year with no hope or possibility of returning to her apartment. In her absence, her granddaughter has virtually moved in and is making claims to the apartment as a family member. What can we do to prevent her use of the apartment, and especially to prevent her ''inheriting'' it should anything happen to her grandmother? . . . C. S., Manhattan

title: WHY TIMING IS EVERYTHING FOR INVESTORS' TAX-PLANNING
description: FEW things are as discouraging as making a bundle in the stock market and then turning a big chunk over to the Internal Revenue Service. Shrewd investors, however, can more than halve their tax liability, or at least delay the payment of taxes without seeing much of their profit disappear. The trick is planning.

title: CELTIC MUSIC: TANNAHILL WEAVERS

description: EVERY taxpayer has different financial and personal circumstances. Consequently, each person confronts somewhat different problems in filling out a tax return. While it is impossible to anticipate all the different situations that may have important tax consequences, some of the more common items are discussed below.

title: SINGLE AGAIN AT 50
description: As a practicing divorce lawyer, I found Martin Gottfried's experience mirrors the countless fears and concerns I hear almost every day from people who, after long and careful thought, are about to be ''single'' again (''Single Again at 50,'' About Men, Jan. 29). Time and again, I have heard clients, otherwise confident in their lives and careers, express great fear of middle-age loneliness.
