title: Bridget Gallagher To Be July Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius E. Gallagher of Columbia, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bridget Patrice Gallagher to Mark Choate Davis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan C. Davis of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is to be in July.

title: THE USE OF FORCE
description: President Reagan has proclaimed that the U.S. is ''standing tall'' and can now deal with the Soviets in self-confidence. He says American might has been restored and Moscow has seen that the U.S. is not afraid to use force when it chooses.

title: DO IT YOURSELF-I.R.S. SAYS IT'S EASY, BUT GIVES HELP
description: FOR years, Larry Brooks, a New York salesman has had someone else prepare his taxes. But this year, for the first time, he is planning to do his own return. ''If I do my own, I have a better handle on why the numbers are there, and I am able to justify them.''

title: Katherine Straus to Be Married in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Peter Straus of New York and Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter Katherine Louise Straus to Blair Charles Caple, the son of Elyse Caple of Kingston, N.Y., and Stanley Caple of Boca Raton, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: Miss Spillane to Wed Insurance Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Spillane of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter Patricia Shea Spillane to Michael Hans Peter Handler, a son of Susi Pretzmann Handler of Vienna and the late Col. Hans Handler. A May wedding is planned.

title: NEW POWERS, NEW POLITICS
description: Although a distinguished journalist, Theodore White seems to have forgotten some of his history (''New Powers, New Politics,'' Feb. 5). It is hardly ''new'' for a political group, such as blacks or women, to seek ''group results and group shares.''

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: FLIGHT AND CRUISE BARGAINS ON SHORT NOTICE
description: The prerequisites are simple: flexibility, a spirit of adventure and a credit card or ready cash. Equipped with those, you can qualify for a broad array of vacation bargains that are available to travelers who require only a few days' notice - sometimes even less - to arrange the time, pack and go.

title: MORE MURDER IN THE MONASTERY
description: Edward Mendelson, a professor of English at Columbia University, is the author of ''Early Auden.'' FLYING TO NOWHERE

title: THE NEW PARTY GIVERS
description: Nearly every day of every week, the invitations go out by the thousands all over Manhattan, none of them hand-engraved and all arriving in triplicate: ''Alan Rish invites you to celebrate the 70th birthday of William S. Burroughs'' at the Limelight. ''Dean Ralston requests your company at a luncheon for Liza Minnelli and James Mason'' at Quo Vadis. ''Nicholas VerPlank Beavers invites you to a party in honor of Cosima von B"ulow.'' Or Baird Jones invites you. Or Gwynne Rivers. Or Whitney Tower Jr. and the Tessera Club. Or the Junior International Club.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Two of the oldest films on this week's cable menu should interest any movie buff. John Murray Anderson's ''King of Jazz'' (1930), an early-talkie revue, may creak now but who cares? Not with an array of lavish, history-making sets and a ''Rhapsody in Blue'' conducted by Paul (''King'') Whiteman with George Gershwin himself at the keyboard. (Thursday at 10 A.M. on WHT.)

title: RESTORATION OF HOMES CREATES JOBS
description: THERE were no diplomas on graduation day last week in the drafty boathouse that served as a school along the Stamford waterfront. No mortarboards were worn and no speeches were made. But for nine men aged 18 to 33 who had just completed a course for carpenters in the restoration of old houses, there was elation.

title: THE TAX SYSTEM-HOW FAIR? THE PAYERS-HOW HONEST?
description: QUESTION: Mr. Egger, is the American taxpayer today more or less honest than he or she was 10 or 20 years ago? EGGER: Clearly, there's a trend away from compliance. I think that's probably a reflection of the whole national mind-set, the relationship between individuals and institutions. Q: How much has it cost in revenues? Or, how many people are not complying? EGGER: We have what we call the Tax Compliance Measurement Program, and this year we are in the process of analyzing the 1979 T.C.M.P. examinations. There's definitely a continuation of the downtrend that started 20 years ago. Compliance dropped by maybe one percentage point in that year, which translates into $5 billion. I think there's a belief on the part of some taxpayers that they won't get caught. Or they think they've got a lot of company, which just isn't so. Even though we're talking about downtrends, you're still talking about compliance in the 90 percentile level. Q: Mr. Chapoton, speaking as a tax policy writer, is compli

title: WHY THE DRAMATIC ARTS EMBRACE HENRY JAMES
description: I t is common knowledge that Henry James had a love

title: N. CAROLINA DOWNS DUKE IN 2 OVERTIMES
description: Michael Jordan scored 5 of his 27 points in the second overtime to lead North Carolina to a 96-83 victory over Duke today in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''The Clock Doctor'' (1871) by Enoch Wood Perry depicts an avuncular old man seated at a table intensely attending to the innards of a clock, as a small boy in overalls watches him raptly, perched on a nearby chair. Such is the stuff of 19th-century American genre painting, a soap opera idiom that appealed to a wide spectrum of middle-class taste in the days before radio and television.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM GOSPELSINGERS TO 'MARIENBAD'
description: Last Year at Marienbad Starring Delphine Seyrig, Giorgio Albertazzi. Screenplay by Alain Robbe-Grillet; directed by Alain Resnais, 1962 JEF Films 93 minutes.

title: Borrowing of Parts Holds Up New Shuttlecraft Launching
description: The first flight of the space shuttle Discovery will be delayed at least two weeks because one of the craft's vital components had to be borrowed for a flight of the shuttle Challenger, space agency officials have confirmed.

title: Correction
description: A review of Def Leppard's ''Pyromania'' on Feb. 19 misstated the catalogue listing. It is Mercury 810 308-1 M-1.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Indiana Pyramid

title: HOFSTRA SWITCHES SIGNALS
description: ALMOST 25 years ago, in the basement of the little theater on the campus of what was then Hofstra College, an FM radio station went on the air. Its 10 watts broadcast to the campus and to a small surrounding area.

title: Zisk Fails Physical
description: Richie Zisk's knee problems started 20 years ago and frequently interrupted his career. Now, two days before his 35th birthday, they may sideline him for good.

title: Truck Driver Cleared by Jury In Thruway Crash Fatal to 3
description: A truck driver charged in a bus-truck crash that killed 3 people and injured 22 others last year was acquitted of charges of reckless driving and driving without a logbook.

title: 1 Killed and 3 Hurt in a Blast And Fire at Home in Queens
description: A powerful gas explosion tore through a Queens home early yesterday, igniting a fire that killed an 11- year-old girl and critically burned her mother and two brothers, authorities said.

title: MEMORY OF A CULTURE
description: Curt Leviant , author of the novel ''The Yemenite Girl,'' is completing a fictional life of the Hasidic master and storyteller Reb Nachman of Bratslav. FROM A RUINED GARDEN

title: Shelley's Mother-in-Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss McGrath to Wed J. J. McNamara
description: Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. McGrath of Pelham Manor and Millbrook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maryann McGrath to James J. McNamara, a son of Kathleen McNamara of Saddle River, N.J., and New York City and the late Gerald C. McNamara.

title: TACKLING ARGENTINA'S WAYWARD ECONOMY
description: BUENOS AIRES BERNARDO GRINSPUN, Economics Minister of Argentina's two-month old democratic Government, describes one of his critics as a ''worker for dictators'' and calls another ''a crystal ball gazer.'' A third, he says, ''doesn't know what he's talking about.''

title: City Seeks Alcohol-Free Day
description: The 60,000 residents of this coastal community have been asked to give up beer, liquor and wine for a week as part of the city's Alcohol Awareness Month.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
DOESN'T QUANTITY COUNT ANYMORE?
description: THE favorite credo of working and otherwise absent mothers is: ''It's not the quantity of time you spend with your children that is important, but the quality of time.''

title: CONCERT: TRIO PLAYS POULENC
description: The Still/Turkovic/Moll trio's Carnegie Recital Hall concert Thursday night had many delights, but with unerring timing, the players saved their best for last - a fleet, joyous and synchronous rendition of Poulenc's Trio for Oboe, Bassoon and Piano, a Chaplinesque exercise in neo-Classicism. In fact, this closing number marked the only time during the evening that all three musicians - the oboist Ray Still, the bassoonist Milan Turkovic and the pianist Phillip Moll - shared the stage.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: THE ''M Counties'' is the way John T. Cunningham, author of the ever-popular ''This is New Jersey'' (Rutgers University Press, New Brunswick 08903, $20; paper, $12.95), refers to Middlesex, Mercer, Monmouth and Morris Counties.

title: INVESTIGATORS CHECK ON THOUSANDS FOR FALSIFIED DEGREES AS DOCTORS
description: Federal and state officials have opened widespread investigations into the validity of medical credentials held by several thousand people working as doctors or seeking medical certification in many areas of the United States.

title: SPRNG FORWARD-LOOKING
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HAND
description: WASHINGTON F OR more than a year, three interlocking questions hovered over the Democrats' extraordinarily long pre-campaign period. Would the Presidential nomination contest last more than a few weeks? Would Walter F. Mondale have trouble getting votes to go with his organizational strength? If so, what contender would emerge with a chance to battle toe-to-toe with Mr. Mondale?

title: THE NATION
description: Congress Works On New Taxes, Just in Case

title:
TV VIEW;
ANN-MARGRET IS RIVETING AS BLANCHE DUBOIS
description: I n the sparsely populated pantheon of this century's

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Sports section on Feb. 19 about Olympic 90-meter ski jumping incorrectly described theaward of a bronze medal in 1974 to Anders Haugen of the United States for his 1924 jumping. The award was not posthumous; Mr. Haugen is living in Yucaipa, Calif.

title: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO FEMINIST FICTION?
description: ONE of the most striking things about recent novels by American women about American women is the fortunate situations of their heroines. They have reasonable incomes, they have good marriages and families, they have friends, they have work, and if they also have their share of life's liabilities - even if, indeed, the liabilities are sometimes the point - they are also blessed with the means of coming to terms with them, through introspection, intellectual application, or, of course, the couch.

title: LEGAL AGE FOR LIQUOR ARGUED ANEW
description: HARTFORD

title: VILLINOVA DEFEATS ST. JOHN'S BY 73-72
description: Gary McLain made a game-clinching steal and converted seven consecutive free throws in overtime today to help Villanova defeat St. John's, 73-72, in the final Big East Conference regular- season game for both teams.

title: Jill S. Adelman to Wed Steven Lustig, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burton Adelman of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jill Susan Adelman, to Steven Lustig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Lustig of Dayton, Ohio. An April wedding is planned.

title:
ART ;
2 SHOWS: MUNCH, 'WORKING DRAWINGS'
description: albeit secondarily - would be the common thread between an exhibition of the prints of the painter Edvard Munch based on the Philip and Lynn Straus collection at the Neuberger Museum at the State University of New York in Purchase and an exhibition of what can generally be called ''working drawings'' of seven contemporary painters and sculptors at the Sarah Lawrence Gallery in Yonkers.

title: Election Day Poll Ban Will Be Tested in Court
description: Washington State election officials said today they hoped television networks' early predictions of Presidential primary results would elicit nationwide support for their state's ban on polling of voters as they leave voting places.

title: Poll Shows Mondale And Hart About Even By The Associated Press
description: A Newsweek poll says Gary Hart is neck and neck with Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential and runs better than Mr. Mondale against President Reagan.

title: Wriston Locklair, 59, Is Dead; Led Juilliard Public Relations
description: Wriston Locklair, director of public relations and assistant to Gideon Waldrop, acting president of the Juilliard School, died Saturday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 59 years old.

title: EXECUTIVES ;  EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., has elected J. A. Brothers a senior vice president.

title: Kathy Sue Bard the Bride Of Joshua Levine, Lawyer
description: At the Sephardic Temple of Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday, Kathy Sue Bard, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold S. Bard of the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn and Palm Beach, Fla., was married to Joshua Seth Levine, a son of Dr. and Mrs. David Levine of Englewood, N.J. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans performed the ceremony.

title: Bill Johnson Wins Downhill in Aspen
description: Bill Johnson continued his assault on the European downhill racers today, winning a World Cup downhill on Aspen Mountain.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A player in a National Hockey League game is racing with the puck toward his opponent's goal when a spectator throws some debris onto the ice that trips him. He loses control of the puck, which is recovered by a defensive player. What is the ruling?

title: CHRYSLER, HIT HARD BY COSTS, STUDIES HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
description: Many American employers say the cost of medical care, which has risen more than tenfold in the last two decades, has become an oppressive burden to their businesses.

title: ; SALVADOR FOOD AID: MINOR MISUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Moncrief Is the Difference
description: Hubie Brown prepares the Knicks for a game differently than most National Basketball Association coaches. Instead of the usual shooting sessions a few hours before a game, the coach holds a ''walk-through'' session. The team is divided into two squads and the opponent's plays and defenses are rehearsed.

title: HART HAS A BIGGER PLANE AND AN EASIER MANNER
description: Gary Hart was celebrating aboard his chartered campaign jet Thursday evening as he completed his first campaign swing through the South, savoring a week in which he won a stunning victory in New Hampshire that propelled him to the role of chief challenger to Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination,

title: Amici Chamber Concert
description: The Amici Chamber Players will perform works by Mozart, Carl Maria von Weber, August Klughardt and others Wednesday at 8:30 P.M. in the Salmagundi Club, 47 Fifth Avenue. There is a suggested contribution of $5. Information: 255-7740.

title: Market PlaceSpotlight On Takeovers
description: T AKEOVERS and rumors of takeovers are instilling life into the stock market these days,

title: AT PRINCETON, ACADEMIA VS. LITTLE RED RIDING HOOD
description: Once upon a time, long before critics talked of ''intertextual analysis,'' before feminism and Marxism, before Jung and Freud, some simple folk sat in circles and told stories about cinder maids and princes and houses made of sugar and cake and snow-white birds that helped little children find their way out of the great green forest.

title: CABARET: DEBBIE SHAPIRO SINGS AT FREDDY'S
description: DEBBIE SHAPIRO, who is currently singing on Broadway in the musical ''Zorba!'', has the requisite accoutrements of a theatrical belter, but it is the softer and more thoughtful side of her musical personality that makes the most pleasing impression in a nightclub. Miss Shapiro, who is giving midnight shows at Freddy's Supper Club, Thursdays through Saturdays until March 17, has a relaxed smoky delivery that recalls the quieter side of Melissa Manchester.

title: STAGE: 'FEN' RETURNS WITH AN AMERICAN CAST
description: THERE'S little sunshine and no hope in the dank, Thomas Hardy-hued world of Caryl Churchill's ''Fen.'' Miss Churchill's characters are downtrodden women who toil in the potato fields of the Fens, an agrarian community in East Anglia. The women live like serfs; they plod from day to day only with the help of such opiates as religion, Valium, booze and sex. Their only peace comes in death.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Area for Art Galleries

title: EAST BLOC LENDING CLIMATE IMPROGES
description: The climate for private bank lending to Eastern European nations has begun to improve in the first upturn since the Polish debt crisis of 1981. Most Eastern European nations, not following Poland's lead, have seen their debt situation improve because of better trade balances and the steps they have taken to reorganize their internal economies.

title: KOHL URGES A U.S.-SOVIET PARLEY BEFORE NOVEMBER
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl urged today that a United States-Soviet summit meeting be held before the Presidential elections.

title: DRUG ARRESTS MOUNTING ON THE LOWER EAST SIDE
description: The movements were sudden and swift.

title: KOCH'S FLAWED HISTORY OF EUROPEAN JEWRY
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption in some editions of Sports Pages on Saturday misidentified the Knicks player in the picture. He was Marvin Webster.

title: PROSPECTS BRIGHTEN FOR PARK AVE. DELI AS RESISTANCE EBBS
description: After weeks of neighborhood uproar and bureaucratic entanglements, the sagging fortunes of a Korean immigrant who wants to open a delicatessen amid the luxury of Park Avenue and 75th Street were looking up yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1984

title: Big Canadian Trade Surplus
description: Canada's surplus in its current account narrowed last year from 1982, but was still the second highest on record, according to the Government. The Government agency Statistics Canada said the nation ended the year with a surplus of $329 million (Canadian) - about $263 million in United States funds - in its current account, giving a surplus for the full year of $1.58 billion (Canadian). In 1982, Canada's current account registered a record surplus of $3.02 billion.

title: 2 AFRIKANERS RAISE DOUBTS ON SEX LAWS
description: Senior South African theologians and intellectuals have begun an assault on the religious and moral arguments used to justify a body of law forbidding sexual relationships between people of different races.

title: PUBLIC POMP AND PRIVATE YAWNS AS RUSSIANS VOTE
description: The Soviet Union held national elections today, an event rich in civic ceremony but entirely lacking in suspense.

title: TOWN SAYS ELDERLY ARE THE 'INDUSTRY'
description: This woodsy 82-square-mile slice of the Pine Barrens is the retirement capital of New Jersey.

title: Miss Chisholm Is Asked About Vice Presidency
description: Former Representative Shirley Chisholm says all the candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination have approached her about joining them as a Vice-Presidential candidate.

title: Allison Is Winner In Carolina 500
description: Bobby Allison pulled away in the late going today to win the Carolina 500 Grand National stock car race at North Carolina Motor Speedway.

title: CANUCKS DEFEAT RANGERS BY 5-4
description: The road to the playoffs has suddenly brought the Rangers down a path of potholes. With only 12 games to go in the regular season, and the likes of Philadelphia, Washington or the Islanders awaiting them in the first round of postseason play, they are now in their worst slump of the season.

title: Gulf Board May Meet Today
description: The board of the Gulf Corporation is expected to meet in emergency session today amid speculation that it will be considering a takeover offer from the Atlantic Richfield Company. The Standard Oil Company of California is also known to be seriously considering a bid for Gulf, but it was uncertain whether any proposal from Socal would be under consideration.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Kronenbourg Beer

title: IMASCO'S SUCCESS IN DRUGSTORES
description: Shoppers Drug Mart last year told its customers ''thanks a billion'' in an advertising campaign that celebrated its first year with more than $1 billion (Canadian) in sales.

title: Convict Waits 1 1/2 Hours To Give Up to the Police
description: An escaped prisoner waited one and a half hours in the cold before finding someone to surrender to early this morning, a day after a fellow fugitive was captured, officials said.

title: New Top Dog
description: The poodle is No.1 no more.

title: An Explanaton
description: Howard Cosell was kidding Joe Pepitone the other night about the failure of the former Yankee to live up to his early promise.

title: CHANNEL J PORNOGRAPHY IS CAUSE OF LOCKOUT LAW
description: -night viewing

title: THE KEYS TO SUCCESS IN ASSISTANCE PLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.S.Bills650inaCampaign To Collect Full Taxes on Tips
description: The Internal Revenue Service asserted today that about 650 casino waitresses and waiters had each failed to report about $10,000 in tips from 1980 and owed the Government an average of $2,397 in back taxes.

title: Lockheed Awards
description: The Lockheed Corporation received a total of $79.6 million in Air Force and Navy contracts, according to the Defense Department. It said the company got $68 million from the Air Force for work on TR-1A tactical reconnaissance aircraft and $11.6 million from the Navy for P-3 patrol aircraft equipment. In addition, the Hughes Aircraft Company received a $44.5 million Navy contract for tactical displays systems for ships.

title: Parties Get $12 Million To Stage Conventions
description: The Federal Election Commission has given the Republican and Democratic National Committees $189,000 each as the final installment of the $6,060,000 million each gets to stage its Presidential nominating convention.

title: HART, IN 2D UPSET, DEFEATS MONDALE IN MAINE CAUCUSES
description: Gary Hart defeated Walter F. Mondale in the Maine Democratic caucuses tonight, scoring his second upset victory in a week in the race for the party's Presidential nomination.

title: GEMAYEL'S SURRENDER
description: Lebanese President Amin Gemayel has brought home from Damascus the kind of ''peace for our time'' that Neville Chamberlain brought home from Munich.

title: No Headline
description: Teri Huebner Marries

title: SUNDAY TREAT: DEVILS LEAVE LAST PLACE
description: By defeating the Los Angeles Kings, 5-3, tonight the Devils accomplished the rarities of scoring a short-handed goal, going unbeaten in three games and moving out of last place.

title: Banker-Oil Link Reported
description: A Chicago banker who managed the loan portfolio of the Davis Oil Company received interests in 78 of the company's wells, according to reports published today.

title: No Headline
description: T. Suffern Tailer Dies; Amateur Golfer in 30's

title: Spring Job
description: Todd Maulding knows that dreams can come true.

title: Washington WatchDeregulation For a 2d Term
description: WASHINGTON D EREGULATION may be stalled, but it's not over - at least in the hopes of the Reagan Administration. Christopher C. DeMuth, the Office of Management and Budget's regulatory chief, has composed a wish-list of what a re-elected Administration's regulatory agenda might look like. He prepared it for the Cabinet Council on Economic Affairs last December, but it has only now come to light.

title: A CHURCH SIGNAL TO POLES
description: It is hard for people in the West to understand the significance of the recent demonstration in Warsaw protesting a seemingly minor decision by the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church. Yet for many Poles, the incident sent an ominous signal. In fact, it may mark the beginning of a serious shift in the role of the church in Poland - although not, perhaps, as threatening a shift as many Poles seem to fear.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Traveling Testimonial

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Jerrico Chief Quits; Aide Named to Post

title: Vigneron Vaults 19-2 1/4 Indoors
description: Thierry Vigneron of France pole-vaulted to a world indoor best of 19 feet 2 1/4 inches in the 15th European Indoor Track and Field Championships today.

title: The U.N. Today March 5, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: LIETZKE BEATS BEAN IN ONE-HOLE PLAYOFF
description: Bruce Lietzke today became the fifth golfer to win a PGA Tour event in a sudden-death playoff this year when he parred the first extra hole and beat Andy Bean in the $500,000 Honda Classic.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of incorrect caption material supplied by Camera Press Ltd, the picture in some editions Saturday accompanying the obituary of Roland Culver, the British actor, was not of Mr. Culver.

title: Reagans Observe Their 32d
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, observed their 32d wedding anniversary privately at the White House today.

title: No Headline
description: IF the bronze plaques honoring those Dodgers

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OUT OF ANTIQUITY

title: People
description: * Thomas Crotty appointed an executive vice president of Sudler & Hennessey.

title: 110 ARE SICKENED BY IMPURE WATER
description: More than 100 residents of this depressed steel town have been sickened by a tiny parasite that has invaded the aging water system and is forcing 45,000 people to boil their drinking water or buy bottled water.

title: PRIVACY CALLED SPUR TO TAX BILL
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, in less than two days last week, approved a $49.3 billion tax increase over the next four years. About the same time, the Senate Finance Committee slogged through its fourth day on a similar bill and will have to meet again next week to finish.

title: MONDALE AND HART TRADE SHARPEST WORDS YET, OVER ARMS CONTROL
description: Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart, the leading Democratic Presidential contenders, had the sharpest exchange of the campaign tonight in a debate over who is more committed to arms control.

title: EARLY REVISION OF SANDINO'S BANDIT IMAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDAY, MARCH 5, 1984 International
description: Formal scrapping of the accord Lebanon reached last May with Israel on security and on a simultaneous Syrian and Israeli troop withdrawal from Lebanon, will be started today, Lebanon's Foreign Minister said. Cancellation of the American-sponsored agreement has been a key Syrian demand in talks on a formula to end Lebanon's political violence. (Page A1, Column 1.) Heavy fighting broke out again in Beirut between the Lebanese Army and anti-Government militiamen as negotiations continued between Lebanese and Syrian officials in Damascus. Fighting was also reported at the strategic mountain town of Suk al Gharb, Shuweifat and Kfar Chima, along the Lebanese Army's line protecting the presidential palace at Baabda. (A6:1.)

title: GLENN, IN SOUTH, PRESSES ISSUES OF 'CHARACTER' FITNESS FOR PRESIDENCY
description: John Glenn, in an effort to rouse his faltering campaign, has raised the pitch of criticism on what he calls the ''character issue'' against his principal Democratic rivals, Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.86

title: EX-SOLIDARITY ADVISER DEFENDED
description: A pro- Solidarity priest gave a sermon today defending a one-time legal adviser to the Solidarity union who faces possible criminal charges of slandering the state.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Carlsberg Corp., a Santa Monica, Calif., real estate company, began a public offering of 25,000 units priced at $1,000 each through Drexel Burnham Lambert; each unit consists of $1,000 principal amount of 9 3/8 percent subordinated notes due March 1, 1994, plus 28 common shares and 20 warrants.

title: PEERING INTO THE STRIKING FACES OF FELLINI AND ALLEN
description: THE handsome opera singer has a face like a death mask, pale and frozen, her features distorted by the envy that twists her spirit. A kindly, foolish journalist has the face of an intelligent clown, his eyes sad and hopeful, his flyaway hair wispy and airborne. The face of an animal keeper tending a rhinoceros has come to bear a remarkable resemblance to his hideous but beloved charge.

title: GERMAINE GREER'S NEW BOOK STIRS A DEBATE
description: Even before publication here, Germaine Greer's new book, ''Sex and Destiny,'' has created a controversy over whether the sexual revolution has emancipated women or worsened their situation.

title: HOUSTON STREAK IS ENDED AT 39
description: Arkansas defeated Houston, 73-68, today, to end the Cougars' 39-game Southwest Conference winning streak.

title: OUTDOORS: WINTER PERCH IN LONG ISLAND STREAMS
description: -area anglers indoors, not so much because they lack fortitude in facing the elements, but rather because the season provides scant motivation in the form of fishing opportunities. One exception remains largely unknown. While the great majority await either the first late-winter warm spell to awaken flounder from their cold-induced dormancy, or April 1 to observe ritualistically the opening day of the trout season, a small cadre of hardy anglers are pulling scrappy, brassy- flanked white perch from the coastal creeks that drain Long Island.

title: AIR FORCE WANTS NEW CARGO PLANE
description: The Air Force has decided, in a master plan for air transport, that it wants to stop buying the Lockheed C-5 cargo plane after current production. Instead, it plans to acquire 220 new aircraft called the C-17, built by McDonnell Douglas, over the next 30 years.

title: 1,000 Are Reported Dead In North Nigeria Clashes
description: A Government-owned newspaper reported today that as many as 1,000 people had died in a week of religious violence in the northeast Nigerian city of Yola and that fighting was still raging.

title: CONFERENCE EXPLORES WAYS TO SUPPORT THE ELDERLY
description: ''Just how robust is the family as a support system for the elderly?'' Dr. Ethel Shanas asked before the silent conference audience. ''We may well ask that, given the forces that have created strain on families as the caretakers of the elderly sick: the increasing proportion of women in the labor force, the decline of family size and the high percentage of families headed by single women.''

title: GERMAN MACHINE TOOLS' RISE
description: Twenty-five years ago the plodding pace of Trumpf G.m.b.H., a sleepy manufacturer of metal shears and power tools, left most people wondering whether the company's beech-leaf logotype symbolized the bloom of spring or the slow decline of autumn.

title: COURT STILL UNRAVELING COAL DEAL HOFFA MADE
description: A little more than a decade ago, not long before he disappeared under still-unexplained circumstances, James R. Hoffa became a secret partner in an ill-fated buyout of a network of debt- ridden coal companies.

title: HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL AT 75
description: It was five years ago that the president of Harvard University broke the carefully nurtured academic quiet here, publishing a commentary on business education that many considered a slap at Harvard Business School's time-honored teaching methods and the direction of its research.

title: TV: AMERICAN BALLET'S 'DON QUIXOTE'
description: THE television version of American Ballet Theater's ''Don Quixote,'' to be shown tonight at 8 on Channel 13, gives a very good idea of what the ballet is like on stage. That means that watchers will probably find it either adorable or silly.

title: SHOLA LYNCH IS AHEAD OF SCHEDULE
description: WINTER'S bitter chill just would not pass. Trees in Central Park, left bare from weeks of cold, swayed under sharp gusts of wind and pedestrians struggled along while seeking relief in scarves and bulky coats.

title: Stearns Reports No Elbow Pain
description: John Stearns of the Mets reported no pain in his damaged elbow today after taking batting practice for the second straight day, and said, ''I feel I'm finally on the right road.''

title: JAZZ:KELLAWAY AND MOORE
description: PAIRING Roger Kellaway on piano and Michael Moore on bass gave Xinno, the restaurant at 128 West Street, an unusually provocative jazz duo, through last night. Mr. Kellaway, who has lived and done most of his performing in California for more than a decade, has recently moved back to New York, bringing with him a fascinating, adventurous and virtuosic approach to the piano.

title: WRITERS AND ABC REACH PACT
description: Half an hour before a scheduled strike, ABC reached a tentative agreement on issues of jurisdiction and job security with its news writers and graphic artists, a spokesman for the their union said last night.

title: PURCHASING AGENTS CITE HIGHER PRICES
description: Industrial companies reported sharp increases in production, inventories and new orders in February, the National Association of Purchasing Managers said yesterday in its monthly survey.

title: U.S. TO SUPPORT MEN'S LAWSUITS ON BIAS DECREE
description: The Justice Department has gone to court to challenge actions taken by the city of Birmingham, Ala., under a decree that the department signed three years ago to increase the hiring and promotion of blacks and women in the city's police and fire departments.

title: FEDERAL CALLOUSNESS ON DANGERS OF EDB
description: The decision to pull contaminated cake mixes from supermarket shelves has left a widespread impression that Americans are being protected from the cancer- causing ethylene dibromide, a colorless liquid pesticide. In fact, as many as 150,000 workers handling EDB- treated grain and citrus products are still being exposed to EDB levels many times higher than those deemed ''safe'' for consumers, to the apparent indifference of Government officials charged with protecting public health and safety.

title: Commandant for West Point
description: The Army has announced the appointment of Brig. Gen. Peter J. Boylan Jr. of the 82d Airborne Divison at Fort Bragg, N.C., as commandant of cadets of the United States Military Academy.

title: No Headline
description: Advertising

title: FRENCH RALLY DEFENDS CATHOLIC SCHOOLS
description: A crowd estimated by the police at more than a half million people gathered today in the streets of Versailles to protest the Socialist Government's plan to tighten state control over the country's largely Roman Catholic private schools.

title: NEW GULF WAR ISSUE: CHEMICAL ARMS
description: A senior Iraqi general suggested here today that Iraq reserved the right to use chemical weapons.

title: South African Expects Rebels to Fight Pacts
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha said today that he expected guerrilla groups fighting the Mozambican and South African Governments to try to ''torpedo'' peace accords between the two countries.

title: Post Gets Bid
description: C. W. Post College of Greenvale, L.I., was invited yesterday to take part in the Division II basketball playoffs of the National Collegiate Athletic Asssociation for the second straight year. The Pioneers won a second straight Big Apple Conference championship by beating Pace, 84-62, on Saturday night for their 29th straight home victory.

title: Power Is Upset
description: St. Francis Prep upset highly regarded Power Memorial, 59-54, and All Hallows defeated Bishop Loughlin, the defending state champion, 61- 54, yesterday at Manhattan College to advance to the semifinals of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball playoffs.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVE BEATS MRS. LLOYD, 6-3, 7-5, 6-1
description: Martina Navratilova ended a season of stunning accomplishments yesterday by pushing herself to the limit in the final of the Virginia Slims Championships and beating Chris Evert Lloyd for the ninth straight time.

title: Police in Indian State Get Emergency Powers
description: The government of Punjab state authorized the police in three districts today to ''shoot to kill'' lawbreakers and to conduct searches and make arrests without warrants.

title: Divided in Prayer
description: Two congregations of honorable Americans will lobby Congress about religion this week. Thousands will pray into Tuesday morning for a constitutional amendment allowing organized prayer in public schools. A smaller but no less devout group will conduct a counter-vigil as the Senate debates a series of prayer proposals.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday

title: BRIEFING
description: White House Kids

title: Ross Roy Acquires Control of Colarossi
description: Ross Roy of Detroit has acquired a majority interest in Colarossi Griswold in New York, a move that returns the agency's banner to the Big Apple. Glen W. Fortinberry, chairman and chief executive of Ross Roy, said the acquisition reflected the agency's strategic intent.

title: Accounts
description: * Stearns & Foster Company to the Bloom Agency/New York.

title: SUSPICIONS OF FALSE MEDICAL CREDENTIALS IGNORED, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The administrator of the Middletown Psychiatric Center said today that she had tried unsuccessfully for four months to get state authorities to investigate the professional qualifications and credentials of a ''doctor'' on her staff.

title: AGREEING ON RAISING CHILDREN
description: SO he says po-TAY-to and she

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Ex-President of Puritan Heads Klein Jeans Unit

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: FOR HANDLERS OF DEVIL'S BAG, A SEARCH FOR ANSWERS
description: THE champagne dinner had been planned earlier Saturday afternoon, when a colt named Devil's Bag was still unbeaten and still looked unbeatable. Now, on Saturday night, two hours after Devil's Bag had finished a distant fourth in the Flamingo Stakes, Philip Gleaves glumly lifted his glass of bubbly and stared at it.

title: TWINS ARE THE DEVICE IN ABC'S 'DARK MIRROR'
description: IS television on a twins binge? A couple of weeks ago, the final episode on CBS of Sidney Sheldon's ''Master of the Game'' revolved around female twins, one trusting and almost saintly, the other viciously diabolical. More or less a similar situation is milked in ''Dark Mirror,'' tonight's television movie on ABC at 9. The use of the same device seems to be a coincidence. Let's hope so.

title: Stallions Defeat Express
description: Joe Cribbs ran 18 yards for a touchdown early in the fourth quarter to help the Birmingham Stallions beat the Los Angeles Express, 21-14, today before a crowd of 14,789.

title: Dancer Fitzgerald Adds Popsicle Products
description: Popsicle Industries, a unit of Consolidated Foods, has shifted some advertising to Dancer Fitzgerald Sample from other agencies.

title: 96 in House Bid Reagan Spur Food Aid for Africa
description: Almost 100 House members formally asked President Reagan today to send emergency grain shipments to Africa and take other steps to ease a food crisis there.

title: Interco Is Winner At Santa Anita
description: Interco, ridden by Pat Valenzuela, passed Journey at Sea at the top of the stretch and pulled away for a 2 3/4- length victory today in the $523,650 Santa Anita Handicap.

title: THE DANCE: JUDITH HOOK PERFORMS
description: SATURDAY night's performance by the Judith Hook Dance Company at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio ought to have been fun. Miss Hook, a choreographer from Rochester, let dance follow dance with only the slightest of pauses, as if her creations were whims of the moment. She set them to jazz, country music and pieces by such disparate but genial composers as Fats Waller and Felix Mendelssohn. And she stressed the informality of the occasion by referring to her dancers by their first names in the program.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Passes 31,000
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 29 points today to become the second player in National Basketball Association history to exceed the 31,000- point mark.

title: SENATOR ANDERSON PROPOSES A 5-YEAR PLAN OF TAX CUTS IN STATE
description: Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, yesterday proposed a five-year program of tax cuts to save the state's taxpayers $1.5 billion a year by 1989.

title: Florida Bank Is Shut
description: The All American National Bank of Virginia Gardens, Fla., was declared insolvent and closed on Friday, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today. All American National, which had deposits of approximately $11 million, had suffered deterioration in its loan portfolio, the Government agency said. The F.D.I.C. was named receiver.

title: GENERALS TOP BULLS BY 28-26
description: For the second week in a row the New Jersey Generals played before a record crowd and for the second time the Generals won. They defeated the Jacksonville Bulls today by 28-26 when Danny Miller's 41-yard field goal attempt went wide to the right with 44 seconds left.

title: GROWING BUDGET DEFICIT
description: The deficit in the Federal budget, which has emerged as a prime issue in the 1984 election campaign, looks like a familiar problem but is really a new one. The deficit is likely to keep widening for years to come, even if the economy continues to grow toward full employment. The nation is now facing a built-in, or structural, deficit - one that will persist whether the business cycle is swinging up or down - unless something is done to slow the growth of Federal spending or to increase the growth of tax revenues or both.

title: SUPPLY OF BONDS LIGHT THIS WEEK
description: Credit market particpants are facing a light supply of new corporate and tax-exempt bonds this week, as high interest rates continue to deter corporate issuers. Many potential borrowers in the tax-exempt market are also stymied while Congress considers new laws limiting sales of various kinds of revenue bonds.

title: BUDGET MANUEVERS, PARTLY OFFSTAGE
description: Since January, the White House has had two goals for the Federal budget: To make some progress in reducing the deficit and to get the credit for any progress in reducing the deficit.

title: ARCO LOAN ATTRACTIVE FOR BANKS
description: Banks around the world clamored last week to participate in the biggest loan ever arranged for a single borrower, $12 billion to the Atlantic Richfield Company. The proceeds are expected to be used by Arco in its bid to acquire the Gulf Corporation.

title: Israel Denies Druse Request
description: A group of Israeli Druse appealed today to the Mayor of Haifa not to receive crewmen from the United States battleship New Jersey because the vessel had shelled Druse villages in Lebanon. The ship has been in the port since Friday. Mayor Arye Gurel dismissed the Druse request, saying that arrangements for a reception on Tuesday had already been completed.

title: U.S. MILITARY URGED TO RECRUIT MORE WOMEN
description: The nation's military services, particularly the Air Force, should make better use of women's talent, the chairman of the House Armed Services Subcommittee on Military Personnel and Compensation said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pies and a Pigeon At the Inner Circle Show

title: Miss O'Toole Married To Christopher Young
description: Rosemary O'Toole, the daughter of Laurence J. O'Toole and the late Marjorie W. O'Toole of Syracuse, was married yesterday to Christopher Norland Young, a son of William S. Young of Cincinnati and Esther N. Young of St. Louis. Family Court Judge Stanley Nason performed the ceremony at a private town house in New York.

title: GASOLINE STORAGE TANKS THAT LEAK EDB INTO GROUNDWATER
description: To the Editor:

title: DOLLAR FALLS IN JAPAN
description: -The dollar fell in early, hectic trading today to a two-year low of 226.60, from the 227.70 New York finish Friday, dealers said. Later it fell further to 225.30 yen, which is the lowest since January 1982, when the dollar touched 217.80, the dealers said.

title: D'AUBUISSON DENIES TIE TO SALVADOR DEATH SQUADS
description: A right-wing candidate in El Salvador's presidential election has denied accusations that he was involved in the country's death squads.

title: MANNES COLLEGE IS CELEBRATING ITS MOVE EAST SIDE TO WEST
description: Picking a music school up bodily and moving it across Central Park is not something one does every day, so when the Mannes College of Music officially opens its new headquarters on West 85th Street today, something of a celebration is being planned. It all begins at 5:30 this afternoon. Mayor Koch is coming and will have a go at conducting the Mannes Brass Ensemble.

title: ARCHITECT AND PRESERVATIONIST
description: Alan Burnham, an architect whose research provided the intellectual foundation for the architectural preservation movement in New York, and a former executive director of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, died Saturday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 71 years old.

title: St. John's Women Win in Big East
description: Barbara Rapp scored a game-high 18 points and had 9 rebounds as St. John's routed Senton Hall, 66-46, yesterday at Alumni Hall to win a second straight Big East Conference women's basketball title and qualify for the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. to Appeal Order On Trapping Wolves

title: 11 ISRAELIS HURT IN SIDON
description: As negotiations continued between Lebanese and Syrian officials in Damascus, sharp clashes broke out between the Lebanese Army and anti-Government militiamen along parts of the Green Line dividing East and West Beirut.

title: Jeffrey Alexander Wed To Ellen Stacey Evans
description: Ellen Stacey Evans, a daughter of Myrna Green of New York and Ben Evans of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Marshall Alexander, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Alexander of Memphis. Rabbis Hillel Friedman and Alex Goldman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Stamford.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Montreal Expos at West Palm Beach, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Yankees open a home-and-home exhibition series against Montreal, the new home of Pete Rose. (Radio - WABC 770, 1:30 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Utah Jazz at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M., So far the Nets have at least one victory against three of the four division leaders in the National Basketball Association - Los Angeles in the Pacific, Milwaukee in the Central and Boston in the Atlantic. But this is their last chance to beat the Midwest Division-leading Jazz. The Jazz beat the Nets in Salt Lake City. Utah brings in Adrian Dantley, who is competing for the N.B.A. scoring lead, for his only appearance at Byrne Meadowlands Arena this season. (Television - SportsChannel 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.).

title: Penn State Wins IC4A Track Title
description: Penn State, helped by Randy Moore's victory in the 800-meter run and a fourth-place finish in the final event, the mile relay, won its first IC4A indoor track and field championship in 25 years today, edging George Mason by 1 point.

title: O'NEILL HOPE ON IRELAND SEEMS TIED TO ELECTION
description: If Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. wants to become ambassador to Ireland, as he has said, he will have to pin his hopes on a Democratic Presidential victory in November.

title: JACKSON OUTLINES HIS VIEWS TO JEWISH GROUP
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson went back before a Jewish audience today to forge a reconciliation with Jews, but he left many members of his audience still expressing skepticism about his feelings toward them.

title: AIDE SAYS GEMAYEL WILL MOVE TODAY TO CUT ISRAEL LINK
description: Lebanon's Foreign Minister, here for talks with Syrian officials, said today that President Amin Gemayel would begin on Monday the process of formally canceling the security and troop withdrawal agreement Lebanon reached last May with Israel.

title: DENNIS MARTINEZ THINKING POSITIVELY
description: While his teammates were playing their way to the World Series last season, Dennis Martinez was thinking only of making his way back to the team's hotel. Champagne awaited the Baltimore Orioles in the Series; a bottle of iced wine awaited Martinez at the hotel.

title: 6 ARABS WOUNDED IN WEST BANK WHEN GUNMEN OPEN FIRE ON BUS
description: At least six Arabs were wounded today when three or four masked gunmen opened fire with automatic weapons at a crowded bus traveling along a narrow road in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LOYALTIES. By Daniel Patrick Moynihan. 96 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95. THE mind of Daniel Patrick Moynihan has ranged so nimbly over so many subjects that the senior Senator of New York may well be the foremost scholar-politician of the land. This slender volume, appearing midway through his second senatorial term, continues Mr. Moynihan's tradition of elegant and original thinking on the big questions of the day. The Senator puts three subjects under scrutiny, all of them having to do with America's role in the world and all of them related to the concept of loyalty - to nation, to good sense, to immutable principle - that the Senator sees his fellow citizens and politicians abandoning at our great peril.

title: EX-AUTO MAKER TO GO ON TRIAL AFTER LONG WAIT
description: Seventeen months after his arrest here by Federal undercover agents who said they acted as he was concluding a multimillion-dollar drug deal, John Z. DeLorean is to go on trial this week on charges of trafficking in cocaine.

title: Snow and TornadosWhip Across Nation By The Associated Press
description: Winter storms in Colorado and Minnesota brought up to eight inches of snow to the eastern foothills of the Rockies yesterday, while a tornado touched down in Louisiana and twisters threatened the Southwest.

title: 8,000 MARCHERS PROTEST PHILIPPINE ELECTIONS
description: About 8,000 anti-Government demonstrators approached to within 20 miles of Manila from both the north and south today in marches to promote a boycott of May 14 parliamentary elections.

title: EPISCOPAL BISHOP
description: Bishop Charles Alfred Voegeli, a former Episcopal Bishop in Haiti who was forced at gunpoint to leave that country in 1964, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 79 years old.

title: Futures/OptionsProfit Squeeze Hurts Brokers
description: Trouble is brewing in the booming futures brokerage business. Indeed, the futures brokerage industry may be on the verge of a shakeout, despite the enormous growth of futures and options business in recent years.

title: THE DEATH GRIP
description: Failure in Lebanon now dominates thinking on U.S. foreign policy. But that preoccupation is likely to be overtaken soon by a far more menacing situation: in El Salvador. There President Reagan's policy is visibly unraveling, and there is no sign that he will change course as he did in Lebanon.

title: Miss Lopez Wins
description: Nancy Lopez, appearing poised to reclaim her position as a dominant player on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, coasted to a three-stroke victory today in the $300,000 Uniden Invitational.

title: GWENDOLYN R. MORGAN
description: Gwendolyn R. Morgan, the wife of Rear Adm. Armand M. Morgan of the Navy, retired, died Feb. 26 of congestive heart failure at the Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md.

title: No Headline
description: -Pediatrics Professor

title: U.S.I.A. BLACKLIST IS BEYOND 'STUPID'
description: To the Editor:

title: Airport Name Is Reinstated
description: Port of Seattle commissioners have reinstated the old name of the airport rechristened for Henry M. Jackson after he died Sept. 1 after more than 30 years in the Senate. The name was changed back to Seattle-Tacoma International Airport last Tuesday.

title: CLUES TO FED POLICY IN FEBRUARY FIGURES
description: Yields of more than 12 percent on Treasury bonds are a good sign that many investors are reluctant to buy long-term notes or bonds while there are warnings that an expanding economy is likely to bring higher interest rates and lower bond prices.

title: Rip Kee
description: RICHARD Rossano cried, his family remembers, when Ruffian broke two bones in her right foreleg during the match race with Foolish Pleasure in 1975. He cried again the next morning, when Ruffian was destroyed following a futile operation. And he cried a third time when the filly was buried that evening, with the flags at half mast, in the infield at Belmont Park.

title: Block, Disguised, Tours Soup Kitchens
description: Suzanne Block, wife of Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, has eaten at soup kitchens disguised in a wig, jeans and an old coat to see how the poor are fed, a department spokesman has confirmed.

title: SALES TO OPEC NATIONS SLUMP
description: A sharp drop in revenues flowing from oil-importing industrial nations to OPEC has been undeniably good for the industrial economies. The billions once spent on petroleum are now staying at home, helping to lift personal incomes and finance purchases of more productive goods.

title: Letter: On Iran Deploring the Crimes of Khomeini
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO SUGGESTS CAREY PAPERS BE AUCTIONED
description: Governor Cuomo is considering putting the official papers of his predecessor, Hugh L. Carey, on microfilm or auctioning them to a university to make them available to historians.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 5, 1984: MONDAY

title: ELECTRIC CO-OPS FACING CHALLENGES ON RACIAL MAKEUP OF BOARDS
description: Upset by rising utility rates, a group of blacks in this central Mississipi town decided last year to run for seats on the all- white board of their local rural electrical cooperative.

title: Election Board Validates McGovern Primary Petitions
description: The state Board of Elections decided Friday to keep former Senator George McGovern on New York's April 3 Democratic primary ballot despite a technical error in his application.

title: Michael Jay Paul Wed To Marilyn Gail Spiro
description: The marriage of Marilyn Gail Spiro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Spiro of Kings Point, L.I., to Michael Jay Paul, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Paul of Oceanside, L.I., took place yesterday at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, assisted by Cantor Barbara Ostfeld-Horowitz, performed the ceremony.

title: Hall of Fame Picks Reese and Ferrell
description: Pee Wee Reese, the shortstop and captain of the old Brooklyn Dodgers, and Rick Ferrell, who caught a record 1,805 games in the American League, were voted into baseball's Hall of Fame today by the committee on veterans.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Fraser and Califano and I know where all the skeletons are buried.

title: BUFFALO'S RAIDS ON APARTMENTS CAUSE BACKLASH
description: Peter Baxter, 22 years old, was up early studying when four Buffalo police officers entered the house he shares with seven other students from the State University here.

title: Indy Driver Killed
description: Mike Mosley, a driver in 15 Indianapolis 500 auto races, was killed Saturday night in a highway accident. Mosley was 37 years old. His son, Michael, 13, was with him but was not seriously hurt.

title: KOCH'S FLAWED HISTORY OF EUROPEAN JEWRY
description: To the Editor:

title: UTAH TOWNS DEBATE NUCLEAR WASTES
description: The debate about what to do with highly radioactive waste from nuclear power plants is leaving deep divisions in small towns here, deep in southeastern Utah.

title: Body of Missing Duck Hunter Found in State Park in Jersey
description: The body of a teen-age duck hunter who had been missing since last November was found by a passer-by on the shore at Island Beach State Park, the police said today. The body of the hunter - Frank Forfa, 19 years old, of Lacey Township - washed ashore Saturday on the Barnegat Bay side of the island, Officer Art Unkefer of the State Police Department Marine Police said. Mr. Forfa and a companion, Richard Harrold, 16, were lost Nov. 25, 1983, after they had went off in a boat to set duck decoys on a small marsh island in Barnegat Bay. Mr. Harrold's body was found eight days later, Officer Unkefer said.

title: Oilers Triumph By 6-1
description: Glenn Anderson scored a pair of first-period goals 42 seconds apart tonight and Wayne Gretzky added two goals and an assist, leading the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Student Allowed to Use Execution Description
description: Joellen Stanton's photograph in the 1984 Brunswick High School's yearbook, ''Dragon,'' will be accompanied by a graphic description of what happens when a person is electrocuted.

title: Bridge: A Defender's Misdemeanor Saves Contract for an Expert
description: Legal misdemeanors can generate unusual positions at the bridge table, and an adaptable expert may be able to take advantage of his opponent's misfortune.

title: MULLIN DRIVES HIMSELF TO EXCEL AS PREPARATION FOR THE PROS
description: UNDER the cover of darkness, he often will return to Alumni Hall at St. John's University for another hour or more of practice. It is during times of solitude such as these that Chris Mullin might play imaginary games on the basketball court, entertaining himself as he did when he was a boy in Brooklyn and would go into his backyard to continue the game he had been watching on television.

title: Nuclear Power Plan From Ebasco Chairman
description: William Wallace 3d, chairman of Ebasco Services Inc., has spent his entire career at that New York company, which designs, engineers and builds some of the world's biggest nuclear power plants.

title: HUGH ODISHAW, 67, WHO LED U.S. EFFORT IN SCIENTIFIC YEAR
description: Hugh Odishaw, director of American endeavors for the International Geophysical Year of 1957-58, a vast undertaking to unlock the secrets of the earth and solar system, died of cancer at the University of Arizona Medical Center yesterday morning. He was 67 years old and a resident of Tucson.

title: Behold: Election-Year Taxes
description: Suddenly there's a will in Congress to raise taxes. The House Ways and Means Committee would collect $50 billion more over three years.

title: QUINTUPLETS' FATHER LOST STRUGGLE IN THE LIMELIGHT
description: He was known as a gentle, easygoing man. He enjoyed cooking bacon and eggs for his seven children in the morning and puttering around his rambling yard in the afternoon.

title: Two Die in the Crash of Auto Driven by an ex-Jets Lineman
description: Two passengers were killed when a car driven by Kenny Neil, a former New York Jets lineman, veered off a road near Kennedy Airport and hit a telephone pole last night, the police reported.

title: RETIREMENT TOWNS FLOURISH IN JERSEY'S FIELDS
description: Rolling land near here that was largely cornfields two years ago is Concordia now, one of the newest of 41 New Jersey retirement villages that are attracting Easterners who prefer closeness to family and friends to the year-round warmth of Florida or the Southwest.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A book review Tuesday of ''A Time of Passion'' by Charles R. Morris misidentified one of two authors of popular ideas that formed the root of ''a fifty-year tradition of expansive pragmatism'' culminating in the Presidency of John F. Kennedy. He was William James.

title: MUSIC: ANNIE FISCHER
description: THE Hungarian pianist Annie Fischer, who offered a program of early Romantic music at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night, retains the vivid, individualist, artistic profile that was once expected from a performng musician but that has by now passed largely into legend. Whether or not one agreed with everything Miss Fischer did Friday night, her performances had a larger- than-life vitality and a prismatic sense of color that was often thrilling.

title: RECITAL: SYLVAN WIND QUINTET
description: THE SYLVAN WIND QUINTET'S debut concert exactly two years ago offered music by American women. Friday night, the group returned to Carnegie Recital Hall with more Americans - four by birth, one by adoption, and among the five, one woman, Katherine Hoover.

title: BIRTHDAY INSPIRES DOLL DUOS
description: A diminutive Prince Charming, with wrinkled brow, wire-frame spectacles and gray hair, offers a golden slipper to a smiling one- shoed Cinderella. The Prince looks like Harry B. Helmsley, and Cinderella is the very image of his wife, Leona.

title: Swedes Hunt 3 Frogmen On Isle Near Navy Base
description: A Swedish military spokesman said today that military forces hunting a foreign submarine had fired in separate incidents at three frogmen spotted emerging from the sea today on the small island of Almoe.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an answer involving the career statistics of the baseball player Buck Freeman in the Feb. 20 column, the runs batted in total was incorrect and the strikeout total was inaccurate. Freeman drove in 713 runs in an 11- year career that ended in 1907, but there is no accurate figure for how many times he struck out because before 1913, such records were either unavailable or incomplete.

title: Organization Man
description: Being an assistant coach in the National Basketball Association can be more difficult than the average fan realizes, especially working with Hubie Brown, the Knicks' coach, a firm believer in organization and statistics.

title: Art and Money
description: Something about the words ''the arts'' evokes the opera glass and the upturned pinky. That's unfortunate, since it prevents perception of what ''the arts'' really represent - an enormous range of responses to the world.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WILLIAM POWELL, FILM STAR, DIES AT 91
description: William Powell, the actor who personified the suave and sophisticated leading man in the 1930's and 40's, died yesterday at Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 91 years old.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Worker in Nuclear Test Dies of Cave-In Injuries
description: A worker employed by a Government contractor has died of injuries suffered in a nuclear accident Feb. 15 at the Nevada Test Site, it was announced today.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
HART'S ECLECTIC PLATFORM BLURS THE LINES BETWEEN LIBERAL AND CONSERVATIVE
description: The political platform of Gary Hart is an eclectic, unconventional package of ideas combining standard liberal Democratic policies with a strong emphasis on free-market economics and the need for economic growth.

title: SCOUTING
description: Hat Sizes Give Mets a Headache

title: LEBANESE CABINET FORMALLY CANCELS PACT WITH ISRAEL
description: Lebanon today formally canceled its troop withdrawal accord with Israel, declaring the American-sponsored agreement ''null and void.''

title: Student Plans Suit InGoalPostInjury
description: A lawyer for the Harvard freshman who was struck in the head by a falling metal goal post after last year's Harvard-Yale football game has filed a notice of intention to sue the city for $50 million.

title: REAGAN ALTERS STAND ON TROOP CUTS
description: President Reagan has moved to modify the Western bargaining stance on reducing troops in Central Europe, Administration officials say.

title: ABRAHAM BLUMSTEIN
description: Abraham Blumstein, a former leader in the wristwatch and jewelry industries, died at Mount Sinai Hospital on Saturday, his 82d birthday, after suffering a heart attack.

title: WALL STREET'S MYSTERY MAN
description: ALEXANDER PAPAMARKOU lived a quiet life here and abroad selling stocks for New York brokers for more than 20 years. Then suddenly - his closest friends would say uncharacteristically - he surfaced in what may have been the accidentally self- generated hullabaloo of publicity surrounding a $55,000, week-long house party he gave in June, 1982, at California's Golden Door.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Sign for Sonics

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
$200 Million Issue From Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, announced that it is selling $200 million of floating rate notes due Sept. 16, 1984, through various dealers.

title: LAKES IN REGION ARE BECOMING MORE ACIDIC
description: The most acidic lakes in upstate New York and northern New England are getting worse even though the sulfate flowing into them has not increased for several years, a panel of experts reported today.

title: ONYX PETROLEUM reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
IC CHIEF AGREES TO STAY AT HELM 2 EXTRA YEARS
description: William B. Johnson has been asked to stay on as chairman and chief executive officer of IC Industries through 1986. Under an earlier agreement, he was to retire at the end of this year.

title: Barclays Net Off 12% in '83
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C., one of Britain's big four clearing banks, said today that increasing taxes and debt payments caused its profits to decline 12 percent in 1983, to $428 million.

title: BIOSTIM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $12,000 for the quarter and $22,000 for the 6 months.

title: ENVIRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $220,000 for the latest quarter and $95,000 for the year-earlier period. c-After a gain of $65,143,000 from the elimination of a former division's liabilities and $1.1 million from a tax credit. d-After income from discontinued operations of $102,000 and a tax credit of $296,000.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,016,000 for the quarter and $2,439,000 for the 6 months and a loss of $1,891,000 for the 6 months on the early extinguishment of debt. c-Including extraordinary tax credits of $1,099,000 for the quarter and $1,552,000 for the 6 months.

title: STEVEN SCOTT LEADS NINE FROM COLORADO
description: STEPHEN SCOTT and the Colorado College New Music Ensemble made luxurious sounds Friday at Roulette, mostly from inside pianos.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Midlands Seen Acting on Evmar
description: The Midlands Energy Company, in an apparent attempt to thwart a possible takeover by the Evmar Oil Corporation, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it had acquired 5.4 percent of the common shares of the Tennessee-Virginia Energy Corporation. It also said it had purchased the assets of a gas distribution business in Fremont, Neb.

title: TREASURY PRICES FALL SHARPLY
description: The credit markets were in retreat yesterday, as prices declined and yields rose for Treasury issues of all maturities. By late in the day, Treasury bond prices were lower by a point or more, and rates on short-term Treasury bills had increased nearly a tenth of a point.

title: MONDALE ATTACKS HART AS CAMPAIGN ENTERS NEW PHASE
description: Gary Hart's victory in the Maine caucuses Sunday propelled the Democratic Presidential campaign into an angry new phase yesterday.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; A Difficult Market To Crack
description: -collar job, makes more than the national average and favors NBC-TV?

title: PETE ROSE IS FACING HIS SEASON OF DECISION
description: At his locker, Pete Rose opened a big brown envelope to discover a color photo of himself in a rumpled Cincinnati Reds uniform before the Montreal Expos even existed. He was slimmer and smaller then with a crew cut, but he had the same sharp stare that he has now below his floppy gray hair in his season of decision.

title: RAGAN, BRAD, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Hawaiian Volcano Threatens Houses
description: The latest eruption of the Kilauea volcano sent a 700-foot-wide river of molten lava surging toward a housing area before it suddenly abated and spared the area's few residents, the authorities said today.

title: Chile and Argentina Recess Talks on Channel
description: Chile and Argentina agreed to a brief recess in talks on the Beagle Channel territorial dispute so that the two delegations can inform their Governments of the progress so far, the Vatican's mediation office announced today.

title: MILWAUKEE ROAD BIDS TO I.C.C.
description: A Federal District Court judge here said today that he would refer three bids offered by competing railroads for the assets of the Milwaukee Road to the Interstate Commerce Commission for further hearings. The carrier has been in bankruptcy proceedings since December 1977.

title: NATIONAL CAN BID SET BY POSNER
description: The National Can Corporation, the nation's third-largest metal can company, said yesterday that the investor Victor Posner, who now owns 37.2 percent of the company, had offered $40 a share for the rest of the shares, or a total of $410 million.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: TITO GOBBI, 68, ITALIAN OPERATIC BARITONE AND DIRECTOR, DIES
description: Tito Gobbi, the Italian operatic baritone, died in Rome yesterday at the age of 68. He had been suffering from cancer.

title: 'CALAMITY JANE' ON CBS
description: ''CALAMITY JANE,'' the two- hour drama at 9 tonight on Channel 2, has brawling, Indians, gunplay, horsemanship and scenery, but it is not a western. It is the colorful story of a character out of Western history, Martha Jane Cannary, better known as Calamity Jane, and it does not center on the traditional good-guy, bad- guy concept that defines a western.

title: Elena S. Kenedy, 95, Is Dead; Widow of Heir to King Ranch
description: Elena Suess Kenedy, a member of the family that established the King Ranch, died at the ranch Friday. She was 95 years old.

title: Pentagon Plan: Spend $3 Billion in Jersey
description: If the Defense Department gets its way, it will spend $3 billion in New Jersey in the 1985 fiscal year for military salaries, retirement benefits, construction and research, a Government report indicated today.

title: Take a Hart Break
description: In the wake of his recent political successes, there's some interest in whether it was Gary Hart or his father who changed the family name from Hartpence in 1961. We wish to register another concern, not about what he did to his name but what others are now doing with it. Is there no end to the obvious puns on ''Hart''?

title: Neil Discharged
description: Less than 12 hours after an accident in which the two passengers in his rented car were killed, Kenny Neil was discharged early yesterday from St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF ISRAEL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split effected Feb. 27.

title: Gun Dealer Held
description: A Queens gun dealer believed to have sold more than 1,000 handguns illegally in the last year was arrested yesterday after the police recovered a cache of guns in his mother's apartment, authorities said.

title: LEVITT CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $290,000 for the quarter and $1,175,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $241,000 for the quarter and $537,000 for the year. d-Net loss

title: INDUSTRIAL ACOUSTICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
11 Hurt in Blaze At Chemical Plant
description: Eleven people were injured today in a fire that destroyed a chemical company plant, spewed noxious fumes and forced the temporary evacuation of 40 families in the neighborhood, authorities said.

title: Resignation at Elsinore
description: Robert R. Maxey, president and chief executive officer of the Elsinore Corporation, which owns hotel-casinos in Las Vegas, Nev., said yesterday that Joseph J. Amoroso had resigned as chairman. The vacancy will not be filled now, Mr. Maxey said.

title: JUDGE ORDERS PROSTITUTE TO SIT BY HIM AT BENCH
description: A judge in Manhattan ordered a prostitute to sit next to him at the bench for several hours last week, and court officials said yesterday that they were ''looking into'' the incident.

title: U.S. Steel, Bridon
description: The United States Steel Corporation said it had agreed to sell its wire rope and strand manufacturing facilities in Trenton and in Oakland City, Ind., to the Bridon American Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. U.S. Steel said that Bridon American had acquired the trademark for Tiger Brand wire rope products and that the company would continue to market the products. Bridon American, based in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., is owned by Bridon P.L.C. of London and Noranda Mines Ltd. of Toronto.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: GOOD BREAKS Last year, the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 20 Lafayette Avenue, near Flatbush Avenue extension, shook with particular joy to a Dance Black America Festival. The reverberations are still being heard there, and the echo becomes stronger tonight when this year's version, ''Sweet Saturday Night: a Celebration of Street and Social Dance,'' opens for a run through next Sunday.

title: Anti-Asian Bias Study Due
description: The Federal Commission on Civil Rights decided today to seek to determine if sentiment against Asian Americans, especially new immigrants, has increased in recent years. John H. Bunzel, the commission member who called for the study, said witnesses at local hearings had said some incidents were a result of decisions by American companies to shift work to Asia. The commission's staff was told to determine by May whether formal hearings would be necessary.

title: AMERICA'S ALTERABLE CONSTITUTIONAL LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. JAMES A. HALSTED, 78, A NUTRITION RESEARCHER
description: Dr. James A. Halsted, a physician who conducted important nutritional research, died of leukemia Friday at the Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 78 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: GADFLY WHO BITES PRESIDENT ON SUPPLY SIDE
description: As a matter of chronological fact, Paul Craig Roberts was born in Atlanta on April 3, 1939. As a matter of formative development, he was born again on a bus in the Soviet city of Tashkent in the summer of 1961.

title: NETS TOP JAZZ FOR 6TH STRAIGHT
description: It did not add up. The all- star guard Otis Birdsong, who had been criticized by the Nets' management early in the season for what it claimed was his inability to score during critical moments in several games, had just become a hero.

title: CARSON OUTFIT GAINS
description: A famous name can be a decidedly mixed blessing. In 1980, when Johnny Carson announced the formation of the Carson Productions Group to make both television programs and feature films, his enterprise received far more extensive press coverage than most new companies would.

description: b-Including a special gain of $258,208.

title: Chess: A Sacrifice of the Exchange Can Have a Delicate Pretext
description: Nowadays the slimmest, most delicate of pretexts can be found to prompt a sacrifice of the exchange.

title: HOW DO 'TALKING' APES DIFFER FROM THEIR PEERS?
description: Lana, a chimpanzee who fascinated scientists a decade ago when she learned to communicate through words and symbols, may soon come out of retirement.

description: Coffee Prices Advance; Grain and Soybeans Up

title: Trilogy Delay
description: Trilogy Ltd. said a design change would delay by about six months, until mid- 1986, its plans to begin shipping a line of large-scale computers. The computer is the first product Trilogy plans to introduce. Since its founding in 1980, the company has concentrated entirely on research and development for the product.

title: Topics Lion, Lamb and Panda
description: Human Surrogates Maybe their signs are incompatible. Maybe it's bad chemistry. Or maybe she just doesn't like the way he wears his fur.

title: Accorsi Joins Browns
description: Ernie Accorsi, who resigned recently as the Baltimore Colts' general manager, joined the Cleveland Browns yesterday as assistant to the team's owner, Art Modell. According to the Browns, Accorsi will work with Modell in all phases of the club's activities.

title: Tidewater
description: Tidewater Inc. said it expected a fourth-quarter write-down of capitalized oil exploration costs of about $14 million. Tidewater, an operator of offshore service vessels, said this would result in a $7.6 million reduction in after-tax profits for the year ending March 31. For the nine months ended Dec. 31, Tidewater earned $13.2 million, or 79 cents a share, on revenues of $259.2 million.

title: SCOTTISH & YORK HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect deconsolidation of certain subsidiaries.

title: FREUD'S LONDON HOUSE IS IN DISPUTE
description: THE current debate over Freud's moral and intellectual legacy is finding a curious reflection on the concrete level of real estate. An American organization that owns Freud's London home wants to convert it to a museum, while the local London housing authority wants to set aside at least part of it as an apartment house.

title: Nebraska Star Dies in Crash
description: The second-best free-throw shooter in the history of the National Collegiate Athletic Association was among two people found dead Sunday night in the wreckage of a private airplane that had been reported missing for more than 36 hours.

LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
