S.E.C. LISTS THAYER SUIT WITNESSES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday listed several prominent businessmen that it intends to call as witnesses in its case against Paul Thayer, the former Deputy Secretary of Defense. Mr. Thayer has been charged with helping eight individuals make $1.9 million by illegally providing them with insider information.

title: FEB. 21-29 AUTO SALES ROSE 24.6%
description: The nation's major automobile manufacturers reported today that sales rose 24.6 percent, on a daily rate basis, in late February.

title: Big Board Lets Gulf Trade
description: The New York Stock Exchange, apparently fearful of losing business, broke with the usual procedure on trading halts yesterday and decided to permit dealing in the Gulf Corporation's stock without waiting for pending takeover news about the company. Gulf, which had requested a trading halt ''pending news developments,'' said the exchange told Gulf that Big Board trading was necessary because Gulf stock was being traded over the counter.

title: LESS EXPENSIVE CHEMISTRY
description: BRUNSWICK, ME. JOHN PAPANIKOLAS was absorbed in an experiment in the organic chemistry laboratory at Bowdoin College the other day, taking about three-thousandths of an ounce of benzaldehyde and acetone, adding an aqueous ethanol solution of sodium hydroxide and pouring the mixture into a tiny flask. He watched the liquid drip through a filter, leaving a residue of yellow crystals that he patiently scraped with a miniature spatula into a test tube no longer than his little finger.

title: AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASTRONOMERS COMPLAIN OF A GLUT OF ASTRAL DATA
description: Astronomy and astrophysics are gathering so much information by telescope that these fields need supercomputers to help make sense of it all, according to an astronomer writing in in Physics Today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are unable to perceive the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Vicar of Rome, or other powerful religious leaders behind every public acknowledgment of the religious heritage long officially recognized by the three constitutional branches of government.

description: and this dancegoer had better confess that, as an amateur geologist, he is fascinated by caves - would have applauded Leslie Chilton's stage designs for ''Sojourn,'' the two-act dance that Shiro Kondo presented Friday night at the Washington Square Church. Miss Chilton filled the church's sanctuary with hanging white silken streamers that looked like stalactites of the purest cave onyx.

title: DENIAL OF TEACHERS' PENSION ON DISMISSAL STRUCK DOWN
description: A Federal judge yesterday declared invalid the system under which New York City public school teachers who are dismissed for incompetence or misconduct automatically lose their pensions.

title: Tussaud's Vandalized
description: A vandal entered Madame Tussaud's wax museum Sunday night and damaged about six of the lifelike figures, officials said. The museum was closed today for repairs. Scotland Yard said a man was under arrest and was being questioned.

description: IN 1983, about 30 million surgical procedures

title: Medal for David Is Urged
description: Two Texans introduced a resolution in the House today urging President Reagan to award the Medal of Freedom to David, the immune-deficient boy who died after spending most of his 12 years in sterile isolation at the Baylor College of Medicine and Texas Children's Hospital in Houston.

title: COURT ACCEPTS KEY BANKRUPTCY CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a company can use the Federal bankruptcy law to escape a legal obligation to clean up a hazardous waste site.

title: ANDAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,455,000 for the quarter, an extraordinary gain of $3,595,000 for the year and equity in net income of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $779,000 for the quarter and $1.4 million for the year. c-After a net loss of $850,000 on the disposition of discontinued operations and equity in net loss of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $63,000. d-Net loss after a net loss of $9.4 million on the disposition of discontinued operations and equity in net loss of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $153,000.

title: Psychotic Drug Ailment Studied
description: Antipsychotic drugs, considered the best treatment for such severe mental disorders as schizophrenia, often cause involuntary twitching movements, a researcher says.

title: HIGH COURT RULES CITIES MAY PUT UP NATIVITY DISPLAYS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that a city may include a Nativity scene as part of an official Christmas display without violating the constitutionally required separation between church and state.

title: REAGAN AND KOHL DISCUSS SOVIET PARLEY
description: President Reagan told Chancellor Helmut Kohl today that he would ''explore every possible avenue for improvement of relations'' with the Soviet Union, but repeated his view that a summit meeting should not be held unless there were prospects for ''fruitful results.''

title: STUDIES MAY OVERTHROW LONG-HELD BELIEFS ON EARTH'S STRUCTURE
description: SCIENTISTS using earthquake waves to chart the earth's interior, in much the same manner as the brain is scanned by computer-assisted tomography, have identified deep patterns that go a long way toward explaining the dynamics of continental drift, earthquakes, and volcanic eruptions.

title: PANEL REJECTS DELAY FOR JUDGE
description: Chief Judge Harry E. Claiborne of the Federal District Court for Nevada lost his last-ditch attempt today to delay his trial on several criminal charges. The trial is now scheduled to begin next Monday in Reno.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $285,000. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $222,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $17,000.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Seattle SuperSonics , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The second game of a six-game Knick home stand, and Seattle's only visit of the season.

title: LEBANON'S CHRISTIANS SPLIT ON SCRAPPING OF PACT WITH ISRAEL
description: Lebanon's cancellation of its accord with Israel appeared today to have split this country's Christians and created a new opposition to President Amin Gemayel.

title: G. & W. Net Up 29.1%
description: Gulf and Western Industries, citing strong gains in all of its operating groups, said yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter rose 29.1 percent on an increase in revenues of 12.7 percent. G. & W. said that net income in the latest three months, ended Jan. 31, advanced to $68.4 million, or 95 cents a share, from $53 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales increased to $1.15 billion, from $1.02 billion.

title: THE DANCE: 'LES NOCES'
description: THE Dance Corps at Purchase, the performing arm of the dance department at the State University of New York at Purchase, greatly enriched the New York dance scene on Friday when it presented a revival of Bronislava Nijinska's rarely seen ''Les Noces,'' created in 1923 for Sergei Diaghilev's Ballets Russes.

title: White House Press Aide Defends Miss Reagan
description: President Reagan, through a spokesman, defended his daughter Maureen today against an attack by a conservative leader.

title: SCARSDALE GROUPS HAIL CRECHE RULING
description: The United States Supreme Court's ruling yesterday that Pawtucket, R.I., may legally display a Nativity scene has stirred hopes of legal victory among some residents of Scarsdale, N.Y., who are seeking the return of Nativity figures in a public park at Christmas.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $874,000. c-Net loss after currency losses of $10,605,000 for the quarter and $12,609,000 for the 6 months. d-After a tax credit of $1,692,000 and a currency loss of $18,000.

description: Even in Houston, where high fences are commonplace, the compound looks strangely out of place on the edge of a residential neighborhood, just off a major interstate highway.

title: WITNESS CONTINUES TO VERIFY ACCOUNT OF A BARROOM RAPE
description: A woman's account that six men helped rape her in a New Bedford bar last year was essentially accurate, a key witness for the prosecution continued to maintain today.

title: IRAQ LEAVES DEAD IRANIANS TO DISPLAY TO REPORTERS

title: Jackson, in Arkansas, Backs Farm Supports
description: Campaigning for votes in the March 17 Arkansas caucuses, the Rev. Jesse Jackson appealed to white farmers today to support him and his advocacy of higher Government price supports.

title: GEMAYEL DECISION REGRETTEDBY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it regretted Lebanon's decision to cancel the agreement on the terms for Israel's withdrawal that was worked out by the United States. It said the United States would leave it to the Arabs to find a substitute formula for achieving the same results.

title: 1984 MAY TEST FLORIDA GOVERNOR'S PROSPECTS
description: This is not an election year for Florida's politically ambitious Governor, Bob Graham, who is considering a 1986 drive for the United States Senate. But the political thicket immediately ahead could make 1984 a referendum year on the Democrat's prospects, according to his friends, colleagues and political analysts in Florida.

title: News Corp. Profit Up
description: News Corporation Ltd., the Australia-based international news organization run by Rupert Murdoch, reported today that for the six months ended Dec. 31 consolidated net profits rose 66 percent, to $52.3 million (Australian), or 82 cents a share, from $31.5 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier. One United States dollar equals about $1.05 (Australian).

title: CRONYNS IN 'GIN GAME'
description: HUME CRONYN and Jessica Tandy are consummate actors, a fact that is self-evident when one watches them gracefully thread their art in and around and under the words of D. L. Coburn's ''The Gin Game.'' The Pulitzer Prize-winning play can be seen tonight at 9 P.M. on American Playhouse on Channel 13.

title: POLITICAL SEASON IS IN FULL FLOWER AT TIP OF AFRICA
description: This is the time of year when South Africa's officialdom has decamped from Pretoria, the administrative capital, to Cape Town, the seat of Parliament. The phenomenon, which occurred in early February, has been compared to a kind of lemming rush that halts at the confluence of two oceans hard by Africa's southernmost tip.

title: Illicit Cards Used To Bilk 2 Casinos
description: A blackjack dealer at the Sands Hotel and Casino and another at Caesars Boardwalk Regency helped two players win more than $500,000 last November by using marked cards, authorities said today.

description: And 1984 promises to be nearly as strong for the makers of dishwashers, stoves, refrigerators, freezers, air-conditioners, microwave ovens and garbage disposals, according to industry analysts and executives.

description: Somewhere under a hillside of hardwood and cedar here rests the ruins of a Revolutionary War artillery academy built so Washington's struggling army could train and arm itself while afield.

title: Alcindor Jersey Back
description: The basketball jersey that Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, then known as Lew Alcindor , wore as a senior at Power Memorial Academy 19 years ago has been recovered by a fellow alumnus, little more than a week after it was stolen from a display case at the school. According to Pat Torney , chairman of the school's physical education department, Manny Couvertier , class of 1982 and a Manhattan resident, was walking through Central Park last Thursday when he saw a man trying to sell the purple-and- gold jersey. Mr. Couvertier paid the seller's price, $50, and gave the shirt back to Power.

description: Raymond J. Dempsey resigned suddenly yesterday as chairman and president of Fidelcor, Pennsylvania's fourth-largest banking company, to take over a banking organization outside the Philadelphia area.

title: ISRAEL CALLS DEMISE OF PACT A BLOW TO BEIRUT FREEDOM JERUSALEM, March 5 - Israel today strongly condemned Lebanon's cancellation of the security agreement between the two countries, calling the decision ''a death sentence for Lebanese independence and sovereignty.''
description: Deploring what it called the Syrian threats that led to the cancellation, Israel stated its willingness to stand by and put the accord into effect in the hope that ''Lebanon will succeed in restoring her sovereignty and in liberating herself from Syrian domination.''

A FAMILIAR QUANDARY
description: UNEMPLOYMENT among young people plagues the inner cities of Britain as much as those of the United States. And like their American counterparts, British educators are expected to try to solve the problem by making young people employable, a neat trick in a country of 50 million people where 3 million are unemployed. In fact, the issue is inseparable from a future of greater automation and less need for human hands.

description: Lebanon formally canceled last May's troop withdrawal agreement with Israel, declaring the United States-sponsored accord ''null and void.'' Israel strongly condemned Lebanon's cancellation of its security accord with Israel, calling the decision ''a death sentence for Lebanese independence and sovereignty.'' (A8:5-6.)

title: A WOMAN NOMINEE: YES, BUT...

The call for a woman Vice President on the Democratic ticket threatens to shift the burden of responsibility away from Ronald Reagan and the Republican Party. The wrong questions are being asked of the wrong party.

title: Tsai & Co. Censured
description: G. Tsai & Company, a small brokerage firm, agreed yesterday to a censure and $7,000 fine by the New York Stock Exchange for being undercapitalized by $152,165 in March 1980. The firm's capital deficiency, which was corrected the following month, ''was in large part attributable to five transfers of cash, which had been made by the firm to its parent,'' the Tsai Financial Corporation, the exchange said. The American Can Company bought the brokerage firm in January.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL DUE IN SUDAN FOR TALKS ON ARMS WASHINGTON, March 5 (Reuters) - A high-ranking Reagan Administration official is on his way to Khartoum to discuss United States military aid to the Sudan, the State Department said today.
description: The trip is being made by Vernon A. Walters, a retired general who is a top aide to Secretary of State George P. Shultz. General Walters will meet with senior Sudanese officials.

title: Multi-Vest Overseer
description: A Federal court today appointed Lee S. Richards 3d of New York, a former Federal prosecutor, to oversee the operations of Multi-Vest Securities Inc., a New York municipal securities dealer charged with defrauding investors in the sale of bonds issued by the Washington Public Power Supply System.

title: NEW THREE-STARS IN MICHELIN
description: The 1984 Guide Michelin for France, published today, awarded its highest rating, three stars, to two restaurants, Jamin in Paris and Esperance in Vezelay, in northern Burgundy. At the same time two three-star establishments were demoted to two stars, leaving unchanged the three-star total of 18, 4 of them in Paris.

title: REAGAN TELLS CITIES HIS POLICY IS THEIR BEST HOPE
description: President Reagan, offering few election- year promises to the nation's cities, told a convention of urban officials today that economic recovery was ''the most important urban renewal program in America.''

title: ARGENTINA, PROSECUTE ALL OFFICERS
description: Who should be prosecuted and punished for Argentina's reign of terror between 1973 and 1983? Ask Estela de Carlotto, a human rights leader: ''I do not care who has to fall or how many are condemned. They kidnapped and tortured my daughter. They murderered her in cold blood and made my grandchild disappear. Now, I want justice.'' She rightly speaks for thousands of countrymen. Unless there is a clear, unambiguous decision to prosecute and punish everyone - no exceptions - involved in criminal acts of abduction, torture and execution, the nation will be unable to rebuild itself in a climate of justice and peace.

title: Ramada Inns Names Officer
description: Ramada Inns Inc. said yesterday that it had appointed Jerry Best executive vice president of the company and president of the hotel group.

title: MONDALE EFFORT IN FLORIDA HINGES ON LITTLE AND BIG NOW CHAPTERS
description: Walter F. Mondale hopes to win the Democratic Presidential primary in this key Southern state with the help of a group that has never before worked for a political candidate, whose budget is $11,000 and whose leader is a Republican.

description: A southbound Amtrak train carrying 249 passengers derailed near here this evening, injuring at least 30 people, none seriously, the authorities said.

title: THE FINE ART OF MODERNIZING THE MODERN
description: THEY are calling it ''Harvey's Mondrian'' at the Museum of Modern Art. The ''Mondrian'' that Harvey Tulcensky, an artist who is employed as an art-handler at the museum, painted in eight hours one Sunday not long ago is part of a juggling act that the museum is performing to redesign its own house. The place has been in transformation since the great Picasso exhibition of 1980 and closed entirely since the first of the year; when it reopens May 17, the museum will be more than double its former size, with its inner spaces all shifted around.

title: SHOLA LYNCH WINS 1,500 RUN IN COLGATE
description: Shola Lynch, the 14-year-old honor student from Hunter High in Manhattan who has excited track fans with her precocious performances, defended her Colgate Women's Games championship in the high school 1,500- meter run impressively last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: CUOMO IS SEEN AS SENDING MIXED SIGNALS ON LILCO
description: In the last few weeks, the Cuomo administration has sent out what legislators, experts on utilities and others describe as varying and sometimes conflicting signals about its position on the fiscally pressed Long Island Lighting Company and the utility's nuclear plant at Shoreham. The Governor and two of his top aides have outlined three somewhat different positions on whether Lilco should abandon the $4.1 billion nuclear plant and what relationship such a decision would have on the likelihood of state help for the company.

title: JERSEY INVESTIGATES FUND FOR NEWARK'S TEACHERS

Kinch walked into his conference room this morning to swear in Robert Neill and John Kelly as the newest members of the Pawtucket Fire Department, their waiting families and friends stood and gave the Mayor a round of applause.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUPREME COURT'S OPINION AND DISSENT ON MUNICIPAL CRECHE
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that a city may include a nativity scene as part of a Christmas display. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger wrote the Court's opinion, which was joined by Associate Justices Byron R. White, Lewis F. Powell Jr., William H. Rehnquist and Sandra Day O'Connor. Justice O'Connor also wrote a separate concurring opinion. Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote a dissent that was joined by Associate Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens.

title: UNDERDOG ROLE SUITS UNCONVENTIONAL VICTOR
description: Gary Hart's role as the underdog of this year's Presidential campaign, a role he is reluctant to yield, suits a personal temperament molded in rural Kansas and the study carrels of Yale, and a political style shaped in another man's race for the Presidency a dozen years ago.

title: A WAY OF GETTING CHEAPER OIL
description: The Gulf Corporation, which has been watching its oil and gas reserves decline steadily, has long been considered the weakest sister among the major oil companies. Thus, whenever rumors swirled about takeover targets among the nation's big international energy concerns, Wall Street usually put Gulf on the top of the list. What has astonished most experts, however, has been the David and Goliath battle that led finally yesterday to the agreement by Gulf that it would permit a merger offer by the Standard Oil Company of California. Few would have thought that Gulf, one of the group of seven international oil concerns that once exercised almost complete control of global oil supplies and prices, could be forced into a shotgun marriage with Socal by a company as small as the Mesa Petroleum Company.

title: PRICE IS $13 BILLION
description: The Gulf Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California announced yesterday that they had signed an agreement for Standard of California to buy Gulf for $13.2 billion in cash, or $80 a share.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALTHOUGH the cooking of Vienna is thought of mostly in terms of desserts, a few other outstanding Viennese dishes are known throughout the world. One is veal cutlets viennoise and the other, oddly enough, is fried chicken. Fried chicken Vienna style, it goes without saying, is a distant relative of the Southern version. Chicken fried in the Southern manner is generally coated with seasoned flour - and, rarely, corn meal - and dropped into very hot fat: in the classic recipe, rendered lard.

description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of President Reagan's address to the 42d annual convention of the National Association of Evangelicals:

title: BLOOMFIELD SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There are no year-ago results because the company was in operations for only 10 days in 1982.

title: PORT AGENCY SEES A GAIN OF 100,000 JOBS IN REGION
description: The New York metropolitan region will gain 100,000 jobs during the year because of a ''rejuvenated'' economy spurred by solid growth in Manhattan's business district, the Port Authority reported yesterday.

title: Vulcan to Be Sold
description: The Ampco-Pittsburgh Corporation said it had agreed to acquire Vulcan Inc. for $13 a share. Vulcan, of Latrobe, Pa., will be merged into an Ampco unit. Both companies said their boards had approved the transaction.

title: Dole Panel's Session Off
description: A drafting session of the Senate Finance Committee was canceled today because intense lobbying by real estate interests had apparently eroded earlier majority support for a provision in the panel's deficit-reduction bill that would increase the depreciation period for nonresidential buildings to 20 years, up from the current 15 years.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 23 about marketing to elderly consumers incorrectly located the offices of Senior Citizens Unlimited, a direct mail marketing agency. They are in Tuckahoe, N.Y.

title: Mingo-Jones Gets Job For Disney Productions
description: This spring, Mingo-Jones Advertising will begin its first corporate campaign for Walt Disney Productions. The theme - ''Discover Disney: More Magic Than Ever.''

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the merger of an affiliated company accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: REPORT ASKS CONTROL OF COPTERS FOR MOVIES
description: A Federal safety board, in a report on the helicopter crash that killed the actor Vic Morrow and two children said today that the Government should control the use of helicopters in the motion picture industry.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Royal Bank of Canada is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: NUMEREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

Zimbabwe Discovers 4,000 in Mass Graves
description: At least 4,000 guerrillas and civilians killed in Zimbabwe's seven- year independence war have been discovered in shallow mass graves, a Government spokesman said today.

title: 130 BOYS SEEK FAME AND FORTUNE AT AUDITION FOR 'OLIVER!'
description: Brian Elias and Alex Yost went to Broadway yesterday ready to be discovered. But before their auditions at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, the two 9-year-olds wrestled on the blue carpet and took turns rolling down the steps from the mezzanine, where boys in all shapes and sizes waited to try out for ''Oliver!''

title: LUBBOCK ORDERS A RIVER, TEXAS STYLE
description: A writer for The New Yorker magazine once observed that San Antonio was the only town in Texas anybody ever accused of having any charm.

title: EASIER PASTA MAKING
description: TO the pasta purist nothing approximates the texture and flavor of the handmade product. The technique for mixing dough, rolling it and cutting it to the desired width is not particularly difficult. The most tricky and time-consuming step is rolling it into sheets before cutting. One must have a firm and steady touch to do it properly with a rolling pin. If the sheets are not perfectly even, the pasta will cook unevenly.

title: No Headline
description: With nine primaries or caucuses only a week away, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today stepped up his criticism of Senator Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale, the two leading contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has elected Ted A. Kohl a senior vice president.

title: LILCO TO SUSPEND ITS STOCK DIVIDEND AND REDUCE STAFF
description: The Long Island Lighting Company will stop paying dividends on its common stock for at least the rest of the year and will reduce its work force by nearly 20 percent, the new chairman of the company announced today.

METAL OBJECTS PUT ON TRACK DERAIL IND TRAIN
description: An eight-car subway train headed south for the Rockaway peninsula derailed early yesterday after hitting pieces of metal put on the tracks by vandals, the police said.

title: Policewoman Testifies In Barroom Rape
description: A bruised, frightened young woman told the police she ''lost count'' as she was repeatedly raped on a barroom pool table, a policewoman testified today, a a year since the assault.

title: Kaypro Price Cut
description: The Kaypro Corporation said it had lowered the suggested retail price for its Kaypro II personal computer by about $300, to $1,295. The company said it had reduced the price to support its network of 1,200 dealers.

title: KOHL DEFENDS SAUDI ARMS DEAL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today defended West Germany's plan to sell arms to Saudi Arabia, asserting that the Saudis were not a threat to Israel.

title: REAGAN SEES U.S. REGAINING 'MORAL BEARINGS'
description: President Reagan, portraying the 1970's as a time of rampant pornography, drug abuse and sexual promiscuity, told an evangelical audience in Ohio yesterday that with his Administration ''Americans are turning back to God.''

title: An 'Awkward' Righetti Begins Role as Reliever
description: John Montefusco pitched the first three innings today, finished his running, took a shower and now was getting dressed.

title: TV STUDIO SERVES CONGRESS
description: The television picture portrayed what looked like an ordinary news conference. Viewers saw Karin Davies of The Anchorage Daily News telling Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, that ''Some Alaskans view you as a hawk,'' and asking, ''Do you think this reputation will make you vulnerable in the upcoming election?''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Book on Pilgrimage Of Holocaust Survivors

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, exhibition, at Bradenton, Fla. Darryl Strawberry and his Met teammates open their spring schedule with Mike Torrez on the mound.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HART SCORES AGAIN IN VERMONT VOTE
description: Gary Hart scored his third victory in a week today in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, with a 3 1/2-to-1 margin over Walter F. Mondale in Vermont's preference vote.

title: Bad War, Bad Peace
description: Amin Gemayel's cancellation of a security pact with Israel confirms that for the first time Israel has lost not a peace, as it contends, but a war.

title: A 'RETURN TO EVEREST' WITH HILLARY
description: ''RETURN TO EVEREST,'' a National Geographic special, is a remarkably gentle television program - both in its sensibility and its topic. Sir Edmund Hillary, who climbed Mount Everest 30 years ago, is seen in Nepal once more, this time doing good works. The Nepalese, meanwhile, seem pleased to have him. A documentary can be awfully patronizing with this kind of subject, but ''Return to Everest'' isn't patronizing at all, and sometimes it is moving. It will be shown on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Dr Pepper Names A New President
description: Joe K. Hughes, who was named yesterday as the new president and chief operating officer of the Dallas- based Dr Pepper Company, traded life on his family's east Texas farm for hand-tailored suits and a 30-year association with Dr. Pepper.

title: SOUTHERN UNION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FRESH SEAFOOD FROM BOSTON, POSTHASTE
description: BOSTON A COLD wind off the North Atlantic scudding across Boston harbor drives clouds of misty rain before it. Fishing boats, back in port after five or more days at sea, tug at their moorings along the docks of the Boston Fish Pier as men in bright yellow oilskins bend into the damp wind, hurrying toward the handsome arched doorway of the New England Fish Exchange.

title: Carter Says Democrats Could Defeat Reagan
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that Ronald Reagan would win the election if it were held now but that the Democrats had a good chance at victory in November if they united and overcame the President's ''personal attractiveness.''

title: Bengals Shopping
description: Now that Steve Young , the former Brigham Young quarterback, has signed a contract worth more than $40 million with the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League, the Cincinnati Bengals are looking over half a dozen or so other players as potential first selections in the National Football League draft. According to Mike Brown , an assistant general manager, the prospects include two Nebraska players, Irving Fryar , a wide receiver, and a guard, Dean Steinkuhler , as well as Boomer Esiason , the Maryland quarterback, and Wilbur Marshall , a Florida linebacker. . . . Meanwhile, Chet Simmons , the commissioner of the U.S.F.L., who has sought to hold the line on player salaries, said he was dismayed by the size of Young's contract.

title: STARCOM INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
MUNSINGWEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: U.S. APPROVES THE SALE OF OIL GEAR TO RUSSIANS
description: The Reagan Administration, in a relaxation of East-West trade restraints, has approved the sale of $40 million worth of submersible drilling pumps to the Soviet Union on the ground that the equipment is available from other industrial countries, trade officials said today.

title: Kennedy Avoids Giving His Support to Mondale
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has turned down efforts by Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign to gain the Senator's endorsement, Mr. Kennedy's press secretary said today.

title: Celtics 108, Bullets 85
description: Robert Parish scored 26 points and Scott Wedman added 16 to lead Boston past Washington. Boston, playing without Larry Bird, won its third consecutive game and improved its record to 46- 15.

title: MOGULS TAKE TO THE SLOPES FOR DEALS
description: HOLLYWOOD HOLLYWOOD is nothing if not trendy. Skiing has replaced cold pasta salads in the affections of any number of studio vice presidents who strap their Nordica boots onto their Pure Gold or Lacroix skis and follow their presidents down the slopes at Aspen, Colo., or Deer Valley, Utah. They are joined there by producers and directors who used to throw themselves face-down on Hawaiian beaches and now push their numb fingers into Kitex gloves.

title: Gypsy-Cab Driver Cited for Bravery
description: A gypsy-cab driver who chased and captured a motorist charged with killing a 9-year-old girl and seriously injuring her brother in a hit-and-run accident was honored yesterday by the City Council.

title: West German Output
description: West German industrial production in January rose nearly 1 percent, seasonally adjusted, from December, the Economics Ministry said today. Output was up 5.75 percent from January 1983.

title: Court Won't Block Recall Election
description: The State Supreme Court today rejected without comment an attempt by Mayor Michael Matthews to block next week's recall election, setting the stage for the vote after a bitter 21- month battle.

title: APPOINTEE TELLS OF LOANS ARRANGED FOR MEESE
description: An accountant who arranged almost $120,000 in loans for the Presidential Counselor Edwin Meese 3d and the deputy White House chief of staff, Michael K. Deaver, said today that he had not disclosed those loans to a Senate committee that held confirmation hearings on his appointment to the board of governors of the United States Postal Service.

title: Evmar Oil Deal
description: The Evmar Oil Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its holdings in the Midlands Energy Company.

title: HOUSE PASSES SHIPPING BILL
description: The House of Representatives approved by voice vote today a compromise bill to allow shipowners broader immunity from antitrust laws.

title: Illinois Hospital Issue Yields 10%
description: A $56.7 million issue of hospital revenue bonds of the Village of Evergreen Park, Ill., for the Little Company of Mary hospital was tentatively priced by John Nuveen & Company with a maximum yield of 10 percent for bonds due in 2012. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 6 percent in 1986 to 9.4 percent in 1996.

title: Rise in Dutch Jobless
description: The number of jobless workers in the Netherlands rose by 4,300, to 838,300, in February from January, the Ministry for Social Affairs said today.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day paper produced an average 9.687 percent yield, up from 9.677 percent last week. The rate on 182-day commercial paper fell to 9.735 percent, from 9.743 percent last week.

title: VOCE OF TOLENTINE HAVING AN UP YEAR
description: Gary Voce, the 6-foot-9-inch, 220- pound center for St. Nicholas of Tolentine High School in the Bronx, drew a blank recently when asked how it felt to be counted among the state's best high school basketball players.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 7, 1984 International
description: The first open split in Syria since President Hafez al-Assad seized power in 1970 was reported by Reagan Administration officials. They said that members of the ruling elite in Damascus were deeply divided over the choice of a successor to the President. (Page A1, Column 1.) George P. Shultz was irritated after hearing most members of a key House committee threaten to curtail aid to El Salvador. The Secretary of State told the Representatives they wanted to ''walk away'' from a vital area of the world ''because there are problems.'' (A1:1-2.)

title: SCOUTING

title: SCREEN: 'THE WORLD OF TOMORROW'
description: ''THE World of Tomorrow,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is a fine, funny feature-length documentary about the New York World's Fair of 1939, when, for a few, short, glittery months, Western civilization paused between the Depression and World War II.

title: MONARCH AVALON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Oregon State Is Accused
description: Oregon State, whose basketball team is ranked among the top 20 by both The Associated Press and United Press International, said Monday that it had been accused by the National Collegiate Athletic Association of 54 violations in the school's basketball and football programs. The charges, which were in a letter of inquiry from the N.C.A.A. and which require the university's response by April 16, were made public by Robert MacVicar, the Oregon State president.

title: PICKENS STILL FAVORS TRUSTS
description: A big winner in the proposed merger of the Gulf Corporation and the Standard Oil Company of California is T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company. He heads an investment group that has accumulated 22 million Gulf shares, or 13 percent the total, at an average price of $44 a share.

title: 'WOODY GUTHRIE: HARD TRAVELIN'
description: ''WOODY GUTHRIE: HARD TRAVELIN' '' is a warmhearted memorial to the folk singer whose songs galvanized organizers and guitar-pickers across the United States. Part biography, part travelogue and part hootenanny, it follows the singer's son, Arlo Guthrie, as he retraces his father's steps and collects reminiscences from his father's family, friends and musical partners. It will be shown tonight at 9:05 on Channel 13.

title: SYRIA SAID TO FACE SPLIT AMONG ELITE OVER SUCCESSION
description: Administration officials said today that the Syrian Government was confronting the first open split among its ruling elite since President Hafez al-Assad seized power in 1970.

title: AVIATION COUNCIL FAULTS SOVIET
description: The governing council of the International Civil Aviation Organization condemned the Soviet Union tonight for shooting down a South Korean jet last September, killing the 269 people aboard.

title: FUJITSU BUYS MORE OF AMDAHL
description: Fujitsu Ltd., the big Japanese computer manufacturer, announced yesterday that it had purchased another large stake in the Amdahl Corporation and a block of options on Amdahl stock that could bring its total share to about 49 percent of the company.

It will mark the first trading in narrow- based index options on the Big Board.

title: RISING VOICE OF CUBAN-AMERICANS
description: Amid the cacophony of contending groups that swell the chorus of interest-group pluralism here, the voice of the Cuban-American community was heard but faintly in most of the 25 years since the exodus after Fidel Castro's takeover.

title: SENATE BACKERS AGREE TO WORDING CHANGES IN PRAYER AMENDMENT
description: In an attempt to win over wavering legislators, Senate Republican leaders agreed today on a compromise version of a proposed constitutional amendment to permit organized prayer in public schools.

title: NCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BRITAIN'S JANE GRIGSON: A NO-NONSENSE COOK
description: ''IF ever I have the chance of arranging a dinner party under the trees of the Elysian Fields,'' Jane Grigson once wrote, ''the first person I shall invite will be the Rev. Sydney Smith.'' She describes Smith, the early-19th-century essayist, in her book ''Food With the Famous'' (Atheneum, 1980) as witty, gay, generous of character and a lover of good food. Mrs. Grigson, the British cookbook author, might have been describing herself.

title: CALIFORNIA VINEYARDS LURE FOREIGN MONEY
description: IT'S not often that a lot of people get together in a place like the Four Seasons to celebrate an invasion. They did yesterday, but there wasn't a traitor in the lot. Writers, wine experts and wine industry figures, they gathered to celebrate the release of Opus One, the new wine created, if that's the word, through the combined efforts of Robert Mondavi, of Oakville, Calif., and Philippe de Rothschild, of Paris and Pauillac, France.

title: Turning to Pros
description: Rosalynn Sumners , the 1983 world champion figure skater who was limited to a silver medal in the 1984 Winter Olympics, said she had decided to seek a professional career and would not defend her title at the 1984 world championships in Ottawa later this month. ''I'm tired of the intense training of amateur competition,'' she said from her home in Edmonds, Wash.

title: Flight Over Canada: A Test for the Cruise; Flight Over Canada: A 'Validation' Test
description: The cruise missile has undergone many free-flight tests in the United States and is being deployed in Europe. The test yesterday in Canada, in which the missile was attached to a wing of a B-52, was aimed at what Air Force officials called a ''validation'' of the route to be used next year when a cruise missile is fired over the same terrain.

title: Financial Study Is Over Budget
description: A two-state commission, named to study the financial ills of the Washington Public Power Supply System's nuclear program, has fallen victim to the same fate by overspending its budget.

description: Banks around the world began signing up yesterday to participate in what would be the biggest loan ever, a $14 billion credit for the Standard Oil Company of California to finance its acquisition of the Gulf Corporation.

description: American Civil Liberties Union attorneys requested a preliminary injunction and a default judgment today in the lawsuit filed on behalf of women runners who want two distance races added to this summer's Olympic events.

title: Ex-Judge's Son Disappears

Kogan, 21 years old, a son of former Judge Zev Kogan, was reported missing. The police said Mr. Kogan purchased a pistol before renting the boat.

title: WARNER-POLYGRAM TIE IS OPPOSED BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that it would challenge the proposed merger of the record divisions of Warner Communications Inc. and Polygram Records Inc. The F.T.C. said it had voted, 4 to 1, to block the merger because it might substantially lessen competition in the record and tape segment of the recorded music industry.

title: MUSIC: NORWEGIAN WORKS AND SOLOISTS COMBINE
description: IT was Norway on parade Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall,

title: Ovett Is Beaten
description: Steve Ovett of Britain, whose 3 minutes 31.36 seconds is the world record in the 1,500-meter run, was beaten by a little-known New Zealander, Peter O'Donoghue, in the Toyota Olympic Countdown track meet today. O'Donoghue was timed in 3:37.08, to Ovett's 3:37.54, winning by about 3 meters.

title: NICARAGUA, CITING RAIDS, SAYS REBELS HAVE NEW SKILLS
description: Nicaraguan officials say that rebels fighting to overthrow their Government have shown new skill in recent days, planting mines in at least one harbor and launching a series of coordinated air and sea attacks.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Puerto Rico Bond Issue Priced by Merrill Lynch
description: A $100 million issue of Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority revenue bonds was offered by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets with a maximum yield of 10.33 percent for 10 1/4 percent bonds that are due in 2009 and carried a price of 99 1/2. Other long-term bonds due in 1999 were offered with a 10 1/4 percent yield, while serial bond yields ranged from 6 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.5 percent in 1994.

description: Two decades ago a weekend tournament consisted almost entirely of pair events. It was normal to have one session of board-a-match team play, but it was relatively unpopular with average players.

30 Die in German Carnival
description: The weeklong annual Rhineland Carnival has so far killed 30 people and injured nearly 1,000, most of them in incidents resulting from drunkenness, the police reported today. The fatalities are double last year's toll.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT FLYERS
description: Pat LaFontaine came home tonight - for the first time. And gauging from the reaction of Islander fans, who chanted his name in thundering verse after he scored a goal and an assist in the Islanders' 5-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers, he has instantly endeared himself on Long Island.

title: Judge Evens and the Dormouse
description: Judge Lester Evens knew just what to do when a prostitute, whose friend was late with the money to pay her fine, kept dozing off in his New York City courtroom last week. He ordered her to sit beside him on the bench.

description: b-Including tax credits of $76,000 for the latest first quarter and $251,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: FOOTBALL'S PERSUADER IS BACK
description: High up in the Hollywood Hills one evening recently, in a house once owned by Cole Porter, five people dined on a terrace overlooking the city of Los Angeles. It was a setting clearly meant for gentle persuasion, and the object of the persuasion was the nation's No. 1 college quarterback, Steve Young of Brigham Young University.

title: Bristol Brass Co. Stops Production
description: The Bristol Brass Company halted production today, bringing to a close what may be the final chapter in a long battle to save the mill.

LEBANON INVITES FACTIONS TO SWISS TALKS
description: The Government today formally invited Lebanese political leaders to a reconciliation conference that is to convene in Switzerland on Monday.

description: A bad bearing and a broken axle on a locomotive were blamed today in the derailment of Amtrak's Silver Star passenger train Monday.

description: The National Semiconductor Corporation agreed to plead guilty yesterday on charges of violating Federal rules concerning the testing of electronic chips used in military equipment.

description: Iraq's Defense Minister denounced the United States today for charging that Iraqi forces had used ''lethal chemical weapons'' against Iranian troops in recent fighting.

THE U.N. TODAY
description: The U.N. Today March 7, 1984 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SHOULD MICE THAT ROAR DECIDE THE NOMINATION
description: I do not have a favorite for the Democratic nomination. What I do have is a powerful conviction that the nomination should not be decided by the people of Iowa, or New Hampshire or even my own state, Maine - delighted as I am that Maine has, with Gary Hart's victory over Walter F. Mondale in the caucuses, achieved more recognition and influence than it deserves.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Hasn't something gone haywire when this great Constitution of ours is invoked to allow Nazis and Ku Klux Klansmen to march on public property, and urge the extermination of Jews and the subjugation of blacks, but it supposedly prevents our children from Bible study or the saying of a simple prayer in their schools?'' - President Reagan. (A20:3.)

title: Testing Time for Mets
description: The Mets held their final workout today before opening a 25-game exhibition schedule in the next 26 days. Manager Dave Johnson said that he would recast the team during that time, with perhaps 11 of the 25 jobs still to be decided.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Indictment for Bruin Craig MacTavish of the Boston Bruins has been indicted in the death of a Maine woman nearly two months ago and faces arraignment today in Essex County (Mass.)

title: SALVADOR PARTY PROTESTS A ROLE FOR d'AUBUISSON; Salvador Party Protests A Role for d'Aubuin
description: The Christian Democratic Party demanded today that Roberto d'Aubuisson, the candidate of the Nationalist Republican Alliance Party, be disqualified from the presidential election March 25.

title: Frustrations for Birdsong
description: Otis Birdsong said yesterday that his uncharacteristic tantrum after the Nets' 120-116 victory over the Utah Jazz Monday was the culmination of ''several things.'' Among the least important, he said, was that he did not start for the third straight game.

title: ALVARADO REVEALS SCHOOL WORKERS AND FRIENDS LENT HIM $62,660
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Anthony J. Alvarado, said last night that since 1981 he had borrowed $62,660 from 11 people, some of them school employees.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AS we all know, the mortality rate for marriages is high here in Split City. Only one out of every two first marriages survives, and those that don't become the business of the divorce lawyer, euphemistically known as the matrimonial lawyer. A Brooklyn woman, known here as Mrs. Donnell, had a consultation with a matrimonial lawyer the other day. She came away feeling that nothing about the divorce process makes much sense.

title: BALLET: ISRAEL COMPANY
description: AS a dance center, Israel is best known for its modern-dance groups. Nevertheless, the country does possess an enterprising Classical company, the Israel Ballet, which danced Monday night at the City Center. The program, a benefit for the Jewish National Fund, was the second performance of a 10-week American tour that began Sunday in Newark.

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $122,000 for the quarter and $407,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $90,000 for the quarter and $215,000 for the year.

description: -Banque Paribas and Credit du Nord, banks controlled by state-owned Compagnie Financi ere de Paribas, said they are starting a joint subsidiary specializing in buyout-by-management transactions.

title: Health Authority
description: A $42.8 million bond issue of the South Dakota Health and Educational Facilities Authority was tentatively priced by an A.G. Becker Paribas group with a yield of 10 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2014, 10 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2004 and 10 percent in 2000. For shorter maturities, yields ranged from 6 percent in 1984 to 9.7 percent in 1996. The bonds are rated single A.

title: Catholic Influence OnIssuesStressed
description: Teachers from 336 Roman Catholic schools in the Archdiocese of New York, holding their 38th annual conference yesterday, were urged to impress upon their pupils the church's contributions in shaping national and international life as well as in their local communities.

title: KOCH IS SEEKING MORE STATE AID DESPITE SURPLUS
description: Mayor Koch came here today seeking more state aid for New York City, saying that the city's expected budget surplus was no reason to deny him more money.

title: TIMBERLINE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Turkish Trade Deficit
description: Turkey's foreign trade deficit widened to $3.5 billion in 1983, an increase of 13.2 percent from 1982.

title: DANCE: MERCE CUNNINGHAM PREMIERE
description: A WORK of haunting beauty is what Merce Cunningham has produced again as a world premiere, and last night at the City Center, it was a perfect opener for the beginning of a two- week season by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company.

title: TRANS-INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Share earnsings give effect to the 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 10.

title: Q&A
description: A READER has written asking about the origin of the term tea towel. I have not been able to find any reasonable explanation. Was it the towel used to cover a tea tray before the serving pieces were added? Was a towel especially set aside for washing cups? Perhaps a reader can supply an explanation.

description: b-Net loss after a nonrecurring charge of $2,714,307 for discontinued product line.

title: Royal Bank of Canada Net Up 14.9%
description: The Royal Bank of Canada, the nation's largest commercial bank, said today that first-quarter profits rose 14.9 percent, to $129.2 million (Canadian), or $1.30 a share, from $112.4 million, or $1.22 a share, a year earlier.

title: Poland Is Investigating A 2d Outspoken Priest
description: The authorities said today that they had started to investigate another outspoken Warsaw priest and were force- feeding a jailed activist from the banned Solidarity movement.

title: COTES DU RHONE WINES: BARGAINS FOR CHANGING U.S. TASTES
description: LIKE tight haircuts and loose trousers, wines of the C^otes du Rh^one have only recently come into fashion. Part of this has to do with lopsided currency rates that allow these moderately priced French wines to be sold in the United States for little more than the price of two large Dr Peppers. tt could also reflect evolving American tastes: those who were weaned on fruity Italian wines and Beaujolais several years ago may now be ready to take the next step toward drier, slightly more sophisticated wines.

title: REALTY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OKLAHOMA GAINS AS TISDALE GETS 31
description: Wayman Tisdale scored 31 points to lead Oklahoma to a 72-66 victory over Missouri tonight in the first round of the Big Eight Conference tourney.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: CREATIVITY The spirit of invention seizes the pride of nations. Yankee ingenuity, that venerable tribute to American know-how, ranks high among inventive firsts and it is being memorialized, in volume, at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. 2 East 91st Street (860- 6868).

title: Oil, Gas Deal For Madison
description: The Madison Fund Inc. and the Inspiration Resources Corporation agreed yesterday to transfer certain oil and gas properties of Inspiration and of Danville Resources to Madison in exchange for common stock. The transaction, which will more than double the size of Madison, is subject to the approval of several boards.

title: CONCERT: MARRINER
description: THE conductor Neville Marriner is probably best known for his many recordings with the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields, the English orchestra he founded 25 years ago, but he also serves as the music director of the Minnesota Orchestra, which appeared at Carnegie Hall Sunday evening.

title: A WARNING ON ADOPTIONS THROUGH ADS
description: ''Parents of one adopted child wish to adopt infant to 2-year-old,'' said the classified advertisement in an Erie, Pa., newspaper. The advertisement produced results within two days, according to Isaac Watson, who answered a call to the number listed.

title: HERBERT J. SELIGMANN
description: Herbert J. Seligmann, an author and journalist, died of a heart attack Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Court Tightens Office-at-Home Rule
description: Lending a new interpretation to a much-amended law, the United States Tax Court has refused to allow a tax deduction for a newspaper editor who routinely used a part of his home as a second office.

title: AMBULANCE CALL DELAY FOR DYING WOMAN BRINGS 300,000 CLAIM
description: A Fire Department official said Monday that a nurse-dispatcher who argued for several minutes with a man who was demanding an ambulance for his dying stepmother was given counseling and returned to duty after a two-day suspension with pay.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL LOS ANGELES RAMS (NFC) Signed Marcellus Greene, cornerback. SEATTLE (AFC) - Signed Jim Youngblood, linebacker, a free agent who had played for the past 11 seasons for the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Dow Drops 12.67 in Heavier Trading
description: Stock prices declined sharply yesterday in heavier trading, with most of the attention again focused on the recently volatile energy issues, which posted large losses.

title: Xerox Introduces Three Machines
description: The Xerox Corporation introduced a high-speed duplicator, the 9900, and two additions to its 10 Series Marathon copiers, the Xerox 1048 and Xerox 1055.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Chief Operating Officer Chosen at Huffy Corp.
description: Richard L. Molen, a sports enthusiast who coaches his children's baseball, soccer, track and basketball teams, will become chief operating officer and executive vice president of the Huffy Corporation, a major manufacturer of bicycles and other sporting goods, effective June 1.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Denies Vice-Presidential Bids
description: Former Representative Shirley Chisholm says she has not been approached by all the candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination about a role as their running mate.

title: ON LENT AND THE SENATE
description: The Senate debate on prayer in the public schools is almost enough to make a man give up religion for Lent. It's fairly obvious that as long as we have politicians of the present stamp, we're going to need to pray for deliverance, but why impose it by constitutional amendment on our children in the public schools?

title: DEMANDS GROW FOR GOVERNOR TO KEEP LONG ISLAND PRISON OPEN
description: Governor Cuomo faced a growing chorus of demands today that he reverse his campaign promise to close the state prison on Long Island.

title: Ulster Prison Official Shot Dead at His Home
description: A senior official at the Maze Prison in Northern Ireland was shot dead outside his Belfast home today by gunmen who used a neighboring house for the ambush. The Irish Republican Army assumed responsibility for the attack.

title: HART, ASSESSING HIS RUSH OF SUPPORT, SAYS IT REFLECTS A DESIRE FOR UNITY
description: ''What I think I may have tapped, and I don't know yet, is a reservoir much vaster than anyone ever contemplated,'' Senator Gary Hart said, referring to the sudden rush of support that has flowed to him in the wake of his victory in the New Hampshire primary a week ago.

title: Economic Scene; The Financial Decontrol Issue
description: UNDER the impact of deregulation, intensified competition and rapid technological change, the Chinese walls that divided financial services among commercial banks, investment banks, big-city banks, regional banks, community banks, savings and loans, securities brokers and dealers, life insurance companies and even big retailers like Sears, Roebuck are falling down.

title: TEXACO TO BUY ITS STOCK BACK
description: Texaco Inc. and Bass Brothers Enterprises announced yesterday that Texaco would buy the 9.7 percent stake in Texaco common stock owned by Bass Brothers and its affiliates.

title: 'MAMA MALONE,' CBS SERIES, BEGINS
description: THE stereotype of the Jewish mother, who is not very much different from the Irish mother, gets a rest this evening as a new CBS series, beginning at 8:30, ransacks the image of the Italian mother. ''Mama Malone,'' pronounced Malo-nay by everybody in her heavily Italianate Brooklyn neighborhood, is the Italian widow of an Irish policeman. Her only memory of him seems to be his capacity for drinking. If you use one stereotype, it seems, why not use them all?

title: DEVIL'S STREAK GOES TO 3 IN WILD GAME
description: In a furious game that would hardly be expected from two teams battling to stay out of last place, the New Jersey Devils defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins by 6-5 tonight with 3 goals in the third period.

title: ...AND HOW TO INVITE STEEP
description: RENT HIKES

title: Too Much of a Not-So-Good Bus
description: When New York's entrepreneurs decided that suburbanites would pay premium fares for seats and air-conditioning on buses to Manhattan, their initiative was welcome. When they are controlled effectively to avoid competing with suburban rail lines, express buses are a good alternative to the private auto for commuters.

title: HORN & HARDART CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Quick Pancake On Shrove Tuesday

title: AGAINST SENDING TROOPS TO THE GULF
description: There has been a lot of hand-wringing about an imminent Iranian blockade of the Strait of Hormuz or other action that could interrupt the flow of oil from the Persian Gulf. This speculation goes over well in Texas where consultants command fat fees by lecturing about oil shocks and price increases - popular topics among oil producers. The matter becomes more serious, however, when the Pentagon talks about the need for military intervention to permit the ''uninterrupted flow of the lifeblood of the free world,'' or when the White House, at least under Jimmy Carter, plans for a Rapid Deployment Force that could be used to keep oil moving during an escalation of the fighting in the Gulf.

title: Detroit Institute of Arts Names Acting Director
description: The Detroit Institute of Arts yesterday announced that Michael Kan had been appointed acting director, effective July 1. He will replace Frederick Cummings, whose 11-year tenure as director ends June 30.

title: KING SCORES 40 IN KNICK VICTORY
description: Bernard King, who normally gets off to a fast start, took longer than usual to begin scoring last night, but he ended up with 40 points to lead theKnicks to a 124-110 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden.

title: KOCH PLANNING TO USE SURPLUS FOR HIRING 150
description: Mayor Koch, faced with a budget surplus and a growing demand for improved services, has decided to hire more workers immediately to sweep streets, fill potholes and repair leaky water pipes, city officials said yesterday.

title: Unilever Net Increases 17%
description: Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products group that includes Lever Brothers and National Starch in the United States, said today that net profit rose 17 percent in the fourth quarter, to $124.3 million, from $106.6 million the year before. Sales rose 3 percent, to $5.27 billion, from $5.13 billion, based on current exchange rates.

title: WHEN THE PRESIDENT'S LAWYER NEEDS A LAWYER
description: When the President has a legal question, on anything from his authority to invade Grenada to his right to appoint or remove an official, it is likely to land on the desk of his lawyer, who is, of course, the Attorney General.

title: Moody's Raises Utility's Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday announced higher ratings for $737 million of debt and preferred stock of the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company. First and refunding mortgage bonds were raised to A-1, from A-2; pollution control revenue bonds were raised to A-2, from A-3; the commercial paper rating was raised to P-1, from P-2, and preferred stock was raised to A-1, from A-2.

Move Reported
description: Hours after an effort was made by Baltimore's mayor and Maryland's governor to hold onto the Colts, it was reported last night that the franchise was ready to finalize a shift to Indianapolis. Coach Frank Kush and Jimmy Irsay , the son of the Baltimore Colts' owner, Robert Irsay , flew to Indianapolis last night, but refused to comment on the reason for being there.

title: 'Lace' Maintains Lead
description: ABC's ''Lace,'' with its second and final episode, won first place again in the Nielsen ratings for the week ended Sunday, but CBS emerged once more as the leading network. CBS's coverage of the Grammy awards was second. CBS won five of the spots in the top 10, ABC four and NBC one.

title: 'I'M GLAD I WAS NOT BORN BEFORE TEA'
description: ''IT vanquisheth heavy dreams, easeth the brain and streng theneth the memory,'' claimed a 17th-century broadside announcing the first public sale in London of an exotic new beverage from China: tea. Quakers and Puritans disputed the claim, denouncing the costly novelty as ''pernicious to health'' and a ''pretext for bringing the wicked of both sexes together in the morning.''

description: Negotiators for a union that represents television news writers and graphics artists reached a tentative settlement with CBS yesterday morning, averting a threatened strike by more than 300 workers in the CBS news division and network-owned stations.

title: Stock Complaint Against Verbatim

Reid Anderson; its president, Malcolm Northrup, and a senior vice president, Geoffrey Bate, together sold stock worth about $3.3 million before news of falling profits and layoffs at the company were released.

title: AUTO UNION SEEKS BIG ECONOMIC GAIN
description: The United Automobile Workers, under pressure from workers seeking to recover concessions granted to a troubled industry two years ago, is planning to ask for major economic gains in in contract talks later this year.

description: Sir Hugh Fraser, a prominent Conservative legislator and friend of the Kennedy family, died today after a long illness, St. Thomas's Hospital announced. He was 66 years old.

description: The Palestine Liberation Organization and the Lebanese Phalangist militia learned the details of Israel's 1982 plan for the invasion of Lebanon before the Israeli Cabinet did, according to a new book by two Israeli journalists.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: JASON RINGENBERG left his father's Illinois hog farm two and a half years ago to try his luck in Nashville's music community. ''It was the classic 'country boy comes to Nashville to get famous' type of story,'' he recalled recently with a laugh. ''I played with a couple of rockabilly bands, and eventually Jeff Johnson, a bass player, introduced me to the small Nashville punk rock scene. Through Jeff I met a guitarist, Warner Hodges, and a drummer, Perry Baggs, who had been in various country and punk rock bands. And the first time we played together, halfway through the first song, I just stopped playing and said: 'This is it! This is the best band I'm ever going to find.''

title: Bucyrus-Erie Plan
description: The Bucyrus- Erie Company, which is involved in the mining, construction machinery and aerospace industries, said it will ask shareholders on April 24 to approve a plan to reorganize and form a holding company named Becor Western Inc. The company said Bucyrus- Erie shareholders would become stockholders of Becor Western, upon approval, and would hold the same number of shares in the new company as they hold in Bucyrus-Erie.

Exact numbers are unknown because many teen-age suicides are recorded as accidental deaths and only a psychological post- mortem could reveal whether the accident was actually a deliberate attempt at self-destruction. What is known is that the rate of suicides by teen-agers has risen more than threefold in the past 25 years and that this increase is real, not the result of better reporting of the problem.

title: MUTI TO BE MUSIC DIRECTOR
description: RICCARDO MUTI, the Italian conductor, will become music director of La Scala opera house in Milan beginning in 1986. According to Stephen Sell, executive director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, Mr. Muti's new job will have no effect on his current activities in Philadelphia. Last fall, Mr. Muti began the first year of a new five-year contract as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra.

title: Britain Orders Inquiry On Radiation Near Base
description: A British Government minister has ordered an investigation into allegations that radiation has caused severe deformities to babies born near a United States nuclear submarine base at Holy Loch in western Scotland.

title: Victor Gets Loan
description: Victor Technologies Inc., which last month filed for reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, has won court approval to borrow up to $4.2 million to keep operating through the end of March. The money would come from Security Pacific National Bank, which is Victor's largest secured creditor and which has financed the company's manufacturing and distribution since bankruptcy proceedings began last month. Victor's board is scheduled to consider a proposal Thursday from a British microcomputer company, Applied Computer Techniques, to buy some of the assets of Victor.

title: VAST U.N. SYSTEM: A VARIETY OF USEFUL PROJECTS
description: In some regions of tropical Africa it is common to see a young child leading a string of men who have lost the power of sight. The men are suffering from a widepread parasitical disease called onchoceriasis, or river blindness.

title: N.C.A.A. Wrestling to Open
description: The teams that have been dominant in recent years, Iowa and Oklahoma State, are co- favorites in the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships that start at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Thursday morning.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Naugles Cutback
description: Naugles Inc.'s chairman, Harold Bulter, said the company planned to announce ''moves the company is making relative to slowing its growth, eliminating the sale of franchises and closing down and subletting about 35 restaurants.'' In over-the-counter trading today, Naugles was the biggest percentage loser, dropping $2.50, to $10.75 bid.

title: RSC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago results include a gain of $240,000, or 7 cents a share, from the sale of property.

description: John Johnson scored 34 points and Gary Voce added 18 as St. Nicholas of Tolentine defeated All Hallows, 73-63, last night in a Catholic High Schools Athletic Association basketball semifinal matching Bronx schools.

description: The latest quarter and 9 months results include Lennox which the company acquired in July 1983.

title: RATE RISE WIDENS SAVINGS BANK LOSS
description: The financial condition of savings banks chartered by New York State grew worse in the fourth quarter of 1983 as rising interest rates caused an increase in their aggregate net operating loss to $59.7 million, the State Banking Department reported yesterday. Their third-quarter loss was $50 million.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
REDUCING CLOSET CLUTTER
description: TO help achieve more effective use of closet space, an extra rod that runs parallel to an existing one allows you to hang clothing in a double row. Stretch-A-Closet is a kit that provides that extra rod without requiring carpentry.

title: Drama in the Stands
description: When Spain's two top soccer clubs met at Vicente Calderon Stadium in Madrid on Sunday, Atletico Madrid's 1-0 victory over its crosstown rival, Real Madrid, must have been especially riveting to the 70,000 frenzied fans. None of them noticed a 70-year- old man who apparently suffered a stroke during the game and slumped over in his seat.

title: 3 Armed Fugitives Arrested
description: Three armed fugitives commandeered a motor home in Kentucky, took the five people in it hostage and drove to Tennessee before being captured Tuesday, the authorities said.

title: Steel Merger And Reagan President Reagan said yesterday that he did not believe that the proposed merger of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation would reduce competition to the point that it would constitute a monopoly.
description: He made his remarks at a luncheon with business editors.

title: The U.N. Today March 8, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TO REGAIN CRUCIFIXES, POLISH STUDENTS HOLD SIT-IN
description: Agricultural students took over their state- run college here today, demanding that crucifixes be put back up in their classrooms. The authorities ordered the college ''suspended'' late tonight and the area was surrounded by riot police, according to Roman Catholic priests in the neighboring village of Garwolin who talked to students who managed to evade the police lines. The priests estimated that 400 of the school's 650 students were involved in the strike and sit-in. A handful of youths told the priests they had tried to march to the Church of the Transfiguration in Garwolin but had turned back when faced with a line of riot police. The strikers were locked in the dormitories, they said, while the police with dogs searched the fields for stragglers or townspeople trying to join the protest. The local prosecutor had warned them that their demonstration was illegal, the students said, and then the director read an official letter announcing the suspension of the school.

title: ; National Can Chairman Says He Will Keep Job
description: Frank W. Considine, chairman and chief executive of the National Can Corporation of Chicago, said yesterday that he would retain both his position and independence if a takeover by Victor Posner is completed.

title: Only One Way for Steel
description: At first glance, it seemed obvious that the Justice Department would approve the merger of two financially beleaguered steel giants, Republic and LTV. This being the Reagan Administration, the department was reputed to be soft on antitrust. Besides, who would dare in an election year to oppose a merger that promised to increase efficiency in a declining industry?

title: IN FRENCH SHIPYARD TOWN, LEFTISTS ARE CASTAWAYS
description: -SUR-MER, France, March 5 - The Mediterranean's pastels, its glistening, leaping light stop at the shipyard gates here. Beyond them is one tough town: a half-dozen bars on Avenue Gambetta, more across the street from the yard, and guys in them, coming off work, talking, their voices lowered, to the quiet precincts of dismay.

title: PUBLIC-EMPLOYEE UNION SUES CUOMO OVER JOB CUTS
description: The state's largest public-employee union sued Governor Cuomo today, accusing him of illegally impounding funds appropriated by the Legislature to restore jobs at state institutions.

description: Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee, the Senate majority leader, today temporarily abandoned his bid for a quick test vote on a school prayer amendment to the Constitution as supporters pressed the efforts to find a winning compromise.

title: MORGAN AGREES TO PAY HIGHER BID FOR GREEK SHIP
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company agreed to pay $1.62 million for the Greek freighter Hellenic Star in United States District Court yesterday, after withdrawing its motion to have the price reduced to $1.25 million.

title: Director Has Not Heard Of Dismissal by Soviet
description: Yuri Lyubimov, the Soviet stage director who was reported dismissed from his job in Moscow for remaining abroad too long, said today that he had not yet received official word of his dismissal.

title: A LINKAGE OF FUTURES MARKETS
description: Futures markets in this country and abroad are about to become more integrated at a time when the industry is still struggling to digest new trading products.

title: TANDON TO CUT STAFF AND MERGE UNITS
description: The Tandon Corporation, the world's largest manufacturer of disk drives for microcomputers, said today that it would lay off 1,000 employees in a consolidation that represents the second major cutback in as many months.

title: Air-Conditioning Failing, Gunn Says
description: The president of the New York City Transit Authority, David L. Gunn, said yesterday that difficulty in obtaining parts might mean that fewer buses and subway trains would be air- conditioned next summer.

title: West German G.N.P.
description: West Germany's gross national product rose 1.3 percent in 1983, adjusted for inflation, the Statistics Office said today. Preliminary estimates had put the increase at 1.2 percent. The rise in 1983 followed declines of 1.1 percent in 1982 and two-tenths of 1 percent in 1981.

title: 2 WHO MADE LOANS TO ALVARADO GOT EXTRA SCHOOL PAY
description: Two New York City school employees who lent money to Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado received extra compensation while working for Mr. Alvarado when he was superintendent in East Harlem, according to Board of Education records.

title: RANGERS DROP FOURTH STRAIGHT
description: The Rangers were slow to start skating tonight, falling behind by two goals in the first period and going on to their fourth straight defeat, a 6-3 loss to the Minnesota North Stars.

description: Did Anthony J. Alvarado mortgage his credibility as the New York City Schools Chancellor by borrowing money from his employees?

description: Expanding its challenge to racial quotas that it sees as discriminating against whites, the Justice Department this week challenged an ordinance in Dade County, Fla., that sets aside some county construction contracts for businesses owned by blacks.

description: When Alan Cranston came back to the Senate from the campaign wars this week, tiny wisps of gray were showing in the fringe of hair he had so carefully kept dyed in his run for President.

description: The season of Lent, which began yesterday with the observance of Ash Wednesday, is for some Christians no longer associated with giving up such pleasures as cigarettes or candy.

description: Commercial banks are becoming increasingly convinced that nearly $3 billion in interest payments owed by Argentina will not be paid by the end of March and that the loans on which those payments are owed will have to be classified as nonperforming.

description: Vice President Bush, beginning a two-day campaign swing through the South today, ridiculed what he referred to as Democratic ''prophets of doom'' who asserted that Reaganomics would never work.

title: I.B.M.-Intel Talks
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said ''discussions are proceeding'' with the Intel Corporation over a license that would allow I.B.M. to make its own Intel 8088 microprocessors for its Personal Computer line. The chips have been in short supply because of demand by I.B.M. and other manufacturers making I.B.M.-compatible machines. Earlier in the week, Intel licensed Commodore International Ltd., a home computer maker, to make the chip, presumably for an I.B.M.-compatible machine of its own.

title: Ambulance Dispatcher Was Criticized Earlier
description: A Fire Department nurse-dispatcher who refused to send an ambulance to a dying woman was criticized a month earlier for a similar incident, officials confirmed today.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: HART AND MONDALE STRIVING TO FIND HOW TO WIN SOUTH
description: Senator Gary Hart and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale sought to outdo each other today in finding a way to cut through the jungle of Southern politics and appeal to the contrasting interest groups in Presidential primaries in Georgia, Alabama and Florida next Tuesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day on Wednesday listing the United States' largest oil companies omitted one major corporation. It was the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), which had 1983 revenues of $29.5 billion.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: It may serve a function. After all, you can whisper behind it, tryst behind it, shelter behind it from a draft. But as shown in a resplendent exhibition that opened this week in the east wing of the National Gallery of Art, the screen need not be prosaic merely because it is useful. Indeed, it need not even be useful: It can declare itself a work of art for art's sake, a pure sculpture, or it can disavow any possible utility - as do many of the contemporary screens in this show.

title: Gold Items Taken In Midtown Theft By The Associated Press
description: A man held up a Federal Express driver in midtown Manhattan yesterday morning, locked him in the back of his truck and fled with three boxes of gold charms worth as much as $100,000, the police said.

title: NEW U.S. STRATEGY ON MIDEAST BEGUN
description: The Reagan Administration is fashioning a new Middle East strategy to build closer ties with Israel and Jordan as well as between those two neighboring countries.

description: Fifty-two countries pledged a total of $658.3 million and 475,000 tons of food grains during the 11th pledging conference of the World Food Program, which ended late Tuesday.

ELEANOR GEHRIG, 79, WIDOW OF YANKEE HALL OF FAME STAR
description: Eleanor Gehrig, the widow of Lou Gehrig, the great Yankee first baseman of half a century ago, died Tuesday night at Presbyterian Hospital. She was 79 years old, and had been ill since last August.

title: AN INSTITUTION FINDS INMATES RESPONDING WELL TO PET THERAPY
description: -- The short man with long red hair slowly bent to ground level and waited while the parrot climbed onto his finger, then gently returned the bird to his shoulder.
