description: It's the task of New York City's Department of Investigation to determine whether Schools Chancellor Anthony Alvarado violated any law in seeking to escape his financial problems. But his admissions that he borrowed more than $80,000 from lenders who included Board of Education employees raise profound questions about his judgment.

title: JACKSON CANDIDACY RAISES NEW QUESTIONS OF PRESS PERFORMANCE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, running for the Democratic Presidential nomination, often ends his speeches by asking young adults in the audience to register to vote. The call is conducted in the style of a revival meeting, and it ends with a host of black supporters around him.

description: A disagreement over whether officials in the Defense Department had prevented one of their fellow officials from presenting Congressional testimony on how to cut military costs continued to simmer today.

CHORUS LINE KEEPS A FIGHTER IN TUNE
description: It was not his idea, Tim Witherspoon was quick to point out, but boxing's first chorus line will be cheering for him at ringside here Friday night when he meets Greg Page in the fight to produce the successor to Larry Holmes as the World Boxing Council's heavyweight champion.

title: FORMER KLANSMAN INDICTED IN BOMBING OF A SYNAGOGUE
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, acquitted in the 1980 shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., then president of the National Urban League, was indicted yesterday for a bombing that destroyed a synagogue in Chattanooga, Tenn., on July 29, 1977.

title: MORGAN LOSES ACCOUNT
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company has been dismissed as one of nine outside investment managers for the nation's second-largest pension fund, aides to the New York State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said today.

title: COLECO LOSES $35 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: Coleco Industries announced yesterday that it lost $35 million in the fourth quarter, more than twice as much as most industry analysts had predicted. A company spokesman said the ''enormity of the loss'' on the Adam home computer surprised even Coleco's top officials.

title: Homosexual Statue Marred
description: A hammer-wielding vandal caused extensive damage to Stanford University's Gay Liberation statue, the campus police said today. The bronze sculpture by George Segal depicts four homosexuals, two women and two men, and the police said each figure was dented in the head, face and body by a barrage of about 40 blows.

title: THE IRREPRESSIBLE ARAFAT
description: The most impressive thing about Yasir Arafat is his resilience. The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization talks with pride about fighting the Israelis for 88 days in southern Lebanon and Beirut, ''the longest Arab-Israeli war,'' he says, and 48 days besieged by Syrian-backed forces in Tripoli.

description: ''Emile Galle: Dreams Into Glass,''

description: A gunboat warned two Spanish fishing vessels to get out of French waters today and opened fire when they refused. Government sources said nine fishermen were wounded.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; 2 Officers Resign From Petro-Lewis
description: Two officers resigned yesterday at the Petro-Lewis Corporation, the Denver-based oil and gas company that last month wrote off $12.8 million and withdrew the offering of a new oil income fund. Petro-Lewis is the country's largest seller of oil and natural gas income funds - limited partnerships holding oil and gas producing properties - and one of the biggest producers in the United States.

description: The coordinator for Gary Hart's Mississippi Presidential campaign resigned today in the face of criticism for his attendance at an all-white athletic banquet.

description: The Chinese Government said today that it had expelled a foreign journalist because he had been caught trying to smuggle antiques out of China.

title: GERMAN A MET OPERA PROSPECT
description: AUGUST EVERDING, the general manager of the Munich State Theaters, has been approached by the Metropolitan Opera to succeed Anthony Bliss as general manager. But, Mr. Everding stressed in a telephone conversation from Munich this week, no concrete offer has as yet been made and the negotiations are only ''in the discussion stage.''

description: New York City has filed suits against three Brooklyn real-estate brokers, charging them with violating Federal, state and local civil-rights laws by denying black and Hispanic people equal access to housing.

SENATE BACKS ENVOY TO VATICAN
description: The Senate today named the first United States Ambassador to the Vatican in more than a century, approving President Reagan's nomination of William A. Wilson for the post.

title:
GARDENING;
SOURCES OF SEEDS FOR UNUSUAL PLANTS
description: SINCE the time has come to send for spring garden catalogues, consideration might be given to the few mail-order nurseries and seed houses that shun standard flowers and vegetables in favor of unusual, rare or largely forgotten plants. These concerns are specialists; a source of fragrant plants, for example, lists over 100 variously scented geraniums.

title: Latin Debt Plan Presented
description: A ''plan of action'' to confront the problems of heavy indebtedness by Latin American nations calls for a ''balanced set of commitments and measures'' by both debtors and lenders.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Year-ago results are not available because the company went public in January 1983.

title: THE DIGITAL REVOLUTION BREEDS SMART NEW APPLIANCES
description: FOR better or worse, the digital revolution has come to the laundry and kitchen. Appliances are beeping, blinking, flashing messages and signaling when doors are ajar, cycles over and motors burned out. And the pace of the revolution will probably pick up. Manufacturers are already tinkering with appliances that listen and speak.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants was taken to Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., yesterday for treatment of a kidney stone by the team physician, Dr. Alan Levy , who said that Parcells's condition was not serious. . . . Julius Adams , at 35 the oldest defensive lineman in the National Football League, has signed a two-year contract to play his 14th year at defensive end for the New England Patriots. . . . A former heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson , 49 years old, will be part of a charity exhibition card in Baltimore March 17 seeking to raise money for that city's St. Vincent de Paul Society. Patterson will box a former amateur boxer, Bob Pomerlane , who is 7 years older. . . . Because Edward J. DeBartolo Sr. owns the Pittsburgh Penguins of the N.H.L. and the Pittsburgh Maulers of the U.S.F.L., the Islander-Penguin game scheduled for Sunday afternoon in Pittsburgh has been shifted to the evening. The Maulers make their home debut that afternoon, and DeBartolo did not want his two teams competing for the fans' attention.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effected Jan. 16.

title: RALLY CUTS LOSS
description: A late rally enabled the stock market to trim some of its earlier sharp losses yesterday in heavier trading, although all three major market indicators ended with fairly large declines.

title: FREE TICKETS SILENCE COAST MAYOR ON A STADIUM
description: Being a big city Mayor is a tricky job. Ask Dianne Feinstein, who is a veteran of public life in San Francisco, where she is in her second term. Nothing in her experience at City Hall prepared her for being cut off from advocating a major project she hopes to see built here.

description: Coach on Move?

EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. announced that Robert G. Moore had joined the company as senior vice president-investments, and that Michael Panitch, vice chairman of its IDS/American Express subsidiary, had resigned.

title: Malavasi Is Replaced
description: Ray Malavasi , the former coach of the Los Angeles Rams who took over as offensive-line coach of the Oakland Invaders of the United States Football League six weeks ago, has been replaced, but not, the Invaders insist, because of the line's poor showing in its first two games. Malavasi has been replaced by Chuck Hutchison , the director of player personnel, who also held both jobs last season. According to a club spokesman, Malavasi had been hired on an indefinite interim basis to take some of the early-season load off Hutchison, who found it difficult to do both jobs during the preseason period, when he was especially busy as personnel director.

title: CONCERN FOR BID HURTS GULF STOCK
description: Gulf Corporation shares plunged $4.50 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, to $64.75, in very heavy trading, reflecting persistent concern that Congress might block Gulf's takeover by the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: Grants Made for Aid to Aged
description: The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation has awarded $3.8 million in grants to 25 interfaith religious coalitions to develop volunteer services to care for thousands of elderly people in their own homes rather than in institutions.

title: Lockheed Gets Missile Contract
description: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, a unit of the Lockheed Corporation, received a $443.3 million Navy contract for submarine- launched missiles and associated hardware, the Defense Department said.

title: Bridge: Declarer in a Jersey Contest Survives a Difficult Situation
description: In general, it is desirable for a player with a strong, balanced hand to become the declarer, so that the opening lead comes around to him. This can usually be managed after a one no-trump opening, especially when transfer bids allow the opener to play nearly all major-suit contracts.

title: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: THE DISCORD ON SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration's hope of a few months ago for a consensus in Congress for stepped-up military support for El Salvador appears to have collapsed in the aftermath of the American setback in Lebanon. The two developments have produced sharp recriminations between Secretary of State George P. Shultz and many members of Congress. Mr. Shultz, in a series of contentious hearings before Congressional committees, has accused Congress of undercutting the diplomatic efforts to salvage the situation in Lebanon by the debate over the tenure of the Marines there and of ''walking away'' from the crisis in El Salvador by threatening to curtail military aid.

title: Henry Wilcoxon Dead at 78; Screen Actor and Producer
description: Henry Wilcoxon, the actor and producer, died Tuesday in his home. He was 78 years old and had been ill with cancer.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Beautiful View at 85

title: DANCE: BLACK CELEBRATION AT BROOKLYN ACADEMY
description: MARDI GRAS festivities came to the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Tuesday night, and it will be Mardi Gras there all the rest of this week until Sunday afternoon thanks to a program called ''Sweet Saturday Night.'' Supervised by Mikki Shepard-Hemans and subtitled ''A Celebration of Black Street and Social Dance,'' it proved to be two hours of sheer joy as it offered a panorama of some of the ways blacks have danced over the centuries.

title: COURT SAYS BAYLOR IS DISCRIMINATORY
description: A Federal District Court here has found Baylor College of Medicine intentionally discriminated against Jewish doctors by excluding them from lucrative practice in Saudi Arabia.

title: ;  Gains for Newspapers
description: With the final December estimates in, Craig C. Standen, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, reports that last year's advertising revenues of daily newspapers were up 16.3 percent from 1982, to $20.6 billion. In December alone, revenues were $1.87 billion, up 11.9 percent. Classified continued to be the hottest category, with an increase of 21.9 percent, to $439.6 million, followed by retail, which was up 9.3 percent, to $1.2 billion, and national, up 8 percent, to $206.9 million.

title: AGED CRIMINAL IS JAILED AGAIN IN LONG CAREER
description: James Barnes claims to be 96 years old, and law-enforcement authorities say he has served time for various crimes, including murder, during the last 54 years.

title: FEDERAL STUDY CITES SLOW ARTS GROWTH
description: A study by the National Endowment for the Arts has found that there was a slowdown in the growth of the performing arts in the 1970's in the United States. It said that ''artistic deficits'' may have been deliberately planned by producers to make ends meet.

title: Bruin Enters Plea In Fatal Accident
description: Craig MacTavish, a 25-year-old forward for the Boston Bruins, pleaded not guilty today to a vehicular-homicide charge and was released by a county judge in his own recognizance.

title: License Baby Sitters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Helms Suing Ex-Partners
description: J. Lynn Helms, who resigned as the head of the Federal Aviation Administration in December after questions were raised about some of his prior business activities, has filed a $225 million lawsuit against several former business partners.

title: 3 KILLED AND 9 HURT BY BOMB ON BUS IN AN ISRAELI PORT
description: Three Israelis were killed and nine wounded today when a bomb exploded on a bus in the port city of Ashdod, south of Tel Aviv. Two of the wounded were released from the hospital after treatment.

title: 'SPECIAL INTEREST' CANT
description: A new cant phrase - ''special interest'' - has entered our political language. Politicians gravely declare themselves against it; television commentators toss the phrase about as if its meaning were transparent; and in this moment of spiritless conservatism there seems to be general agreement that the Republic will be endangered if ''special interests'' aren't curbed.

title: QUESTIONS POSED BY SNIPER CASE AT PENN STATION
description: As long ago as last August, three different shootings near Pennsylvania Station were linked by police ballistics tests to a single gun. But not until Feb. 21, after three more men had been shot inside the station itself, did the Police Department inform the public and set up a task force of 30 officers that is now combing the area day and night for a sniper.

title: MAHRES BEATEN IN LAST RACE
description: The title of ''America's Best Skier'' will probably stay with Phil Mahre for years, but the hope he had of ending his career with a World Cup giant slalom victory evaporated on Vail Mountain today after the first run.

title: Madrid Exchange Shift
description: The Madrid Stock Exchange plans to increase its trading week to five days from four and lengthen daily trading sessions by 45 minutes, to two and a half hours.

title: No Headline
description: G.M.-Toyota Deal Advances

title: 3 GENERATIONS OF FARM LIFE ON AUCTION BLOCK
description: When Elmer Stone first saw his family's new farm here, he was 3 years old. The President's name then was William Howard Taft. And there was no such thing yet as a World War.

title: WHIMSICAL AND IDIOSYNCRATIC FURNITURE IN LOS ANGELES
description: WHEN the furniture show called ''L.A. Apocalypse'' opened at the Whiteley Gallery in Los Angeles in January, hundreds of people waited their turn along La Brea Avenue to see the more than 50 pieces made by 25 artists. By the time the show closed last month sales had indeed gone very well.

title: Columbia Drops Mahar
description: After turning in just two winning seasons in six years, Buddy Mahar is being dropped as Columbia's basketball coach when his contract expires in June, Athletic Director Al Paul announced yesterday. ''After evaluating the entire direction of the program, we felt that this was the time for a change,'' said Paul, who announced that a search for a new coach would begin immediately. Mahar, whose team had an 8-18 record this season, compiled a six-year mark of 70-86.

title: HOWARD WEINBERGER
description: Howard Weinberger, who served for 20 years as an attorney for the New York State Labor Relations Board and was a founder and officer of the San Juan Racing Association, died yesterday at his home in Roslyn Heights, L.I. He was 70 years old.

title: Baltimore Still Hopeful
description: Mayor William Schaefer of Baltimore reported being told by the Colts' owner today that there was no final deal to move the team to Indianapolis, a transfer that had seemed imminent only hours before. Mayor Schaefer said that he had a three-minute telephone conversation this morning with the owner, Robert Irsay.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Adds Another Sears Account
description: Having removed its Sears Business Systems Centers account from the N. W. Ayer advertising agency in January, Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that it was assigning the business to Ogilvy & Mather, Chicago.

title: TOM SEAVER'S ADJUSTMENT
description: SARASOTA, Fla.

title: No Headline
description: Barroom Rape Trial Hears of Failed Call

title: TOKYO LEADER HURT IN ATTACK
description: Kiichi Miyazawa, a Japanese politician widely considered to be a leading candidate for the prime ministership, was attacked by an assailant wielding a knife and an ashtray this morning in a leading Tokyo hotel.

title: A SCOTTISH PILGRIMAGE TO NATCHEZ MANSIONS
description: The Duke of Atholl took the grand tour of Natchez this week, one of 150,000 visitors to do so each year, compared with 110,000 that last year toured his home in Scotland, Blair Castle.

title: COURT CLEARS SPENDING FOR WESTWAY BY STATE
description: New York State can spend its own money for preliminary work on the Westway project now, before there is a final decision on whether the project will be built, according to a decision yesterday by a Federal appeals court.

title: The Subject Is Immovable
description: The 6-year- old boy stopped and stared. He gazed up at the athlete with the 54- inch waist and the nickname ''Taboo.'' The little boy attempted to lift the giant's leg, like a mouse trying to topple a bear.

title: WHY GARY HART?
description: The incredible can no longer be denied: Walter Mondale is at the end of the road.

title: Woman Is Mardi Gras Victim
description: A 52-year-old woman was crushed to death between a parade pickup truck and a Mardi Gras float Tuesday night.

title: French Airliner Hijacked And Flown to Geneva
description: An Algerian student who said he had a bag of explosives hijacked an Air France jetliner with 68 people aboard today and ordered it flown to Geneva, and Swiss policemen disguised as airport staff overpowered him nearly five hours later.

title: 22-Year Sentence In 34th St. Crash
description: A Bronx man whose car smashed into a crowded store off Herald Square last May, killing a woman and injuring 26 others, was sentenced yesterday to 22 years to life in prison.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Azienda Autonoma delle Ferrovie dello Stato, the Italian railroad, said it was floating a 100 million Deutsche mark Eurobond (about $38 million) through an international banking consortium managed by Commerzbank of West Germany. The 7-year bond carries an annual coupon of 8 percent and an issue price at 99.5 percent, with repayment due on April 1, 1991.

title: Article 037737 -- No Title
description: Paavo Haavikko, a Finnish poet, novelist and playwright, has been awarded the $25,000 Neustadt International Prize for Literature.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized gains of $35,149 for the latest year and $250,812 for the previous year.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amedco Inc. , a health care and funeral supply company based in Springfield, Ill., said it had made an investment in Henderson, Few & Co., an Atlanta-based investment banking company, which would lead to 100 percent ownership. Terms were not disclosed.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $3,025,000.

title: Key Rates
Girl Goes on Trial In Miner's Slaying
description: A 15- year-old Newark girl went on trial as an adult today on charges that she had planned and directed the robbery and murder of a disabled coal miner.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Oh, there goes the old shovel. Oh, God!'' - Mildred Stone, at auction of family farm to pay debts. (A18:4.)

title: Seoul Pledges Import Aid
description: South Korea said today that it would undertake a broad import liberalization program as a big trade mission here announced purchase of more than $2.4 billion of American goods.

title: REAGAN REPORTEDLY PLANS TO SEEK $93 MILLION IN AID FOR EL SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration is planning to ask for $93 million in expedited military aid to El Salvador, Senate Appropriations Committee sources said this evening.

title: DANCE: GRAHAM TROUPE
description: MARTHA GRAHAM'S ''Death and Entrances'' began as an examination of the lives of the Bront"e sisters. At its premiere in 1943, the dance was a portrait of a woman coming to terms with essential rage and regret and their resolution. Revived by the Martha Graham Dance Company on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, ''Death and Entrances'' provides yet another searing instance of Miss Graham's gift for revealing the female psyche without a trace of sentiment.

title: SCENE DESIGNERS DABBLE IN EARTH ART ON STAGE
description: SCENIC designers have been taking a step away from scene shops and into the natural world, reproducing on stage aspects of the environment that are geological as well as dramatic. In the process, they are posing new physical challenges for actors.

title: MARTIN NIEMOLLER, RESOLUTE FOE OF HITLER
description: The Rev. Martin Niem"oller, the German Protestant preacher, theologian and church leader who led church opposition to Hitler and survived the Dachau concentration camp, died Tuesday at his home in Wiesbaden, West German Protestant church officials announced. He was 92 years old.

title: Safety of the Elderly
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Ford to Export Engines
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to export up to 250,000 automobile engines a year from its Dearborn, Mich., engine plant to Ford of Europe, beginning in 1986.

title: SHAMIR ASCRIBES BAD FAITH TO CAIRO
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir asserted today that as soon as the Egyptians got Sinai back under the terms of the 1979 peace treaty, they reneged on other clauses of the pact that call for normalization between the two countries.

title: DIPLOMATIC VICTORY IN SOUTHERN AFRICA?
description: The Reagan Administration may be turning its disastrous policy in Southern Africa into an election-year diplomatic triumph - a package deal removing Cuban troops from Angola and bringing stability to the region and independence to South- West Africa, generally known as Namibia.

title: FROM DUBLIN, A PLEA NOT TO GIVE TO THE I.R.A.
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald today sharply criticized Americans who continue to give money or encouragement to the Irish Republican Army.

title: Out of Work
description: His name may go down in legal history, but what Bob Boris could use right now is a job.

title: Braniff Stalls Sale
description: Braniff Inc. announced today that it is postponing the public sale of its common stock.

title: LICENSE BABY SITTERS
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: JUDGE BACKS MERRILL IN TEAMSTERS VALUATION
description: A Federal judge in Chicago has said that Merrill Lynch & Company acted properly when it determined that the assets of an insurance company being purchased by a teamsters health and welfare fund were worth $10.75 million.

title: IRAQ DISPLAYS TEENAGERS HELD AS PRISONERS OF WAR
description: Six boys, 14 and 15 years old, were marched in single file into a marbled meeting hall of the Information Ministry here today. They wore motley pieces of military uniforms or boys' clothes, and their heads were bent downward, their eyes fixed to the floor. They were Iranian prisoners of war.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Drug Crackdown Confirmed
description: The Customs Service has cracked down on the Colombian cocaine trade, inspecting all airplanes, passengers and shipments from Colombia to the United States, officials confirmed Tuesday. The effort, involving extra inspectors in Miami, Houston and New Orleans, got under way March 1 without public announcement, officials said. Dennis Murphy, a spokesman for the Customs Service, said the agency had found ''a lot of cocaine'' in six days, and had seized ''over $300,000 in currency that was unreported.''

title: CHROMALLOY AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes pretax provision of $51.1 million to reduce the carrying values of certain assets in the company's transportation and petroleum services segments. c-Includes pretax provision for asset writedowns of $60.7 million. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $37 million.

title: STATE DEPT. OFFICIAL SCORNS 'OUR EUROPEAN FRIENDS'
description: A senior State Department official accused the West European allies today of practicing a ''blame America first syndrome'' in relations with the United States.

title: THEATER: IN ALASKA
description: NEW HAVEN NINA SHENGOLD'S ''Homesteaders,'' the main stage attraction at the Long Wharf, is one of those plays that has Regional Theater written all over it. Set in picturesque summertime Alaska, it is dripping in local color and features a strapping cast handsomely attired in L. L. Bean- style wet gear. Michael Yeargan's setting - a rustic cabin in a remote fishing community - is so realistic it could earn a permanent home in Disney World's Frontierland. Unfortunately, almost nothing that happens within the cabin seems real at all.

title: Budweiser's Brewers Lose Battle in Britain
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc., the American company that makes Budweiser beer, lost a court appeal in London today to claim exclusive use of the name Budweiser for beer in Britain.

title: Higher Drinking Age Cuts Jersey Fatalities
description: Drunken-driving convictions and fatal accidents involving people under the age of 21 have dropped since New Jersey raised its legal drinking age, the State Motor Vehicles Director said today.

title: Deposits Climb At Thrift Units
description: Savers deposited $6.8 billion more in savings and loan associations during January than they withdrew, producing the biggest net increase in 11 months, the Government said today. At the same time, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said, institutions closed $10 billion in mortgage loans, a record for the month of January but down from the $14.2 billion record set in December.

title: Swale Wins by 8 At Gulfstream
description: Swale, ranked as the second-best 2-year-old in the country last year behind Devil's Bag, began his campaign toward the Kentucky Derby with a flourish today by scoring an eight- length victory in the Hutcheson Stakes on opening day at Gulfstream Park.

title: RESTORING PAINTED FURNITURE
description: Collectors of furniture made by country cabinetmakers are often not aware that much of this simple pine furniture was painted before being sold. In a misguided effort to get back to the ''true'' surface - the raw wood or a simple wax finish - this paint is often ruthlessly stripped away by new owners. There goes the painted work, some good, some indifferent - sponged, stenciled, grain painted or just covered with plain milk-based paint.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Amdahl Corporation misidentified the exchange on which its stock is traded. It is the American Stock Exchange.

title: Devils' Streak Ends at 3
description: Jim Korn broke a 4-4 third-period deadlock with his third goal of the game tonight to lead the Toronto Maple Leafs to an 8-4 triumph over the Devils. New Jersey's winning streak, its longest since moving from Colorado before last season, was ended at three games.

title: ;  Bank Holding Unit Sets Offering
description: Republic New York Corporation, a bank holding company, is offering a $50 million issue of 20-year floating rate notes and a $50 million issue of adjustable rate preferred stock, both through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: LAWYER PLEADS GUILTY TO HELPING KILLER FLEE
description: Mary Evans, a lawyer who fell so deeply in love with the killer she was defending that she helped him escape, pleaded guilty today to under an agreement in which she could receive a suspended sentence. Her lawyer said she would enter a mental hospital.

title: CANADA ANNOUNCES NEW EFFORT TO CUT ACID RAIN
description: Federal and provincial environmental officials have announced here that Canada will move ahead on its own without the United States to try to cut industrial emissions linked to acid-rain pollution by 50 percent in the next decade.

title: Nets Take 7th In Row
description: Led by Albert King, who scored 12 of his team-high 20 points in the final quarter, the New Jersey Nets turned back the Milwaukee Bucks tonight, 106-100, and extended their winning streak to seven games. Milwaukee's six-game streak ended.

title: Presidential Roots
description: Steeped as we are in the quadrennial foray over who will reside

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Peace Appeal in Parade

title: LAYOFFS AT LILCO LEAVE WORKERS HURT AND BITTER
description: The first day of work as a construction mechanic at the Long Island Lighting Company was ''exhilarating,'' John Hart recalled today. ''It was great to know you were with a strong outfit. I figured I could stay for my career.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAFIA PRINCESS: Growing Up in Sam Giancana's Family. By Antoinette Giancana and Thomas C. Renner. Illustrated. 304 pages. William Morrow.

title: SOCAL'S CHAIRMAN OPTIMISTIC ON GULF BID
description: The bid by the Standard Oil Company of California to acquire the Gulf Corporation for $13.2 billion should be approved if the Federal Trade Commission applies the same standards that enabled Texaco Inc. to purchase the Getty Oil Company, the chairman of Standard of California said today.

title: WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: COAST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $3.2 million from the sale of real property. c-Including a gain of $18.3 million from the sale of loans acquired in the merger with Century Federal Savings & Loan Assn. on July 1, 1982.

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West German Town Bans SS Reunion
description: The town manager prohibited a group of Nazi SS veterans today from holding a reunion in May in a local auditorium, citing security problems and bad publicity.

title: ABC'S 'TWO MARRIAGES' NOW A WEEKLY SERIES
description: AFTER a limited run a few months ago, ''Two Marriages'' returns to ABC tonight at 8 o'clock as a regular weekly series. Set in a small mid- America town that is still rural around the edges, this is a ''nice'' soap opera for all those people and groups who might object to the steamier aspects of the network's ''Dynasty'' or ''Hotel.'' Overflowing with middle-class values and morality lessons, ''Two Marriages'' is an updated version of ''Father Knows Best,'' mixed with several generous dashes of ''The Waltons.'' If nothing else, mother is now getting a bigger piece of the family action.

title: DAXOR CORPORATION reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Big East Conference tournament, quarterfinals, at Madison Square Garden: Syracuse vs. Connecticut, 1 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 1 P.M.); Villanova vs. Pittsburgh, 3 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 3 P.M.); Georgetown vs. Providence or Seton Hall, 7 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M.); Boston College vs. St. John's, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 9 P.M. Radio - WGBB, 1240; WNYE-FM, 91.5; WRTN-FM, 93.5; all at 9 P.M.)

title: LED EUROPEAN ATOMIC CENTER
description: Sir John Bertram Adams, a particle physicist and former executive director general of the European Organization for Nuclear Research, died Saturday in Geneva. He was 63 years old and had lung surgery last November.

title: CONTEST IS NOW ONE OF PERSONALITY AND MESSAGE
description: Somewhere in the sprawling Washington headquarters of Walter F. Mondale, the delegate counters are still at work. But no one pays much attention now to these dutiful accountants of the political world, because the contest between Gary Hart and Mr. Mondale hinges, for the moment at least, on the broader questions of personality and message.

title: INTER-CITY GAS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $4,417,000. c-After a tax credit of $1,203,000. The company said that a reassessment of its investment in Keeprite Inc. resulted in a writeoff of goodwill totaling $4,697,000. This charge together with the cost of closing a manufacturing plant, less tax loss carryforwards, resulted in total net charges of $4,417,000 in 1983.

title: Newsweek and Time's Computer Publications
description: An alert reader of this week's Advertising Age noted an ad for a Newsweek computer-oriented one-shot publication called Access and also a news article about a Time Inc. property bringing out a newsletter with the same orientation and same name. Was this another case of stepping on a competitor's toes?

title: Technology; Hurdles Facing An Electric Car
description: LONDON

title: TASS SAYS U.S. ACTS IN PERSIAN GULF IMPERIL PEACE
description: Tass, the Soviet press agency, said in a statement today that the Soviet Union did not recognize a restriction on air and sea traffic imposed by the United States in the Persian Gulf. It said the United States actions in the gulf were ''creating a grave threat to peace and international security'' and warned of ''possible dangerous consequences.''

title: COURSE ON REPAIRS OFFERED FOR WOMEN
description: Home heating, plumbing and electrical work are some of the topics to be covered in the Women Teaching Women course, which operates in connection with the New York City Technical College.

title: STRIKE CUTS NEW YORK FUR OUTPUT
description: The two-week-old strike in New York City's unionized fur industry, the largest in the country, has had scant effect so far because it is the industry's slowest time of the year, producers and retailers say.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: -it-yourselfers who put up a paper or vinyl wall covering select one that has no selvage - an unprinted border or edge that must be trimmed off. They also often choose a prepasted paper, which needs only to be moistened on the back or dipped in water before pasting up.

title: 16 STORIES ABOVE 5TH AVENUE, A VICTORIAN GLASSHOUSE
description: ONE can only guess what Queen Victoria would have said about it: ''We are not amused.'' Granted, the apartment is a tribute to her era. The owners are collectors of 19th-century wicker, and their rooms have all the earmarks of the period: abundance, comfort and plenty of froth.

title: WHAT INSTITUTIONS ARE SELLING
description: Since Individual Retirement Accounts were made available in 1982 to all Americans with earned income, financial institutions of all types have been aggressively seeking new and repeat business from I.R.A. investors with a wide variety of offerings: Banks and Savings and Loan Associations. Certificates of deposit for up to five years are widely offered, at fixed rates established when the account is opened or at variable rates tied to some external benchmark and that may change periodically until the certificate matures.

title: Light Slavery Sentences Being Appealed by U.S.
description: The Justice Department notifed a court today that it intended to appeal the lenient sentences given two Texans convicted of holding 12 Mexican workers in slavery.

title: BIOSPHERICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Interventions For Currency
description: The Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury bought $193.4 million of German marks in the foreign exchange markets in the three months ending Jan. 31, the New York Fed said yesterday at its regular quarterly briefing.

title: GLASS WORKS BY A SCULPTOR
description: BORN in Italy, Isabel Giampietro Knoll, below, came to the United States as a child, trained as a sculptor, returned to Europe in the 1950's and created works in glass as graceful as they are innovative.

title: 50,000 JOIN PROTEST IN MANILA
description: About 50,000 anti-Government protesters marched through the city's main thoroughfares today urging a boycott of the National Assembly elections of May 14 and the resignation of the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: DIET COKE CLAIM IGNITES DISPUTE OVER NO. 3 SPOT
description: The Coca-Cola Company opened the pre-summer soft-drink campaigns yesterday with the claim that Diet Coke had ousted 7-Up in the fourth quarter as the nation's No. 3-selling soft drink, behind Coke and Pepsi-Cola.

title: ;  The Trustee for J. David Is Not New to the Role
description: Louis Metzger, the foreman of the San Diego County grand jury that indicted C. Arnholt Smith following the collapse of the United States National Bank, has been appointed trustee of J. David & Company, the high-flying San Diego international currency trading firm shut down by a bankruptcy court last month.

title: HOW MONDALE FALTERED
description: As Walter F. Mondale moved across the South today for nearly a week of campaigning that may prove the most crucial to his troubled drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination, the question that shadows him and his staff is why, almost overnight, the Mondale ''juggernaut'' has suddenly slowed.

title: Erica Jong Suit Accuses Ex-Husband on Book
description: Erica Jong, the author, has sued her former husband for $4 million, charging that he interfered with the publication of her new book, ''Molly's Book of Divorce.''

title: Head of Mesa In Washington
description: T. Boone Pickens, chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, met today with Senator J. Bennett Johnston, the Louisiana Democrat who is drafting a bill to curtail oil-industry mergers.

title: STRONGEST EFFORT YET TO PUT ORGANIZED PRAYER IN SCHOOLS
description: The proposed constitutional amendments now being debated in the Senate are, depending on one's point of view, the most promising or most threatening of scores of efforts over the past 20 years to undo the Supreme Court rulings that put an end to organized prayer in America's public schools.

title: Walker's Pact Extended
description: Donald Trump, the owner of the Generals, will announce at a news conference at Giants Stadium today a three-year extension of Herschel Walker's contract. Under the extension, reported to be worth $5 million, Walker will remain with the team through the 1988 season, with his annual salary raised to $1.6 million.

title: BREAKFAST DEALS, ONCE OVER LIGHTLY
description: At first glance one recent morning, the territorial imperative of the Dorset Hotel dining room seemed to have been seriously violated. There, sitting at his customary table, was J. Richard Munro, president of Time Inc. But at the next table - potentially too close for comfort - sat Frederick S. Pierce, president of ABC.

title: STANDARDS FOR ALL THE WORKERS
description: For two weeks in January, a stream of witnesses came to the offices of the International Labor Organization here. They were testifying before a special commission of inquiry set up to investigate formal complaints about the conditions of labor in Poland after the suppression of Solidarity, the independent union.

title: FOR EMPLOYEES OF 'THE BRASS' IN BRISTOL, SHUTDOWN SIGNALS DEATH OF AN ERA
description: Walking past idle machinery in the Bristol Brass Company's silent and chilly mill here today, Philip K. Ludwig, the company treasurer, said, ''It's been a tough few years for Bristol.''

title: Court Backs RKO On WOR License
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals here has ruled that RKO General Inc. should be allowed to retain its five-year license for WOR-TV, Channel 9, in New Jersey.

title: Lindner Raises Stake in Fisher
description: Fisher Foods Inc. said the American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl H. Lindner, had reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission an agreement to buy an additional 17 percent of Fisher's shares.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: VISAGES There are all sorts of faces peering at you off the wall these days in the three exhibitions at the International Center of Photography, 1136 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street (860-1783). Students of character, if not of photography, may exercise their judgment in faces of models, of field workers, of politicians, of proletarians.

title: ; ENTER THE KNOWLEDGE SUPERPOWER
description: To the Editor:

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
U.S. Accuses 36 InDrugSmuggling
description: Thirty-six people have been indicted in connection with an eight-year drug- smuggling operation that brought more than 72,000 pounds of marijuana into Connecticut, United States Attorney Alan H. Nevas announced today.

title: OFFICER, ON STAND, GIVES ACCOUNT OF KILLING IN MIAMI GAME ARCADE
description: A Miami police officer, defending himself on charges of manslaughter, testified in a state court here today that he ''deliberately'' shot a suspect he was attempting to take into custody when it appeared the victim was going for his own gun.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: 3 Acquitted on the Coast In Union Fraud Case

title: TV LOCAL NEWS RATINGS FALL
description: The three network-owned stations in New York have lost a significant share of the audience for their early- evening newscasts during the last year, according to figures released by the A. C. Nielsen ratings service.

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEWHALL RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company began operations on March 10, 1983. Latest results are for the periods from March 10, 1983, through Dec. 31, 1983.

title: FIGHTING ERUPTS IN CENTRAL BEIRUT
description: Christians and Moslems clashed in central Beirut today and there were artillery duels in the mountains as a Saudi mediator met with Lebanese officials to try to forge a new cease-fire.

title: Democratic Advertising To Focus on Senate
description: Democrats for the 80's, a political action committee, today announced plans for a series of television and radio commercials, the first of which tells the voter there is ''no real income tax cut for you.''

title: HERS
description: I HAVE an English springer spaniel named

title: Ethiopia Expels 2 As Spies for Moscow
description: The Marxist Government of Ethiopia has expelled two Soviet diplomats on espionage charges less than a month after breaking up what it said was a United States spy ring and expelling four Americans, Western diplomatic sources said today.

title: Coach of Oilers To Face Charge
description: Glen Sather, the Edmonton Oilers' coach and general manager, has been charged with assaulting a 70-year-old spectator during a game, a Vancouver prosecutor said today.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE PRSUING EFFORTS TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: Both the House and the Senate moved ahead today with their own proposals for reducing Federal budget deficits despite the stalled bipartisan talks between Congress and the Reagan Administration.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article about the Islanders in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday misidentified Pat LaFontaine. He played for the United States Olympic hockey team.

title: Quanex Measures
description: The Quanex Corporation said it had asked its shareholders to approve anti-takeover measures at the company's annual meeting on April 18.

title: Hartford Shift Seen For Indoor Cosmos
description: The Cosmos' indoor venture will most likely move to the Hartford Civic Center next season because of poor attendance and the high cost of playing in major arenas in the New York area, Rafael de la Sierra, the team's president, said today.

title: I.R.A.'S: SELLING BLITZ BEGINS
description: Citibank is keeping many of its branches open past normal banking hours. The New York Life Insurance Company is running special investment seminars. And, of course, there is the ferocious advertising blitz by banks, brokerages, insurance companies and others.

title: WINNER IN SCIENCE IS 'MULTIFACETED'
description: In a laboratory there often comes a period when nothing is going on and the students decide to take it easy. But 17- year-old Christopher R. Montanaro of South Paris is not one to take it easy.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sinatra Oil on the Block

title: HART, ONCE WEAK IN FLORIDA, IS NOW SEEN AS ONE OF TOP CHALLENGERS
description: Three weeks ago, Senator Gary Hart's Florida campaign consisted of a half-dozen volunteers who had neither an office nor a telephone. ''Until then, we didn't see much future in Florida,'' said Mike Abrams, a Miami legislator who is the campaign's state chairman.

title: White House Explains Reagan Church Habits
description: President Reagan's spokesman said today that the President seldom attended church services because he disliked inconveniencing parishioners. He also said that Mr. Reagan did not intend to make morality a campaign issue.

title: YANKS BEAT BRAVES, 1-0
description: -The Yankees beat the Atlanta Braves today, 1-0, on singles in the eighth inning by Stan Javier, Matt Winters and Don Baylor. In gaining the shutout, Ray Fontenot, Curt Brown and Clay Christiansen permitted nine hits.

title: VODAVI TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There are no year-ago results because the company began operations on Jan. 31, 1983. Results for the latest period are for the 11 months ended Dec. 31, 1983.

title: 4 in Brink's Case Indicted in Jersey
description: Four of those accused in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery in New York have been indicted in New Jersey on robbery charges in an armored-car holdup in 1978 at the Livingston Mall.

title: METS LOSE TO PIRATES IN JOHNSON'S DEBUT
description: The Mets opened their 25-game exhibition season today with a salute from Chuck Tanner, the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, who said, ''They've improved themselves more than anybody.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: TRANS-LUX CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TESTIMONY CONFLICTS AT A HEARING ON INMATE'S PAROLE FROM FISHKILL
description: A State Senate committee heard conflicting testimony today on whether two members of a parole board had seen a letter by a prisoner who, after his parole, killed himself after a shootout with the police in Elmira.

title: Policeman Given 7-Year Term In Slaying of Security Officer
description: A 17- year veteran of the Newark police force was sentenced today to seven years in prison in the shooting death of a hospital security officer during a barroom argument over their authority as peace officers.

title: BOND PRICES TUMBLE ON RATE FEARS
description: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday and long-term yields rose to their highest levels since September 1982 following a new warning by the Federal Reserve chairman, Paul A. Volcker, that pressure was mounting to raise interest rates.

title: FUGITIVE IS SLAIN IN CAROLINA TOWN
description: A fugitive from a Tennessee prison who had said he would not be taken alive died in a gun battle with sheriff's deputies today and his partner was captured.

title: WHAT THE MENTALLY ILL HOMELESS DON'T NEED
description: To the Editor:

title: COOPERBIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
C.D. Rates Rise Again
description: Interest rates on six-month certificates of deposit continued to rise nationwide in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: O'Neill Depicts Hart As Clear Front-Runner
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that Senator Gary Hart was clearly the leader for the Democratic Presidential nomination and that Walter F. Mondale would be able to overtake him only if he could ''change his image.''

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE Closing the Drug Supermarket
description: ''This place is like a hell. The cops have made it that way. They used to give a foot. Now they don't give an inch.''

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KEANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Korean Shipyard Lag
description: South Korea's heavily export-oriented shipbuilding industry failed to receive any foreign ship orders in February, clouding the outlook for the industry, the Korea Shipbuilders Association said today.

title: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 25
description: The year-earlier share earnings have been restated to reflect the 3-for- 2 stock split of the company's common stock effective Sept. 23, 1983.

title: Changes at Platt Music
description: The Platt Music Corporation, a private company that leases space in department stores and sells consumer electronic products, announced yesterday that it had named Michael Glazer chairman and chief executive and Thomas P. Bagan, 40 years old, president and chief operating officer. Mr. Glazer, who is 35, has been with the company since 1972. He succeeds Herman Platt, 74, son of the founder, who becomes chairman of the executive committee. Mr. Bagan comes from Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago retail chain, where he was president and chief operating officer.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: WHEN Carmen Lundy moves around the small stage in the Greene Street Cafe, singing with skillfully calculated rhythmic emphasis and a warm vocal quality, she has the unmistakable aura of the seasoned jazz singer.

title: TOP ECONOMIC ADVISER FINDS GROWTH AT 6%, EXCEEDING FORECASTS
description: The chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers today predicted an annual growth rate for the national economy this winter that is considerably higher than what the Administration and most private economists were expecting just a month ago.

title: POP: LOVE SONGS BY ENRICO MACIAS
description: ENRICO MACIAS, one of pop's most cosmopolitan singers, is performing through March 18 at the Nederlander Theater. In the concert, he sings in Hebrew, Greek, Spanish, English and Armenian, along with his primary language, French.

title: LINCOLN INCOME LIFE INSURNCE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $109,658 and investment gains of $660,205. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $175,685 and investment losses of $257,490. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $236,842 and investment gains of $655,821. e-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $929,696 and investment losses of $117,351.

title: No Headline
description: In one of the boldest moves a manager of the Yankees ever made, Bill Virdon ended Bobby Murcer's career as a center fielder in 1974, shifting him to right field and replacing him in center with Elliott Maddox. Ten years and two managing jobs later, Virdon has made a similarly bold move with the Montreal Expos.

title: SUPPLEMENTAL PAY INVOLVED IN ALVARADO INQUIRY IS WIDELY USED IN SCHOOLS
description: Supplemental pay for school employees doing extra work after regular hours - a benefit that has come under scrutiny in the case of Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado - is an official and widely used practice throughout the New York City school system.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: A STROLL AROUND CITY'S BEST LOBBIES
description: LOBBIES may be functional areas that collect and organize people for their ascent into a building, but in Manhattan they are also among the great artifacts of the city. Architects and builders, to create a good first impression, have often concentrated their attention and budgets on them: the well-conceived, well- executed lobby can be a synopsis of both a building and a period of architectural history. If New York is a living architectural museum, lobbies form a distinct type of exhibit within it.

title: MYERS, L E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: BEIRUT VIOLENCE DEBATE CANCELED BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 8 (Reuters) - As rocket-propelled grenades exploded overhead, a special meeting of the Lebanese Parliament called to consider an inquiry into the latest upsurge of violence was postponed today for lack of a quorum.
description: Only about 30 deputies braved shelling and shooting in central Beirut to attend the meeting. The 99-seat Assembly requires a quorum of 46, so the Speaker, Kamel al Assad, postponed the session.

title: N.H.L. Rebuffed On Trust Inquiry
description: The Supreme Court of Canada ruled today that the National Hockey League must hand over financial documents to national antitrust officials investigating the league's refusal to allow the sale of the St. Louis Blues to a group of Saskatoon investors.

title: HARD-ROCK: TOWNSHEND
description: IT doesn't seem to bother Simon

title: HEMOTEC INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Mayor Assembling A Videotape Library

title: MOVER INDICTED IN EXTORTION CASE
description: A moving-company owner was indicted yesterday on charges of holding truckloads of furniture and office equipment for ransom from Manhattan businesses.

title: ISRAEL CALLS JEWISH TERRORISTS ISOLATED
description: The chief of investigations for the Israeli national police said today that the Jews arrested this week for attacks on Arabs did not constitute a sophisticated underground terrorist movement, but were men ''on the verge of insanity'' driven by fantasies of what their actions would accomplish.

title: THEATER: 'AWAKE AND SING!' REVIVED
description: IN its new and generally inadequate revival at the Circle in the Square, Clifford Odets's ''Awake and Sing!'' is not the rousing experience it was for Group Theater audiences of almost 50 years ago. Yet the play's failings are not necessarily the ones you'd expect. Whatever else is wrong with ''Awake and Sing!'' its theme remains contemporary. Odets was out to excoriate the pagan gods of materialism and success in American life. When his play's principal proselytizer for those empty values, Bessie Berger, champions the golden rule that ''money talks,'' we could also be hearing Willy Loman or even the daydreaming hustlers of ''American Buffalo.''

title: Debt Issues
description: * Chrysler Financial Corp., a Troy, Mich., financing subsidiary of Chrysler Corporation, had its public offering of $200 million 13 1/2 percent notes due March 15, 1991, priced by Salomon Brothers at 98.60 percent, plus accrued interest, to yield 13.82 percent. The notes are redeemable after March 14, 1989, at the option of the company at 100 percent.

title: FREED NAMIBIAN GIVEN LIMITED TRAVEL RIGHTS
description: -West Africa, March 8 - South African authorities approved travel documents today for Herman Toivo ya Toivo, a leading black nationalist in South-West Africa who was released last week after 16 years of detention.

title: 'Heartland' Music
description: At the Kitchen (925-3615), 59 Wooster Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M., a program called ''Music From the Heartland'' will feature a clarinet quartet led by Douglas Ewart, along with music by the drummer Steve McCall and the woodwind player and saxophonist Edward Wilkerson. Tickets are $5, or a Theater Development Fund voucher and 50 cents.

title: SENATE UNIT BARS NEW FUNDS TO AID NICARAGUA REBELS
description: A key Senate committee today rejected a proposal by President Reagan that would have nearly doubled aid this year to the Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: Starvation in Zimbabwe Charged by Ex-Leader
description: Former Prime Minister Ian D. Smith said today that Government operations against rebels in southwestern Zimbabwe were causing starvation and driving civilians into neighboring Botswana.

title: Public Workers' Strike Disrupts France
description: A one-day strike by public employees to protest Government efforts to hold the line on salaries disrupted many services across France today.

title: A TOWN IN CONNECTICUT HAS A STAKE IN MIDWEST
description: For three generations, this tiny rural town in the northeastern corner of the state has helped meet its school budget by renting a parcel of land that it owns 1,300 miles away.

title: FARMERS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of property of $868,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and the year. c-Includes gains on the sale of property of $1,411,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,036,000, or 9 cents a share, for the year.

title: THE EVENING HOUR
description: OPINIONS may vary about whether the Guggenheim Museum is a good place to display art, but there was general agreement Wednesday night that it's a great place to have a party. When the floor of the rotunda is filled with round tables covered in gray cloths, black china and miniature orchids, the view is equally pretty whether you're at eye level or looking down from a bar set up at the top of the spiral ramp.

title: TRICO PRODUCTS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sign Language Gives Clear Signal Amid the Din
description: It's a weird sight, grown men and

title: ILLUSORY BENEFITS OF A FIXED SENTENCING SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Legal Services Corp. Barred From Closing Four Centers
description: A Federal District Court has blocked the Legal Services Corporation from cutting off funds for this year for regional training centers in Massachusetts, Arkansas, Indiana and Colorado and forcing them to close.

title: LUXURY-CAR LOBBY WINS A REVERSAL
description: Lobbyists for expensive automobiles won a victory in the Senate Finance Committee today by turning around a 10- to-4 vote of last week that limited the depreciation deductions for cars used by businesses to $15,000.

title: FILM: 'MIKE'S MURDER,' WITH DEBRA WINGER
description: ''MIKE'S MURDER,'' written and directed by James Bridges (''Urban Cowboy,'' ''The China Syndrome''), has the form of melodrama, but it's really a moonily romantic elegy for Mike (Mark Keyloun), a good-looking, two-bit Hollywood hustler and amateur drug dealer.

title: Honda of America Plans Ohio Plant
description: Honda of America Manufacturing Inc. said it will build a $30 million plant in western Ohio to manufacture motorcycle engines.

title: Irish Reels and Jigs
description: Traditional Irish reels and jigs will be performed by the Buckley Family Dancers on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue.

title: PRYOR RECOMMITMENT
description: Aaron Pryor , the former World Boxing Association junior welterweight champion who retired last year, will hold a news conference today at which he will announce his return to boxing and a reconciliation with his manager, Buddy LaRosa .

title: SCREEN: 'SPLASH,' A MERMAID'S LOVE
description: THOUGH Ron Howard's comedies don't adhere to any familiar formulas - Mr. Howard's funny ''Night Shift'' was about a prostitution ring operating out of a morgue, and his even more disarming new ''Splash'' is about a mermaid in Manhattan - they have a comfortably old-fashioned flavor. ''Splash'' may feature a heroine with fins, but it's mostly a standard love story, albeit one with some delightful new twists. The boy (Tom Hanks) is a lonely bachelor with a single overriding wish: ''to meet a woman, fall in love, get married, have a kid and see him play a tooth in the school play.'' And the girl (Daryl Hannah) at first knows only one word of English: ''Bloomingdale's.''

title: THE WORTH OF A PAROLE OFFICER'S WEEK
description: To the Editor:

title: ODD RITES OF SPRING TAKE OVER SLOPES
description: Before the snow melts off the slopes and the trails of Eastern ski areas, there is a pre-spring wacky winter season. Highlighting this brief period are competitions that call for unusual skills on skis as well as unusual entry requirements.

title: Korean Steel Contract
description: The Davy McKee Company of Britain and the Korea Heavy Industries and Construction Company have signed a $70.7 million contract with South Korea's state-run Pohang Iron and Steel Company to supply blast furnace facilities for its second integrated steel mill. A Pohang spokesman said today that Davy McKee would supply facilities worth $50.7 million, while the South Korean company's portion was worth $20 million. Construction is to begin in 1985.

title: LIVING IN SILICON VALLEY: SUCCESS HAS ITS PRICE
description: A few weeks ago scouts from Warner Brothers were here roaming around the California electronics area looking for backdrops for a new prime-time television soap opera called ''Midas Valley.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They were not Poles who came at us innocents with riot sticks, shields, helmets, guns and gas.

title: OPERA RETURNS AFTER 66 YEARS
description: Tonight and for seven more performances over the next four weeks, Metropolitan Opera audiences will have a chance to solve for themselves the mystery of Riccardo Zandonai's ''Francesca da Rimini.'' When it was new 70 years ago, ''Francesca'' was seen as a first major thrust by the man who was to lead Italian opera through the first half of the 20th century. Indeed, Ricordi, the powerful Milanese music publisher, saw Zandonai as Puccini's natural successor.

title: Tennessee Bank Charges
description: An accountant and his former secretary were indicted today by a Federal grand jury investigating the failure of nine Tennessee banks linked to Jake Butcher and his brother, C. .H. Butcher Jr.

title: Hart Gets Biggest Share Of U.S. Matching Fund
description: The Federal Election Commission mailed out matching fund payments today to eight Democratic Presidential candidates or former candidates. Senator Gary Hart of Colorado received the largest amount for the latest two-week period.

title: Stocks Up Slightly In Slower Trading
description: Stock prices made a modest advance yesterday in slower trading after declining in the preceding three sessions.

title: Advertising; Four-A's Focuses on The World
description: When 879 people interested in advertising find their way to this luxurious but hard-to-get-to oasis for a three-day meeting, it must mean that business is good and the winter is bad.

title: HINES, EDWARD, LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $271,000 for the quarter and $1.5 million for the year and income of $5.5 million for the year from a reduction of the estimated loss on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss d-Including a tax benefit of $581,000, a loss of $7,874,000 from discontinued operations, and an estimated loss of $19,863,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Leaseway Notes
description: A $50 million issue of the Leaseway Transportation Corporation's 12 1/2 percent collateralized trust notes are offered at 99 7/8 to yield 12.534 percent through underwriteres led by Salomon Brothers. The notes are rated A-3 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: AMERIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $2,853,000 for the quarter and $9,495,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,432,000. d-Net income after net from discontinued operations of $35,345,000. The results for all periods include the operations of its finance units which were sold to Fuji Bank Ltd. in January and the results of the American National Corp., which Amerifin has agreed to sell to the First Chicago Corp. These subsidiaries are classified as discontinued operations. Amerifin was formerly the Walter E. Heller International Corp.

title: MONEY DATA SPUR RATE RISES
description: Interest rates rose yesterday, with most of the increases coming late in the day after the Federal Reserve announced that the nation's basic money supply fell by $1.5 billion in the week ended Feb. 27.

title: MCI Unit Picks Wells, Rich, Greene
description: The MCI Digital Information Services Corporation, a subsidiary of the MCI Communications Corporation, has appointed Wells, Rich, Greene as its agency of record.

title: 25,000 YOUTH JOBS SUMMER GOAL
description: Business leaders and public officials called on employers yesterday to help provide 25,000 summer jobs for young people from poor families in New York City.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies of Business Day yesterday quoted President Reagan incorrectly on his view of the proposed merger of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation. According to a White House transcript, the President said, ''Since I know that this is a legal matter that's being decided I have tried to keep quiet on it, but I don't mind telling you that I do not believe that such a merger would reduce competition to the point that it would constitute monopoly at all.''

title: Sakharov Is Reported In Failing Health
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and rights activist, is in failing health, under constant surveillance and occasional harassment, and barred from receiving visitors in his exile in Gorky, a friend who visited him secretly said yesterday.

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a loss of $48,000 from discontinued operations. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect the sale of two units.

title: MARKET FACTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HART'S FANS CAN'T SAY WHY THEY ARE
description: The workers he greeted as they filed into the Hays International aircraft plant, the students he spoke to over breakfast at Birmingham-Southern College and the supporters who cheered him at a City Hall rally here this afternoon have at least one thing in common: they do not know much about Senator Gary Hart, who in an extraordinary week has become the leading contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: NEW BUILDINGS HEAD
description: Charles M. Smith Jr. distilled his own philosophy in a few simple words: ''This is, after all, a city of building. Building keeps this city alive. The dollars that go into building are multiplied many times over. It is a mainstay of this city.'' With that, he was off to City Hall, where Mayor Koch announced that he had named Mr. Smith to be the next Buildings Commissioner.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, some copies of the Late Edition yesterday omitted page D2 and carried page D27 twice. Readers wishing copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: MERCANTILE STORES CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

UP TO 7 INCHES ARE FORECAST
description: Between 1 and and 3 inches of snow fell in the metropolitan area by 1 o'clock this morning while between 4 to 7 inches was forecast for the metropolitan area with up to 8 inches predicted to fall over eastern Long Island, up to 6 inches in Connecticut and 4 inches in Albany and Buffalo, according to the National Weather Service.

title: New Violence Leaves 3 Dead in Punjab
description: Renewed violence in Punjab state left three people dead today, pushing the death toll to 91 since rioting between Hindus and Sikhs broke out Feb. 14, officials said.

title: TIMES SQUARE DEVELOPMENT PLAN: A LESSON IN POLITICS AND POWER
description: In 1948, a former bank teller named Trammell Crow made his first investment in real estate by building a modest-sized warehouse in Dallas. Today, at 69, he is believed to be the nation's largest owner of commercial property, with his affiliated companies valued at $7 billion.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Changes Possible For Faberge Account

title: 2 Boys Held in Try To Derail IND Train
description: Two teen-age boys were arrested yesterday and accused of trying to derail a Manhattan-bound IND train in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn by putting a piece of metal on the tracks.

title: Catching Lessons
description: If catchers are born, but not made, then Clint Hurdle is in trouble. At the age of 26, after nine seasons in which he played first base, third base and the outfield, the Mets are trying to convert him into a catcher. And Hurdle has the bruises to prove it.

title: EMPIRE-CROWN AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $17,718 for the quarter and $81,378 for the year and extraordinary gains of $17,966 for the quarter and $324,607 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $63,033 for the quarter and $109,747 for the year. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: RussellL.Wyckoff,68,Dies; Founded Jersey Newspaper
description: Russell L. Wyckoff - founder of The Suburban News, which is published twice a week in Westfield, N.J. - died of Alzheimer's disease Wednesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 68 years old and lived in Westfield, Normandy Beach, N.J., and Atlantis, Fla.

title: LOUISVILLE RALLIES
description: Milt Wagner scored 11 of his game-high 18 points in the second half to lead Louisville to a 62-55 victory over Cincinnati in the opening round of the Metro Conference tournament.

title: Public Service Indiana Rate Rise
description: The state's Public Service Commission approved a plan that gives Public Service Indiana a $37.9 million emergency rate increase, which should raise rates by about 5 percent.

title: Reagan to Meet With Pope
description: President Reagan tentatively plans to meet with Pope John Paul II in Fairbanks, Alaska, on May 2 when the two leaders cross paths on trips to or from the Far East, Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said today.

title: ERICSSON, L M, TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ISRAELI ARMY CHOIR VISITS
description: For the Israel Army Rabbinical Choir, this weekend's engagement at the Beacon Theater represents an unusual set of working conditions. The audience won't be in uniform; rockets and gunfire won't be a counterpoint to the music. The choir's job - which, according to its music director, Capt. Moshe Rosenblum, is ''making people happy'' - should be easier than on its usual circuit, which covers Israeli army bases.

title: BRITAIN PROTESTS IRAQI MISSILE ATTACK ON CARGO SHIP
description: The British Government protested to Iraq today over a missile attack that damaged a British cargo ship in the Persian Gulf last week.

title: ADVANCE ON A ADVANCE IN FIGHTING DEAFNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: MCLEAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,973,000. c-Net income.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON PLAN TO SPUR MORE WHEAT FARMERS TO CUT CROPS
description: The Reagan Administration today abandoned its opposition to paying wheat farmers to reduce their 1984 plantings and agreed to support a last-minute amendment by the Senate Agriculture Committee to entice more wheat growers to participate in the program.

title: Sunshine Seeks Ranchers Corp.
description: The Sunshine Mining Company said today that it had offered to acquire the Ranchers Exploration and Development Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at about $221.6 million. Sunshine said Ranchers had not yet responded to its offer.

title: Home Loan Rates Down
description: Interest rates on home loans offered by lenders declined in February for the sixth consecutive month, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: ART: MET HONORS CHASE, AN AMERICAN LEGEND
description: VISITORS to the retrospective exhibition of William Merritt Chase (1849-1916) at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are likely to come away with his late self-portrait uppermost in their minds. He made himself look exactly what he was - a well-liked, well-fed and well-dressed old gentleman, who was on top of his profession and on top of himself.

title: Heinz Profit Rises by 9.5%
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that its profit for the third quarter ending Jan. 25 rose 9.5 percent, to $50.7 million, from $46.3 million a year earlier.

title: APPLE COMPUTER LOSES SALES-MARKETING AIDE
description: E. Floyd Kvamme, 46, one of the most senior executives in California's Silicon Valley, has resigned from Apple Computer Inc.

title:
A MEETING OF MINDS ON MIDDLE EAST PEACE;
AN ARAB: TALK WITH PALESTINIANS
description: It is singularly appropriate for Palestinians and Israelis to talk directly to one another. Unless these two peoples can themselves move toward conciliation, no third party can significantly contribute to a negotiated settlement of their conflict.

title: STAGE: ACTING COMPANY'S 'PIECES OF 8'
description: FOR a brief, seasonal New York engagement at the Public Theater, The Acting Company is presenting ''Pieces of 8,'' a collage of one-act plays, conceived and directed by Alan Schneider. The evening is intended as a sampler of works by contemporary authors and of the acting talent of this nomadic, national company. In both respects, this is a distinctly minor representation. Playwrights are slighted and promising actors are not given adequate opportunity for self- expression. Each sketch is additionally diminished by being introduced by a few lines of doggerel.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
description: The latest quarter and 6 months' nets include a gain on the sale of a carpet yarn facility of 30 cents a share. All share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective for shareholders of record March 1, 1984.

description: -SHOD

title: OUR MOST PRUDENT POLICY LIES IN THE OPERATION OF SHOREHAM
description: To the Editor:

title: TURNPIKE TOLL STIRS RIVALRIES IN CONNECTICUT
description: An old debate over whether to abolish the tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike flared anew today with arguments that pointed up the state's regional differences.

title: No Headline
description: 32 Buses With Cracks Found in Washington

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ART: CLASSICAL DRAWINGS BY FRENCH ARCHITECTS
description: ''PARIS-ROME-ATHENS'' can be approached as travelogue, architectural history, art history and as an argument for and against academic art education. At the I.B.M. Gallery of Science and Art, Madison Avenue and 56th Street, through March 24, the exhibition is a 19th-century journey to sanctuaries and temples in Athens, Delos, Delphi, Eleusis, Olympia and Paestum. We see Henri Labrouste years before he designed the celebrated Biblioth eque Ste.-Genevi eve and Charles Garnier before his Paris Opera. With the help of the voluminous and scholarly catalogue, the exhibition also lays out many of the issues - particularly the issue of color - that were of such concern to 19th- and early-20th-century French architects.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER KEY LIBEL RULING, DEBATE GOES ON
description: A landmark Supreme Court decision that strengthened press protections in libel cases is being eroded by new court decisions and growing public antagonism toward news organizations, press lawyers said yesterday at a conference marking the 20th anniversary of the ruling.

title: IRAN KEEPS ARMY ON HOLD, U.S. SAYS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Iran appeared to be trying to wear down Iraq with costly attacks by untrained units to set the stage for a possibly decisive thrust by regular forces.

title: 13 Philadelphia Officers Indicted by Grand Jury
description: A Federal grand jury indicted 13 Philadelphia policemen today on charges of racketeering, extortion and conspiracy in connection with what prosecutors said was the collection of $300,000 to protect video poker machines used for gambling.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ARTS WITHOUT MYSTERY. By Denis Donoghue. 151 pages. Little, Brown. $15.95.

title: EMBRACING VOLATILE CHURCH-STATE ISSUES
description: The Supreme Court, fresh from upholding the display of a municipalNativity scene, may soon add even more fuel to the volatile mixture of religion and politics.

description: b-Net loss.

Big East Conference tournament, semifinals, at Madison Square Garden, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M. (Television - First game, MSG Cable, 7 P.M.; second game, Channel 9, 9 P.M.)

title: Nicaragua Reports Freighter Damaged by Mine Is Sinking
description: A Panamanian freighter that ran into a mine last night was taking on water fast today and appeared to be in danger of sinking, Government officials said.

description: Peter Rodman, a longtime

title: Kentucky Wins, 92-79 =
description: Melvin Turpin tied a tournament record, scoring 42 points as Kentucky took an early 19-point lead and coasted to a 92-79 triumph over Georgia in the quarterfinals of the Southeastern Conference tournament.
