description: b-Includes equity in income of insurance operations of $2.1 million for the quarter and $5.1 million for the year. c-Includes equity in income of insurance operations of $1.7 million for the quarter and $4.9 million for the year.

title: Economic Scene; The Anxious Bond Market
description: PAUL A. VOLCKER, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, alarmed the financial markets this week by saying that the economy looks ''very strong in a number of directions.'' With economic growth so powerful, he said, private credit demands are rising and the big budget deficits are putting pressure on interest rates ''in only one direction.''

title: AN ELLIS COLLECTION TAKES PAST AS PROLOGUE
description: What is it that makes one designer's work stand out, so that he achieves the cachet of a fashion leader and his opinions are treasured even in fields that are reasonably remote from fashion?

title: Midland Bank Profits Off
description: Large losses at its 57 percent owned subsidiary, the Crocker National Corporation in California, reduced profits at the Midland Bank P.L.C. last year by 21 percent, to $169 million, at current exchange rates, from $215 million in 1982.

title: RETURN OF CRUCIFIXES IS DEMANDED
description: Some 3,000 young people, many with tears streaming down their faces, attended a morning-long mass here today in protest against the removal of crucifixes from their classrooms.

title: COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WALKER RE-SIGNS FORMILLIONS
description: Donald Trump, the owner of the Generals, announced today that he had signed Herschel Walker to a new four-year contract that will keep the star running back with the team through the 1989 season.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Capital Holding Corp. , a stockholder-owned life insurance organization based in Louisville, Ky., said it had agreed in principle to acquire Parker Pen Co.'s 80 percent interest in First Deposit Corp., a San Francisco-based financial institution, for about $10 million.

title: Stagger Along With Shoreham
description: The long-expected is now official: Reeling from its disastrous investment in the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the Long Island Lighting Company will cut its work force by one-fifth and stop paying dividends on its common stock.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS STAKE HELD
description: The Financial Corporation of America, a West Coast financial services company that owns America's largest thrift institution, confirmed yesterday that it now holds about 4.9 percent - or about 10 million shares - of the common stock outstanding of the American Express Company.

title: KLEER VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The results do not reflect the full year of operations of Nestle-Lemur Co. acquired in December.

title: POLS AND POLITICIANS PUT HART AHEAD IN THE MASSACHUSETTS PRIMARY
description: The momentum of Senator Gary Hart's recent triumphs has become so powerful that Walter F. Mondale's superior organization at this point seems unlikely to stop the Coloradan from winning the Massachusetts primary next Tuesday, according to politicians and public opinion polls here.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The results include operations of two companies acquired in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1984 and accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: F.C.C. WON'T BLOCK WARNER STOCK DEAL
description: The Federal Communications Commission ruled yesterday that it would not overturn the stock deal that made Chris-Craft Industries the largest stockholder in Warner Communications Inc., thus dealing a blow to Rupert Murdoch's bid for control of Warner.

title: Information Displays Stake
description: A group led by Leonard Levy, a private investor, said it and Mr. Levy now own 20.9 percent of Information Displays Inc. Mr. Levy said he personally owns 18.3 percent of the company, a Armonk, N.Y., maker of computer systems.

title: Illinois Triumphs To Tie for First
description: Bruce Douglas tossed in 15 points and George Montgomery got 14 as Illinois rolled past Minnesota 53-41 tonight to move back into a first-place tie with Purdue in the Big Ten basketball race.

title: Chinese Leader Visits Jordan
description: President Li Xiannian of China arrived here today for talks with King Hussein. Mr. Li, 75 years old, the first Chinese head of state to visit Jordan, said he hoped the trip would ''contribute to enhancing relations between China and other Arab countries.''

title: INDEPENDENCE HEALTH PLAN reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $454,000 for the latest year and $450,000 for the earlier year.

title: DAYTON HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After gains from discontinued operations of $299,000 for the quarter and $2,270,000 for the year. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $2,185,000 for the quarter and $8,348,000 for year. The company said that in the latest year its LIFO provision resulted in a charge against earnings of 13 cents a share versus 1 cent a share in the earlier year. The share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 22,1983

title: Nevada-Las Vegas Gai ns
description: Eric Booker scored 21 points and Richie Adams had 19 points as the University Nevada-Las Vegas rolled to a 70- 55 victory over San Jose State in the opening round of the Pacific Coast Athletic Association tournament.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose to their highest level since May 1983 in the period ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: MICHAEL JOEL SKLAR
description: Michael Joel Sklar, an actor, writer and fashion retailer, died of lymphoma Monday at New York University Medical Center.

title: Farm Workers in Texas Win Protection in Court
description: A judge has extended state workers' compensation protection to more than 200,000 farm and ranch workers, ruling it was unconstitutional to exclude them.

title: Koch-Weinberger Letters: A Postscript
description: After almost seven months of oral

title: Unstrangling Westway
description: For the second time, a United States Appeals Court finds reason to criticize District Judge Thomas Griesa's judgment on a Westway ruling. A year ago, while upholding his demand for a supplemental Environmental Impact Statement, the Appeals Court questioned his findings of ''bad faith'' on the part of Government officials favoring Westway.

title: SPLIT SCREEN CANDIDATE
description: While all eyes are on the Democratic donnybrook, little note is taken of a curious, split-screen re-election campaign at the White House.

title: Yonkers Gets Fiscal Warning
description: After meeting today with Yonkers officials, Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello gave the city until next Thursday to come up with what he called a ''comprehensive, credible plan to achieve fiscal balance.''

title: Payment by Vatican Seen
description: The Vatican has agreed to pay $250 million to the creditors of the failed Banco Ambrosiano by borrowing the money and distributing it in three installments, sources said today.

title: Olympic Aircraft Deal
description: Olympic Aviation, a domestic subsidiary of Greece's national airline, Olympic Airways, has ordered four West German-made Dornier 228-200 turboprop aircraft for use on domestic routes to the smaller Greek islands, a spokesman at the Ministry of Communications said today. The total purchase will amount to $9.4 million, including training for Olympic Aviation personnel, he said.

title: Diner's Journal
description: SEVERAL years ago, buffalomania stampeded across America. The once nearly extinct American bison was said to be making a comeback, thanks in part to ranchers who saw it as a potentially lucrative source of meat. Buffalo, and its much proclaimed hybrid, beefalo, were called the meat of the future - high in protein, intensely flavorful and, best of all, leaner and more healthful than beef or pork. The stampede slowed when home cooks and professional chefs failed to heed the message.

title: CONCERT: TORADZE, PIANIST, WITH PHILHARMONIC
description: IT is a cliche of concert life that

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 9, 1984 International
description: President Reagan was rebuffed by a key Senate committee, which rejected a request that would have nearly doubled United States aid this year to the Nicaraguan rebels. The Republican-controlled panel, the Senate Appropriations Committee, said it had been inadequately consulted about the issue. (Page A1, Column 6.) About 3,000 young Poles, many with tears streaming down their faces, attended a morning-long mass in protest against the removal of crucifixes from their classrooms. A protest that led Wednesday night to an official order indefinitely closing an agricultural college spread to three high schools in the rural village of Garwolin, 40 miles from Warsaw. (A1:3-4.)

title: The U.N. Today March 9, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Chevron in Sudan
description: Chevron, a unit of the Standard Oil Company of California, is to resume oil exploration in southern Sudan after more than a month's suspension because of rebel attacks, the official Sudan news agency said.

title: Accounts
description: Empire Group, packagers of the Empire State Municipal Exempt Trust, a fund of tax-free municipal bonds, to Isidore & Paulson.

title: NORTH-WEST TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BROADWAY
description: HAROLD PRINCE is becoming the Henry Kissinger of theatrical directors, shuttling from one big project to another. At the moment, Mr. Prince is in rehearsal with Arthur Kopit's new play, ''End of the World With Symposium to Follow.'' As soon as the company packs up and goes to Washington at the end of the month for its Broadway tryout - opening night in New York is May 6 - Mr. Prince will go into rehearsal with another Broadway-bound drama, ''Play Memory'' by Joanna Glass. ''Play Memory'' will open April 26 at the Longacre Theater.

title: THE DANCE: 'CLYTEMNESTRA' REVIVED
description: ''CLYTEMNESTRA,'' which the Martha Graham Dance Company revived superlatively Wednesday night at the State Theater, has acquired a reputation as a cult work. It would be more accurate to see it as epic theater.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doug Mitchell , a 48-year-old Calgary, Alberta, lawyer who in the 1960's had a brief career as a linebacker in the Canadian Football League, was named yesterday to succeed Jake Gaudaur as C.F.L. commissioner. . . . Pascual Perez , the Atlanta Braves' right-hander, had his contract renewed. Perez has been in jail in the Dominican Republic since January on drug charges.

title: PINCKEY LEADS VILLANOVA TO VICTORY
description: After being smothered by a Pittsburgh defense in the first half that held him to 4 points, Villanova's best player, the forward Ed Pinckney, scored 17 points in the second-half yesterday to lead the Wildcats to a 75- 65 victory over the Panthers in the second game of the Big East tournament quarterfinals.

title: HART'S RESULTS IN NEW ENGLAND TURN OUT WORKERS IN SEATTLE
description: Before Senator Gary Hart's upset victory in the New Hampshire primary, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale seemed assured of winning the Democratic party caucuses next Tuesday across Washington State.

title: Gourmet to TBWA
description: Gourmet magazine, a Conde Nast publication, has named TBWA Advertising as its agency of record. This is the first time in its 43-year history that the magazine has had an agency. The other two agencies competing for the account were Calet, Hirsch & Spector, and Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss.

title: Bridge: Bergen and Cohen Leading In Finals of Grand National
description: The last leg of a remarkable triple seemed in sight here tonight when Marty Bergen of White Plains and Larry Cohen of New York led into the final session of the Grand National Pair Championship.

title: EMC INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MCGRATH SPEAKS KINDLY OF MERGERS
description: J. Paul McGrath, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, today described as exaggerated the fears of people who assert that large corporate mergers consume capital and who therefore want to restrict them by law.

title: FERVANT DEBATE ON SCHOOL PRAYER
description: The debate raging in the Capitol over officially approved prayer in the public schools is starting to resemble a holy war.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOVERNOR'S CLAIMS ON MINORITY HIRINGS CRITICIZED
description: A Puerto Rican research and advocacy group and the Cuomo administration have clashed over the Governor's record on black and Hispanic appointments.

title: MISCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Standard Co., a diversified manufacturing and building products company, has elected to its board Louis Fernandez, chairman of the Monsanto Co., and James F. Lardner, vice president of Deere & Co.

title: RACE FOR SMALLER COMPUTERS
description: When the Tandy Corporation brought out the first truly popular ''lap computer'' a year ago, the $800 Radio Shack machine was quickly embraced by traveling salespeople, executives, journalists and others looking for a computer small enough to slip into a briefcase and powerful enough to communicate with the home office.

title: Brooklyn Congressman Says He'll Endorse Hart
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said today that he would endorse Senator Gary Hart for the Democratic nomination.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day yesterday listing the earnings of state-chartered savings banks in Westchester omitted one major bank. It was the Village Savings Bank of Port Chester, which had assets of $253.2 million and net operating income of $470,000 in the fourth quarter of 1983.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 9, 1984

title: Harvester Joins Renault in Venture
description: The International Harvester Company and Renault, France's state-owned auto group, announced a joint venture to manufacture tractor parts in Europe.

title: LAFONTAINE GETS 2 AS ISLANDERS ROMP
description: It will not always be this way for Pat LaFontaine, of course. The Islanders' remarkable Olympian rookie will face other teams besides the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Injured Shorter Will Try 10,000
description: In the 1970's, Frank Shorter was America's premier Olympic marathon runner, winning the event in the 1972 Games and finishing second in 1976. At the age of 36, he had hoped to try for another medal in the event this year at Los Angeles, but he said yesterday that a stress fracture of his right foot has caused him to abandon that attempt.

title: Three Executives Out In Shake-Up at Amway
description: The Amway Corporation, the big direct-sales company that pleaded guilty recently to charges of customs fraud in Canada, said yesterday that three senior executives had left and that more might follow.

title: More Close Calls
description: Five of the seven medal-play tournaments on the PGA Tour so far this year have been settled by a sudden- death playoff, and six have been decided by a margin of one stroke on the final hole. Never before has the tour started off with such a string of photo finishes.

title: AUCTIONS
description: palm-size vessels of glass, porcelain, amber, rock crystal, ivory, malachite, jade and turquoise, dating from the 17th century on - will be sold next Thursday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street. Among the 337 snuff bottles, are 213 from a European collector, who is identified in the catalogue by a pseudonym, Mei Ling. His collection covers the full range of these collectibles. The one expected to bring the highest price is a Chien Lung 18th-century portrait bottle in enameled glass from the workshops of the palace in Peking depicting a girl in a blue gown. If, as expected, it sells for as much as $60,000, it will eclipse the $55,000 record paid in New York in 1979 for another 18th-century enameled-glass bottle, from the imperial workshops.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS HONDURAS AIDED 2 REBEL ATTACKS
description: Nicaragua accused Honduras today of assisting anti-Government rebels in carrying out two attacks on this country this week.

title: ST. JOHN'S WINS OPENER IN BIG EAST TOURNAMENT
description: St. Johns's and Boston College finished their regular seasons with identical 17-10 records. And in the balanced Big East Conference, they were both 8-8. They also split their only two meetings by a total of 5 points. So, it was only fitting last night that in their most most critical game of the season, the final margin was just a free throw.

title: Illinois State Upset
description: Greg Brandon scored 19 points and pulled in 17 rebounds to lead Creighton to a 69-59 victory over Illinois State in a semifinal of the Missouri Valley Conference tournament.

title: Net at Philips Is Up Sharply
description: N.V. Philips, the Dutch electronics group, said today that earnings more than doubled in the fourth quarter and rose by 49 percent for the year. Net income in the three-month period soared to $96.9 million, or 51 cents a share, from $35 million, or 19 cents a share.

title: DANCE: 2 CENTURIES WITH PILAR RIOJA
description: THE dance in Spain has a rich and distinctive history. It is, to a large extent, a buried history. But ''Teoria y Juego del Duende'' (''Theory and Play of the Duende''), a program spanning two centuries of Spanish dance, performed by Pilar Rioja on Wednesday at the Repertorio Espanol's Gramercy Arts Theater, provided tantalizing glimpses of its traditions. It was also an evening of beautifully produced and nuanced theater.

title: People Express
description: People Express Airlines Inc., which last month agreed to lease three airplanes from a Boeing Company subsidiary, announced another two-year lease for an additional used 747-100 airplane. People Express said it also has the option to purchase the airplane, scheduled for delivery by the spring of 1985, for $16.5 million. People Express, which began low-cost service in 1981 and now flies to about 20 cities in the United States and to London, said it had not determined on which routes the aircraft would be used.

title: McDonnell Award
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation received a $615.1 million Air Force contract for 39 F-15 figher planes, the Defense Department said. It also said that the RCA Corporation had been given a $156 million Navy contract for weapons defense systems.

title: TOPICS Chilled
description: Walking the Dog

title: Nomination For S.E.C.
description: President Reagan will nominate Charles L. Marinaccio, the chief minority counsel on the Senate Banking Committee, to the Securities and Exchange Commission, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said today.

title: NEW START IN CLINTON HILL FOR DILAPIDATED ELEGANCE
description: The old Mohawk Hotel, once an elegant residential hotel but now a shabby reminder of the storied past of Brooklyn's Clinton Hill, will soon rejoin that neighborhood's stock of viable housing.

title: People
description: * Stephen A. Novick named an executive vice president of Grey Advertising.

title: INVENTION, DESIGN, ENGINEERNG ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PARADISE FRUIT CO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
The Pearl Fits In At Syracuse
description: Dwayne Washington returned home yesterday and promptly destroyed a slew of myths involving him. He tossed up no game- ending bombs from midcourt, he made no mad dashes the length of the court, he threw no passes between his legs or behind his back.

title: BUILDINGS WITH A HEAR OF GREEN
description: TROPICAL trees. Hanging vines. Cooling waterfalls. Are they far away? Not for New Yorkers who can wander through midtown and find them. They can walk through the ChemCourt greenhouse just north of Grand Central Terminal or sit under tropical trees at the Park Avenue Plaza. Such intimate contacts with tropical foliage can be found in the public areas of many of the city's commercial buildings. Although most of the buildings close for weekends, many lushly planted public spaces remain open to provide respite from the harsh edges of the city. Most have areas with tables and chairs; some have modest restaurants with lunch-brunch menus or small kiosks that sell coffee, tea and cakes. A few are sophisticated urban malls.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; M.B.I.A. Plans to Insure Debt-Service Reserves
description: The Municipal Bond Insurance Association announced plans yesterday to offer insurance on the debt-service reserve funds of municipalities.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The net for the year-ago 9 months includes a tax credit of $270,000.

title: CUNNINGHAM IN DANCE AND DRAWING
description: THERE was a time, in the beginning, when Merce Cunningham taught endless dance classes in Greenwich Village studios, saving the fees for that single concert of new works toward which he worked each year. Mr. Cunningham branched out in the mid-1950's when John Cage, the avant-gardist and composer, suggested they try for a few college bookings across the country, trundled to by company van.

title: U.S. Makes New Bid On Baby Doe Records
description: The Justice Department yesterday asked the entire United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York to consider Government requests to review the medical records of Baby Jane Doe.

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. The company is listed on the Philadelphia, Midwest and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FILIPINO DANCE IN BRONX

title: ART: SIGNS OF ROBERT COTTINGHAM
description: SOMETHING often commented on by European visitors is the plethora of reading matter to be found on American streets. By which they mean not just billboards but the whole agglomeration of signs proclaiming names, goods, services and traffic regulations. Urban renewal has swept a lot of it away, but that doesn't mean you have to go to Las Vegas to find towns that are the sums of their motel and diner heraldry or that New York City itself doesn't abound in emblems and notices, stacked vertically though they may be.

title: CALPROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings have been adjusted to give effect to a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December.

title: MONDALE STRUGGLES TO MAINTAIN UNIONISTS' SUPPORT IN ALABAMA
description: Walter F. Mondale, once expected to win solid union support in the Democratic Presidential primary in this strategically important Southern state, is now struggling to hold onto that backing.

title: Nationalistic Spirits
description: During the Prohibition year of 1932, the Government created something of a sensation when it allowed Olympic athletes from France and Italy to bring wine with them to the Summer Games in Los Angeles. Now, 52 years later, Prohibition is a distant memory, and wine flows like water in California.

title: HAWKER SIDDELEY CANADA LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special gain of $357,000. c-After a special charge of $1,512,000. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: NICKLAUS SHOOTS 67, TRAILS LEADERS BY ONE
description: Just playing tournament golf as an also-ran in the winter is not enough for Jack Nicklaus to prepare for the Masters in April. He wants to be in the chase a few times before the first major tournament of the year.

title: Merger Rumors Lift Enstar Stock
description: The Enstar Corporation's stock rose $1.125, to $16.50, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as rumors circulated that the company might be the object of a takeover bid.

title: TEAM HALTS SEARCH FOR CLIMBER
description: A Japanese team searching Mount McKinley for the body of the mountaineer Naomi Uemura has abandoned the search and is descending the mountain, a pilot said today.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''WHAT'S a preview for if you can't work on your film?'' asked James Bridges, whose February 1983 preview of ''Mike's Murder,'' in Larkspur Landing, Calif., gave him an opportunity to do more work than he had anticipated. In fact, that first public screening, according to Mr. Bridges, elicited audience reaction that was so ''disastrous'' that it induced him to change the film considerably. It also gave ''Mike's Murder,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center, Gemini and other theaters (reviewed on page C16), the reputation of a movie in trouble.

title: Price of Fame
description: Steve Young , the quarterback who was signed by the Los Angeles Express to a four-year contract that will pay him more than $40 million in the next 43 years, says he is having problems dealing with the spotlight.

title: NEW DINOSAUR THEORY BACKED
description: Five newly published geological studies indicate that several species of plants and animals became extinct at about the same time 65 million years ago, researchers say.

title: First Union in Bid For Florida Coast
description: The First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., said it had agreed to acquire Florida Coast Banks Inc. of Pompano Beach, Fla., for a minimum of $75 million whenever laws prohibiting interstate banking are changed.

title: Transactions
description: CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Julio Franco, shortstop, to a one-year contract. FOOTBALL

title: Swiss Consumer Prices
description: Consumer prices in Switzerland rose 2.9 percent in February from a year earlier and four-tenths of 1 percent from January, the Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today.

title: NEWFOUNDLAND IS DENIED HIBERNIA OILFIELD CONTROL
description: The Supreme Court of Canada today upheld federal domain over the offshore Hibernia oilfield, rejecting the Province of Newfoundland's claim that it owned all mineral rights to the huge discovery by virtue of its former status as an independent nation.

title: Defense Rests in Slaying By Policeman in Miami
description: The defense rested today in the manslaughter trial of a Miami police officer charged with the fatal shooting of a young black man in a video game room.

title: SCURRY LEADS L.I.U. OVER ST. FRANCIS
description: Carey Scurry scored 12 points, pulled down 20 rebounds and blocked 5 shots to lead top-seeded Long Island University to a 67-62 victory over St. Francis (N.Y.) tonight in the quarterfinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro tournament at the McCann Recreation Center.

title: EQUITABLE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The net in the latest quarter includes a gain of $6.1 million, or 52 cents a share, from a U.S. Supreme Court decision permitting a unit of the company to price certain volumes of its natural gas production in accordance with the Natural Gas Policy Act of 1978 rather than a lower cost of service basis.

title: MOTHER'S RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 24
description: b-Including a tax recovery of $259,000. c-Including a tax recovery of $192,000 and a gain of $94,000 on the sale of assets.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
METS BEATEN, 4-0
description: The Chicago White Sox won their fourth straight exhibition game when they defeated the Mets, 4-0, Thursday.

title: PENTAGIN BACKS ADVANCED DEFENSE DESPITE FLAWS
description: Pentagon officials said today that they could not be sure a costly research program would result in a high degree of protection against nuclear missiles for the American civilian population.

title: WHITEHALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Donahue' to Be Moved To New York in 1985
description: ''Donahue,'' the talk show whose host is Phil Donahue, will move to New York City next January after a decade of broadcasting from Chicago.

title: WITH LAUREL AND HARDY IN THE 20'S
description: IN the midst of another ''festival,'' which is a code word for

title: OPTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $494,000 for the quarter and $2,231,000 for the year.

title: Dining Out Guide: Down-Home Texas Cooking
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that appeared in The Times. Stars are followed by the date on which the reviews were published. Prices are current.

title: French Firing on Fishermen Called Unacceptable by Spain
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said today that the firing on two Spanish fishing vessels by a French patrol boat was ''unacceptable'' and a setback for relations between the countries.

title: THACKER WINNER OF 3 MATCHES
description: Tab Thacker of North Carolina State, the most imposing wrestler at the N.C.A.A. championships, got what he called ''a big scare'' in his second match today. When you're 447.5 pounds, even the scares are sizable.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Staving Off Bias In the Next City Election

title: Alvarados Owe Fines Of $2,100 on 2 Autos
description: Records at the Parking Violations Bureau show that Anthony J. Alvarado, the Schools Chancellor, and Ellen Kirshbaum, his wife, owe $2,100 in unpaid parking tickets and fines on two automobiles they own now or have owned in the past.

title: HODEL FINDS ENERGY UNHURT BY TAKEOVERS
description: Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today that recent merger activity involving large oil companies would not have any significant impact on the nation's energy security.

title: TECHNALYSIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Settlement for Death Is Set at $4.1 Million
description: A settlement of $4.1 million was announced yesterday in the case of a 31- year-old accountant who was killed in 1982 in a crane accident at a construction site on Madison Avenue near 53d Street.

title: ATHENS SAYS TURKS FIRED AT GREEK SHIP
description: Greece said today that one of its warships had been fired on by Turkish ships and that Athens had responded by placing its armed forces on alert.

title: FOUR MORE WHO MADE LOANS TO ALVARADO GOT EXTRA PAY
description: A draft audit by the New York City Comptroller has found that four more school employees who lent money to Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado received extra pay when Mr. Alvarado was a district superintendent.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect a 20 percent stock dividend distributed in April 1983 and a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in October 1983.

title: PRAYER ISSUE AND POLITICS
description: In the midst of his campaign of invoking God and selected church-state issues on the political circuit, President Reagan found time this week to quote the dissident writer H. L. Mencken: ''Puritanism is the haunting fear that someone somewhere may be happy.'' ''I'm sure you won't agree,'' the President told his audience of fundamentalist ministers, drawing some laughter while cautioning that the current campaign to enact evangelical notions into law must not be allowed to founder on charges of ''narrow-mindedness.''

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a net loss from discontinued operations of $79,000. The year-ago results reflect the retroactive effect that has been given to the discontinuance of operations of Bowne Information Systems Inc.

title: PAPERCRAFT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANGRY BOXERS MEETING FOR HOLME'S OLD TITLE
description: Boxing's crowning achievement in confusion will take place here Friday night when a third world heavyweight champion will be decided. But whether the crown is taken seriously, and whether it turns out to be worn by Greg Page, the slight favorite, or Tim Witherspoon, politics cannot obscure the fact that this is a matchup of perhaps the two most talented, if overweight, young and angry heavyweights in the world.

title: COAST KILLER GETS PAROLE OF 3 HOURS
description: Theodore Streleski, who murdered a professor at Stanford University in 1978 and has left open the possibility of killing again, was jailed after three hours on parole today for refusing to abide by terms of his release.

title: AMERICAN BELLY DANCERS UNDULATE IN MIDDLE EAST
description: The most benign invaders of the Middle East are armed with veils, fringes and beads.

title:
REAGAN SAID TO AGREE TO SEEK PACT ON BUDGET WITH G.O.P. SENATORS;
TALKS ON MILITARY CUTS AWAITED AS BIPARTISAN EFFORTS SEEM TO FADE
description: President Reagan agreed today to try to work out a package with Senate Republicans that would include some reductions in his request for military spending, according to an official close to the negotiations.

title: NEW QUESTIONS DELAY SENATE PANEL VOTE ON MEESE
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee decided today to postpone a vote on the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d to be Attorney General to give its members more time to study additional information he has supplied.

title: APPLIED DEVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $136,000 from discontinued operations.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 041115 -- No Title
description: Wall Street traders, big sellers of Gulf Corporation stock only 24 hours before, became big buyers yesterday.

title: AUTO IS CRUSHED IN BRONX CRASH KILLING 2 PEOPLE
description: Two people were killed yesterday when their car swerved across a wide, grassy strip on the New England Thruway in the Bronx, was rammed by another car and then was crushed by a tractor-trailer, the police said.

title: CANADIANS, YIELDING TO FUROR, CALL OFF HUNT FOR BABY SEALS
description: Canadian sealers, citing the effects of international protests, said today that the clubbing of baby harp seals had been put off indefinitely.

title: 'HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE' FROM BEST SELLER
description: ''THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE,'' Tony Richardson's screen adaptation of John Irving's best-selling novel, is relentlessly faithful to the source material, which is to comic literature, including the works of Kurt Vonnegut Jr. and Joseph Heller, what whoopee cushions are to wit.

title: Japanese Bank Deal in Chicago
description: The Chicago City Council has agreed to allow Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. to provide a letter of credit to guarantee a $259 million short-term borrowing plan.

title: Chattem Unit Sale
description: Chattem Inc. said it had tentatively agreed to sell the business and assets of its Petrochemicals Company to DeSoto Inc. for about $25 million plus the assumption of some liabilities. Chattem is based in Chattanooga, Tenn.; DeSoto in Des Plaines, Ill.

title: OPPONENTS GEAR UP
description: After a couple of hours of debate today on a constitutional amendment to permit organized school prayer, the Senate quit until Monday.

title: RAPE TRIAL IS MONITORED BY A WOMEN'S COALITION
description: As the trial of six men charged with raping a 22-year-old woman in a bar proceeds in nearby Fall River, Darlene Wheeler, a young mother of two, sits in the front row and laboriously jots down testimony.

title: SPECIALTY COMPOSITES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $34,100 for the quarter and $44,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: Temple Rolls, 78-54
description: Terence Stansbury hit for 21 points and led Temple on a 21-6 spurt early in the second half as the Owls rolled to a 78-54 victory over Massachusetts to move into the semifinals of the Atlantic 10 tournament.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $59,000 for the quarter and $77,000 for the year and a loss of $175,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $30,000 and a tax credit of $826,000. d-After a loss of $420,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Overtone Singing
description: The Harmonic Choir, founded in 1975 by David Hykes, has adapted a Mongolian type of overtone singing, in which each singer can produce two or more tones simultaneously.

title: ART: PHOTGRAPHERS WHO VENTURED TO TIBET
description: THE first Western woman to enter Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, was Alexandra David- Neel (1869-1969), a French citizen who disguised herself as a beggar for two months to infiltrate the Forbidden City. She was only an amateur photographer, but she took some remarkable pictures of this remote mountain country, then virtually closed to foreigners. And she was by no means alone. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, a handful of other stalwarts from the Western world - scientists, explorers, mountaineers, soul-searchers and even professional photographers - managed to slip into Tibet, lugging their cumbersome cameras.

title: TIMES V. SULLIVAN: OUTLINE OF THE CASE
description: On March 29, 1960, an advertisement in The New York Times headlined ''Heed Their Rising Voices'' asked for contributions to help the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil-rights leaders combat an officially sanctioned ''wave of terror.''

title: GERMANIA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (ALTON, ILL) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $180,000. c-Net loss.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: Colgate-Palmolive To Pick New Chief

title: Cecil McBee Jazz
description: The bassist Cecil McBee will lead a group including Chico Freeman on tenor saxophone tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall (247- 7459), 154 West 57th Street. Tickets are $8.50. A free lecture on the history of jazz by the clarinetist John Carter will precede the concert at 6:30 P.M.; reservations may be made by calling 593-6414.

title: NEW LEADER PLANS SHIFTS AT FABERGE
description: Faberge Inc., the cosmetics company acquired in January by the McGregor Corporation for $168.6 million, will sell its interest in a cancer detecting device, shed many of its cosmetics brands and get out of the movie business, said Daniel J. Manella, chairman of McGregor.

title: No Headline
description: Jane Seymour Kelley; Led League of Voters

title: Worker Safety Job Undone
description: Thorne Auchter has announced his resignation as director of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. To say that he did his job for three years would be misleading; undid the job is more like it.

title: Fullback Faces Surgery
description: Hammering into the line year after year has taken its toll on Mark van Eeghen . The New England Patriot fullback, a 10-year veteran of the National Football League, missed the last two games of the 1983 season with a herniated disk, and now he faces neck surgery to repair nerve damage caused by that constant pounding, according to club officials.

title: AN ISRAELI: TALK WITH PALESTINIANS
description: The struggle between Israelis and Palestinians cannot be resolved by military force. Neither side can win a clear victory, and neither will ever unilaterally dictate the conditions of a solution. National struggles such as this one must be resolved politically.

title: WINDFALL FOR MR. HART
description: Having awarded the Democratic Presidential nomination to Walter Mondale before anyone had voted, many in the press-poll-and-pundit complex are now awarding it to Gary Hart on the strength of unexpected results in four small and unrepresentative states - all likely to go Republican next November.

title: GALLUP'S SURVEY GIVES HART 9-POINT LEAD OVER REAGAN
description: Reports of a surge of support across the nation for Senator Gary Hart since his victories in New England Presidential primaries were bolstered today by a Gallup poll that showed him leading President Reagan in a national sample of voters.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ''I THOUGHT that was Bobby Short playing,'' one amused patron said, as she joined us for dinner at Diva, a small Upper East Side restaurant. ''Well, maybe not Bobby Short,'' said another guest, who already knew about the piano, ''but it's like cocktail music.''

title: GLENN CRITICIZES HART'S ARMS PLAN
description: Trying to make national defense a major issue in three Democratic Presidential primaries in the South, Senator John Glenn today criticized Senator Gary Hart's military proposals as ''dangerous.''

title: Jackson Presses Rivals On South's Voting Rules
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today challenged the other Democratic Presidential candidates to join him in a court suit aimed at doing away with runoff primaries in Mississippi.

title: 2 CONTRADICT MANILA ON AQUINO KILLING
description: Government statements that Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was slain on the airport runway last summer were contradicted today by two private security guards, who said they saw the opposition leader still on the airplane stairs when the first shot rang out.

title: DANCE: NEW WORK BY MERCE CUNNINGHAM
description: AS a choreographer, Merce Cunningham celebrates the possibilities of change. As a practical man of the theater, he can cope with the necessity for change, as was demonstrated when, because of a dancer's illness, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company altered Wednesday night's scheduled program at the City Center and offered repeat performances of ''Coast Zone,'' ''Pictures'' and the previously unreviewed ''Roadrunners.''

title: PUBLISHING: PROMISING OLDER WRITERS
description: PUBLISHERS are forever on the lookout for promising young writers, but writing is by no means exclusively a young man's or a young woman's game. In fact, a number of elderly men and women who had never before been widely published, or who had not been published in decades, have recently become published authors.

title: GEORGETOWN TOPS PROVIDENCE
description: Georgetown has so much depth and talent, it's often said, that the Hoyas could field two basketball teams and still win. The Hoyas certainly looked like two teams last night at Madison Square Garden as they revived after a lethargic first half and defeated Providence, 70-50, in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament.

title: PITTSBURGH FEARS THE LOSS OF GULF
description: Ever since Gulf moved into its 38-story granite skyscraper during the Great Depression, colored lights atop the landmark building have alerted area residents to upcoming weather prospects. This winter, the system has been flashing its ominous blue more than usual, a warning of foul weather ahead.

title: LORIMAR reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Christian Brothers Close Old Part of Winery
description: The Christian Brothers winery in a 102-year-old stone building known as Greystone, which draws 500,000 tourists a year, has been closed because of structural problems.

title: Aetna Unit to Sell 25% of Its Assets
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said its Geosource Inc. unit had agreed to sell about 25 percent of its assets to a group of investors, including certain members of its management, in a leveraged buyout transaction. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Addison's 31 Lift Syracuse
description: Syracuse put together a solid first half, stalled early in the second half, then finished strongly to defeat Connecticut, 73-58, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Big East Conference basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Father in Suicide Owed Back Taxes
description: The father of the Kienast quintuplets, William Kienast, who committed suicide last Saturday, owed the Internal Revenue Service $60,761 in back taxes, according to an I.R.S. official.

title: Bochte in Bloom
description: The way Bruce Bochte tells it, when he quit baseball at the end of the 1982 season after hitting .297 for the Seattle Mariners, he and his wife spent more than a year living on a small island in Puget Sound, where he supervised a garden for a group of nature lovers, meditated on the future of the planet and did not touch a bat or a ball. Now that the 33-year-old Bochte has returned to baseball as a first baseman for the Oakland A's, Steve Boros , the Oakland manager, has begun to doubt the story.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Gertrude Hildreth, A C P

title: U.S.MAINSTREAM FOR A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: Driver Is Killed In Holland Tunnel
description: A New Jersey driver who tried to switch lanes in the Holland Tunnel was killed and a cabdriver was injured in a head-on collision early yesterday, officials said.

title: Market Place; Lilco's Troubled Outlook
description: FOR Wall Street, the troubles of

title: Ex-Sheriff Gets 10 Years
description: Former Sheriff Harold White of Marion County, who was elected on a pledge to clean up drug trafficking, was sentenced today to 10 years in prison for lying to a grand jury and taking money from a drug dealer. Rey Orta, a drug dealer granted immunity for cooperating, testified that he paid Mr. White about $1,000 a month for about 18 months, in return for which the sheriff would tell him when the authorities were investigating his dealings. Federal District Judge James H. Meredith sentenced Mr. White to five years for conspiracy and five years for lying to the jury.

title: SERVISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the year-ago fourth quarter reflect a nonrecurring rehabilitation credit equal to 8 cents a share for an acquired property in Long Beach, Calif.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Mayor of 52d Street

title: PRESSURE AND COMPROMISE SAVED TIMES SQUARE PROJECT
description: Within days after the Times Square redevelopment plan collapsed last August, pressure began to build on Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch to put it back together again.

title: MILLER, H, & SONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
PATH to Repair A Drawbridge
description: Rehabilitation will begin next month on a malfunctioning drawbridge in Jersey City that has caused numerous delays in PATH train service.

title: Official Arrested In Sexual Assault
description: The chief public official of this community was arrested today on charges of first-degree kidnapping and third-degree sexual assault.

title: Winners and Winners at the Table
description: Last baseball season Tony Pena, the first-string catcher for the Pittsburgh Pirates, earned $365,000. After starting far apart in bargaining over the winter, the Pirates and Pena finally signed a four-year contract with an average annual salary of $887,500, plus possible bonuses of $285,000.

title: COMPANY NEWS ; Ranchers Agrees To a Bid by Hecla
description: The Ranchers Exploration and Development Corporation agreed today to be acquired by the Hecla Mining Company in an exchange of stock valued at about $194 million. The combination would form the nation's largest silver mining company.

title: CITICORP SHAKES UP CHICAGO
description: The executives sent here six weeks ago by Citicorp to merge the $4 billion First Federal Savings and Loan Association into the bank holding company have barely unpacked, but already there are signs of the changes they promise to bring to banking here.

title: Bureau Permitted To Retire Disabled
description: Public employers can force disabled employees to retire, because keeping them on the payroll is against the public's interest, a state appeals court ruled today.

title: FOR THE SECOND STAGE, ITS FIRST NEW THEATER
description: In 1976 ''Serenading Louie,'' a play Lanford Wilson had written in 1969, was first produced in New York. ''It was received rather indifferently,'' says the playwright. ''It was not published, and afterward, I found that many, many people had never even heard of it. Plays can just drop down a black hole after they've been done.''

title: RANGERS WIN AND END SLUMP
description: The Rangers said all along that James Patrick would bring them good things. And tonight, playing in only his second National Hockey League game, the 20-year-old defenseman proved those words true.

title: Conference Tournaments; Temple Is Toppled By West Virginia MORGANTOWN, W. Va., March 9 (UPI) - Dale Blaney sank an off-balance 13-foot jump shot with three seconds to play and Tim Kearney added a free throw to give West Virginia a 67-65 upset victory over Temple in the semifinals tonight.
description: Top-seeded Temple led by 65-64 with 30 seconds remaining but Charles Rayne missed the front end of a one-and-one situation from the foul line and the Mountaineers rebounded. West Virginia worked the ball downcourt to set up Blaney's game-winner from near the foul line.

title: Christ the King Captures Title
description: Christ the King made its first appearance in the Catholic High Schools' Athletic Association championship a stunningly successful one last night by routing St. Nicholas of Tolentine, 83-65, at Fordham University.

title: Your Money; Dissecting an Annual Report
description: AS the season of annual reports nears its peak, millions of individual investors can expect to receive booklets of financial statements and other information from the corporations whose common stock they hold. Regardless of how glossy the paper or how large the pictures, the essence of the document continues to be the figures that demonstrate the company's performance over the last year and its prospects for the future.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Sterilizer Co., a diversified Erie, Pa., health-care company, said it had acquired nearly all of the assets of American Medical Resources Inc. of Buena Park, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: SCOUTING
description: C.B.A. Hopefuls

title: Blast in London Club Reported to Injure 30
description: Scotland Yard said an explosive device went off at a night club in central London's Mayfair district early today, and 30 people were reported hurt.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SHAW INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
WANTED FOR 'ADOPTION': A COUNTRY DOCTOR
description: Nine years ago, Curtis and Alvina Bill moved here from Denver to spend, as Mrs. Bill put it, ''our last years with our children.''

title: Test for Breining
description: When the right-handed pitcher Fred Breining showed up at the San Francisco training camp with a sore shoulder, Giant officials say, they dismissed the ailment as the usual spring stiffness. And it was with a clear conscience, they say, that they traded him recently to the Montreal Expos for Al Oliver .

title: Robert Morris Gains
description: A 17-foot jump shot by Mark Dobbs with two seconds to play and a pair of free throws by Chipper Harris with a second to go gave Robert Morris, the two-time defending champion, a 62-58 victory over Fairleigh Dickinson tonight in the semifinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro playoffs at the McCann Recreation Center.

title: END OF A CAREER?
description: Billie Jean King , who has been playing in the Bridgestone women's doubles tournament in Japan, may be ending her tournament career. Mrs. King, who teamed with Sharon Walsh to beat Beth Herr and Gigi Fernandez , 6-0, 6-2, 6-3, in the tournament's second round yesterday, said she planned to concentrate on coaching and giving seminars, at least for a while. ''I've made no plans to play after this tournament,'' she said.

title: POLES OPEN TALKS ON THE CRUCIFIX CONTROVERSY
description: Roman Catholic Church leaders began meetings with Government officials today to discuss the turmoil that erupted in this farming area in December over the removal of crucifixes from classrooms.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
UNIDATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: No revenue figures were reported because the company was in a development stage.

title: 4 CONVICTED IN LARGE-SCALE SALES OF HEROIN IN CITY
description: Four men were convicted in Manhattan yesterday of Federal charges involving a large heroin-selling ring headed by a reputed organized-crime figure.

title: F.B.I. DISPLAYS RESCUE TACTICS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's new 50-member hostage rescue team staged a public demonstration today in an effort to frighten terrorists away from the Olympic Games and the national political conventions.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including securities gains of $2,743,826 for the quarter and $6,519,377 for the year.

title: J. David Deadline
description: A Federal judge ordered the president of the investment firm, J. David & Company, to turn over all of the company's business records by next Friday. Judge Gordon Thompson of United States District Court gave Jerry D. Dominelli, founder of a foreign exchange trading firm that has been forced into bankruptcy court by its investors, a week to give a grand jury the records. Mr. Dominelli had sought to quash the grand jury subpoena, saying that providing the records would jeopardize his rights against self-incrimination.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with a review of a photo exhibition on Tibet at the Asia Society misidentified the photographer. He was Heinrich Harrer.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: OTB Parlor on Stage

title: N.C. STATE BEATEN BY MARYLAND, 69-63
description: For almost a year, Jim Valvano had parlayed success and a gift of gab to perfect his characterization of ''Coach V,'' the energetic, wise- cracking New Yorker whose street smarts helped him elevate a good, but not great team to the national championship last season. But tonight, it was Lefty Driesell, the Maryland coach, who was telling the jokes while Valvano sat dejected behind a makeshift curtain in the interview area, contemplating the latest in a series of frustrations.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 quarter and year nets include $389,000 gain on the sale of property.

title: Gannett Wants U.S. News
description: The Gannett Company would like to make a bid for the weekly magazine, U.S. News & World Report, but no deal is imminent, Gannett's chairman, Allen H. Neuharth, said. ''Gannett has had friendly conversations with U.S. News for quite a number of years,'' he said.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday, halting their weeklong rise, as reports that an accord had been reached on the Federal budget filtered through to the credit markets and sparked renewed buying interest.

title: DRESS BARN reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
No Headline
description: Dr. Leopold Arnaud, dean emeritus and Ware Professor Emeritus of Columbia University's School of Architecture, died yesterday in a nursing home in Paris. He was 89 years old and lived in Fontainebleau.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: -SEEING There's an unusual photo opportunity in mid-Manhattan, a chance to look at a New York, at an America, that is no more, as seen 40 and more years ago through the eyes and the cameras of two great photographers.

title: LOSSES IN ART SWINDLE NOW REPORTED AT 2 MILLION
description: Art dealers and gallery owners are reporting new thefts by an indicted Manhattan man in what they say is one of the largest New York City art swindles in decades.

title: SOUTHERN MINERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: WITHERSPOON OUTPOINTS PAGE FOR TITLE
description: With the two other titleholders at ringside, along with Muhammad Ali - a reminder that the world has survived three heavyweight champions before - Tim Witherspoon outpointed Greg Page tonight to become the third man in the current crowded picture.

title: Texas Rate Rise
description: The Texas Utilities Company said a subsidiary, the Texas Utilities Electric Company, had filed for a $304.2 million, or 8 percent, rate increase. The utility serves north-central, east and west Texas.

title: THOMAS BOUCHARD
description: Thomas Bouchard, a photographer of dancers and artists and a film maker, died at his home Monday in Brewster, Mass.

title: MINI-COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $222,397 for the latest first quarter and $30,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Min-Computer Systems is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: L D BRINKMAN reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Meyer's Last Hurrah
description: Ray Meyer of DePaul is closing out a 42-year basketball coaching career, and there is expected to be a lot of hoopla and nostalgia when his Blue Demons play their final regular-season game, against Marquette today at the Rosemont (Ill.) Horizon. The 70- year-old Meyer, however, has something bigger on his mind than the farewell ceremonies - the game itself.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Utah Jazz, at Madison Square Garden, 1 P.M. A rare Saturday afternoon game for the Knicks, who yield the Garden tonight to the Big East Conference final. (Television - MSG Cable, 1 P.M., live, and 7:30 P.M., tape.)

title: Moscow Agrees to Sell Advanced Arms to India
description: The Soviet Union agreed today to sell India fighter jets, warships, missiles, army hardware and electronic surveillance systems, Indian officials said.

title: AEGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NET STRING ENDED AT 7 BY PISTONS, 122-118
description: Isiah Thomas scored 24 points, including 12 in the fourth quarter, to rally the Detroit Pistons to a 122-118 victory over the Nets tonight. The loss snapped the Nets' winning streak at seven.

title: NICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
V BAND SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $91,027.

description: b-Net income c-After a gain of $1,615,000 from tax credits. d-Net loss The latest year results include those of R & G Communications Inc., acquired Feb. 28, 1983, and American Phone Centers Inc., acquired June 8, 1983, on a pooling-of-interests basis. Also, 1983 and 1982 include results of properties acquired from General Dynamics in October 1982.

title: South Africa to Drop Case Against Journalists
description: The Government said today that it would drop charges against two journalists and the wife of one in connection with an article quoting a ''banned'' woman.

title: Raid on Nursing Home Finds Anemic Patients
description: Eight anemic, malnourished patients were removed from a nursing home today after investigators found it infested with rats and littered with human excrement.

title: GEORGETOWN AND SYRACUSE GAIN FINAL
description: Dwayne Washington displayed his offensive repertory last night at Madison Square Garden, including stutter-steps and head fakes, as he led Syracuse University to a 66-65 victory over Villanova in the semifinal round of the Big East Conference tournament.

title: No Headline
description: Raymond P. Whearty, FormerFederalOfficial

title: SOVIET PUZZLE: NEW HAT FOR THE CHIEF?
description: The Kremlin announced today that the Supreme Soviet, the nominal Parliament, would meet here on April 11, an occasion that could produce a successor to Yuri V. Andropov as head of state.

title: WYOMING POSES A WESTERN TEST FOR 2 DEMOCRATS
description: Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale face their first Democratic Presidential test in the West on Saturday when they square off in caucuses in Wyoming, a state that historically has favored Republicans.

title: MICHIGAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $862,000 for the quarter and $717,000 for the year and extraordinary charges of $6,204,000 for the quarter and $3,617,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,654,000 for the quarter and $9,341,000 for the year and an extraordinary gain of $2,725,000 for the year. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: 3 SENATORS SEEK MEESE'S RETURN FOR QUESTIONING
description: Three members of the Senate Judiciary Committee suggested today that Edwin Meese 3d should return for questioning about whether he knew that Ronald Reagan's 1980 political campaign had obtained information from within President Carter's camp.

title: KENWIN SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
GOLDEN AND MANES VIE AT HEARING ON STADIUM
description: The Brooklyn and Queens Borough Presidents said yesterday that a new professional sports stadium was needed in New York City, and each said his borough was the best place to build it.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: EMPLOYMENT RISES
description: The national unemployment rate fell an additional two- tenths of a point in February, to 7.7 percent, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Hart Tells of Getting Navy Commission in '80
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado said today that he applied for a Navy commission in the 1970's so he could enter active duty in the event of a war in the Persian Gulf.

title: Trade Dispute On Newsprint
description: Canada said today that it would ask the the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to set up a special panel to examine its complaint that the European Economic Community has impaired access for its newsprint.

title: STORY BASED ON DANTE CANTO
description: ''Francesca da Rimini,'' the best- known of Riccardo Zandonai's eight operas, derives its story from Canto V of Dante's ''Inferno,'' as retold in Gabriele D'Annunzio's 1902 tragedy. There are some 30 operas on the subject as well as orchestral versions, of which the most famous is Tchaikovsky's tone poem.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Pryor Returning
description: Aaron Pryor , who retired as the World Boxing Association's junior- welterweight champion last year, confirmed yesterday that he would make a comeback, and said he wanted to fight Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini and Sugar Ray Leonard . ''If Sugar Ray can come out of retirement with one eye, I can come out with the problems I've had,'' said the undefeated 28-year-old boxer.

title: BERKLEY, W R, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After realized gains on investments of $153,000 for the quarter and $3,586,000 for the year. c-Includes tax benefits of $2,751,000 for the quarter and $6,995,000 for the year and after realized losses on investments of $440,000 for the quarter and $475,000 for the year.

title: ECLECTIC ROCH NIGHTSPOT STAGES A BENEFIT PREVIEW
description: ''This place is going to be the mini-Smithsonian of rock-and-roll!'' declared Dan Aykroyd, gesturing toward the packed dance floor at the Hard Rock Cafe, New York's newest, and perhaps most eclectic, nightspot at 221 West 57th Street. The cafe, which is partly owned by Mr. Aykroyd, will not have its official opening-night party until Monday, but Thursday night about 375 guests got a preview during a benefit organized by the Junior Committee of the Boys' Club of New York.

title: DODGERS' WHITFIELD IS STARTING ANEW
description: As Terry Whitfield prepared today for his first game at Fort Lauderdale Stadium in seven years, he talked about the more difficult task of preparing to play baseball in the major leagues again.

title: BROCK HOTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: INSPIRATION RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income after an extraordinary gain. c-After an extraordinary gain. The 1982 results include an extraordinary gain of $44,979,000 from an asset sale. The results have been restated to give effect to the corporation's reorganization concluded last summer.

title: DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES ARE NOT TAILORING THEIR SPEECHES FOR ALABAMIANS
description: Gary Hart, a political curiosity in these parts, came to the State Capitol Thursday to take his turn at what has become a command performance in the Democratic Presidential primary campaign in Alabama.

title: AS THE FREEZE ON STATE ARTS SUPPORT CONTINUES
description: To the Editor:

title: Landlord Is Jailed In Contempt Case
description: The owner of an East Harlem building who failed to provide heat for nine months in 1981 surrendered yesterday to begin serving a 25-day sentence for contempt of court,

title: U.S. IS STEPPING UP MILITARY ACTIVITY FOR SALVADORANS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that United States military activity in Central America was being stepped up in advance of El Salvador's presidential election March 25.

title: DANCE: MARTHA GRAHAM TROUPE PRESENTS 'CAVE OF THE HEART'
description: Something beyond theater is going on these days at Lincoln Center, where the Martha Graham Dance Company is performing at the New York State Theater through March 18. It has to do with paying homage, as well as enjoying dance. On Thursday, the reverent silence that greeted ''Primitive Mysteries,'' an ageless, elemental Graham signature work, changed to muted gasps with the season's first performance of her electric ''Cave of the Heart,'' and then culminated in a roaring, poignantly affectionate standing ovation that greeted Miss Graham as she took a curtain call after ''Acts of Light.''

title: HART'S APPEAL IS TO CYNICS, MONDALE TELLS 400 STUDENTS
description: Walter F. Mondale, concerned about a rush of young voters to Senator Gary Hart, asserted today that his opponent had ''marketed himself'' to appeal to a cynical generation that grew up in ''an earthquake zone'' of war, economic uncertainty and political corruption.

title: EX-IM BANK IS OFFERING 2D MAJOR LOAN SUBSIDY
description: The Export-Import Bank, in a departure from the early emphasis of the Reagan Administration, announced today for the second time in two weeks the approval of a heavily subsidized loan to help an American company compete in a foreign market.

title: COLUMBIAN NORTHLAND EXLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax benefits. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

description: A group including Shamrock Associates told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it will ask the Dorsey Corporation to consider a leveraged buyout of its assets.

ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: The year-earlier share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 4-for-3 stock split distributed on July 15, 1983.

title: I.B.M. IS LICENSED TO MAKEINTEL CHIP
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a licensing agreement with the Intel Corporation that would permit I.B.M. to manufacture on its own the microprocessor that lies at the heart of its expanding line of Personal Computers.

title: OTTAWA REJECTS BAN ON SEAL HUNT
description: Two Cabinet ministers said today that they had rejected a proposal from the Canadian Sealers Association that there be a formal Government ban on killing seal pups, which have not been hunted since 1982.

title: SAPIENZA LEADS QUALIFIERS IN 3,000
description: Jim Sapienza, a 20-year-old Dartmouth junior from Louisville, Ky., calls himself ''a thinking man's runner.'' Today, the thinking man used his head to stay out of trouble and led the men's 3,000-meter qualifiers in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's indoor track and field championships.

title: PATENTS;
description: Machine Turns Speech Into Typed Signals

title: Mrs. Reagan Schedules Talk
description: Nancy Reagan, the President's wife, plans to make a solo political appearance Monday before the Magic Circle Women's Republican Club in Houston, her press secretary, Sheila Tate, said Thursday. After the Houston luncheon, Mrs. Reagan will fly to Phoenix to visit her ailing mother and will remain overnight, the secretary said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 10, 1984

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The water rots everything - it corrodes steel, it rots out rail ties, it shorts out signal systems. You don't want it in the subway.'' - Morris Loshinsky, deputy chief engineer for the Transit Authority. (1:1.)

title: GEORGIA VOTE SEEN AS UNPREDICTABLE
description: Few seasoned Georgia politicians will venture a guess as to the outcome of the Democratic Presidential primary in this state on Tuesday. Those willing to make a forecast said the contest appeared to be between Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and Walter F. Mondale, with Senator John Glenn of Ohio and the Rev. Jesse Jackson as imponderable elements.

title: 580 Claims Against U.S. Are Filed by Grenadians
description: Grenadians have filed 580 claims seeking about $100 million in damages for losses caused by the United States-led invasion last year, a Government official said today.

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $93,000 from tax recovery.

title: No Headline
description: Harry B. Haines Dies; Publisher of Dispatch

title: Baldrige Scolds Justice Department
description: Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige, in a strong attack on another Federal agency, has termed the Justice Department's decision to block the proposed merger of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation ''a world class mistake for the United States.''

title: Auburn, Kentucky Win NASHVILLE, March 9 (AP) - Charles Barkley scored 21 points, including two deciding free throws in the final 43 seconds, as Auburn beat Tennessee, 60-58, tonight and moved into the final of the Southeastern Conference tournament for the first time.
description: Barkley missed three other free- throw attempts in the final minute.

title: DOCTOR OF POLITICS By Russell Baker
description: It isn't easy being a campaign doctor in a season like this. Here's Gary Hart, for example, on the telephone:

title: MOVE BEGINS IN CONGRESS TO BLOCK ARMS SALE TO JORDAN AND SAUDIS
description: Some key members of Congress have begun an effort to stop the Reagan Administration's proposed sales of portable Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Jordan and Saudi Arabia.

title: OLGA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
NATIONAL WESTERN LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $125,000 from reversal of capital loss carryforward.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Southeast Options
description: The Southeast Banking Corporatiion said it had exercised its options to buy about 4.5 million shares of its common from two shareholder groups headed by Jack Burstein, Robert Marlin and Samuel Adler, and by M. Lee Pearce and the Pan American Hospital Corporation. Southeast said that it completed the purchase of about 3.6 million shares today for about $105.3 million and that closings on the remaining shares will take place during the next few months. Southeast, which has about 18.8 million shares outstanding, closed today at $22.625, up 12 1/2 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: IRAN ACCUSES IRAQ OF CHEMICAL WAR
description: Iran charged again today that Iraqi forces were using chemical weapons in their attempt to retake an artificial island that Iranian forces seized in southern border marshlands two weeks ago.

title: CHANGES PROPOSED IN CLEAN AIR LAW
description: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency proposed today to change the national standard limiting the amount of dust, soot and other solid particles in the air.

title: GULF'S DEFEAT AND ITS LESSONS
description: On Wall Street, the $13.2 billion takeover of the Gulf Corporation - the largest in corporate history - is described as the merger that should not have happened. And a decade ago, Wall Street people say, it would not have.

title: C. W. Post Gains In Regional, 65-62
description: Mike Henderson scored on a layup with 1 minute 30 seconds remaining, and Greg Dixon made three free throws in the final 27 seconds as C. W. Post (26- 4) captured an opening-round game of the N.C.A.A. Division II East Regional, 65-62, over Gannon at the losers' gym here.

title: GREECE DROPS PROTEST ON TURKISH SHELLING
description: A crisis between two members of the Atlantic alliance suddenly receded today after Greece announced that it had concluded that Turkish warships had not intentionally fired on a Greek destroyer in the Aegean Sea.

title: Letter: On Air Travel Who Wants to Ban Smoking on Planes? To the Editor:
description: We beg to differ with your Feb. 23 editorial ''Smoking in the Sky.'' Proponents of further airline smoking restrictions have not made a credible case.

title: SCOUTING
description: Future Is Now

title: Mondale Support Found Slipping in CBS Poll
description: A CBS News poll released yesterday shows a dramatic rise in support among Democrats for Senator Gary Hart as that party's Presidential nominee. The poll found that 38 percent of Democrats polled nationwide would like to see Senator Hart nominated, against only 7 percent before the New Hampshire primary.

title: DOW OFF 7.33 POINTS, TO 1,139.76
description: Stock prices fell yesterday for the fourth day this week in light trading. The news of a sharp drop in the unemployment rate only heightened fears of tight money and an increase in interest rates.

title: Books of The Times
description: LIFE IN RUSSIA. By Michael Binyon. 286

title: Cuba May Join Coffee Group
description: Cuba is considering whether to join the International Coffee Organization, Iradio Cartaya, commercial counselor at the Cuban Embassy in London, said today.

title: ManHurls$26,000 Into Queens Street
description: A taxi driver with a history of mental problems withdrew his life savings of $26,000 from his bank yesterday, went outside and tossed the cash into the air, the police said.

title: HANOVER INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $109,165 related to tax adjustments. c-Net income after a tax adjustment charge of $124,960.

title: DINING OUT: THE WOES OF A NONSMOKER
description: Ask people who dine out often what bothers them most in restaurants, and ranked just below poor food and noise is smoking.

title: CARMA LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 30
IOWA, WITH FINALISTS, DOMINATES MEET
description: Iowa placed five wrestlers in the 10 finals at the 54th N.C.A.A. wrestling championships tonight and assumed a commanding position for winning its seventh consecutive national title.

title: Mr. Alvarado, Please Go
description: The recently bright and promising career of New York's Schools Chancellor, Anthony Alvarado, is effectively destroyed.

title: U.S. STEEL AND NATIONAL DROP PLAN TO MERGE STEEL DIVIIONS
description: Two of the nation's largest steel producers, the United States Steel Corporation and National Intergroup Inc., said yesterday that they had called off an agreement to merge their steel operations because of the Justice Department's opposition on antitrust grounds.

title: YELLOW RAIN EVIDENCE THAT CANNOT BE IGNORED
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Retrospective
description: A film retrospective of the career of the Japanese actor Toshiro Mifune running through April 29 continues this weekend at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street. Today at 1 P.M., it will be ''Saga of the Vagabonds'' (1959), followed at 3:30 P.M. by ''Hell in the Pacific,'' a 1968 film in English, with Lee Marvin, the only film in the series without subtitles.

title: Aide in Ambulance Case Says People Hound Her
description: A nurse who delayed sending an ambulance to the aid of a dying woman said today that public outrage, including motorists who drive by her residence crying ''Murderer! Murderer!'' had made her a prisoner in her own home.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: House Calls

title: CUOMO SEEKS TO LET GROCERIES SELL WINE MADE IN NEW YORK
description: Governor Cuomo proposed legislation yesterday to permit the sale of wines - but only those made in New York State - in grocery stores.

title: CHOI'S ORDEAL: GOOD POLICY TURNED INTO 'IVY LEAGUE SOCIALISM'
description: T o the Editor:

title: HARDING CARPETS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Fire Disrupts Cruise Off Coast of Florida
description: Fire broke out tonight on the cruise ship Scandinavian Sea with 946 people aboard, but no injuries were reported as passengers donned life jackets and were herded to the vessel's top two decks, officials said.

title: Budget Games With Medicaid
description: Last year, when New York State celebrated a plan to help localities with the growing cost of Medicaid, New York City came away believing the deal included a total shift of payments for the mentally ill. That was only fair, because state policies over the years had vastly increased the burden of the mentally ill on the city's health care system.

title: ON GERMAN FRONTIER: A CHRONICLER BUILDS HIS CASE
description: If Chancellor Helmut Kohl really wanted to please the Communist authorities in East Germany, he would arrange for Carl-Hermann Retemeyer to close down his operation on the second floor of a police station here in the foothills of the Harz Mountains.

title: HEAVY FIGHTING ERUPTS ANEW IN BEIRUT
description: Heavy fighting broke out today between Lebanese Army forces and Moslem militias along the Green Line dividing East and West Beirut.

title: Suspect Killed in Drug Raid
description: A suspected drug dealer was killed and a police officer was shot in the right hand yesterday during a raid in Harlem, the police said. The dead man, Juan Almonte, 60 years old, was shot in the head, the police said. The officer, Capt. Louis Anemone, 38, was one of eight officers who participated in the raid in an apartment at 547 West 142d Street shortly after 8 P.M. The officer was in stable condition at Columbia- Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: EIKONIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Roberts Takeover
description: Beecham Group P.L.C. said it plans to acquire Roberts Consolidated Industries for $85 million. Roberts, based in the United States, is a supplier of branded contact adhesives, carpet-laying adhesives and accessories and wood preservatives, with subsidiaries in Canada, West Germany, the Netherlands, Australia and New Zealand.

title: ENIGMA WHO DOESN'T BELONG TO 'THE CLUB'
description: The Senate is a place of vaulting egos, where seniority and geniality are highly esteemed. It is not surprising that among many of his colleagues, Senator Gary Hart's unexpectedly strong showing in the Democratic primaries has evoked astonishment, admiration and a bit of envy.

title: NICHLAUS SHARES 3-WAY LEAD AT 136
description: Even though he shot a 67 in the opening round of the Doral-Eastern Open Thursday and was only a shot off the lead, Jack Nicklaus went to see his longtime golf adviser, Jack Grout, later that day. Nicklaus wasn't happy with his swing and wanted help from the teacher.

title: THE SECRET INGREDIENT IN GIRL SCOUT COOKIES
description: A good sales pitch dies hard, even with the grumpiest customers.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 29.
