title: LIBEL AWARDS FOUND TO EXCEED 2 OTHER GROUPS
description: Juries award more money to people whose reputations have been blackened by news organizations than to people hurt by incompetent doctors or faulty products, according to a new study.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company had no share earnings for the year-ago fourth quarter because of preferred stock requirements.

title: Louisville Upset, 69-61 MEMPHIS, March 9 (AP) - Virginia Tech got 24 points from Perry Young and the Hokies stunned Louisville with a tenacious full-court press to post a 69-61 victory over the Cardinals in the semifinal round of the Metro Conference tournament tonight.
description: ''We cannot play any harder than we did down the stretch tonight,'' said Coach Charlie Moir of Virginia Tech.

title: HIGH WATER ROTS SUBWAY TUNNELS
description: The water table in New York City has risen as much as 10 feet over the last 30 years, eroding some subway tunnels so badly that they may have to be rebuilt, transit officials said yesterday.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Citizen Maree
description: Sydney Maree has found it difficult to work up much patriotism for his South African birthplace. As a black, he was not allowed to compete against whites until 1976.

description: a man was reading the sports

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SYRIA CELEBRATES SOFTLY
description: President Hafez al-Assad looms large over Damascus. His piercing brown eyes stare down at pedestrians from a colorful banner portrait that covers a five-story building on Youssef al- Azmi Circle, a major downtown thoroughfare.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ROCKY MOUNTAIN NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
AROUND THE NATION Hospital Shreds Records Involving Accused Nurse
description: The County Hospital here has destroyed 9,000 pounds of its pharmaceutical records, some of them under subpoena by a grand jury that brought a child injury charge against Genene Jones, a licensed vocational nurse recently convicted of murder, officials said today.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTH AFFILIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $11,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including extraordinary credits of $17,000 for the quarter and $34,000 for the year.

title: NEW RULES ON CHECK CLEARING
description: WHEN you tell the landlord that the check is in the mail, is the money in your bank account? That question has long worried consumers whose banks took several days to clear checks they had deposited. But thanks to regulations that took effect Thursday, the answer should now be less confusing for New York depositors.

title: Teacher Charges AssaultbyStudent
description: A Mercer County official who is a full- time junior high school teacher here has charged a 16-year-old student with assault and battery after a shoving match, and said today that violence against teachers occurred daily.

title: Bridge: A New England Team Wins
description: A bid by two New York experts to score a unique triple fell just short here Thursday night, and the Grand National Pair Championship title went to New England.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Including equity in earnings of unconsolidated subsidiaries of $167,000 for the latest year and $132,000 for the previous year.

title: EMPLOYEES' LOANS TO ALVARADO INVESTIGATED BY 2 DISTRICT ATTORNEYS
description: The District Attorneys of Brooklyn and Manhattan are investigating the loans made by school employees to City Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado and hiring practices in the East Harlem district he once led, officials said yesterday.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: The Search For Sam Todd
description: It is to be expected that in a city as dense and complex as New York there will always be unsolved mysteries, but none in recent years has been any more unexpected or baffling than the disappearance of Samuel Todd, the 24-year-old Yale Divinity School student who fell from sight in the early morning hours of New Year's Day.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a credit from the sale of a building and land of $3,999,000. The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1983.

title: Opposition Pulls Out Of Sandinista Council
description: Three more opposition parties and a labor union withdrew from the Sandinista-dominated Council of State today.

title: Stable OPEC Course Urged
description: An OPEC committee, as expected, recommended today that the group maintain the oil price and production policies established a year ago, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut prices for the first time ever.

title: Mexico to Sell Companies
description: The Government will sell off 339 companies swept up in a 1982 bank nationalization, but will retain control of 128 other companies seized in the takeover, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Matters of Opinion
description: In his recent speech in Columbus,

title: ON HAZARDOUS WASTE
description: For every person in America, almost two tons of hazardous wastes are disposed of each year. A strong regulatory effort is needed to control this monumental tinderbox of industrial refuse that imperils the environment. Next week, the Senate could reauthorize this country's most important hazardous-waste legislation, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976. This law should be strengthened to prevent careless and criminal dumping of hazardous wastes. However, the Administration's New Federalism pushes for state takeover of hazardous-waste regulation without providing adequate funding or assurance of uniform stringency among state programs.

title: THE INTENT OF TITLE IX

title: CONSOLIDATED PIPE LINES CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Jim Eisenreich, who played only two games last season before a nervous disorder sidelined him, made another move toward winning the center fielder job with the Minnesota Twins yesterday as he singled three times and doubled in a 4-3 loss to Houston. It was his second straight four-hit game, but his eight-hit streak was stopped when he flied to center in the ninth. . . . Moses Malone , the Philadelphia 76ers' all-star center, missed last night's home game against Seattle because he was in Houston visiting his wife and his son, Michael Earl Malone , who was born during the afternoon, weighing 8 pounds 4 ounces. . . . An investment group headed by H. R. (Bum) Bright , a Dallas businessman, is the latest of three groups seeking to buy the Dallas Cowboys, according to a published report.

title: LOCAL EMPHASIS BUOYS TV STATION
description: -BARRE, Pa. - Channel 16, or WNEP-TV, is not exactly a giant among stations but it has gained a big place in a small market with a formula that combines local programming and local news with community service to achieve high ratings.

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $115,000 for the quarter and $202,000 for the 9 months. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $48,000.

title: Diversified Gets Antitrust Award
description: A Federal court jury returned a $35 million judgment for Diversified Industries in its antitrust lawsuit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Diversified, based in St. Louis, charged that A.T.& T. and two units had deliberately put Diversified out of the wire-recycling business.

title: NEWYORK CITY JOBLESS RATE JUMPED TO 9.2% IN FEBRUARY
description: The unemployment rate for New York State was unchanged last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday, but it went up in New York City and dropped sharply in New Jersey.

title: ORION CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $4,000 for the quarter and $7,592,000 for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $675,000 for the quarter and $444,000 for the year and a gain of $218,000 for the year on the retirement of notes payable.

title: OVERSAW WAR SALVAGE EFFORT
description: Vice Adm. Homer N. Wallin, U.S.N. retired, who directed the salvage and repair of the naval vessels sunk in the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died Tuesday in Seattle. He was 90 years old.

title: REAGAN'S POCKET VETO OF SALVADOR AID BILL UPHELD
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that President Reagan had the constitutional authority to use a pocket veto between two sessions of Congress.

title: AWAKENING THE VOTERS
description: ''Would you like to register to vote?'' I asked, but I had already lost the attention of the two New York City public high school seniors. They were more interested in singer Melba Moore, who had come to the school to speak to them about voter registration. The students clearly hoped that she would perform but were completely uninterested in our attempt to integrate them into the democratic process. I began to realize that a voter registration campaign is not a simple thing.

title: Key Rates
SATURDAY, MARCH 10, 1984 International
description: The United States is stepping up military activity in Central America before El Salvador's presidential election March 25. Reagan Administration officials said the actions included new small-scale military maneuvers in Honduras, doubling to 1,700 the number of American military people in Honduras and arming United States military advisers in El Salvador with heavier weapons to protect themselves. (Page 1, Column 4.) Some key Congressmen are trying to block the Reagan Administration's proposed sales of portable antiaircraft missiles to Jordan and Saudi Arabia. They said the effort had the backing of Republicans and Democrats in both houses and the support of a leading pro-Israeli lobbying group. (1:2.)

title: SUN CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After equity in loss of Chromalloy American Corp. of $11,623,000. c-Net income after equity in loss of Chromalloy American of $1,747,000. d-After equity in loss of Chromalloy's discontinued operations of $12,923,000.

title: Man, 77, With Gun Seized Near Mondale
description: Pandemonium briefly beset Walter F. Mondale's campaign at a stop here tonight when Secret Service agents pounced on an elderly man in the hand-shaking crowd, wrestled him down and whisked him away for questioning after someone noticed a pistol in a holster strapped to his waist.

title: Rockwell Gets Contract
description: The Rockwell International Corporation received a $681.6 million Air Force contract for work on 10 airframes for the B-1B bomber, the Defense Department said. The award is an option on an existing contract.

title: FELDSTEIN BACKS FED RESTRAINT
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the President's chief economic adviser, went public today with a detailed presentation of a new debate within the Reagan Administration - this time over the monetary policies of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: MILITARY BUDGET STILL BLOCKS AGREEMENT ON DEFICIT
description: President Reagan conferred again today with leading Republican senators to seek agreement on a deficit-reducing package for next year, but he was reportedly still at odds with them over the size of the increase in military appropriations.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Maurice Carroll

title: TO MAKE UTILITIES THINK TWICE BEFORE THEY BUILD
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the sale of the freighters Hellenic Star and Hellenic Ideal incorrectly reported the appraisals by the ship brokering firm of Jacq. Pierot Jr. & Sons Inc. They were $1.8 million for the Star and $1.5 million of the Ideal. The figures in the article were the opening bids, set by the United States District Court.

title: CRAMER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: TO GET MAIL DELIVERED
description: It is time to consider private competition for the United States Postal Service in New York City. Under its monopoly on general delivery services, the Postal Service has failed to deliver mail in a reasonably quick and efficient manner. The resulting costs to the public are too high to accept.

title: Muskie Is Recovering
description: Edmund S. Muskie, the former Senator and Secretary of State, was reported in good condition today at Georgetown University Hospital after undergoing surgery to remove his appendix. The 69-year-old Democrat from Maine entered the hospital Tuesday complaining of stomach cramps.

title: BIGGEST STORM OF THE WINTER BRINGS UP TO A FOOT OF SNOW
description: The winter's heaviest snowstorm swirled into the metropolitan area Thursday evening, blanketing the region with up to a foot of snow before ending yesterday morning.

title: Las Vegas Advances INGLEWOOD, Calif., March 9 (AP) - Jeff Collins scored 19 points to lead Nevada-Las Vegas to a 91-78 victory over Utah State in a semifinal game of the Pacific Coast Athletic Association tournament.
description: In the second game at the Forum, University of California-Irvine was to meet Fresno State for the remaining spot in Saturday afternoon's finals.

title: Tax Rebel's Daughter Dead
description: Linda Kahl Holder, the 36-year-old daughter of Gordon Kahl, a tax protester killed last year in a battle with the police, was found shot dead in her car Tuesday morning near here, the Ector County Sheriff's office reported Wednesday. Gordon Kahl, her father, was hunted last year in connection with the killing of two Federal marshals in North Dakota and was killed in a gunfight June 3 in Arkansas.

title: DANCE: CUNNINGHAM
description: Merce Cunningham's current creative jag is one of the most interesting in his career. Its most recent manifestation is ''Inlets 2,'' which was given its New York premiere by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company Thursday night at the City Center.

title: MET OPERA: DOMINGO IN 'FRANCESCA DA RIMINI'
description: The Metropolitan Opera turned itself into a time machine Friday night when Riccardo Zandonai's ''Francesca da Rimini'' was revived - if that is the right word - after an absence of 66 years from the company's repertory.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
INTENSE, GUARDED EROTICISM IN PHOTOS AT PRINCETON GALLERY
description: PRINCETON HAVING originated at the Corcoran Art Gallery in Washington, Emmet Gowin's photography retrospective is now at the Princeton University Art Museum.

title: STUDENT-RUN RADIO SHOW IS FOCUSING ON AMERICA
description: Garth Ancier remembers using household tape to splice together recordings for a radio show he began 10 years ago as a junior in high school.

title: Divers Find 12 Bodies In Sunken U.S. Ship
description: Divers searching the wreck of an American oil-drilling ship that sank off South China last year have found the remains of 12 of the 81 crewmen, most of them in the vessel's recreation area, the ship's owner said.

title: A WELCOME JAPAESE NEWCOMER
description: NEW HAVEN has done it again. The city can usually be counted on for having the most varied choices in ethnic cuisine, and now it has doubled its number of Japanese restaurants.

description: AT 6:30 P.M. on Jan. 6, 1981, word

title: CABARET: SANDERS QUARTET
description: From the time in the mid-1960's when Pharoah Sanders was playing with John Coltrane's group, his style on saxophone has moved between shrill, extended squeals and jagged rasps, long, extended, slow-building mood settings and relatively straightforward, mainstream playing. Although there has always been something of all this present, the shriek and rasp attack predominated in his early days and the exotic moods took over in the 70's.

description: A Broadside From a Defender Of the Pentagon

title: PESTICIDE BILL SETS OFF DISPUTE
description: AN ''antipesticide'' measure introduced by Senator Raymond Lesniak, Democrat of Elizabeth, has evoked strong opposition from chemical manufacturers, and last week opened a rift between environmentalists and farmers.

title: W. A. Peattie to Marry Bradley Penn Sturges
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Sturges 3d of Mobile, Ala., have announced the engagement of their daughter Bradley Penn Sturges to William Austin Peattie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Peattie of Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is to take place May 12.

description: Too Much Money Can Cause Headaches, Too

description: To the Editor:

title: VICTORS OVER CANCER
description: As a breast-cancer patient and a hot-line counselor, I always read about other women's stories with great interest. One theme that occurs with alarming frequency is the initial misdiagnosis that many of us experience.

title: No Headline
description: WHEN Mexico's new Government slashed public spending and reduced real wages last year, it won accolades from Western bankers eager to believe that austerity was the answer to Latin America's debt crisis.

title: SHULTZ OPPOSES MOVING MISSION OUT OF TEL AVIV
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has warned Congress that passage of a bill to move the United States Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem could provoke a wave of anti-American violence throughout the Islamic world.

title: A NEW PROGRAM FOR LOW-INCOME FAMILIES
description: CHUGGING down the tracks from Washington this year is a new Federal initiative to assist the construction of rental housing. It was born in Congress last year under the sponsorship of two Democrats, Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn.

title: BLUES DOWN DEVILS IN OVERTIME BY 6-5
description: Rob Ramage scored his 12th goal of the season with 43 seconds remaining in the third period and scored on a power play 3 minutes 9 seconds into overtime, lifting the St. Louis Blues to a 6-5 victory tonight over the Devils.

title:
Letters to LI Editor;
DINING OUT: ANOTHER VIEW
description: Dining Out: Another View I was stunned when I read the Dining Out column Jan. 29. It was titled ''It's the Setting That Shines,'' and it reviewed Devin's restaurant in Garden City.

title: CRIMEAN TATAR SENTENCED TO 6TH TERM OF DETENTION
description: A Crimean Tatar nationalist who has spent most of his adult life in Soviet prisons or in exile was sentenced to a sixth term of detention in Tashkent last month.

description: INTRODUCING MOZART

title: Ustinov Ends Visit to India
description: Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Soviet Defense Minister, flew home today after agreeing to supply advanced weapons. Indian Defense Ministry sources quoted by the newspaper The Statesman said, ''Russia has agreed to making available a more sophisticated version of the MIG and refitting the Indian submarine fleet with better propulsion and improved sonar systems apart from making more submarines and cruisers available.''

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW FOR CHINESE-FOOD ENTHUSIASTS
description: T HE rapidity with which Chinese restaurants have recently opened in the county (and their ability to remain open) is testimony to the widespead enthusiasm for that cuisine. Despite its regional variety, most of the new kitchens seem to follow the fad for Sichuan- Hunanese cooking; and perusing menus can bring on a case of dej a vu. Thus new dishes, inspired variations on old ones and posted lists of seasonal specials have become more welcome than ever.

title: REAGAN'S SIGNALS AND CHERNENKO'S
description: Only two months ago, I said publicly that relations between the United States and the Soviet Union were the worst that I had known in the 63 years since I first went to Russia as a young physician to try to help combat a typhus epidemic.

title: GUNMEN OPEN FIRE ON PROTESTANT MARCH IN ULSTER
description: Roman Catholic youths hurled gasoline bombs and unidentified gunmen shot at the police and British troops guarding a Protestant march today, the police said.

title: HEADLINERS
description: Of Art and Artifice When Manhattan prosecutors charged Dennis R. Anderson in a $700,000 art swindle last week, they apparently didn't know the half of it.

title: EX-CARTER OFFICIAL CALLS REAGAN'S FOREIGN POLICY A 'DISASTER'
description: The head of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency in the Administration of Jimmy Carter said in New York yesterday that a review of the Reagan Administration's foreign and military policy ''was a little like conducting a guided tour of downtown Beirut.''

title: CONNECTICUIT JOURNAL
description: REPORTS of a steadily growing state budget surplus might seem to be reason for good cheer to legislators and state officials alike, as they prepare to adopt a tax and spending plan for the next fiscal year. Instead, the news has touched off a debate, with charges of overtaxing and countercharges of irresponsible financial analysis, in a battle that could threaten hopes for bipartisan support on a long- range plan to repair Connecticut's roads and bridges.

title:
Opinions;
RAIL STATION VS. PURE WATER?

Uncomfortable and inaccurate connotations are often attached to the term in current usage. For many people, visions of the infamous snail darter episode come immediately, and perhaps involuntarily, to mind.

title: CRIME
description: Martha Hennissart and Mary J. Latis, under the pen name of Emma Lathen, have been very busy since 1961 with their Wall Street mysteries featuring Putnam Thatcher. Under the name of R. B. Dominic, they also have been writing a series about Representative Ben Safford, Democrat of Ohio, the first of which appeared in 1968. It may be that the Lathen books are more popular than Dominic's, and certainly there are many more of them. But Ben Safford has many admirers. They feel that he is a more likable figure than the stuffier and rather mysterious Thatcher, who seems to have no life of his own outside his bank.

Doctors said Friday that Jimmy is now ''nearly normal'' after six weeks in intensive care. He could be home within three weeks, they said.

It is the first portable video recorder with high-fidelity sound, and its claim to versatility rests on the fact that it also functions as a stationary home VCR without the need of the add-ons (tuner and timer) required by portable VCR's. Aside from all that, it makes a top fidelity audio recorder surpassing in this respect even far more expensive sound only equipment.

The principal impression is of drabness enhanced, not relieved, by the garish personality cult. Underneath, diplomats sense a morose weariness and a growing belief that the war with Iran, now well into its fourth year, cannot be won by either side.

description: Philippine elections have often been marked by fraud and violence, but in most instances the winners were usually the choice of the majority. The last two elections under President Ferdinand E. Marcos have been described by critics as the most ''blatantly rigged'' of all. Mr. Marcos, who has been politically besieged since last summer, has a strong interest in seeing that the assembly elections on May 14, are, in the words of the opposition, ''clean and fair,'' at least in appearance.

title: STOPS ON A NORTHEAST TOUR
description: The area of northeastern England known as Northumbria, which counts the ruins of Hadrian's Wall among its historical assets, is about 270 miles north of London. Among its chief cities are Newcastle-upon-Tyne, an industrial city, and Durham. Newcastle's major attraction for visitors interested in the region's past is the Museum of Antiquities, which is known for its Roman artifacts and model of the wall. In Durham, notable landmarks are the cathedral and the castle, both started in the 11th century.

title: 5 LONDON BOMBS LINKED TO LIBYANS
description: A bomb went off at a basement nightclub here early today, wounding 24 people, three of them seriously. The police said it might have been planted by Libyan terrorists as part of a campaign against Libyan exiles. Four other bombs Friday night were also linked to Libyans. One exploded a short time before the nightclub blast outside a shop in the Bayswater district that sells Arab newspapers. No injuries were reported.

title: A 387-MILLION-BARREL RESERVE GIVES U.S. AN ACE IN THE HOLE
description: Ever since the 1973-74 Arab embargo, the possibility that the West's oil lifeline to the Persian Gulf could again be severed has caused shudder among American policymakers. They and allied planners have worried most about a blockage of the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow passageway through which about eight million barrels of oil - roughly 20 percent of Western consumption - flows to market daily.

title: BRINGING OUT THE BEST IN WOOD PANELING: THE RIGHT STEPS
description: WHEN wood panels are used on interior walls, they normally do not need painting or refinishing for many years and thus are often thought of as being almost maintenance-free. However, like any other interior surface, wood paneling does get dull and dirty-looking in time, so it will require periodic cleaning or polishing if you want to keep the panels reasonably fresh-looking and to retain much of the original beauty of the natural wood grain.

title: ALONG THE BORDER BETWEEN CHURCH AND STATE
description: W ITH one public opinion poll showing that the vast majority of Americans favor prayer in the schools, it's perhaps not surprising that the distance between church and state seems to be narrowing as Election Day approaches. Appearing before the National Association of Evangelicals in Columbus, Ohio, last week, President Reagan hailed what he called ''a great national renewal'' that has seen Americans turn away from pornography, drug abuse and sexual promiscuity and turn ''back to God.'' What remained, he went on, was adoption of a constitutional amendment undoing the Supreme Court's 22-year-old ban. ''Hasn't something gone haywire when this great Constitution of ours is invoked to allow Nazis and Ku Klux Klansmen to march on public property,'' Mr. Reagan said, ''but it supposedly prevents our children from Bible study or the saying of a simple prayer in their schools?''

title: 2,300 HONOR RALPH AND ALICE AND ED AND TRIXIE
description: It was a scene that could have been taken from a major exhibition at a museum. All day long, people stood in line, waiting to look reverentially at ancient items in display cases.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''The interplay between performer and audience is like nothing else,'' says Lena Horne during her one-woman Broadway show. That live interplay is exactly what's missing from any televised version of any stage work.

title: The Mondale Mystery
description: That noise people are hearing in Massachusetts, Florida, Alabama, Georgia and elsewhere is the air hissing out of Fritz Mondale's tires. His machine rolled smoothly through the preliminaries, but then came the shocking blowout in New England. And now, as the campaign moves on to Super Tuesday, there's that hiss.

title: A NEW BREED OF DIRECTOR CHANGES THE FACE OF OPERA
description: A bout a century ago George Bernard Shaw noted with some vexation that stagings of Italian opera tended to be set in only one period - ''the past''- and two places - ''an exterior'' and ''an interior.'' He found in those performances ''sheer carelessness, lack of artistic conscience'' and the ''cynical conviction that nothing particularly matters in an opera so long as the singers draw good houses.'' Wagner, writing about the German Imperial Opera House, noted the same problems, referring to the ''piebald medley'' on stage, with virtuoso singers treating the rest of the opera as a ''superfluous adjunct.''

title: SATIRE IS BACK, BUT WITHOUT THE BITE
description: T wenty-odd years ago New York was simultaneously playing host to the Premise, the Second City, Lenny Bruce and, from Britain with bile, Dudley Moore and others in ''Beyond the Fringe.'' Social satire, political satire, every sort of satire seemed to be modestly thriving, and at a time when the world was rather happier than now and seemed less in need of that savage indignation which the poet Juvenal recommended to would-be members of the International Brotherhood of Parodists, Lampooners and Scurrilous Vituperators. The knives have occasionally been drawn since then - in 1973 by the National Lampoon, for instance, with its wickedly conceived Woodshuck Festival of Love, Peace and Death - but mostly they have been left to rust in their sheaths or handed over to television, which has proceeded to substitute bromide for venom at the end of the blade. So the coincidental convergence on New York of no less than three revues in recent days - ''Babalooney,'' ''Orwell That Ends Well,'' ''A . . . My Name Is Alice'' - raised nostalgic and more than nostalgic hopes. Might the odd shark or piranha turn out to be patrolling the serene theatrical waters?

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Self Service And Variety Conran's 10th American home-furnishings shop, which opened early in February in White Plains, offers fabrics, floor coverings, kitchenware, china, glassware, lamps, gift items, stationery, food and toys - all on open shelves for self-service selection with the help of shopping carts. It is in the part of White Plains that intersects with the town of Greenburgh near the County Center, but the sales tax throughout is kept at the city's rate.

title: AUTO-INDUSTRY PROFITS COULD MAKE CONTRACT TALKS COSTLY

title: CUTBACK CURTAILS WATCH ON WETLANDS

Hamilton, an official in the State Department of Environmental Conservation, accompanied one of the department's law enforcement officers to investigate a suspected discrepancy on a bulkhead project - a construction activity regulated under the agency's tidal wetlands program. The two men found that the property owner had indeed built the bulkhead farther offshore than his wetlands permit had authorized.

title: GOING PUBLIC WITH A PRIVATE DRAMA
description: THE first generation or two of readers who grew up under the spell of T. S. Eliot's poetry generally accepted Eliot's critical principles as well. Great art, he insisted, is essentially impersonal; there is a sharp distinction to be drawn, in his famous phrase, between the man who suffers and the mind that creates. From which it follows that a poem like ''The Waste Land'' can properly be approached as an indictment of modern culture or a picture of the human condition, but in no significant sense as a reflection of the author's purely personal experience.

title: YOUNG PEOPLE'S CONCERTS AT 60
description: A little over 60 years ago, on Jan. 24, 1924, the conductor Ernest Schelling inaugurated the New York Philharmonic's Young People's Concerts at the now defunct Aeolian Hall on West 43d Street. His expressed intention was ''to introduce children to the enjoyment of good music, to give them factual information about music and musicians, to stir their imaginations and open new horizons, and to make them music citizens of tommorrow.'' These concerts have become an integral part of New York musical life; the conductors who have led Young People's Concerts over the years include Bruno Walter, Leopold Stokowski, Michael Tilson Thomas and, of course, Leonard Bernstein. During Mr. Bernstein's tenure as music director of the Philharmonic, from 1958 until 1969, the concerts were televised nationwide. As such, there is a distinct possibility that Mr. Bernstein may be the most influential music teacher of all time, one with literally millions of former students.

title: MET OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN 'GIOVANNI'
description: Three artists who were not involved in this season's earlier Metropolitan Opera performances of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' have joined the cast. Swing a baguette on Montana Avenue in Santa Monica and you'll hit two rewrites and an adaptation of a novel by James M. Cain. On the other hand, in New York, it's hard to find three-hole typing paper, on which scripts are invariably typed. In Los Angeles the stuff is sold in kiosks, like newspapers and Lotto tickets.

title: THEATER: MIRROR REP, IN A REVIVAL OF 'RAIN'
description: It is late in the theatrical monsoon season to think of ''Rain'' as anything other than a potboiler, but anyone attempting to stage the old melodrama should at least keep the pot at a steady boil. The production at the Mirror Repertory Company is so studiously inept as to make one wonder what the director, John Strasberg, had in mind when he added it to the company's repertory (which also includes Odets's ''Paradise Lost'' and Susan Glaspell's ''Inheritors'').

title: JAPAN'S YOUTH SEEM OLD BEFORE THEIR TIME
description: The ''examination hell'' season just ended for Japanese students. Youngsters have stopped studying until they drop, preparing for tests that could lead to prestigious schools and good careers. But while students are enjoying the respite, many parents and teachers are considering whether this kind of education makes sense.

title: PANEL ON POVERTY TO LIST REMEDIES
description: NEW HAVEN This city can combat poverty in part by improving both the environment in which poor children grow up and the distribution of social services, a special commission has concluded.

title: Deborah Emerson to Wed David Pinkham in June
description: -2-14 Deborah Myers Emerson, a curatorial assistant in the 20th-century art department of the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, and David Struthers Pinkham, a teacher at the Shore Country Day School in Beverly, Mass., plan to be married in June.

title: PICASSO IN HIS LAST YEARS WAS BOTH WARRIOR AND VICTIM
description: T he time is right for Picasso's late paintings. More than 10 years have now passed since the death of an artist who often seemed too much with us. In addition, because of the Neo-Expressionist style that is unthinkable without late Picasso, we are now accustomed to seemingly clumsy figures and an apparently crude use of paint. Looking now at Picasso's quirky late paintings, where paint seems not so much to have been applied as rubbed or scribbled on the canvas, it is hard to remember that just three years ago the same paintings were, for many people, an anathema.

title: LAFFER: SIGNS OF HIS 'CURVE' IN THE RECOVERY
description: HE was the wunderkind economist of the Nixon Administration, then the guru behind California's 1978 ''tax revolt.'' But Arthur Laffer won fame, and the devotion of supply-side Reagan campaigners, with a parabolic curve first conceived 10 years ago - the story goes - on a napkin over lunch.

title: GRAHAM'S 'RITE OF SPRING' IS A CREATIVE TRIUMPH
description: T he theme of rebirth has been a dominant one in Martha Graham's dancing and choreography. There is something symbolically apt, then, in the crowning achievement with which she has just astounded us - her own version of Stravinsky's ecstatic hymn to renewal, ''The Rite of Spring.''

title: THE DEEPENING TROUBLES OF CHANCELLOR ALVARADO
description: Months ago, New York City Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado was reflecting on his days as superintendent in East Harlem's District 4, where he earned a reputation not only for educational innovation but for casual bookkeeping. There was nothing casual about it, he insisted. ''The fact is, we knew exactly what we were doing,'' Mr. Alvarado said. ''I used to say, 'We could go to jail, but we wouldn't go to hell.' ''

title: 'JUNO' DRAMATIZES IRISH TROUBLES
description: IF any good has come out of the ongoing troubles in Ireland, it would be found in the material proffered to Irishplaywrights. Sean O'Casey's ''Juno and the Paycock'' is not about the internal politics of Ireland per se, but the play's delineation of the breakup of the Boyle family is even more pronounced against its background of a deteriorating Ireland. This Irish tragedy, in which the action takes place in 1922, is the latest offering by the Arena Players Repertory Company of East Farmingdale.

title: CHINA'S QUIET COURTSHIP OF SOUTH KOREA

title: MAN WHO WAS SHOT INSIDE PENN STATION DIES OF HIS WOUND

title: FAMILY REUNION IN CHINA
description: Audrey Topping's description of her father's trip back to China was a thoroughly endearing tribute. She made her readers feel they were there. And, most of all, her family's story encapsulates what's best about Chinese and American relations - that we are at last free to be friends and renew the ties we always had. TRACYTURNER New York City

title:
FASHION PREVIEW;
READY FOR AUTUMN
description: IN THE ITALIAN READY-TO-WEAR collections for next fall and winter, which open in Milan today, the immediate visual impact is of unstructured tailoring, fabrics as lush and as soft as a cherished stuffed animal, leaner lines and fewer accessories. Perhaps the only extravagant detail is the exaggerated shoulders that are used to anchor dramatic, oversize coats tossed over jackets whose lapels are more likely to knot, wrap or tie than to just lie flat. Pair the coat and jacket with a slim, midcalf skirt - better still, a pair of pleated trousers - and that is the way Milanese designers see their woman for next winter.

title: CABARET: CAROL WOODS IN A DEBUT
description: Carol Woods, the blues and soul belter who has appeared in the Off Broadway musicals ''One Mo' Time'' and ''Taking My Turn,'' has a large, earthy voice with a sassy cutting edge that recalls both Dinah Washington and Nancy Wilson. Miss Woods, who appeared in the debut of a cabaret act on Tuesday at Sweetwater's, also has an emotional range that embraces a mischievous sensuality and a soaring pop-gospel emotionalism.

title: OWNING UP TO THE ABANDONED CAR MESS
description: Every seven minutes, someone abandons a car somewhere in New York City. On Manhattan streets, in wooded Queens parks, in secluded Staten Island swamps, abandoned vehicles ultimately become the city's responsibility. Since even a single derelict auto can give a neighborhood the look of a community under siege, untowed cars have become for many people a highly visible symbol of the city's struggle to meet its obligations.

SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
A NOVEL MIX OF YOUTH, PRIDE AND IDIOCY
description: AMONG the fondest memories of my Bronx childhood is St. Patrick's Day, 1968. The day, its parade and that general madness that attends late adolescence have combined this winter to provide the basis for a novel.

title: Psychiatrists And Drugs
description: Psychotherapeutic drugs, a survey shows, ''are grossly underutilized, resulting in unnecessary suffering and functional impairment,'' according to Arthur Rifkin, M.D., director of Mount Sinai's division of clinical psychopharmacological research (Letters to the Editor, Feb. 12). Thirty- seven years of psychiatric practice in office, hospital and clinic, including five and a half years as the clinical director of Brooklyn State Hospital, lead this author to exactly the opposite conclusion.

title: FOLK: 'BRAMBLE AND ROSE'

title:
NUMISMATICS;
WHO NEEDS THOSE FANCY MINT PACKAGES?
description: Packaging plays a major role in the marketing of almost every product these days, and coins are no exception. Government mints have placed increasing emphasis on colorful, elaborate packages for their special coins and coin sets. However, many hobbyists have come to the conclusion that much of this packaging is superfluous and simply serves as camouflage for overly inflated prices.

Now, as a result of an investigation at the small denominational college in Orange City, Iowa, McKinstrey and three other students have been forced to withdraw from school.

O'Rourke and members of Westchester's Board of Legislators were braving the snows of Albany, trying, in Mr. O'Rourke's words, ''to get as many of these items on the road as we can.''

title: THE POTATO TAKES CENTER STAGE AT PACE UNIVERSITY'S GALLERY
description: N OW, between winter and spring, is a good time to commemorate the potato, whose color and contour matches the landscape. The artists Gerard Renaldi and Shiela Zelermyer have gone further. They see the potato as nothing less than the carrier of civilization. With literally a ton of help from the Maine Potato Commission they have turned the Gallery at the Pace University campus in Briarcliff Manor into a lumpy meditation on humanity and society.

title:
Art;
CHARMS OF WATERCOLOR
description: The delights of the watercolor medium are many, but many, but so are its demands, as anyone who hs ever taken up the watercolorist's brush will agree. Among its charms are the wonderful range of tonal effects - from rich and intense to sparse and ephemeral - of which it is capable, and the textural variety it achieves by interaction with paper.

title: Elbow and Contract Hurting Candelaria
description: Two things are paining John Candelaria these days: his contract and his left elbow. And both are paining the Pittsburgh Pirates, because Candelaria is their best pitcher and they probably cannot afford to either fight him or trade him.

title: The Broken Plows of Africa
description: Africa needs emergency food aid, and quickly. The worst drought in this century has gripped a score of countries in southern Africa, threatening lives and stability. But weather isn't the only culprit. If Africa is to feed itself in years ahead, it also needs incentives to scrap a failed marketing system that in too many countries keeps farmers poor and granaries empty.

title: HEADLINERS
description: $40 Million? He'll Pass Steve Young , the Brigham Young University quarterback who has spent weeks trying to decide which professional football team he would allow to make him rich, concluded last week that the Los Angeles Express had his number.

title: Birdsong Out 4 Weeks
description: Otis Birdsong, the Nets' leading scorer, lost his place in the starting lineup recently. Now he will be out of the lineup up to four weeks because he suffered a severe sprain of his right wrist during the 122-118 loss to the Detroit Pistons Friday night in Pontiac, Mich.

title: Victors Over Cancer
description: Curtis Bill Pepper's article ''The Victors: Patients Who Conquered Cancer,'' Jan. 29, reaffirmed many things that I have observed watching my son's recovery from cancer. It is nice to see a body of evidence developing to support the ''intangibles'' of the recovery process. I think this information will help all of us in facing illness in the future. CATHERINE HEALY, Baldwin, N.Y.

title: FILIPINOS, RECALLING '41, IN NEW DOUBT ON U.S.
description: Like thousands of Filipinos of his generation, Juan Ponce Enrile, now 60 years old, fought the Japanese occupiers of the Philippines during World War II as a guerrilla. Eventually he was captured and turned over to the Japanese secret police, who tortured him.

title: MUSI
description: C: DEBUTS IN REVIE W

title:
ABOUT MEN;
END OF A LINE
description: THERE WERE PEOPLE IN OUR NEIGHBORHOOD who thought my father was a widower, he spent so much time with his son. ''You don't know how much ribbing I took for wheeling a baby around in a carriage,'' he told me recently. But wheel he did, and much more. He coached teams I played on as a little kid and even assisted the coaches of my high school and summer baseball teams. He was a favorite chaperone for church- group trips and dances. I never felt crowded by his presence, and as I grew older, I appreciated the attention and genuine interest he showed in me and my friends and our accomplishments. Later, visiting the homes of college friends, I was quickly struck by the absence of their fathers, not to mention the resentment it had caused. My main excuse for putting off children until my late 30's was that my own life was not settled enough to allow me to spend as much time with my own children as my father had spent with me. I never imagined not having a son. In fact, I grew up feeling sorry for men without sons.

title: TEA MEETINGS: AFTERNOON OPTION
description: Mario Budwig of London and Ralph E. Schulz of Burlingame, Calif., were sitting in the Rotunda of the Pierre Hotel the other afternoon engrossed in conversation. It was a somewhat unusual setting for a business meeting, an oval room with an aura of romance, its ceiling painted to resemble a blue sky with fluffy white clouds and its curved walls covered with murals of pastoral scenes. The only sounds were the murmurs emanating from other tables and the gentle clink of china. It was, in several words, serene, tranquil and civilized.

description: Broadcast TV

description: After reading Robert Dodd's article, ''When Petunias Beckon, Just Wave Back'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 29), I could not resist sending in this poem. I call it: BOTANICAL BALONEY

title: VICTORS OVER CANCER
description: I believe I read Curtis Bill Pepper's article with greater understanding than most other readers. I, too, am a cancer survivor; however, no one knows how long that may be.

description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title: ARTISTRY TRANSFORMS THE FOLK SONG
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about recordings.

title: ATOM DISASTER EVACUATION TEST SURVIVES 'GLITCHES'
description: Federal, state and local officials exchanged praise at a critique here today of the first full-scale field test of the Government's draft plan for handling a disaster at a nuclear power plant. However, they said, the exercise suffered from ''glitches.''

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS A Camel Who Walked Miles
description: PAMELA CAMEL. By Bill Peet. (Houghton Mifflin, $11.95.) This tale is in Bill Peet's best tradition - a cheerfully told, villain-less fable about personal growth and bravery.

title: A TUNER UNDERGOES A TORTURE TEST
description: M y inbred parsimony bridles at the thought of a single component costing more than most people spend on a complete stereo system, especially if I must concede that in some situations it's worth all that money. This is clearly the case with Tandberg's Model 3001A, which has been somewhat immodestly heralded as the world's best FM tuner.

title: FAMILY REUNION IN CHINA
description: Audrey Topping's article confirms the impressions we had of Ambassador Chester Ronning when my wife and I had the pleasure of receiving him and his daughter Meme at our home in Washington in February 1971. He is a man of wisdom, filled with compassion and imbued with a penetrating sense of humor.

title: STORE CLOSING IMPEDES ELDERLY SHOPPERS
description: T HREE times a week, Rose Ferro of the Garth Road section of Eastchester sets out to do her marketing. If it is mild and dry, she walks the mile to the Shopwell food store in the village of Scarsdale, passing a dark and empty C-Town Supermarket on her way. At Shopwell, she will buy only the few items she can carry home in one bag, because Rose Ferro is 85 years old and physically not very strong.

title: New York Congressmen Called Solid for Mondale
description: Support for Walter F. Mondale among New York members of the House of Representatives who will be delegates at the Democratic National Convention remains solid despite recent victories by Senator Gary Hart of Colorado.

title: Blaze on Cruise Ship Forces 946 to Flee
description: A fire aboard a cruise ship burned out of control today, a day after the blaze broke out five miles from shore, cutting short a gambling excursion and forcing the ship to return to port with 946 people aboard.

title: Dining Out; A VISTA OF TWINKLING LIGHTS
description: I T may not be Windows on the World, but Burgundy's, the restaurant that opened last October in the North Shore Towers apartment

title: ANNISTON, ALA., VOTERS FOCUS ON HART'S STYLE, NOT ON HIS ISSUES
description: It was a quiet afternoon and the two bookstore clerks had time to chat about the Democratic primary in Alabama next Tuesday.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN ANNADALE-HUGUENOT
description: NESTLED together on the South Shore bordering Raritan Bay, the Staten Island communities of Annadale and Huguenot have many things in common: a tough commute to Manhattan, large tracts of woodland populated by the frequent pheasant, a dearth of sidewalks and sewers, alternately muddy-dusty-muddy roadways, and people putting up houses worth anywhere from $275,000 to $750,000.

title: No"el F. Caraccio Wed To Kenneth R. Wolff
description: No"el Frances Caraccio, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sal L. Caraccio of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kenneth Robert Wolff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wolff of Harrison, N.Y. Msgr. Daniel V. Flynn and Rabbi Albert Sturmer performed the ceremony at the Convent of the Holy Child in Rye.

title: THE MARKET'S FEAR OF A HOT ECONOMY
description: Wall Street appeared convinced that the economy was growing fast enough to make higher interest rates inevitable. In anticipation of credit demand exceeding supply, rates staged a major upward move, with long-bond yields hitting their highest levels since September 1982. Buyers all but disappeared. Economists have feared that the heated pace of economic expansion in January would continue into February, putting pressure on inflation and prompting the Federal Reserve to slow the growth by raising interest rates. Those fears were heightened on Friday as the Government reported that unemployment had again fallen to 7.7 percent in February from 7.9 percent in January and that the economy was strong enough to absorb 700,000 new jobs. Adding to the concern, the Council of Economic Advisers chairman, Martin S. Feldstein, predicted that first- quarter inflation-adjusted growth would be 6 percent, or much greater than the slowdown that was expected when the year began. Stocks were also battered for most of the week by interest rate fears. On very low trading volume, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.72 points, to 1,139.76. And even a $1.5 billion drop in the money supply did not cheer investors because it wasn't as large as they had expectd.

title: HOFSTRA SPONSORS EISENHOWER STUDY
description: Dozens of scholars, generals and former government officials will gather at Hofstra University at the end of the month for the most ambitious evaluation of Dwight David Eisenhower in more than two decades.

description: Peter Frank is a poet, critic and curator. His ''Something Else Press: An Annotated Bibliography'' was published in 1983. A NOT-SO-STILL LIFE

description: Spain is inching toward a decision on one of the most delicate foreign policy matters it has faced in recent years: diplomatic recognition of Israel.

description: BOARD members of New York cooperative apartment buildings find that the question of real-estate taxes is never far from their minds. They need to monitor assessments constantly, whether the building was converted a year or a decade ago.

description: SAN FRANCISCO ''IT'S going to be a busy few weeks,'' George M. Keller said as he relaxed in an over- stuffed chair in his San Francisco office.

description: Michael Billington writes frequently about theater in London.

description: At Little Falls, a tiny community near the center of New York, the Mohawk River turns to rapids, tumbling over jagged rocks as it winds its way toward the Hudson. When David Goodman looks at the topography, he sees energy and economic opportunity.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: A SENSE of anxiety about his family's future has plagued Douglas Nogaki for nearly two and a half years, he says, and it all stems from what he calls a minor incident involving two youths and the performance of his job.

title: MUSIC: ERIC ROSS, SERIAL PLUS JAZZ
description: In the two pieces he presented Monday at Roulette, the composer Eric Ross sought to combine the detailed ordering of serial music with the emotional range of jazz improvisation. ''Electronic Suite'' and ''Variations,'' two duets, came out as a sort of Stockhausenlike organized anarchy - a carefully textured flow of sounds with bits of thematic material bobbing around the surface.

title: THE NATION
description: Socal Plans a Merger Splurge

title: TEACHING KIDNEY-STONE SURGERY
description: HELEN DAVITT has undergone major surgery twice for kidney stones. Both times, she remembers waking up feeling as if she were going to die. Her husband, Harold, recalls being afraid he was going to lose her. Recently, the kidney stones grew back, and Mrs. Davitt faced surgery again. This time the surgery was different.

title: Young's Pact Beyond Reason
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CHRONICLE OF A DEATH FORETOLD, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Ballantine, $3.50.) Winner of the Nobel Prize for literature in 1982, Gabriel Garcia Marquez is a character in this "very strange and brilliantly conceived" novel, "a sort of metaphysical murder mystery" that reconstructs events associated with the death of a rich, handsome fellow who lived many years ago in the Caribbean town where the author grew up. "The subject of the novel is the unthinkable," Leonard Michaels said in his review. "As more and more is revealed about the murder, less and less is known." THE PRINTING REVOLUTION IN EARLY MODERN EUROPE, by Elizabeth L. Eisenstein. (Cambridge University Press, $9.95.) An abridged version of Elizabeth L. Eisenstein's two-volume 1979 work, "The Printing Press as an Agent of Change," which Raymond A. Sokolov reviewed, this handsome paperback has additional illustrations and no footnotes. The author, a professor of history at the University of Michigan, supports her "general themes with specific proof and fascinating details" as she examines "the role of the press as a crucial and active force in the shaping of early modern life."

title: THE OTHER GIACOMETTI
description: Michael Brenson is an art critic and reporter for The New York Times.

title: Miss Geoghegan Planning to Wed T. H. Bedecarre
description: -1-18, 3 lines cut Margaret Kathryn Geoghegan, an assistant account executive at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, New York, plans to be married in June to Thomas Hamilton Bedecarre, an account executive for Ogilvy & Mather, also in Neww York.

title: A CONTRARY FORMULA FOR PICKING STOCKS
description: ON Wall Street, the life of a contrarian can be a lonely one, constantly bucking the crowd and getting little peer support. But last year one contrarian investment firm, Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, found itself with many supporters and few scoffers.

description: The farmers of the Aladi Production Brigade look little different from the Han Chinese of other Manchurian villages set in the low brown hills north of the city of Jilin.

description: ELIZABETH KOLBERT is an American writer who lives in Hamburg.

description: With the first office building in Glenpointe Centre in Teaneck, N.J., more than 70 percent leased, the developer of the mixed-use project, Alfred Sanzari, has broken ground for a second one, Glenpointe West.

title: THE WORLD
description: Ottawa Wins On Offshore Oil

title: Pact Signed, Award Tops It
description: A jury decided to award Douglas Powell, a former railroad brakeman, $1.2 million in a personal injury suit minutes after he decided to settle for $350,000. Mr. Powell signed the settlement Wednesday before he learned of the award. He had sued the Missouri-Pacific Railroad Company for $2.5 million, charging that it was negligent in 1978 when a pallet fell off a railroad car and struck him at Odem, Tex. The case had gone to the jury when he decided to take the $350,000.

title: FOR RURAL CLINTON, A $200 MILLION COMPLEX
description: CLINTON TOWNSHIP lies in the part of New Jersey's rural core where soft hills and white church steeples closely resemble the New England countryside.

title:
speaking personally;
THE SIREN SONG OF GARDENIA CREME SOAP
description: W E all read about Caribbean cruises at this time of year, journeys to little islands with enticements: sunlight, awninged palm trees, permanent-press waves, libidinous sand dunes, pink lobster bisques. Promises. Temptations. Good packaging. Yet, I am an Ivory Soap type. I like plain wrappings, squared-off shapes, straight suds without perfume. It isn't even the bargain price that appeals to me; it is the directness of an honest product.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: BECAUSE environmental education has not been made part of the general curriculum in New Jersey's public schools, and because such education is the object of annual budget cutbacks in the state's Department of Environmental Protection, environmental schooling is often up to individual school boards, principals and teachers.

description: INCIDENTAL MUSIC

title: Arizona Nuclear Plant Delays Start for a Year
description: The Arizona Public Service Company has announced another one-year delay in starting up the first reactor at its Palo Verde Nuclear Power Generating Station west of Phoenix.

title: Alicia Castilla Marries Mark Zelek in Florida
description: -1-14, 2 lines The marriage of Alicia Margarita Castilla and Mark Edward Zelek, alumni of the Columbia University School of Law, took place yesterday at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Coral Gables, Fla. The Rev. John McHugh, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. George P. Cardona.

title: COUNTRY-ROCK: JERRY WALKER
description: Jerry Jeff Walker embodies the dual nature of country-rock, which developed in Texas in the 1970's as an alternative to Nashville's pop formulas. The ''outlaw'' school to which Mr. Walker belongs sought to revive pre- Nashville styles such as raw barroom honky tonk and Western swing.

title: WHAT,EXACTLY, IS A JAZZ SINGER?
description: T he use of the word ''jazz'' to identify a form of music has been a controversial point ever since the connection was first made almost 70 years ago. Then, ''jazz,'' which had a vulgar sexual connotation, was applied derogatorily by musicians in Chicago to the performances of a band from New Orleans in an effort to turn Chicago audiences against the Southerners. But the New Orleans musicians turned the tables by proudly proclaiming themselves a ''jazz band'' and the word, as a musical reference, caught on.

title: IRAQ'S GUNS GET PRIORITY OVER BUTTER
description: Iraq, in the fourth year of the war with Iran, has clearly broken with its earlier economic aims.

title: REPERTORY TAKES ROOT - AND FEEDS BROADWAY; BOSTON$
description: TOS F ive years ago, Robert Brustein pulled up stakes from New Haven, where he had in 1966 transformed the Yale Drama School from a graduate program into a conservatory and founded the Yale Repertory Theater, and started over in Cambridge, Mass. Occupying the Loeb Drama Center at Harvard, he brought with him from Yale a core staff and some of the company and, most important, an ideal of creating a resident professional acting ensemble performing new plays and classics in rotating repertory.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEATED
description: Slowly, shift by shift, period by period, the Rangers appear to have their game on the rebound. Less than 24 hours after snapping a four-game losing streak with a victory in Winnipeg, they turned in their most impressive performance in nearly a month tonight with a 3-2 victory over the Edmonton Oilers.

title: THE WORLD
description: Cultists Riot In Nigeria

title: ART NOUVEAU WITH AN ODD PEDIGREE
description: L ouis Comfort Tiffany's lamps and other Art Nouveau objects were at the center of the volatile art market of the last decade. They attracted serious collectors, more than a score of investors - and a drug smuggler. All of these buyers vied for these turn-of-the-century stained- glass lamps, flower-form vases, organic bronzes and curvaceous furniture, causing prices to rocket to stratospheric levels.

title: STORY BASED ON DANTE CANTO
description: ''Francesca da Rimini,'' the best- known of Riccardo Zandonai's eight operas, derives its story from Canto V of Dante's ''Inferno,'' as retold in Gabriele D'Annunzio's 1902 tragedy. There are some 30 operas on the subject as well as orchestral versions, of which the most famous is Tchaikovsky's tone poem.

title: A BRONX COALITION ASSISTS TEEN-AGE MOTHERS
description: Theresa was 14 years old when she became pregnant. She had wanted to go to college. She had dreams of becoming a lawyer. When she gave birth to a son at 15, she said, ''I thought my life was over.''

title: ELEGANT BRONX MANSION TO REOPEN FOR AGED POOR
description: When Andrew Freedman, a self- made millionaire, died 69 years ago, he left $5 million to build a residence in the Bronx where once-wealthy individuals could live graciously despite their declining fortunes.

title: Montclair State Beaten by Upsala
description: James Gist scored 22 points and Roosevelt Peoples added 14 and the winning basket with 5 seconds left as Upsala beat Montclair State, 57-56, tonight in a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III quarterfinal basketball game.

title: Elizabeth Vaughn Engaged to Wed L. L. Hlavacek Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Warren Vaughn of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Warner Vaughn, to Lawrence L. Hlavacek Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hlavacek of Pennington, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: New Jersey Leader Foresees Dead Heat
description: James F. Maloney, the New Jersey Democratic chairman, says the race for the state's 122 Democratic National Convention delegates appears to be ''a dead heat'' between Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota and Senator Gary Hart of Colorado.

title: POP: JASON AND THE SCORCHERS
description: In true honky-tonk style, Jason and the Scorchers stomped and twanged and yodeled through its set Thursday at Irving Plaza. The four-man band from Nashville harnesses the best parts of country tradition - its directness, its irreverence and its casual delivery - to the untrammeled drive of rock.

title: BERLINERS HAIL TOGETHERNESS AND JESSE OWENS
description: The City of West Berlin honored the memory of Jesse Owens today by naming an avenue for him outside the stadium where he astonished Hitler's Germany and the world by winning four Olympic gold medals in 1936.

title: No Beats
description: To the Editor:

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Unusual punishment was ordered in Federal District Court in Lincoln, Neb., last July after a highway construction company pleaded guilty to bid rigging. The company was ordered to donate $1,475,000 to endow a professorship in ethics at the University of Nebraska.

title: Winter Games Lacked a Hero
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LIETZKE AND ARCHER TIED FOR DORAL LEAD
description: Bruce Lietzke, who won last week's Honda Classic on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff with Andy Bean, predicted today that the PGA Tour will have its sixth Sunday playoff of the year to decide the winner in the 23d annual Doral- Eastern Open.

title:
GARDENING;
STARTING A PLANT FROM THE SEED
description: WHILE commercial greenhouses grow a wide range of annual flower and vegetable varieties, there are several reasons why a gardener might wish to grow at least some of his own.

title: DINING A LA TURNPIKE TO CHANGE
description: N EXT year, Howard Johnson's lease with the state to run 10 restaurants on the Connecticut Turnpike expires. Already, state officials have been ''besieged'' by national food concerns wanting to take over the operation and change it drastically, said Edward M. Archibald, an assistant chief administrative officer in the State Department of Transportation.

title: BUDGET SEASON IN ALBANY: CUOMO VS. REAGAN
description: Last month Governor Cuomo was arguing with the Attorney General, Robert Abrams, who had challenged Mr. Cuomo's plan for betting on professional sports. Now Mr. Cuomo is in a feud with the Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, over Mr. Regan's comments on the proposed state budget.

title: BEST SELLERS March 11, 1984Fiction 1 1
description: THE ACQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $17.95.) A lawyer finds himself caught in a conspiracy to take over the world. 2119 PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. 325 SMART WOMEN, by Judy Blume. (Putnam, $15.95.) title: SCHOOL VISIT FOR REAGAN
description: -President Reagan will visit Congress Heights Elementary School here Monday, the White House has announced. The President will visit a computer classroom, donate books to the library and speak to the students in the auditorium, the announcement said Friday.

title: BOYER DECRIES TEACHER STATUS
description: ''IT'S ALMOST heartbreaking,'' said Dr. Ernest L. Boyer. He was describing the scene at the exclusive Dalton School in New York City, where hundreds of teachers from public and private schools gathered on a rainy Saturday last November to receive $300 cash prizes and a bit of recognition for their exemplary teaching programs.

title: Marcia Eisenberg a Bride
description: Marcia Eisenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Eisenberg of New York, was married yesterday to Dan Arthur Kusnetz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kusnetz of Houston. Rabbi Kenneth Hain performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I. The bride and bridegroom are both lawyers, she with the New York law firm of De Vos & Company and he with Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood.

title: SPECIAL-INTEREST GROUPS ARE USING THE POWER OF TV
description: Richard Lacayo often reports on the television industry.

title: Everton and Watford Gain Soccer Semifinals
description: Everton and Watford reached the semifinals of the English Football Association Cup soccer competition today.

title: OUTSIDER, INSIDERS
description: Slamming the Door

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A MOVE THAT WAS PREDICTABLE
description: ''STUNNED,'' ''shocked'' and ''confused'' is how LTV and Republic Steel executives described themselves after the Justice Department vetoed their proposed merger. If that shock is genuine, they should supplement their high-priced lawyers with a high school student who can read and do simple arithmetic. For the merger involved such large market shares that even former Assistant Attorney General William Baxter's relaxed 1982 guidelines for acceptable mergers were violated.

title: THE COLLAPSE OF LEBANON'S ARMY: U.S. SAID TO IGNORE FACTIONALISM
description: In the 14 months that the United States trained the Lebanese Army, American military officers and diplomats in Beirut warned repeatedly that the new army was in danger of failing because of religious factional disputes. But officials in Washington say they chose to let the Lebanese cope with the problem themselves.

title: POSTINGS ; MELDING DESIGN AND PLANNING
description: The theory and practice of urban design and how it relates to public and private projects will be the focus of a two-day conference in Hartford on Tuesday and Wednesday that is expected to draw 200 architects, city planners and design professionals from around the country as well as interested laymen.

title: FIRE I. VEHICLE RULES PONDERED
description: ALTHOUGH there are no roads on Fire Island, the broad ocean beach presents a natural highway to the owners of off-road vehicles. A fair policy for maintaining strict protection of the fragile seashore environment, while still allowing vehicles to travel on the beach, has been sought since 1964, when the Fire Island National Seashore was established.

title: HANNAH WEINSTEIN, PRODUCER AND POLITICAL ACTIVIST, IS DEAD
description: Hannah Weinstein, a Hollywood film producer and a political activist, died of a heart attack Friday at her home on Park Avenue. She was 72 years old.

title: Long Islanders ; TYING IN BUILDING AND INVENTING
description: '' WHAT I do most,'' said Gene Balin of Locust Valley, ''is think.'' Ever since his teen- age years in the Bronx during the Depression, when his dreams centered on ways of coming by enough money to take a girl out for an ice cream soda, Mr. Ballin has been an inventor. Along the way, he has also been a developer who, he said, ''built thousands of houses along the South Shore,'' generally under the name Waterview Homes, from Atlantic Beach to Bellmore.

title: BASS HATCHERY AIDS NATURE
description: THE summer haunts of the striped bass remain stilled by winter. Beaches along the South Shore and around Montauk and Orient Points to Long Island Sound are just beginning to shed their winter ice. John (Boog) Powell, the former major league star, has a special reason for wanting the police in Key West, Fla., to find the burglar who took $26,000 worth of his possessions from his home there Wednesday night. Judge Harry Claiborne asked Justice Rehnquist Friday to stop the felony trial so the full Court could consider his argument that judges are immune from prosecution unless they have been removed from office. Judge Claiborne, the chief Federal judge in Nevada, was indicted Dec. 8, 1983, charged with accepting $30,000 from Joseph Conforte, the brothel owner.

title: RESTORING THE LLOYD'S OF LONDON MYSTIQUE
description: Godfrey Hodgson is a writer who lives in England. This article is adapted from his book ''Lloyd's of London: A Reputation at Risk,'' to be published in June by The Viking Press. BETWEEN LONDON BRIDGE AND THE TOWER, IN the oldest part of the City of London, the bit that still seems to smell of the sea, is the insurance capital of the world. Here, a stone's throw from the Bank of England and the other financial icons of the city, are clustered the offices of nearly every insurance enterprise of any size in the world - all drawn there by the long, low building on Lime Street. This is Lloyd's, where all the perils of the world, its storms and fires and floods and earthquakes, and every possible man-made calamity are systematically reduced to manageable routine. These perils are chopped up and shared out so that instead of being an unbearable risk for a few, they are a small risk for many and thus lose their terror. That is the fundamental idea of insurance: to make risks bearable by sharing them around. Lloyd's is the place where marine insurance has been written for 300 years (the earliest surviving reference to ''Mr. Edward Lloyd's coffeehouse in Tower Street'' dates to 1688), and it was around that primal function that other insurance markets have grown up.

title: MUSIC: FESTIVAL OF MODERNS OPENS IN CALIFORNIA

By now, the Cal Arts festival has become one of the most important in the country, offering a vital alternative to the fast-fading austerities of Northeastern academic rationalism. The closest Eastern equivalent would probably be Tanglewood's week of contemporary music or the Juilliard School's contemporary music festival, which seem sadly unfocused and unimaginative by comparison.

description: Citro"en, a member of the Peugeot S.A. auto group, has proposed a cut of about 6,000 of its 43,000 jobs. Last month, company officials indicated that 3,500 jobs would be eliminated through early retirement.

title: Miss Johnson Wins by 5
description: Chris Johnson, playing bogey-free golf for 53 of the tournament's final 55 holes, fired a par 72 today to win the $150,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Samaritan Turquoise Classic by five strokes from Patty Hayes.

title: IMPROVING INDUSTRY'S IMAGE
description: Convinced that misleading and untruthful political advertising contributes to the negative image of all advertising, the American Association of Advertising Agencies has initiated a program for monitoring it coast to coast and on all levels.

title: TRIAL OVER X-CARS OPENS THIS WEEK
description: Trial of a civil suit brought by the Justice Department is scheduled to begin in Federal District Court this week. In the suit, the United States seeks more than $4 million in penalties from the General Motors Corporation, which is charged with building 1.1 million defective 1980 X-cars.

title: Carolina Party 'Favors' Jackson as Favorite Son
description: State Democratic leaders voted Saturday to ''favor'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson as a favorite-son Presidential candidate, but they did not give the Greenville native a full-fledged endorsement.

title: 2 Arizona Fugitives Sought; One May Be in New York Area
description: A search for two Arizona fugitives who are suspected of shooting an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation is being carried out in the Washington and New York metropolitan areas.

title: Bridge: 3 New York Stars Win Share Of Titles in Spring Nationals
description: Two major titles were decided here Saturday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals, and the four winners included three of New York's best-known personalities.

title: Fasting and Crucifixes Hold Poland's Attention
description: Seven Roman Catholics resumed a hunger strike today to protest Cardinal Jozef Cardinal Glemp's transfer of a parish priest to a rural area.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Avco Corp., Greenwich, Conn., filed for a shelf registration covering up to $100 million of unsecured senior or subordinated debt securities.

title: N. CAROLINA STATE SELECTED FOR N.I.T.
description: North Carolina State, last year's National Collegiate Athletic Association champion, was one of first teams selected yesterday to the 32-team National Invitation Tournament field.

title: FOR CITY SALONS, LONG ISLAND RIVAL
description: The customers often know one another, bring their babies and chat in the waiting area, but there the resemblance to the suburban beauty shop ceases. Nubest & Company, the largest salon on Long Island, draws its clientele not only from Montauk to Queens, but also from Westchester and Connecticut, and even competes with big-name salons in Manhattan. One draw is that its prices are reasonable, but its services are extensive and far above the usual level one expects so far away from Madison Avenue.

title: PHILLIES TURN TO YOUTH
description: ''It ticks me off,'' Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies was saying. ''Last year, they picked us for fourth place because we were too old. This year, they pick us for fourth because we're too young.''

title: MURDOCH'S EMPIRE DIVERSE IN AUSTRALIA
description: Rupert Murdoch, whose wealth of almost $240 million recently earned him the distinction of being the richest man in Australia, has not set foot in his homeland for more than a year.

title: SCOUTING'S VIDEO AGE: PLAY IT AGAIN, COACH
description: BARBARA MAHONEY was immediately aware of the consequences of the birthday gift she gave her husband, Brian, last December. She had been married to a basketball coach for too long to have any doubts. For two years, cable television had been available to the residents of Rockville Centre, L.I. For all that time, Brian Mahoney, an assistant coach at St. John's University, wanted the cable installed in their home. His wife said nothing doing.

title: TREASURY ISSUES SKIMPY THIS WEEK
description: Government securities dealers face another week without new issues of Treasury notes or bonds, though auctions are scheduled for bills due in 3, 6 and 12 months. The lack of note and bond auctions since Feb. 28 has not prevented prices from falling, and market participants are well aware that the Treasury will re-emerge as a major borrower later this month.

title: Overcharging On Phone Bills
description: Seven of eight major long-distance phone companies overcharge customers for the length of time they talk on the telephone, and six are charging for unconnected calls, a study concluded. The report, released today by Consumer's Checkbook and based on 2,000 calls made through eight long-distance phone companies, found that Western Union's ''Metrofone'' billed for 32 percent of ''no answers,'' ''busys'' and other uncompleted calls, and that the International Telephone and Telegraph Company's ''Niteline'' service did not charge at all for calls lasting under 30 seconds.

title: Mr. Meese's Answers Are Inadequate
description: While Edwin Meese has rested his case for Senate confirmation as Attorney General, troublesome questions remain about his fitness for one of the nation's loftiest positions of trust.

title: Wounded Woman Reported Stable
description: A Connecticut woman remained in stable condition in New York Hospital last night after she was shot in the arm Saturday while riding in a car on the Bruckner Expressway in the Bronx, officials said.

title: THE NIGHT THAT 38 STOOD BY AS A LIFE WAS LOST
description: It flashes through Margaret Swinchoski's mind, each time she walks past the Kew Gardens, Queens, train station: This was where Kitty Genovese met her killer.

title: Jason Kuschner Wed To Andrea L. Haring
description: Andrea Lynn Haring, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Jack Haring of Princeton Junction, N.J., was married yesterday to Jason Charles Kuschner, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Kuschner of Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Richard Leonard of All Souls Unitarian Church in Manhattan performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: American Envoy, Just Back, Meets Gromyko in Moscow
description: The American Ambassador to Moscow, Arthur A. Hartman, just back here from talks in Washington on the new leadership in the Kremlin, met today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: Purdue 63 Minnesota 62
description: Jim Rowinski's 19 points helped Purdue finish in a tie for the Big Ten title with Illinois.

title: A CABLE GROUP'S SIGNAL IS NOTHING IF NOT DIRECT
description: Sometimes the shortest distance between two points is not a straight line.

title: Greenland Backs Terms In Common Market Exit
description: Greenland has approved the terms set for its withdrawal from the European Common Market, ending a two-year battle for control over its lucurative fishing waters.

title: MUSIC: CONTINUUM
description: WISDOM, the music of Arvo Part seems to tell us, is not a process of accumulation but simply a throwing away of what we don't need. The orchestra and soloists of Continuum led by Joel Sachs brought us this message of simplicity and repose in an evening of Mr. Part's music Saturday at Alice Tully Hall.

title: DELOREAN JURY PANEL TO FACE QUESTIONS ON SURVEY RESULTS
description: Armed with the results of a 42-page questionnaire, a Federal district court is ready to begin face-to-face questioning of jurors Tuesday for the cocaine conspiracy trial of John Z. DeLorean.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.94

title: WHEN A SON OR DAUGHTER IS A HOMOSEXUAL
description: Several months after Gloria Back told her son that he had to seek psychiatric help to reverse his homosexuality or be barred from her home, he phoned her to ask, ''Are you still my mother?''

title: Professor Seeks John Lennon Papers
description: In a case that could change the way the Government handles secret information, a California professor will ask a judge Monday to order the Federal Bureau of Investigation to explain why some files on John Lennon remain classified for ''national security'' reasons.

title: Moves by Houston Gas
description: The Houston Natural Gas Corporation said its board had approved steps aimed at increasing the value of its stock and discouraging unwelcome tender offers. A spokesman, A. Hardie Davis, said on Friday that the company had not been approached by any companies interested in a merger since it and the Coastal Corporation agreed last month to end their hostile offers for each other's shares.

title: MCDONALD'S IS BATTLING WITH BLACK FRANCHISEE
description: Charles Griffis came to California in 1977 when he heard he might be able to buy a McDonald's franchise in Santa Barbara. He had completed a training program for the restaurant chain, but was operating his own gasoline station in Michigan at the time.

title: Washington Watch; Reagan Panel's Industrial View
