description: WASHINGTON

title: ; CREDIT CARDS SURCHARGES: LET THE GOUGER BEWARE
description: To the Editor:

title: MORE SEE RATE-RISE PRESSURE
description: The credit markets seem increasingly convinced that pressures are building in the economy for higher interest rates but not so high that the economic recovery would end soon.

title: CORPORATE-GIANT LIST CHANGES
description: Vigorous economic growth throughout 1983 has shaken up the rankings of the nation's 25 largest nonfinancial corporations. And, as a result of regulatory changes and merger decisions, the list of America's biggest companies is almost certain to undergo even more dramatic change this year.

title: SPORT WORLD SPECIALS
description: Happy Alternatives

title: ABOUT BOSTON
description: Once a year he comes out of his splendid seclusion in the gold-domed Statehouse, down from the hushed Senate chamber where he is the highest paid and arguably the most powerful state legislator in the country.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, MARCH 12, 1984
description: Companies

title: Officer and Suspect Wounded In Central Park West Gunfight
description: A police sergeant and the man he was chasing wounded each other in a running gun battle along Central Park West early yesterday, the police said.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Somewhat Tall Story

title: FOR SOVIET EXPERTS, A FADING DREAM
description: For almost two decades, the dream of Soviet experts in the Foreign Service has been for one of their own to be at the right hand of the Secretary of State and to have influence with the President. To them and to many outside scholars of Soviet affairs, having diplomats such as George F. Kennan, Charles E. Bohlen, and Llewelyan E. Thompson - the major advisers on Soviet affairs after World War II - is necessary to put American policy toward the Soviet Union back on a steady course.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS PROPOSE TALKS OVER NAMIBIA
description: -West Africa, March 11 - South Africa today proposed the convening of a regional peace conference on South-West Africa that would include the rebels fighting for control over the territory.

title: JOB RECRUITER GETS RECRUITED HIMSELF
description: Carl W. Menk, the executive job recruiter, has himself been recruited.

title: BRIEFING
description: That Sinking Feeling

title: Petro-Lewis Withdrawals
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, a troubled oil and gas company that is one of the nation's largest sponsors of oil income funds, said more investors had sought to withdraw their funds in February than in any previous month. Not all of them will be immediately compensated, it said.

title: LETERMAN AIDE LOSES A JOB
description: Calvert DeForest now knows the wages of stardom.

title: Market Place; Fluctuations In Oil Stocks
description: OIL shares were much in the news last week, and this week promises more of the same. Last Monday, the Gulf Corporation, as expected, got a buyout bid from one of its suitors. But after the initial euphoria subsided, so did the price of Gulf's stock. Standard Oil of California agreed to buy Gulf for $13.2 billion, or $80 a share, in what would rank as the biggest merger ever.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: T. S. ELIOT: A Study in Character and Style. By Ronald Bush. 287 pages. Oxford University Press. $25.

title: Jets 6, Nordiques 5
description: Morris Lukowich scored his second goal of the game to tie the score for Winnipeg with one minute left in regulation time, then helped set up Dale Hawerchuk for the shot that beat Quebec in overtime.

title: Housing Help From Mr. T
description: Crashing through doors to fight

title: BROTHER SHIFTED
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria shuffled his Cabinet today and named three new Vice Presidents that included his younger brother.

title: SCRANTON BIDS FAREWELL TO BISHOP O'CONNOR
description: Thousands of people made their way through steadily falling snow here today to bid an emotional farewell to Bishop John J. O'Connor, who will be installed next week as the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York.

title: Medal Captures Title on Knockout
description: Mark Medal of Jersey City won the vacant International Boxing Federation's junior middleweight title today by stopping previously unbeaten Earl Hargrove of Philadelphia in the fifth round of their scheduled 15-rounder.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Leader Criticizes Hart
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.- C.I.O, said Saturday that Gary Hart had not brought any truly new ideas to his Presidential campaign.

title: JACKSON,TRUMAN WIN
description: Springfield Gardens, the defending Public Schools Athletic League basketball champion, could not overcome a slow start and poor rebounding yesterday and lost by 77-71 to Andrew Jackson in the A division semifinals at St. John's University.

title: NICKLAUS IS SECOND
description: Playing the final nine of a $400,000 golf tournament in a close struggle with Jack Nicklaus is good cause for a serious case of the jitters. But Tom Kite, who may be getting used to it, said, ''I was as calm today as I have ever been going down to the wire of a golf tournament.''

title: CHAMBER: STUTTGART GROUP
description: WHAT Karl M"unchinger achieved with his Stuttgart Chamber Orchestra in Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon is an admonition to every peripatetic American music director, who splits commitments and career plans for the sake of glamour and variety.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TRANSCRIPT OF 5 CANDIDATES' DEBATE IN ATLANTA
description: Following are key sections of a transcript of a debate yesterday among the five major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination in the Fox Theater in Atlanta, Ga., as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the Cable News Network.

title: GOSSAGE: RELIEF AS EX-YANK
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

title: SCHOOL PRAYER: A POLITICAL DIRIGIBLE
description: I no longer remember how many years it took for me to realize I was making a mistake in the Pledge of Allegiance. With high passion, I stood beside my seat in my Harlem grammar school and repeated the Pledge to the Flag, which always drooped next to the teacher's desk. My feelings were doubtless warmed by my having two uncles who had been in the Great War, one in the Navy, the other as a mule driver in the Army who brought ammunition up to the front in France.

title: NEW LEBANON TALKS: FORCED OPTIMISM AND CRUMBS OF HOPE
description: Flying to Switzerland for the start of Lebanon's second national reconciliation conference, Foreign Minister Elie Salem was sitting in the first-class cabin talking with a friend about the prospects for the success of the peace talks beginning Monday. Suddenly a man from the tourist section threw open the curtain dividing it from the first-class cabin, walked up to the Foreign Minister and asked: ''Mr. Minister, the Lebanese people sitting in back just want one word from you. Are you optimistic or pessimistic?''

title: Hockey Playoff Goes to Duluth
description: North Dakota defeated Minnesota- Duluth, 5-4, today in the second game of the Western Collegiate Hockey Association playoffs.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: JACKSON IN SOUTH
description: The peach trees are blooming, the sun is warming the earth and the Rev. Jesse Jackson has come to Dixie in the springtime to claim the fruits of what he says he planted years ago.

title: California Newspaper Shuts
description: With a headline reading, ''Bye Bye Berkeley,'' the 107-year-old Berkeley Gazette closed Saturday, apparently a victim of inability to adapt to social and economic changes and competition from other San Francisco Bay area daily newspapers.

title: FIRST GAME OF CHESS FINAL IS DRAWN
description: Gary Kasparov and Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union agreed to a draw after the 33d move of the first game of their final candidates match Saturday in Vilnius, in the Soviet Republic of Lithuania.

title: Nuggets 149 Blazers 123
description: With Kiki Vandeweghe scoring 36 points and Alex English 34, the Nuggets rolled up the most points scored against Portland this season.

title: MUSIC: PREMIERE OF CAGE'S 'MUOYCE'
description: ''RIVERRUN, past Eve and Adam's,'' is the way Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake'' begins, ''from swerve of shore to bend of bay. . . .'' John Cage's ''Muoyce,'' dissects and reassembles Joyce's complete text using either the composer's standard ''chance operations'' or some other arcane formula. It begins this way:

title: FARM WORKERS ON COAST CHALLENGE UNIVERSITY'S AGRICULTURE RESEARCH
description: The right of a public university to spend tax dollars to develop labor-saving machinery used by private farmers will be challenged in an unusual trial scheduled to begin here Monday.

title: McCann-Erickson Gets More From Goodyear
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has shifted all its international advertising outside North America to McCann-Erickson, which had shared that role with Campbell- Ewald.

title: Miami (Ohio) 42 Kent State 40
description: Chuck Stahl's 23-foot jump shot with two seconds remaining gave Miami the championship of the Mid- American Conference tournament and an N.C.A.A. berth.

title: PRAYER: ANCHORED IN THE SOIL OF LIBERTY
description: Those who object to prayer in the schools do so on two grounds - that the Constitution bars it, and that any prayer would be religiously divisive. Neither objection holds up under careful scrutiny. On the contrary, for students who profess religious belief, the opportunity for prayer is an essential part of full free speech rights.

title: THE BUYER AND SELLER FACE-OFF
description: A DESK is a desk. A car is a car.

title: Larouche Hurt
description: Pierre Larouche was on the sidelines Saturday night for the first time this season, resting a sore right wrist that will remain in a soft cast until midweek. Larouche has 44 goals, leaving him 6 short of the Ranger record for a season set by Vic Hadfield in 1971-72. Fifty goals could also bring a financial bonus.

title: URBAN SCHOOL OFFICIALS SAY STRONG MEASURES TO CURB VIOLENCE ARE WORKING
description: Urban education officials say strong measures have been taken to make their schools safer in the last few years. Conditions have stopped deteriorating, they say, and are probably better.

title: Miss Bierstein Marries A Fellow Law Student
description: Andrea Bierstein and Martin Fleisher, seniors at New York University School of Law and editors of The Review of Law and Social Change there, were married yesterday. Rabbi Louis J. Sigel performed the ceremony at the 24 Fifth Avenue Restaurant.

title: Garn on Next Fed Nominee
description: The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee is advising President Reagan that the next nominee to the Federal Reserve Board must be schooled on farm and small-business matters to receive approval from his panel.

title: 7 to Share $18 Million In Massachusetts Lottery
description: Four ticketholders have stepped forward to claim their shares in the $18.2 million Megabucks lottery, including a 21-year-old carpenter and a 67-year-old woman who longs to see Holland when the tulips are in bloom.

title: FRANCE'S SILICON FUTURE IS TODDLING ON THE RIVIERA
description: With the fervor of a middle-aged convert to body-building, France is pulling, lifting and trying to talk itself into modernity. The creed has a home here in the hills behind Antibes on the C^ote d'Azur, the kind of place where some of the French hope their future begins.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 12, 1984: MONDAY Interco IncRoper Corp TUESDAY Amer Stores

title: PETRA CHAIRMAN MOVES TO LARGER BANK AUDI
description: Peter J. Tanous has resigned as chairman of the Petra Capital Corporation, an Arab-controlled Wall Street investment banking firm, to become executive vice president of Bank Audi.

title: 7 Killed as Colombians Vote in Local Elections
description: Colombians voted for members of city councils and state assemblies today, and the Government reported a larger turnout than had been expected.

title: BID FOUGHT BY CASTLE & COOKE
description: Castle & Cooke Inc., the Hawaii- based food producer and distributor, said yesterday that it was fighting a hostile takeover attempt by Charles E. Hurwitz, a Texas financier and oilman and participant in numerous corporate raids.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A United Press International dispatch from Addis Ababa, Ethiopia published March 7 incorrectly characterized a resolution on Angola and Mozambique approved by the Organization of African Unity. The resolution expressed ''sympathy and deep understanding for the diplomatic efforts undertaken by Angola and Mozambique to preserve their independence and national sovereignty.''

title: Marine Killed in Auto Crash
description: A United States marine who spent three months on duty in Beirut was killed in a traffic accident while on liberty in Israel's northern port city of Haifa, a police spokesman said today.

title: THE MUSIC MAKERS' SELF-INFLICTED PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH TV'S FOREMOST NEWS ANCHOR
description: PARISYou see this place?'' said Christine Ockrent, waving her cigar around the tiny glassed-in office. ''In French television, this is luxurious. In fact, it took me 15 months to get it.''

title: DUPREE HELPS BREAKERS WIN
description: Marcus Dupree scored the first time he handled the football in a professional game, then added another first-quarter touchdown today to lead the New Orleans Breakers to a 37-14 victory over the Memphis Showboats.

title: GENERALS DEFEAT STARS BY 17-14
description: The new New Jersey Generals proved today that they can play with the elite of the United States Football League when they beat the Philadelphia Stars, 17-14, at Giants Stadium before a crowd of 46,716.

title: Christine Olko Is Married To Dr. Salvatore R. Lenzo
description: Christine Marie Olko, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Olko of Locust Valley, L.I., was married in New York yesterday to Dr. Salvatore R. Lenzo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Lenzo of Hollis Hills, Queens. The Rev. Frederick D. Hoesli performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title: No Headline
description: The Orange Saw Red

title: NEW TOWERS AND ROWDIES
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Carol L. Barash Weds a Doctor
description: Carol Lynn Barash, a daughter of Mimi Coppersmith of State College and Johnstown, Pa., and the late Sy Barash, was married yesterday to Dr. Jed Aryeh Kwartler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin E. Kwartler of Ridgewood, N.J. Rabbi Jeffrey Eisenstat performed the ceremony at Congregation Brit Shalom in State College.

title: The Montreal Museum Plans a Picasso Show
description: The Montreal Museum of Fine Arts said it will stage an exclusive exhibition of works from Pablo Picasso's personal collection, some of which have never been seen before.

title: Hundreds Flee NewarkHotel
description: A fire in the Carlton Hotel here Saturday night forced hundreds of people into the street, injured three people and damaged eight rooms, authorities said.

title: A NEW RANGER GETS A SOUVENIR
description: Bob Brooke had his plans formalized before leaving Edmonton, Alberta, yesterday with the Rangers. The puck in his pocket was going to Acton, Mass., care of Dick Brooke, father and curator.

title: Suit for Secret Ballot In Michigan Dismissed
description: A suit to force a secret ballot in the Michigan Democratic caucuses, filed by supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, was dismissed Friday by State Circuit Judge Carolyn Stell.

title: No Headline
description: Search Is Made in City For Missing TV Artist

title: 20 CENTS WORTH OF LOVE
description: Since Jan. 31 the United States Postal Service has distributed 237.4 million stamps printed five times with the word LOVE, followed by USA 20 cents. The stamp is the third issued by the Postal Service to celebrate love.

title: Not Quite a Pax Pretoria
description: Something interesting is happening in southern Africa: call it pragmatic engagement. For hard- headed reasons, the white-run government of South Africa is talking peace with its sworn enemies in black Africa. It seems to be saying that if they stay inside their frontiers, it will, too. And it is asking its uneasy neighbors to formalize their already considerable trade.

title: Alfonsin Links Debt, Inflation
description: Argentina wants to pay off its $45 billion foreign debt but needs time to get inflation, now at a level of 450 percent, under control, President Raul Alfonsin said in an interview published in Newsweek magazine. Separately, Venezuelan officials negotiating the country's $35 billion foreign debt will meet with creditors this week in New York, Finance Ministry sources said. The issue of another 90-day moratorium on debt payments, after the current grace period expires April 30, is likely to be addressed.

title: Hawks 108, Bucks 94
description: With Dominique Wilkins getting 29 points, the Hawks ended a seven-game losing streak and knocked the Bucks out of first place in the Central Division.

title: TRIAL ON COURT CORRUPTION IN CHICAGO BEGINS
description: Spectators crowded into a Federal courtroom last week to learn just what a Federal investigation of corruption in the Cook County court system had turned up.

title: Dr. Hyman Is Married To Dr. William Fricke
description: Dr. Susan Lynn Hyman and Dr. William Allan Fricke were married yesterday at Temple Beth Sholom in New City, N.Y., by Rabbi David Fass.

title: Patti LuPone Signed For Revival of 'Oliver'
description: Patti LuPone, who was the original Evita on Broadway, has been signed to co-star with Ron Moody in the revival of Lionel Bart's musical ''Oliver.''

title: Pope Declares New Saint
description: Pope John Paul II today canonized Sister Paola Frassinetti, founder of the Congregation of the Sisters of St. Dorothy, which has houses in 12 countries. The Pope praised the 19th-century Italian nun during a service at St. Peter's Basilica as showing ''the true value of women''

title: 'HER LIFE AS A MAN' TONIGHT ON NBC
description: WE'VE had Dustin Hoffman playing a woman in ''Tootsie'' and Barbra Streisand playing a boy in ''Yentl.'' Now, not to be left out of the fashionable identity games, television is offering Robyn Douglass, whose credits include being a Playboy covergirl in 1974, in the role of a bearded young sports writer. Based on a Carol Lynn Mithers article that appeared in The Village Voice a couple of years ago, ''Her Life as a Man'' can be seen on NBC tonight at 9.

title: Ethiopia Cancels Talks On Sudanese Situation
description: Ethiopia, accusing the United States of a huge arms airlift to the Sudan, said today that it would not attend talks aimed at easing tension with the Sudan that were scheduled to start in Nairobi on Monday.

title: No Headline
description: Trains Being Rerouted On Manhattan Bridge

title: DEFENSE STRATEGIES TAKE SHAPE AT BRINK'S TRIAL
description: As jury selection continued here in the Brink's trial of Kathy Boudin and Samuel Brown, defense attorneys have begun to reveal the initial outlines of their cases.

title: PRAYER AND POLITICS
description: If Senator Howard Baker and other sponsors of the school prayer amendment now before the Senate have their way, we can expect public school classrooms to begin the day something like this:

title: Dole Gets Cancer Award
description: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, was awarded the 10th National Achievement Award from the Association of Cancer Centers Saturday. He said the cancer centers should receive more Federal money to cover the high cost of cancer treatment.

title: People
description: * Charles Griffith and Gordon C. Sleepew 3d elected senior vice presidents at Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: HART'S INTELLECTUAL ODYSSEY BEGAN IN SMALL CHURCH COLLEGE
description: Bethany Nazarene College, a small church-affiliated school at the center of this town, was Gary Hart's intellectual incubator and the site of his first political tests.

title: 11-YEAR-OLD MINISTERS TO NEEDS OF HOMELESS
description: At home, Trevor Ferrell is a quiet 11-year- old who studies enough to get average grades, sometimes squabbles with his brother and sisters, swims in season in the family pool and rides his minibike around the cul-de-sac on their quiet suburban street.

title: Israeli Death Toll at 575
description: An Israeli public works employee wounded in January in an ambush in southern Lebanon died today, a military spokesman said. It brought to 575 the number of Israelis killed in Lebanon since Israel's invasion in June 1982.

title: THE PRINCE OF SILENT COMEDY
description: HOLLYWOOD IN 1912, the Titanic sank, vitamin

title: SUPERIOR OIL GETS OFFER FROM MOBIL
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it had secretly agreed to buy 22 percent of the Superior Oil Company from the founding Keck family and would offer the company's remaining stockholders the same price, $45 a share, or a total of $5.7 billion.

title: Montclair Mayor Plans Senate Race
description: Mayor Mary Mochary, a Republican, will announce on Monday that she intends to run for the Republican nomination to contest the United States Senate seat held by Bill Bradley, a Democrat, an aide said today.

title: No Headline
description: Question Box

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want to remind you, this is not a funeral. Some guys just can't hold a job.''

title: DEAN NAMED HEAD OF TEACHERS COLLEGE IN SHIFT AT COLUMBIA
description: The dean of Teachers College of Columbia University, P. Michael Timpane, has been named the college's new president.

title: Artworks in the Wind
description: Some kite-fliers found yesterday's

title: Fire Aboard Cruise ShipExtinguished After 2 Days
description: A fire that raged for nearly two days through the cruise liner Scandinavian Sea was extinguished today, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: Applied to Acquire Assets of Victor
description: Applied Computer Techniques P.L.C. said the board of Victor Technologies Inc. had agreed to sell substantially all assets of its computer business to Applied Computer. Victor filed for bankruptcy on Feb. 6 and Applied said it was told that its offer had the support of the creditors' committee.

title: A WOMAN'S PHONE BILL GIVES WRONG NUMBER: $109,504.86
description: For weeks, Jane Landenberger had been receiving strange phone calls at her Bedford, N.Y., home. Then, last Monday, came the oddest call of all: She was talking on the phone when an operator broke in to say that the telephone company was trying to reach her, and that it was urgent.

title: RETIRED VOTERS WAVERING IN FLORIDA
description: Like a lot of the retired people who live in the pastel condominium blocks and oceanside high-rise buildings here, Irving Feldman says he has not made up his mind whom he will vote for in the Democratic primary election Tuesday.

title: Jazz: Cecil McBee, Bassist, Performs
description: THE bassist Cecil McBee works constantly around New York as a sideman, but on Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall he offered a chance to hear all the subtleties of his playing. In a concert of duets, with Chico Freeman on tenor and soprano saxophones, bass flute and bass clarinet, Mr. McBee reaffirmed that only a handful of bassists can match his technique.

title: THEATER: 'UP IN CENTRAL PARK'
description: WHEN ''Up in Central Park'' was first produced in 1945, it was viewed as a successful effort by its composer, Sigmund Romberg, then 58 years old, to finally get away from the European operetta style with which he had made his reputation (''Blossom Time,'' ''The Student Prince,'' ''The Desert Song,'' even ''The New Moon,'' despite its New Orleans setting) and to adapt to the manner of the Broadway theater.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS DEBATE ACTION ON MEESE'S '80 CAMPAIGN PAPERS
description: Questions about whether a special prosecutor should be appointed to look into how the 1980 Reagan campaign organization obtained information from Jimmy Carter's campaign are being raised by some Senate Democrats as well as by a Federal Judge.

title: ALABAMA BLACK LEADERS ARE URGING PRAGMATISM IN SUPPORTING MONDALE
description: It is a question asked again and again of black politicians who support Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination: Why aren't they supporting the Rev. Jesse Jackson?

title: Arrows Lose, 6-5
description: Tim Walters scored two of the five St. Louis goals in the third quarter to lead the St. Louis Steamers to a 6-5 victory over the Arrows in a Major Indoor Soccer League today.

title: LABELS IN LEBANON ARE CHAOTIC, TOO
description: The ideological terms that are the common currency of politics in many places do not seem to apply in Lebanon, where the meanings of words such as left and right often dissolve into factional slogans.

title: NEW FEARS FOR BANKS ON LATIN DEBT
description: Some bankers in the United States are no longer as optimistic that the Latin American debt crisis is working itself out.

title: VOLUNTEER AGENCIES PLAYING LARGER ROLE IN U.S. FOREIGN AID
description: A host of private and voluntary assistance agencies are playing an increasingly active role in foreign aid.

title: RETURN OF MR. NOT-
description: Eight years ago, Jimmy Carter won the Florida primary by being Mr. Not-Wallace, and then beat President Ford by running as Mr. Not-Nixon. Four years ago, Mr. Carter was ousted by a candidate who ran not so much as Ronald Reagan as Mr. Not-Carter.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press in Business Day on Wednesday gave incorrect figures for the budget and expenses of a commission studying the financial problems at the Washington Public Power Supply System. The commission had a budget of $200,000, including $150,000 for legal expenses. Its legal and related expenses totaled $149,000; an additional $20,000 in printing and mailing expenses was billed through the law firm conducting the study.

title: UPSTATE POWER LINE WILL DEFACE NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; A Celebration of Strings
description: Some came from as far away as

title: A DISCOUNT MALL 11 STORIES HIGH PLANNED IN CITY
description: An 11-story West Side building, once the world's largest refrigerated warehouse, is being converted into what developers say will be Manhattan's first discount mall.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 12, 1984

title: CLASHES FLARE AGAIN IN BEIRUT ON BORDER BETWEEN THE SECTORS
description: Moslem militiamen fought sporadic battles with Lebanese Army and Christian militia forces here today. The most serious clashes took place along the demarcation line dividing Moslem West Beirut from the Christian eastern sector.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: National Hero on Skis

title: Running Away
description: If all the Americans who've played Emily, or the Stage Manager or any other resident of Grover's Corners, N.H., were asked to shout, the sound would deafen the country. The complete Sycamore family would be pretty noisy too.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT PENGUINS,6-4
description: Sloppily, but somehow inevitably, the Islanders' mixed-up combinations responded tonight with a 6-4 victory over the National Hockey League's least successful team, the Penguins.

title: QUEBEC MOB WRECKS COPTER OF FOES OF SEAL HUNT
description: A mob of about 100 seal-hunt supporters stormed onto the runway of a small Quebec airport today and overturned the helicopter of an environmental group that had been filming seals, the police said.

title: MAN SAID TO HAVE KILLED 150 STANDS TRIAL IN TEXAS DEATH
description: Henry Lee Lucas, a 47-year-old convicted killer who the authorities say has confessed more than 150 murders, goes on trial Monday in San Angelo, Tex., for strangling a hitchhiker in 1979.

title: STUDENT PROTESTS MAY TEST SEOUL'SD RECENT EASING OF POLITICAL CURBS
description: The South Korean Government has loosened controls on political dissidents in recent weeks, but it has suggested that restrictions could be reim posed if its opponents grow too strong.

title: OUTDOORS: BAIT MAKERS STRIVE FOR MORE TEMPTING PRODUCTS
description: E VEN when he dwelled in caves, man was seeking new ways to catch fish. There are two major approaches to this when nets, traps, spears, clubs, stones, pitchforks, harpoons, or inebriants such as derris root are not employed. One involves artificial flies or lures, the other involves bait, and for centuries anglers have been brewing concoctions intended to make natural baits more attractive to fish.

title: N.C.A.A. CHOOSES 53 TEAMS
description: The information has traveled in a different way in the two years since the announcement of the National Collegiate Athletic Association pairings evolved from a series of private telephone calls to a made-for-television event. But one factor has not changed: Despite the presence of 53 teams, the largest of the 46 N.C.A.A. tournaments, the selection committee knows the field is not large enough to satisfy everyone.

title: Israeli Orthodox Jews Protest Arrest of Rabbi After Clashes
description: Angry rabbis today threatened to bring down Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Government after the latest round of clashes between secular and Orthodox Jews.

title: Gas Well Burns, Flames Seen for Miles
description: A natural gas well continued burning out of control today with its flames visible for miles, but firefighters allowed about 60 people who had been evacuated to return to their homes.

title: DRIESELL ON TOP IN A.C.C.
description: It was his own lofty aspirations as much as anything that has been used against Charles (Lefty) Driesell to diminish his record as the Maryland basketball coach. When Driesell came to College Park in 1969, he vowed to make the Terrapins the U.C.L.A. of the East. Ever since, he has had difficulty simply trying to be the North Carolina of the Atlantic Coast Conference.

title: Letter: On Ecology Time for Assiduity on Acid Rain
description: To the Editor:

title: FAKE M.D. PROBLEM GROWING, STATE OFFICIALS SAY
description: New York State officials in charge of an investigation of doctors' credentials say the problem is substantially larger than they had suspected.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 12, 1984 International
description: Syria's Cabinet was shuffled by President Hafez al-Assad, who appointed three new vice presidents that included his younger brother, Rifaat al-Assad. Arab political figures and Western analysts said they viewed the changes as an effort by President Assad to carefully balance power among his potential political successors. (Page A1, Column 1.) Another bombing attack in Britain that the police said was directed at Libyan exiles opposed to the Government of Muammar el-Qaddafi took place in Manchester near an apartment occupied by Libyans. No one was hurt in the blast. On Saturday, a bomb exploded in a basement nightclub in the Mayfair section of London, injuring 23 people, shortly before a bomb exploded at a shop in the city's Bayswater district that sells Arab newspapers. (A3:4.)

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: A NEW HAMPSHIRE BIAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor Questions Parole for Suspect
description: A convicted rapist, who is charged in another attack and described as a major suspect in the slayings of nine people, had been prematurely paroled from prison four months before the killings began, a county prosecutor says.

title: DANCE: MYTHS INTERPRETED BY MARTHA GRAHAM
description: PERFORMANCES by the Martha Graham Dance Company can resemble family reunions of the human race attended by figures from age-old myths and legends, most of them in states of flamboyant agitation. Among those who turned up at Saturday afternoon's performance at the New York State Theater were Adam and Eve (in ''Embattled Garden''), Hector and Andromache (in ''Andromache's Lament'') and Ariadne and the Minotaur (in ''Errand Into the Maze''). And romping their way through ''Diversion of Angels'' were the blissfully happy inhabitants of some idyllic realm in the temperate zone of Miss Graham's imagination.

title: Lost Woman, 70, Is Found Dead
description: The body of a 70-year-old nursing home resident, who had wandered away from her family on a shopping trip, was found in the Saugatuck River today after authorities conducted an all-night search.

title: BONN SOCIALISTS FLIRTING WITH NATO
description: West Germany's Social Democratic Party, in a somewhat chastened mood after its unsuccessful campaign against American medium- range missiles, is trying to re-establish its credentials as a supporter of the Atlantic alliance and shows signs of returning to more centrist foreign policy positions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OUT OF ANTIQUITY Ethiopia, once known as Abyssinia, was a land of mystery to Europeans, who for centuries sought to find there Prester John, the legendary Christian king of Africa. The exhibition now showing at the African-American Institute, 833 First Avenue, at 47th Street (949-5666), has nothing to do with Prester John, but, in its way, it is an even more fabulous testament to the antique and devout Christianity of this large land on Africa's northeast shoulder.

title: The Atlanta Constitution Urges Vote for Mondale
description: The Atlanta Constitution on Saturday endorsed Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, citing the former Vice President's ''exceptionally broad experience.''

title: ACTIVIST, IN 70'S, SAYS AGE DISTINGUISHES HER
description: Maggie Kuhn, the 78-year-old co-founder and leader of the Gray Panthers, wants to be known not as a ''senior citizen,'' a term she detests, but as ''an old woman.''

title: DANCE: MERCE CUNNINGHAM TROUPE
description: AUDIENCE response can be very interesting. ''But I don't understand it,'' a man muttered after each dance performed by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Saturday night at City Center. Useless to suggest that the point might just be to observe, and that the dance could simply be, at heart, Mr. Cunningham's pretext for working out and displaying interesting shapes and physical conundrums.

title: Oilers 12, Canucks 2
description: Jari Kurri and Mark Messier scored three goals each and Wayne Gretzky added two goals and three assists. The margin of victory was Edmonton's largest ever, surpassing a 13-4 victory over the Devils last Nov. 19.

title: Battling Gobbledygook
description: ''The programmatic impact of the

title: 20 YEARS AFTER THE MURDER OF KITTY GENOVESE, THE QUESTION REMAINS: WHY?
description: When Catherine Genovese's cry in the night went unanswered by 38 of her neighbors, experts in human behavior were as hard put as anyone else to explain the inaction of the witnesses to her savage murder. ''Nonrational behavior,'' one sociologist called it.

title: CAPITALS FRUSTRATE BRUINS, 2-1
description: Alan Haworth scored midway through the second period, and Washington's league-leading defense, sparked by the goalie Pat Riggin, held off repeated Boston attacks as the Capitals edged Boston, 2-1, tonight.

title: MARINE SPECIALIST HEAD OF NEW PETROFERM UNIT
description: Rear Adm. William M. Benkert has been named president and chief executive officer of Petroferm Marine Inc., a new subsidiary of Petroferm USA.

title: LEONARDO DA VINCI AS A MAN OF PEACE AND WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Diamond Shamrock Corp., an integrated oil and gas company based in Dallas, has elected Roger R. Hemminghaus senior vice president, planning and development.

title: Mary Donahue Marries Michael Quinlan, an Actor
description: Mary Catherine Donahue, a daughter of Rosemary DePhillips Donahue of Clifton and Spring Lake, N.J., and Daniel Donahue of West Paterson, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Denis Quinlan, a son of James Quinlan of Flushing, Queens, and the late Margaret Quinlan. The Rev. Eugene O'Brien, president of the Fairfield (Conn.)

title: A CANADIAN SPLIT ON UNIONS
description: Two years ago, members of the United Mine Workers went on strike against the Cape Breton Development Corporation, a coal company owned by the Canadian Government. Despite sending more than $300,000 (United States) in annual dues to the Washington-based union, they discovered they had no strike fund. Nonetheless, the bitter dispute dragged on for 13 weeks before an agreement was reached on a new contract.

title: SENATE TAX DEPRECIATION FIGHT GOES ON
description: Senator Bob Dole, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, looked to the back of the hearing room last week and caught the eye of Gil Thurm, a lobbyist for the National Association of Realtors.

title: Futures/Options; OEX Trades: Early Signal
description: FROM the day the Standard & Poor's 100 index

title: Man Is Charged In Shotgun Death
description: A man who said he was playing with a 12-gauge shotgun shot and killed a 16- year-old girl today in his home here, the police said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Business People column on Tuesday about the Chittenden Corporation misidentified the Attorney General of Vermont. He is John Easton.

title: HOUSTON CAPTURES SOUTHWEST TOURNEY
description: Michael Young scored 19 of his 23 points in the second half as Houston defeated Arkansas, 57-56, today to capture the Southwest Conference tournament and gain a berth in the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs.

title: 3 HURT IN 2 NEW BOMB BLASTS IN BRITAIN
description: Two bombs exploded today in the vicinity of an apartment occupied by Libyans in the northwestern city of Manchester in a second day of attacks that the police said were directed at Libyan exiles opposed to the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Three people were wounded.

title: MAURICE MACMILLAN, M.P. AND PUBLISHER IS DEAD IN LONDON
description: Maurice Victor Macmillan, a scion of the British publishing empire and the only son of former Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, died Saturday in his sleep of complications after heart surgery, the family reported in London yesterday. He was 63 years old.

title: JAZZ FALLS
description: Moses Malone and Julius Erving led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 120-97 rout of the slumping Utah Jazz today.

title: ATLANTIC CITY BRACED FOR RECALL VOTE
description: Voters here will decide on Tuesday whether their Mayor should be removed from office midway through the four-year term he won by a narrow margin in 1982.

title: JAPANESE TO LET AMERICANS JOIN COUNCILS SHAPING INDUSTRY POLICY
description: After months of debate, the Japanese Government has agreed to permit American representatives to participate in the influential advisory councils that shape the nation's industrial policy, a senior United States trade official said here today.

title: DEMOCRATS' FORUM BECOMES A VEHICLE TO CRITICIZE HART
description: In a nationally televised debate marked by sharp clashes, Walter F. Mondale and other candidates repeatedly attacked Gary Hart today in a concerted attempt to halt his surge to the forefront of the Democratic Presidential race.

title: ROBERTSON STEPS UP TRAINING
description: Andre Robertson began spring training with the motto, ''Take it easy,'' the advice he got from the Yankee staff when he arrived here after a winter spent recuperating from an automobile accident.

title: WHEN THE I.M.F. INSISTS ON AUSTERITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Cambodian Rebels Cut Vietnam Supply Route
description: Thai Army officers said today that the Vietnamese had been forced to airlift supplies to their army outposts in western Cambodia because guerrillas had cut their main supply routes on the ground.

title: 'MAMMA HALE' GIVES HOME TO BABIES OF ADDICTS
description: On the fourth floor of a Harlem brownstone, Clara Hale held a baby in her arms and swayed in a bentwood rocker. Her head was tilted and her wrinkled cheek brushed against the baby's crown.

title: AMERICAN TAKES ON UNITED
description: With its order late last month for 67 new MD-80 jetliners from the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation, American Airlines has added the weight and reach it needs to challenge United Air Lines as the nation's biggest air carrier, analysts say.

title: Althea Triumphs In Santa Susana
description: Althea, the 2-year-old filly champion of 1983, won the 45th running of the Santa Susana Stakes as expected today. The only surprise of the $159,000 race at Santa Anita came when Personable Lady beat Life's Magic for second place.

title: No Headline
description: Janice Ehrlich Weds

title: McEnroe Defeats Lendl
description: John McEnroe continued his mastery over Ivan Lendl with a 6-1, 6-3 victory today in the Belgian Indoor tennis championships.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. University of Alabama , at Tuscaloosa, Ala., 2 P.M. Mets vs. Boston Red Sox , at Winter Haven, Fla., 1:30 P.M. Boxing Vilomar Fernandez vs.

title: OIL POLICY A POINT OF DISPUTE BETWEEN MONDALE AND HART
description: Exchanges between Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale over energy policy in today's debate between Democratic Presidential candidates in Atlanta revived a dispute that split the Senate during the Carter Administration.

title: NETS DEFEAT SONICX, 106-105, ON LATE SHOT BY KING
description: Back when they were teammates and roommates at the University of Maryland, Buck Williams said he didn't worry about Albert King being in a slump. King worked so hard, Williams said, that most of his lows didn't last very long.

title: Flyers 3, Flames 2
description: Len Hachborn and Glen Cochrane scored 17 seconds apart to help give Philadelphia the victory.

title: ;  Texas Investor Blocked On Castle & Cook Tie
description: Charles E. Hurwitz continues to build his business empire. Mr. Hurwitz, a Texas investor, may have his eye on Castle & Cooke Inc., the big Hawaiian food producer, although his stock purchases so far have been termed for investment purposes only.

title: NUCLEAR POWER MAY BE DANGEROUS TO OUR TREES
description: To the Editor:

title: IN INDIA'S NORTHEAST: THE TAMING OF THE GUERRILLA
description: Paramilitary troops armed with automatic weapons and equipped with radios continuously patrol the streets of this capital of the northeastern frontier state of Manipur, searching for insurgents fighting for independence from India. Posters of ''wanted criminals'' with photos and rewards are plastered at street corners, bringing to mind Hollywood westerns.

title: SUIT OVER BIAS IN FOSTER CARE SETTLED BY CITY
description: After 11 years of legal arguments, New York City and the American Civil Liberties Union have settled a lawsuit with an agreement to place children in foster-care agencies on a first come, first served basis, regardless of their race or religion.

title: 'Getting On' With Education
description: Board of Education members said

title: DEMOCRATS DISCUSS WOMAN ON TICKET
description: The idea of naming a woman as the Vice-Presidential candidate on the Democratic ticket is becoming more and more popular, according to party officials and others who follow politics. They say the proposal has a credibilty it never had before.

title: Workers Reprimanded In Loss of Secret Papers
description: The State Department said today three employees have been reprimanded for their role in the mistaken delivery to a local prison of a filing cabinet full of top secret Government documents.

title: Sharp Welsh Plant
description: The Sharp Corporation of Japan plans to build a $21.8 million video recorder factory at Wrexham in north Wales, creating 600 jobs, the Government announced today. Nicholas Edwards, Secretary of State for Wales, said full production is scheduled for 1988. He said the factory was expected to have an eventual output of 500,000 video recorders a year, about 25 percent of the current British market.

title: Australian Beef Protest
description: Reports that Japan plans to give favored treatment to beef imports from the United States sparked a storm of protest from Australian officials today. Talks between the Prime Ministers of Japan and Australia were urged.

title: CITY'S STORE SALES UP 13.7% IN MONTH New York City's retail sales of general merchandise rose 13.7 percent last month from the level of February 1983, a spot-check found last week. It was the biggest year-to-year sales gain since last June.
description: Meanwhile, sales rose 15.6 percent last month in the metropolitan area, which includes the city stores' suburban branches, for the largest gain since April 1981.

title: Houston Gas Stock Falls After Report
description: The stock of the Houston Natural Gas Corporation fell in a rising market today following its report late Friday that directors had decided the company should remain independent.

title: South African Oil Controls
description: The South African Government expects Parliament to expand the Government's regulatory and censorship powers over the country's oil industry, officials said today.

title: NATIONAL BUSINESS COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Castle & Cooke Inc. misstated the number of shares outstanding and their total worth, based on Friday's closing price. There are 28.2 million, worth $507.6 million.

title: MOSCOW REPEATS ARMS TALKS STAND
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, said today that talks with the United States on limiting strategic and medium- range nuclear weapons ''can be resumed at any moment'' if Washington removes ''the obstacles'' it created by deploying new missiles.

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 13, 1984 International
description: Amin Gemayel opened the second Lebanese reconciliation conference in five months, appealing for an end to ''nine years of insane and continuous war.'' Lebanon's eight senior Moslem and Christian leaders gathered in a conference room in Lausanne, Switzerland, to hear President Gemayel deliver an opening address in subdued and almost sad tones. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) The commander of Lebanon's Army has offered his resignation to President Gemayel as a concession to anti- Government factions, according to military officials in Beirut. They said the move could ultimately lead to a Lebanese Army closely aligned with Syria's foreign policy and security objectives. (A8:1-3.)

title: No Headline
description: Gen. Robert L. Schulz, An Aide to Eisenhower

title: CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The 1984 results include $35,000 of revenues and a $2,000 net loss of Cenvill Properties Inc., formerly a wholly owned subsidiary, whose shares were distributed to Cenvill Development shareholders on Oct. 14. The year-ago share earnings are after a preferred dividend of 5 cents.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Xerox Unit Offers Notes

title: DANCE: KEI TAKEI WITH MORE 'LIGHT'
description: KEI TAKEI creates dream landscapes and scenarios of chill, often eerie beauty that flow together with a kind of irrational logic. On Friday at La Mama E.T.C., the Japanese-born experimentalist presented Parts 14 and 15 of ''Light,'' a theater dance piece in 19 discrete sections that she has been adding to since 1969, when she formed a performing company called Moving Earth. These two pieces offered a fine introduction to that work.

title: Cameras/Bulbs
description: Prime Time Death

title: Gulfstream Race To Miss Oceana
description: Miss Oceana, the top-ranked 2-year- old filly in the country last year, scored her second victory without a defeat as a 3-year-old by winning the $40,180 Forward Gal Stakes today at Gulfstream Park.

title: Escapee Pleads Not Guilty
description: James Clegg, one of two escaped convicts who terrorized the state, pleaded not guilty today to charges of murdering Paul Windrow, a Sunday school teacher, and kidnapping his wife, Elizabeth. In Erwin, Bernice Blevins, a janitor at East Tennessee State University, was indicted on charges that she harbored Mr. Clegg and another fugitive, Ronald Freeman. Mr. Freeman died Wednesday after a shootout with the authorities in Marion, N.C., and Mr. Clegg was captured.

title: Against All Odds
description: Iba is a magical name in college basketball coaching, but a comparative newcomer will be carrying it into a preliminary-round game in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournamanet tonight at Dayton, Ohio, when Houston Baptist plays Alcorn State.

title: Textbook Case for Koch
description: ''Will you autograph my book?'' a student asked Mayor Koch when he visited Lehman College.

title: Action Urged on East Timor
description: More than 130 Portuguese politicians and intellectuals urged President Reagan today to help find a solution to what they called genocide in Indonesian- ruled East Timor, a former Portuguese colony. With Prime Minister Mario Soares of Portugal due to see Mr. Reagan in Washington Wednesday, the group said the President had been silent on East Timor, which they called a ''victim of occupation and genocide.'' Human rights groups say up to 200,000 Timorese have died from hunger, disease and warfare since Indonesia invaded and annexed East Timor in 1975.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $48,000 for the quarter and income of $102,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $79,000 for the quarter and $301,000 for the year.

title: TRANSIT SHOWING HOW HOUSTON AND DALLAS DIFFER
description: Both Houston and Dallas grew with the automobile, but even in this land of 12-lane freeways, increasing traffic congestion has been forcing the cities to reconsider. Over the last year, each voted on a mass transit proposal: Houston, no; Dallas, yes.

title: DEMOCRATS FOCUS ON SOUTH AS HART ANSWERS CRITICISM
description: Four of the five Democratic Presidential aspirants campaigned in the South today as nine states across the nation prepared for a potentially crucial set of primary elections and caucuses on Tuesday.

title: A NATIONWIDE PRIMARY WOULD BE OF NO HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 FACE $32 MILLION TAX CHARGES
description: Four New Jersey businessmen were indicted today on charges of bilking the Government out of more than $32 million in income taxes through a tax shelter scheme involving about 700 investors.

title: RUCKELSHAUS'S NON- SOLUTION ON ACID RAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: IPL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Phoenix Suns , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. Larry Nance, who beat out Julius Erving for the National Basketball Association's slam-dunk title at the All-Star Game, makes his only appearance at the Garden this season.

title: RIVALS STAY ONE STEP AHEAD OF I.B.M. PORTABLE
description: WHEN I.B.M. recently announced it was introducing a portable personal computer, many pundits on Wall Street declared the death of companies manufacturing I.B.M. PC-compatible computers. Stock prices of corporations like Compaq plunged to what would have been considered bargain-basement prices if the shares had not been priced at a premium to begin with.

title: ESTEBAN'S MEXICAN FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $186,000 from a tax credit. c-Net loss

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avery International, Pasadena, Calif., a manufacturer of self-adhesive products, has named Robert W. Caldwell vice president and general manager of the Fasson Roll Materials division.

title: FLEEING NAZI'S FRIEND IN POSTWAR ROME
description: To the Editor:

title: AND NOW THE PROBLEM IS HONEY
description: Until a few years ago, honey was a quiet commodity that avoided controversy.

title: Chile Ousts Leader Of Copper Workers
description: President Augusto Pinochet's Government ousted Rodolfo Seguel today as leader of Chilean copper workers, the semiofficial Orbe press agency said.

title: HEALTHCARE SERVICES GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
200 AT STANFORD ASSAIL ATTACK ON 'GAY LIBERATION' ARTWORK
description: Nearly 200 people rallied today at Stanford University to protest the vandalizing of a sculpture titled ''Gay Liberation.''

title: Moore Rekindling His Boxing Spirit
description: Roberto Duran did more to Davey Moore than take away his World Boxing Association junior-middleweight championship last June at Madison Square Garden. In the eighth round when Duran stopped Moore, who had won his first 12 pro fights, he seemed to drain Moore's boundless confidence.

title: CHINA AND SOVIET OPEN NEW ROUND OF TALKS
description: The Soviet Union and China began a new round of talks today on a normalization of relations, but there appeared to be little expectation on either side of a breakthrough on the issues that have impeded progress.

title: HEARING OPENS ON BANS
description: A three-day hearing began yesterday in Tampa, Fla., where Richard Bloch, an arbitrator, will determine whether Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's one-year suspensions of Willie Wilson, Jerry Martin and Willie Aikens are to be upheld over the protest of the Major League Baseball Players Association. No decision is expected before next week.

title: Talking Business
description: Antitrust Rules Held Inflexible

title: Phone-Mate Talks
description: Phone-Mate Inc. said it is ''pursuing affiliation discussions resulting from an overture from an unnamed company.'' The statement, without further details, was part of an announcement saying Phone-Mate expects to report a 1983 loss of at least $5 million and will drop its line of telephones. Corporate officers were unavailable for comment.

title: No Headline
description: Delayed Road Money Is Now Going to States

title: U.S. Says It Seeks To Bolster Sudan Forces
description: The United States said today that it was seeking ways to strengthen the military forces of the Sudan against what it called ''increased security threats,'' but denied Ethiopian charges that a big arms airlift to the Sudan was under way.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 13, 1984

title: St. Regis in Accord To Buy Back Stock
description: The St. Regis Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed with investors led by General Oriental Ltd., whose chairman is Sir James Goldsmith, the British financier, to buy back 3,062,900 shares of its common stock at $52 a share.

title: I.R.S. SEEKS LINKS TO COUNTY COMPUTERS IN TEXAS TO FIND DEBTORS
description: An Internal Revenue Service office in Texas is seeking to establish electronic links with the computers of 80 counties that will provide it instant access to local records concerning property taxes, voter registration and automobile ownership.

title: HART SURGE SAID TO RIDE ON GENERATIONAL APPEAL
description: Senator Gary Hart initially rejected the advice of strategists who suggested last fall that he build his election campaign primarily around a generational theme, for fear it would be divisive. But eventually he agreed, and now foes as well as supporters say his surge of popularity rides strongly on generational appeal.

title: WINKELMAN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
PROSECTION RESTS IN TRIAL OF TWO IN RAPE CHARGES
description: The prosecution rested its case today against two men charged in a barroom gang rape after a police officer testified that she had interviewed a hysterical rape victim who ''couldn't believe what had happened to her.''

title: Mrs. Sulzberger Given Award for Citizenship
description: The Museum of the City of New York presented its annual $24 Award to Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger last night.

title: STATE PANEL TO SUGGEST REOPENING NUCLEAR DUMP NEAR BUFFALO
description: A state panel will recommend that a nuclear-waste dump in West Valley, near Buffalo, that was closed in 1975 after a leak should be reopened, at least temporarily, members of the panel said today.

title: UNITED FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special charge of $3,294,000 on the writedown of investment in MICC Investments Ltd.

title: CONCERT: CZECH PHILHARMONIC PLAYS
description: THE Czech Philharmonic speaks Dvorak as fluently as a good American orchestra speaks Copland or a good English one speaks Elgar: Phrases slip into place naturally, accents fall easily, inflections hardly need to be rehearsed. That is primarily why the Czechoslovak orchestra's concert last night at Carnegie Hall gave a great deal of purely musical pleasure even when technical details could be quibbled with here and there. Vaclav Neumann, the conductor, did not make a show of trying to put Dvorak's music in a new light or to put a chrome- plated shine on it. He allowed each piece to flower in its own good time, letting its unaffected melody come and go without any sense of interpretative strain.

title: BOMB FOUND AT LONDON NIGHTCLUB
description: The police dismantled a bomb tonight at a popular Middle Eastern nightclub in the heart of London. It was the latest incident in a series that Scotland Yard blames on Libyan terrorists.

title: New Bulgarian Envoy Is Accepted by Italy
description: Italy said today that it had accepted a new Bulgarian ambassador to replace the diplomat who was recalled 15 months ago at the height of tensions over purported Bulgarian involvement in the shooting of Pope John Paul II in 1981.

title: HOUSE PANEL REPORT IS RAISING QUESTIONS ON MX DEPLOYMENT
description: A report prepared for the House Appropriations Committee questions whether the Air Force can meet its timetable for deploying the first 10 MX missiles and whether silos modified for their use will be adequately tested, according to a Congressional aide.

title: CAUTION IS URGED ON MEDICAL ETHICS
description: THE Federal Government should have only a limited direct role in making policy on ethical problems of medical practice, Morris B. Abram, a former chairman of a Presidential commission on medical ethics, argues in an article in a medical journal.

title: MODULAR COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GILLIES GETTING INTO THE PLAYS
description: Clark Gillies sounded as if he wanted to be convinced. For the last few games, at least, he has been making a good argument for himself.

title: PISTONS SIGN THOMAS TO $10 MILLION PACT
description: The Detroit Pistons today signed their all-star guard, Isiah Thomas, to a 10-year contract worth a reported $1 million a year, the longest and richest contract in the team's history.

title: Harvester Loan
description: The International Harvester Company said a key loan to International Harvester France, a wholly owned subsidiary, had been extended to June 30. It said the $12 million loan, provided by five French banks, the French Government and the parent company, had originally been due March 9. The loan provides interim financing until the operational and financial restructuring plans of International Harvester France are in place, the farm equipment company said.

title: Business as Usual
description: The drug dealers in Madison Square

title: 13.6% RISE IN OUTLAYS IS PLANNED
description: Businesses in the United States plan to spend a record $343.6 billion on modernization and expansion this year, up 13.6 percent from 1983, the Commerce Department said today.

title: JERSEY MAYOR WINS SUPPORT IN CAMPAIGN FOR U.S. SENATE
description: Mayor Mary Mochary of Montclair had the support of the Kean administration and the New Jersey Republican leadership today as she began her campaign for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate.

title: GENERALS TO HIRE MORE SECURITY
description: The Generals said today that a series of meetings would be held this week between officials of the team and the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority to resolve the issue of violence in the stands.

title: YANKS WON'T START MATTINGLY
description: In certain ways, Don Mattingly's prospects have never been better as he prepares for his second major league season, but in other ways they have never been worse.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-ago share earnings adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend issued Feb. 15.

title: U.S.-India Phone Plan
description: India proposes to spend about $12 billion on telecommunications in the next five years, according to an American official who heads a trade mission here.

title: Justice Dept. Opposes Curb on Money Brokers
description: The Justice Department has joined the Treasury Department in opposing regulations proposed by two Federal deposit insurance agencies that would severely limit the activities of money brokers.

title: State Cites Less Use Of Dangerous Drugs
description: The State Health Commissioner says doctors are prescribing potentially dangerous drugs such as methaqualone much less frequently than five years ago, thereby reducing the likelihood of abuses.

title: U.S.-SOVIET CULTURAL TIES MUST WORK BOTH WAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISING;
description: 2 New Agencies Chosen For Molson Products

title: BRADFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $235,000 for the quarter and $71,000 for the year. c-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $496,000 for the quarter and year.

title: DO ANIMALS HAVE THE CAPACITY TO PLAN?
description: IN the grasslands of Kenya where a

title: Faubus of Arkansas Pays Compliment to Jackson
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has received a complimentary letter from former Gov. Orval Faubus of Arkansas, who is best known for his role as an adversary to the integration of Little Rock's Central High School in 1957.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: The U.N. Today; March 13, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Mullin Is Honored
description: Chris Mullin, the St. John's guard, has been named to the United Press International all-America first team. The 6-foot-6-inch junior, who helped carry his team to a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, was joined by another Big East player, the junior center Patrick Ewing from Georgetown, and two members of North Carolina's team: the senior forward Sam Perkins and the junior guard Michael Jordan. Wayman Tisdale, Oklahoma's sophomore forward, was the fifth player.

title: BROOKLYN DEVELOPER WITHDRAWS REQUEST FOR TAX EXEMPTION
description: A private developer withdrew a request yesterday for a city tax benefit on a project to convert vacant industrial buildings in Brooklyn into an office complex. As a result, the developer said he was no longer bound to save manufacturing jobs in nearby buildings.

title: Required Reading 'Capital Corruption'
description: Following is an excerpt from ''Capital Corruption,'' a new book by Amatai Etzioni, distinguished professor of sociology at George Washington University, published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich:

title: North Stars Win in Overtime
description: Tom McCarthy scored only 10 seconds into overtime tonight to give the the Minnesota North Stars a 7-6 victory over the Montreal Canadiens. McCarthy finished with three goals, all scored after a bench-clearing brawl in the third period that resulted in the ejection of five players.

title: No Headline
description: Robert Thrun, Counsel To P C D

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Metropolitan Report on March 1 with an article about a citywide drop in reported felonies during 1983 - using information obtained from the Police Department - failed to account for the effect of boundary changes in 10 precincts. For those - the 19th, 23d, 25th, 26th, 28th, 30th, 32d, 34th, 120th and 122d - crime rates could not be compared with those of 1982. Overall, the city registered a 9 percent decrease in reported felonies during 1983, a figure that remains valid.

title: Market Place; Semiconductor Analysts Split
description: SEMICONDUCTOR stocks were stellar performers from early 1982 until January, when prices for equities in general turned downward. Within that two-year time frame, Motorola's stock tripled and the price of Advanced Micro Devices soared more than sevenfold.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including investment gains of $3,732,000 for the latest year and $5,123,000 for the previous year. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 4-for-1 stock split paid in January 1984.

title: A GOOD FIVE CENT MISERY INDEX
description: The headlines in all the papers yesterday morning were the same - they all talked about how the other four candidates turned their attack against the perceived front-runner, Gary Hart, in that lively Democratic Presidential debate in Atlanta on Sunday. As usual, the think-alike press corps missed the big issue.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
INDUSTRIAL NATIONS TRY TO EASE TRADE CURBS
description: The United States and its industrial allies are moving toward an agreement on a new trade pact intended to reduce protectionism now that their economies are starting to recover from the recession, according to Western diplomats involved in the negotiations.

title: Government to Monitor Voting in Single County
description: The Justice Department said today that it was sending 25 observers to Conecuh County, Ala., to insure that there is no interference with black voters in Tuesday's Presidential primary voting.

title: Venezuelan Austerity Plan
description: The Venezuelan Government is expected to announce plans to sell or reorganize a number of state- owned companies as part of its austerity program, Venezuelan newspapers reported today. The international airline, Viasa, and Venezuela's Industrial Bank would be affected, they said.

title: Sonic Takes a Fall
description: David Thompson of the Seattle SuperSonics was injured in an incident Friday night at Studio 54, team officials said yesterday, and as a result will be out the rest of the season. The injury was diagnosed as torn ligaments in the left knee, resulting from a tumble down a flight of stairs at the discoth eque.

title: Delta Reduces Florida Fares
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. yesterday reduced its one-way fares to $89 for overnight coach flights from New York to Fort Lauderdale, Tampa and St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: No Rush Seen on Prayer Issue
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today he would let debate on a proposed constitutional amendment to permit organized prayer in public schools run on for at least another week.

title: CBS EMPLOYEES VOTE NOT TO STRIKE
description: Members of the Writers Guild of America were scheduled to take a strike vote last night after negotiations between CBS and the union, which represents news writers and graphic artists, broke off.

title: Beamon's Moment Suspended in Time
description: Bob Beamon, who in 1968 set the remarkable Olympic and world long-jump record that still stands, nowadays jumps only when giving a clinic to youngsters, or possibly over a puddle. One may generally find Bob Beamon working with youngsters, for whom he designs programs at one of the 300 or so parks where he is in charge of sports development for the Dade County (Fla.) Department of Parks and Recreation.

title: PROCESS YIELDS FUEL FROM CHAPARRAL
description: Early tests have suggested the feasibility of using mobile harvesting units to roam the arid range country of the Southwest, chewing up and processing the scrubby vegetation, thereby clearing the land for cattle range and producing diesel oil as a byproduct.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Including a gain of $896,000 from discontinued and spunoff operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $1,726,000 from discontinued and spunoff operations.

title: Peabody in Coal Test
description: The Peabody Holding Company said today that it would provide up to $4 million in a cooperative effort to build an experimental coal-fired electric power plant designed to reduce sulfuric emissions suspected of producing acid rain. The company, parent of the Peabody Coal Company, said the plant, near Paducah, Ky., would be its first public involvement in coal research.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TURING'S MAN. Western Culture in the Computer Age. By J. David Bolter. 264 pages. University of North Carolina Press. Hard-cover, $19.95; paper, $8.95.

title: WEIMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $158,000 for the quarter for the reversal of a tax credit and a tax credit of $67,000 for the year. c-After a charge of $5,000 for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit and a tax credit of $52,000 for the year.

title: GEMAYEL, OPENING TALKS, URGES AN END TO '9 YEARS OF INSANE WAR'
description: President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon opened his country's second reconciliation conference in five months today, appealing for an end to ''nine years of insane and continuous war.''

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
; D.D.B. Helps Hershey Introduce Skor Candy
description: The Hershey Chocolate Company is breaking a new advertising campaign by its agency, Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: Trial Is Delayed In Point-Fix Case
description: The trial of Ernie Cobb on charges that he conspired in a point-shaving scheme while starring on the Boston College basketball team in the 1978-79 season was postponed for a day yesterday at Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: A.T.& T. PLANS TO EXTEND DISCOUNTS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to extend discounts on long-distance calls nationwide this year, company officials said yesterday. The move could increase the pressure on A.T.& T.'s smaller long-distance competitors.

title: A DEVOTED DIPLOMAT: JOAO CLEMENTE BAENA SOARES
description: Joao Clemente Baena Soares, chosen today as Secretary General of the Organization of American States, says his election was as much the result of Brazil's foreign policy as his personal qualities. His own aptness for the post was never in question. Over the past 30 years, he rose steadily through the ranks in Brazil's Foreign Service to become under secretary, the top career job. His sober style and professional competence have also long been respected in the region.

title: UNIVERSITY GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $318,000 on the sale of the company's interest in the Genetics Clinics Partnership. c-Net loss.

title: CBS-TV PURCHASES NIXON VIDEOTAPES
description: CBS News has purchased the right to broadcast 90 minutes of conservations between former President Richard M. Nixon and a one-time aide, a CBS News official said yesterday.

title: GRAND CENTRAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Net loss including a tax credit of $1,306,324.

title: PATIENT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Prime-Time Gems Too Rare
description: If the 1983 National Football League

title: Tactel Merger Off
description: The American Cellular Network Corporation said its agreement in principle to merge with Tactel Systems Inc. had been terminated by both sides. John F. Scarpa, president of American Cellular, said the ''objectives of both companies would be better served'' by not merging. Mr. Scarpa said, however, that the two companies might together pursue ventures in the mobile communications industry. Tactel, based in Pittsburgh, is a privately owned communications equipment concern.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
NOTES ON FASHION
description: Every street here is covered with confetti. Not only were the Milanese fall fashion collections being staged at the fairgrounds, the shoe show, the Moda Calzatura, was in full swing, as was Modit, the presentations of less expensive Italian sportswear. The hotels are so overbooked that 20,000 visitors had to find rooms as far away as Switzerland. On top of that, there was the Carnevale Ambrosiano to celebrate Martedi Grasso, or Mardi Gras.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a LIFO charge of $2,071,000 for the quarter and a LIFO credit of $1,135,000 for the year. c-After a LIFO charge of $2,429,000 for the quarter and a LIFO credit of $3,126,000 for the year.

title: SUBURB OF TEL AVIV TENSE OVER SABBATH ISSUE
description: The walls of the city hall of this Tel Aviv suburb were smeared overnight with black-inked slogans threatening the Mayor and expressing outrage over the municipality's decision to permit movie theaters and coffee houses to operate on the Sabbath.

title: Wranglers Rout Federals by 37-7
description: Greg Landry threw three touchdown passes, including two to Trumaine Johnson, to lead the Arizona Wranglers to a 37-7 rout of the Washington Federals tonight.

title: STORY OF BLINDNESS, THEME OF LOVE
description: -for-television movie on CBS tonight can be gleaned from the fact that one of the major sponsors is a manufacturer of dog food. More about that below. The movie, ''Second Sight: A Love Story,'' starring Elizabeth Montgomery, can be seen at 9 P.M.

title: 'THICKE OF NIGHT' SHIFTS
description: ''Thicke of the Night,'' the late- night syndicated talk show that was billed as a youthful challenge to ''The Tonight Show with Johnny Carson'' when it was introduced last September, has been switched from the 11:30 P.M. time slot to 12:30 A.M. by WNEW-TV, the station that broadcasts the program in the New York metropolitan area.

title: D O C OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings have been restated giving effect to the 2-for-1 stock split for shareholders of record July 11, 1983.

title: GENERAL NUTRITION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 4
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A CASE STUDY ON WALL STREET: HOW NEWS FEEDS VOLATILITY
description: It was 9:30 A.M. last Wednesday, with bond trading just starting to percolate, and the stock and options markets a half-hour from opening. The mood was already black. Stock prices had dropped the previous day, and long-term bonds had hit a seven-month low.

title: Hospital Supply
description: The American Hospital Supply Corporation said it expects to spend more than $700 million in research and product development during the next five years, up from $262 million in the preceding five years.

title: STRIKE CLOSES MORE THAN HALF OF BRITISH COAL MINES
description: More than half of Britain's coal mines were closed by a strike today, but there were some signs of disunity among the miners and there seemed little chance that the walkout would have the devastating consequences of the nationwide stoppage of a decade ago.

title: SAI GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including a capital gain of $292,000 for the quarter and year and income of $241,000 for the year from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Kubota's Net Up 93.6%
description: Kubota Ltd., Japan's largest agricultural machinery maker, said today that its third-quarter consolidated net earnings jumped 93.6 percent from the previous year. The company said it had a profit of $11.9 million in the three-month period, on a 5.9 percent rise in revenue, to $591 million.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Are You Better Off Than You Were . . .
description: Ronald Reagan skewered Jimmy Carter in their 1980 television debate with one memorable line. ''Are you better off than you were four years ago?'' he asked the voters to ask themselves.

title: Vice President for Panama
description: The National Assembly met in special session today and approved Carlos Ozores Typaldos as Panama's Vice President. Mr. Ozores fills the spot left vacant when Jorge Illueca was sworn in as President Feb. 13. Mr. Illueca became President after Ricardo de la Espriella resigned unexpectedly, citing ''personal reasons.''

title: Giants Trade Jackson
description: Terry Jackson, who has made no secret of his desire to be traded by the New York Giants, got his wish yesterday. The Giants sent their seven-year cornerback, the club leader in interceptions last season, to the Seattle Seahawks for an undisclosed 1984 draft choice.

title: HCW INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The year-earlier results include gain of about $1.1 million from the sale of the company's HCW-Delhi Inc. operations.

title: IMOGEN CLARE HOLST
description: Imogen Clare Holst, a conductor, musician and daughter of the composer Gustav Holst, died at her Aldeburgh home today, her lawyer said.

title: Still Hounding Mr. and Mrs. Doe
description: Three weeks ago the parents of Long Island's Baby Jane Doe may have thought their legal torment had finally ended. Yet another court, this time a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, had ruled that the Government did not have the authority to inspect their daughter's medical records.

title: Brink's Defendant Asks New Lawyer
description: Samuel Brown, one of the defendants in the Brink's robbery and murder trial, sought today to discharge his court- appointed lawyer, Robert Isseks. But he was apparently dissuaded from doing so by the judge, who ordered that jury selection continue.

title: New Feelers on Colts
description: Robert Irsay 's inclination on where to move his Baltimore Colts, or whether to move them at all, may be more unsettled than ever. Several reports out of Indianapolis last week, and the visit of some Colt officials to that city, had made it seem as if a transfer there was imminent.

title: GEAC COMPUTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Advertising; Sexual Content In TV Ads
description: THOSE people who find the sexual content of American television advertising upsetting would cringe at commercials being shown elsewhere in the world.

title: ;  F.H.L.B. Bonds
description: The Office of Finance said the Federal Home Loan Bank will offer $420 million in bonds Tuesday. The office said the offering will consist of one issue maturing March 25, 1988. It will be used to partially refund the issue maturing on March 26 in the amount of $800 million.

title: Feud Simmers Down
description: The Cincinnati Red slugger, Dave Parker , who expressed anger last week after learning that he had been described in Willie Stargell 's autobiography as a man who played baseball out of ''hate'' and ''revenge,'' now says that things have been somewhat smoothed over. Parker said Sunday that he had subsequently spoken to his former teammate and that ''the man told me to go out and have a good year.''

title: WELTY BOOK IS FIRST HARVARD U. BEST SELLER
description: -ONE years and thousands of books after its founding, Harvard University Press has published what officials of the press believe to be its first best seller. The book is ''One Writer's Beginnings,'' a slender autobiographical sketch by Eudora Welty, the 74- year-old author who has lived most of of her life in Jackson, Miss., and who has focused her literary talents on the Deep South.

title: Irish Leader Assails Terrorism
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland finished a full day of meetings in the city by again calling last night for a peaceful solution to the political conflicts in the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland.
