title: PATENT LAW APPROVED BY CHINESE LEGISLATORS
description: China's nominal legislature today approved the nation's first patent law, apparently aimed at reassuring potential foreign investors that their technology would not be illegally copied.

title: HYPONEX CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $114,000 for the latest year and $196,000 for the previous year.

title: BOGG'S DISCIPLINE SHOWS IN AVERAGE
description: Carl Yastrzemski, after 3,419 hits and 452 home runs in 23 seasons in the big leagues, might have warned the Mets and their bright young pitchers about Wade Boggs and the other heavy hitters on the Boston Red Sox.

title: THE NOT-SO-GENTLE WOOING OF SALVADOR'S PEASANTS
description: The wooden planks of the barn and the trunks of every tree on this farming cooperative are splashed with paint calling on the 600 families who live here to vote for Roberto d'Aubuisson, the presidential candidate of the far right, who has opposed land redistribution.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption Sunday on page 1 of The Guide gave an incorrect opening date for the Scandinavian film series at Film Forum 2. It opens Friday.

title: CABLE-TV RULE AT ISSUE
description: A proposal to relieve holders of cable-television franchises of their obligation to offer a 70-channel capacity in the first three years of operation is scheduled for a vote Thursday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Howard Chivers, 67, U.S. Skiing Champion
description: Howard P. Chivers, a member of the United States Ski Hall of Fame, died last Thursday of cancer at Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital in Hanover, N.H., where he resided. He was 67 years old.

title: AN ORATOR MAY BLOSSOM INTO SPEAKER, OR MORE
description: Jim Wright's cup runneth over these days. After seven years as the House majority leader, wondering if he would ever have the opportunity to move up to the top spot and become Speaker of the House, he now finds that Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. will serve no more than one additional term, and maybe less if he can manage an appointment as Ambassador to Ireland.

title: A Celebrity Cookoff
description: A Celebrity Cookoff

title: The Tanaiste's View
description: According to Ireland's Tanaiste, or

title: GERMAN MATH SCORES CAUSE ALARM IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON WHILE Americans worry about Japanese children's academic achievements, Britons are equally concerned about what they see as West German youths' superior performance.

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
MONDALE SAYS FRONT-RUNNER IMAGE HURT PROSPECTS
description: ''I'm fine, I'm at peace, I'm sort of liberated,'' Walter F. Mondale said with a faint smile today.

title: PUBLIC EMPLOYEES COVETED BY UNIONS
description: With a law allowing government workers to join unions coming into effect April 1 in this state, labor unions are battling with one another to pick up tens of thousands of new members.

title: N.E.A. RATINGS OF SOFTWARE STIR CRIES OF CONFLICT
description: THE National Education Association has begun evaluating and selling educational computer programs for the nation's elementary and secondary schools, prompting criticism from educators and computer industry executives that the teachers' union is engaged in conflicts of interest.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANALYST FOCUSES ON LIFE'S EARLY YEARS
description: Dr. Margaret S. Mahler, one of the nation's pre-eminent child psychiatrists, made a rare appearance here over the weekend to bring what she believes is a message of the greatest urgency to a crowded gathering of parents, nursery school teachers and day care workers.

title: Board Refuses to Allow Broadcast of Execution
description: James (Cowboy) Autry lost his request today that television stations be allowed to broadcast his execution by injection, and lawyers said they believed he also would lose requests for stays.

title: BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $370,000 for the quarter and $1,195,000 for the year. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $31,000 and a tax credit of $275,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $226,000 and a tax credit of $330,000.

title: BRANIFF TO REDUCE ITS STOCK OFFERING
description: Braniff Inc., reborn from bankruptcy as a stripped-down, business-oriented airline on March 1, said today that it would lower the amount and price per share of the common stock it plans to issue ''on or about March 14.''

title: Intecom in Pact
description: Intecom Inc. said it had signed an agreement with Italtel Telematica, the marketing arm of the Italian Public Telephone Authority, for Italtel to sell Intecom's integrated business exchange product in Europe. The two companies will work jointly to modify the system to European technical specifications. Intecom will make the units at its plant here, with shipments set for the middle of this year.

title: Burger Rejects Bid to Lift Ban on Home Knitters
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today refused to temporarily lift restrictions on the home employment of knitters who work in the outerwear industry.

title: DANCE FESTIVAL PLANS BIRTHDAY PARTY
description: The American Dance Festival will celebrate its 50th anniversary this summer by commissioning works by eight dance organizations and by holding an international modern- dance festival featuring performances by eight foreign companies.

title: Cohalan Proposes Sales Tax Increase
description: Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan recommended today that a quarter of a percentage point be added to the county's 3 percent sales tax.

title: Coleco Plant Lays Off 300
description: Coleco Industries confirmed industry rumors that it had laid off about 300 workers, out of 4,500 that work at its main plant in Amsterdam, N.Y., where its Adam home computer system is made. Barbara Wruck, a company spokesman, said the layoffs took place March 2 and March 5, but were not publicly announced.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The date of the Larry Holmes- Gerrie Coetzee heavyweight title unification fight will be June 1 or June 8, Mike Cohen, one of the promoters, said yesterday. . . . The United States Tennis Association has named Andrea Jaeger, Kathy Jordan, Kathy Horvath and Anne Smith to the Federation Cup team for the annual international tournament that will be held in Brazil next July. . . Rich Gossage , the former New York Yankee reliever, made his spring training debut yesterday with the San Diego Padres, pitching one inning, giving up two hits and striking out one in the Padres' 7-3 exhibition victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: CONCERT: ISRAEL ARMY GROUPS
description: THE splendid cantorial tenor of Lieut. Col. Ari Braun was the main attraction at this weekend's Beacon Theater performances of the Israel Army Choir and Orchestra. A seventh generation cantor, who has served as Chief Cantor of the Israeli armed forces for the last eight years, Colonel Braun possesses a genuinely heroic voice that carried easily through the Beacon Theater even in an unamplified segment of yesterday's afternoon concert.

title: POSTMASTER GENERAL ONE
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Issues
description: * Criterion Acceptance Corp. announced the public offering of $15.6 million of 12.25 percent Government National Mortgage Association-collateralized series E bonds due on April 28, 2014, through First Boston Corp. The bonds are priced at 100 to yield 12.25 percent on a nominal basis and 12.45 percent on a semiannual equivalent basis.

title: G.M. Shares Profit
description: The General Motors Corporation began distributing $322.2 million from the company's profit-sharing plan to 531,000 eligible United States employees. The auto company said payments amounted to about $640 for an employee on a normal schedule throughout 1983. The plan was introduced in 1982 when the United Automobile Workers made concessions in the face of an industry slump. G.M. reported profits of $3.73 billion in 1983, a company record.

title: 'Baby Doe' Curbs Sought on U.S.
description: Six of the nation's leading medical and hospital groups moved yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to permanently bar the Federal Government from investigating how hospitals handle so-called Baby Doe cases involving the treatment of severely handicapped infants.

title: HARPER GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter included nonrecurring charges of about $600,000. The year-earlier quarter and year nets include a $389,000 gain on the sale of real property.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL BACKS STEEL STAND IN A CABINET SPLIT
description: Attorney General William French Smith, widening a Cabinet-level split, today issued a strong statement supporting the Justice Department's position on a proposed merger of two steel companies.

title: CITY ROAD JOBS FAULTED ON HIRING OF MINORITIES
description: The Cuomo administration, accusing New York City of failing to enforce minority- group hiring rules in a street repair program, has suspended payments for two projects and threatened to take control of the entire program away from the city.

title: NON-PROFIT UNITS CALLED SKILLFUL IN SURVIVING CUTS
description: Major nonprofit agencies in New York City that provide health and other services for the poor have survived Federal budget reductions better than those in other large cities, according to a survey.

title: THE MYTH OF SAUDI DIPLOMACY
description: One of the most pernicious myths about the Middle East is that the Saudis are reliable allies who can bring other Arab countries into delicate deals to the United States' advantage. In fact, all evidence is to the contrary.

title: RISES IN COLLEGE TUITION AND FEES ARE MODERATING
description: Most colleges and universities in the region will raise tuition and fees by 7 to 8 percent this fall. Though this increase is double the rate of inflation, it is below the increases of recent years.

title: JAPAN SEES U.S. ROLE AS EXPERTS
description: The most likely role for American representatives in the advisory councils that guide Japan's industrial policy will be as expert witnesses, Japanese officials said today.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $379,000 for the quarter and year.

title: The Righetti Experiment
description: The day Dave Righetti arrived at the Yankees'

Grey Adds Chef Saluto; Ogilvy Ends Miller Bid
description: Grey Advertising, the Jeno's agency since 1983, when it picked up the frozen food line, has been assigned yet another product from the client.

title: ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $33,000 for the quarter and $101,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary loss of $92,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $124,000 for the year.

title: High PCB Level Found at Landfill
description: Monitoring of contaminated oil, illegally dumped at a Brooklyn landfill and seeping into Jamaica Bay, has turned up high levels of dangerous PCB's, city officials reported yesterday.

title: BRIDGE: 32 TEAMS FIGHT FOR SURVIVAL IN THE VANDERBILT KNOCKOUT
description: The Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship continued here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. Thirty- two teams, including the eight top- seeded ones, remained from the 55 that started out on Sunday.

title: HIATUS HERNIAS OFTEN MISDIAGNOSED
description: AHIATUS hernia is a disorder that is rarely fatal or life- shortening, but it can be terribly distressing for the millions of people who are afflicted. And it can be very difficult to diagnose.

title: Combustion Will Buy 2 Companies
description: Combustion Engineering Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Jamesbury Corporation for $29.25 a share, or $100 million.

title: Prof. Martin Zimmerman, 57; Expert on Plants' Physiology
description: Dr. Martin Zimmerman, a leading scholar in the field of plant physiology, died of cancer Wednesday at the Stillman Infirmary at Harvard University. He was 57 years old and lived in Petersham, Mass.

title: LOCAL T.V. HELPING HART SHARPEN IMAGE IN SOUTH
description: As Senator Gary Hart's jetliner settled through the pale evening sky toward the lights and cameras waiting for him at Miami International Airport the other night, the changed relationship involving the candidate, the television cameras and the voters in this campaign year was about to become dramatically clear.

title: SOME GREEKS FIND PROMISE OF U.S. FADES
description: For Emmanuel Sofos at 25, the American fantasy has faded and he is seriously considering going home to the Greek island of Kos.

title: LEWIS IS CONFIDENT OF BREAKING MARK
description: Carl Lewis said yesterday that he had no timetable for his assault on Bob Beamon's world-record long jump of 29 feet 2 1/2 inches, but that he was sure he could eventually shatter the mark.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: REAGAN ADAMANT ON SALVADOR ARMS
description: President Reagan warned Congress today that El Salvador was running out of ammunition and other military supplies. He said it would be unable to hold secure elections later this month unless his request for emergency arms aid is quickly approved.

title: SENATOR AGAIN PRESENTS OIL-MERGER MORATORIUM
description: The staff of Senator J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, today began circulating an amendment that would impose a six-month moratorium on all oil-industry takeovers of companies with more than 100 million barrels of proven oil reserves.

title: CONCERT: CANTICUM NOVUM
description: THE St. John Passion is denser, more fiercely chromatic in its melodic writing and generally less outgoing than Bach's more familiar chronicle of Holy Week, the St Matthew; but listeners should be periodically reminded of its darker beauties. The Canticum Novum under Harold Rosenbaum performed the St. John on Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall using a small chorus (usually seven on a part), an ensemble of Baroque instruments and six vocal soloists.

title: RB Industries Will Buy Sloane Furniture Chain
description: W & J Sloane Inc., the East Coast furniture chain that has been operating at a loss for several years, will be sold to RB Industries, a West Coast furniture retailer, for ''several million dollars'' in cash, the companies said yesterday. Sloane's is a subsidiary of the City Stores Company of Philadelphia.

title: THEATER: 'THE DANUBE' AT THE AMERICAN PLACE
description: IN her new play at the American

title: POLICY SHIFT BY PRETORIA
description: -West Africa, March 12 - With its proposal for regional peace talks, South Africa has offered fresh evidence of a major attempt to replace outright military actions against black foes with a complex web of deals and agreements designed to neutralize exiled black opposition. Moreover, in what some South African commentators see as an overambitious maneuver, the country's leaders seem to be seeking to promote themselves as an acknowledged regional power in a relationship with black- ruled nations who are being asked, implicitly, to accept South Africa's demand to deal with its own racial crisis in its own way, at its own pace and by its own rules.

title: ;  Group's Leader Named In Grace Restructuring
description: W.R. Grace & Company announced yesterday that it had named Robert W. Samuels as group executive of the industrial chemicals group. Mr. Samuels in effect will be chief executive of the operation, which has $2.3 billion in annual sales.

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
4 British Banks List Bad Debts
description: Britain's four largest banks have announced record provisions for bad debts for 1983.

title: STRIKER PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'Warning' Sign in Czech Pokes Fun at Hart Reply
description: Walter F. Mondale's campaign staff, poking fun at Senator Gary Hart, distributed signs today aboard their campaign plane saying, ''Nestrilejte My Jsme Civilisti,'' Czech for ''Don't shoot, we are civilians.''

title: DENTAL SCHOOL DEAN IS AMONG 9 INDICTED IN CLEVELAND FRAUD
description: The dean of the Case Western Reserve University School of Dentistry was among nine people and five local businesses indicted here today on charges of grand theft and attempted grand theft. Prosecutors said the charges resulted from a complicated bank and insurance fraud scheme.

title: VALUABLE LAND AT ALEXANDER'S
description: ''The retail business is a good one, especially if you have the right real estate,'' the late George Farkas, the dynamic founder of Alexander's Inc., once said. ''Sometimes,'' in fact, ''the locations can be even more important than the goods you sell.''

title: NUMAC OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a special gain of $9,250,585.

title: U.S. CRITICIZES SOVIET ARMS VIEW
description: The State Department said again today that there was ''no justification'' for the continued Soviet refusal to resume negotiations on limiting nuclear weapons.

title: ;  Deere Unit Gets Parent's Rating
description: Duff & Phelps said it had assigned a D & P-4 - or low AA - rating to the proposed $150 million floating-rate note issue due 1993 of the John Deere Credit Company, a subsidiary of Deere & Company.

title: Children's Free Opera Sets Haydn's 'Speziale'
description: Young opera fans will be offered free performances of Haydn's ''Speziale'' (The Apothecary) later this month by the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble as part of its ''Children's Free Opera of New York'' series.

title: AT MILAN FALL FASHION SHOWS, CASUAL FLAIR
description: Proving once again that imagination and efficiency need not be mutually exclusive, Italian fashion producers began introducing their fall and winter collections during the weekend with their usual elan. The main thrust is in the direction of men's styles for women, an idea Giorgio Armani developed skillfully in his spring collection six months ago. It is as if everyone else picked up where Armani left off.

title: MCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including net realized investment gains of $104,000 for the quarter and $1,517,000 for the year. c-Net income including a net realized investment gain of $1,013,000. d-Incluiding a net realized investment gain of $1,037,000.

title: Gymnasts Withdraw
description: Gymnasts from the Soviet Union and East Germany have withdrawn from the 1984 American Cup competition Saturday and Sunday at Madison Square Garden, according to the United States Gymnastics Federation. A Soviet telegram yesterday to the U.S.G.F. said the withdrawal stemmed from an ''anti-Soviet campaign'' in the United States that ardizes ''security of Soviet sportsmen in the U.S.A.'' The East German telegram apologized for their withdrawal, citing ''illness of our athletes.'' The withdrawals from the garden event will eliminate two prominent international stars, Aleksandr Pogorelov of the Soviet Union and Maxi Gnauck of East Germany.

title: Petro-Lewis Gets Bids for Properties
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation said it had received proposals from more than 60 companies to buy oil and gas properties.

title: S-P DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CORRECTION
description: A table in the Business section on Sunday with an article about the airline industry gave an incorrect figure for Jet America's 1983 net income. The airline reported an $8 million profit.

title: MONEY TROUBLES EASED IN WHEELCHAIR GAMES
description: The international body governing wheelchair sports has taken new steps to raise money so that the Seventh World Wheelchair Games can be held in the United States for the first time.

title: Norway Trade Surplus
description: Norway's foreign trade surplus widened by 28.6 percent, to $488 million, in February from the period a year ago, the Central Bureau of Statistics said today.

title: FUND-RAISING AT THE WHITNEY
description: WHEN the Whitney Museum decided to hang what may be the first major exhibition of American flower paintings and drawings, it knew it was taking a chance. Flowers are beautiful, decorative and periodically derided as lacking the intellectual content sufficient to challenge the serious artist. The subject matter, despite the master painters represented, was bound to draw criticism.

title: ;  People
description: * Emine Messiqua, president of FCB/Europe, and Edward A. Roncarelli, president of the FCB Multinational Business Group, have been elected to the board of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, and William W. Galvin 3d named an executive vice president of Carl Byoir & Associates, an F.C.B. subsidiary.

title: 80's Lines for 50's Prices
description: Abe Lebewohl looked with dismay at

title: Yonkers Officials Want State Loan
description: Yonkers officials agreed today that a loan from the state was the only way to solve the city's fiscal problems.

title: U.S. FACTORIES REACH INTO THE FUTURE
description: AMERICAN manufacturers are rapidly equipping many of their factories with an array of highly sophisticated and computerized new technologies in a powerful move to reassert a lead eroded by intense international competition.

title: LEBANON'S ARMY CHIEF OFFERS TO RESIGN
description: The commander of the Lebanese Army, Gen. Ibrahim Tannous, has offered his resignation to President Amin Gemayel as a concession to anti-Government factions, military officials here said today.

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TREASURY PRICES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: The credit markets, where prices have been sliding in recent weeks in the face of continued indications that economic growth remains strong and fears that higher interest rates are imminent, advanced slightly yesterday in light trading. Prices of key Government issues rose modestly, leading to a drop in yields.

title: MARYLANDERS MAY GET CHOICE OF STATE SONGS
description: In an effort to chase away the ghost of the Confederacy, the Maryland Legislature is working on an alternative version of Maryland's 123-year-old state song.

title: COOPER CANADA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After special gains of $377,000 for the latest year and $716,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: A.T.& T. Acts To Fill Orders
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company told Federal regulators today that the company was undertaking a crash program to eliminate a crush of new orders for WATS and private business lines.

description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $122,900. c-Net loss

title: EX-CRIME FIGURE IS EXPECTED TO TESTIFY ON LAUNDERING OF BILLIONS IN BANKS
description: A former high-level organized- crime figure is expected to testify here tomorrow on how the underworld is believed to have laundered billions of dollars through American banks, officials of the President's Commission on Organized Crime said yesterday.

title: Brazil and U.S.  Pause on Steel
description: Talks between Brazil and the United States aimed at reducing Brazilian steel exports and ending American antidumping levies have halted temporarily, a Brazilian Trade Ministry spokesman said today.

title: EMIGRE NOVELISTS LOOK AT U.S.
description: THE scores of Soviet writers who have found their way to the West in the last decade were evidently accompanied by their Slavic muse. Most of them continue to write in Russian about Russia, to associate with other emigres and to lament what they believe is a lack of understanding among Americans about the nature of the Soviet regime.

title: SPI PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Nigeria Stand On Oil Quota
description: Nigeria's oil minister has denied reports that his country is actively seeking an increase in the petroleum production quota set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, OPEC's news agency reported today.

title: PHOTOS OF TRIBAL RITUAL PROMPT SUIT
description: For centuries, newcomers to the Rio Grande Valley have been fascinated by Indian ways, while the members of this small Indian community have tried to preserve the secrecy of tribal rituals against the outsiders' prying eyes.

title: POLISH CARDINAL IS BACK HOME TO FACE FUROR OVER CRUCIFIXES
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, returned home today from a South American tour to face a conflict with the Communist authorities over the removal of crucifixes from public school classrooms and a revolt from parishioners demanding that he rescind the transfer of a pro-Solidarity priest.

title: SELECTION OF JURORS BEGINS IN TRIAL OF FEDERAL JUDGE IN NEVADA
description: Jury selection began here today for one of the most divisive and bitterly contested criminal cases in Nevada's history.

title: Colombia's Ruling Party Trails in Local Elections
description: The governing Conservative Party trailed the opposition Liberals in 18 of Colombia's 23 provinces, according to partial returns from local elections Sunday.

title: HEAVY FIGHTING IS REPORTED ALONG IRAN-IRAQ BORDER AREA
description: Heavy fighting was reported continuing today in southern border marshes where an Iranian invasion force seized an artificial island in an Iraqi oil-producing area late last month.

title: POLITICAL SCIENTIST AT M.I.T.
description: Dr. Ithiel de Sola Pool, professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and an authority on the social impact of computers and the mass media, died of cancer Sunday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 66 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Nissan Calls Car No. 1
description: The Nissan Motor Company's Sunny model became the world's top car in terms of production last year, with 556,340 units built, the company said today. The Sunny pushed the Corolla of the Toyota Motor Corporation out of the top spot, which it had held for the last four years, a Nissan official said. Corolla production totaled 555,706, followed by the General Motors Corporation's Cierra, with 527,391.

title: BARCLAYS BID FOR STOCK FIRMS
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C., asserting that it intended to become a major force in the securities markets, said today that it planned to buy control of Wedd Durlacher Mordaunt, the largest stock wholesaler in the City of London, and de Zoete & Bevan, one of its largest stockbrokers.

title: TURNING THE STAMPEDE
description: In the Democratic candidates' debate here, John Glenn roused himself from his downward slide long enough to describe Gary Hart's precipitous ascent as ''the politics of stampede'' - perhaps the only quotable remark of the Glenn campaign.

title: RECOTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to give effect to a 50 percent share distribution on April 28, 1983 and another 50 percent share distribution on Sept. 19, 1983.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AEG-Telefunken Trades for Stake
description: AEG-Telefunken A.G. said it is swapping its remaining 25 percent share, worth $9.6 million, in Telefunken Fernseh und Rundfunk G.m.b.H. for a stake in Thomson S.A.'s new home-electronics holding company, Thomson Grand Publique.

title: BLACKS SEARCH FOR A HISTORY IN NOVA SCOTIA
description: The 34,000 or so blacks of Nova Scotia are struggling to establish a sense of history that the outside world - and, for the most part, they themselves - were not aware they had.

title: RECITAL: KIRI TE KANAWA
description: THERE was a subsidiary drama surrounding Kiri Te Kanawa's song recital at the Metropolitan Opera Sunday afternoon that often proved more vivid than the singing itself. James Levine, Miss Te Kanawa's scheduled accompanist, had rehearsed with her all week despite a cut finger; but finding the soreness increasing, Mr. Levine called in - less than 24 hours before the concert - young Douglas Fisher to replace him. This was Mr. Fisher's first major New York appearance; and with a soldout house at the Met, it must have been a daunting one.

title: TRAUMATIC BEGININGS: MOST CHILDREN SEEM ABLE TO RECOVER
description: AS prevailing popular notions have it, wounded children - the emotionally disturbed, the abused, the unloved - are likely to be psychologically crippled as adults.

title: PRONOUNCE PAC'S 'POX'
description: When Congress passed a law in 1974 requiring political candidates to disclose the sources of their campaign money, many citizens rejoiced. At long last, this murky area would be bathed in sunshine; the voters' wisdom would cleanse the system. But the murk remains.

title: Graham Bill Changed
description: ''The Rite of Spring'' has been added to Thursday night's program by the Martha Graham Dance Company at the State Theater. description: MODERN ART The art that occupies the gallery of the Center for Inter-American Relations, 680 Park Avenue (249-8950), is fairly new, nothing from before 1930, but it is at the same time as ancient as the Indian people whose mythology runs through it.

description: Officials from France, West Germany, Britain and Spain agreed on a $1.7 billion plan for the Airbus Industrie consortium to build a new short- to medium- range jetliner, the A320.

title: PRETORIA'S PLAN TAKES U.S. BY SURPRISE
description: The Reagan Administration was taken by surprise by South Africa's decision to propose a regional peace conference on South-West Africa and was not consulted beforehand, State Department officials said today.

description: The military services met or exceeded their recruitment goals in the first quarter of the fiscal year 1984 and fully 94 percent of the recruits had high school diplomas, the Pentagon says.

title: Executive at Uniworld Promoted to President
description: Herbert Kemp, an executive vice president of Uniworld Group Inc., has been appointed its president and chief operating officer.

description: In 1951 John Chaney, who was the Philadelphia Public League's most valuable player, coveted admission to Temple, but needed complete financial aid to attend college. ''We're talking poor as in

title: JERSEY STUDIES RISE IN HOSPITAL COSTS
description: Hospital operating expenses in New Jersey have continued to accelerate despite an innovative state program designed to slow the rise in health-care costs.

title: MET IN ACCORD WITH PROTESTERS OVER 'RIGOLETTO'
description: The Metropolitan Opera said yesterday that it had agreed to withdraw from sale at its bookstore the libretto of a modernized ''Rigoletto,'' because Italian-American groups had protested that the book contained ''offensive and prejudicial'' material.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; New Yorker Head Gets Hearst Post
description: George J. Green, president of the New Yorker Magazine Inc., is leaving to become executive vice president and group publishng director of Hearst Magazines, a unit of the Hearst Corporation.

title: BRAZILIAN ELECTED TO TOP O.A.S. POST
description: Joao Clemente Baena Soares of Brazil won election today as Secretary General of the Organization of American States.

title: Looking Good
description: There is official Olympic candy, film, clothing and soda, among other items for the Summer Games in Los Angeles.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $142,000 for the latest year and $38,000 for the previous year.

title: Australian Output Up
description: Manufacturing production in Australia rose 2.4 percent in 1983, the Australian Bureau of Statistics reported today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I envision all the Lebanese people with us and I clearly detect the tears in the eyes of the mothers whose young children have been killed or are missing, and I also see the orphans, the bereaved, the displaced, the needy and those uncertain about their future and their survival, all looking to us here in the hope that we bring forth the good news of salvation to a people exhausted by massacres and to a nation afflicted with wounds.'' - President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon.

title: James W. Maloney,Thoroughbred Trainer
description: James W. Maloney of East Norwich, L.I., who trained many stakes-winning racehorses during a half-century in the thoroughbred sport, died Saturday at Rochester (Minn.) Methodist Hospital, a part of the Mayo Clinic.

title: LINGAN WARREN, SAFEWAY LEADER
description: Lingan A. Warren, a former president and chief operating officer of Safeway Stores, died Saturday in San Mateo, Calif. He was 94 years old and lived in Hillsborough, Calif.

title: Omega 7 Leader Faces New Counts
description: Charges of murdering a Cuban official and carrying out numerous bombings were added yesterday to a Federal indictment of Eduardo Arocena, described as the leader of Omega 7, an anti-Castro group of Cuban exiles.

title: MULTIPLEX CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MAVERICK RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Debt Issues
description: * American Hospital Supply Corp . said it was raising $50 million (Canadian) through a 10-year retractable Eurobond with a 12 3/8 percent coupon and par price for the first five years. The lead manager is Wood Gundy Ltd.

title: Ex-California Lawmaker Plans Bid to Regain Seat
description: Former Representative Robert K. Dornan, a conservative Republican who made an unsuccessful bid for the Senate in 1982, plans to seek the House seat that he says was ''stolen'' from him by reapportionment.

title: Super Valu Stores
description: Super Valu Stores Inc. said it would sell its County Seat Stores Inc. division to Carson Pirie Scott & Company for about $71 million.

title: COPPER PRICES CLIMB AS SPECULATORS RETURN
description: Prices of copper futures rose yesterday to their highest levels since early December amid the continuing strength of demand for the metal. This prompted most domestic copper producers to add a cent or two a pound to their prices yesterday.

title: Kidnappers in Italy Free Girl
description: The 8-year-old daughter of an Italian tour company operator, kidnapped from her private school two months ago, has been freed after payment of a reported $2.1 million ransom. The police said the ransom was paid Sunday. The gang released Federica Isoardi late Monday in front of a parish church outside Savona, a Ligurian coastal city near France and about 60 miles from her hometown of Cuneo.

title: ISRAELI SAYS SOVIET HATES JEWS
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said tonight that the Soviet Union refused to renew relations with Israel because of its hatred of the Jewish people.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNEXPURGATED BENNY HILL CONTINUES
description: BENNY HILL, the British comic, has for years been an irrepressible fixture on the syndicated television circuit in this country. Naughty, saucy, bawdy - call him whatever you want, the music-hall veteran has his legions of fans. ''The Benny Hill Show'' has been making popular whoopee on the BBC since 1969.

Historical Times Inc. Buys Country Journal
description: Historical Times Inc., which publishes five small magazines out of Harrisburg, Pa., has acquired Blair & Ketchum's Country Journal for an undisclosed amount in an eight-figure transaction. It will take over the operation from William S. Blair, one- time president of Harper's magazine, and Richard M. Ketchum.

title: SALVADORAN SLAUGHTER
description: The State Department is attempting, once again, to persuade Congress that the human rights situation in El Salvador is improving. The department has a new approach: It involves discounting the deaths of hapless peasants killed by the army in its campaign to quash the guerrillas. No one who cares about human rights can accept this sinister accounting.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: OF MURDER AND MADNESS. By Gerry Spence. 463 pages. Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: Senate Committee Backs Tax Changes
description: The Senate Finance Committee today approved a reduction in the tax benefits from income-averaging as it labored through its eighth day of work on a package to shrink future deficits in the Federal budget.

title: Striking Miners Shut Many British Pits
description: More than 100,000 striking miners kept over half of Britain's pits shut today, sending pickets to block those miners wanting to work and touching off renewed violence.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch yesterday on aid for El Salvador omitted several words from remarks President Reagan made during a visit to an elementary school and added one. In answering a child's question on what Mr. Reagan does at the White House, the President replied, ''There are a lot of people who have been asking that.''

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,309,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: WINE TALK
description: A CURIOUS phenomenon of the wine world in recent years has been the fashion for so- called pocket wine books. Hugh Johnson's ''Pocket Encyclopedia of Wine'' seems to have started it all in 1977. It was such a success that publishers quickly ground out a modest little list of clones, most of them reshaped and cut-down versions of works in more conventional sizes.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: Results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Prime Home Improvement Centers Inc. on Jan. 12, 1984, on a pooling of interests basis.

title: THE DANCE: 2 WORKS BY ZEROMOVING
description: EVERY season for the past few years, ZeroMoving Dance Company has come to New York from its home in Philadelphia, and it has usually been a welcome visitor. However, Sunday night it brought two recently choreographed works to the Theater of the Riverside Church and, although one was fantastical and the other was satirical, both were dull.

title: Warning for Boxers
description: Jose Sulaiman , the president of the Wolrd Boxing Council, said yesterday the council's most recent studies showed boxing mouthguards were possible contributors to brain injuries. He said the studies, done for the W.B.C. by its Sports Medicine Foundation, cast doubt on continued use of the mouthguard.

title: CREDIT CARD CONCERN WILL MOVE ITS OFFICES FROM THE CITY TO L.I.
description: First Card Services Inc., the last major credit card operation in New York City, will move its offices and its 400 employees to Long Island next summer, company officials said yesterday.

description: Stock prices made a broad advance yesterday in accelerated trading, helped by indications that the nation's economy might not be overheating, as some traders had feared.

title: Union Mutual
description: The Union Mutual Life Insurance Company is ''seriously pursuing'' conversion to public ownership, its president, Colin C. Hampton, announced. Mr. Hampton said Union Mutual's directors had authorized management to design a plan to move from a mutual form of ownership to a capital stock corporation. He said the conversion would make the company more competitive by enhancing its ability to raise capital or make acquisitions through issuance of additional shares of stock. Union Mutual, with assets of $4 billion, is ranked by Fortune magazine as the nation's 34th-largest life insurance company.

title: U.S. Phone Card Billed for $125,883
description: In the fifth incident to be reported in the last three days involving the abuse of a telephone credit card number, the New York Telephone Company said yesterday that someone had run up $125,883 in fraudulent calls by using a credit card number assigned to two officials in a Federal Government office in Manhattan.

title: VOTERS' VIEWS ON ECONOMY APPEAR DECISIVE
description: In the crucial primary battles between Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale yesterday, the election returns followed the pattern of the economy, state by state. Prosperity favored Senator Hart and adversity Mr. Mondale.

title: UNION SEEKS VOTE ON OFFER BY CBS
description: The executive council of the Writers Guild of America voted yesterday to submit the latest contract offer from CBS to its membership for a ratification vote. The move came less than a day after members of the union of news writers, graphic artists, desk assistants and researchers voted not to strike CBS.

title: FOUNDERS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $326,000 for the quarter and $691,000 for the year. c-After capital gains of $11,632 for the quarter and $161,574 for the year. The 1983 results include the operations of the American Defender Life Insurance Co. from April 1, date of acquisition.

title: JAZZ GROUP: DON CHERRY
description: DON CHERRY didn't play much trumpet Monday at Tramps, where he will be leading various groups for the next five Mondays. Most of the time, he played electric piano and directed the Everyman Band - Marty Fogel on saxophones, Bruce Yaw on electric bass and Michael Suchorsky on drums - in a genial travelogue of a set.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Sports Pages yesterday about Temple University incorrectly cited the last year its basketball team qualified for the N.C.A.A.'s championship tournament. It was 1979.

description: Nets vs. Phoenix Suns, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Of the teams that were in the National Basketball Association when the Nets joined for the 1976- 77 season, Phoenix has fared the worst against them, with a record of 7-13. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:35 P.M.) 76ers vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Philadelphia. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.)

title: SHELLING IN BEIRUT KILLS AT LEAST 25
description: As the leaders of Lebanon's warring factions were negotiating a cease-fire in Switzerland today, the people of Beirut were recovering from a night of shelling that left at least 25 people dead and 40 wounded. At least half the dead were said to be children.

description: ''The church is not turning back.'' - Bishop Jan Mazur of Siedlce, Poland.

description: Results for the latest periods include proceeds of approximately $217,000 of death benefits from an insurance policy on the life of an officer of a unit.

title: No Headline
description: Reagan Asks Approval Of 11 for Legal Panel

title: CONCERT: GABRIELI STRINGS
description: THE 250 or so New Yorkers who had the wit or good luck to be at the Metropolitan Museum Monday night heard a warming evening of chamber music. The players were the Gabrieli String Quartet of Britain, and their music was by Haydn, Britten and Tchaikovsky.

title: Helicopter Crash Kills Two
description: Two Navy reserve aviators on a training mission were killed Sunday when their helicopter crashed and burned in central Alabama after apparently hitting some power lines.

title: SOUTH AFRICA URGED TO MEET WITH 6 BLACK-RULED NEIGHBORS
description: -West Africa, March 13 - President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia has offered to set up a meeting between South Africa and black-ruled Africa's so-called frontline countries, a six-nation grouping aimed at furthering the cause of black majority rule in the region.

title: Acquittal in Slavery Case
description: Michael James Asam, a 24-year-old who worked for a dairy farm, was acquitted today of keeping two farmhands as slaves and conspiring to violate their civil rights. His employers, Ike and Margarethe Kozminski, were convicted of those charges last month.

description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 14, 1984

title: U.A.W. Assails Church on Talks
description: Leaders of District 65 of the United Automobile Workers yesterday denounced the labor policies of the United Methodist Church's General Board of Global Ministries.

description: Q.

title: L.I.R.R. HALTS DELIVERY OF CARS THAT FAILED TEST
description: The delivery of new commuter cars for the Long Island Rail Road is being delayed indefinitely because of a flaw in the way they draw power from the third rail, transit officials said yesterday.

title: KENNINGTON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ADAMS DRUG CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Bob Lee, deputy New Jersey state athletic commissioner since 1978, will be nominated to succeed Jersey Joe Walcott as commissioner, Governor Thomas Kean announced. Walcott, the former heavyweight champion, retired Jan. 31 on his 70th birthday. The appointment of the Lee, 50, requires the confirmation of the State Senate. . . . Gunther Behnke , a highly recruited 7-foot-4-inch center from West Germany, will attend the University of Kentucky, according to his father.

title: POP: EXERCISE IN NOSTALGIA
description: ''LOVE LETTERS IN THE SAND,'' the season's third program in the 92d Street Y's Lyrics and Lyricists series devoted to American Pop of the 1930's, was a well-designed exercise in nostalgia. Concentrating on what the artistic director Maurice Levine called ''32-bar songs not connected to the theater or to the movies,'' the program interwove singing, film clips, dancing and reminiscences, with a smooth-running narration by the local disk jockey Marty Wilson.

title: MAKING OLD CONSTITUENCY A NEW ONE FOR REAGAN
description: President Reagan's new liaison to American Jewish officials and groups, Marshall J. Breger, sometimes finds himself at the White House discussing policy questions just before sundown Friday. Then, as an Orthodox Jew, he leaves his wallet and briefcase at the White House before walking home to observe the Sabbath.

title: LTV Deal Discussed
description: Negotiations between the Justice Department and the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation resumed today. Progress was reported toward agreement on terms under which the department would allow a merger of LTV and Republic, and Mark T. Sheehan, spokesman for the Justice Department, said the talks would continue.

description: TAMPA, Fla.

description: A wave of desertions by soldiers in Kabul, the Afghan capital, has followed a Government decision to extend the tours of duty of soldiers in the capital from three to four years, Western diplomats said here today.

description: Ever since a Federal judge in Los Angeles ruled on

title: 'SADAT' FILM SALE BARRED
description: An Egyptian judge Monday forbade the sale or rental of any copies of a controversial American film about the life of the late President Anwar el-Sadat until the court rules on a suit against Columbia Pictures, the film's American producers.

title: RETAIL SALES DOWN 0.2% IN FEBRUARY
description: Retail sales slipped by two-tenths of 1 percent in February from January but remained well ahead of the sales pace of a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MESA, A SHOWCASE FOR PICKENS
description: The chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, T. Boone Pickens, has acquired a reputation he says he does not like.

title: LEBANESE AT UNITY TALKS REACH A CEASE-FIRE PACT
description: Lebanon's factional leaders attending a unity conference here agreed today on a cease-fire in Beirut. Accord came after a day of often bitter debate over who was responsible for the fighting.

title: A BIG CANADIAN JACKPOT IN SOCAL, MOBIL DEALS
description: If the Standard Oil Company of California and the Mobil Corporation win their respective takeover battles for the Gulf Corporation and the Superior Oil Company, a big part of both jackpots will lie in Canada.

title: SALVADORAN PROMISES A SAFE ELECTION
description: The Chief of Staff of the Salvadoran armed forces said today that the army had shortages of some types of ammunition and communications equipment but that the shortages were not an immediate threat to the country's presidential election.

title: Nixon Cautions on Extremes In Dealing With Soviet Union
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon said last night that the United States should avoid ''extremes'' in dealing with the Soviet Union.

title: Protectionism, Provincialism and Wine
description: New York's Governor Cuomo wants to give grocery stores the right to sell wine, now a liquor store monopoly. In return, he would give liquor stores the now-forbidden opportunity to sell snack foods.

title: BISHOP REBUTS CRITCISM OF A HOLOCAUST ANALOGY
description: Bishop John J. O'Connor of Scranton, Pa., who will be installed Monday as the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, said yesterday that he was ''outraged'' by the inferences that had been drawn from his comparison of abortion in the United States to the Nazi Holocaust in World War II.

title: BRIDGE: 4 SEEDED TEAMS FALL VICTIM TO UPSETS IN THE VANDERBILT
description: Four top-ranked teams were on the sidelines after a day of upsets here in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, premier event of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: RELIGION'S LOSS IN THE NATIVITY-SCENE RULING
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation and Katalystiks International announced that they had signed a memorandum of understanding for the acquisition by the end of May of Katalystiks' fluid-cracking catalyst business by the Connecticut-based chemicals and plastics company. Neither Union Carbide nor Katalystiks, based in Baltimore, would disclose the proposed purchase price. However, Francis Ramage of English China Clays of St. Ancell, England, one of three companies that owns Katalystiks, said the deal is currently worth $107 million and includes the assumption of loans.

title: PAGURIAN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Tokyo Listing for Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company plans to apply in April for listing on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, an official with the Daiwa Securities Company said today.

title: U.S. COMMISSION CITES NEW DATA
description: The Federal Parole Commission, citing ''new information,'' said yesterday that it was revoking its decision to grant early parole to Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader.

description: In 1931, Joe Miceli opened his barbershop in the Carlyle Hotel.

title: ISSUE OF JOURNALISM IN NIXON TALKS
description: The decision by CBS News to purchase the right to broadcast 90 minutes of conversations between former President Richard M. Nixon and a former aide has raised sensitive questions in journalistic circles. Chief among them is whether CBS News has surrendered its editorial sovereignty and allowed Mr. Nixon, in effect, to produce his own programs.

title: Town Rejects Seat-Belt Law
description: This village voted Monday against an ordinance to require motorists to fasten seat belts. The vote of 145 to 51 in a nonbinding referendum represented a 53 percent turnout, said Rosemary Woodward, the Village Clerk. She said the turnout was close to a record for a Richland-only issue.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1.4 million. c-Net income including a tax credit of $2.5 million.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
REAGAN GIVES UP ON 2-PARTY TALKS
description: President Reagan was quoted today as saying he had ''lost a little faith in the bipartisan approach'' to the budget and would now work exclusively with Republicans to forge an agreement on spending cuts for the next fiscal year.

title: Foster Content
description: George Foster is aware that some people consider him a $10 million lemon. But, at the age of 35, heading into his 13th season in the big leagues and his third with the Mets, he believes that he no longer must apologize for the buildup or the money that accompanied him to New York.

title: TALK OF A REAGAN-CHERNENKOPARLEY IS DENIED
description: The visiting West German opposition leader said here today that the United States and the Soviet Union had discussed the possibility of a meeting between President Reagan and Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader. The report was denied by the United States Embassy.

title: 'This Hellish Poison'
description: All war dehumanizes, but chemical warfare dehumanizes completely. What Churchill called ''this hellish poison'' has excited loathing since the first yellow-green cloud of mustard gas was loosed at Ypres by the Germans in 1915. But the infernal became routine during World War I. In 1925, former belligerents adopted a Geneva protocol outlawing gas weapons as ''justly condemned by the general opinion of the civilized world.''

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: TWO CHINAS There are two ways of looking at everything, from the inside and the outside, a bromide graphically exhibited in two current but separate Midtown photograph exhibitions that depict China.

title: YOUTH ROBS WOMAN TRAPPED UNDERNEATH BUS IN TRENTON OF $2,000 TRENTON, March 13 (AP) - A 28-year-old woman stepped off a sidewalk into the side of a moving bus, and then lay helpless between its wheels as a teen-ager made off with her purse and the $2,000 inside, according to the police. A passer-by gave chase after the theft Monday and recovered the money, and the youth was arrested today after being identified by an off-duty police officer who spotted him leaving the scene. Linda Manion of Morrisville, Pa., who was dragged about 20 feet by the bus, was listed in guarded condition in the intensive care unit at Helene Fuld Medical Center with fractures of the pelvis, clavicle and wrist, a hospital spokesman said. The 15-year-old boy, whose name was not released because of his age, was being held in the Mercer County Youth House until a hearing Wednesday.
description: Had Just Cashed Check According to the police, Miss Manion had just cashed a $2,000 check, which she had received in settlement of a civil suit, at a downtown bank when she stepped off the curb into the side of the bus. ''She said she was on her way to meet a friend,'' said a police spokesman, Sgt. Robert Orlowski. ''I don't know if she was preoccupied or what. She just walked into the bus.'' He said he did not know what type of lawsuit had been settled. Miss Manion was trapped under the bus near the left rear wheel, and it took rescue workers about 15 minutes to free her, he said.

title: LIBYAN CHARGED IN LONDON BLASTS
description: Charges were filed today against a Libyan businessman and three other people in connection with a series of weekend bombings that investigators said were directed at critics of Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader.

title: Test to Screen Phone Calls
description: The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania said it was planning a trial of a new service that would give telephone customers the ability to screen out unwanted calls and to know who was calling them. The company said the service would be offered in the Harrisburg area, which has 100,000 customers, for one year starting May 20.

title: MICHAEL JACKSON'S GLOVE STIRS UP A JERSEY SCHOOL
description: It started with a glove.

title: U.S. Aircraft Carrier Sets Sail For Coast of Central America
description: An aircraft carrier and three escorts set sail for Central America today and United States combat units are preparing to conduct exercises in Honduras later this month, Pentagon officials said.

title: N.F.L. MAY DRAFT U.S.F.L. PLAYERS
description: The National Football League club owners, who so far have avoided altering league policies as a response to the United States Football League, plan to discuss the possibility of a supplemental draft of U.S.F.L. players when they meet next week in Honolulu.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: STAGE: MODERN 'CAESAR'
description: AN American flag flies in the background. Police sirens begin to whine, clearing the way for the political ruler of the hour. The badges on the burly men in blue read ''Metropolitan Police, District of Columbia.'' Caesar enters, wearing a double-breasted pinstripe suit and a red, white and blue tie; a soothsayer-journalist, with a camera dangling from his chest, says, ''Beware the Ides of March.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY PRESIDENT
description: Following are excerpts from a speech here today by President Reagan to the Young Leadership Conference of the United Jewish Appeal, as made available by the White House:

title: CONCERT: MUSIC PROJECT
description: THE performance of Brahms's Clarinet Quintet by the Music Project in Merkin Hall Monday night seemed unassuming, so relaxed was the players' musical approach. Though thoroughly professional, the group did not cultivate a professionally aggressive pose; the music was played, as chamber music should be, as if for friends who happened to drop by to listen.

description: The playwright Jorge Andrade, who was noted for his panoramic cycle of plays embracing Brazilian history, died of heart disease here today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: Westchester Financial

title: AWARD TO A 'QUINTESSENTIAL NEW YORKER'
description: MAYOR KOCH, presenting Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger with the Museum of the City of New York's annual $24 Award for her support of cultural and civic institutions on Monday night, reminded her that they had a lot in common. ''We're both authors,'' he said. The Mayor described Mrs. Sulzberger as the ''quintessential New Yorker'' as he gave her a plaque with the numerals 24 formed by silver dollars. ''If you keep it long enough, it will appreciate,'' he said jokingly.

title: OPPOSITE TACKS TAKEN ON MERGERS
description: Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that he would propose legislation to curb hostile corporate takeovers.

title: Automatix Sees A Loss for 1983
description: Automatix Inc. said it expects to report a loss for 1983 and will restate its financial statements for all or part of the first three quarters of the year.

title: Enalapril Report Denied by Merck
description: Merck & Company said it had received no requests from regulatory authorities for additional medical tests on its new cardio-vascular agent, Enalapril.

description: Following is the text of the letter sent today by Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's counselor, to Senator Strom Thurmond, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee:

title: TEMPORARILY LEASH WALL ST. WILDCATTERS
description: In the pioneer days of the oil industry, fortunes were made overnight through discoveries such as the Spindletop field in east Texas. Some families whose names are still legend - the Hunts, the Klebergs and the Murchisons - amassed tens of millions of dollars.

title: Homecoming, Of a Sort
description: A. R. Nielson, chairman of Canadian Superior Oil Ltd. in Calgary, Alberta, will in a sense be coming home if the Mobil Corporation is successful in taking over Superior Oil: Mr. Nielson spent 27 years with Mobil Canada, the last 10 as president of the subsidiary. He left to join Superior in 1977.

title: FINANCIAL PROBLEMS ARE COMPROMISING NONPROFIT THEATERS
description: Leaders of many of the nation's major nonprofit theaters, faced with continuing financial problems, say they are making artistic compromises to remain solvent. This retrenchment affects an informal network of theaters that has produced virtually all the major American dramas and many musicals for the last decade.

title: Breland in Final
description: Mark Breland, the world amateur welterweight champion, moved within one fight of winning his fifth New York Golden Gloves championship last night with a second-round knockout of Antonio Ratliff.

title: JUDGE SENTENCES WARNER EXECUTIVE
description: An executive of Warner Communications was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to five years of community service after being convicted of racketeering, fraud and perjury. The executive, Solomon M. Weiss, was also fined $58,000 on the criminal charges, which involved Warner's purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater.

title: MET OPERA: A REVIVAL OF MOZART
description: THE John Dexter production of Mozart's ''Entf"uhrung aus dem Serail,'' with Jocelyn Herbert's colorful cut-out sets and costumes, has a picturesque charm with any performers. But since its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera in 1979, the cast has shifted about a good deal.

title: Grenada Bars Singer Set to Honor Slain Chief
description: Grenada's interim Government dampened a celebration planned today to honor the coup that brought the late Maurice Bishop to power by preventing a calypso performer from entering the country.

title: BALDWIN-UNITED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated. Year-ago share earnings are fully diluted.

title: L.I.U. OUT, PRINCETON GAINS IN N.C.A.A.
description: Northeastern, holding off Long Island University in the second half of a frantically-paced game, defeated the Blackbirds, 90-87, today in the first game of a National Collegiate Athletic Association preliminary-round tripleheader at the Palestra.

title: REGULATOR'S FEARS FOR THRIFT UNITS
description: The Federal official who regulates savings and loan associations, under widespread attack for a proposal to restrict the placement of deposits by money brokers, has privately told members of Congress that the thrift industry is in worse financial condition than is generally realized.

title: Midlands Energy
description: The Midlands Energy Company said its directors had authorized the company's investment bankers, Kidder, Peabody & Company, to seek a plan for the sale of the oil and gas exploration company.

title: MAYOR RECALLED IN ATLANTIC CITY BY A 3-2 MARGIN
description: Michael J. Matthews was recalled as the city's Mayor tonight after serving 20 months of his four-year term and was replaced by James L. Usry, an assistant city schools superintendent.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TO PRODUCE YOGURT CHEESE
description: YOGURT, which has become so popular among Americans over the last 10 years, has been a staple in other parts of the world for centuries. Curdled milk products are believed to have been discovered soon after man learned how to milk animals at the beginning of the neolithic age. The discovery of yogurt was probably an accident: Milk left in the sun for several hours in the presence of certain bacteria would form curds, creating yogurt.

title: ONE SENATE PANEL APPROVES AID FOR THE NICARAGUA REBELS
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee today approved President Reagan's proposal for more aid for Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Patient Attacked In Hospital Bed
description: A seriously ill patient at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center was attacked in his private room at 2:50 A.M. yesterday while strapped in bed by someone who apparently tried to strangle him with a rubber tube and then set him on fire, the police said.

title: ORR LEADS KNICKS' ROMP
description: The matchup at power forward looked frighteningly one-sided last night. Louis Orr of the Knicks, 6 feet 9 inches tall and listed at only 190 pounds, against Maurice Lucas of the Phoenix Suns, 6-9 and 235. Lucas is one of the league's most physical players, and when he got into early foul trouble, Larry Nance, 6-10 and 217, and noted for his vicious dunk shots, played against Orr.

title: Maine Man Convicted On 2 Counts in Crash
description: Justice Carl O. Bradford of York County Superior Court today found Charles W. Chamberlain not guilty of manslaughter in a fatal two-car crash a year ago at Arundel but ruled that he was guilty of two counts of procuring liquor for the minors involved in the accident, in which three Sanford teen-agers and a Freeport man were killed.

title: No Headline
description: Texas Official Rejects Rules on Science Texts

title: BOND PRICES LOSE EARLY GAINS
description: News indicating the economic expansion might be slowing down prompted an early rally in the credit markets yesterday, but in the afternoon traders took a second look at the figures and became sellers, pushing down bond prices and raising interest rates slightly in light trading.

title: SUICIDE IN NEW YORK'S SUBURBS THE LIFE AND DEATH OF JUSTIN, 14
description: At the age of 14, his musical tastes ran more toward Beethoven and Mozart than toward Michael Jackson and Boy George. He was proud that he had a better command of Shakespeare than had many of his junior high school classmates.

title: U.S. FAULTED BY GATT ON NICARAGUAN SUGAR
description: The intergovernmental agency that oversees world trade found today that the United States had violated its rules by drastically cutting Nicaragua's sugar quota last year.

title: LITTLE-KNOWN TENANT FARMERS' UNION WILL RECALL ITS BOLD PAST AT REUNION
description: On the steamy night of July 13, 1934, 18 men, 11 of them white and 7 black, met in a rickety schoolhouse on a cotton plantation near Tyronza, Ark., and formed a bold union, the Southern Tenant Farmers Union.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Disney Resignation Spurs Speculation
description: When Roy E. Disney resigned Monday as a director of Walt Disney Productions, it meant that the company's largest single stockholder, with 2.15 percent of the outstanding shares, was at least temporarily pulling up stakes.

title: Hilda W. Smith, 95, Educator
description: Hilda Worthington Smith, a pioneer in labor education, died of leukemia Saturday at a nursing home in Washington. She was 95 years old.

The union said the pact, details of which had previously been announced, was approved by a vote of 5,532 to 695. The airline is seeking similar concessions from other unions.

title: ITT NET CLIMBED 13.5% IN 4TH QUARTER OF 1983

description: The defense for one of six men charged with raping a woman in a bar in nearby New Bedford opened its case today, saying the woman had voluntarily had sexual relations with his client, then ''one thing led to another'' and other patrons joined in.

description: IN recent years, physicians have

title: ENFANT TERRIBLE OF BRAZILIAN CHURCH: FEISTY AT 75
description: Leaning across the long, dark palace table, the Archbishop discussed his announced retirement. ''Of course I'm not going to hang up my boots,'' he said, lowering his voice as though passing sensitive information. ''I've been thinking of starting a circus.''

description: Geidar A. Aliyev, a Soviet First Deputy Prime Minister, left today for Moscow after a three-day visit during which he conferred with President Hafez al-Assad.

The loss compared with previously restated net earnings of $22.3 million, or $1 a share fully diluted, in the 1982 period.

title: LIFE RETURNS QUICKLY TO AREAS DEVASTATED BY MOUNT ST. HELENS
