WROTE ABOUT EAST GERMANY
description: Uwe Johnson, a leading immigrant East German novelist who lived for a time in the United States, has died in England, the Berlin Academy of Art reported yesterday. He was 49 years old. The cause of death was not announced.

title: Brazil Wins Nigeria Pact
description: Brazil has won an international bidding contest to refine Nigerian oil this year, the state oil company, Petrobras, announced today.

title: MAGIC CIRCLE ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
TURNER PAINTING TO BE AUCTIONED
description: A late, experimental painting by J. M. W. Turner, ''Seascape Folkestone,'' is the most important art work from the $6 million collection of the late British art historian Kenneth Clark that will be sold by Sotheby's in London in June.

title: REAGAN MAKES PLEA FOR U.S. JEWS' SUPPORT ON ARMS SALES TO JORDAN
description: President Reagan appealed to American Jews today to support his plans to supply advanced military equipment to Jordan. He said such assistance ''does not threaten Israel'' and helps deter Syria from trying ''to dominate the region.''

title: Picking Up the Check
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: ACTMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $246,000 for the quarter and $428,500 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $207,000.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: The 1984 results include gain on the sale of shopping centers of $40.1 million, a pretax loss provision of $12 million for liquidation of the Bullock's Northern California division and a pretax capital contribution of $15 million to the Federal Department Stores Foundation. The latest quarter and year sales exclude fourth quarter sales of the Bullock's Northern California division which is being liquidated as previously reported.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 14, 1984 International
description: Poland's church stood fast in its demand that crucifixes be displayed in public school classrooms, but the authorities insisted again that the crosses must be removed. The Roman Catholic Church's position was announced after a meeting of the nine-member ruling body composed of Jozef Cardinal Glemp and the senior bishops. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Additional aid for Nicaraguan rebels was approved without dissent at a closed meeting of the Senate Intelligence Committee. (A1:2-3.)

title: CRIB-SAFETY MEETING IS IGNORED
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission was ignored by most of the children's furniture industry today, with only 2 manufacturers out of 50 responding to invitations to a meeting to discuss the commission's call for new standards for crib safety.

title: PEAK HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company began operations in September 1982.

title: CHEMICAL ATTACK CHARGED BY IRAN
description: Iran charged that Iraq used chemical weapons again today in an attack on its forces on Majnoon Island north of Basra, and wounded ''tens'' of Iranian soldiers. The accusation came as a United Nations team arrived in Teheran to investigate Iranian charges that Iraq had used chemical arms in the 3 1/2-year-old war.

title: Staying Put
description: Undergraduate college football stars, as a result of a Federal judge's recent ruling, may now forsake their remaining eligibility and test their talents in the professional leagues. But two of the college game's most publicized players plan to remain in school, at least for the moment.

title: NEW YORK MARKETS THAT CARRY THE FISH
description: THE markets in the metropolitan area that carry skate, dogfish, sea robin, conger and other neglected species are one of two kinds. Either they are the very large ones, such as those on Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, that supply a wide range of fish to a varied ethnic clientele, or they are tucked into such communities as Chinatown or Elmhurst, Queens, where traditional ethnic cooking has created a demand.

title: Hooton Issues Demand
description: If Burt Hooton can't be a starting pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers in 1984, he thinks he might be better off working elsewhere.

title: Executive Joins Kleiner Perkins
description: E. Floyd Kvamme, 46 years old, who earlier this week resigned as vice president of marketing and sales at Apple Computer Inc., has joined the venture capital firm of Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers in San Francisco as a general partner.

title: Former Punjab Leader Escapes Assassination
description: Darbara Singh, the former Chief Minister of Punjab state, escaped assassination today when gunmen fired at him while he was attending a funeral.

title: MAGNETICS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring expense of $915,803 for the phaseout of operations and start-up costs. Year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in December 1983.

title: BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $12.8 million writedown primarily of exploration programs offshore Abu Dhabi and Colombia for the quarter and year. c-Net income.

title: ON THE MORNING AFTER
description: On the morning after an American Presidential primary election, the news is dominated by numbers, winners and journalists. Nobody talks much about the losers, or the philosophy of these struggles, or what the historians or the novelists of the future would think about these strange events.

title: EAST SIDE DRUG SWEEPS HAILED BY MORGENTHAU
description: The Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday that a recent crackdown on narcotics sales on the Lower East Side was ''a tremendous success.''

title: CALIFORNIA PORTLAND CEENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WHAT RESTAURANTS MUST LEARN ABOUT WOMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: CULTIVATING OCTOPUS FOR U.S. TABLES
description: A University of Miami oceanography professor who has eaten octupus for 40 years is trying to convince Americans that they are really tasty.

title: Mullin, Ewing Honored
description: Chris Mullin of St. John's and Patrick Ewing of Georgetown shared honors yesterday, as the basketball coaches of the Big East Conference named them the league's players of the year.

title: AMERICAN ELECTROMEDICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net income.

title: SCHEIB, EARL, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: MEDIPLEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PENSION INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-No comparable year-ago results are available because the company was not publicly traded prior to its spinoff from Academy Insurance Group Inc. in the fourth quarter of 1983.

title: Federated Net Rises 21.3%
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest department store operator, reported earnings of $172.7 million, or $3.55 a share, in the quarter ended Jan. 28. The total was 21.3 percent higher than the $142.4 million, or $2.93 a share, earned in the same period a year earlier.

title: Swedes Censure Banks
description: Sweden's Bank Inspection Board has censured 25 financial institutions for granting excessively large loans to wealthy individuals, most of whom used the loans as tax breaks. Censure is the board's strongest punishment. It cannot take formal action against the institutions.

title: TAXES CUT FOR BRITONS IN BUDGET
description: Tax reforms and cuts in public spending, steps intended to slow inflation and reduce interest rates, mark Britain's budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1.

title: Cybernex Blocked In I.B.M. Case
description: United States District Judge Robert T. Aguilar has blocked the Cybernex Corporation of San Jose, Calif., founded by five former International Business Machines Corporaton employees, from using I.B.M. trade secrets in making thin-film data-storage heads, used to store and retrieve computer information. In a statement, William Klein, Cybernex president and chief executive, said that his company had stopped relying on data that are disputed in the lawsuit.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Italian Prices Increase
description: Wholesale prices in Italy rose 1.4 percent in January from December 1983 and were up 10.2 percent from January 1983, the State Statistical Institute said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arco Chemical Co., a division of Atlantic Richfield Co., and Arrahona S.A. have signed an agreement in principle in which Arco Chemical, through a subsidiary of Arco, will purchase from Arrahona certain assets in Barcelona, Spain, used in the manufacture of polystyrene and acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene resins.

title: Byrd Speaks to Baker
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee announced today that it had called Edwin Meese 3d back for additional hearings on his appointment to be Attorney General, in part because Mr. Meese said he had failed to list a friend's ''personal, interest- free loan of $15,000'' to his wife on a 1981 financial disclosure form.

title: PICKING UP THE CHECK
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: ;  Bankers Trust Chooses Index Funds' Manager The Bankers Trust Company has chosen Kathleen A. Condon to oversee its $12.5 billion of index funds, the largest such operation in the nation.
description: Miss Condon, 35, replaces Seth M. Lynn, also 35, who resigned to start his own index fund business in Tarrytown, N.Y., to be called Great American Core Investors Inc. Under his management over the last three years, the Bankers Trust funds grew from $2.4 billion.

title: Alvarado Report Is Due March 22
description: The City Department of Investigation said yesterday that it planned to prepare an interim report by March 22 on loans the Schools Chancellor accepted from some subordinates.

title: SERVISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHEN A ROUTINE VISA TO U.S. ISN'T ROUTINE
description: Two weeks before El Salvador chooses a new President, the United States finds itself in the curious position of supporting the elections but discouraging visits to this country by any of the six candidates.

title: Estrogen Therapy
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: TEXAS EXECUTES CONVICTED KILLER WHO WON LATE REPRIEVE IN 1983
description: James D. Autry, convicted murderer of a convenience store clerk, was executed early today by injection of sodium thiopental.

title: Changes for Philharmonic
description: Because of the illness of Rudolf Firkusny, who was to perform this week with the New York Philharmonic, last week's programs will be repeated. The concerts, conducted by Semyon Bychkov, will include Beethoven's ''Prometheus'' Overture, Rachmaninoff's Symphony No. 2 and Liszt's Piano Concerto No. 1 with Alexander Toradze as soloist. The performances will be given tomorrow at 8 P.M., Friday at 2 P.M., Saturday at 8 P.M. and Tuesday at 8 P.M.

title:
Market Place;
Cost Pressures On Drug Issues
description: -mandated program that regulates what hospitals charge Medicare patients could provide long-term investment opportunities in the equities of the companies that furnish drugs to those hospitals.

title: YACHTSMAN SERVED SAILMAKING CONCERN
description: George Ratsey, a yachtsman and fifth-generation member of the English sailmaking concern of Ratsey & Lapthorn, died of respiratory failure Monday at his home in Wellesley, Mass. He was 78 years old.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Feb. 27 listing sales and earnings for 286 companies in the last quarter of 1983 misstated the net income of the Newmont Mining Corporation. It was $960,000.

title: ;  Former NASA Pioneer Heads Space Industries
description: Maxime A. Faget Jr., who helped send many of the nation's most important rockets into orbit, is back in the space business.

title: GOLFER OVERCOMING SOME LONG ODDS
description: Tony Sills dug into a huge cheeseburger at the Doral Country Club restaurant and sipped a soft drink after shooting a 3-under 69 on the Blue Monster course during last week's Doral-Eastern Open.

title: BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FREED POLE HOPES TO GET HER U.N. JOB BACK
description: After more than four years in a Polish prison on spying charges, Alicja Wesolowska would like to go back to work at the United Nations in New York.

title: THE PORSCHE FRANCHISE FIGHT
description: Porsche dealers reacted with hostility and a flurry of lawsuits when Porsche A.G., the West German maker of expensive sports cars, announced plans last month to abolish its franchise dealer system in the United States.

title: THE CHRISTIAN ARABS
description: To the Editor: As a Christian Arab, I was not at all moved by the dubious concern shown by Mr. Safire over the fate of Chris

title: Britain's Output Rises
description: Britain's output in all industries rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in January from December, with manufacturing output alone up five-tenths of 1 percent, the Central Statistics Office said today.

title: 2D GAME IN CHESS IS DRAWN
description: Vasily Smyslov and Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union drew the second game of their final candidates chess match yesterday in Vilnius, in the Soviet Republic of Lithuania.

title: Lectures on Short Story Focus on Latin America
description: A six-evening lecture series on the Latin American short story, at the Center for Inter-American Relations, will begin on Tuesday with a talk on Julio Cortazar's ''End of the Game,'' by Alfred Mac Adam of Barnard College.

title: Baliff Meets Mondale; This Time 200 Applaud
description: Clarence H. Montgomery finally got his chance to shake Walter F. Mondale's hand.

title: PARAGON COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
'The King of Kings'
description: Democrats from the Bronx plan to

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ON the fourth floor of the American Museum of Natural History a public-school class of 20 first-graders stood in the Hall of the Early Dinosaurs looking profoundly bored. This surprised David Lilly, who happened to be passing by. ''Five and 6 years old is definitely the dinosaur age,'' said Mr. Lilly, a former teacher and principal and now an educational consultant. ''They are fascinated with the enormousness of the skeletons and with the matching length and difficulty of the names.''

title: Farmers Open Blockade In North Dakota Protest
description: About 70 farmers drove tractors, trucks and cars into this town of 16,000 people today, blockading bank parking lots and Federal agencies to demand that the Government help improve the sagging agricultural economy.

title: Sudan Responds to Ethiopia
description: The Sudan expressed ''surprise and regret'' yesterday at Ethiopia's decision not to attend talks, scheduled to have taken place Monday, aimed at easing tension between the two countries.

title: AIDES URGE HIM TO QUIT THE RACE
description: Senator John Glenn conceded defeat in the Alabama and Georgia primaries this evening, saying he would assess his future after returning to Washington Wednesday.

title: SHIRLEY IMPRESSING YANKEES
description: Two pitchers competing for the remaining spots on the Yankee staff had different turns of fortune today, with Bob Shirley running his streak of scoreless innings to nine and Rudy May injuring the hamstring muscle in his right leg.

title: A NEW CHANCE FOR 'CAGNEY & LACEY'
description: Comebacks are virtually unheard of on television, where programs are rarely given a second chance to sink or swim. Yet Orion Television's ''Cagney & Lacey,'' a program about two police officers who are women that was canceled last spring, will be given a new life Monday evening on CBS. Its resurrection is extraordinary, but what is even more remarkable is the fact that this is not the first revival of the series; one might say this was a show that simply refused to die.

title: K Mart Is Buying Associated Hosts
description: The K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest non-food retailer, has agreed to take over the Associated Hosts Inc. restaurant chain for $80 million in stock, the two companies announced today.

title: FENDI FURS: ARE THEY PLAIN OR FANCY?
description: The Fendi fur collection dominated the day's showings, but the talk was all about technical wizardry: how squirrel could masquerade as mink, how weasel could imitate peacock feathers, how mole could be lacquered in silver or gold to shine at night.

title: REPORT SAYS U.S. IS OFTEN IN U.N.'S MINORITY
description: The vast majority of United Nations member nations last year voted against the United States five times more frequently than they voted with it, according to an American study of voting patterns distributed here today.

title: Stumbling Around the Prayer Maze
description: We are grateful for strong Senate staffs.

title: CENCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STANFORD REJECTS A REAGAN CENTER
description: Stanford University's Board of Trustees, by a vote of 22 to 4, today rejected a proposal to put a $40 million Ronald Reagan Center for Public Affairs on the grounds of the university.

title: New Lights on Broadway
description: A theater was born on Broadway

title: REFEREES DISMISS PHILLIPS AS COUNSEL
description: The National Basketball Association's referees, upset in part with slow negotiations and the resulting 100-day lockout by the league that caused them to miss the exhibitions and the start of the regular season, have dismissed Richie Phillips, the general counsel of their union.

title: EASING THE PAIN IN FAMILIES OF TEEN-AGE SUICIDES
description: A man refused to accept blame for his son's suicide. A woman said she felt someone had to take the blame for the death of her teen-age son.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS IN POLAND INSIST ON CRUCIFIXES FOR PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: The Roman Catholic Church said today that it would not back down from its demands that crucifixes be returned to public school classrooms, and the authorities declared anew that the crosses had to go.

title: Ralston Is Replaced
description: Last year the Oakland Invaders, under Coach John Ralston, had a 9-9 record and won the United States Football League's Pacific Division championship. This year, however, the best they have been able to do is score a single touchdown in three straight losses.

title: MEDICAL 21 CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOTT'S SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A 'COLLECTIVE MADNESS'
description: To the Editor: In writing of ''the abandonment of the Christians of Lebanon,'' William Safire implies that the Christian world should automatically support certain Christian political leaders in Lebanon. Such counsel only feeds the collective madness that has brought Lebanon and most of the Middle East to its present torment.

title: MCGOVERN PLANS WITHDRAWAL
description: Senator Gary Hart won the Massachusetts primary today, with former Senator George McGovern finishing third and saying he would withdraw from the race as he had pledged he would unless he took the first or second spot. Speaking to his supporters in Boston, Mr. McGovern said, ''With all good cheer I fully accept the verdict of my special friends, the voters in Massachusetts.'' Mr. McGovern won only Massachusetts and the District of Columbia in 1972 when he was the Democratic Presidential candidate and was trounced by Richard Nixon. Mr. McGovern said he would now consider whether to endorse one of the four remaining Democratic contenders.

title: GREAT WESTERN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $12,781.

title: Second Justice Gets Plea In Federal Judge's Trial
description: A second Supreme Court Justice was asked today to delay the trial of Chief Judge Harry E. Claiborne, of the Federal District Court of Nevada, on charges including accepting $30,000 in bribes from a brothel owner.

title: MONY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including gains of $30,000 for the quarter and $493,000 for the 9 months on the sale of investments. c-Including gains of $690,000 for the quarter and $228,000 for the 9 months on the sale of investments.

title: AGENCY FINDS A VAST EXCESS IN ARMS COSTS
description: The Reagan Administration may have underestimated the price of its five-year military buildup by hundreds of billions of dollars, the General Accounting Office said in a report today.

title: Prince Quits the Explorers
description: Hippopotamus steak? Buffalo hors

title: More Guards Due
description: Rowdy behavior by Pittsburgh Mauler fans Sunday at the team's first home game has prompted Three Rivers Stadium's security company to double the number of guards from 70 to about 150 for the next game.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: -based band whose first four albums were million-sellers, has not been heard from in almost two years. Ric Ocasek, the group's chief songwriter, made a moderately successful solo album, and other members were involved in various side projects. But most of the group kept a low profile, using the time to recuperate from several hectic years of touring and recording.

title: Real Estate; Showroom Space for Artisans
description: THE Park Avenue Atrium, the office building on 46th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues that Olympia & York rebuilt and expanded at a cost of $90 million, does not seem to be a likely site for a showroom of gifts and novelty items. The cost of the space, the desire of many merchandisers to display goods near their competitors and perhaps even real estate tradition have kept most commercial showrooms out of prime midtown office buildings, particularly those on Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues.

title: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Including a special gain of $1,415,000 for the quarter and year. Results are for 13 and 53 weeks for the latest periods and 12 and 52 weeks for the year-ago periods. Oshawa Group is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: BERRY INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $139,000 for the quarter and income of $796,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $73,000 for the quarter and a loss of $56,000 for the year from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the discontinuances of the marine services and oil and gas segments.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Maine Plant Closing
description: G. H. Bass & Company said the high cost of doing business would force it to close its Rumford plant, putting 270 people out of work. Richard Bourret, president of Bass, said in a letter to employees Monday that the plant would be converted to a warehouse after operations are consolidated at Wilton, Me., by May 1.

title: Economic Scene; Argentina's Ban on Beef
description: BUENOS AIRES

title: Motorola Phones
description: Motorola Inc. introduced a hand-held cellular telephone today, describing it as a ''milestone product'' that would provide businessmen with reliable communications wherever they traveled. The phone, the Dyna T-A-C 8000X, is a small, battery-powered instrument that provides the convenience of cellular, mobile phone service without being tied to an automobile, said Edward F. Staiano, a Motorola vice president. The phones are now in production, he added, and are being marketed by Motorola as well as cellular telephone companies. Mr. Staiano said the phone carries a list price of $3,995 if purchased outright, although the unit can also be leased.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: DISHES may be named for operas (eggs Carmen), opera stars (Melba toast), composers (tournedos Rossini) or battles (veal Marengo). Frequently they bear forms of the names of places celebrated for an ingredient, as Crecy indicates the use of carrots, Argenteuil of asparagus and Florentine of spinach.

title: Careers; Personnel Chief and Efficiency
description: PRODUCTIVITY is one of those concepts that everyone in management talks about, but few know what to do about. New answers may now be coming from personnel directors.

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Coaches' Laments
description: Loyola University in Chicago finished the basketball season with a 20- 9 record, including victories over four teams headed for the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament and the National Invitation Tournament. But Loyola didn't get an invitation from either, and Coach Gene Sullivan doesn't think that's fair.

title: ARO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
New York Senate Stalls Change in Primary Rules
description: A key Republican State Senator says it may be too late to let former Democratic Presidential candidates get off New York's April 3 primary ballot.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Soda Bread for the 17th

title: SHUNNED WOMAN SAYS ELDERS BETRAYED HER
description: Marian Guinn, seeking $1.35 million in damages in a suit against a Church of Christ congregation, told a Tulsa jury today that she had been singled out for public discipline by church elders who had promised to keep a confession about an affair secret.

title: GEMAYEL OVERSEES NO BASTION OF WESTERN VALUES
description: To the Editor:

title: WAITING FOR SHELLEY
description: The papers didn't do much with the death of Dippy LaMoyne the other day. There was just one paragraph in The Times. ''Aged Hurler Dies in Gutter'' was the headline. He died ''penniless,'' it said. Good old Dippy; that's the way he dreamed of it.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The New York Times/CBS News polls yesterday in Alabama, Georgia and Massachusetts were based on questionnaires completed by Democratic voters as they left polling places in randomly selected precincts in all parts of each state.

title: A Small Squad With Big Hopes
description: Ambrosio Quilez and Tom Thorkelsen of St. Thomas Aquinas College in Sparkill, N.Y., know a lot about winning basketball games. They have contributed to 133 victories in 146 games in the last 4 years under Coach Dave Possinger.

title: McDonnell Planes
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won a total of $194.5 million in four Navy contracts for production of F-18 aircraft and F-18 aircraft trainers, the Defense Department said.

title: GOODEN PITCHES WELL FOR METS
description: Dwight Gooden pitched three more strong innings today on the road to what looks like a full-time job on the Mets at the age of 19. But he also has a split fingernail that could disrupt his training schedule.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CALLS X-CARS SAFE
description: The General Motors Corporation argued today that its 1980 X-cars, which the Government says have defective rear braking systems, are among the safest automobiles on the highway, but the Government said it wanted all the cars recalled.

title: AND NOW, A VIDEO 'YEARBOOK'
description: Members of the video generation will be able to recapture the sounds as well as the sights of their high school years in Alton with a taped ''yearbook.''

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: Soviet Plant in Greece
description: After years of negotiations, Greece and the Soviet Union have signed a deal to build a $400 million aluminum plant here.

title: Bill on Pony Express Gains
description: A House Interior subcommittee passed a bill today to study whether to preserve the Pony Express Trail, which was used by riders to carry mail in the 19th century.

title: UNESCO SEEKS U.S. REQUEST FOR INQUIRY
description: A Unesco official said today that a proposed investigation of the organization by a United States Congressional team could be held only if the Reagan Administration officially requested it.

title: 2-MAN GARBAGE TRUCKS AT ISSUE AGAIN
description: The Koch administration's effort to reduce the number of workers on garbage trucks has failed in some neighborhoods, with city and union officials trading charges over the reasons.

title: ALTANTIC CITY'S NEW MAYOR SWORN IN AFTER COURT DELAY
description: James L. Usry was sworn in today as Mayor after last-minute legal maneuvers by the outgoing Mayor, Michael J. Matthews, had blocked the ceremony and left this casino city without a chief executive for two hours.

title: ;  President's Post Filled By Electro-Biology Inc.
description: Electro-Biology Inc., a Fairfield, N.J., medical products company, filled a two-year vacancy yesterday when it named James A. Wimbush its new president and chief operating officer. Mr. Wimbush, who is 48, comes to Electro-Biology from Collaborative Research Inc., where he was president and chief executive officer.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 3 SENATORS UNITE ON OIL-MERGE CURB
description: Three Senators bent on curbing oil-industry mergers have negotiated an agreement for a common bill under which large acquisitions would be barred for six months, one of the Senators, Howard M. Metzenbaum, said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BELOW CANAL TriBeCa, the triangular region south of Canal Street, was once New York's entrepot for fruit and vegetables and assorted industrial enterprise. Now it has been metamorphosed into condominiums and a territory that is almost as lively after dark as its erstwhile business was before dawn.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
FORMER CHICAGO PUBLISHER IS NAMED TO LEAD THE DAILY NEWS
description: James F. Hoge, the publisher of the Chicago Sun-Times until two months ago, was named publisher of The Daily News in New York yesterday.
