UNESCO GETS COMPLAINTS OF 24 NATIONS
description: The United States and 23 other industrial countries belonging to Unesco presented to its director general today a list of changes they would like put into effect.

title: CREDIT CRAD DRIVES WOOING THE AFFLUENT
description: The swirling Congressional debate over credit card surcharges has focused attention on an industry that, more than ever, is looking for new ways to expand and reach higher-income customers. The three major cards, American Express, Visa and Mastercard, have all, for example, recently begun national advertising campaigns, stressing their versatility and aimed directly at the luxury travel and entertainment market.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH THE KING OF JORDAN
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of an interview today with King Hussein of Jordan, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Harcourt Book Awards Being Presented Today
description: The second annual Alfred Harcourt Award in biography and memoirs will be presented today at Columbia University to Lloyd Goodrich for his book ''Thomas Eakins,'' published by Harvard University Press in 1982.

title: U.S. Reports It Erred On U.N. Voting Figure
description: The United States Mission to the United Nations said today that figures it presented indicating severe American isolation at the world body in the Carter Administration were incorrect.

title: DEWEY KOBAYASHI
description: Dewey Kobayashi, whose Kitch'n Cook'd brand potato chips won worldwide popularity, has died at his home on the island of Maui.

title: Ice Storm Causes Power Failures
description: Power failures darkened more than 20,000 homes and businesses in northern New Jersey and Westchester, Rockland and Orange Counties after freezing rain snapped tree limbs and knocked down power lines on Tuesday night.

title: LURE OF LIFE IN AMERICA SPAWNS MANILA CON GAME
description: A framed collection of small full-face photographs known as the rogues' gallery hangs on a wall in the consular section of the American Embassy here. It is next to the row of windows with little openings at the bottom where, on the average working day, more than 400 Filipinos apply for tourist visas for the United States.

title: HOW THE POLLS WERE MADE
description: The New York Times/CBS News Polls in Alabama, Georgia and Massachusetts are based on questionnaires completed by Democratic voters as they left polling places in randomly selected precincts in all parts of each state.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am very concerned about the United States and its double standard everywhere.

title: Canadian Astronaut Chosen
description: Marc Garneau, a 35-year-old commander in the Canadian Navy, has been chosen as a payload specialist on the October space shuttle mission, officials said today. He will be the first Canadian to fly in space.

title: ;  Addendum
description: * Levin Public Relations and Marketing, a new company in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Market Place; High-Quality Issues Stressed
description: SOME technical analysts believe that the steep drop in stock prices earlier this year has wrought so much damage to the market's internal structure that further extensive declines appear likely before the bottom is reached. However, some investment firms now are espousing the contrary view, namely that prices of numerous leading stocks have fallen to levels where they represent sound, fundamental values, regardless of the short-term vagaries of the market.

title: Standing by Mondale
description: Edward J. Cleary, newly installed

title: DANCE: A QUARTET FOR FIVE
description: WHEN does a quartet involve more than four people? When it's Merce Cunningham's ''Quartet,'' the dance for a cast of five that the Merce Cunningham Dance Company offered Tuesday night at the City Center.

title: O'Neill Says Mondale Needs To Improve His Image for TV
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., said today that Walter F. Mondale's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination is still ''alive and kicking'' but that he needed to work on his television image.

title: SFM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $484,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,188,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $352,000.

title: MEACHAM STRIVING TO STAY WITH YANKEES
description: On the day Andre Robertson broke his neck in a near-fatal automobile accident last August, Bobby Meacham and his wife prayed for the Yankee shortstop's recovery.

title: FURNITURE AWARD PRESENTED
description: -ORIENTED crowd sat in the ornate Grand Ballroom of the Plaza Hotel to hear the results of Progressive Architecture magazine's fourth annual International Furniture Competition. A jury that included the architects Charles Gwathmey, Cini Boeri and Andrew Batey, the industrial designer David Rowland, and Michael McCoy of the Cranbrook Academy of Art had given the award, out of 783 submissions, to Bruce Tomb of San Francisco for his Cooktop Table, above left. Designs given citations and mentions included the tripod table by Martin Kohn of Toronto, left, and the cabinet by Demir Hamami of Bethesda, Md., below.

title: PRODUCT DESIGN & ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
48 FEININGER OILS REACH U.S.
description: -EIGHT paintings by Lyonel Feininger which were left behind when the artist fled Nazi Germany have arrived in this country after a decade of lawsuits and difficult negotiations between the State Department, the East German Government and the estate of his widow.

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split in May 1983.

title: Spain Wants France To Explain Boat Attack
description: Spain deployed about 800 paramilitary Civil Guards at the French border today to escort French truck convoys into Spain and prevent further attacks by Basque fishermen who have burned at least 16 vehicles since Sunday.

title: Hymac Ltd. to Be Sold
description: Hymac Ltd., part of the collapsed IBH Holding A.G. group of West Germany, will be sold to Northern Engineering Industries P.L.C., a spokesman for the receivers in bankruptcy said. The price was not disclosed.

title: Firefighter Killed In Yonkers Blaze
description: A 30-year veteran firefighter died in a three-alarm fire at a warehouse when the building's roof collapsed, authorities said today.

title: Gulf Broadcast
description: The American Financial Corporation and its chairman, Carl Lindner, acquired 5,484,846 common shares, or 12.5 percent of the shares outstanding, of the Gulf Broadcast Company of Dallas, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. American Financial, a diversified financial holding company based in Cincinnati, and Mr. Lindner acquired the shares as a result of the liquidation of the Gulf United Corporation, which distributed its assets to stockholders. Gulf Broadcast owns three television stations and eight radio stations.

title: SCIENTIFIC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FORDHAM UNIVERSITY NAMES JESUIT EDITOR AS ITS NEW PRESIDENT
description: The Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, who began his career as an educator and has spent the last 12 years on the Jesuit magazine America, was named yesterday to be the next president of Fordham University.

title: LENA HORNE ON CABLE, 'LADY AND HER MUSIC'
description: NEARLY three years ago, ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music'' opened for a limited run on Broadway and proved so successful that, in addition to winning several prestigious awards, it was extended for a year. Toward the end of the run, the show was taped by the RKO Video Group and the result is an ''exclusive entertainment special'' that can be seen on the pay-television channel Showtime tonight at 8.

title: COMPUSHOP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
IS THERE NO SHAME?
description: A number of Federal criminal laws forbid Government officials to accept money or other benefits from outsiders in conflict with their public duties. There now are serious grounds to believe Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General, may have violated several of those laws.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Borg-Warner Corp. said it and Clark Equipment Co. had terminated joint venture talks about the making and marketing of manual transmissions and clutches because they were unable to agree on terms.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Applied Materials, Santa Clara, Calif., a producer of wafer fabrication systems, has promoted Howard Neff to the newly created position of vice president of operations.

title: U.S. SEES PROBLEM IN WARTIME WEAPON CARE
description: Thousands of American civilians who maintain weapons and military communications overseas are under no obligation to stay if hostilities break out, a House panel was told today by officials of the General Accounting Office.

title: PRIMO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
China Urban Income
description: The per capita income in Chinese urban families last year rose 6 percent to an average of 500 yuan, or about $250, the Government said.

title: 'Samurai' Burglars Held Penny Marshall Hostage
description: The actress Penny Marshall was briefly held hostage in her Hollywood home by two teen-age burglars dressed as Japanese warriors and armed with a samurai sword, the police said today.

title: Koch Aide Quits For House Race
description: Rafael Esparra resigned yesterday after four years as Mayor Koch's Special Adviser for Hispanic Affairs to enter a House primary race in Brooklyn's 11th Congressional District.

title: MCGOVERN GRATIFIED WITH RESPECT WON AS HE LEAVES RACE
description: George McGovern's quixotic quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, which began in a sea of ridicule and ended with about 20 delegates won, has nevertheless restored the 1972 nominee to a respectable position inside the Democratic Party, he and other aides said today.

title: TOWN SAYS HOSTAGE BROUGHT ON HER OWN KILLING
description: The family and friends of a woman who was shot and killed by an Escondido police officer while fleeing an abductor have expressed shock and anger about the city's contention that her actions contributed to her death.

title: No Headline
description: Suit Seeks to Protect Miners From Radon

title: Limits on Ads By Doctors Eased
description: The State Board of Medical Examiners today voted to remove most of its restrictions on doctors' advertising.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IN hanging a wall covering, it is

title: Dollar Decline Affecting Rates
description: Recent declines in the dollar could push interest rates higher, Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said today.

title: DISPUTE ON DATES IN FIX TRIAL
description: A key Government informant testified yesterday that he learned in December 1978 that Ernie Cobb, then a star guard on the Boston College basketball team, had joined a point- shaving conspiracy that season.

title: TUBE WORM COLONY SEEN IN UNUSUAL WATERS
description: A community of giant clams, tube worms and other exotic creatures, previously thought to live only where superheated water erupts from the floor of the Pacific Ocean, has been discovered in the Gulf of Mexico west of Florida, according to the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.

title: MUSIC: CZECH PHILHARMONIC'S SMETANA
description: THIS season we are observing the 100th anniversary of Bedrich Smetana's death, which occurred on May 12, 1884. Unfortunately, we in New York aren't observing it quite so lavishly as was once intended.

title: MEESE ASSISTANT UNABLE TO FIND REQUESTED DATA
description: An aide to Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, has said that he cannot find a document requested by Congressional investigators, according to materials made public today by a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect a pretax writedown of $502,000 for the quarter and year in connection with the company's oil and gas drilling activities. Year-ago results reflect pretax writedowns of $979,000 for the quarter and $1,309,000 for the year in connection with the company's oil and gas drilling activities.

title: MARCH 1-10 AUTO SALES ROSE 31.5%
description: The nation's six major auto makers reported today that sales in the March 1-10 period surged 31.5 percent from a year earlier, continuing the stronger- than-expected pace that has prevailed since December.

title: TO THE RESCUE OF U.S. RURAL ELECTRIFICATION
description: To the Editor:

title: CARTER: LABOR HURT MONDALE
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that former Vice President Walter F. Mondale has suffered in the early Democratic Presidential primaries because of his endorsement by labor and other special-interest groups.

title: Bond Prices Decline Again
description: Bond prices sagged further yesterday in light trading, as a number of mostly technical factors combined to put upward pressure on interest rates.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
description: b-Net loss

title: INCREASING NUMBERS OF AGED RETURN NORTH FROM FLORIDA
description: The number of elderly people returning from Florida to New York rose sharply during the last decade, a new analysis of Census Bureau data shows. Those returning were older, poorer and more likely to be widowed than those who moved to Florida from New York in the same decade.

title: Colgate Names Financial Chief
description: Paul A. Jones, 55 years old, is

title: BROWN: BIG 8 TITLE AND MAYBE A HOME
description: When the game ended last Saturday night at Kansas City's Kemper Arena, when a frantic finish had overcome a 5-point deficit in the final two and a half minutes, and the University of Kansas was the Big Eight champion, Larry Brown had once more created an opportunity to change an image he has grown to despise.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Feb. 13 about travel services of the Fugazy International Corporation incorrectly reported its status at the East Side Airlines Terminal. Carey Transportation Inc. holds the exclusive franchise for bus service there.

title: 2,000 AIDING THE SEARCH FOR SAN FRANCISCO BOY
description: For reasons nobody can fully explain, the disappearance last month of 10-year-old Kevin Collins has touched this city's heart.

title: Mr. Meese's Memory
description: Edwin Meese, President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General, has a powerful ''forgettory.'' That's the term former Senator Sam Ervin used in talking about public officials who lose their memory when asked about dubious financial deals.

title: HELPED PRESERVE LANDMARKS
description: Ralph C. Menapace Jr., a lawyer who had led the Municipal Art Society of New York and was long active in the effort to preserve landmarks, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and also lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: A BUDGETARY STRAITJACKET FIT FOR CONGRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: MY 12-year old son just walked into my study on the verge of tears. He and his best friend, Ian, had a fight. Ian stormed away on his bicycle. Teddy didn't think this was fair. He wanted a chance to explain himself and ''talk it out,'' although when I asked him what the fight was about, he couldn't remember.

title: DAHLBERG ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $150,325 for the quarter and a gain of $1,488,321 for the year from discontinued operations. Year-ago revenues have been restated to include revenue realized from marketing services provided to dealers.

title: Army Ousts Last Civilian In Guinea Bissau Regime
description: The military was in full control today of the main governing body in the West African state of Guinea Bissau after the dismissal Tuesday night of the nation's civilian Vice President.

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income including net income from discontinued operations of $9.2 million and an extraordinary tax credit of $9.1 million. c-Including net income from discontinued operations of $4.1 million and an extraordinary tax credit of $9.1 million. d-Including net income from discontioued operations of $12.1 million and an extraordinary tax credit of $20 million.

title: Physicist, 67, Dies in Crash Of His Plane in Connecticut
description: The pilot of a single-engine Piper plane was killed this morning when his aircraft crashed while he was trying to land it at Groton-New London Airport.

title: BEIRUT CEASE-FIRE IS GENERALLY FIRM
description: The Lebanese capital awoke today to the surprising sounds of silence, but periodic gun battles and the shelling of some civilian areas during the day marred a cease-fire agreed to by political leaders in Switzerland.

title: BID BY JACKSON IS CITED IN BLACKS' BIG TURNOUT
description: Black voters in many Congressional districts in Georgia and Alabama turned out in numbers that often exceeded statewide turnout averages in Tuesday's primary. According to politicians, this occurred partly because of the lure of the candidacy of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and partly because of the spirited competition for their votes between Mr. Jackson and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.

title: Democratic Primary Results Data from the Associated Press
description: Alabama

title: Sipe Shall Return
description: Brian Sipe , who has missed two games since undergoing arthroscopic surgery on his right knee, will return at quarterback Sunday when the Generals travel to Houston to play the Gamblers, Coach Walt Michaels said yesterday.

title: Talent Review
description: In a letter to the coaches of National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-A football teams, Chet Simmons, the commissioner of the United States Football League, has stressed that the ''rule of reason'' should apply when an underclassman wants to leave college to sign a professional contract. Simmons has proposed that a review board be established to deal with such cases.

title: Boeing, Rockwell Military Contracts
description: The Boeing Company received $511.9 million and the Rockwell International Corporation received $433.7 million in Government contracts, the Defense Department said.

title: GUNMEN WOUND I.R.A. POLITICAL LEADER
description: The head of the political wing of the Provisional Irish Republican Army was shot and wounded along with three companions as they rode in a car through the heart of Belfast this afternoon.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $447,000.

title: MOVING INDUSTRY'S REVIVAL
description: The country's major moving companies are expected to begin slowly phasing out the price cutting and discounting that kept them rolling through the recession. The economy's improvement has meant that people are now moving nearly as often as they did four or five years ago, before the recession hit.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: EDWIN C. KEMBLE
description: Edwin C. Kemble, whose 1917 Harvard doctoral thesis was the first in the United States on theoretical physics, died Monday at his home here.

title: ARMANI REFINES MANNISH LOOK
description: If Giorgio Armani's fall opening Tuesday night didn't have the same clout as his spring show six months ago, it is not really his fault. Clones of his broad-shouldered, man-tailored casual look have been appearing in almost every collection since the fall and winter showings began here over the weekend. In his last collection, he banished accessories. Now hardly a necklace or a jewel is to be seen at other houses.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS AID FOR SALVADOR
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved President Reagan's requests for urgent extra military aid for El Salvador and for Nicaraguan rebels.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Madison Square Garden, 8 P.M. World B. Free, the Cavaliers' star from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, has scored 60 points in their two games against the Knicks this season, but New York has won both. (Television - MSG Cable, 8 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 8 P.M.) Los Angeles Lakers vs. San Antonio Spurs, at Inglewood, Calif. (Television - USA Cable, 10:30 P.M.)

title: LEBANESE AT CONFERENCE DISCUSS POLITICAL SHIFTS
description: Delegates to the Lebanese reconciliation conference began detailed talks today on a program of national political changes.

title: Thruway to Get New Ticket Units
description: The New York State Thruway Authority plans to install about two dozen automatic ''ticket spitters'' as part of a $15 million project to upgrade its toll stations on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, officials said today.

title: Arg"uello Restless
description: Alexis Arg"uello is reconsidering his decision of last September to retire from boxing after a distinguished career and titles in the featherweight, junior lightweight and lightweight divisions.

title: PREFERRED FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Midlands Rejects Proposal on Stock
description: The Midlands Energy Company said its board had rejected a proposal to buy back 14 percent of its shares from the Evmar Oil Corporation for $33 a share. Midlands said its directors had authorized Kidder, Peabody & Company ''to seek a financial alternative that might result in the sale of the company at a price substantially higher than the current market price.''

title: Grand Jury Refuses to Indict In Deaths of 2,000 Horses
description: A grand jury found wrongdoing but no ''criminal aspect'' to a horse-trading scheme that collapsed when thousands of the animals began starving to death, the jury foreman said.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Cable TV Network Names New Chief
description: Thomas F. Burchill has been named president and chief executive officer of Hearst/ABC-Viacom Entertainment Services, the joint venture that owns Lifetime, a 24-hour cable television network. Lifetime, born Feb. 1 from the merger of Hearst/ABC's Daytime and Viacom's Cable Health Network, is an advertiser-supported basic cable service.

title: 2 NAMED FOR U.S. DISTRICT JUDGESHIP IN NEW YORK
description: Two prominent Manhattan lawyers were recommended to President Reagan yesterday for appointment as Federal judges in the Southern District of New York.

title: CONVEST ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Includes gain of $542,000 from a tax credit.

title: Acquittal in Slavery Case
description: Michael James Asam, a 24-year-old who worked for a dairy farm, was acquitted Tuesday of charges of keeping two farmhands as slaves and conspiring to violate their civil rights. His employers, Ike and Margarethe Kozminski, were convicted of those charges last month. Mr. Asam had been accused of aiding the Kozminskis in holding Robert Fulmer, 57, and Louis Molitoris, 60.

title: Trafalgar Bid For P & O
description: The Monopolies Commission today authorized Trafalgar House P.L.C., whose shipping interests include the Cunard Line, to renew its takeover bid for the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company.

title: ITT FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is a financial services subsidiary of the ITT Corp.

title: GLEMP JOINS FRAY OVER CRUCIFIXES
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp issued a challenge tonight on laws separating church and state, saying most Poles wanted crucifixes displayed in their classrooms as a symbol of Polish nationalism.

title: Phillips Pleads Case
description: Richie Phillips , dismissed as general counsel of the National Basketball Association's referees union, said yesterday that he did ''a great job for these people.''

title: NEBRASKA LEGISLATURE IMPEACHES ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: The Nebraska Legislature voted today to impeach Attorney General Paul Douglas for alleged misconduct in his dealings with a savings institution that failed last year.

title: Devils Tie Capitals
description: Mel Bridgman's 21st goal of the season, with 11 minutes 8 seconds left in the game, gave the Devils a 3-3 tie with the Washington Capitals tonight.

title: TENAFLY SCHOOL REFLECTS ON PEOPLE WHO SUFFER
description: First the classroom of teen-age students placed gauze over their eyes and tried to read a newspaper. Then they wrapped bandages around their fingers and tried to turn the pages. Finally they stuffed their ears with balls of cotton and tried to talk to one another.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL METS (NL) - Released Mickey Mahler, Phil Huffman and rick Anderson, pitchers; Jim Maler, First baseman; Rafael Santana, infielder, and Ronn Reynolds, catcher. Brian Giles sprained his right ankle and will be out of action at least a week.

title: Barnett Banks
description: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Bank of Hallandale and Trust Company for about $40 million.

title: SCRIPTURES REQUIRED DENOUNCING WOMEN IN CHURCH, ELDERS TESTIFY
description: Three elders of the Collinsville Church of Christ, accused in a $1.35 million suit of invading a woman's privacy, branded her a fornicator ''because the Scripture demanded it,'' one of them testified here today.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings reflect the issuance of one million common shares in May 1983.

title: CALENDAR: EXHIBITION OF ARCHITECTURAL PLANS
description: Cornell University Performing Arts

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ; Time for a Change in Name
description: For 121 years it has been the Long

title: Information Stock
description: Leonard Levy, a private investor, said he had increased his holdings in Information Displays Inc. with the purchase of 108,500 shares. He now holds 665,355 shares, or about 21.9 percent. Mr. Levy said a group he heads owns 24.5 percent, or 745,255 shares, of Information Displays, a maker of computer systems based in Armonk, N.Y.

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: TAMPERING SPURS U.S. TO RESTRICT LEADED GAS
description: Automobile owners' tampering with emissions control devices, particularly catalytic converters, is a key concern in the Environmental Protection Agency's plan to speed the phase-out of leaded gasoline, agency officials say.

title: OUT TOWNS
description: North, east and west of New York, in that great wilderness known as the suburbs, man and nature often collide.

title: HEADED U.S. DELEGATION TO U.N.
description: James J. Wadsworth, a former chief American delegate to the United Nations, government administrator and New York state Assemblyman, died Tuesday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 78 years old.

title: VASQUEZ'S LAWYER CITES NEW WITNESS
description: A private investigator will testify that he heard Eddie Maple say he lied when he told a Federal grand jury that Jacinto Vasquez had offered him a bribe to fix a horse race in 1974, according to documents filed yesterday with the State Racing and Wagering Board. The papers were filed by Vasquez, who is seeking a new hearing before the board.

title: O'KOREN SPARKS NETS' VICTORY
description: Mike O'Koren has seen the depressing side, the many nights when he was never called because he was injured or unwanted. And so tonight he did not want to celebrate, even after scoring a season-high 20 points, making two critical defensive plays and leading the Nets to a 108-102 victory over the Phoenix Suns.

title: HUSSEIN RULES OUT TALKS WITH ISRAEL AND BARS U.S. ROLE
description: King Hussein of Jordan today ruled out direct negotiations with Israel any time soon. He said the United States, through one-sided support for Israel, had lost its credibility as a mediator in efforts to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict.

title: IRAQI STAND BACKED BY ARAB LEAGUE MEETING
description: The foreign ministers of Arab League countries tonight condemned Iran for refusing to enter into negotiations with Iraq and indirectly called on all nations to take no actions that would help the Iranians in the war.

title: Mets Pound White Sox
description: The Mets pounded

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Feb. 25.

title: SIMPLE QUESTIONS
description: The man who dropped in couldn't be called ordinary, but he had no claim to distinction. He was an Iraqi who exiled himself to Paris a year or so ago, reads the newspapers and had simple questions.

title: LANGER BIOMECHANICS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income

title: Ads for MTV Cable Adopting New Theme
description: The national advertising campaign that starts Monday for the MTV: Music Television cable network was previewed yesterday by Robert W. Pittman, chief operating officer of Warner-Amex Satellite Entertainment, in a lunchtime talk to the New York Television Academy at the Copacabana.

title: Questions, Questions
description: The IND and BMT lines that go over

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; U.S. Savings and Loan In Eurobond Offering
description: The first Eurobond offering by a United States savings and loan association collateralized by Government National Mortgage Association certificates was announced yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 15, 1984

title: Bulgarian to Be Rejailed In Papal Shooting Case
description: A Rome appeals court ordered today that a Bulgarian return to jail to await possible trial for complicity in the shooting of Pope John Paul II.

title: Technology; Desktop Links To Mainframes
description: ONE of the newest computer industry buzzwords is ''micro-mainframe link.'' Dozens of companies are falling over themselves to announce products designed to allow desktop microcomputers to exchange information with mainframes, large central corporate computers.

title: IMPRACTICAL EXTRA DIGIT FOR NEW YORK PHONES
description: To the Editor:

title: Split Among Democrats Is Welcomed by Aide
description: The Reagan re-election campaign will not be ''totally unhappy'' if Walter F. Mondale emerges the winner of a bloody Democratic primary race, James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, said today.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Article 054594 -- No Title
description: The Senate Finance Committee, shifting from its effort to raise taxes and cut spending to trim the Government's budget deficits, approved tax cuts today that would total $6.1 billion over four years.

title: BOSTON MAYOR TAKES ACTION TO PROMOTE RACIAL HARMONY
description: Mayor Raymond L. Flynn, standing over a small plastic-covered kitchen table in a predominantly black section of the city, gave the widow of a black man shot nine years ago by two white police officers a check for $843,498 today and a moving apology.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
SEA CONTAINERS GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VIEWING OF PUBLIC TV SUFFERS A DROP
description: Viewing of public television in the country's largest cities was down substantially in January, and both February and March are expected to show declines as well.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: Mattel Reports New Debt Pact
description: Mattel Inc.

title: Contrary View On Second Look
description: Did a player charge? Was there goaltending? No matter the call, there is almost another view to a basketball official's decision.

title: ;  Accounts
description: * American Motors Corporation to Grey Advertising-Canada for all Canadian advertising of Jeep and Renault vehicles.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: INVISIBLE MENDING. By Frederick Busch. 277 pages. David R. Godine.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Colombia Rebels Raid A Town and Free 125
description: About 100 guerrillas today slipped into Florencia, the capital of Caqueta state, on public buses, captured the jail, freed 125 inmates and armed some with stolen weapons before the army drove them off, officials reported.

title: THE 2 KOREAS CANNOT AGREE EVEN TO TALK
description: Despite a new exchange of letters and a spate of messages in which each side says it wants to be reunified with the other, North Korea and South Korea seem unlikely to get together even to talk about getting together.

title: PHONE-IN SERVICE DROPS MESSAGES ON SEXUALITY
description: Tape recordings that deal with sexual subjects have been dropped from a call-in telephone service because of protests from Roman Catholics and leaders of groups opposed to abortion, according to the supermarket chain that operates the service.

title: SPECIAL EFFECTS: THE CRAFTSMAN WHO DO TROMPE L'OEIL INTERIORS
description: -L'OEIL artistry has for many years been part of the visual fabric of the city. Building facades, parking-lot walls, apartment-house lobbies and restaurants present bold canvases of illusionistic art. But in the last few years there has been a resurgence in the popularity of trompe-l'oeil techniques in home interiors.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DANCE: RUDOLF NUREYEV VISITS GRAHAM TROUPE
description: RUDOLF NUREYEV dropped in for a single night's guest appearance with the Martha Graham Dance Company Tuesday evening at the State Theater and garnered repeated rounds of warm applause. The event was a benefit for the Martha Graham School and had all the earmarks of a special occasion.

title: Youth EndsTerm For Racial Attack
description: One of three young white men convicted in the June 1982 fatal beating of a black transit worker has been freed after serving seven months in prison, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: Kodak Bonuses
description: Eastman Kodak Company officials said that $254.3 million in ''wage dividends'' would be distributed to 93,000 people employed by the company in 1983.

title: FLOWER SHOW BRINGS SUMMER TO PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA ''MY accountant thinks I'm on an ego trip,'' said Charles Gale of Gale Nurseries. He was being queried about his efforts - and the $35,000 he had spent - to persuade so many summer flowers to bloom this week in his exhibition at the Philadelphia Flower Show. The five-acre show, which opened last Sunday and runs through next Sunday, is sponsored by the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society and has as its theme this year ''A Trip to the Orient.'' Included are 83 trade booths and exhibits by 27 nurseries and florists, 7 plant societies, 13 educational groups and 583 amateur classes.

title: U.S.CocaineDrive Delays Travelers
description: The United States Customs Service has begun a new crackdown on cocaine smuggling, with inspections of all cargo ships, airliners and passenger luggage from Colombia.

title: GROVER A. WHALEN Jr.
description: Grover A. Whalen Jr., a certified public accountant and the son of Grover A. Whalen, New York City's official greeter from 1919 to 1953, died of cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan.

title: WOMAN WAS WILLING, RAPE DEFENDANT SAYS
description: One of six men charged with rape in a barroom incident testified today that he had tried and failed to have sex on pool table with a willing woman who hugged him afterward and asked him to take her home.

title: Redmen Buoyed
description: Coach Lou Carnesecca of St. John's will be absorbed with the present tonight as his Redmen play Temple in a first-round game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in Charlotte, Va. But when the coach has time to look forward to the 1984-85 season, he will have occasion to smile.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Great Western Financial Corp, through its wholly owned subsidiary, GW Mortgage Securities Corp., announced it had filed for up to $1 billion in collateralized mortgage obligations. No underwriters have been named and interest rates and maturities will be established upon issue.

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses including tax credits of $1,567,000 for the quarter and $723,000 for the year. Latest results are for the two months and eleven months ended Dec 31, 1983, since the company changed its fiscal year-end from Jan. 31 to Dec. 31. Year-ago results are for the quarter and year ended Jan. 31, 1983.

title: PICTURE FRAME CARE
description: It's a rare household that doesn't have one or two old picture frames sitting around in closets or garages awaiting repairs or rejuvenation.

title: HOW TO STOP SYRIA
description: Syria has won the day in Lebanon. And its Soviet allies are delighted. It's all over but the killing.

title: Cuomo Pledges Aid For Victims of AIDS
description: Governor Cuomo, facing sharp criticism from the Episcopal Bishop of New York, reversed himself today and said he expected to provide $4.1 million in his budget for victims of AIDS.

title: British Miners Barred From Extending Strike
description: A court barred militant coal miners today from using ''flying pickets'' - men who move swiftly from place to place, as needed - to extend a strike to all of Britain.

title: THE CREDIT CARD FEE DISPUTE
description: Rarely has Congress had before it an issue with effects as wide-reaching as the question of whether merchants should be permitted to impose fees on customers who make purchases with credit cards. It affects millions of card holders, hundreds of thousands of merchants and billions of dollars that flow through the accounts of banks and credit card companies.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Arguments Delayed In Miami Police Trial
description: The chief prosecutor's illness today forced postponement of final arguments in the manslaughter trial of a police officer, Luis Alvarez, whose shooting of a young black man in a video arcade set off a three-day riot.

title: SALVADORAN LEGISLATOR SLAIN, THE 3D ASSASSINATED IN 1984
description: A deputy from the conservative National Conciliation Party was shot to death tonight by unidentified gunmen in downtown San Salvador.

title: The Democrats:
description: A Delegate Update

title: JIM VALVANO'S VIEW
description: Even though the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament has whittled itself down to the Final 48, the defending champion is not defending. North Carolina State, with a 19-13 record, was not deemed worthy of an invitation by the selection committee. Jim Valvano now is on the outside looking in, which adds to the validity of the Wolfpack coach's view on form and format.

title: JET AMERICA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $3,552,000 for the quarter and $3,655,000 for the year and a gain of $6.4 million for the quarter and year on the sale of tax benefits. c-Net loss

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 15, 1984 International
description: King Hussein of Jordan ruled out direct negotiations with Israel any time soon. He also said the United States, through one-sided support for Israel, had lost its credibility as a mediator in efforts to resolve Arab-Israeli differences. (Page A1, Column 6.) King Hussein's criticism of President Reagan's policies, one day after Mr. Reagan defended Jordan before a pro-Israeli audience, will probably discourage any American initiatives in the Middle East for some time, according to a Reagan Administration official. (A11:1.)

title: ;  Harris Offering
description: The Harris Graphics Corporation said it had filed for an initial public offering of three million common shares.

title: BRIEFING
description: Those Energy Coupons

title: TV: 'ROCKIN' AND ROLLIN' WITH PHIL SPECTER,' A DOCUMENTARY
description: ''ROCKIN' & ROLLIN' WITH PHIL SPECTOR'' is a peculiar testimonial to the man who established the pop record producer as a star. The documentary, which will be shown at 10:30 tonight on Channel 13, is mistitled - Mr. Spector appears just briefly, in a 1965 film clip - and starts out praising Mr. Spector in order to bury him.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $1,052,600 for the quarter and $1,324,600 for the year. c-After a tax credit of $29,700. d-Net loss. The year-earlier quarter results was comprised of two months and the 1982 year ended Oct. 31, but the company has changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31.

title: CHOICE AND USE OF POTTING SOILS
description: THIS is the time of year when gardeners are starting seed indoors or repotting house plants. For such tasks, potting soil is an important consideration because good roots are what plants are all about.

title: More Money for a 49er
description: Dwight Clark , the San Francisco 49er wide receiver, has signed a three-year contract that will reportedly give him a total of $1.675 million and make him the highest-paid player on the club - but not for long. Joe Montana , the quarterback, has also been renegotiating his contract.

title: TECHNODYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $1,829,000 from the sale of Acton Environmental Testing Corp. Year-ago revenues include $1,210,000 for the quarter and $2,175,000 for the 6 months from Acton Environmental Testing, a wholly owned subsidiary, which was subsequently sold.

title: Austerity in Venezuela
description: President Jaime Lusinchi announced austerity plans tonight aimed at rescuing the economy from the effects of a world oil oversupply and a $35 billion foreign debt. He said salaries and benefits for some officials would be cut and the Government would study the restructuring, merging or disposal of money-losing state industries. Mr. Lusinchi also announced a hiring freeze for the bureaucracy, which employs 1.2 million, or about one of every 13 Venezuelans. He said cuts in public spending would save $1.3 billion and another $3.5 billion would come from a modification of exchange controls.

title: Papers for Tennessee Walking Horses Queried
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is is conducting a nationwide probe of charges that breeding papers for Tennessee walking horses were falsified, The Nashville Banner reported today.

title: Of Analogy and Abortion
description: It's good to have Bishop John J. O'Connor's explanation greatly narrowing the sense in which he would compare abortion in America with the Nazis' slaughter of Jews. He expresses outrage that this page read his initial remarks as implying that Hitler had a ''Jewish'' problem needing solution and that women choosing an abortion were guilty of a crime comparable to the Holocaust. That is a welcome clarification.

title: Horizon/Meamco
description: The Horizon ad agency of Athens, specialists in advertising in the Middle East, which recently bought out its Foote, Cone & Belding partner, has now merged with Meamco (Middle East Advertising and Marketing Corporation) of New York.

title: Internorth Plans
description: Internorth Inc. shareholders will vote on a proposal intended to prevent a two-tiered tender offer as well as a proposal to increase the number of common shares, according to the company's proxy statement. The first proposal would require that a potential acquirer, in order to exercise a two-step merger, would have to acquire 80 percent of the voting stock in the first-step tender offer, persuade other holders to join votes to equal 80 percent or be prepared to pay the highest price to all remaining shareholders.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS SEEK TO QUESTION THOSE WHO AIDED MESSE FINANCIALLY
description: Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee said today that they wanted to question almost everyone involved in providing financial help to Edwin Meese 3d before they could vote on his nomination to be Attorney General.

title: Yields Rise For C.D.'s
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit rose nationwide yesterday to 9.56 percent, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: AS LOFT HOUSING FACES OVERDUE REGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: A PRIEST'S RETURN TO THE BRONX
description: The Rev. Joseph Aloysius O'Hare says he is going home.

title: LICENSING OF REACTOR IN SOUTH QUESTIONED BY COMMITTEE HEAD
description: Federal regulators gave the Grand Gulf nuclear power plant in Mississippi a test license despite hundreds of errors in its equipment testing and performance standards, a House subcommittee chairman said today.

title: Senator Helms Even With Governor in Poll
description: Senator Jesse Helms pulled even with his Democratic opponent, Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., in the race for a United States Senate seat, a statewide poll indicated Tuesday.

title: HOW MONDALE'S FLAGGING CAMPAIGN WAS REVIVED
description: Walter F. Mondale revived his flagging Presidential drive in the Southern primaries Tuesday with crucial strength among black voters, with appeal on bread-and-butter economic issues and with sharp attacks that damaged the public image of Senator Gary Hart, according to the findings of New York Times/CBS News Polls. As Hart strategists and other politicans observed, the Mondale drive for the Democratic Presidential nomination was also aided significantly by the ability of Senator John Glenn of Ohio to pull 21 percent of the vote in Alabama and 18 percent in Georgia. Mr. Glenn's support came mainly among the same sort of independent voters and pro-Reagan Democrats who formed the core of Senator Hart's support.

title: HOW ERRORS CONVICTED WRONG MAN
description: Nathaniel Carter shifted his lanky frame, turning the chair to get a better look at his former wife, Delisa, who sat a few feet away in the witness box of an oak-paneled Queens courtroom. She was confessing to murder.

title: Primary on April 7 Called Off by Louisiana
description: Louisiana election officials today canceled plans for a state primary April 7, inviting a possible court challenge under the Federal Voting Rights Act.

title: DATRICON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter and year losses included about $282,000 in charges related to the discontinuance of a product line.

title: TENSE MEDICAL STUDENTS MEET FUTURE
description: Leslie A. Vensel had an upset stomach. Sandra Chaplan broke out in a rash. Robin J. Mitchell had had trouble sleeping.

title: INDIA STILL LOOKS TO SOVIET BUT ELSEWHERE TOO
description: The Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri F. Ustinov, ended a six-day visit here last week by assuring India that Moscow would supply it with a variety of up-to-date military equipment. This will reportedly include one of the latest MIG fighters, intended to counter the F-16's that Pakistan is receiving from the United States.

title: Profit at Semiconductor
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation announced yesterday that it earned $15.4 million, or 18 cents a share, in the third quarter ended March 4, contrasted with a loss of $18.5 million in the comparable period last year.

title: TURNER BROADCASTING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss.

title: CELEBRATING WILLIAM MORRIS'S WORKS
description: LONDON SEVERAL exhibitions and celebrations planned to coincide with the 150th birthday of William Morris on March 24 indicate a renewal of interest in one of the 19th century's most interesting men, and one of its most difficult to categorize. A painter, weaver, printer and pattern maker whose designs led to the revival of decorative arts in Britain known as the Arts and Crafts Movement, Morris was most well known in his time as a poet. He was also a novelist and critic with decided opinions about the social and economic upheavals of the Victorian age. By the time he died in 1896, five years before Queen Victoria, Morris had accomplished so much that his doctor said he had died of ''simply being William Morris.''

title: Prudential's Bache in Black
description: Prudential-Bache Securities

title: War Across the Hudson
description: ''We in New Jersey would like to have a clean Big Apple, not a rotten apple,'' declares Senator Frank Lautenberg. ''New York City is a manifestation of what's wrong with America,'' rumbles Passaic's Representative Robert Roe.

title: ; Two Steps Down, But a Step Forward
description: Numerous college recruiters sharpened their map-reading and correspondence skills by either finding their way to John Benbrook's home in Middletown, N.J., or sending him letters of entreaty.

title: Moore Stops Oswald in 3d
description: Davey Moore, in his first bout since he lost his World Boxing Association title to Roberto Duran, stopped Monte Oswald tonight in the third round of a scheduled 10-round junior middleweight bout.

title: 'DYNASTY' LUXURY FOR SALE
description: There have been Dukes of Hazzard toy cars, M*A*S*H T-shirts, J. R. beer, and Muppets merchandise of virtually every description. Now there will be a Dynasty fur collection, a perfume called ''Forever Krystle'' and a line of tuxedos in a color that, as the advertising declares, is ''richer than royal and darker than midnight - it's Dynasty blue.''

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,321,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: PUPIL PRAYER VOTE BLOCKED IN SENATE
description: One Democrat blocked efforts today by Senate Republicans to bring to a vote President Reagan's proposed constitutional amendment to sanction vocal prayer in the public schools.

title: Canada Retail Sales Up
description: Canadian seasonally adjusted retail sales rose 3.1 percent in January, to $9.33 billion, after a downward revised eight-tenths of 1 percent rise in December, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The agency originally reported the December increase as 1.3 percent.

title: COSTLY MEDICAL DEVICES PROPERLY ALLOTED
description: To the Editor:

title: Carnesecca Counts His Blessings
description: Lou Carnesecca said he traced the origin of the basketball referee to the days of the Roman Empire, when the Romans sat in the Colosseum, giving the thumbs-up and thumbs-down signs. The St. John's coach also speculated on the effect of the moon on winning and losing streaks - a popular theory in Europe, no kidding, he said - and offered an unsolicited scouting report on Auburn, one of the teams participating in the first round of the East regional here.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: The Rangers are still in a state of mix-and-match. Nightly they must keep six players out of the lineup, with the playoffs only three weeks away. They are searching for the right people in the right places, hoping to find the combinations that will bring them their first Stanley Cup since 1940.

title: Music in the Jungle
description: It was an incongruous sight, a six-

title: CITY NAMED ANDROPOV MAKES MAPS OBSOLETE
description: The Soviet leadership today announced a number of memorials to Yuri V. Andropov, including giving his name to a 1,000-year- old Volga River city where he started his political career in the 1930's.

title: AGENCY DISPUTING LAW'S JURISDICTION
description: The Federal Energy Department has agreed to obey the toxic waste disposal law at its nuclear facilities only on a voluntary basis, although a written opinion by the Justice Department said that it is subject to the law.

title: U.S. DISCOURAGED BY KING'S REMARKS
description: An Administration official said today that King Hussein's criticism of President Reagan's policies, one day after the President defended Jordan before a pro-Israeli audience, would probably discourage any new American initiatives in the Middle East for some time.

title: No Headline
description: Jury Finds Man Guilty I

title: LYUBIMOV'S FALL
description: Yuri Lyubimov, the Russian director who was dimissed from his post as head of the Taganka Theater in Moscow this month, said today that his downfall had resulted in part from the death of Yuri V. Andropov, who had often shielded him from the wrath of Soviet cultural watchdogs.

title: Comings and Goings
description: -captain of the Boston College basketball team, quit the team just before the Eagles' participation in the National Invitation Tournament. He told television station WBZ that he was quitting because of incidents ''over a couple of years'' involving Coach Gary Williams .

title: A WEST WING MYSTERY: WHERE IS BAKER'S FROG?
description: Staff disarray is once again plaguing the Reagan White House, this time over the whereabouts of a frog reported missing from the office of James A. Baker 3d, the President's chief of staff.

title: Bell Atlantic
description: The Bell Atlantic Telephone Companies have agreed to process equipment service orders, both from their own affiliates and from independent vendors, through a single entity, the North American Telecommunications Association said. Under the agreement, filed with the Federal Communications Commission, the seven Bell Atlantic operating companies will process service requests from all business equipment customers through a central operations group.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT THE RECOVERY
description: It's a custom of the political season that Presidents seeking re-election take credit for good times and promise ever better times ahead. President Reagan is no exception. What he hasn't reckoned on is the business cycle, which may well create a starkly different climate sometime in the next 18 months, perhaps even before the election.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: aGovernor Vetoes Bill On Homosexual Rights

title: MODERN MUSEUM GIVEN 249 ABSTRACT WORKS
description: Two-hundred-and-forty-nine works of art from the collection of the McCrory Corporation, including examples from every major 20th-century geometric abstract style or movement, and a $1.75 million contribution have been given to the Museum of Modern Art by the corporation.

title: Senator to Auction Farm
description: Many of the 3,000 Georgia farmers who went out of business last year blamed Congress for their economic hardship, but on Monday a Senator announced that he, too, was shutting down his farming operation. The auctioneer's gavel is to fall Friday on all the farming equipment on the 2,500-acre spread owned by Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia. Senator Nunn said his decision was based on the retirement of his long-time farm manager, S. Watson Fisher.

title: MILLER-WOHL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
MONDALE IS FACING FINANCIAL SQUEEZE IN NOMINATION BID
description: The Democratic Presidential campaign moved yesterday toward the key political states of the industrial Middle West. At the same time, Walter F. Mondale's campaign began to feel a financial squeeze at a crucial phase of the struggle for the nomination.

title: New Walt Disney Film Sets Opening Record
description: Walt Disney Productions said this week that its new film, ''Splash,'' had an opening weekend gross of $6,174,059, the highest such gross in the company's history.

title: Advertising; Meeting People's Publisher
description: THE fast track you keep hearing

title: Rail Engineer Sentenced
description: An Illinois Central Gulf engineer, convicted of being drunk when a train hauling toxic chemicals derailed in 1982, was ordered today to spend one year in prison and pay a $5,000 fine. State District Judge Kenneth Fogg gave the engineer, Edwin Peyton Robertson, a five-year prison term but suspended all but one year of it. The judge also put him on active probation for five years, ordering him to attend a substance abuse clinic as part of his probation.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
FOR HANGING INDOOR PLANTS
description: GROWING plants indoors requires specialized equipment, and there are some new products to make plant- care easier.

title: Hughes Aircraft Fight
description: After eight years, the battle for control of the Hughes Aircraft Company, one of the nation's largest aerospace and military contractors, is nearing a climax, with at least three factions submitting names for trustees of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $72,000 for the quarter and $323,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $3,564,000 from disocntinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting methods for oil and gas operations.

title: FAIR SHOWS A RISE IN EAST-WEST TRADE
description: With the climate for private banks' lending to Eastern European nations improving, a modest recovery in East-West trade seems to have begun.

title: MUSIC: 2 ANNIVERSARIES AND LEONARD BERNSTEIN
description: SOMEBODY at the New York Philharmonic had a bright idea to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the orchestra's Young People's Concerts. The Portland Youth Philharmonic is the oldest youth orchestra in the country, and it, too, is celebrating its 60th anniversary this year. So the Oregon ensemble, on its way to a European tour, was invited to Avery Fisher Hall for a joint concert with the local Philharmonic last night.

title: INVENTORIES UP 0.4% AND SALES 1.3%
description: Businesses increased their inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent in January while sales were up a brisk 1.3 percent from December's record levels, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CANADIAN FOUNDATION CO LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After special gains of $700,000 for the latest year and $4.5 million for the earlier year.

title: NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MONDALE DEPENDS ON LABOR TO WIN MICHIGAN CAUCUSES
description: Michigan's Democrats will conduct caucuses Saturday, and once again Walter F. Mondale's campaign is counting heavily on the support of organized labor.

title: 500 Flee Boston Hotel Fire; Third This Year at the Westin
description: About 500 guests of the Westin Hotel stayed overnight in other quarters after an electrical fire, the third this year at the 37-story luxury building, forced them to flee into a snowstorm, officials said.

title: NELSON, L B, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ad Claims for Coffee Among Settled Issues
description: The crowd that is promoting coffee to the younger set as well as the Coke and 7-Up gangs got some of their advertising claims investigated by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: SEACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $20,754,000 for the quarter and $7,061,000 for the year, a gain of $4,612,000 for the year on the disposal of container operations and a provision of $23 million for the year for the loss on the disposal of shipping operations. c-Including a gain of $1,989,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $4,083,000.

title: ILLINOIS TO TEST LEADERS TUESDAY FOR BIG STAKES
description: Now that Senator Gary Hart has swept the New England Democratic Presidential primaries and split the South with Walter F. Mondale, the 194 delegates in Illinois loom large. They make up the largest bloc elected yet in a primary and the first in a major Middle Western industrial state.

title: A.T.&T. to Close Baltimore Works
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterady that it would phase out its Baltimore manufacturing operations over the next 12 to 18 months, eliminating 3,500 jobs.

title: TONSILLECTOMY FOUND JUSTIFIED IN SOME CASES
description: Contrary to much current medical opinion, tonsillectomy can be effective for children suffering frequent, very severe sore throats, according to a study published yesterday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Evan Morris Wilson Is Dead; 30 Years in Foreign Service
description: Evan Morris Wilson, a retired Foreign Service officer, died Tuesday of cancer at his home in Washington. He was 74 years old.

title: TELCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss c-Including an extraordinary credit of $121,000. Share earnings reflect a 1-for-2 reverse stock split in December 1983.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A WASHINGTON-NEW YORK APPRAISAL
description: Can you find a good pastrami sandwich in the capital? Do Georgetowners eat bagels?

title: EMPIRE SAVINGS OF TEXAS IS SHUT DOWN
description: The Federal agency that regulates savings associations today shut down the Empire Savings and Loan Association of Mesquite, Tex., which it said was insolvent and had obtained more than 85 percent of its deposits, or about $262 million, from money brokers, nearly all of it in 1983.

title: CASEY'S GENERAL STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MENTALLY ILL CRIMINALS: 'AS CULPABLE AS ANYONE'
description: To the Editor:

title: TANZANIA FACING INTERNAL STRAINS
description: A substantial number of people on this spice-growing island show signs of disenchantment with Zanzibar's merger 20 years ago with the mainland African state then called Tanganyika.

title: Dr. Charles D. Hendley Dies; Eye Research Helped Pilots
description: Dr. Charles D. Hendley, a physiologist whose research during World War II helped improve the night flying abilities of pilots, died of a heart attack Monday at Middlesex General and University Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Highland Park, N.J.

title: Dow Up 1.26; Trading Slows
description: Stock prices finished mixed yesterday in slower trading when new concern over interest rates dampened some of the investors' recent enthusiasm.

title: FREY ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
FINANCIER DECLINES TO TESTIFY IN CASH-LAUNDERING INQUIRY
description: A financier declined to testify here yesterday before the President's Commission on Organized Crime about how his currency-exchange company purportedly was used by criminals to launder about $100 million.

title: New Yacht Race Is Planned Here
description: A new international yacht race called the Liberty Cup and featuring some of the world's foremost sailors, including Ted Turner, will be held as part of the Harbor Festival celebrations in New York over the Fourth of July weekend.

title: PACIFIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $631,000 for the quarter and $614,000 for the year. c-Net income including extraordinary credits of $492,000 for the quarter and $488,000 for the year.

title: F.C.C. Is Upheld on Equal-Time Rule
description: In a victory for broadcasters, an appellate court has ruled that radio and television stations may sponsor political debates without giving equal time to candidates they don't invite.

title: ALBANY LEADERS CITE DOUBTS ON CUOMO'S WINE SALES PLAN
description: The leaders of both houses of the State Legislature said today that they had serious doubts about Governor Cuomo's proposal to allow the sale of wine - but only New York State wine - in grocery stores.

title: PENTAGON'S RULES WAIVE GUARANTEES
description: The Department of Defense will permit its officials to waive in many cases a new law requiring that weapons be guaranteed by their makers.

title: BRIDGE
description: Third- round play in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here Tuesday produced only one major upset - a defeat for a sentimental favorite, Oswald Jacoby.

title: THE LONELY WORLD OF MICHAEL BURKE
description: AN amusing item on this paper's sports page caught my eye a couple of months ago. It concerned the progress that Michael Burke, who retired from an executive position at Madison Square Garden and moved to Ireland in 1981, is making on his autobiography, tentatively titled ''Outrageous Good Fortune.'' ''I've been consumed by it,'' he told a visitor last fall, ''and I've liked it.'' But he conceded that the solitary literary life had taken some getting used to.

title: NETWORK SECURITY CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CALIFORNIA TOWN'S ISSUE: IS IT RUGGED OR SLUMMY?
description: Depending mostly on where you live, this unincorporated town of 1,500 people overlooking the Pacific is either a picturesque rural slum, a vestige of 60's life styles or a town that is an extended family, the only place in the Bay Area to pursue ''innovative approaches to life'' in peace and harmony.

title: THE DEMOCRATS- AND THE DEMOCRATS
description: Super Tuesday, decision day of dread, ended up bringing good news to both leading Democratic candidates and to both Democratic Parties.

title: Top Glenn Aide Leaves To Work for Gary Hart
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio lost a New York state campaign chairman today to Senator Gary Hart.

title: U.S.I.A.'S 'BLACKLIST'
description: The moment the United States Information Agency's ''blacklist'' of speakers surfaced last month, agency officials disavowed it.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
2 GERMANYS AND DETENTE
description: As West and East Germany forge a miniature version of detente in the center of Europe, officials and diplomats here say neither the United States nor the Soviet Union is exercising much control over the warming relations between their respective German allies. The latest forum for encounters between politicians of the two Germanys was the Leipzig fair in East Germany, where Erich Honecker, the country's Communist Party leader, disclosed this week that he had accepted an invitation to make his first official visit to West Germany. Bonn to Be Avoided

title: Boys Die After Fall Into Lake
description: Doctors worked for 10 hours late Tuesday and early today to save two brothers who fell through ice on a mountain lake and were trapped under water, one for 20 minutes and the other for 45 minutes.

title: S. M. Flickinger May Sell Control
description: S. M. Flickinger Inc., the fifth-largest wholesale grocery company in the nation, said without elaboration that it was negotiating the possible sale of controlling interest in the company.

title: The U.N. Today; March 15, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: What's in a Name?
description: It was only in the last decade that the University of Massachusetts, under pressure from Indian groups, dropped the century-old Redmen nickname for its athletic teams and adopted the designation Minutemen. That satisfied the Indian groups, but not, it turned out, everybody else.

title: SEARS ROEBUCK ACCEPTANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN'S ELECTION YEAR TAPESTRY: A TRIP TO CHINA
description: As the Democratic Presidential candidates stagger through a blur of rallies and handshaking, White House officials are completing plans for a more stately election year tapestry for President Reagan: his trip to China at the end of April.

title: Aminoil President Adds Title of Chief Executive
description: J. B. Coffman, president and chief operating officer of Aminoil Inc., has been named chief executive, effective April 1. Aminoil, a subsidiary of R. J. Reynolds Industries, is one of the largest independent petroleum exploration and production companies.

title: DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. Is Sued On Drug Searches
description: A Colombian steamship line has filed suit against the United States Government, charging that a new crackdown on cocaine smuggling has led to ''oppressive'' and ''unreasonable'' search methods that have entailed ''additional costs and delay'' for the line and violated its rights.

title: Addenda
description: * Seventeen magazine increasing its circulation rate base 3.3 percent, to 1.55 million, from 1.5 million, and its advertising rates by the same percentage, with the August issue.

title: NATO Begins War Games
description: Shadowed by Soviet ships and planes, a fleet that NATO called the biggest it had ever assembled steamed toward northern Norway today to begin the Teamwork 84 military maneuvers.

title: NUTRI/SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MILAN MESSAGE: A MEN'S-WEAR LOOK
description: There is no difficulty deciphering the fashion message from Milan for the fall season. The emphasis is clearly on man-tailored clothes, especially coats, jackets and pants. The coats are almost invariably wide-shouldered and loose, to fit over everything including the jackets, and are almost ankle-length. Skirts are shorter, but not by much.

title: BID TO SANCTION SCHOOL PRAYERS KILLED IN SENATE
description: The Senate today overwhelmingly rejected a proposed constitutional amendment to sanction silent prayer in the public schools. It agreed to vote Tuesday on President Reagan's proposal for vocal prayer.

title: PIZZA INN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in August 1983.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Cobb Is Called Vital to Plot

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
RIGHTIST POLITICIAN, A RETIRED COLONEL, IS SLAIN IN SALVADOR
description: A retired colonel who worked for a far-right political party was shot to death here today by unidentified gunmen.

title: Houston Industries
description: Houston Industries said the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's Atomic Safety and Licensing Board had found that project design and construction on its South Texas Nuclear Project meets Federal requirements. It said the board had also affirmed its ''character and competence'' as project manager. A group had charged that Houston Industries lacked the managerial character and technical competence to operate the plant safely.

title: 14-Ounce Baby InStableCondition
description: A 14-ounce baby boy born four and a half months premature was listed in stable condition yesterday at Misericordia Hospital in the Bronx.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Ballet in Queens
description: American Ballet Theater II, the touring unit of Ballet Theater, will make its only metropolitan-area appearance of the season tomorrow night at 8 in the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION. By

title: FEBRUARY'S PRODUCTION UP BY 1.2%
description: Industrial production rose 1.2 percent in February from January, the second strong increase in two months, offering what one analyst called further proof of ''a superb business expansion.''

title: 'First Camera' Canceled By NBC as of April 1
description: ''First Camera,'' the NBC Sunday night news magazine program, has been canceled.

title: WEST SIDE RESTAURATEUR
description: Pierre Pujol, owner of the Pierre Au Tunnel restaurant on Manhattan's West Side for more than 30 years, died yesterday in a hospital in Toulouse, France. He had suffered a stroke more than two weeks ago at his home in Erce in the foothills of the Pyrenees.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''WHEN I went to school here, we didn't talk about Lincoln Center, we didn't talk about Carnegie Hall, when something was happening, it was sure to be at the Hunter College Playhouse,'' Bernice Kinard Baxter, class of '51 and now a faculty member at the college, recalled. Restoring the venerable playhouse to its former position as a first- rate theater - right now it is used mainly as classroom space - was the purpose of a benefit that included a concert by the soprano Martina Arroyo and a dinner in the new student cafeteria, transformed with candles, flowers and soft lights. Miss Arroyo, class of '56, was one of many to reflect nostalgically about her alma mater.

description: John Glenn, once considered the principal challenger to Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, plans to withdraw from the race, top campaign aides said today.

title: DE BEERS'S FUTURE IN NAMIBIA
description: -West Africa - If southern Africa's optimists are to be believed, the stirrings of political independence for South-West Africa are again in the air. But if the testimony of the diamond mines that stretch through surf and pale desert northward from here are any indication, the economic counterpart of such freedom will prove even more elusive.

title: Australian Strikes Ebb
description: Australia lost fewer working days because of strikes last year, the Government said today. For each thousand employees, 249 working days were lost to strikes in 1983, down from 396 days per thousand in 1982 and the least since 1967.

title: NORTH CAROLINA MAN EXECUTED IN DEATHS OF 3 POLICE OFFICERS

title: FRAUDULENT TRIAL SETS OFF PURGE IN SOVIET REPUBLIC
description: An official Soviet account of a miscarriage of justice, in which five men were falsely accused of a double murder in 1981, has ended with a wholesale purge of police and judicial officials in the western republic of Byelorussia.

title: MAN WITH A LOADED SHOTGUN IS SHOT OUTSIDE WHITE HOUSE
description: A White House guard tonight shot and wounded a man on the sidewalk outside the White House grounds after he drew a loaded sawed-off shotgun, a spokesman for the United States Park Police said.

title: Edward B. Haines Dies at 73;Ex-Paterson News Publisher
description: Edward B. Haines, publisher emeritus of The News of Paterson, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Wayne General Hospital today. He was 73 years old and lived in Paterson.

description: The Sony Corporation and Canon Inc., two high technology Japanese companies, reported sharply increased profits.

title: Flyers Win, 6-3
description: Dave Poulin scored two goals and added an assist as the Flyers defeated the Boston Bruins, 6-3, tonight. Philadelphia trails the third-place Rangers by a point in the Patrick Division race. Bobby Clarke, playing for the first time since Coach Bob McCammon forced him to take a week's rest, assisted on the Flyers' first goal for his 1,200th National Hockey League point, a milestone only 10 other players have reached.

title: AWARD IN A CHURCH PRIVACY SUIT
description: A jury today awarded $390,000 to a divorced woman who filed a $1.3 million lawsuit against the Collinsville Church of Christ and three of its elders for publicly denouncing her for the ''sin of fornication.''

description: ALMOST everyone agrees that deregulation has increased the nation's economic efficiency. The process has introduced new competition into the markets and has forced traditional providers of goods and services to analyze their costs and streamline their operations.

description: The Mitel Corporation said it would lay off at least 191 full-time workers at its United States plants and another 155 temporary workers in Puerto Rico.

title: Striking Back
description: When his Loyola of Chicago team was passed over for the National Invitation Tournament, Coach Gene Sullivan 's first response was to threaten a lawsuit. Then he got a better idea - staging a counter-tournament for other 20-game winners snubbed by the N.I.T. Yesterday, after floating the proposal in the Chicago press, Sullivan was meeting with three separate groups offering to put up the $50,000 to $75,000 he figures it will take to finance such a tournament. According to an assistant, Doug Bruno, four teams, (Bucknell, George Mason, Montana and Samford) have agreed to participate; two (Ohio University and Illinois-Chicago) have expressed interest in the idea, and two others (Navy and Texas-San Antonio) are considering the proposal.

title: Prosecution Ends in Trial Of 9 Klansmen and Nazis
description: -SALEM, N.C., March 15 - After eight weeks of testimony, the prosecution rested its case today in the Federal trial of six Ku Klux Klan members and three American Nazi Party members accused of civil rights violations in the 1979 shooting deaths of five Communist Workers Party members in Greensboro, N.C.
