title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Detroit Pistons, at Pontiac, Mich. In the Nets' last 10 games, their only loss has been to Detroit. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M., tape. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.)

title: ART: FERNAND KHNOPFF OF BELGIAN SYMBOLISTS
description: FOR quite a while now, the Belgian Symbolist movement of the 1880's and 90's has been drifting downstream toward us like a wreath of orchids on an all- but-stagnant river. Northern mists have kept us from getting too close, so that we know the Belgian Symbolists as tranced phantoms, rather than as people who might walk into a downtown tavern in Brussels and order a quadruple helping of eel pie.

title: MATTEL REPORTS $171.3 MILLION DEFICIT FOR QUARTER
description: Mattel Inc. reported yesterday that previously announced provisions for discontinuing its consumer electronics and other non-toy divisions resulted in a loss of $171.3 million in the quarter ended Jan. 28.

title: Merrill May Cut 1,000 Employees
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, parent of the nation's largest brokerage firm, said it might lay off as many as 1,000 administrative and clerical employees over the next six weeks to reduce costs.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Texaco Planning to Sell Record Eurobond Issue
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it planned to sell $800 million in 10-year convertible bonds to investors outside the United States in what would be the biggest such issue ever in the Eurobond market.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Dow Rises by 1.36; Trading Moderate
description: Stock prices posted a modest advance yesterday in moderate trading as many institutional investors continued to remain on the sidelines because of uncertainty over interest rates.

title: Intel to Farm Out Some of Its Work
description: The Intel Corporation said it would contract out the manufacturing of certain semiconductor products to help alleviate severe product shortages.

title: ART: BAZIOTES, A RARELY SEEN FANTASIST
description: OF the pioneer New York artists attending the birth of Abstract Expressionism in the early 1940's, William Baziotes (1912-63) is today one of the least exhibited. A traveling Baziotes show appeared at four small museums in 1978, but in New York the work was last seen at the Marlborough Gallery in 1971, after a memorial show at the Guggenheim Museum six years earlier. One reason may be that Baziotes's lyrical, phantasmagorical work, which retained the Surrealist affinities that his colleagues broke away from, lacks the drive and energy of canvases made by such true Abstract Expressionists as Jackson Pollock, Robert Motherwell and Clyfford Still.

title: CUOMO SHIFTS SITE OF NEW PRISON FROM BRONX TO EAST RIVER ISLAND
description: Governor Cuomo announced today that the state had abandoned its effort to build a 1,000-cell maximum-security prison in the South Bronx and instead would construct the prison on North Brother Island in the East River.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: No Jazz Return To Las Vegas

title: TRIAL OF U.S. JUDGE IN BRIBE CASE OPEN
description: A Government prosecutor said today that Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne had failed to include thousands of dollars of legal-fee payments in his tax returns.

title: WATCHMAN SHOT IN '83 IS TERMED VICTIM OF THE PENN STATION SNIPER
description: A seventh victim has been identified in the Pennsylvania Station sniper investigation, the police said yesterday.

title: Camp Casualties
description: Two baseball stars are hurting in training camp. First, the often-ailing George Brett of the Kansas City Royals was struck in the mouth by a hard-bouncing grounder Wednesday and will have oral surgery to straighten some of his teeth.

title: Prices Rise in Germany
description: Wholesale prices in West Germany rose seven-tenths of 1 percent during February and were up 4.9 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today.

title: A LOOK AT CLOWNING AS A SERIOUS JOB
description: It was a big, confusing day for 2 1/2- year-old Michole Jones of the South Bronx. Instead of her normal eight hours with a baby sitter, she got to go to her mother's high school to see the clown. Four clowns, actually.

title: Panhandle Unit Submits Proposals
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation said its Trunkline Gas Company unit had submitted new proposals to several large gas producers as the basis for settling its take-or-pay exposure, which was $1.1 billion at year-end.

title: Cable TV Penetration
description: A. C. Nielsen has released its latest quarterly report on the household penetration of cable TV, which has now reached 41.2 percent of the nation's 34.7 million television households. This compares with 37.2 percent in February 1983 and 40.5 percent last November.

title: Princeton Eliminated in West;  Las Vegas 68 Princeton 56
description: Ed Catchings and Eric Booker, a pair of reserves, each scored 18 points as Nevada-Las Vegas overpowered Princeton, 68-56, tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association West Regional.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Buffton Corp, an oil and gas company based in Fort Worth, said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire all the operations of Flo Control Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: THEATER: 'PEARSE MOTEL'
description: ADULTS collide in Hugh Leonard's satirical bedroom farce, ''The Patrick Pearse Motel.'' The play, first presented in Dublin in 1971 and now having its New York premiere at the Riverwest Theater, is not ''Da,'' and does not pretend to be. Mr. Leonard simply sets up his situation and lets the dominoes fall. The dialogue is funny, the jokes are in character, and they are aimed at ecumenical targets: the Irish and the English, church and state, husbands and errant wives, patriots and hypocrites.

title: PUTTING A VALUE ON U.S. NEWS
description: Within days, the financial secrets of U.S. News & World Report Inc. will be sent by Morgan Stanley & Company to several prospective buyers. Bidding for the employee-owned company and weekly news magazine will then begin.

title: United Upsets J.A.L.
description: Japan Air Lines said today that it might file a complaint against United Airlines, a subsidiary of UAL Inc., on the ground that a reduced-fare package planned by United for flights from Japan to the United States is unfair.

title: SPSVoted More Funds
description: The city's Board of Estimate yesterday approved an additional $80,737.82 for the Transit Authority's new Coney Island Paint Shop.

title: TRAVELING THEATER ARRIVES
description: When the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater began in 1967, the traveling part could not have been more literal. It was a company with a street-theater ethic and a vagabond's itinerary, moving from park to park and borough to borough with plays that mirrored the lives of its Spanish-speaking audiences. Between each summer's performances, Miriam Colon Edgar, founder of the group, stored the scenery in her apartment.

title: JOHN C. DEMOS
description: Judge John C. Demos of State Superior Court, a lawyer for more than 40 years, died of cancer Wednesday at Middlesex General-University Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Monroe.

title: WHITE HOUSE MAY BALK SOME MEESE WITNESSES
description: Senate Democrats and Republicans today discussed a tentative proposal for resuming hearings Tuesday on the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's counselor, to be Attorney General.

title: McGovern Won't Back Anyone for Nomination
description: George McGovern, his own campaign over, said today he would not endorse anyone for President but would try instead to persuade Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart of Colorado not to ''turn each other into hamburger.''

title: PENTAGON WARNED NOT TO BYPASS ARMS GUARANTEES
description: Pentagon officials were warned today that legislators might try to ''stop payment'' on some military appropriations if the Defense Department did not enforce a new law guaranteeing the quality and performance of weapons.

description: * Candy's of Pueblo, Colo., a Mexican food manufacturer, to Marsteller, and Burson-Marsteller, Denver.

title: Racing Comeback
description: Emerson Fittipaldi , the two-time world champion who retired from Formula One racing two years ago, said he would drive on the Indy-car circuit this year. Fittipaldi, a 37-year- old Brazilian, retired after several of his friends, including the Canadian star Gilles Villeneuve , had been killed or badly injured in Formula One's ground-effects cars. Now, however, the ground effects in Formula One racing have been virtually eliminated, and the Indy cars have been modified so that the drivers have regained much of the control that they had lost.

title: Long Shot
description: Arnold Campbell, a 5-foot-10-inch, 245-pound high school senior from Bossier City, La., is causing problems for Tracy Sundlun, the president of the Metropolitan Athletics Congress and the meet director on Sunday for the Pathmark National Scholastic Classic indoor track and field meet at Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Larouche's Quest Is Falling Short
description: Pierre Larouche will not be in the Ranger lineup for tomorrow afternoon's game in Philadelphia. Larouche, the club's leading scorer with 44 goals, will be missing his third straight game because of a sprained right wrist.

title: STOCKER & YALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Plant Canceled By Maine Utility
description: The Central Maine Power Company canceled plans to build a large coal-fired plant on Sears Island in Searsport, Me.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT ROSE IN JANUARY
description: Consumers took on $4.34 billion more in installment debt than they paid off during January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The January increase was less than the record $6.61 billion rise the month before, but analysts said the decline was expected because the December borrowing rate was unsustainably high.

title: I.B.M. TO TRIPLE PC OUTPUT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that shipments of its Personal Computer line this year would be triple the number produced in 1983. The company also said it planned to spend $500 million in 1984 to expand its production capacity and conduct further research and development on small computers.

title: STAGE: A PROFESSOR DEBATES A SCULPTOR
description: -character plays look so effortless that we tend to forget how much craft goes into them. In '' 'night, Mother'' and ''Mass Appeal,'' to pick recent examples, the conversations and confrontations seem to flow spontaneously; there's little time even to notice that a writer is at work. To see a two-character play that fails, however, is to appreciate just how difficult the form really is. An inexperienced writer must quickly fall back on contrivances, gimmicks and formulas to keep two people talking - and, pretty soon, the characters are ground to dust in the gears of the playwright's laborious machinery.

title: At Last, a Foster Care Reform
description: For Shirley Wilder, a black 12-year-old runaway, New York City's foster care system turned adolescence into a long nightmare. The voluntary agencies that contract with the city to provide foster care rejected her. That caused her to be placed in a state school that takes delinquents, then a state foster home and, finally, an upstate Roman Catholic institution. Along the way she bore a child. When subsequently denied birth control assistance at the Catholic agency, she ran away.

title: BUDGET NEWS SPURS A RALLY
description: News that the Reagan Administration and Republican leaders had agreed on a three-year, $150 billion deficit-reduction program set off a late rally yesterday in the credit markets.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Tornadoes Kill FourIn Northern ArkansasHEBER SPRINGS, Ark., March 13 (AP) - Tornadoes cut a swath across north-central Arkansas today, destroying a bridge, and killing four people and injuring more than two dozen others. One tornado demolished the 150-foot-long Edgemont Bridge over Greers Ferry Lake miles north of Little Rock in Cleburne County.

title: PRESIDENT AGREES TO MILITARY CUTS TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: President Reagan, attempting to break the legislative deadlock on his budget, agreed today with the Republican Congressional leadership to reduce his request for military spending authority by $57 billion in the next three years.

description: b-After writedown of receivables of $3.6 million. c-Net income after a charge of $1.5 million.

title: THEATER: 'EQUINOX,' A PARABLE
description: BEFORE becoming an exile in America, Mario Diament was the executive editor of Jacobo Timerman's newspaper, La Opinion, in Argentina. Mr. Timerman was in the audience Wednesday at INTAR for the opening of Mr. Diament's ''Equinox,'' and it was clear from the play that the two men share a political and moral common ground.

title: REAGAN'S REQUESTS FOR LATIN AID RUN INTO NEW TROUBLE IN CONGRESS
description: President Reagan's effort to hasten Congressional approval of emergency arms and economic aid for Central America ran into new and serious difficulty today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dale Hunter , the Quebec Nordique center, was suspended for three games by the National Hockey League for a slashing incident against Buffalo on March 4. . . . A panel of 300 sportswriters, broadcasters and coaches have chosen Michael Jordan of North Carolina as the recipient of the Naismith Award as the college basketball player of the year. Cheryl Miller of Southern California was selected as the top female player. . . . Don King , the promoter, said that Billy Costello would make his first defense of the World Boxing Council's superlightweight title on April 15, against Ron Shields , the top-ranked contender. The site has not been determined.

title: Iraqis Tell of Gains In Fight for Island
description: Iraqi officials said today that Iraq had gained a bridgehead on Majnoon Island and was maintaining artillery fire and air strikes against Iranian positions there.

title: ONE KILLED AND SCORES HURT
description: Amtrak's westbound Empire Builder was struck today by a loaded gravel truck that a train attendant said ''tried to beat'' the train past a crossing. The authorities said the truck driver was killed and scores of the train's passengers injured, 10 critically.

description: After Nancy Moore and Roger Engels were married, Mr. Engels wanted to return the telephone he had been renting in his old house. The couple, who live in Fredericksburg, Va., found that the nearest A.T.& T. Phone Center Store that would accept such returns was in Springfield, a suburb of Washington, D.C., more than 40 miles away.

description: b-Net loss

title: Market Place ; BULLISH VIEWS ON GREYHOUND
description: THE Greyhound Corporation, which last fall

title: ART: BRONZE GARDEN OF SCULPTURED PLANTS
description: NANCY GRAVES is a dynamo. In her current exhibition, at M. Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, through March 29, her colored bronze sculptures of plants have flourished to such a point of Postmodernist profusion that her previous sculptured plants, which once appeared inexhaustibly inventive and exuberant, may now seem, in comparison, almost like stolid oaks. Graves's new garden of delights contains almost every conceivable kind of human and artistic fruit. She seems to have gone from place to place, sniffing out every corner of the world around her and the history of art, then welding the disjunctive and sometimes debased objects into fabulous creations that are governed by her law alone.

title: Senate Seeking Inquiry Into Parole Testimony
description: A Senate committee has called for a criminal investigation into conflicting testimony provided by parole officers about the release of a prisoner who was later involved in a shoot-out with police. The prisoner - Jerry Mitchell - killed himself and an accomplice following a shoot-out with the police in Elmira in which an officer was accidently shot and killed by another officer.

title: The Crosses of Poland
description: Americans debating the constitutional line between church and state may not easily appreciate how intimately history has linked church, state and nation in Poland. But Poles who would govern that nation ought to know better than to underestimate the political power of the cross.

title: MUSIC: ALBERT'S 'INTO ECLIPSE'
description: -INTENSITY work for tenor and chamber orchestra was given its first New York performance at the Goodman House on Wednesday night by Music Today, the Hebrew Arts School's modern-music group led by Gerard Schwarz. Entitled ''Into Eclipse,'' the half-hour song cycle is by Stephen Albert, a New York-born composer who in his early 40's.

title: CONGRESS'S CRUCIAL WAR ROLE
description: Americ a has suffered a serious disappointment in Lebanon, raising questions about our decision to station marines in Beirut. It would, however, be a grave mistake to seek to use this as a reason for excluding Congress from a role in such decisions. Yet Secretary of State George P. Shultz has virtually suggested that.

title: Coast Thrift Unit Sells Eurobonds
description: The Financial Corporation of America said today that its State Savings and Loan Association unit of Stockton, Calif., had sold a $125 million Eurobond issue at par with a 12 percent coupon and a five-year maturity.

title: COMMONWEALTH OIL REFINING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a $2.9 million gain on the retirement of long-term debt. c-After a gain on termination of pension plans of $1.3 million. The company is listed on the Pacific and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: AUCTIONS
description: JAPANESE art and artifacts are up for auction over the next two weeks at both Christies and Sotheby's. The bidding at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, begins next Wednesday at 10 A.M. with the auction of the Russell C. Veit collection of more than 300 Japanese sword guards, or tsubas. Mr. Veit, a Standard Oil heir and an artist, assembled his collection more than 50 years ago, and it has not been seen since his death in 1957.

title: ANTISATELLITE BAN CALLED UNSOUND
description: A Pentagon official told the Senate today that he believed it would be ''extremely difficult, if not impossible,'' to verify that the Soviet Union was complying with any treaty to prohibit weapons capable of destroying space satellites. He predicted the White House would take a similar view later this month.

title: REVELSTOKE COMPANIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss.

title: Profits Lead to a Hula
description: On the sidewalk in front of the Merrill Lynch office in the Wall Street area yesterday morning, Sam H. Walton looked up nervously for a ray of sun. He said he was glad it wasn't snowing.

title: Reggae at Roseland
description: The British reggae band UB40 will perform tonight at Roseland, Broadway and 52d Street. The show begins at 8:15 P.M. with an opening set by Urban Blight. Tickets are $13.50, and the number for more information is 254-2800.

title: BLACK UNEMPLOYMENT
description: It is the clear view of this Administration that social welfare programs stifle creativity, stymie productivity, have a disincentive effect on black people, on people who receive, but we know that this country cannot afford to be neutral on race. We cannot say that this is a program for the economy and black people are going to benefit, but we don't have to focus on them specifically.

title: NICARAGUAN PORT THOUGHT TO BE MINED
description: Anti-Sandinista rebels have planted mines around this key port, and two have exploded and caused serious damage, according to shippers and diplomats here and in Managua.

title: DOCTOR TESTIFIES IN AQUINO CASE
description: The airport doctor testified today that, contrary to usual procedure, he received no request for help when the opposition leader, former Senator Benigno S. Aquino Jr., was shot on the airport tarmac last Aug. 21.

title: Irish Leader Cautions Americans on Terrorists
description: Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland urged Americans today to stop supporting Irish terrorists.

title: On the Rebound
description: The Denver Nuggets, led by a frontcourt of Kiki Vandeweghe, Alex English and Dan Issel that averages 74.7 points a game, are the top-scoring team in the National Basketball Association with an average of 123.2 points.

title: Bass Group Lifts Stake in Retailer
description: An investment group consisting of members of Bass Brothers Enterprises of Fort Worth; a Texas partnership, and a California partnership has increased its stake in Alexander's Inc., the New York-based retail chain, to 9.5 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A Tear for St. Patrick
description: Garret FitzGerald, Ireland's Prime Minister, deserves better. On the eve of St. Patrick's Day he came to America to offer a vision of Irish nationalism very different from the one that usually dominates the headlines. Yet before he reached the rostrum of a joint meeting of Congress, Protestant gunmen in Northern Ireland did their best to drag the argument to its primitive worst.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including a gain of $21.2 million, or $1.69 a share, from the sale of property.

title: COMMITTEE SHAPES DEFICIT REDUCTION
description: The Senate Finance Committee, after 10 days of drafting, tonight approved a $2 increase in the tax on a gallon of liquor and a rise in taxes on the real estate industry as it all but completed work on a $74 billion deficit-reduction package.

title: U.S. OFFER BIG STEEL A DEAL
description: Big steel is asking Washington for two concessions. It is calling for a halt to crippling foreign imports. And it wants exemption from antitrust prosecution on at least two proposed mergers. Both requests give Washington an opportunity to breathe new life into one of America's critical industries. Unfortunately, that chance is quickly slipping away.

title: Reynolds Seeks Canada Dry
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries

title: MUSIC SCHEDULE IS LIKELY
description: Cast your mind on other days That we in coming days may be Still the indomitable Irishry.

title: TRACING A GRAND HERITAGE
description: TOMORROW is St. Patrick's Day, and to New York it is the occasion for more than a parade, although there will be one, as there has been on this day every year since 1852. It is a time, perhaps, to remember the leading role that the Irish have played in building New York, often in governing it and frequently in uplifting and entertaining it.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: Cognoscenti and would-be cognoscenti have been flocking to Jams on the Upper East Side for the last six weeks, eager to be among the first to sample the California cuisine they have heard so much about.

title: SANDWELL & CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a special gain of $842,000. c-After a special charge of $511,000.

title: YOUNG JAZZ FESTIVAL STAR IN NEW YORK CLUB DEBUT
description: ONE of the happiest surprises at last year's Kool Jazz Festival was the Carnegie Recital Hall debut of the young pianist Michel Petrucciani. Mr. Petrucciani, who had already entranced audiences and critics in Europe and on the West Coast, is a bravura technician, who has been compared to Art Tatum, Bill Evans and Keith Jarrett, among others. But his style is really his own. In concert, he plays mostly his own songs, mixed with an occasional standard.

title: Arrow Electronics
description: Arrow Electronics said today that it had filed a registration statement covering an offering of $60 million of subordinated debentures due in 2004. It said it expected the debentures to be offered later this month by Bear, Stearns & Company and L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.

title: Yeshivan to See Parade
description: The only Irishman at Yeshiva University, Robert Rhodes, has solved his problem of how to attend the St. Patrick's Day Parade tomorrow without violating the laws of his religion.

title: Williams Suspended
description: He had his problems when he was with the Knicks, and now Sly Williams has been suspended for four days by the Atlanta Hawks because of what the Hawks describe as improper bench conduct during a game against Kansas City Wednesday night in Atlanta. The suspension will reportedly cost Williams $11,000 and force him to miss tonight's game at Philadelphia and tomorrow's home game against Boston.

title: 30 Drill-Ship Bodies Found
description: Thirty bodies from an American oil drilling ship that sank in the South China Sea are being sent to Hong Kong for identification, Chinese oil officials said today. With fewer than half the missing members of the ship Glomar Java Sea recovered, divers have given up the search for more bodies of the 81 men on board when the vessel sank during Typhoon Lex on Oct. 25.

title: SOCAL SEES DANGER IN A MERGER CURB
description: The head of the Standard Oil Company of California warned today of ''potentially fatal'' consequences for the company and its stockholders if the Government imposed a moratorium on oil industry mergers along the lines of a bill sponsored by three Senators.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE PETROLEUMS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $591,000. c-Net loss.

title: AEQUITRON MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SPECIAL JOYS OF PURIM MARKED AROUND CITY
description: While Irishmen of all nationalities are celebrating St. Patrick's Day tomorrow, Jews of all persuasions will be getting ready for festivities of their own starting at sundown and continuing Sunday. The occasion is Purim, a holiday that commemorates the rescue of the Jews in Persia many, many centuries ago.

title: A DEMOCRATIC WING ALIVE AND ACTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: China Stiffens Trade Control
description: China announced today that it was returning to tight state control over foreign trade.

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: The share earnings have been restated to reflect stock splits of 2-for-1 on March 17, 1983, and June 22, 1983.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Pair of Executives Promoted at HBO
description: Home Box Office Inc., the Time Inc. subsidiary, announced two executive changes yesterday.

title: LEGAL PROBLEMS FOUND IN LILCO PLAN
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission received a report yesterday describing extensive legal difficulties with an emergency evacuation plan prepared by the Long Island Lighting Company for its Shoreham nuclear reactor.

title: PUBLISHING: GOVERNOR WRITES CAMPAIGN BOOK
description: ABOUT a month before its Feb. 13 publication date, Mayor Koch's political autobiography, ''Mayor,'' was already widely discussed, debated and deplored in the nation's newspapers. By Feb. 19 it was a best seller, and the initial printing by Simon & Schuster of 30,000 copies has since grown to 180,000 copies after eight printings. The book is currently the No. 1 nonfiction best seller in America.

title: Somali Guerrillas Claim Some Advances
description: Somali guerrillas said today that they had killed 123 Government soldiers and wounded 231 in the last week in northwestern and central Somalia.

title: Toyo Kogyo Study Of U.S. Plant Sites
description: The Toyo Kogyo Company, which makes Mazda cars, said today that it is studying three locations in the United States where it may establish auto manufacturng operations.

title: BURNS IN 4-WAY TIE FOR GOLF LEAD AT 67
description: The day started on a few bad notes for George Burns but ended surprisingly well for him - much better than he expected.

title: Fighting Area-Code Change
description: A fringe benefit of a much regulated

title: NO RESPECTER OF APARTHEID, DROUGHT SCORCHES ALL
description: When the rains came the other day, the feeling among the white farmers was that the downpour, which cracked a sullen sky with cobalt-blue lightning and coaxed a whiff of life from dead earth, had come too late - roughly three years too late. In any event, they said, what little that fell was not enough to moisten their lands.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Name Game
description: Cleveland Pittsburgh Crosby seems finally to have found a home - in Houston. The 6-foot-5-inch, 250- pound defensive end has started the last two games for the Houston Gamblers and has been credited with six solo tackles and four sacks of the quarterback.

title: FLAWED ATTACK ON REAGAN SOCIAL POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCKFORD TAKES A HARD LOOK AT HART
description: Roger Bruyn works at the huge Chrysler plant outside Rockford, and the other day a union official handed him a leaflet at the factory gate. It said Senator Gary Hart had voted against a plan several years ago to rescue the automobile maker.

title: Barclays Plans $378 Million Sale
description: The Barclays American Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $378 million in medium- term notes. The company said the notes would be due from nine months to ten years from date of issue.

title: MAAZEL WILL NOT RENEW VIENNA OPERA CONTRACTS
description: Lorin Maazel, the American conductor, said yesterday that he would not renew his contracts as general manager and principal conductor of the Vienna State Opera, after their expiration in 1986 and 1987. His statement followed criticisms of his tenure reported in the Viennese press.

title: BALANCE ON TUESDAY
description: Super Tuesday has restored some sanity and balance to the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: ORAL ROBERTS LOSES TO MEMPHIS STATE
description: Keith Lee scored 26 points and Memphis State hit clutch free throws in the tory over Oral Roberts in a first round National Collegiate Athletic Association Midwest Regional game tonight.

title: FAULTY CONVICTION FOR MURDER: CRACKS IN THE JUSTICE SYSTEM
description: When Nathaniel Carter was arrested for murder on Sept. 19, 1981, the Queens District Attorney's office quickly went to work. The prosecutors said they had to move fast. If they did not get an indictment in four days, Mr. Carter would be freed.

title: ; LET US HAVE REGIONAL PRIMARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDALE-HART EXCHANGES GROW SHARPER
description: The campaign between Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart of Colorado grew increasingly acrimonious today as the rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination exchanged charges and personal attacks.

title: KNICKS TRIUMPH ON 61-POINT 2D HALF
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers' plan last night was to force the Knicks into a slow, methodical game. The Knicks cooperated in the first half and struggled.

title: LEGISLATIVE CHIEFS ASSAIL CUOMO FOR CRITICISM ON WINE SALES ISSUE
description: Legislative leaders criticized Governor Cuomo yesterday for his suggestion that they were responding to the influence of lobbyists for liquor stores when they raised doubts about his plan to sell New York State wines in grocery stores.

title: BOARD BLOCKS TAX BREAK FOR HOME FOR THE ELDERLY
description: Turning years of mutual mistrust into a sustained public shouting match, neighbors, clergymen and politicians from the Bronx fought bitterly yesterday at a hearing before the city's Board of Estimate on a proposed home for the aged in the Riverdale section.

title: Football Farewells
description: Mel Blount and Billy Joe DuPree, two National Football League veterans who enjoyed exceptional careers dating from the early 1970's, announced their retirements yesterday. The 35-year-old Blount, a defensive back who helped the Pittsburgh Steelers to four Super Bowl championships in a career that spanned 14 years, will spend much of his time working at the Mel Blount Youth Home for troubled youngsters, which he established on his farm in Vidalia, Ga.

title: Salazar Out of Meet
description: Alberto Salazar , the fastest marathon runner in history, has a medical problem that has forced him to withdraw from the United States team that will compete in the world cross- championships March 25 at the Meadowlands. Fred Lebow, the president of the New York Road Runners Club, which is organizing the meet, said that doctors had determined that Salazar was anemic and had ordered him to cut back on his training and refrain from participating.

title: BRIDGE: ONE SEEDED TEAM REMAINS IN THE VANDERBILT KNOCKOUT
description: The upsets continued here in the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, and the semifinals began this afternoon with only one of the top eight seeded teams still in contention.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Cannon Group , a motion picture company in Hollywood, began offering through E.F. Hutton & Co. $30 million of its 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures due March 15, 2009.

title: WHITE CASTLE MAKING MARK IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: Downtown drivers may get a shock here soon: the sight of a White Castle hamburger stand cruising along city streets on the way to a new life as a registered historic place housing an all-woman construction company.

title: People
description: * Arlene Carlson has been appointed director of corporate communications/advertising at the McGregor Corporation.

title: SCREEN: JAMES GARNER STARS IN 'TANK'
description: ''THE bottom line,'' says Billy (C. Thomas Howell), the teen-age son of Sgt. Maj. Zack Carey (James Garner), ''is that he's my father, and I love him.''

title: INGRID BERGMAN'S STORY
description: TONIGHT at 9 on Channel 13, there will be a biography of Ingrid Bergman, who died in 1982. ''Ingrid'' was made by Wombat Productions, with John Gielgud as narrator. It is a celebration of the actress and the woman. Former colleagues and friends describe her warmly. Colleen Dewhurst: ''She never stopped working.'' Jose Ferrer: ''She insisted on honesty and truth.'' Liv Ullmann: ''She never had time to waste.''

title: GYMNASTS ON MOVE TO SEEK COACHING
description: Top-level gymnasts, with their grace and flow and acrobatic ability, seemingly perform effortlessly, without a care in the world. In truth, behind the glamour lies an undercurrent of tension common to the world- class level of many sports.

title: GLEMP INSISTS ON TRANSFERRING PRIEST WHO BACKS SOLIDARITY
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Polish Primate, refused today to rescind an order transferring a pro-Solidarity priest to the countryside, but hundreds of the priest's supporters were still gathered in his former church here tonight.

title: PINIELLA WEIGHS RETIREMENT
description: Lou Piniella said today that he was on the verge of retiring after 15 major league seasons and that he intended to discuss his decision with George Steinbrenner and the other Yankee executives in the next few days.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Chemical Bank announced that Louis F. Dempsey had joined it as executive vice president in charge of the bank's International Investment Services division.

title: Watanabe Wins And Retains Title
description: Jiro Watanabe of Japan successfully defended the World Boxing Association's junior-bantamweight title for the sixth time when he stopped Celso Chavez in the 15th round tonight.

title: EDWARD A. MERKLE, EX-CHIEF OF A MAJOR INVESTMENT FUND
description: Edward A. Merkle, who began on Wall Street as a page at the New York Stock Exchange and went on to become president of one of the country's largest investment firms, died of heart disease Tuesday at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in Haworth, N.J.

title: CONCERT: BRITTEN'S 'CURLEW RIVER'
description: ONE of the thumb prints that identify Benjamin Britten's music is its penchant for astringent sonorities, achieved by putting conventional instruments into conflict in unusual registers and inventive combinations. It is as if the late British composer were stimulated by the idea of the beauty inherent in clashing sounds and wanted to mediate between them. Interestingly, Britten also was attracted to the idea of reconciling apparently conflicting dramatic styles, never more obviously than in his series of three ''church operas'' - or, as he called them, ''parables for church performance.''

title: LUBY'S CAFETERIAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
SCREEN: 'ICE PIRATES' IN SPACE
description: ''THE ICE PIRATES,'' which opens today at the Warner and other theaters, is a busy, bewildering, exceedingly jokey science-fiction film that looks like a ''Star Wars'' spinoff made in an underdeveloped galaxy.

title: No Headline
description: Alexander Insurer To Report a Loss

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Suit Against Foundation Is Dismissed in Chicago
description: A complaint by J. Roderick MacArthur charging eight of his co-directors of the multimillion-dollar MacArthur Foundation of Chicago with wasting the philanthropy's funds was dismissed Tuesday in Cook County Circuit Court.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1983 and a 100 percent stock dividend in December 1983.

title: WILLCOX & GIBBS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $833,000 and a net charge of $1,248,000 related to the discontinuance of the company's sample bulk facility in Illinois. c-Including net income from discontinued operations of $518,000 and a tax credit of $543,000.

title: Swiss Lower House Votes to Join U.N.
description: The lower house of the Swiss Parliament voted today in favor of making Switzerland a member of the United Nations. The decision, on a 112-78 vote after an 11 1/2- hour debate, must be approved by the Parliament's upper house before there can be a national referendum.

title: NEWS SUMMARY FRIDAY, MARCH 16, 1984 International
description: Washington disputed Jordan by saying that ''there is no possibility of progress toward peace'' in the Middle East unless Jordan and other Arab countries agree to negotiate with Israel. (Page A1, Column 1.) The Lebanese parley was disrupted by a shouting match among the delegates over the issue of relations with Israel. The dispute demonstrated the lack of consensus among the eight factional leaders meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland, over the basic identity of Lebanon. (A6:1.) National

title: Former Governor Enters Kentucky Senate Race
description: John Y. Brown Jr., a former Governor of Kentucky, announced today he would run for election to the Senate.

title: TV: COVERAGE OF HART
description: TELEVISION turned on Gary Hart Tuesday night, implying there was less to his candidacy than met the eye.

title: U.S. SAYS POSITION OF HUSSEIN HURTS CHANCE FOR PEACE
description: The Reagan Administration said today that there is no possibility of progress toward peace in the Middle East unless Jordan and other Arab countries agree to negotiate with Israel.

title: L.I. Diner Owner Kills Intruder
description: The owner of a diner who spent the night in his restaurant to ward off burglars shot and killed an intruder early today and went home leaving the body where it fell and without reporting the death, the police said.

title: SHOT BY TEMPLE AT BUZZER TOPS REDMEN IN N.C.A.A.
description: As often as this had happened in the past, what enabled St. John's to persevere was the belief that it was not possible to lose every close game it played. So as Chris Mullin caught his breath at the free-throw line and made note of the circumstances in the hectic final seconds of tonight's game, he was pleased to have the opportunity to reverse a pattern of frustration that had tormented the Redmen all season.

title: Harvester's Hopes
description: The International Harvester Company's hopes for a return to profitablity in 1984 hinge largely on an anticipated increase in farm equipment sales, the company's chairman, Donald Lennox, said at the company's annual meeting. He said the company hoped for ''a meaningful improvement'' - and even that was a departure from his prepared text, which said the company expected ''financial results that will please you.''

title: VIRGINIA SURVIVES WITHOUT SAMPSON
description: If Virginia has accomplished anything this season, it is the reassurance that its winning tradition under Coach Terry Holland has not been compromised.

title: SENATE VOTE ON SCHOOL PRAYER
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate rejected, 81 to 15, a proposed constitutional amendment to authorize periods for silent prayer in public schools. The measure had been offered as an alternative to President Reagan's proposal to authorize spoken prayer in schools, which is expected to be voted on early next week.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Vegetarian Greene St. And a Really Hot Sauce
description: IT can be lean pickings in New

title: BEST OF IVES, WALL TO WALL
description: CHARLES IVES, America's quintessential composer, and the series of exuberant, free ''wall to wall'' marathon concerts at Symphony Space might seem to have been meant for each other. It's actually taken the venturesome Upper West Side performance space six years to get around to Ives, and the 12-hour Ives festival that will take place there tomorrow is the 13th in a series dating back to 1978. But it promises to be as festive as any marathon Symphony Space has offered - as festive, in fact, as the music of Ives itself.

title: JURY FINDS CLERK IN CHICAGO GUILTY
description: R. SHIPP

title: BRITISH THIEVES GET $7 MILLION
description: Thieves broke into Woburn Abbey, one of England's finest country mansions, on Wednesday night and carried away silver antiques valued at about $7 million, the police said today. It was the biggest haul in a recent series of thefts from stately manor houses whose owners have been forced by the pressure of taxes and maintenance costs to open them to the public.

title: A MAN FIGHTS 'LADIES' NIGHTS'
description: Richard Savino is upset when his friends ask him why he hates women. ''They don't understand,'' he says. ''I consider myself a radical feminist. Women are equal and they don't need to be pampered.''

title: New Products Boom
description: After a traditionally sluggish January, new product introductions in the area of grocery and health and beauty aids-packaged goods boomed in February to 150, from 139 in February 1983 and 103 in January of this year, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News. The scores for two-month totals stand at 253 this year and 238 for the same period last year.

title: KASPAROV WINS GAME IN MATCH WITH SMYSLOV
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union defeated his countryman Vasily Smyslov on Wednesday in the third game of their final candidates chess match in Vilnius, in the Soviet Republic of Lithuania. The 20-year-old whiz took a 2-1 lead over the 62-year-old former world champion.

title: THE RIGHTS OF AN INFANT SURVIVING ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: O.& M. Ad Efforts
description: From various facets of Ogilvy & Mather are emerging three totally different advertising efforts.

title: SHOUTING DISRUPTS LEBANESE PARLEY
description: The Lebanese reconciliation conference was disrupted today by a shouting match over the question of relations with Israel.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $15,000. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $120,000 for the quarter and $211,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $505,000 and $851,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $176,000. The year-ago 6 months income from continuing operations includes a gain from real estate transaction of $662,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: POLICEMAN IN MIAMI IS AQUITTED BY JURY IN SLAYING OF BLACK
description: A Miami police officer whose fatal shooting of a young black man sparked three days of violence in the Overtown neighborhood here in December 1982 was acquitted tonight of manslaughter charges stemming from the incident.

title: NOMA INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are per Class A common share.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31

title: Aquinas Gains In N.A.I.A. Play
description: Joe Esposito scored 16 points in the second half as fifth-seeded St. Thomas Aquinas pulled away today from Phillips University of Oklahoma, 75-65, in the first round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament.

title: THE EDITORIAL NOTEBOOK Remembrance of a Girl Scout Past
description: What a madeleine dipped in tea did for Marcel Proust, reading about the 50th anniversary of Girl Scout cookies did for me recently. It took no Thin Mint and milk to resurrect a time when I was personally responsible for at least 50 of the more than two billion boxes sold since 1934.

title: BOEING AND JAPANESE STUDY BUILDING A PLANE
description: The Boeing Company, the country's major builder of commercial aircraft, said today that it had joined with three large Japanese companies and a trade group to explore the prospects of designing and building an ''advanced technology'' airplane.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about paintings by Lyonel Feininger misstated the title of Ralph F. Colin and the occupation of his son Ralph F. Colin Jr. The senior Mr. Colin is counsel to the law firm of Rosenman Colin Freund Lewis & Cohen, where he is a retired senior partner. His son is a vice president of a Columbia Records division.

title: ST. PATRICK PARADE PUTS SCHOOLS IN BOYCOTT LAST
description: Schools that boycotted the St. Patrick's Day Parade last year to protest the selection of an Irish Republican Army fund-raiser as grand marshal will be required to march at the back of the parade this year.

title: CANOES ARE READY
description: Although the recent bitterly cold

title: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After tax benefits of $668,000 for the latest quarter and $581,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: LAWSUIT SAYS CITY'S SHELTERS ILLEGALLY EJECT THE HOMELESS
description: A lawsuit was filed against New York City and State yesterday, charging that homeless individuals are being illegally ejected from city-operated shelters and forced to sleep in the streets or seek assistance at other ''inferior and forbidding'' shelters.

title: GREATE BAY CASINO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $254,000 for the quarter and $7,479,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $1,276,000 for the quarter and $6,561,000 for the year.

AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
WRIGHT ON PRESIDENT: 'THAT IS A LIE'
description: Representative Jim Wright livened up the opening minutes of a House session this week by accusing President Reagan of having lied about lack of Democratic cooperation in seeking budget reductions.

title: Columnist Has a Plan To Confuse the Pollsters
description: Mike Royko, the columnist for The Chicago Tribune, suggested to his readers today that they try to add some spice to primary election night next Tuesday by lying to polltakers about how they voted.

title: TORTUOUS TARRYTOWN DISPUTE NEARS END
description: -FIVE years after Clement Merowit finished a network of winding development called Woodland Lakes, a suit has been resolved over who should pay for them. But both his lawyers and counsel for the village are still quarreling over how much the municipality must pay.

title: HART VICTORIES TURN TIDE OF FINANCES
description: As Senator Gary Hart's chances for the Democratic Presidential nomination have risen from slim to promising in only two weeks, his campaign's financial position has been similarly transformed.

title: ALVARADO TELLS REGENTS OF PERIL IN STIFFER RULES
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor said today that a shortage of foreign-language teachers could imperil a state plan to toughen graduation standards for high school students.

title: TO PUNISH THE PERPETRATORS OF 'TOXIC TERRORISM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Indoor Crafts Fair
description: Crafts of every kind will be found at an indoor fair Sunday at Yonkers Raceway, off the Major Deegan Expressway.

title: BEIRUT MILITIAS HOPE FOR QUICK PEACE
description: This afternoon a round of automatic rifle bursts broke the extraordinary quiet that a cease-fire had bequeathed to this devastated southern suburb of Beirut, situated on the battle line between Christian and Moslem forces.

title: TOMLINSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After a loss of $294,848 from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $575,815 from discontinued operations.

title: Money Fund Assets Increase
description: Total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased to their highest level since early May in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today; March 16, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FEDERAL-LOCAL MANHUNT ENSNARES OVER 2,000 FUGITIVES ON THE COAST
description: Law- enforcement officials said today that a manhunt by Federal and local officials had brought in more than 2,000 fugitives in California in the last 10 weeks.

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
DANCE: TAKATO ASAKAWA IN 'CLYTEMNESTRA'
description: THE first sight the State Theater audience had of Takako Asakawa Wednesday night in the title role of Martha Graham's ''Clytemnestra'' was of a smoldering rage-filled figure. In that instant, Miss Asakawa promised a highly charged portrayal. In the end, she delivered a performance filled with great dancing and nuanced acting.

title: Suspect Charged In 5 Knife Attacks
description: A Manhattan man has been charged with five knifepoint attacks on women in upper Manhattan in the past month, the police said yesterday.

title: IT'S MAPLE-SYRUP TIME
description: With the approach of spring, it's maple-syrup time once more north of New York City, offering an opportunity for residents of the metropolitan area to watch a maple-syruping operation and to taste the product.

title: No Headline
description: Defense Ends for One Of Six in Rape Case

title: 5 SENATORS OPPOSE SCHOOL PRAYER MEASURE
description: Five of the Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut oppose President Reagan's proposed constitutional amendment to allow authorized periods of vocal prayer in the public schools.

description: b-Including tax credits of $36,000 for the quarter and $783,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $405,000 for the quarter and $1,247,000 for the year, a loss of $120,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and income of $270,000 from discontinued operations for the year.

TENNEY ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in June 1983.

title: ANOTHER TEEN-AGER IS BELIEVED A SUICIDE IN WESTCHESTER AREA
description: The 19-year-old son of the Bedford, N.Y., Town Clerk was found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning Wednesday, apparently the latest in a series of at least five teen-age suicides in Westchester and Putnam Counties since early February.

title: STRONGER MARKET REVIVES A COOPER SQUARE PROJECT
description: The redevelopment clock has ticked erratically at a midblock site on lower Third Avenue in the Cooper Square area. Ten years ago a developer demolished the existing building there and started to go ahead with new construction.

title: B.Y.U. Advances; W. Virginia Wins BIRMINGHAM, Ala., March 15 (UPI) - Devin Durrant, the nation's No. 3 major college scorer, had 23 points tonight to lead Brigham Young to an 84-68 victory over Alabama-Birmingham in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Mideast Regional.
description: Earlier in the evening, J. J. Crawl, a West Virginia sophomore, stole an errant pass and scored on a last-second layup to give the Mountaineers a 64-62 victory over Oregon State.

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Connecticut Seeks BorderSalesTaxes
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that the state was pressing its crackdown on residents who made large purchases out of state to avoid paying the 7.5 percent Connecticut sales tax.

title: Continental May Sell Its Card Unit
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation said it is considering the sale of its Town and Country credit card business. The bank holding company said that talks on such a sale have been under way for several months and that Goldman, Sachs & Company had been retained as an adviser

title: ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL AND B.P. NET UP
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies and the British Petroleum Company today reported higher earnings for 1983.

description: IT is one thing to picture Jason Robards in his

title: Reagan Criticizes FoesIn a White House Talk
description: President Reagan, courting Hispanic voters with visions of economic opportunity, has accused the Democrats of promoting policies that failed to prevent economic stagnation and a wave of crime and drug abuse.

title: LTV, Republic In U.S. Talks
description: Further signs of progress were seen today as representatives of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation met twice with the Justice Department in an effort to reach a merger plan acceptable to the Government.

title:
PATENTS;
Controlling Door Locks From a Central Office
description: A system for controlling locks at a number of distant locations was patented this week. Patent 4,436,958 was issued in the name of the Western Electric Company, which is now entitled A.T.& T. Technologies Inc., and has offices in New York.

title: P.S.E.&G. Gets A Rate Increase
description: The New Jersey Board of Public Utilities today awarded a $295 million rate increase to the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in a decision expected to raise the average monthly electric bill by about 8 percent.

title: GAMBLE BIDES TIME
description: Oscar Gamble caught himself just in time, laughing as he asked, ''Who's pitching for us tonight?'' during a telephone conversation from his Alabama home.

title: FOR WOMEN OF INDIA, A RITE OF SPRING IS SOUR
description: The sunny green campus of Delhi University looked much like an occupied zone under curfew today. Soldiers piled out of trucks and stationed themselves in fives and sixes around the grounds, riot sticks at the ready. Few students were about. Some student hostels looked deserted.

title: A THREAT REBORN
description: To the Editor:

title: Kidnap Victim's FatherIs Said to Shoot Suspect
description: A man being returned to stand trial on charges of kidnapping a 12- year-old boy was shot in the head by the youth's father at the airport here tonight, the police said.

title: THE CITY ;  Strike at El Al
description: Employees of El Al Israel Airlines in New York went on strike yesterday morning in a dispute over a new contract and concessions sought by the airline.

title: WESTCHESTER THEATER CASE
description: Fifteen months ago, a Federal prosecutor said in open court that ''the real culprit'' in a stock fraud and kickback scheme was Steven J. Ross, chairman of Warner Communications. To date, however - after two company executives have pleaded guilty and a third has been convicted after a trial - no charges have been filed against Mr. Ross.

title: 11.2% JUMP IN STARTS OF HOUSING
description: Construction of new homes and apartments surged 11.2 percent in February, to an annual rate of 2.2 million units, the highest level in nearly six years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. PHOTOGRAPHER IS SHOT DEAD COVERING A BATTLE IN EL SALVADOR
description: An American photographer for Newsweek magazine was shot and killed today when he was caught in crossfire between Government and guerrilla troops about 16 miles north of here.

title: Swedish Inflation Off
description: A ''gasoline price war'' offset higher food prices, pushing average consumer prices in Sweden down four- tenths of 1 percent in February from January, Statistics Sweden said today. The decrease left prices 7.9 percent higher than the level of February 1983, the Government agency said.

title: Gergen in Running For PBS President
description: David R. Gergen, the former director of communications for President Reagan, is the latest candidate for the presidency of the Public Broadcasting Service, public television officials said yesterday.

title: UNLICENSED RESTAURANTS WARNED ON DRINKS
description: Owners of 10 New York City restaurants that do not have liquor licenses but allow customers to bring in their own wine, beer or other alcoholic beverages have been told by the state to cease the practice or face possible fines or imprisonment.

title: TIGHT RACE GIVES WEIGHT TO CONNECTICUT PRIMARY
description: Connecticut, which was cast several weeks ago only as a bit player in the road show for the Democratic Presidential nomination, is poised now for a more prominent role.

title: U.S. ENVOY SEIZED IN WEST BEIRUT, 3RD AMERICAN TO VANISH IN 6 WEEKS
description: An American diplomat was kidnapped at gunpoint here today by a carload of unidentified gunmen outside his apartment building as he was leaving for work.

title: Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it expects its 1984 capital spending to total between $800 million and $850 million, up from $630 million in 1983. Last year's spending was down from $829 million in 1982 and $1.18 billion in 1981, which followed five other years of spending of more than $1 billion. A spokesman said that spending in 1983 was lower than in previous years because heavy spending in earlier years had eliminated the need for new capacity.

title: KANSAS, ILLINOIS ST. EACH GAIN BY POINT
description: Outplayed and outsmarted, trailing by 14 points in the first half, by 10 with just over 10 minutes to play and by 9 with more than eight minutes to go, Kansas came from behind to defeat Alcorn State, 57-56, tonight in a first- round game of the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional.

title: PAINTER'S SPEEDING SENTENCE: ART LECTURES FOR PUBLIC
description: The artist Frank Stella, who was facing a sentence of 30 days in jail for speeding in this upstate community, will instead spend two weekends in April or May lecturing to local residents about his painting.

description: The Lotus Development Corporation said it had settled a suit it filed two months ago against Rixon Inc., a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., in which it charged Rixon with making illegal copies of the popular Lotus 1-2-3 program for its branch offices.

description: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF COTTON

description: There were no share earnings for the latest quarter because preferred stock dividends exceeded net income.

title: New Generals Punter
description: Tim Cutts, a barefoot rookie kicker from Mississippi State, won the job as the Generals' punter in February when he beat out Bob Grupp at training camp. Since the season began, however, Cutts has not been able to get his foot into the ball, even with his shoe off.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

description: A Criminal Court judge in Manhattan under investigation for ordering a prostitute to join him on the bench will probably be transferred to Civil Court soon, court officials said yesterday.

title: NORMAN LEADS BY 3 STROKES
description: Greg Norman, the 29-year-old Australian who lives in Florida but has spent most of the last eight years on golf courses all over the world, said he has had his fill of continuous globe-trotting.

title: DANCE: JUILLIARD ENSEMBLE'S ANNUAL SPRING PROGRAM
description: The annual spring concert by the Juilliard Dance Ensemble is always an event in the dance world. So many of the Juilliard School's dance-division alumni can be found in today's top modern-dance companies that such concerts consistently offer a preview of tomorrow's talent.

title: PACT ON DEFICIT: NEAR AND YET SO FAR
description: The $150 billion deficit-reducing package worked out between Senate Republicans and President Reagan seems to be, in principle, relatively easy for Congress to adopt. And it would, both Democrats and Republicans acknowledge, make a small start in reducing future budget deficits. A good half of the package has already been approved by various committees in the Republican-controlled Senate and the Democratic-led House. Tax increases, once thought to be the most nettlesome issue because this is an election year and because of Mr. Reagan's distaste for them, now appear to be one of the best bets.

description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that New York City had rejected a revision of its rent-stabilization code that tenant groups said would have substantially weakened their rights.

description: On the terraced hills of the Apennines outside this city, there is still snow. But in the city it is already spring.

description: Rising prices for fresh produce and some cuts of beef pushed Canada's annual inflation rate to 5.5 percent last month, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.

title: PLANE BOMBS THE SUDAN, WHICH ACCUSES LIBYANS
description: An unidentified warplane flew over the Sudanese city of Omdurman today and dropped five bombs, and President Gaafar al- Nimeiry accused Libya of having ordered the action. The Sudanese radio said five people were killed and two wounded.

description: President Reagan telephoned Bishop John J. O'Connor of Scranton, Pa., yesterday to wish him well in his new assignment as Archbishop of New York and praised him for speaking out against abortion, according to a spokesman for the New York Archdiocese.

description: Edwin Meese 3d said today that critics of his nomination to be Attorney General were making ''false and misleading statements.'' He added, ''I have engaged in no improper conduct.''

description: James W. Hutchins, convicted of killing three policemen, died quietly by lethal injection today.

description: Alda Melo, a stitcher in a textile factory, says she remembers many houses and tenements in sections of this former whaling port were ''old and gray'' when she first came to this country from the Azores when she was 10 years old.

NATIONAL PARK SERVICE RESISTS SHIFT IN RANGE MANAGEMENT
description: The National Park Service is protesting new Interior Department rules that would enable private ranchers to assume responsibility for managing grazing lands within National Parks, department officials said today.

title: FOES OF SANDINISTAS CALL VOTING LAW UNFAIR
description: The Sandinista-dominated Council of State gave final approval Thursday night to a law that will govern elections set for Nov. 4. But opposition leaders said today that the law would not give them an equal chance to compete.

description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April 1983 and a 10 percent stock dividend to be paid in April 1984.

description: NORTHLAND

title: FAILURES OF FRIENDSHIP
description: After Ed Meese came to Washington to sit at the right hand of the President, he fell on hard times. I'd warned him it would happen.

title: St. John's Bows
description: Tresa Brown sank two free throws with seven seconds remaining in overtime tonight, giving North Carolina an 81-79 victory over St. John's in the first round of the N.C.A.A. East Regional women's tournament. With only seconds left in regulation and St. John's down by 71-69, Anne Marie McNamee hit both ends of a one-and-one situation to force the overtime. St. John's was ahead, 79-77, with 47 seconds left in overtime when North Carolina's Eileen McCann hit an 18-foot jumper, setting the stage for Miss Brown.

title: CTG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: POLISH LEADER ASSURES AND WARNS THE CHURCH
description: The Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, said today that the Communist authorities wanted ''good relations with the Roman Catholic Church,'' but he warned against political activity under church banners.

title: FULL PARTNERS IN NEW PLANE
description: Now it is aerospace.

title: Setback for Perez
description: Pascual Perez, the Atlanta Brave pitcher who is facing a drug-trafficking charge in his native Dominican Republic, has lost a bid to have his trial shifted from his home city, Santiago. The Dominican Supreme Court rejected his request for a change of venue, clearing the way for setting a trial date in Santiago, where, Perez fears, local officials will be under pressure to make an example of him.

title: U.S. DROPS PACT WITH SOVIET ON ENVOYS
description: The United States formally notified the Soviet Union today that it was suspending a 1982 agreement under which the ambassadors of the two countries were permitted to travel to and from the respective capitals aboard special flights.

title: ON THE RIVIERA: HIGH BEAUTY AND MORE LOW MARKS
description: For a gorgeous city, Nice seems to make people speak badly of it. For a place whose bay shines with a dozen gradations of blue, for a town where the early morning smells are still of flowers and the sea, the line on Nice can be hard. Nietzsche, who lived here a century ago, spake cruelly of the city, the locals recall, describing the citizenry as rapacious. The Scottish novelist Tobias Smolett, they remember, gave Nice low marks as well. Graham Greene, who has a house nearby, brought things up to date a few years ago, writing an accusatory pamphlet in which City Hall, the police and the Nice establishment came off as crooks and thugs.

title: TWO WHO RAIDED COMPUTERS PLEADING GUILTY
description: Two young men who broke into large computers in the United States and Canada last June, simply to prove they could do it, have pleaded guilty to two misdemeanor charges, according to documents filed today in Federal District Court.

title: IONA FALLS, 58-57, ON MISS AT LINE
description: ROY S. JOHNSON

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Dec. 22, 1983.

title: 5.1% Inflation In Britain
description: Britain's annual rate of inflation remained at 5.1 percent in February, for the second consecutive month, the Government said today. ''Today's figures show that we are very much on course,'' the Employment Secretary, Tom King, said, adding that the Government's forecast of 4.5 percent inflation by the end of the year ''is already in sight.'' The report, issued by the Department of Employment, said the Government's retail price index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in February, for a cumulative annual rate of 5.1 percent. Price increases for food, alcohol, clothing, footwear and durable household goods were largely balanced by decreases for gasoline and used cars.

title: HART AND MONDALE, ON STUMPIN ILLINOIS, ASSAIL EACH OTHER AS PRIMARY NEARS
description: Senator Gary Hart, in a foreign policy speech that sought to draw the contrasts between himself and Walter F. Mondale, today urged ''restraint'' in United States relations abroad ''rather than intervention, military action and covert operations.''

title: PRODUCER PRICES RISE BY 0.4%
description: The Producer Price Index climbed a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in February, despite the upward pressure of a sizable increase in food costs and the biggest jump in more than four years in prices for home heating oil, the Labor Department reported today.

title: AMAREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax writedown of $7 million on the value of gas and oil properties. Year-ago quarter and 9 months losses are restated because the company is no longer accounting for accrued interest on debt.

title: MORE HOMELESS TO GO TO ARMORY ON PARK AVENUE
description: Several hundred additional homeless men will be given shelter in the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue, according to city and state officials. The armory now takes in about 150 men a night.

title: 2 Dead in Canal
description: The bodies of two Rider College students were found today in a car submerged in the swollen Delaware and Raritan Canal three days after they apparently made a wrong turn off a dirt road during a rainstorm while leaving a restaurant, officials said.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
CUOMO SAYS FINANCES FORCED HIM TO CUT JOBS
description: Governor Cuomo told the Legislature today that financial considerations had forced him to cut jobs last year at public universities and state institutions for the mentally ill.

title: AROUND THE WORLD Iraq Reports CapturingPart of Oil-Rich Island
description: Convoys of Iraqi reinforcements poured into Basra today amid Iraqi reports that its forces had seized the northern end of the oil-rich Majnoon island and were pressing south.

title: COBB SAID TO HAVE GOT $2,000
description: Rick Kuhn, the former Boston College basketball player serving a 10- year prison sentence for conspiring to rig scores in the 1978-79 season, testified yesterday that a star teammate, Ernie Cobb, had also been in the scheme and had received $2,000 in bribes from gamblers.

title: Jackson Derides PoliciesOf Glenn's Campaign
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, making a drive through this state on the eve of precinct caucuses Saturday, said today that the Presidential bid of Senator John Glenn of Ohio had suffered from ''miscalculations'' that the Democratic Party was ready to move toward President Reagan.

title: Panel to Handle Fare Cheats Gains
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it was preparing legislation to establish an administrative panel to prosecute subway fare evaders and others who violate transit regulations.

title: F.D.A. WANTS MORE INFORMATION ON PLANS FOR 2ND ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: Doctors at the University of Utah, hoping to receive approval to implant an artificial heart a second time, were dealt a setback today when the Food and Drug Administration formally requested additional information.

title: AFTER MANY YEARS OF IRRELEVANCE, THE NEW YORK PRIMARY COUNTS
description: For Walter F. Mondale's campaign leader in New York, the state primary is ''absolutely essential.''

title: Wilson Foods Plan Accepted
description: Creditors of the Wilson Foods Corporation, the nation's largest fresh pork processor, accepted the company's proposed plan of reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, the company said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'd like nothing better than to stay in this race and compete in every primary, every caucus, and win the nomination of my party, but in the past few weeks it became clear that none of these things is going to happen.'' - John Glenn. (8:1.)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, MARCH 17, 1984

title: TRIZEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-1 stock split in January.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by Reuters in the Finance/New Issues column of Business Day yesterday, about a Eurobond offering, misidentified the unit of the Financial Corporation of America that made the sale. It is the American Savings and Loan Association.

title: OLYMPIC ARTS EVENT IN PERIL
description: Robert Wilson, the avant-garde playwright, director and designer, said he might be forced to cancel his planned eight-hour, multinational contribution to the Los Angeles Olympic Arts Festival unless he can raise the $1.2 million remaining of the work's projected $2.6 million cost by April 1.

title: Lyubimov Is Reported Out of Party in Moscow
description: The Soviet director Yuri Lyubimov was expelled today from the Communist Party for failure to pay his membership fee, a Radio Denmark correspondent reported from Moscow.

title: Pizza Time Sees 4th-Quarter Loss SUNNYVALE, Calif. March 16 (Reuters) - Pizza Time Theater Inc. said it expects to report a fourth- quarter loss from operations of at least $16 million, compared with profits of $2.5 million, or 42 cents a share, a year before. The fourth quarter will also reflect a write-off of about $35 million from the closing of uneconomical restaurant-entertainment operations and certain other year-end adjustments, the company said.
description: Pizza Time's president, Randall Pike, also said the company is seeking to defer payment of certain obligations and has written to some creditors saying it is ''in extremely serious financial difficulties.'' If significant relief is not granted, Pizza Time said it could file for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. In over-the-counter trading today, Pizza Time was the second-biggest percentage loser, dropping 87.5 cents, to $4.50 bid.

title: Fotomat-Heizer
description: The Fotomat Corporation said it had granted the Heizer Corporation, a business-development concern that now owns 20 percent of its common stock, the right to buy another 2.5 million shares for $5 million. Fotomat, a photo processor, now has about 10 million shares outstanding. Fotomat also said it expects to enter into an amended loan agreement with its bank lenders that would increase the size of its existing revolving credit to $18 million, from $12.5 million, and extend the agreement through September.

Fisher Foods
description: Fisher Foods Inc. said Carl H. Lindner, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Financial Corporation, would be nominated as chairman of Fisher, an operator of supermarkets. Fisher said Mr. Lindner was one of four officers designated by American Financial for election to Fisher's seven-man board of directors at its annual meeting on May 15. Last week, Fisher said a proposed stock purchase by American Financial would raise its stake in Fisher to 35 percent, from 18 percent.

title: MET OPERA: CAST CHANGES IN VERDI'S 'FORZA'
description: Cast changes at the Metropolitan Opera often carry with them a certain dilution of quality. Not so Thursday night for ''La Forza del Destino.''

title: Loews Reports St. Regis Stake
description: The Loews Corporation said it holds the equivalent of 8.5 percent of the common shares outstanding of the St. Regis Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Loews said it holds the shares ''solely for investment'' and has no intention of seeking control of St. Regis.

title: YONKERS PASSES 9-3/4% SALES TAX IN BUDGET PLAN
description: The City Council today adopted a package of proposals, including an increase of the present 8 1/4 percent sales tax to 9 3/4 percent, that it hopes will eliminate multimillion-dollar deficits this year and next.

title: HELEN M. HARRIS, 87, A LONGTIME WORKER IN WELFARE PROGRAMS
description: Helen M. Harris, a social worker who administered Federal and local welfare programs in the city for more than 40 years, died yesterday at the Cabrini Medical Center. She was 87 years old and lived most of her life in New York City.

description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact today resumed the negotiations on troop reductions in Central Europe that were suspended last December as part of a Soviet protest over the deployment of American medium-range missiles.

title: McKesson Offer
description: The McKesson Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to invest up to $20 million in convertible subordinated debentures to be issued by the Environmental Systems Company.

title: SPECIAL GOALIES OF BOTH SEXES
description: Tom Barrasso is something special. The 18-year-old goalie from Stow, Mass., who had a 0.73 goals- against average in his senior year at Acton-Boxboro High School, was selected fifth over all in the National Hockey League entry draft last spring by the Buffalo Sabres.

title: G.O.P. LEADERSHIP VOWED NOT TO CUT MILITARY FURTHER
description: Congressional officials said today that President Reagan agreed to reduce his military budget request only after Senate Republican leaders committed themselves to making no further cuts.

title: KETTERING INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include the operations of American Display Corp. which was acquired on April 30, 1983.

title: Moulton Dance Troupe To Hold Gala Benefit
description: The Charles Moulton Dance Company will hold its fifth anniversary gala benefit Monday at 7 P.M. in the Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street.

title: SATURDAY, MARCH 17, 1984 International
description: Mozambique and South Africa signed a nonaggression treaty, promising to withhold support for each other's internal foes. It was the first such pact between South Africa and a black- ruled African country. Both countries are bitter ideological adversaries. The pact was a major diplomatic victory for South Africa in its campaign against the African National Congress, the most prominent of the exiled groups fighting South Africa's apartheid policies from bases in Mozambique. (Page 1, Column 1.) Another American was kidnapped in Beirut. William F. Buckley, first secretary in the political section of the United States Embassy, was forced out of his car at gunpoint as he was leaving for work and was driven off in another car. He was the third American to disappear from West Beirut since Moslem militiamen seized control of that part of the Lebanese capital Feb. 6. (1:1.)

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Signed Jerry Martin, outfielder, to a contract to become effective when his suspension is lifted.

title: ONE TAR FOR ALL
description: When a mob of good citizens is about to tar and feather someone and ride him out of town on a rail - as seems about to happen to Schools Chancellor Anthony Alvarado - you know it's always a good time to ask some questions about the stampede. Such as: ''Hold on a minute, pilgrim. Are you sure we're doing the right thing here?''

title: MOZAMBIQUE SIGNS ACCORD ON REBELS WITH SOUTH AFRICA
description: Mozambique and South Africa, bitter ideological adversaries, signed a nonaggression treaty today, promising to withhold support for one another's internal foes. It was the first such pact between South Africa and a black-ruled African country.

title: AMBULANCE DISPATCHER IS OUSTED
description: A nurse who argued with a man, scolded him for using foul language and delayed sending an ambulance for his dying stepmother was dismissed today, the Dallas Fire Department said.

title: BEER MAKERS OFFER LESS POTENT BREWS
description: The nation's brewers, faced with flat sales and increasing public concern about alcohol abuse, are test- marketing low-alcohol beer, their first significant innovation since light beer 10 years ago.
