description: b-After a loss of $12,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $24,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTHCARE SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: FOR ECONOMIC BENEFIT, OPERATE SHOREHAM
description: Although Governor Cuomo sounds at times as if he has already decided that the Shoreham nuclear plant should never operate, the question deserves to be considered on its own merit, and entirely apart from the question about who's to bear its costs and how they may be mitigated. A careful reading of last December's report by the Marburger Commission - Governor Cuomo's fact-finding panel on Shoreham, of which I was a member - reveals much about the comparative economic merits of operating and not operating the plant.

title:
PATENTS;
45 Licenses for Patents Owned by Government
description: Licenses for commercial use of 45 federally owned inventions were given this week by the Office of Government Inventions and Patents, Springfield, Va. Notice was published in the Patent Office Official Gazette.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Frankfort, Ky., dispatch by United Press International in the Campaign Notes column yesterday, on the entry of former Gov. John Y. Brown in Kentucky's Senate race, misstated his party affiliation. He is a Democrat.

title: SANITATION FORCE SMALLEST IN YEARS
description: The number of uniformed workers in New York City's Sanitation Department has reached what the department says may be the lowest level in 30 or 40 years.

title: POLICE OCCUPY TENSE AREAS IN MIAMI AFTER 300 ARRESTS
description: Hundreds of police officers today continued to occupy sections of some of the city's predominantly black neighborhoods, where sporadic outbursts of violence Thursday night resulted in more than 300 arrests.

title: Sect Member SentencedIn Death of Her Son
description: A member of a religous sect was sentenced today to 4 to 15 years in prison for beating her 12-year-old son to death at a camp run by the sect.

title: ONE LESS SPARTAN
description: The Spartans of St. Thomas Aquinas College arrived in Kansas City, Mo., on Tuesday with an undermanned squad of eight players for the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball tournament.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MUSIC: NEW ENSEMBLE PRISM
description: Prism, a new chamber orchestra under the musical direction of Robert Black, presented an ambitious inaugural concert at the Symphony Space Tuesday night. The program opened with a cautious performance of the Serenade No. 2 in A (Op. 16) by Johannes Brahms. Mr. Black, a fine pianist, is still a rather stiff conductor, and the ensemble playing was little more than dutiful.

title: A City of Tinsel and Ashes ''Atlantic City will finally start on its long- awaited rise from the ashes of greed and neglect and, like the mythological phoenix, this city will be renewed.''
description: So said James Usry on being sworn in as Mayor of Atlantic City after a day of court challenges from his ousted opponent, Michael Matthews. Mr. Usry's election is the city's best hope of resolving its problems without worsening crisis.

title: SIMMONS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Eating on the Move
description: A venerable Washington process called ''working the room'' was noted at a dinner here the other night by the former Mayor of Atlanta, Maynard Jackson. Mr. Jackson was master of ceremonies at a gathering of the Joint Center for Political Studies. ''You will notice that the tables are spread out,'' Mr. Jackson said, ''because at Washington dinners, the diners never remain seated.''

title: U.S. Arrests 9 In a Drug Case
description: Federal law enforcement officials said today that they had broken up a major drug ring in South Jersey by arresting nine members of the Gambino crime organization on charges of possession and conspiracy to distribute heroin and cocaine.

title:
PATENTS;
A Meter Service Card; Device to Help Golfers
description: Luther G. Simjian, president of Command Automation Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was granted a patent this week for a card-controlled metering device.

title: INDUSTRY'S USE OF CAPACITY UP TO 80.7%
description: Industry operated at 80.7 percent of capacity in February, registering the 15th consecutive monthly rise since the recession ended in late 1982, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: SPRING BASEBALL UP NORTH
description: Spring - the official date is still

title: MARTIN TO JOIN METS AFTER SUSPENSION
description: Jerry Martin signed a one-year contract with the Mets today and will join them when his suspension from baseball is lifted.

title: SPARE PARTS FOR CONGRESS
description: The issue is literally a nuts-and-

title: FORDHAM IS DEFEATED BY 75-63 IN N.I.T. By The Associated Press
description: The junior forward Randy Worster led Weber State to a 75-63 victory over Fordham (19-15) in the first round of the National Invitation tournament last night in Ogden, Utah.

title: AH, FOR THE BAGEL OF YESTERYEAR
description: An old Yiddish recipe for a bagel directs the baker to take a hole and put some dough around it. The basic concept has not changed since the recipe first appeared - the bagel is still round, more or less, and it still has a hole in the middle - but the amount and kind of dough have undergone a drastic metamorphosis.

title: ON THE RECORD ; HART'S FOREIGN POLICY
description: From a speech by Senator Gary Hart yesterday to the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations:

title: Louisiana RebuffedOn Calling Off Primary
description: The Justice Department told Louisiana today that the state could not legally cancel its April 7 Presidential preference primary.

title: A PAVAROTTI FIRST PLANNED AT GARDEN
description: Luciano Pavarotti, the Italian tenor who has made the greatest public impact of any singer since the days of Enrico Caruso, will give a concert in Madison Square Garden on the evening of Aug. 16.

title: NU-MED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $50,000.

title: F.C.C. Supports CBS Over Plea of Churches
description: CBS did not act improperly when it refused to provide air time to five major Protestant churches to respond to a ''60 Minutes'' report in 1983 on the use of missionary and relief funds, the Federal Communications Commission has ruled.

title: Bridge: Martel Off to a Large Lead As Vanderbilt Final Begins
description: Teams led by Chip Martel of Davis, Calif., and Cliff Russell of Miami clashed in the final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship here this afternoon. After 16 deals of a scheduled 64, Martel led by the overwhelming margin of 70 international match points, an opening burst that seemed likely to decide the match.

title: HOWELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Crash Injures 12
description: A bus carrying 44 passengers drove off the Garden State Parkway into woods near Toms River, N.J., last night, sending 12 people to nearby hospitals with minor injuries, according to the New Jersey state police.

title: WITH FEW WORDS, GLENN WITHDRAWS
description: For John Glenn, the end came quietly, with no brass bands, no chants from supporters, not even a request for an autograph. There were only a news conference in a Congressional hearing room and a few words that were just short of melancholy.

WOODWARD & LOTHROP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28

description: A consortium headed by a Dallas businessman, H. R. (Bum) Bright , has made a deal to purchase the Dallas Cowboys for an estimated $75 million, a Dallas television station, WFAA, reported yesterday.

Key Canadian LiberalSays He's a Candidate
description: Former Finance Minister John Turner, who left the Government of Pierre Elliott Trudeau eight years ago, officially declared his candidacy today for the leadership of the Liberal Party, taking on the role of front-runner among the announced candidates.

title: U.S. REPAYS BANKS $431 MILLION DEBT OWED BY 4 NATIONS
description: The Department of Agriculture reported today that it had paid American banks $431 million since last May to make good on Government guarantees of loans to four countries.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the Senate's rejection of a proposed constitutional amendment to sanction silent prayer in the schools misstated the party affiliation of Senator Lowell P. Weicker of Connecticut. He is a Republican.

title: NEW SECURITY STEPS BEING TAKEN AT WHITE HOUSE AFTER SHOOTING
description: The White House today announced new security measures to prevent terrorism and protect President Reagan.

title: Israelis Reported to Consider A New Pullback in Lebanon
description: The Israeli military command is considering pulling back to a new line in southern Lebanon between the Zaharani and Litani Rivers, the Israeli radio reported today.

description: Charles (Chesty) McDonald, a former bobsledder for the United States Olympic team, died of bronchopneumonia Thursday at Albany Veterans Hospital.

title: ABANDON SHOREHAM: CONSIDER ALTERNATIVES
description: Everyone agrees that the $4.1 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant is a costly mistake that can never pay for itself. Still unanswered, though, is the question: Should the plant should be completed and brought into operation?

title: MONDALE IS HOPEFUL ON FIVE CAUCUSES TODAY
description: Walter F. Mondale is looking to Democratic caucuses in Michigan and four other states Saturday for a weekend surge to lift his chances going into the Illinois primary next Tuesday.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sales of real estate of $513,970 for the latest quarter and $449,010 for the year-earlier period.

title: Kennedy Son GivenProbation in Drug Case
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who pleaded guilty in September to possessing heroin, today began two years of probation.

title: OUTLINES OF THE NEW YORK VOTE
description: After the complexities of past years, the outlines of the April 3 Democratic Presidential primary election in New York seem clear cut. But some complications remain.

title: Ford Credit in Filing
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company said today that it had notified the Securities and Exchange Commission it plans to offer $1 billion of notes with maturities ranging from nine months to five years. The notes will be priced at 100 percent of par value and interest rates will be set when they are issued, the company said in a shelf-registration statement.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Walter Payton, the Chicago Bears' star running back, said he would undergo minor arthroscopic surgery on both knees to relieve persistent soreness and fluid. . . . Tiffany Chin , who finished fourth in the Olympic figure- skating competition last month, will not compete in the world championships next week because of a bruised left foot. . . . The Tulsa Roughnecks, the financially ailing soccer team that was recently sold to the Tulsa Cable Company, have announced the departure of their coach, Steve Earle; their assistant coach, Keith Weller, and three players, including a leading scorer, Zequinha.

title: WASHINGTON TRIUMPHS
description: Washington, led by Detlef Schrempf with 23 points, defeated Nevada-Reno, 64-54, tonight in a first- round game in the N.C.A.A West Regional.

title: MULHOLLAND RESIGNS AS PRESIDENT OF NBC
description: Robert E. Mulholland, president and chief operating officer of NBC for the last two and a half years, announced his resignation yesterday.

title: APL-Evans Pact
description: The APL Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Shelter Products Group of the Evans Products Corporation for about $45 million.

title: FEDERAL COURT REFUSES TO BAR BLACK JUDGE IN ALABAMA CASE
description: Alabama's first black Federal judge will be allowed to preside over a Justice Department desegregation case against the state's college system, a Federal appeals court judge has ruled.

title: HAROLD M. STEINMETZ
description: Harold M. Steinmetz, a lawyer who retired in 1972 after nearly 30 years as president of the Fossan Company, a machine-parts concern in Greenwich, Conn., died Thursday at Greenwich Hospital.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WARD HOLDS POLICE TO A HIGH STANDARD
description: Returning from the funeral of an officer killed outside a private social club in Brooklyn, Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward sternly reminded a class of young recruits early last month that the police must be held to higher standards than civilians. He recalled that his own son resigned from the force in 1981 while facing departmental charges of chronic lateness and losing his police radio and revolver.

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a nonrecurring loss of $1,400,000 from equity securities transactions.

title: Adolph Stuber Is Dead at 94; Began Grand Central Display
description: Adolph Stuber, creator of Eastman Kodak Company's Colorama exhibit in Grand Central Terminal in New York City, died of an aneurysm Thursday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 94.

title: MANAGEMENT GROUP PLANS CONDEC OFFER
description: The Condec Corporation, which was the subject late last year of a proxy fight waged by a group of dissident shareholders, said yesterday that a management group intends to make a $28-a-share acquisition offer.

title: OF LEGUMOPHOBIA AND OTHER SUCH 'SINS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan and FitzGerald Meet
description: President Reagan joined Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland today in calling for an end to terrorism in Northern Ireland and reconciliation between the British province's Roman Catholics and Protestants. Mr. Reagan, who is to visit Ireland in June, spoke at a White House luncheon for Mr. FitzGerald after they held talks.

title: Celtics Win 50th
description: Scott Wedman and Danny Ainge sparked a fourth quarter surge tonight that lifted Boston to a 109-99 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: RETURN OF LITERARY SOCIETY
description: It was called the Stylus Literary

title: KING HUSSEINS' REBUFF: EVOLUTION OF A SURPRISE
description: King Hussein of Jordan has been in power for more than 30 years in a region not known for the longevity of its rulers. His ability to keep afloat was once described as the result of his having ''pursued a policy of alternately bowing to the storm and confronting it.''

title: A Bid to Murdoch on Warner Seen
description: Trading was suspended yesterday in shares of Warner Communications Inc. and Chris-Craft Industries at the companies' request, and speculation grew that one of the two would purchase Rupert Murdoch's 7 percent stake in Warner.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $4,110,000 for the quarter and $4,895,000 for the year, and a gain of $756,000 for the year from an accounting change.

title: VIRCO MANUFACTURING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $354,000, or 19 cents a share, from the sale of real estate. Share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend payable April 23.

title: Damson Revises Dorchester Offer
description: The Damson Oil Corporation said it had revised its acquisition offer for the Dorchester Gas Company to provide for the payment of $22.50 a share for any and all Dorchester shares outstanding.

title: The Right Link in SalvadorThere's a storm in Congress over linkage. Speaker O'Neill thunders that Mr. Reagan is ''unfit to be President'' because the Administration linked military aid for Central America to food relief for Africa. Secretary Shultz sputters that human rights purists on Capitol Hill have linked aid for El Salvador to impossible conditions, thus effectively abandoning an ally. But this is a skirmish, not a showdown.
description: Congress by its votes has shown no willingness to cut off aid to El Salvador or to C.I.A.-backed rebels in Nicaragua. It's not about to risk appearing to coddle Marxist-Leninists in an election year. And the Administration, meanwhile, is stuck with a flawed, unworkable policy. It all spells deadlock.

title: Chuck Out the Checkoffs The ''chickadee checkoff'' allows taxpayers in 31 states to donate a dollar to wildlife preservation. Alabama tax returns permit a similar donation for the arts (the Chekhov checkoff?). Tax returns in Colorado, California and elsewhere invite contributions to prevent child abuse and help battered women. Now the Senate Finance Committee has devised an Olympics checkoff for every Form 1040.
description: There's no shortage of worthy causes - and that's the problem. The proliferation of these checkoffs puts tax collectors in the business of fund-raising, where they don't belong.

title: NOVELTY AT THIRD
description: Tony LaRussa, the manager of the White Sox, reflected on the rewards of success recently and said: ''A year ago, I was hanging by my fingernails. This year, I've been told my job is safe - at least through spring training.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Campaign for Olmedo's Seat

title: SOL L. KLEIN
description: Sol L. Klein, founder and retired president of Nettie Rosenstein Accessories Inc., died in his sleep last Saturday while vacationing at the home of his son, Barry, in Trabuco Canyon, Calif.

title: S.E.C. Staff Backs Ford
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's staff has upheld the Ford Motor Company's right to ignore a shareholder proposal submitted by a dismissed company vice president who wants Ford to study merging with the Chrysler Corporation, according to documents released today.

title: OF LEGUMOPHOBIA AND OTHER SUCH 'SINS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Rate of Infant Deaths in U.S. At Lowest Point in History
description: America's rate of infant deaths is the lowest in the nation's history, a Federal health official told Congress today.

title: THE GREENING OF PEACE
description: Some 43 million Americans have an Irish heritage. Through the years, the mystique of the Irish, a quality of mind and spirit that emanates from the island, has become one of the ingredients in the makeup of American society. Americans for the most part appear to be conscious of and pleased about the nation's Irish connection.

title: THAYER CASE SHIFTS TO DALLAS
description: Paul Thayer, former Deputy Secretary of Defense, and eight other people who have been charged with illegally trading stock on the basis of inside information won an important legal skirmish yesterday when a Federal judge in New York ordered their trial moved to Dallas.

title: I.M.F. SAYS U.S. DEFICITS THREATEN WORLD UPTURN
description: The International Monetary Fund, in its strongest criticism yet of the economic policies of the Reagan Administration, said today that United States budget deficits were keeping interest rates at unusually high levels and thus threatened the world economic recovery.

title: Young's Indoctrination
description: Steve Young, the new quarterback for the Los Angeles Express, knows he's under pressure to justify his $40 million contract, and the former Brigham Young star said he was determined to do his best in the game with the San Antonio Gunslingers in Texas today. ''What I do, I do 100 percent,'' said Young, who will not be in uniform but will be watching to familiarize himself with the Express offense.

title: Roloff Beny Is Dead at 60; Painter and Photographer
description: Roloff Beny, a painter, print maker and internationally acclaimed photographer, died yesterday of a heart attack in his studio in Rome. He was 60 years old.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Tracy Caulkin Sets Swim Marks

title: LouisvilleGainsVillanova Rallies
description: The guards Lancaster Gordon and Milt Wagner ignited two scoring spurts that led Louisville to a 72-59 victory tonight over Morehead State in a first-round N.C.A.A. Mideast Regional game.

title: Parole Panel Nomination
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Daniel Raul Lopez, a hearing representative to the Board of Prison Terms since 1974, to be a member of the United States Parole Commission. Mr. Lopez is a former California correction officer who lives in Oceanside, Calif.

title: Some British MinersVote Not to StrikeLONDON, March 16 (AP) - Coal miners in four regions voted today not to join a five-day-old strike, splitting the union and raising fears of more violence on picket lines.
description: About 20,000 miners in Lancashire, South Derbyshire, the Midlands and Northumberland voted to stay on the job.

description: John A. Kiefner, a Government maintenance inspector and occasional private pilot who was an Air Corps ground officer in World War II, aimed his flashlight on the underwing area of a Trans World Airlines jumbo jet on a ramp at Kennedy International Airport early this month.

title: N.F.L. Seeks Draft Plan The National Football League is trying to work out a plan to include
description: undergraduates in its draft of college players, if not next May, then in

title: MIAMI DRIVE IS MOUNTED TO GET BLACKS ON JURIES
description: Four recent trials in which all-white juries decided the fate of four Miami area police officers accused of killing black men have spurred a drive here to change the state's laws on selecting trial juries to improve the chances of placing blacks on the panels.

title: NUMBERS GAMES
description: F OR almost two weeks, Gary Hart remained silent under Walter F. Mondale's repeated suggestions that Americans should not entrust the Presidency to a man as unknown, untested and perhaps unstable as Mr. Hart. Finally, on Thursday, Mr. Hart struck. ''He knows in his heart there is no blemish on my character that would prohibit me from governing this country in this decade,'' Mr. Hart said. Later that day, the Colorado Senator backtracked, saying he had been incorrectly told that the former Vice President was running commercials about the fact that Mr. Hart has changed his name, his date of birth and his signature.

title: SALVADOR REBELS BAR TRUCE FOR ELECTION
description: A guerrilla leader said today that the insurgents would ''deepen'' the war, ''before, during and after'' the elections. His statement came after a new series of rebel attacks during the night.

title: No Headline
description: 2 Die Upstate in Crash OfPlaneCarryingDrug

title: FOR BRAHMS AT 151, THE CELEBRATIONS CONTINUE
description: One might have thought that Deutsche Grammophon, having amassed its 62-disk Brahms Edition last year honoring the composer's 150th birthday, would have had its fill. Clearly, one should not underestimate the venerable Hamburg label's devotion to its hometown hero. Included in that series were Herbert von Karajan's 1978 recordings of the symphonies and ''Tragic'' Overture and Leonard Bernstein's 1983 Double Concerto. Now DG sets up shop on the next block, offering Mr. Bernstein's symphonies, ''Tragic''and ''Academic Festival'' Overtures, and ''Haydn'' Variations (2741 023, four disks, digital) and Mr. Karajan's Double Concerto - with yet another ''Tragic'' Overture (410 603-1, digital). And the market, however crowded already, is undeniably richer for having them.

title: HAD BOASTED OF KILLING 30 OR MORE
description: The republican terrorist who headed Ireland's most-wanted list was captured today after a shoot-out at dawn with 40 heavily armed detectives at an isolated cottage in the Irish Republic where he was holed up with three confederates.

title: KNICKS TRIUMPH AS KING SCORES 38
description: With 6 minutes 51 seconds remaining in the opening quarter last night, Bernard King was called for a rare foul: He was caught throwing an elbow at Mark Olberding.

description: NEW HAVEN WHEN Yale's School of Organization and Management opened its doors in September 1976, Kingman Brewster Jr., then the university's president, presented it with its own coat of arms.

title: WILDCLIFF TO BE CONVERTED TO ARTS CENTER
description: NEW ROCHELLE WILDCLIFF MUSEUM, once one of this city's premiere resources, attracting thousands of patrons yearly from the county and beyond, is about to be resurrected - not as a nature center, its original incarnation, but as an arts institution that will include a 150-seat theater.

title: FOOD
description: NE OF THE PERquisites and joys of being a supposed authority - in my own case, a food critic - is the license to deal in hyperbole and to have the public accept it. I find it a pleasure to talk about the best, the finest, the ultimate. I was recently asked to name the greatest of all sauces to be found in the classic French repertory and I almost immediately answered sauce americaine, a response not wholly unrelated, I suppose, to my having recently dined on this tarragon-flavored lobster and tomato sauce.

title: DALLAS POLICE GET PERMISSION TO SELL GUNS FOR CITY'S PROFIT
description: The Dallas City Council has received a report from a city board that recommends restrictions on the sale of pistols.

description: At a time of the year when he rarely excels, Dave Winfield seemed more relieved than alarmed by a spike wound that will keep him out of the batter's box here for at least a week.

description: It might not seem possible for a

description: IT took the University of Hartford's Lincoln Theater more

title: GUIDE TO GRATUITIES, COUNTRY BY COUNTRY
description: The following guide offers suggestions on appropriate levels of tipping in the countries listed. In some cases - see West Germany for an example - when neighboring countries have similar tipping practices, they have been grouped under one heading. In many places inflation will soon outdate exact figures. When sums in local money are given, the traveler should check the current rate.

description: CHERYL BLACKERBY is travel editor of The Palm Beach Post.

description: Manchester United regained the lead in the English League First Division soccer standings for the first time since October with a crushing 4-0 home victory over Arsenal today.

description: Christina Onassis, 33 years old, heiress to a Greek shipping fortune, was married today to Thierry Roussel, 31, a French businessman.

description: Attorney General William French Smith met today with other Justice Department officials to consider whether to open an investigation into the financial dealings of the Presidential counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, who has been nominated to replace Mr. Smith.

title: LEBANESE POLITICIANS JOCKEY FOR POSITION
description: After two days of private talks, Lebanon's factional leaders gathered again today to debate a list put together by President Amin Gemayel of various proposals for a political settlement.

title: LISTEN! IT'S THE SOUND OF SPRING COMING
description: TUESDAY, March 20, at 5:25 A.M., E.S.T., I'll be outdoors greeting the arrival of spring. Welcoming spring is something I've been doing for almost 30 years now. I was taught to do it by 22 first graders on a noisy street in Manhattan. It's a lesson I'm glad I learned.

title: U.S. AND YONKERS IN SCHOOL ACCORD
description: After months of emotional debate and millions of dollars in legal expenses, a tentative out-of-court settlement has been reached in a four-year- old Federal lawsuit seeking to integrate the public schools in Yonkers, officials said yesterday.

description: Peter Braestrup is editor of The Wilson Quarterly and author of ''Big Story,'' an analysis of Vietnam news coverage.THE KENNEDY CRISES

title: THE ENIRONMENT
description: CONDITIONAL revocation by the state's Department of Environmental Protection of the largest building permit in the Smithville case came as somewhat of a surprise to opponents of the development.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: With the heralding of the $60,000 college education in 1982, many schools increased their loans to needy students to help cover the tuition. Fewer schools added to their scholarships.

title: A NEW LIFT FOR MCDONNELL DOUGLAS
description: IN November 1981, Sanford N. McDonnell, who had recently taken over from his uncle as chairman of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, received an unsolicited telephone call from James E. Worsham, an engineer with the folksy strains of rural Kentucky in his voice.

title: DREAMS CAPTURED IN GLASS
description: Emil Galle's glass designs are masterworks in the French Art Nouveau style, weighty wares locking insects, flowers, leaves, pine cones and winged creatures in milky or murky layers, shaped into classical, naturalistic or primordial forms. Although made to function as vases, bowls, bottles and lamps, they seldom do. That's because the collectors and museums who own them regard these works as art treasures too precious for everyday use.

title: 'WELL' AND 'GENERATION APART,' ON HOLOCAUST
description: ''The Well'' is a Yiddish-language short feature that depicts a young Jewish man from Eastern Europe in 1939 as he gradually becomes aware of the fate that awaits his people. When he goes to the well in his tiny village, he finds it muddy, and the gravity of this omen is conveyed through much overreaction and pantomime.

title: CLUSTERS AT A COUNTRY CLUB
description: On a 10-acre parcel of land next to the 16th hole of the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., a developer is building 54 town houses.

title: A French Trimaran Has Inflatable Sails
description: The two French sailors arrived in midtown Manhattan recently wearing jeans, red sailing jackets and carrying a big wooden box. In their brief stop en route home to Marseilles from Canada, Alain Gabbay and Vincent DeVictor paused long enough for lunch and to open the box.

title: OF CBS' PLANS TO BROADCAST CONVERSATIONS WITH MR. NIXON
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: JUILLIARD GROUP IN LIMON 'MISSA BREVIS'
description: The Juilliard Dance Ensemble's second program of the season, presented on Friday at the Juilliard Theater, provided not just a suggestion of the variety of American modern dance but the occasion for some impressive performing.

title: O'ROURKE SAYS HE WILL NOT SIGN 'IN HASTE'
description: AFTER two months of controversy, the County Board of Legislators voted 13 to 3 last Monday to lease 21 acres of Grasslands Reservation property to the Robert Martin Company for 99 years.

title: SWALE IS 3D AS 39-1 SHOT WINS
description: Darn That Alarm, a 39-to-1 shot, led every step of the way through a slow pace to score an upset in the $122,000 Fountain of Youth Stakes for 3-year- olds today at Gulfstream Park. Counterfeit Money finished second, half a length behind and a length in front of Swale, the 1-to-2 favorite.

title: IN NORWALK, YANKEE DOODLE SPURS A DANCY OF A DEBATE
description: NORWALK PERHAPS this city's most endearing legend is that when Yankee Doodle went to town riding on his pony, he did so from Norwalk, more than two centuries ago.

title: Chicago Mayor Joins Jesse Jackson at Rally
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today returned here to his spiritual and political base for a rally at the headquarters of Operation PUSH. Mr. Jackson was joined on the podium by Mayor Harold Washington.

description: A smiling, self-confident Yasir Arafat defiantly insists that despite his forced ouster from Lebanon, his leadership of the faction-ridden Palestine Liberation Organization is as strong as ever.

title: Spain Curbs Control Of Schools by Church
description: Parliament has approved broad educational changes that will reduce the influence of the Roman Catholic Church in schools and increase the state's control over the curriculum.

title: WHICH INSTRUMENTS ARE BEST FOR BACK?
description: Using the right instruments is one of the central tenets of the ''authenticity'' movement - you don't play harpsichord music on that gargantuan keyboard mutant, the piano. But beginning tomorrow night in Carnegie Recital Hall, the musician and scholar Rosalyn Tureck will be presenting a series of six concerts and lectures drawing attention to some of the ambiguities in Baroque instrumentation. The series of all- Bach performances will juxtapose different editions of the same work, different instruments playing the same work, and different transcriptions of the same work by both Bach and Miss Tureck.

title: VA. COMMONWEALTH GUARD PRODUCES
description: Calvin Duncan's reputation as the strong, slippery and explosive guard from Virginia Commonwealth had preceded him to the Rams' opening-round encounter against Northeastern in the N.C.A.A. East Regional Friday night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. But for most of the game, he was quiet, passing up open jump shots for passes to teammates.

title: BUILDING ON ITS GOLDEN STAKE IN THE MILITARY
description: Like many other American aerospace companies, McDonnell Douglas has a reputation as a manufacturer of civilian products that is dwarfed by its stake in the military economy. Last year it ranked No. 2 among top defense contractors, garnering more than $6 billion in prime contract awards from the Pentagon. Only the magalithic General Dynamics placed higher.

title: CHOCOLATE, THE EXCEPTION, IS THE FOOD FOR ALL SEASONS
description: THE majority of the subjects presented in this column relate to the seasons. Either the foods are seasonally available - citrus fruits in winter and peaches in summer, for example - or the recipes themselves are seasonally appropriate. Thick soups are not the topic for July any more than chilled ones would be suggested now.

title: ONE VOICE AND MANY -- A POET'S DEBT TO PROSE
description: During a writing career of 30 years, James Wright used an extraordinary array of styles and voices in passionate poems that range from the intensely lyrical to somber expressions of disillusionment. He worried about the language he used in his poems and once wrote that for a long time he had been ''slicking into my own words / The beautiful language of my friends.'' His resolve: ''I have to use my own now.'' His remarks below reflect not only part of the outlook of his later poetry, but some of the concerns about language that enliven many of his poems. This is an edited version of a talk Wright gave on March 30, 1977 in a series of ''Conversations'' sponsored by the Academy of American Poets. It is the first transcription taken from the academy's tape-recorded archive of American poets. Wright died four years ago on March 25 at the age of 52. HEN I was thinking about how to begin this evening, I wanted to talk about some of the authors I care most about, and I came to realize that most of them are writers of prose. Many of them are very sardonic about themselves, and some of them have a rather sour attitude toward poetry. I don't know why that should be so appealing to me. There is something about the sudden rejection of poetry (or maybe it's a rejection of a certain kind of rhetoric) which in itself can suddenly reach over into some kind of rhythm, some closeness of life.

title: STREETS HAVE ROOTS, TOO

I wondered who they were and when they had built the one-room house snuggled against the hill, which was to become the kitchen of the house I remember.

title: TIPPING TACTICS AROUND THE WORLD
description: There is an extraordinary fat red volume in many French homes and offices called the ''Guide to Protocol and Manners.'' It is really, in a subliminal way, a Michelin of middle-class insecurities, but no matter: For a story line, it offers a young man named Patrice, driven by an almost morbid fear of the faux pas, and a certain Monsieur Blancpain, who tries to buff Patrice up to the sheen of someone knowing in which order to greet the Bishop of Orleans and the Turkish Ambassador at a garden party. With the metaphysics squeezed out, Patrice and M. Blancpain are Candide and Pangloss all over again. Voltaire sought truth, brevity and method; all I wanted from Patrice and his mentor was a line on the well-educated tip.

title: SCREEN: 'GERMANY PALE MOTHER' SET IN THE NAZI ERA
description: Helma Sanders-Brahms's ''Germany Pale Mother'' is narrated by a woman who says she is telling her parents' story, as well as her country's. Her parents' courtship began during the Nazis' rise to power, and it was, she says, ''perfectly normal, only it happened at this time, in this country.'' Their marriage was marked by long separations, as Hans (Ernst Jacobi) went off to fight in the war, and Helene (Eva Mattes) stayed home, raising her daughter and enduring almost every imaginable physical hardship.

title: CHRONOLOGY OFFERS A FRESH PERSPECTIVE ON THE BLUES
description: Twenty-five years ago, a handful of American record collectors began reissuing their precious 78-rpm country blues disks from the 1920's on long-playing albums. The first of these albums were sampler- type anthologies, designed to introduce the music to a new generation of fans, or albums by a single prolific performer. But it was soon evident that haphazard anthologizing could only lead to confusion, and relatively few of the early blues artists had made enough 78-rpm disks to fill an album. So the early blues reissue labels, principally Folkways/RBF and the Origin Jazz Library, borrowed an idea from the regional approach to jazz history - New Orleans style, Chicago jazz, and so on - and began assembling anthologies of Memphis blues, Georgia blues, Mississippi blues, and other regional styles. Subsequent reissue labels like Yazoo and Herwin boasted considerably improved sound quality, but they continued to program most of their albums along regional lines.

Campaign analysts, whose trade should make them astute connoisseurs of rhetorical appeals, have recently been astonished by the seductive allure of one candidate's ''New Ideas.'' title: ODETS'S MASTERWORK SHINES THROUGH
description: When Clifford Odets pressed his fellow-members of the Group Theater to put on ''Awake and Sing!'' in 1934, Lee Strasberg lost his temper. ''You don't seem to understand, Cliff,'' he snapped. ''We don't like your play. We don't want to do your play. It has a small horizon.'' That judgment did not, of course, prevail. Within a few months, the play had opened on Broadway, and its apprentice author was being acclaimed a ''somebody'' by Walter Winchell and more modestly praised for his ''fervor and skill'' by Brooks Atkinson. But Strasberg's sneer is still instructive, at least as a reminder of the very different expectations intelligent people brought to drama 50 years ago. If he thought the horizons of ''Awake and Sing!'' small, how would he have measured some of our own day's plays about family discord? The East and West extremes of Tina Howe's undeniably talented, indisputably absorbing ''Painting Churches,'' for instance, would have to be rated the left and right sides of an average-sized shoebox.

title: STANLEY FINK GETS DOWN TO BUSINESS

The Assembly had just put a state budget into place on time for the first time in three years. There was cheering, laughter and a mood of euphoria throughout the chamber. ''You gave me a better budget than the one I gave you,'' Mr. Cuomo said. Mr. Fink responded, ''That makes us happy.''

title: A TACTICAL RETREAT ON MILITARY SPENDING
description: WASHINGTON W ITH televised fanfare, President Reagan came out to the Rose Garden last week to announce that he was pulling back on his military spending requests. But the first sign that there may be less than meets the eye in the Administration's ''compromise'' spending levels came from the Administration itself. A White House ''fact sheet'' said Mr. Reagan was now seeking only a 5.1 percent increase in military spending authority for the 1985 fiscal year after of inflation, rather than the 13 percent increase he proposed in January. A day later, however, the Office of Management and Budget acknowledged that the increase was actually 7.8 percent.

title: IN POP MUSIC, THE RACES REMAIN FAR APART

Mr. Jackson's eight prizes were more by two than anybody had ever won at a Grammy ceremony. His latest album, ''Thriller,'' may sell 35 million ''units,'' a unit being a record, cassette or compact disk. When it reached 25 million a few weeks ago, it became the biggest-selling record of all time.

The chumminess continues, unfortunately, in the dining room where closely spaced tables make private conversation difficult. And seating becomes even tighter as places for three are set at tables meant for two, an ungracious arrangement at those times when tables for four remain empty.

description: Gene Sullivan, the Loyola of Chicago basketball coach, who is at odds with the National Invitation Tournament, has abandoned plans to hold a ''Cinderella Classic'' for eight 20- game winners passed over by the N.I.T. ''The whole thing's been called off,'' said Sullivan's assistant, Doug Bruno. Although five schools agreed to join Loyola in the tournament, Bruno said, the plans were dropped after Illinois-Chicago, which was expected to be the host, and Ohio decided not to enter.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: As a result of a mail campaign from fervid viewers, shrewdly encouraged by executive producer Barney Rosenzweig, and the subsequent winning of some top Emmy Awards, the once cancelled ''Cagney & Lacey'' is being revived by CBS. The weekly series returns for a third season Monday at 10 P.M.

title: HARD TIMES FAILED TO DETER
description: RISE OF BARITONE'S CAREER

title: THE THEATER'S AVANT-GARDE BRANCHES OUT
description: The close of the 1960's was a halcyon time for the theatrical avant-garde. Theaters, churches and lofts from Manhattan's West Side to the Brooklyn Academy of Music were filled with experimentation as conceptual directors led ensemble companies into adventurous avenues. In the space of a single season, theatergoers could see the Open Theater's ''Serpent''; Jerzy Grotowski's Polish Lab Theater; and Robert Wilson's first revolutionary epic, ''The Life and Times of Sigmund Freud.'' Stretching the timeline a bit, one could also see Tom O'Horgan's production of ''Tom Paine,'' Richard Schechner's ''Dionysus in '69,'' Charles Ludlam's ''Bluebeard,'' Andre Gregory's ''Alice in Wonderland,'' and Richard Foreman's early experiments with his Ontological-Hysteric Theater. Arriving in New York in 1969, as a young visitor from Rumania, Andrei Serban looked around at all the theatrical activity and said that the ''avant- garde was in flower.'' In 1984, one might wonder

title: UNESCO'S CRITICS HAVE THEIR SAY
description: When the United States announced that it would pull out of Unesco by the end of 1984 unless the organization mended its ways, 23 other industrial countries took up the gauntlet. They presented a list of complaints and suggestions for change to Unesco last week.

title: A SHIRT'S TALE
description: A BERNARD KALB is the State Department correspondent for NBC News. certain blue shirt of mine, a favorite traveling companion, recently poured forth this agonized soliloquy, which I recorded word for word: My itineraries in 1983 streaked the globe, threaded in all directions. Europe. North Africa. The Middle East. Latin America. Asia. To such out-of-the-way places as the Khyber Pass between Pakistan and Afghanistan, to the ancient ruins at Carthage in Tunisia, the shimmering Red Sea city of Jidda, now being modernized by Saudi oil. To Rome and Tokyo, Manila and Damascus, New Delhi and Cairo. The whole world tucked away in the very seams of my being.

title:

description: -Hudson River ferry service, a move triggered by Governor Kean, is a welcome change in regional transit policy.

title: Miss Schneider, Gary J. Casarsa To Marry May 5
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Isadore Schneider of New York and Brookfield, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Schneider, to Gary Joseph Casarsa, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Casarsa of Amherst, N.Y. A May 5 wedding is planned.

title: Kidnapping Suspect Dead
description: A karate instructor accused of kidnapping one of his students died today of a gunshot wound to the head.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: MAPLE SUGAR TIME, RAILPASS PLUS A BUS
description: The Lore Of Maple Sugar In Pennsylvania Long ago, according to legend, the Big Indian in the Sky rested his hand upon a sugar maple tree, and when he drew it away, he discovered that his fingers were sticky. When he put his fingers in his mouth, he learned of a sweetness beyond imagining.

title: Correction
description: A table with an article last Sunday about the airline industry gave an incorrect figure for Jet America's 1983 net income. The airline reported an $8 million profit.

title: Rosario Defeats Elizondo
description: Edwin Rosario of Puerto Rico stopped Roberto Elizondo at 1 minute 57 seconds of the first round today to retain his World Boxing Council lightweight title. It was Rosario's first defense since he won here May 1 last year and improved his record to 28-0.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Gelfman of Lido Beach, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jill Leslie Gelfman to Howard Scott Olonoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Olonoff, also of Lido Beach. The wedding is to be in October.

title: UPSTATE BOY IS YOUNGEST TO GET A PERFECT S.A.T. MATH SCORE
description: A seventh-grader here who became the youngest person to score a perfect 800 on the mathematics section of the Scholastic Aptitude Test says it really wasn't hard: ''I just figured it out logically.''

description: PER WELINDER has only one complaint about Connecticut: People here do not take skateboarding seriously. He should know. The 21-year-old Swede is the world champion skateboard freestylist and although he has lived in the state for two years, hardly anyone appears to have noticed.

title: IRAN UNDER KHOMEINI
description: Terence Smith's otherwise fair and informative account of developments during the first five years of the Islamic Republic of Iran fails to avoid a common journalistic pitfall. Mr. Smith finds the susceptibility of the Iranian people to the Ayatollah Khomeini's propaganda incomprehensible from a ''Western'' point of view, implying that the phenomenon of religious fanaticism is a strictly ''Eastern'' commodity (as though Hitler's very similar propaganda a generation or so ago had not subverted a sizable portion of the ''West''). Historians and journalists are all too ready to fall back upon an East-West dichotomy when the cultural phenomenon they seek to explain passes beyond their comprehension.

title: No Headline
description: Waiting for the 'Flash'

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Henry Moore is some way into his 80's now, and he hasn't been too well this winter. But he keeps busy.

title: Polly D. Emmons To Be May Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry I. Emmons of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Polly Dean Emmons to Stuart McAlpin Tilghman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Tilghman of New York and Fairfield, Conn.

title: 2 ARE CONVICTED IN NEW ENGLAND RAPE CASE
description: A jury in Superior Court today convicted two men of aggravated rape of a young woman at a bar in nearby New Bedford.

title: ELECTRONIC ALMANACS ARE THERE FOR THE ASKING
description: Job hunters in Toronto can go up to a computer terminal in a hotel lobby or shopping center, push a few buttons and look at help-wanted listings.

title: STUDENTS EXPLORE HUMANITIES THEMES IN THEIR WRITING
description: QUESTIONS for a high school student: How can you make a required paper one you want to write? How can you end with a paper your teacher, and even your classmates, will want to read?

title: A CZECH PLAY WITHIN TWO PLAYS
description: THE Czechoslovak playwright Pavel Kohout has never seen a production of his play ''Poor Murderer.'' The Czech Government will provide him with a passport and exit visa only on the condition that his family be left behind and that he never return to Czechoslovakia. Consequently, Mr. Kohout's work, which has been translated into several languages and performed all over the world, including on Broadway, and now at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, can only be imagined by the author.

title: SOCRATES SPOKE HERE
description: ''Pardon me,'' she said, this small, neat Belgian woman with a teen-age daughter in tow. ''Have you found the shoemaker's shop?'' When I shook my head, she frowned fiercely. ''Simon's shop,'' she said, pointing to a page in her guidebook. ''It's where Socrates came to have his boots fixed. You wouldn't want to miss it.''

description: Charles S. Maier is a professor of European history at Harvard University and the author of ''Recasting Bourgeois Europe.'' He is writing a political history of 20th- century inflation. STRATEGY AND DIPLOMACY 1870-1945

Mondale should be no surprise to anyone; they are the most recent sign of a split that has existed for generations between those who believe in the Democratic Party as an institution and those who believe in it as a vehicle for change.

DINING OUT;
A CATERER TRIES A NEW LOCATION
description: KEEPING up with the changing restaurant scene can be a full-time job. The chef from one establishment suddenly pops up at another one, or the ma^itre d'h^otel at one popular spot opens his own place. Some restaurants switch owners and names seemingly with the seasons.

description: TWENTY years ago, as some residents of Freeport like to remember, people would get all dressed up on a Saturday night to go shopping on South Main Street. ''This was

title: Kremlin's Warning to Turkey Brings Response on Missiles
description: The Soviet Union has told Turkey that its increased military cooperation with the United States ''is creating a threat again Russia'' and has asked whether Turkey is considering installing cruise or Pershing missiles on its soil, according to Turkish press reports.

description: Owners, executives and coaches of the 28 National Football League teams will begin their annual meetings in Honolulu tomorrow with most club officials in agreement that the biggest problem facing the league is rising costs, created by the emergence of the United States Football League.

title: Data Bank; March 18, 1984
DISPUTING SUBURBAN ASSESSORS
description: THE correct way to assess cooperative apartments for property-tax purposes outside New York City is still largely unresolved. The co-op form of ownership is still so alien, and in some places the law so fuzzy, that legal battles tend to accompany any effort by taxing authorities to revise their valuations.

title: Old Country Road in Melville; Long Island Journal
description: AT the age of 84, with 64 years of Naval service behind him, plus a slew of awards for developing the nuclear- powered submarine, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover undoubtedly has some idea of ''Man's Purpose in Life.'' So it's the subject he has chosen to address Friday when he delivers the University Distinguished Lecture at the State University at Stony Brook. The talk will be given at 2 P.M. in the university's Fine Arts Center recital hall. It will be free and open to the public.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: IN A DARK, DARK ROOM: And Other Scary Stories. By Alvin Schwartz. Illustrated by Dirk Zimmer. (Harper & Row.

title: RANGERS LOSE, 6-4, AFTER LEADING, 4-1
description: The Rangers, jockeying for playoff position, took a giant step backward today, falling into fourth place in the Patrick Division with a 6-4 loss to the Flyers at the Spectrum.

title: MORE FUNDS FOR HOME CARE OF RETARDED URGED
description: New York State should put a greater emphasis on helping families who care for the mentally retarded and the severely disabled at home, a state commission said yesterday.

BUSINESS FORUM;
THE FEAR OF CONCENTRATION IS JUSTIFIED
description: IF Congress does nothing to stop the

title: A TRATTORIA TO REMEMBER
description: LA PETITE TRATTORIA in Lynbrook is a modest storefront restaurant. It may not be worth traveling halfway across the Island to dine here, but if you are in the area, it is a good place to remember for a special meal. It has a surprisingly ambitious menu.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 UP, UP AND AWAY
description: It's not an ill wind that members of the Long Island's Kite Fliers Association are looking for today. Rather, it's some brisk winds to take their creations aloft for ''The Magnificent March Madman Marathon.'' The kite fly starts at noon at parking field No. 6 in Jones Beach State Park, and all those with a kite - or just a yen to walk along the beach with the wind blowing at their back - are invited to come along for the free fun.

title: Kentucky and Maryland Win
description: Taking advantage of steals and turnovers, Kentucky took an early 11-point lead today and then went on to defeat Brigham Young, 93- 68, in the second round of the Mideast Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: Walkout by 300,000 in India Paralyzes Its Major Harbors
description: A strike by 300,000 dock workers entered its second day today, paralyzing India's 10 major ports, stranding 120 ships and halting oil supplies.

title: THE NEW SOUTH WARMS TO NORTHERN ORTHODOXIES
description: The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., for all his faith in a liberalized South, might have found it hard to believe: Two Deep South states, Alabama and Georgia, saved the Presidential candidacy of Walter F. Mondale, a liberal Democrat whose policies once were condemned by the majority in the region. To top it all off, in last week's Democratic primaries, a greater percentage of blacks than whites turned out to vote.

title: THE WORLD
description: Senators Take Their Time on Salvador Aid

title:
About Westchester;
THE VOW
description: SCARSDALE WHEN her grandmother died of cancer, Maria Kliavkoff ''looked at the casket and made a vow to one day do something of significance against the disease.''

title: CHOOSING THE RIGHT ADJUSTABLE MORTGAGE
description: ''IDIDN'T do that much shopping around, other than

title: Music; NEW 'SHOWCASES' IN THE COUNTY OR ARTISTS IN RESIDENCE
description: FROM its tentative beginnings five years ago, the music series at the Ossining Public Library has grown into an eagerly awaited, deeply appreciated part of the community's cultural life. ''Attendance has been growing steadily,'' says Jane Clark, the program's coordinator, ''and all our performances are now videotaped, both for showing on American Cable and for use in the library's own shut-in service for people who can't leave their homes.''

title: SENATORS WANT MORE ANSWERS FROM MEESE
description: By now, Presidential counselor Edwin Meese 3d and the White House had expected his confirmation as Attorney General to be a mere formality, but last week the Senate Judiciary Committee decided to call him back for more questions.

title: STUDENTS DON'T GO FOR ANYTHING GOES ANYMORE
description: After a 15-year absence, restrictions on dormitory visits from members of the opposite sex were being reinstituted last week at Western Illinois University. No, the university is not returning to the once-popular philosophy of ''in loco parentis,'' under which many colleges, Western Illinois among them, functioned as students' surrogate parents. Rather, the rules are back because undergraduates asked for them. ''We had a lot of complaints about students being kicked out of their rooms by roommates,'' said James B. Miner, director of student activities.

title: THE COMMON MARKET COPES WITH ITS 'BRITISH PROBLEM'
description: Britain has belonged to the European Economic Community for more than a decade now, and it has spent much of that time squabbling with its partners. No front-line British politician talks much anymore about pulling out (and the Labor party seems to be on the verge of renouncing its formal commitment to withdrawal), but few politicians have very much to say in favor of the Common Market as it now stands.

title: NOW IT'S MOSCOW THAT NEEDS SYRIA
description: The hallmark of Soviet policy in the Middle East has been persistence rather than success.

title: SOLVING PROBLEMS THAT ARISE WITH FAUILTY DOORBELLS
description: DOORBELLS and door chimes are remarkably dependable devices that will normally operate for years with little or no attention on the part of the homeowner. However, problems sometimes develop that may keep the bell or chime from ringing when the push button on the outside is pressed, or that may cause it to work only intermittently.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: EVEN IN LAUSANNE, TALK MAY BE CHEAP
description: Before attending each session of the Lebanese reconciliation conference, the Druse leader, Walid Jumblat, likes to look around his suite at the Beau Rivage Hotel, make sure everyone in his entourage is ready, and then say, ''O.K., let's go down to the show.''

title: Racing Figure Charged
description: Arnold Kirkpatrick, an executive of Spendthrift Farms in Lexington, Ky., and a racing writer, has been charged by Federal authorities with illegal possession of cocaine. The 43-year-old Kirkpatrick, who was named an unindicted co-conspirator in a drug case in January, was charged with possessing 23.68 grams of cocaine after Federal agents searched his home last Wednesday.

title: HOW I WAS BROKEN BY THE K.G.B.
description: Victor Krasin is a former Soviet human-rights activist who emigrated in 1975 and lives in New York. This article is adapted from ''The Trial,'' by Victor Krasin, published in Russian by Chalidze Publications, New York, 1983. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis THE CELL DOOR OPENED and a lieutenant of the K.G.B. security police looked in. ''Get ready,'' he said. ''And fast.'' I had no sooner put on my jacket than the door opened again. ''Come on.'' He hurried me down the prison corridor and handed me over to the warden, who led me into his office. A tall, heavyset man stood up behind the desk and said: ''I am Chairman Andropov of the K.G.B.'' He extended his hand. I shook it and said: ''I recognized you from your pictures.'' He offered me a chair and examined me affably through his glasses. ''I've been told that you are undergoing a crisis of confidence in the K.G.B.'' ''Do you blame me?'' I replied. ''We kept our word at the trial, but the judge gave us six years each.'' The time was September 1973, nine years before Yuri V. Andropov began his short reign as the Soviet Union's top leader. The scene was Moscow's Lefortovo Prison. The Soviet human- rights movement had been in existence for eight years. For the first time in Soviet history, people had overcome their fears, spoken out and openly exposed violations of legal norms. It was our victory over the slavery in which we had lived for almost half a century.

title: CONSERVATIVE NOTE IN HECKSHER ANNUAL
description: THIS year's Long Island Artists' Exhibition, the 29th to be sponsored at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington by the Huntington Township Art League, looks somewhat tame in comparison with previous annuals. There are few of the big, bold, colorful abstractions that stood out in last year's selection, and none of the bizarre, eccentric sculptures that enlivened the galleries last March.

title: No Headline
description: Sheryl Krulik Is Married

title: No Headline
description: AT ANCHOR IN KASHMIR BY RICHARD REEVES

title: MEDICAL CONFERENCE TO FOCUS ON EFFECTS OF AGENT ORANGE
description: THE letter sent by one of the state's Vietnam veterans to James A. Sparrow of Stamford last week was a cry for help. The writer said he had health problems that could be related to exposure to a herbicide used in Vietnam called Agent Orange, that he was depressed and that he could not find work.

title:
TV VIEW;
ARE CHANNEL 13'S VIEWERS BEING SHORTCHANGED?
description: T he theme of WNET/Channel 13's Festival '84 fund-raising efforts, which conclude tonight at 8 with a three-hour ''Gala of Stars,'' is ''Television Worth Paying For.'' Presumably, this refers to the special programming that has been assembled for the festival, though the more suspicious viewer might justifiably begin worrying about public television's possible pay-TV ambitions. The point here, however, is that, for the most part, this is not television worth paying for. It is a hodgepodge of mediocre acquisitions, British comedies that have been rerun unto tedium, quality productions that have already been seen elsewhere, glitzy and rather tacky galas, and a batch of startlingly uneven old movies.

title: KASPAROV ON VERGE OF VICTORY IN 4TH GAME OF CHESS MATCH
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union is on the verge of winning the fourth game of his final candidates chess match with his countryman, Vasily Smyslov. When play was broken off at the 41st move Friday, the 20-year-old Kasparov had an extra pawn and positional advantage.

title: A PARLEY ON ULTER REFLECTS DEPTH OF CONFLICT
description: For the last 15 years, scholars who have studied the political and sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland have spoken of what a bitter place it is and how it seems trapped by its own long history and recent violence.

title: Dr. Barbara Koppel Weds Dr. Pedley
description: Dr. Barbara Sue Koppel, assistant professor of neurology at New York Medical College and attending neurologist at the Metropolitan Hospital in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Timothy A. Pedley 4th, professor of neurology at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, of which the bride is an alumna, and director of Clinical Neurophysiology Laboratories at Presbyterian Hospital. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: WHY FELDSTEIN HANGS TOUGH
description: Adam Smith is the pen name of George J. W. Goodman, author of ''Paper Money'' and ''The Money Game,'' and chairman of a New York investment partnership. By Adam Smith HE COUNCIL OF ECO nomic advisers - the very phrase has an august, Nestorian sound, as if black-robed sages sat in a circle, deliberating. The Council was formed 38 years ago to provide the President with economic research and advice. There are three members, supported by a sizable staff. The current chairman, Martin S. Feldstein, is a 44-year-old Harvard economist considered a mainstream conservative. Feldstein has become a figure of controversy and enough of a celebrity to be caricatured on the editorial pages.

title: Marchers Say Inquiry In Killings Is Lacking
description: Nearly 500 chanting women marched past X-rated movie houses and adult bookstores to protest what they said was a lack of police vigor in the investigation of a series of stranglings.

title: LABOR SONG'S WRITER, FRAIL AT 83, SHOWS SHE IS STILL A FIGHTER
description: Florence Reece, who will be 84 years old next month, lay in her hospital bed, fragile and white. She tried to eat, but, with her stomach ailment, that seemed too much effort. She said she would probably just have coffee.

title: Helen Miller to Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Miller of Foxhall Farm, Round Hill, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Holmes Miller, to James Michael Birch, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander A. Birch Jr. of Corvallis, Ore. A June wedding is planned.

title: China and Britain Speed Hong Kong Talks
description: China and Britain today ended another round of talks on the future of Hong Kong and announced a stepped-up pace in the negotiations.

title: SOUTH KOREANS FEAR MOVE TO 'ERASE' KWANGJU
description: After Maj. Gen. Chun Doo Hwan seized power and imposed strict martial law four years ago, students in this southwestern city took to the streets. By the end of their uprising in late May 1980, Government troops had killed nearly 200 people by official count, and far more than that according to Kwangju residents.

title: NOVEL CONVERSION ;
description: A former public-school building in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn that dates back to 1888 is being transformed into 28 condominium apartments.

title: CRITICS'S CHOICES
description: A successful cabaret inevitably develops an image created by the kind of bookings or productions that have brought it success. Sweetwaters, the restaurant at Amsterdam Avenue and West 68th Street, has for some time drawn many of its cabaret performers from the casts of the black musicals that have proliferated on Broadway in recent years.

title: The Prinsendam
description: To the Editor:

title: JERSEY CITY: RIVALRY NOT NEW
description: TO UNDERSTAND this city's past and its struggle to shed its image as New York City's poor relation, one has to look beyond the standard history books to pamphlets written and compiled by relatively obscure scholars on the basis of old documents, letters and newspaper articles.

title: The Landfill At Old Bethpage
description: I represent an organization known as R.A.G.E. (Residents Against Garbage Expansion). R.A.G.E. was recently formed because residents of Old Bethpage, Plainview, Woodbury, Farmingdale and other communities were not satisfied with the progress being made in cleaning up and safeguarding our environment. Our goals are to force the closure of the Old Bethpage landfill, clean it up and continuously monitor it, and prevent the construction of the proposed resource recovery facility.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: JURORS TAKE STAND
description: SLOWLY, slowly, the jury pool in the Brinks trial begins to fill. By midweek, more than a dozen men and women had made it through the detailed questioning and challenges for ''cause'' - such as knowing too much about the case - and others were being added every few days. When the pool contains 72 such candidates, a final panel of 12 potential jurors and four alternates will be selected.

title: BEING SMART IS NOT SO GREAT
description: THREE years ago, I married a man with not-so-ordinary brains. He is not only a member of Mensa (upper 2 percent of the population according to I.Q.) but also a member of Intertel (upper 1 percent).

title: Kitty Hawk
description: To the Editor:

title: A PHOEIX RAISES A STIR
description: TWO years ago, when Capt. Greg Brazier first set sail hauling cargo across Long Island Sound, he won acclaim both for building his 70-foot packet schooner - the Phoenix - from scratch and for raising from the ashes the Island's maritime past.

title: Jane L. Ades and Dr. Lewis Aron to Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Ades of Sands Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Louise Ades to Dr. Lewis Aron, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rubin Aron of Hollis Hills, Queens. The wedding is to be in June.

title: THE REGION
description: The Low Road on Street Repairs

title: B.U. AND R.P.I. FALL
description: Bowling Green stunned Boston University, 5-1, in overtime, and North Dakota upset Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, 4-2, last night to eliminate the East's top two seeded teams from the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey quarterfinals.

title: DANCE: PORTRAIT SKETCHES
description: It was appropriate that Thom Fogarty danced in an art gallery Wednesday night, for ''Hindsight,'' the hourlong work that he presented at the SoHo Center for Visual Artists, consisted of choreographic portrait sketches of crazed, weary or down- and-out people on the city streets.

title: THE SOCIAL COSTS OF AGRICULTURAL INNOVATION
description: There was standing room only in a courtroom here last week for the opening of a highly unusual lawsuit challenging the rights of university researchers to develop labor-saving machinery for farms.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LOBBYISTS in Trenton spent $750,000 more last year than in 1982 to influence legislation, according to the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission.

title: No Headline
description: New & Noteworthy THE RANDOM HOUSE BOOK OF TWENTIETH-CENTURY FRENCH POETRY: With Translations by American and British Poets, edited by Paul Auster. (Vintage, $11.95.) This generous, deftly edited bilingual collection offers selections from the work of roughly 50 modern French poets rendered by 84 translators. ''The matches are often superbly good, showing a real intimacy'' of originals and translations, according to our critic, Peter Brooks, who called the anthology ''a source of renewable delights and discoveries'' that ''everyone interested in modern poetry should have close to hand.'' CLARE BOOTHE LUCE, by Wilfrid Sheed. (Berkley, $7.95.) Wilfrid Sheed, critic, essayist and novelist, of fers a brief, breezy portrait of Clare Boothe Luce - playwright, politician, ambassador and widow of the publisher Henry R. Luce. His discussion of American Catholicism and its luminaries in the 50's and his ''evocation of the America of which Luce's Life magazine was the apotheoisis'' are brilliant, Mary Cantwell said in her review, but she wished Mr. Sheed had interposed himself less between his subject and his readers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of audio cassette versions of spy novels on Feb. 19 misstated the telephone number of Recorded Books, Inc. The number is 301-868- 7856.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
THE GLOOM AND DOOM IS OVERSTATED
description: MOBIL'S proposed acquisition of Superior Oil, in the wake of other recent announcements, has intensified the public discussion of oil company mergers. Much of the debate has dealt with the possibility that a move to fewer and larger companies would reduce competition and exploration and raise prices to consumers. But these consequences are unlikely in today's energy market. In some situations, mergers may offer benefits to companies and thus to their customers by increasing the efficiency of oil findings, production and marketing. Thus, at least part of today's debate should focus on whether or not a specific merger will achieve goals such as these.

title: NOW MOBIL ENTERS THE MERGER GAME
description: The fourth multibillion-dollar oil merger in recent weeks was proposed by the Mobil Corporation, when it offered to pay $5.7 billion for all shares of the Superior Oil Company. Before making the offer public, Mobil had secretly agreed to buy 22 percent of Superior from the founding Keck family and offered to pay $45 a share for the remaining 78 percent. The merger would keep Mobil firmly ensconced as the nation's No. 2 oil concern, but more important, it would add one billion barrels of oil and oil equivalents to Mobil's reserves. The purchase also seemed calculated to avoid the kind of antitrust problems Mobil encountered earlier when it tried to acquire Marathon Oil and Cities Service. Superior has no refineries or gasoline stations. The proposed merger , nevertheless, stirred the political waters even more in Washington, touching off moves in Congress to halt temporarily big oil mergers while the consequences of such combinations could be studied. Three key senators - two Democrats and a Republican - proposed legislation that would place a moratorium on the purchase, retroactive to Feb. 28, of any company with oil reserves of 100 million barrels or more. Such a level would include the nation's 50 largest oil companies and could affect both Socal's purchase of Gulf and Mobil's acquisition of Superior. Chances for passage seemed slim, however.

title: ON THE BOOK-PARTY CIRCUIT- SERVING TYPHOID MARY'S SOUP
description: Samuel G. Freedman is a reporter for The New York Times. HEN Simon & Schuster threw a party for Jacqueline Susann some years ago, one chair at every table remained vacant. The publishers weren't expecting Banquo, they wanted Miss Susann to have a seat at every stop on her conversational rounds. It is a telling story about the book party circuit, which exists largely for authors' self-esteem. With a few exceptions, a book party does not generate much in the way of sales or publicity. As for the food, the writer and eater Calvin Trillin says, ''The tastiness varies in inverse proportion to the stature of the writer. I think people are at least getting a little more self- conscious about giving guests a napkin with something awful on a cracker.''

The Leslie of the nonfiction book was a friend of Mrs. Rosenberg's adoptive daughter, Karin, and her second book, ''Being Adopted,'' prominently features Karin and two other adopted county youngsters.

title: International
description: An emergency airlift to the Sudan is being discussed by the United States and Egypt because of the bombing attack on the chief Sudanese city of Omdurman on Friday, Reagan Administration officials said. The airlift would provide military equipment to bolster the Sudan's defenses against Libya and Ethiopia. An Administration official said there was no doubt that Friday's attack was carried out by Libya. (Page 1, Column 4.) Ireland's most-wanted terrorist was captured after a 90-minute gun battle with 40 detectives at a cottage in County Clare where he had been hiding with three confederates. The arrest of Dominic McGlinchey, known as Mad Dog because of his ruthlessness, was hailed by James Prior, Britain's Secretary of State for Northern Ireland, as a major victory over terrorism. (1:1.)

title: SUFFOLK LEADS ALL U.S. COUNTIES IN THE USE OF WIRETAPS
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY has emerged as the leading user of court-sanctioned telephone wiretaps in the United States.

title:
Long Island Opinion;
WHY THE GOVERNMENT IS PRESSING THE 'BABY DOE' CASE
description: F EW issues are as difficult or as emotionally charged as the question of what medical measures ought to be taken to save the life of a newborn child who, irrespective of life-preserving medical treatment, is expected to be incurably handicapped in his or her future life.

title: Away From Voodooland
description: For the good of the country and the discomfort of Democrats, President Reagan has yielded and produced a second, less damaging Federal budget. He has agreed to cut back military spending and to accept a further raise in taxes, abandoning a resistance that threatened to throttle recovery both at home and abroad. If Mr. Reagan holds to the promise of his announcement in the White House Rose Garden Thursday, he has committed himself to a welcome and overdue change of course.

title: LOSS O OLD HOME TROUBLES RIVERHEAD

title: 'I'M NOT REPLACING RALPH SAMPSON'
description: HE didn't play basketball until he was 14 years old. He was born in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and his family moved to the Bronx when he was 7. In his leisure time during those intervening years, he preferred to swim and play volleyball and paint. But now Olden Polynice is the 6-foot-11-inch freshman center at the University of Virginia, the center who followed Ralph Sampson.

title: CONGRESS STUDIES THE URGE TO MERGE
description: Many authorities regard the current flurry of corporate mergers - including the Standard Oil Company of California's $13.2 billion bid for the Gulf Corporation - as part of a wave that began in the mid-1970's.

title: EUROPE ON THE BRINK
description: The anxious cried havoc so many times as the vision of integrating Europe sank into what is now called ''the swamp of Brussels'' that they were shrugged off. Optimism can become a pernicious, paralyzing habit too.

title: Corinna Gardner To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Cushman Gardner of Nyack, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Corinna Madeline Gardner, to Dr. John Thomas Barnard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Murray Barnard of Wichita Falls, Tex.

title: 1,500 LED TO SAFETY AS 5 IRT CARS DERAIL UNDER THE EAST RIVER
description: About 1,500 passengers on two subway trains were evacuated yesterday evening after 5 cars of a 10-car Brooklyn-bound IRT train jumped the tracks in a tunnel under the East River, according to the Transit Authority. Several injuries were reported.

title: HEALTH EXPERTS SAY CURRENT FLU SEASON MAY BE ABOUT OVER
description: A publication of the national Centers for Disease Control says the 1983-84 flu season, which brought widespread outbreaks but not many deaths, may be nearing its end.

title: SINGLE PARENT AND A CHILD'S PARTY
description: SANDI SAMUELS hadn't done her ''homework.'' The assignment had been to write a letter from her son telling her what he expected from his bar mitzvah; but instead of ''trying to get in touch with his feelings,'' as Wendy Baltaxe, director of singles activities at the Greater Five Towns Y.M.- Y.W.H.A. in Cedarhurst, had asked, Mrs. Samuels had merely jotted down a few phrases about ''my joyous occasion'' and ''the essence of being Jewish.''

title: EFFORT BEGINS TO CUT PORT'S LABOR COST
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has begun a legal battle to make the port more competitive by reducing the labor costs of handling container cargo.

title: AN INSURANCE COMMISSIONER'S LIABLILITIES
description: The heralded changes in New Jersey's automobile insurance system should all be in place by July 1, allowing motorists to save about $150 on their premiums. But even as officials were preparing the rules for trimming insurance policies - now among the highest, if not the highest, in the nation - the restructured system claimed its first victim.

title: ST. LOUIS SCAVENGING CURB CALLED OPPRESSIVE
description: This city wants to ban scavengers from picking through residential garbage for food and aluminum cans, but opponents have denounced the ban as an unfeeling slap at the poor and homeless who are trying to stay alive.

title: MOSCOW'S LINE IS STILL BUSY
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, the new Soviet leader, kept relations with Washington on hold last week. Meeting with Hans-Jochen Vogel, the West German opposition leader, Mr. Chernenko again said that arms control talks would have to wait until the United States removed ''obstacles,'' namely the Pershing 2 and cruise missiles, from Western Europe.

title: FOR HIM, REALTY IS A NOBLE CALLING
description: LONDON GERALD Cavendish Grosvenor spent the first part of March slogging around the muddy, frigid English countryside in the Territorial Army, Britain's version of the Army Reserves. It's the only two weeks in the year when the Duke of Westminster takes orders.

description: Neil McCarthy, the Weber State basketball coach, told his Wildcats that he wanted them ''to shoot good'' against Fordham Friday night in the National Invitation Tournament.

description: WITH the approach of a Scholastic Aptitude Test on May 5, parents and students have renewed their questions over the efficacy and worth of S.A.T. preparation courses, which seek to raise verbal and mathematical scores through a variety of independently conducted training sessions.

description: Democrats in the Assembly have delayed action on the repeal of a new state income tax on some Social Security benefits paid to some elderly New Yorkers.

description: Efren Herrera kicked a 34-yard field goal with seven seconds remaining today to give the Oklahoma Outlaws a 17-14 victory over the Chicago Blitz.

title: COLLEGE AND SCHOOLS BECOMING 'PARTNERS'
description: A NEW program at the State University of New York at Purchase will link the college with 11 county school districts in a partnership designed to provide academic courses and programs for students and conferences on major educational issues for school board members, administrators and teachers.
