description: Randy Franks scored 26 points tonight as St. Augustine's of Raleigh, N.C., defeated Sacred Heart, 107-92, in the N.C.A.A. Division II quarterfinals. St. Augustine's, the Eastern Regional champions, plays Kentucky Wesleyan in the semifinals Friday at the Springfield (Mass.)

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;
PLAN NEEDED FOR A DIVERSE STATE ECONOMY
description: FOR years now there has been a serious lack of adequate economic planning at the Federal and state levels that would alleviate the negative impact to companies and workers affected by contract cutbacks or cancellations, such as will occur at Pratt and Whitney and its subcontractors as a result of the ''Great Engine War'' with General Electric.

title: Westchester Opinion; ONE SUNNY DAY, TINKERBELL LEFT FOREVER
description: I HONESTLY believe that the most thrilling moment any 5-year-old boy can stand is to watch the Darling's nursery window fling open and see Peter Pan come soaring through. Every time I remember Sandy Duncan - or Mary Martin from my own impressionable childhood - my heart skips a beat, and I sigh over my own gravity-laden limbs. For sure, my son Adam's heart, as well as my nearly 4-year-old daughter's, soared, too.

title: STATE TRIES TO CONTROL WETLANDS PERMITS
description: IN 1979, a growing checklist of regulatory responsibilities pushed the State Department of Environmental Conservation into a reorganization. Under Robert F. Flacke, who was then Commissioner, the agency began consolidating administrative units, streamlining regulatory procedures and trimming duplication.

title: NEW PERSPECTIVE ON AFRICAN WILDLIFE
description: Several years ago when I first heard about hot-air balloon safaris over the game-filled plains of Kenya the idea struck me as being like a submarine cruise around Manhattan Island: interesting but what's the point? Still, having enjoyed game viewing from cars and lodges in the three years that I lived in Kenya, and having once spent a pleasant morning ballooning with a political candidate in New York, I decided on a recent return to Africa to book myself onto a safari balloon in the spirit of those who, like George Leigh Mallory (1886-1924), ascend things because they are there.

title: About Long Island
description: THE other day, I saw in an encyclopedia (I was looking for a fact - I don't usually browse through them) that Long Island is a fairly venerable piece of real estate, with its northern fork going back to the Pleistocene Era, when it was deposited there by the melting ice age. The southern fork is part of the Ronkonkoma Moraine, older even than the North Fork.

title: CRIME
description: About two years ago, Sara Paretsky attracted some attention with her first novel, ''Indemnity Only.'' Now comes DEADLOCK (Dial, $14.95), the second adventure of V. I. Warshawski, the woman private eye who operates out of Chicago. The title is a play on words that refers to the waterway locks through which boat traffic passes.

title: HART BACKERS TRYING TO SKIRT PUERTO RICO PRIMARY
description: Supporters of Senator Gary Hart have scheduled Democratic Party caucuses throughout Puerto Rico Sunday in an effort to pick delegates outside the party primary.

title:
GARDENING;
WHERE TO GO FOR INFORMATION
description: WHEN faced with a new season, many gardeners confess the feelings of inadequacy. The vast number of plants available, the complexities of correcting site problems and the headaches of defending plants against the perils of nature seem all too bewildering. There need be little reason for this concern, however, for there are many resources within one's own community.

title: GLENN DEPARTURE SAID TO AID HART
description: As Senator John Glenn formally gave up his quest for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination, some of his top strategists suggested that Senator Gary Hart was likely to benefit more from his departure from the race than Walter F. Mondale.

title: NEIGHBORLINESS SUDDENLY BREAKS OUT IN SOUTHERN AFRICA
description: South Africa's special brand of gunboat diplomacy is paying off. Last month, it reached a de facto cease-fire agreement with Angola that imposes severe constraints on the insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization, Pretoria's principal black adversary in South-West Africa. And last week, Prime Minister P. W. Botha traveled in regal style to the no man's land along the Mozambique border to sign a treaty of ''Non-Aggression and Good Neighborliness'' with President Samora Machel, once the pivotal supporter of the most prominent organization fighting apartheid, the African National Congress. In Africa's colonial history, the importance of the signing might be compared with Cecil Rhodes's acceptance of the surrender of Lobengula, King of the Matabeles, in 1888.

title: GAMBLERS' OFFENSE WILL TEST GENERALS
description: ''Every week it sure is different,'' said Jim LeClair, the inside linebacker for the Generals and the team's defensive leader. The 33-year-old LeClair, who came to the Generals and the United States Football League after 12 seasons with the Cincinnati Bengals, could hardly have said the same about the National Football League.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MARKET SLUMP TAKING ITS TOLL ON DEALERS
description: Some coin dealers seem to have weathered the lengthy market slump with little trouble, but others are experiencing major problems. For some, the financial illness has been terminal.

title: Ellen Wasch Is Betrothed
description: The engagement of Ellen Wasch to Allen W. Reedy has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sidney G. Wasch of East Hills, L.I., parents of the future bride.

title: No Headline
description: VERSES TO GO ABROAD Abroad is peculiar names above the shops. Strange, too, the cookery and the cops. The people Prattle with tongues there, they rattle Inscrutable money, and with foreign eyes Follow your foreign eccentricities.

title: KEY WEST DIALOGUE
description: Ann Beattie: Key West looks like a lurid postcard. The colors are very intense, and almost everywhere you look there is something scenic. I mean, you can go around Key West taking pictures in your head, because almost everything is perfect. You can't miss there. If there's a crack in the sidewalk, there's hibiscus growing in it. If you see an ugly empty lot, there's always the weird juxtaposition - a mansion directly adjoining it. There's really no harmony. If there's harmony there, it's in the air, it's not really in the way things physically relate to each other.

title: A SAMPLE OF 'NEW IDEAS'
description: Senator Gary Hart has cited various proposals as examples of his ''new ideas.'' Among them are these:

title: The Protection Of Drinking Water
description: ''The Right to a Drink of Water'' by Suffolk County Legislator Wayne Prospect (Opinion Page, Feb. 19) touched on only one aspect of protecting our water supply, which is to preserve the last 100,000 acres of pine barrens in eastern Long Island.

title:
ANTIQUES;
TREND TO ELEGANCE AT A 'MINI-MUSEUM' IN SHREWSURY
description: SHREWSBURY A VISIT to International Galleries on Newman Springs Road here is a bit like visiting a mini-museum. A 2,000- year-old Etruscan amphora, a 14th- century Austrian woodcarving of a Madonna and Child and a three-foot- high, 1599 bronze urn in the Mannerist art style share space with American, English, Dutch, Venetian and French furnishings from the 16th to the 20th centuries.

title: THE REGION
description: Change of Venue For a Prison

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported a new development with its radio station that many a commercial station might have envied: Its audience was growing rapidly. The F.B.I.'s listeners, however, were criminals and others who had bought FM scanners and were tuning in the bureau's station, KGB-770, to keep abreast of agents' movements.

title: No Headline
description: March 18, 1984Fiction 112 THE AQUITAINE PROGRESSION, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $17.95.) A lawyer finds himself caught in a conspiracy to take over the world. 2220 PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery.

title: J.PatrickKellyJr. Plans to Be Wed ToMaureenKelly
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John H. Kelly of North Caldwell and Spring Lake, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter Maureen Kelly to J. Patrick Kelly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelly of Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Susan Frances Wiener Marries Richard Golub
description: Susan Frances Wiener, a daughter of Lolie Wiener of West Trenton, N.J., and the late Samuel Wiener, was married yesterday to Richard William Golub, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Golub of the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre.

title: Boat Wrecked, Race Off
description: The 130th boat race between Oxford and Cambridge was postponed for 24 hours today after an accident had wrecked the Cambridge boat. Less than 20 minutes before the start at Putney on the Thames, the Cambridge crew, on a practice run, smashed into the mooring rope of a stationary tug.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Fewer young musicians have been making their debuts this season than ever before, partly perhaps because the debut itself is becoming less important. More careers are taking shape through the winning of competitions, establishing chamber groups and specializing in a particular repertory. Last week, for example, each artist reviewed was already a seasoned professional who had chosen one of these routes.

title: 'SPINAL TAP' DRAWS LAUGHTER FROM ROCK
description: film pioneered by D. A. Pennebaker in ''Don't Look

title: DANCE: 2 RETHORST QUARTETS
description: Susan Rethorst choreographed the two dances for four women that were presented Friday night in the Danspace of St. Mark's Church, and she choreographed them very well. Indeed, she choreographed them so well that they appeared to be totally spontaneous events. Things happened in them. Quite intricate things. But one could never be sure why they did, or what might happen next.

title: EVE QUELER UNEARTHS THE OFFBEAT
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music.

title: SOUTH KOREA TAKES SOME OF THE WRAPS OFF ITS CAMPUSES
description: Since his military takeover of the South Korean Government four years ago, President Chun Doo Hwan has endured a civil uprising that his soldiers suppressed with considerable loss of life, financial scandals touching his wife's family, hundreds of student protests and an assassination bombing in Burma that killed some of his closest aides. Anyone who could survive all that might be reasonably expected to prevail through anything.

title: THE REGION
description: House Rules for The Homeless

title: AGING CAPE MAY LIGHTHOUSE IS SYMBOL OF THE PAST
description: Every night, when darkness descends on this small seaside community at the southern tip of New Jersey, the light comes on in the old lighthouse and stays on until daybreak - a fact of life here for 125 years.

title: Tibetan Exiles Send Protest To Chinese Leader and U.N.
description: More than 50,000 Tibetan exiles have sent letters to Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China and to the United Nations demanding the withdrawal of Chinese troops from their Himalayan homeland, a spokesman for their leader, the Dalai Lama, says.

title: A COMPETITION OF COLORS FOR INTERNATIONAL, FESTIVE 'LOOK' AT THE GAMES
description: Forget about red, white and blue bunting, banners or balloons for the 1984 Summer Olympic Games in Los Angeles. Think pink. Hot pink.

title: HOW 'THE SECOND MRS. TANQUERAY' LAUNCHED 'MRS. PAT'
description: A major star of early 20th-century theater was Beatrice Rose Stella Tanner, billed professionally as Mrs. Patrick Campbell. Stella, or Mrs. Pat as she also came to be known, appeared in a succession of hits and flops ranging from Shakespeare's ''Romeo and Juliet'' to Shaw's ''Pygmalion.'' Shaw's choice of Mrs. Campbell for the part of the cockney charmer Eliza Doolittle reflected their passionate but platonic relationship, recorded in an exchange of letters that stretched over 30 years. The flamboyant actress is the subject of ''Mrs. Pat,'' a biography by Margot Peters, newly published by Alfred A. Knopf. In the following excerpt, as the still-unknown Stella is recovering from illness, the playwright Arthur Wing Pinero begins his search for the right actress to star in his daring new drama, ''The Second Mrs. Tanqueray.''

title: Marriage in May For Miss Shevell
description: The engagement of Nancy Ellen Shevell and Bruce Arthur Blakeman has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Myron P. Shevell of Verona, N.J., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Blakeman of Valley Stream, L.I., and Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Tracy Caulkins Takes 200-Yard Butterfly Title
description: Tracy Caulkins of Florida set a National Collegiate Athletic Association and meet record today and claimed her 12th N.C.A.A. career title by winning the 200-yard butterfly at the Division I women's swimming and diving championships.

title: BOYER REPORT GETS RAVES AND CAVEATS
description: AMID the battle over an alternative licensing route for New Jersey teachers comes a report on the subject that has received high marks from normally opposing camps.

title: U.S. AND EGYPTIANS CONSIDER AIRLIFT OF ARMS TO SUDAN
description: The United States and Egypt are considering an emergency airlift of military equipment to the Sudan because of a bombing attack on Omdurman, the Sudan's main city, on Friday, Administration officials said today.

description: Bomb explosions were reported in six Chilean cities overnight, including one that blacked out a large part of the capital.

title: LISTEN! IS THAT HREALLY THE VOICE OF THE MET MUSEUM?
description: Balthus has created a unique and dreamlike world of stillness and light, of fantasy, tension and ambiguity,'' the magisterial voice informs me. I turn up the volume on my Acoustiguide, the better to concentrate on the rich tones - a product of France, Harvard and a keen ear for stage diction - of Philippe de Montebello, the Metropolitan Museum's director. He is guiding me on a taped tour of the Met's current show, a retrospective of the French painter Balthus (pronounced Bal-toos). And behind his mellifluous delivery I can sense the authoritative voice of the mighty Metropolitan itself, graciously undertaking to repair my esthetic deficiences. Dutifully, I make tracks for the first Balthus gallery.

title: NOT A NICE LOT
description: Lawrence Stone is a professor of history at Princeton University. His most recent books are ''The Past and the Present'' and the forthcoming ''An Open Elite? England 1540-1880,'' written in collaboration with Jeanne C. Fawtier Stone. THE HISTORY MEN

title: PHILIPPINE ELECTION ALREADY STIRRING DISPUTES
description: Although the campaign for the May parliamentary elections is scheduled to begin next Saturday, the Government and its political foes are already skirmishing in the battle for votes.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Everett J. Warner was not known to be a churchgoer in his 94 years on earth. But when the Greenport, L.I., paint store proprietor died in the spring of 1983, he left all his worldly goods - $2 million plus - to six churches and a synagogue in the village.

title: CAPITALS CLOSE IN, EDGING ISLANDERS
description: The Washington Capitals came into Nassau Coliseum tonight talking about learning how to play under pressure. They left with a pressure- filled 2-1 victory over the Islanders that they say they will remember in the playoffs.

description: SHOREHAM, the reactor built to cut electric rates on Long Island but now threatening to bankrupt its builder, has added a new contradiction to its long history.

title: HEADLINERS
description: A Would-Be Adviser According to his uncle, David A. Mahonski often talked about going ''to see the President and straighten him out.'' It seems he may have intended to do it with a sawed-off shotgun. Mr. Mahonski had the recently purchased weapon with him last week when White House guards approached him on the sidewalk outside the Presidential residence.

title: BIG IRANIAN OFFENSIVE IS THOUGHT TO HAVE STARTED
description: The military high command announced today that Iranian forces were about to begin a major offensive. An informed Iraqi source said the announcement meant the offensive was under way.

title: RESEARCHER SEEKS MORE DATA ON MANAGEING DELAWARE BAY
description: A professor who has led a three-year study of Delaware Bay says that even though the bay is ''certainly not pristine,'' it is getting cleaner and can handle well-planned industrial growth.

title: WHY REAGAN IS A FREE-TRADE VILLAIN
description: WHEN the 98th Congress came to Washington last year, many feared it would enact major new trade restrictions. It has n't yet. And faced with a tight election-year timetable, it seems unlikely to do so in 1984 either.

CONNECTICUT OPINION;
MIDDLE AGE: A PERIOD OF GROWTH, NOT DEBILITATION
description: WHEN I was growing up, my mother told me when I was misbehaving that ''One day you will have children just like you.''

Opinion;
DISCORD? HAMONY? WE'RE ALL
description: EARS

title: HART TAPS A GENERATION OF YOUNG PROFESSIONALS
description: Philip Hall grew up in a small Texas town, then went off to college and law school. The other night he stood in the lobby of a fancy Chicago hotel and explained why he was attending a fund-raising event for Senator Gary Hart.

title: RECORD SHOWS HART FOCUSING ON ARMS, ENERGY AND DEFICIT
description: Within three months after becoming a Senator in 1975, Gary Hart parted company with most of his Democratic colleagues and voted against a proposal to stimulate the economy by granting a 10 percent rebate of individual income taxes.

title: AN ENDURING SPEAKER IDEA TAKES A CUE FROM CONCERTS
description: In an industry which lives by compulsive innovation,

title:
Dining Out;
FILLING A NEED ON NORTHWEST SHORE
description: PURPLE as a plumb, Dudley's glows in a residential neighborhood dotted with charming old houses, some of them dating from 1742. It is one of those establishments that allots equal time and space to drinking and dining; and judging from the packed parking lot and the camaraderie at the bar, it may be on to something. The chumminess continues, unfortunately, in the dining room where closely spaced tables make private conversation difficult. And seating becomes even tighter as places for three are set at tables meant for two, an ungracious arrangement at those times when tables for four remain empty.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: FASHION AS ART IN MILAN
description: Milan,Italy-If you can tell a book by its cover, you can tell an Italian city by its telephone book. Milan's pictures a sculpture (a modern horse and rider) by Marino Marini. Indeed, the Milanese see themselves as an extremely cultured lot and it was obvious this week that fashion, for them, is an art.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Hawkins
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Hyde Hawkins of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Barrett Hawkins to Gaye Hakan Sokmensuer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Adil Sokmensuer of Palm Beach, Fla. The wedding is to be in September.

title: IRAN UNDER KHOMEINI --
description: Terence Smith seems to suggest that, while the clerics will continue to play a central role in Iran, the long-term survival of the Islamic regime is in doubt. In discussing the regime and its prospects, a comparison might be useful.

title:
Careful Shopper;
SHAMROCKS AND MORE, ALL YEAR ROUND
description: Shamrocks and More All Year Round Kelly's International Gifts in White Plains provides shopping options for those who believe in ''the wearin' of the green'' all 365 days, not just for St. Patrick's Day. The shop is tucked under J. E. Kelly Opticians, with direct entry from the Waller Avenue parking lot at the corner of Maple Avenue - the window with the shamrock decoration ($8.50).

title: Guest Observer; Outasight Outerwear
description: My 16-year-old daughter, Leah, came in from the bitter cold recently, protected by the kind of denim jacket Georgia farmers wear in August.

title: ONB READING 300 AMERICAN NOVELS
description: This is, in essence, a defense of a judging bias. The occasion is this year's PEN/ Faulkner Awards, which I, along with fellow novelists Mary Gordon and David Bradley, am in the process of selecting. The pool is some 250-300 new books of American fiction, all published in 1983. It is our charge to choose five or six books of particular distinction, with a first prize for one of them. An impossible task of course and, at root, perhaps a political one.

title: PROSECTUTION PLANS TO WRAP UP TAX ISSUES IN TRIAL OF FEDERAL JUDGE
description: The prosecution in the trial of Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne is expected to complete its tax case Monday and turn to the evidence offered to support the charge that the judge took bribes.

title: GREECE UNDER PAPANDREOU: LEFTIST BUT IN WESTERN CAMP
description: After 40 years of almost continuous right-wing domination, Greece has lurched sharply to the left under Andreas Papandreou and his Socialist party that came to power in 1981.

title: THE DANCE: 'SWEET HOLMES'
description: THE Theater of the Riverside Church's admirable Choreo Showcases have provided new choreographers with a place to present their dances and a public to view them. Thursday, the theater opened its final showcase of the season. The results were mixed, but surprisingly adventurous.

title: High School Marks Set
description: Dennis Mitchell and Wenda Vereen, two New Jersey high school sprinters, set national 300-meter dash records today in the Pathmark National Scholastic Classic at Princeton University's Jadwin Gym.

title: BELLI SAYS LAW FIRM THRIVES DESPITE FIGHTS
description: Melvin Belli's job is suing people, but these days, many of the people he is suing are lawyers who used to work for him - and the suits tend to be ugly squabbles over who stole whose clients, complete with charges of incompetence, slander and fraud.

title: 'JOE'S BOYS' HONOR AN UNFORGETTABLE COACH
description: Not far from the sandlot baseball diamonds where Joseph Austin taught them how to play - and, they say, how to live - ''Joe's Boys'' and their neighbors jammed a Queens playground yesterday to wish the coach a happy 80th birthday.

title: Daughter in Brooklyn Is Held In Killing of Father With an Ax
description: A Brooklyn man was killed Saturday when his daughter struck him with an ax, the police said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: HUSSEIN REBUKES U.S. ON ARMS DEAL
description: King Hussein of Jordan said today that his country needed American weapons and military aid ''very badly,'' but that he would search for arms elsewhere if the terms of the transfers were demeaning to his country.

title: Kasler Executive Quits; Company Cites Conflicts
description: L. Dan Spencer has resigned as president, chief operating officer and a director of the Kasler Corporation, a concrete pourer and construction company based in San Bernardino, Calif. Mr. Spencer's predecessor had similarly resigned five months ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1984
description: International

title: Oceanliners and the Cargo Islanders
description: After barely 10 years of full operation, New York City's passenger terminal on the Hudson is attracting too few ships to run year around. All of us who welcomed the terminal with such enthusiasm have to acknowledge now that it was a mistake, saddling the city with more than $3 million a year in debt service and no permanent jobs to show for the money. Just about the only lasting gain is the new demonstration that economic ''development'' has to be justifiable by likely economic results.

title: TIMES SQ. PLAN GETTING WARY PUBLIC APPROVAL
description: Civic and community leaders have reacted to the $1.6 billion plan to rebuild Times Square with general support, but it has often been coupled with sharp questioning or criticism of some aspects of the proposal.

title: Charley Lau Dead, Called One of Best Batting Instructors
description: Charley Lau, the batting coach of the Chicago White Sox who was considered one of the finest batting instructors in the major leagues, died today of cancer of the colon at his home. He was 50 years old.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Wins Florida Tourney
description: Chris Evert Lloyd took only 47 minutes to beat Bonnie Gadusek, 6-0, 6-1, today for the championship of the $150,000 Virginia Slims of Florida tournament.

title: RECORD PRIZE FOR QUEENS LOTTO TICKET
description: Sometime between 8 o'clock Thursday morning and 8 o'clock Saturday night, someone bought a Lotto ticket somewhere in Queens that will make its owner the winner of the largest unshared lottery prize ever won in the United States. That much is definite, but little else is.

title: BUYING VS. EXPLORING FOR OIL
description: It has become the pat explanation for why Texaco is buying Getty, why Standard of California is swallowing Gulf and why Mobil is bidding for Superior - oil is cheaper to buy on Wall Street than to explore and drill for.

title: CAPITALS LOSE TO BLUES, 5-3
description: A short-handed goal by Brian Sutter at 6 minutes 30 seconds of the third period lifted the St. Louis Blues to a 5-3 victory over the Washington Capitals tonight.

title: Zurbriggen Wins World Skiing Title
description: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland secured the overall World Ski Cup title today by taking 13th place in a slalom that was won by Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg.

title: DANCE: MANY STYLES BY AMERICAN BALLET II
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER II made its only New York-area appearance of the season on Saturday and filled Queens College's Colden Center for the Performing Arts in Flushing with youthful high spirits and some good dancing. The company, a young touring wing for American Ballet Theater, performed ballets in an unusually wide range of styles, from classics by Petipa and Bournonville to a familiar crowd-pleaser and a new ballet.

title: Jersey to Check Lottery Procedure
description: Lottery officials said today that they planned to check their procedures after the same winning number came up two days in a row in the Pick-It game.

title: Informer's Call Reported Before Suspect's Slaying
description: An unidentified man called the authorities Friday and tried to warn them that someone might try to harm a kidnapping suspect minutes before the suspect was fatally shot by the father of the kidnapping victim, according to a sheriff's deputy.

title: SUITS IN THE SPRING FORECAST
description: The approach of spring, the poets notwithstanding, is signaled in the city not by robins but by softly tailored, Chanel-like suits.

title: No Headline
description: May Lisa Ross Marries

title: DESPITE CEASE-FIRE, FIGHTING STILL RACKS BEIRUT
description: Moslem militiamen and loyalist Lebanese Army soldiers exchanged machine- gun, rocket and mortar fire today along the Green Line dividing Moslem and Christian parts of Beirut.

title: CHAMBER: ASPEN WIND
description: THE ASPEN WIND QUINTET is one of the best ensembles of its kind, the five young musicians playing now with the smooth consistency of a grand organ, now with the bumptious charm of a village band. Its Saturday afternoon concert at Carnegie Recital Hall was devoted entirely to music of the 20th century.

title: SIGNS OF RESTRAINT BY FED AWAITED
description: Concerns about the rapid pace of economic expansion and a renewal of inflationary pressures are likely to continue to dominate both the mood of the credit markets and trading activity as participants await signs from the Federal Reserve that it has acted to bring growth rates down to more sustainable levels.

title: Storm From the Rockies Wreaks Havoc in Plains By The Associated Press
description: A blizzard that left up to 2 feet of snow in Utah blew out of the Rockies into the Plains yesterday, closing highways with windblown snow.

title: ;  Ally & Gargano Net
description: Ally & Gargano, which only recently went public, wants its shareholders to know a certain unpleasant fact in advance - 1984 fiscal year earnings will be lower than 1983's. So without being overly specific it is announcing that two of its ''large'' clients have surprised the agency by cutting back on their spending, while a third has shifted its spending from this fiscal year ending June 30, to next.

title: UNHAPPINESS WITH ANTITRUST POLICY
description: It seems that no one is happy with antitrust policy. The Justice Department's opposition to the proposed merger of the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation is being assailed as inflexible and niggardly. At the same time, a block east on Constitution Avenue in Washington, the Federal Trade Commission is drawing fire for failing to act more vigorously to block the spate of oil mergers.

title: FIRST STEP TAKEN BY JUSTICE DEPT. ON MEESE INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department has opened an investigation into financial dealings of Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, the White House said tonight. Mr. Meese said he had asked for a postponement of further Senate hearings on his nomination to be Attorney General.

title: U.S. SETS TRADE CURB FOR DIGITAL
description: The Commerce Department has quietly imposed major restrictions on the Digital Equipment Corporation to control the export of its computers, several months after one of the company's most sophisticated machines was seized en route to the Soviet Union.

title: SENATE'S REAL ESTATE TAX BLOW
description: Tax legislation approved last week by the Senate Finance Committee marks a potentially major setback for the real-estate industry by threatening to slash the value of property as an investment, analysts and Capitol aides agreed on the weekend.

title: Team to Examine Teen-Age Suicides
description: A series of teen-age suicides in the northern suburbs of New York has led to a four-year, $750,000 study by a Columbia University psychiatric team.

title: FULLY TACKLE THE DEFICITS
description: The alarms about uncontrolled deficit spending have become familiar if not tiresome. Deficits keep interest rates high. Deficits are potentially inflationary. Deficits compete with investment. Deficits reduce our industrial competitiveness by making the dollar more expensive to foreign customers.

title: KEY SECTIONS FROM CHICAGO DEBATE AMONG THREE DEMOCRATS
description: Following are key sections of a transcript of a debate at the Westin Hotel in Chicago among three Democratic candidates for the Presidential nomination, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of the C-Span network.

title: Yankees Are Attentive
description: Agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Drug Enforcement Administration gave their annual spring training lecture to the Yankees on Friday, and the response among the players was far different than in years past.

title: TEMPLE U. IS REACHING OUT TO RENEW COMMUNITY
description: As Marjorie Farmer sat in an unaccustomed place, behind a student's table at Temple University, the glitter in her eyes and the gleam of her smile seemed bright enough to light the classroom.

title: Oxford Rows to a Record
description: Oxford outrowed the Cambridge crew in record time today, scoring a ninth straight victory in the 130th race between the two English universities on the River Thames.

title: PECHINEY COUNTING ON QUEBEC PLANT
description: The non-Communist world's fourth-largest aluminum producer, buffeted by a string of heavy losses, is trying to turn itself around.

title: Jim Brown's Best Sport
description: MANHASSET, L.I.

title: MEXICAN BORDER PLANTS BEGINING TO HIRE MEN
description: After years of being a nearly all-female preserve, Mexico's border assembly plants have begun to employ men.

title: IS THERE NO DECENCY?
description: Sometimes the character of a Government - its values, its sense of decency - is exposed by a single small episode. That has just happened to the Reagan Administration.

title: Marcie B. Schneider Weds Fellow Doctor
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday Dr. Marcie Beth Schneider, a first-year resident in the Jacobi-Montefiore pediatric program, was married to Dr. Michael S. Ader, a fellow in gastroenterology at the Manhattan Veterans Hospital. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony.

title: Back to Baseball Basics
description: Given baseball's penchant for celebrating its own minutiae, it should only be a matter of time before the original disk holding the Oakland A's complete 1982 and 1983 computerized statistics is enshrined at Cooperstown alongside, say, Babe Ruth's bat or Willie Mays's glove.

title: How Will Women Spend the Sixpence?
description: There was a time when a woman's vote was thought of, if at all, as a corollary to her husband's or father's. Now the female vote is assiduously courted, analyzed and construed as monolithic or dismissed as a myth.

title: No Headline
description: Three Children Dead After Fire in Camden

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blocker Energy Corp., Houston, has promoted James H. Morris to president and chief operating officer.

title: Pennzoil Outlay
description: The Pennzoil Company said it expects its 1984 capital spending to total $390 million, up from $355 million last year.

title: Angola's Leader Meets With Castro on Africa
description: President Fidel Castro and President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola have begun talks here with discussions focusing on southern Africa, the Cuban press agency reported today.

title: A Foreign Flavor
description: A United States-Soviet trade

title: A Buick Hubcap-Deep In City's Bureaucracy
description: Hard on the heels of the Park Avenue delicatessen imbroglio comes a curiousity of a different sort - a white-and-gray Buick Regal that has been abandoned for at least 10 days at the corner of 61st Street and Park in a traffic lane, a car's width from the curb.

title: GEORGETOWN AND DEPAUL ADVANCE
description: When the final buzzer sounded, long after the outcome of their game had been in doubt, the basketball players from DePaul headed to where their coach had been working. The players were soon around Ray Meyer. There were so many arms wrapped so tightly round so many shoulders that there did not seem to be much room for a 70-year-old coach to breathe a sigh of relief.

title: 2,000 British Policemen Sent Into Coalfields
description: About 2,000 police officers were moved into one of Britain's biggest coalfields today to prevent clashes between striking and working miners.

title: WHALERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders are smart and successful and with four Stanley Cups, they have shown how to tie up opposing players who dare wander in front of their net.

title: MANY HART AIDES DATE FROM MCGOVERN PERIOD
description: In the last several years, as President Reagan consolidated his hold on the capital and as the 1984 election neared, a disparate group of Washington insiders, political strategists and public opinion specialists has been drifting into the orbit of Senator Gary Hart.

title: FACTS AND DOCUMENTS ON EUROPEAN JEWRY
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFENSE TO BEGIN IN KLAN-NAZI TRIAL
description: -SALEM, N.C., March 18 - Defense testimony is to begin Monday in the Federal trial of six Ku Klux Klansmen and three American Nazi Party members accused of violating the civil rights of five Communist Workers Party members killed in a gun battle in Greensboro, N.C., in 1979.

title: IN FOOD IRRADIATION, THE BENEFITS PREVAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Famed Voices Join for One Cause
description: Frank Sinatra is a hard act to follow. So is Luciano Pavarotti. So is Diana Ross. Ditto Montserrat Caballe.

title: BRAZIL SAYS SANCTIONS IMPERIL TRADE
description: Brazil is complaining that, while under pressure from creditors to increase its trade surplus, its export drive is being undermined by new protectionist measures.

title: PITT, VA. TECH ADVANCE
description: George Allen and Billy Culbertson sank six free throws in the last three minutes today to lead Pittsburgh (18-12) to a 66-63 victory over Florida State in the first game of a National Invitation Tournament doubleheader.

title: GAMBLERS TO GENERALS, 32-25
description: Jim Kelly, the Houston Gamblers' rookie quarterback, showed the Generals' veterans a thing or two about what to do with a football today. Playing only his fourth game as a professional, Kelly led the Gamblers to a victory that was more decisive than the final score, 32-25.

title: DEBT ACCORD SOUGHT
description: The Government of Raul Alfonsin, which restored democracy after eight years of a repressive military dictatorship, is struggling to pull Argentina back from the brink of financial collapse.

title: VIRGINIA, SYRACUSE MOVE ON
description: Each of the first three games here in the first and second rounds of the National Collegiate Athletic Association East Regional were decided by plays in the final moments. So anticipation was high for yet another wrenching finale in the last contest, featuring Syracuse and its mercurial guard, Dwayne (Pearl) Washington.

title: Futures/Options; Big Growth in Orders Paralyzing Trading Pits
description: WHEN the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's computer system ''crashed'' last Friday, it not only handcuffed traders using the world's second-biggest futures market for several hours, but to many in the industry it served as a reminder of the paralysis that is engulfing the current system of trading in these markets.

title: KUHN TO PLAY ROLE IN BELCHER DISPUTE
description: The Tim Belcher case is not dead and neither is the ongoing confrontation between Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and the Yankees.

title: Jonathan Band Is Wed To Leesa Shawn Fields
description: Leesa Shawn Fields, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Fields of Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Jonathan Band, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Band of Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi David Gordis performed the ceremony at the Calvert Collection, an art gallery in Washington.

title: STARS OF WORLD IN JERSEY MEET
description: BEFORE a recent road race in Portland, Ore., Bill Rodgers, Mike Musyoki, Jon Sinclair and Pat Porter gave a clinic. When it ended, eager listeners surrounded their table and collected autographs from Rodgers, a four-time winner of the New York City and Boston marathons, and Musyoki and Sinclair, two of the most successful road racers.

title: Mrs. Kassebaum Uses '36 Slogan for '84 Race
description: Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, wearing a ''deeds not deficits'' button that was used in her father's 1936 Presidential campaign, said Saturday that she would seek re-election to fight Government deficits and push for arms control.

title: Case-Hoyt Sale
description: Bell Canada Enterprises Inc. said its Ronalds-Federated Ltd. unit would acquire the Case-Hoyt Corporation of Rochester. Terms were not disclosed.

title: BURIAL IS LONG DELAYED FOR NAMELESS WOMAN
description: It began as the story of a woman waiting for a resting place. No one could say what her name was in life, and so in death she was caught between those who insist on accurate record-keeping, and those who believe that even the nameless people who sleep in the streets are entitled to a decent burial.

title: IRISH QUICKLY HAND TERRORIST TO BRITISH
description: The Irish police today extradited Dublin's most-wanted terrorist, captured Saturday after a shootout with police, to British authorities in Northern Ireland.

title: Bomb Scare Ends Rotterdam Final
description: A bomb scare forced the men's singles final between Ivan Lendl and Jimmy Connors to be called off here at a $250,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: Lissa Burger Marries Bryan Joel Holzberg
description: Lissa Burger, the daughter of Abbie Swyer Burger of Great Neck, L.I., and Eugene Burger of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Bryan Joel Holzberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin M. Holzberg of Babylon, L.I. Rabbi Richard Smith performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Hebrew Congregation.

title: B. C. Beaten, 7-6
description: Newell Brown scored a goal and added three assists to lead Michigan State to a 7-6 victory tonight over Boston College in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I hockey quarterfinals.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 19, 1984: MONDAY Horizon Bancorp Sierra Pac Pwr TUESDAY CPC Intl Joy Mfg Fedl Paper Board Pueblo Intl Firestone Tire & Rub Upjohn Co Hi-Shear Indus

title: SENATOR ASSAILS STATE PANEL IN DEATH OF A PRISON INMATE
description: The State Correction Commission was accused yesterday by a state senator of having ''whitewashed'' the death of a state prison inmate.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: PARISIAN PAST There is an aura of elegance long gone in the round, columned and marbled lobby of the mansion that the French Cultural Services, the arts arm of the French Government, calls home at 972 Fifth Avenue (570-4400). This feeling is considerably enhanced by the current exhibition that has turned the mansion's elaborate entranceway into an ad hoc gallery.

title: 'KATE & ALLIE,' ABOUT 2 DIVORCED WOMEN, ON CBS
description: TAKE two divorced New York City women, add three children between them, move them all into the same apartment, and you have the basic situation devised for ''Kate & Allie,'' a weekly series having its premiere on CBS tonight at 9.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 19, 1984 International
description: The U.S. dispatched two Awacs to Egypt to bolster air defenses in the Sudan against a repetition of last Friday's air raid on the city of Omdurman. Administration officials said the dispatch of the surveillance planes, which was carried out in secrecy, was authorized by President Reagan after a joint request was received from the Egyptians and the Sudanese, who have a defense treaty. American officials said that Friday's attack was carried out by Libya. (Page A1, Column 1.) Argentina's economic crisis is unprecedented, according to its Under Secretary of Defense, Horatio Jaunarena. He and other members of the Government of President Raul Alfonsin are struggling to pull the country back from the brink of collapse. The new Government, which restored democracy after eight years of military dictatorship, also faces opposition from pro-military Peronist unions. (A1:2.)

title: GEORGETOWN AND DEPAUL ADVANCE
description: Patrick Ewing tipped in a missed foul shot with 51 seconds left, and Michael Jackson added a free throw with 8 seconds remaining to help give Georgetown a 37-36 victory over Southern Methodist today in an N.C.A.A. West Regional game.

title: RIGHT SCORES A SOCCER COUP IN EL SALVADOR
description: A squad from the right-wing Nationalist Republican Alliance faced down a group of 11 purported Communists today - in a soccer match staged by the party as a metaphor for El Salvador's election campaign. The rightists won.

title: STAR COLTS LOSE SOME GLITTER
description: With 47 days to go until the Kentucky Derby, whispers of betrayal are starting to rise from race-track grandstands around the country, in what is becoming as much a ritual as the Derby itself.

title: ILLINOIS DEBATE PROVES SPIRITED FOR DEMOCRATS
description: In a debate here tonight, Walter F. Mondale and Gary Hart clashed repeatedly over Mr. Hart's ''new ideas'' campaign theme and over the local issues that have divided this city's Democrats along racial lines.

title: ; Sylvia Syms Sings Johnny Mercer's Work
description: One of the difficulties faced by a singer who is putting together a program of Johnny Mercer's songs is the fact that so many of them are well known that it is difficult to avoid those that listeners may have heard too often. Sylvia Syms, who is singing a Mercer program at the Cafe Carlyle through Saturday, manages to hit representative high spots of his songwriting career along with a sampling of the variety of songs that he wrote, from the sassy ''Goody Goody'' to the self-deprecatory ''I'm an Old Cowhand,'' the shimmering ''Skylark'' and the sensuous ''Old Black Magic.''

title: LOYALTY IS TESTED IN A CHICAGO WARD
description: R. SHIPP

title: PRICE OF ROAD REPAIRS: SWELLING TRAFFIC JAMS
description: As New York City rebuilds its aging bridges, tunnels and roadways, motorists will be confronted over the next few years with more detours and traffic jams than they have ever seen, traffic officials say.

title: SENATOR PERCY TAKES COMPETITION SERIOUSLY
description: Six years ago when he was running for his third term, Senator Charles H. Percy's aides concede, he was overconfident and did not take seriously his Democratic opponent, Alex Seith.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MONTE CASSINO. By David Hapgood and David Richardson. 269 pages. Illustrated. Congdon & Weed. $17.95.

title: Avigaition Wins Santa Anita Race
description: Avigaition, ridden by Bill Shoemaker, rallied on the final turn to win the accident-marred $156,000 Santa Ana Handicap by 2 3/4 lengths from Pride of Rosewood at Santa Anita.

title: INCREASE IN MUSICALES BENEFITS PLAYERS
description: NEITHER Carnegie nor Avery Fisher Hall is feeling any threat, but there seems to be a growing interest in town for musical performances in private homes.

title: Denis Vaughan Leads The Juilliard Orchestra
description: New York's firsthand knowledge of Denis Vaughan began last season with his appearance at the Juilliard Opera Center; but only Friday night did the Australian conductor get around to making his United States debut in the symphonic repertory. This concert with the Juilliard Orchestra at Alice Tully Hall made an impressive start to what one hopes will become a busy career in this country.

title: WARNER-MURDOCH DEAL CRITICIZED
description: A day after Warner Communications bought back all of Rupert Murdoch's interest in the entertainment conglomerate, ending his takeover campaign, critics of the deal described it as a boon to everyone except Warner's small stockholders.

title: Deficit Accord Seen by Regan
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan has predicted that the booming United States economy will begin to slow in the months ahead and that Congress will approve a plan to reduce the budget deficit. At a stopover Saturday on his way to China, Mr. Regan said current interest rates made it highly unlikely that the economy could continue to expand at its present pace.

title: The U.N. Today March 19, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 'CONSTITUTION' PREVIEW STUDIES WAR POWERS ACT
description: ''THE CONSTITUTION: THAT DELICATE BALANCE,'' a public-television series that will be presented in the fall, is being shown in preview tonight. There is no compelling reason why a fall series should be previewed now except, presumably, that the segment being shown is so timely. It explores the War Powers Act, trying to answer an important Constitutional question. Can a President commit troops without the permission of Congress? This worthwhile program will be seen on Channels 13 and 49 at 10 P.M.

title: COMMON MARKET SHOWDOWN TODAY
description: President Francois Mitterrand launched a series of diplomatic initiatives over the weekend in what aides described as an 11th- hour attempt to prevent summit talks that open here Monday between leaders of the Common Market countries from breaking down in another disagreement.

title: SHORT-TERM GAINS FOR INDIA ECONOMY
description: There is an axiom here that as the monsoon goes, so, in large measure, goes India's economy. In a country where most land remains unirrigated and agriculture is the biggest sector of the economy, a short, weak monsoon can start a recession.

title: KOCH TO ENDORSE MONDALE OVER HART, CITY AIDE SAYS
description: -ranking New York Democratic politicians who has not endorsed Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, is expected to endorse Mr. Mondale today, according to a senior City Hall aide.

title: On the Record ; ; Mondale's Foreign Policy
description: From remarks by Walter F. Mondale March 14 to the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations.

title: KOCH WINS PLAYOFF AFTER A 63
description: Gary Koch today became the first player to win two PGA Tour tournaments this year when he birdied the second hole of a sudden-death playoff to beat a former Walker Cup teammate, George Burns, for the $72,000 first prize in Arnold Palmer's $400,000 Bay Hill Classic.

title: AMERICA'S CONSTRICTED 'VOICE'
description: The large Voice of America transmitting station on the island of Rhodes, Greece, is assisted these days by excellent satellite relay, and it renders its broadcasts clear and strong. This is unfortunate, for in the last three years the content of its English-language broadcasts has become so blatantly self-serving of Reagan Administration policies that in Greece it is no more credible - and perhaps a little less so - than Radio Moscow. The major difference between the two is that Radio Moscow prefers symphonic music while the V.O.A. promotes bubble-gum music.

title: ANIMATED STRAVINSKY
description: ALTHOUGH R. O. Blechman's animated version of Igor Stravinsky's ''Histoire du Soldat (The Soldier's Tale),'' which will be shown on Channel 13 tonight at 8, is an uneven affair, it is worth the viewer's attention. Mr. Blechman has not merely retold ''The Soldier's Tale,'' he has built an oddly compelling visual fantasy around Stravinsky's music and the composer's adaptation, with C. F. Ramuz, of an old Russian legend.

title: Advertising; Personality Change for Beatrice
description: THE new Beatrice Foods Company under James L. Dutt,

title: Washington Watch; Effort to Bar Soviet Goods
description: WASHINGTON

title: Chris Johnson Wins by 6 Shots
description: Chris Johnson posted a six-under-par 66 today to capture the $22,500 first prize at the Tucson Open with a four- day total of 272, 16 under par.

title: Louisville Wins, Illinois Advances
description: Milt Wagner sank a 12-foot shot from the right baseline with 5 seconds left to lift Louisville to a 69-67 victory over Tulsa in a second round game of the Mideast Regionals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Polish Communists Issue Message of Confidence
description: Poland's Communist Party sent a message today to the Soviet Union and other Eastern European allies assuring them that it was again strong enough to defeat any challenge to its authority by political opponents.

title: TIRELESS BALDRIGE STUMPS BOSTON FOR BOSS'S CAUSE
description: Malcolm Baldrige, the Secretary of Commerce, spent an exhausting day going from hotel to hotel as a Reagan loyalist, bringing his economic message to Boston and asking for support for his President.

title: Turks Report 12 Deaths From Fasting in Jails
description: Diplomatic sources and relatives of prisoners say that as many as 12 people have fasted to death in Turkish jails over the last few weeks in protests against prison torture and bad living conditions.

title: MONASTERY AWAITING 5 REFUGEES
description: In the quiet of their monastery in a mountain valley in Vermont, an order of Benedictine monks waits to give sanctuary to a Guatemalan family of illegal refugees moving slowly toward Vermont in a caravan of cars on the open road.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; G.E. Credit Officer Joining Fuji's Heller
description: Norman P. Blake Jr., executive vice president for financing operations at the General Electric Credit Corporation, has joined the Heller International Corporation as chairman and chief executive.

title: CBS IS PROMOTING NEW YORK SHOWS
description: With tonight's premiere of ''Kate & Allie,'' a spunky new prime-time comedy series produced in New York about two divorced mothers living together with their children in Greenwich Village, CBS is as eager to prove a point as it is to have a hit.

title: BRIEFING
description: Republican Commercials

title: Pemex Cites Its '83 Gains
description: Mexico's proven hydrocarbon reserves increased by 500 million barrels in 1983, to 72.5 billion barrels, the director of Mexico's national oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, announced today.

title: Plea From a Sapling
description: Trees have feelings, too. A slim sapling leans forlornly against a stake outside 221 East 22d Street.

title: Bridge: Kathie Wei's Team Appears Close to a Knockout Victory
description: The top women's team in the United States seemed on the road to another title here today as the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals drew to a close.

title: Tolerance Before Prayer
description: In forcing a Senate vote on his prayer amendment, President Reagan rejects the prayers of many senators for deliverance from a cruel choice. To vote for the amendment is to desecrate the religious neutrality that is a cornerstone of American liberty. To vote against it is to appear an enemy of God.

title: IN FOCUS: THE U.S. MOVIE REVIEWER
description: John Mendenhall is confused. For nearly 30 years he has labored unnoticed in an out-of-the-way United States Information Agency office. Nobody questioned his work or his method of going about it. Hardly anyone paid any attention.

title: LEBANESE AT ODDS, CANCEL A SESSION
description: Lebanon's factional leaders at the national unity talks argued again today over political proposals, and many delegates began to question openly whether any meaningful agreement was possible.

title: Judith
description: Judith Elster, a copy editor for The Dispatch, a newspaper in Union City, N.J., was married yesterday to Stephen Schlesinger, an assistant to Governor Cuomo for communications. Rabbi Philip Schecter and the Rev. Joel Scholefield, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the chapel of the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: KNICKS' ATTENDANCE ONLY FAIR
description: At a time when Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers is closing in on Wilt Chamberlain's career- scoring record of 31,419 points, it was announced during the Knicks-Kansas City Kings game Saturday night that, with with his third-period layup, Louis Orr had surpassed 3,000 points for his career.

title: JACKSON ASKS ARABS AND JEWS TO WORK FOR UNDERSTANDING
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson urged today that Arabs and Jews ''go out from their own circles and see the other's suffering'' in the hope of establishing a new understanding.

title: ILL-CONCEIVED CONTROL OF COMMERCIAL RENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDGET TAN LURES TOURISTS FOR A DAY
description: The story doesn't begin here. It actually starts 1,100 miles away on a rain-soaked runway in New Jersey.

title: Japanese Protest Missiles
description: Thousands of Japanese rallied in the port cities of Yokosuka, Sasebo and Naha today to protest the scheduled deployment of Tomahawk nuclear cruise missiles on United States Navy ships, Japanese reports said. The police said 4,000 people rallied at a park in Yokosuka, a city that is the site of a United States Navy base.

title: STATISTICS EXCULPATE THE 'DEMON CYCLIST'
description: To the Editor:

title: Miami Police Plan Said To Have Averted Riots
description: The authorities said today that a revised antiriot strategy and efforts by black residents helped Miami avoid racial rioting after a Hispanic police officer was cleared in the slaying of a black man.

title: Market Place; Stock Trading: Signs of Vigor
description: THE stock market started and finished last

title: COURSE FOR 'LATCHKEY' CHILDREN AND PARENTS
description: The question is every parent's nightmare, but it was raised matter-of-factly enough in the room full of children:

title: KNIGHT ENTRUSTS INDIANA TO A FRESHMAN
description: The buzzer sounded to end the first half, and Indiana, which had held the ball for the last shot against Richmond succeeded only in holding it too long. Bobby Knight rose from his seat on the bench to strike a now familiar pose, hands on hips, plaid sports jacket unbuttoned and a glare fixed on the freshman guard Steve Alford who discreetly studied his shoelaces as he trotted off the court.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Police Tail and the Crime Dog
description: How are the police doing at reducing crime? That's what politicians and reporters ask whenever New York City publishes its annual crime statistics. It's the wrong question.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: OUTDOORS: BASS ANGLING AND BIG MONEY
description: ONCE limited to the south and central portions of this country, fresh-water black bass fishing tournaments offering cash and merchandise prizes are now established in the Northeast.

title: ;  Dunhill Personnel Aide Promoted to Presidency
description: Charles Gray is an excited man, and not only because of his recent appointment as president of Dunhill Personnel System Inc.

title: MISSING MARSHAL FOUND DEAD
description: The body of a city marshal missing since last Tuesday when he was serving eviction papers was found in a garbage-strewn lot in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: GIBBONS, A ROOKIE, MAY CATCH FOR METS
description: John Gibbons has Jerry Grote's gumption and John Stearns's swagger, qualities that bring back fond memories for the Mets and bode well for the future.

title: Bonn Innovating in Trade With East
description: For years, the announcements at the weeklong Leipzig trade fair followed a pattern: a Western company agreed to supply an Eastern bloc country with a ready- to-use industrial plant.

title: MARCOS FAULTS U.S. ROLE IN PHILIPPINE POLITICS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that Americans had ''no business'' in Philippine politics nor any say about who this country's President should be.

title: Songs of the Depression At Michael's Pub
description: The final concert of last summer's Kool Jazz Festival, an evening of songs of the Great Depression sung and played by performers who lived through those years, has been adapted in a condensed version as ''Hard Times, Good Times,'' appearing at Michael's Pub. The cast consists of five jazz musicians - Doc Cheatham on trumpet; Eddie Barefield, tenor saxophone; Marty Napoleon, piano; Jack Lesberg, bass, and Johnny Blowers, drums - and the singer Dolly Dawn, who was a 14- year-old vocalist with George Hall's orchestra at the Hotel Taft in 1935.

title: FURY AROUSED BY PLAN TO MANAGE THE DELAWARE
description: The Lumberland Town Board met Friday night and decorum was thrown out the window.

title: ACROSS INDIA, THE ENGLISH TONGUE GET NEW TWIST
description: The traveler wanted to fly from Calcutta to Delhi, but wasn't sure whether he would be free to go on Tuesday or Wednesday.

title: THE MATCHUP
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Cowboys Agree on Sale to Texans
description: Clint Murchison, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys since their first season in the National Football League, 1960, has agreed to sell the team to a partnership of 11 Texans that includes Tex Schramm, the only general manager the team has had.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY'S PATENT WAR
description: The commercial success of the biotechnology industry may no longer hinge on the next scientific breakthrough or the clinical testing of drugs created through gene-splicing techniques.

title: The Democrats:
description: A Delegate Update

title: BEFORE 3,600 O'CONNOR OFFICIALLY TAKES HELM
description: Sister George Francis stood on tiptoe on her kneeler to catch a glimpse of John J. O'Connor, wearing the purple robes of Lent and his new gold archbishop's miter, as he followed a procession of 22 bishops down the aisle of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: THE APRIL SURPRISE
description: As the cherry trees bloom in the middle of April, pundits will be analyzing the Pennsylvania primary and gearing up for Texas, the White House press corps will be getting its shots for the President's climb of the Great Wall of China, and taxpayers will be hastening to send the I.R.S. happy returns.

title: ;  Accounts
description: * Eljenn International Corp., Newton, Mass., a shampoo product manufacturer, to Cosmopulos, Crowley & Daley, Boston.

title: ; Racz & Dessimoz Gets Contax/Yashica Work
description: The restrained merriment in the high-ceilinged offices of Racz & Dessimoz Associates overlooking Madison Square Park from Fifth Avenue last week was generated by the acquistion of the of the Contax/Yashica account, which, with the high-end Contax and mass appeal Yashica, nicely fills the agency's camera category.

title: 2 AWACS AIRCRAFT SENT TO BOLSTER SUDAN AFTER RAID
description: The United States has dispatched two Awacs surveillance planes to Egypt to bolster air defenses in the Sudan against a repetition of Friday's air raid on the city of Omdurman, Administration officials said today.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: National Invitation Tournament : Second-round games, all at 8 P.M., Notre Dame (18-11) vs. Boston College (18-11) at Springfield, Mass.; Tennessee- Chattanooga (24-6) at Tennessee (20-13); Weber State (23-8) at Southwest Louisiana (21-8); Nebraska (18-11) at Xavier of Ohio (21-10); Marquette (17-12) at Michigan (19-10), Santa Clara (23-8) at Lamar (26-4).

title: CHURCH VOWS TO APPEAL $390,000 AWARD IN WOMAN'S PRIVACY SUIT
description: Elders of the Church of Christ here assured members today that they would appeal a $390,000 verdict awarded Thursday to Marian Guinn, a member whose love affair the elders had denounced from the pulpit.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.98

title: Kasparov Takes 4th Game of Match
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union won the fourth game of the final candidates chess match with his countryman Vasily Smyslov on Saturday in Vilnius, in the Soviet Republic of Lithuania. The 20-year-old whiz increased his lead to 3-1 over the 62-year-old former world champion.

title: Lower Phone Fee Weighed
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is probably going to propose a 50-cent fee for long-distance information calls instead of the 75-cent fee it proposed last fall, an official said Friday.

title: U.S. STUDY FINDS 25% PRICE RISES IN SOME WEAPON PARTS PURCHASES
description: An investigation by the General Accounting Office into practices at four Pentagon buying centers showed price increases of more than 25 percent annually for some spare parts, according to preliminary findings.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: F.B.I. Agents' Roles In Inquiry Reported
description: Two agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation infiltrated gambling circles here, maintaining false identities as gamblers even after they were arrested and convicted, according to a newspaper report.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The number of detour signs out there and the number of words on them explaining alternate routes will be the equivalent of reading 'War and Peace' on the road.

title: FOR SHIP CHRISTENERS, THE SOCIETY OF SPONSORS
description: On a spring day nearly 22 years ago, Jacqueline Kennedy smashed a bottle of champagne against the bow of a nuclear submarine, saying, ''Je te baptise Lafayette.''

title: ; CITY TRAFFIC: A VISION WORTH REVIVING
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A forward pass in a National Football League game hits an official, then is caught in the field of play by an eligible receiver before it strikes the ground. What is the ruling? Suppose the ball hits a down- marker or the chains that indicate the yardage before it is caught by an eliible receiver?

title: 2 TYPES OF CHEMICAL WAR AGENTS DETECTED IN HOSPITALIZED IRANIANS
description: A Belgian toxicologist said last week that his laboratory had found two forms of chemical warfare agents in samples taken from Iranian soldiers reportedly struck by an Iraqi chemical attack on Feb. 27.

title: RECITAL: EUGENE BARBAN ON PIANO AT GARNEGIE
description: DURING much of Eugene Barban's piano recital in Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon, a listener wondered why the playing was not more effective than it was. Mr. Barban, who teaches at Winthrop College, is certainly a skilled technician - even the dense passages of Schumann's ''Kreisleriana'' were cleanly articulated. He also has a keen lyrical sense - the Air from Grieg's ''Holberg'' Suite was sweetly sung.

title: UTILITY ISSUES LEAD NEW OFFERINGS
description: No new auctions of Treasury notes or bonds are scheduled this week, but dealers in Government securities expect the Treasury to announce Tuesday that next week it will auction about $15 billion of notes and bonds divided into maturities of 4 years, 7 years and 20 years.

title: Netherlands Output Up
description: Industrial production in the Netherlands rose 1.8 percent in January from December and was up 6.5 percent from January 1983, the Central Bureau of Statistics said.

title: Surgeon Fatally Stabs Intruder in L.I. Home
description: A Long Island surgeon stabbed an intruder to death with a kitchen knife Saturday in his Roosevelt, L.I., home, the Nassau County police said.

title: West Virginia Governor To Seek U.S. Senate Seat
description: Gov. John D. (Jay) Rockefeller 4th has announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Senate.

title: YONKERS SCHOOL INTEGRATION FACING FISCAL HURDLE
description: Financing for a plan to desegregate the Yonkers public schools voluntarily was cast into doubt yesterday by officials of the financially troubled city.

title: Pomare Dance Film
description: A 1964 film of ''Blues for the Jungle,'' a signature modern dance work by Eleo Pomare, will be shown Thursday at 6 P.M. at the Vital Arts Center, 78 Fifth Avenue, as a benefit for the Pomare company's training and development program for dancers and choreographers. Mr. Pomare will speak before the film's showing. Tickets are $10. Reservations: 675- 1136.

title: Curling Camaraderie
description: ''We rent our ice,'' said C. Kenneth Cooper, as he and his New York teammates prepared for a century-old curling contest between the United States and Canada.

title: JAZZ: TANYA MARIA PERFORMS
description: -rising Brazilian jazz star, has reached a crucial career crossroads where she must decide how far to go in a pop direction. The singer-pianist-composer, who performed at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday, made her reputation as a scat-singing virtuoso using her solid Oscar Peterson-influenced piano as a springboard for sassy, amusing excursions into vocalese that express a headstrong musical personality.

title: 51 in Rhode Island Hurt in Chemical Fires
description: Two chemical fires at separate sites in the Providence area resulted in injuries to 49 firefighters and two police officers this weekend, according to the authorities.

title: MUSIC: NEARLY 12 HOURS OF TRIBUTE TO IVES
description: IT may be that the time is ripe for

title: DANCE: LISA KRAUS ON LIFE
description: LISA KRAUS recently visited India, a country she found fascinating but strange. Returning home, she unexpectedly found America to be just as strange. Her culture shock led her to examine both life in general and the various fine arts, including dance. And she decided that life and art alike can be perplexing, funny, sad and marvelous.

title: OPERA: GOLDOVSKY COMPANY'S FAREWELL
description: WHEN Violetta died in ''La Traviata'' at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts yesterday afternoon, it was not a typical tubercular demise. For with her, in those closing scenes of Verdi's opera, a company was also making its farewells, ending, with it, an era of American operatic history.

title: THE SEXES: DIFFERENCES IN SPEECH
description: ONE of the funniest moments in the movie ''Tootsie'' is the bar scene in which Dustin Hoffman bats a pair of six-inch eyelashes and, with a perky smile, tells the waiter, ''I'll have a Dubonnet on the rocks with a twist, please?''

title: RECITAL: MAURIZIO POLLINI PLAYS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: MAURIZIO POLLINI'S extraordinary evening of Schumann and Chopin at Carnegie Hall Saturday night may never have touched our hearts, but to call his playing cold would be unfair. Those who do, I suspect, find it difficult to forgive Mr. Pollini the inner perfection of his piano technique; still, once our latent jealousy is past, we begin to appreciate what a gifted and sophisticated musical athlete he is.

title: Truman Wins P.S.A.L. Title
description: Andrew Jackson had the much-heralded three-guard offense but Truman High School made a strong case for defense yesterday. The Mustangs defeated Jackson, 69-55, to win the A Division championship of the Public Schools Athletic League.

title: MONDALE IS VICTOR IN PUERTO RICO
description: More than 150,000 voters turned out to give former Vice President Walter F. Mondale an overwhelming victory today in a primary held by one faction of the Democratic Party. Meanwhile, 2,522 other voters participated in caucuses set up at the last minute that voted to give Senator Gary Hart all but one delegate to the national convention.

title: VIDMAR AND MISS RETTON WIN
description: The McDonald's American Cup remained America's cup yesterday. For the second consecutive year, Peter Vidmar of Los Angeles and Mary Lou Retton of Fairmont, W. Va., won the all-round titles in the prestigious 14-nation gymnastics competition, and they and Julianne McNamara of Danville, Calif., each received a perfect score of 10.

title: IF AN ECONOMIC PANEL, NOT COURTS, HANDLED ANTITRUST CASES
description: To the Editor:

title: Foe of Mugabe Charges Youths Broke Up Rally
description: Joshua Nkomo, the opposition leader, said today that ax-wielding supporters of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe broke up an opposition rally Sunday, wounding 10 people.

title: E.P.A. Considers a Ban On Pesticide Using DDT
description: A pesticide popular with citrus and cotton growers and home gardeners is under Federal scrutiny because it contains the banned pesticide DDT.

title: German Prices Up 0.2%
description: West German producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in February for a 2.6 percent increase since February 1983, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: More Sea Gulls For Winfield
description: Between innings of a Yankee baseball game on Aug. 4 in Toronto last year, Dave Winfield tossed a warmup ball from center field toward the bullpen. It bounced once and struck a seagull, killing the bird.

title: NEWPORT ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PSYCH SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income after tax credit of $24,000.

title: JACKSON ON THE ARABS From remarks by the Rev. Jesse Jackson Sunday to the convention of the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee in Washington.
description: The dehumanization of Arab people has brought great suffering to you as a people. Because of it, the crusades and centuries of colonialization and oppression were justified. And even today killings and occupations are legitimized by anti-Arab racism.

title: MUSIC Frank Lowe Quintet Plays at Sweet Basil
description: The Frank Lowe Quintet played a hard-swinging second set at Sweet Basil Sunday, as it brought two 1960's luminaries - Grachan Moncur 3d on trombone and Charles Moffett on drums - back to the New York club circuit. The quintet played a fast free- jazz piece, a modal ballad and a relaxed, bluesy tune.

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHEN BANKRUPTCY THREATENS JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hart Won Caucuses In Oklahoma With 43.3% OKLAHOMA CITY, March 19 (AP) - Gary Hart won Oklahoma's Democratic precinct caucuses last week by a margin of 4.4 percentage points, according to almost complete figures released Monday by state party officials.
description: The results would give him and Walter F. Mondale 20 national convention delegates each, with 3 delegates unpledged, the officials said.

title: ISRAELI COALITION PARTNER SEEKS EARLY ELECTION
description: A small party in the governing coalition said tonight that it would introduce a bill this week to dissolve Parliament and advance the national elections now scheduled for November 1985.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
IN POLAND, NEWS IS NOT ALWAYS NEWS
description: There seem to be two kinds of news in Poland: what the newspapers print and what the people want to know.

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 20, 1984 International
description: The United States warned Libya that there could be ''serious consequences'' if it interfered with the two Awacs surveillance planes that were sent to help deter Libyan air attacks on the Sudan, according to a Reagan Administration official. The Awacs were sent to Egypt to join Egyptian fighters in patrolling Sudanese airspace. (Page A1, Column 6.) Summit talks on the Common Market ran into problems when Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain again demanded far-reaching changes in the way the 10-nation European Economic Community works. A two-day meeting of European Government leaders in Brussels is widely seen as decisive for the trade-bloc's future and for Western Europe's hopes of closer economic and political unity. (A1:5.)

title: Richardson Is RunningFor Tsongas Senate Seat
description: Elliot L. Richardson, who has held more Cabinet posts than anyone else, today announced his candidacy for the Senate.

title: PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFULS GO AFTER NEW YORK MONEY
description: It was Walter F. Mondale calling. ''Is Mrs. Kuhn there?'' he asked.

title: Business and the Law; International Antitrust Test
description: THERE have been plenty of cases recently in

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ; WHAT'S NEW
description: Every year for a decade now, the French Film Office, an industry organization, has brought to New York a showcase series of films made in France by directors and with talent that is, on this side of the ocean, new and untried. This year's series, the 10th anniversary showing of ''Perspectives on French Cinema,'' starts today and runs through March 29 at Metro Cinema, Broadway and 99th Street (222-1200).

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 26
F.D.I.C. PLACING CURBS ON DEPOSIT PROTECTION
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, in a change of policy, served notice today that when banks fail and their accounts are shifted to other banks, it may not grant full protection to depositors with balances larger than $100,000.

title: The New Amsterdam With American Works
description: Celebrations of American musical eclecticism seem to be in the air this season, and in that genre, the concert by the New Amsterdam Singers in Merkin Hall Sunday night was particularly well programmed. It began with the witty ''Modern Music'' by William Billings - the title speaking of the modernity of the late 18th-century - and ended with Henry Brant's equally playful ''Three-way Canon Blues'' of 1946 - combining American blues with that most academic of musical forms.

title: NEW COMPAQ PORTABLE ADDS HARD DISK DRIVE
description: At the moment, the Compaq seems to be the most popular portable I.B.M. PC-compatible computer on the market. It is also the only portable that claims 100 percent compatibility with I.B.M. software. Furthermore, now that International Business Machines has announced its own portable PC, Compaq has stepped ahead with a new machine called the Compaq Plus, which boasts a hard disk in addition to its single floppy disk drive.

title: Players Tell of Gifts
description: Former Oregon State basketball players call them ''grippers,'' the rabid fans who wanted to get close to them and who offered a variety of gifts for the privilege.

title: MACGREGOR SPORTING GOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $198,500 for the quarter and $273,800 for the 6 months. c-Net loss. Results reflect a 2-for-1 stock distribution paid in January 1984.

title: Hart's Ancestry TracedTo White House Families
description: Gary Hart is a distant cousin of five former White House residents - Abraham Lincoln, William Howard Taft, Gerald R. Ford, Ellen Wilson and Mamie Eisenhower - according to Gary Roberts, research director of the New England Historic Genealogical Society.

title: Pirates Top Mets, 10-9
description: The Pirates beat the Mets, 10-9, today as Scott Holman was roughed up for nine runs, his first of the spring, including a pair of second- inning home runs by Tony Pena and Jim Morrison and a homer by Dale Berra in the six-run third inning. For the Mets, Keith Hernandez had his first home run of the season, a three- run shot that tied the game in the sixth inning. But the Pirates came back in the bottom of the sixth to score the winning run on a single by Amos Otis.

title: IN BIRMINGHAM, WHITES NOW GET U.S. LEGAL AID
description: Johnny Johnson in 1966 was the second black to be hired as a patrolman in the Police Department here. Lieutenant Johnson looks back to that period with feelings of bitterness and triumph.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,015,000. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,413,000 for the quarter and $2,125,000 for the 9 months.

title: HART ON 'LESSON OF VIETNAM'
description: Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by Senator Gary Hart as he campaigned in Illinois:

title: Buried Treasure
description: Hidden in the Met press guide - page 50, paragraph 8 - is one of the secret statistics of the 1983 baseball season. Hubie Brooks, unbeknownst to few outside his immediate family, led the National League last season with a .354 average with men in scoring position and was second, at .336, with runners on base.

title: Utah Man Found Guilty In Slayings of 5 Boys
description: Arthur Gary Bishop, a 32-year-old former bookkeeper, Eagle Scout and honor student, was found guilty tonight of first-degree murder in the abduction and slayings of five boys.

title: Sonics Back Thompson
description: The Seattle SuperSonics are supporting David Thompson 's contention that he was ''set up'' or ''sucker- punched'' when he tumbled down stairs at New York's Studio 54 and injured his knee. ''We have seen the gentleman who claims he was hit by David and who David claims hit or shoved him,'' said General Manager Les Habegger , discussing the team's preliminary investigation into the incident.

title: CONCERT: DAVID BURGE
description: One of America's important pianists passed through New York over the weekend, though I doubt that many serious music listeners have ever heard his name. He is David Burge, a man who has given over a major talent and the good part of a life's work to playing new music.

title: KOCH BACKS MONDALE FOR DEMOCRATIC NOMINATION
description: Mayor Koch yesterday endorsed Walter F. Mondale yesterday for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He coupled the action with praise of Senator Gary Hart and a stinging attack on the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: ST. PETERSBURG MANAGES TO MAKE ITSELF YOUNGER
description: It was just after midnight and The National Bar in downtown St. Petersburg was almost empty. A sad, slow piece of country music was on the jukebox for the seventh time in an hour and the bartender, a spirited woman in her 50's, was still singing along.

title: MISS WITT IS LEADER
description: Katarina Witt of East Germany, the Olympic gold medal winner, took the lead after the women's compulsory figures today at the world figure skating championships.

title: ITEMS VARY IN SIMILAR TAX BILLS
