description: The tax bill that the Senate Finance Committee substantially completed last week would raise an estimated $48 billion through Sept. 30, 1987. A similar measure approved March 1 by the House Ways and Means Committee would raise about $49 billion. Here is a comparison of the bills:

title: FOR MILITARY LEADERS, THE SHADOW OF VIETNAM
description: As military officers here talk about the invasion of Grenada and the deployment of marines to Lebanon, or the possibility of fighting in Central America or the Persian Gulf, the legacy of Vietnam is striking.

title: REVISED REPORTS BY MEESE MADE PUBLIC AS WIDE INQUIRY IS ORDERED
description: The White House today made public Edwin Meese 3d's revised financial disclosure forms, while officials of the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation discussed plans for an inquiry into Mr. Meese's financial dealings.

title: DANCE: SURPRISES IN LAST GRAHAM BILL
description: WITH Martha Graham joining her dancers for a curtain call, as she has to a standing ovation at every performance for the last three weeks, the Martha Graham Dance Company ended its season Sunday night in the State Theater.

title: CHINA COMPLAINS TO U.S. OF DICRIMINATORY TRADE
description: China's Minister of Finance, Wang Bingqian, told Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today that China wanted to expand Chinese-American trade. As a start, he demanded that the United States eliminate what he called discriminatory restrictions on imports from China.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
'HAUNTED' ON AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE
description: WHEN Brooke Adams arrives home, in Michael Roemer's ''Haunted,'' she is carrying a copy of Brooke Hayward's ''Haywire.'' The choice of reading matter is no coincidence. Both the book and Michael Roemer's television film, presented tonight at 9 on American Playhouse on Channel 13, deal with unhappy families and forlorn daughters who survive as an act of will. While the Hollywood memoir benefited from specifics, the film is weakened by generalities and irresolution.

title: CITY RELIGOUS LEADERS LAUD O'CONNOR'S CALL FOR NEW UNITY AMONG THEM
description: Religious leaders in New York responded with enthusiasm yesterday to the call of Archbishop John J. O'Connor for a new spirit of unity among them, but some noted that differences on some social issues continued to divide them.

title: BROTHEL OWNER TELLS JURY HE GAVE JUDGE $85,000
description: Joseph Conforte, a brothel owner, convicted extortionist and tax evader, testified today that on two occasions he had given Federal District Judge Harry E. Claiborne a total of $85,000 in bribes.

title: HIGH COURT TO HEAR INDIAN CLAIM
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Oneida Indians had the right to sue two upstate New York counties for ''wrongful occupation'' of their ancestral lands.

title: LEGITIMIZING THE BAD
description: To the Editor: Richard Bernstein is correct in pointing out that certain U.N. agen

title: NEW FENCE CAPITALIZES ON DEER'S POOR 3-D VISION
description: -tailed deer bounding in the meadows of rural areas is a joy to behold for visitors, but to farmers the deer are a pest that can destroy their crops. Farmers have built fences, used repellents and even killed deer in their efforts to reduce the damage, but none of the measures have proved effective.

title: India Prolongs Control Over Punjab State
description: The Indian Parliament today extended for six more months direct Government control of Punjab state, where nearly 90 people have been killed in violence between Sikhs and Hindus.

title: U.S. WARNS LIBYA AGAINST ATTACKING AWACS OVER SUDAN
description: The United States told Libya today that there could be ''serious consequences'' if it interfered with the Awacs surveillance planes that have been sent to help deter Libyan air attacks on the Sudan, an Administration official said.

title: TAX AMNESTY, TAX HONESTY
description: Honesty may be the best policy, but amnesty is giving it a good run among state tax collectors. Impressed by Massachusetts' recent revenue windfall, Governor Cuomo wants to try it in New York. It's a gimmick.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Pettibone Restructuring
description: The Pettibone Corporation said today that it had signed a $112 million agreement with its bank and insurance company for restructuring the company. It said the pact provides for a two-year loan secured by fixed assets, inventories and current assets of the company and its subsidiaries.

title: GENEVE CAPITAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,000,000 from the sale of real estate by a majority- owned subsidiary.

title: AGING RETAIL CHAIN REVIVES
description: In the spring of 1981, a new management team at the Cherry Webb and Touraine stores in Pawtucket, R.I., met to grapple with the first annual loss in the long history of the specialty apparel chain.

title: ; THE 'CHAOS' THAT PERMEATES THE U.N. SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
O'CONNOR IS INSTALLED AS ARCHBISHOP
description: In rites of both majesty and whimsy, John J. O'Connor yesterday took occupancy of St. Patrick's cathedral chair as the eighth Archbishop of New York.

title: CRITICAL SHIFT FOR JAPAN'S STEEL
description: From a distance, the steel mill here looks like a rusted erector set rising from a thicket of Japanese tile roofs.

title: DR.MORRISH.BERNSTEIN
description: Dr. Morris H. Bernstein, associate clinical professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died of cancer last Wednesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: GLOSSER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
PROF. CHARLEY LAU
description: Halfway through last season, Charley Lau learned he had cancer of the colon. But when he wasn't hospitalized for treatment, he would continue to work with his White Sox hitters in batting practice at Comiskey Park, then leave before the game started in order to go home to rest.

title: ABDUCTION OF BUSINESSMAN ALARMS JAPANESE
description: A wealthy Japanese industrialist was kidnapped Sunday in the first abduction of a prominent businessman here in memory. The incident baffled many Japanese and left some worried about ''Western-style'' crime breaking out in their country.

title: PEOPLE INDIFFERENT TO VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''This is the

title: OF KING HUSSEIN'S VALUES AND PRINCIPLES
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr
description: Dr. Olga Frankel, a child psychiatrist and medical director of the Steinway Child and Family Developmental Center in Astoria, Queens, died of cancer Saturday at Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens. She was 70 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Barnett Banks
description: Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. said it had acquired 5.3 percent of the shares outstanding of Florida Coast Banks Inc. and acquired options to purchase up to an additional 16.1 percent.

title: STATE PANEL CALLS FOR CHANGES AT ATTICA, INCLUDING FEWER PRISONERS
description: Describing the Attica prison as ''a correctional facility that requires a number of major reforms,'' the State Commission of Correction called today for a rapid reduction in its inmate population.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After tax credits of $400,000 for the quarter and $918,000 for the 9 months. c-After a tax credit of $325,000. d-After a tax credit of $992,000 and a gain on extinguishment of debt of $296,000.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $170,000 for the quarter and $1,000,000 for the 9 months. Results for the latest quarter and 9 months include the operations of Graniteville Co. and Wilson Brothers on a consolidated basis.

title: ;  I.B.M. Executive Heads Videotex Joint Venture
description: Theodore C. Papes Jr., a vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, has been named the president and chief executive officer of the new videotex joint venture announced last month by I.B.M., CBS Inc. and Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Huffington Starts A Bid for Enstar
description: The Enstar Corporation rose 75 cents, to $16.50, today on the New York Stock Exchange following the report that Roy M. Huffington has begun a bid to gain control of Enstar, a natural gas and oil exploration company.

title: MARROW TRANSPLANT: A REALISTIC BUT STILL DRAMATIC VIEW
description: IT WAS a perfect soap opera: A

title: Changing a Mind
description: When a college basketball team reaches the round of 16 in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament, it can be certain that the opposition on that level will be talented and challenging.

title: 7 OTHER ARCHBISHOPS HELD NEW YORK POST
description: The Most Rev. John J. O'Connor is the eighth Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: DWG to Exercise Axia Stock Option
description: The DWG Corporation said it intends to exercise an option to buy 776,200 shares of Axia Inc. from Guardian Industries and a Guardian unit for $20 each.

title: Profits Plunge At Big Board
description: Earnings for New York Stock Exchange member firms dealing with the public plunged to $21 million in 1983's fourth quarter, down from $345 million in the third quarter and $825 million in the fourth period of 1982.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, MARCH 20, 1984
description: The Economy

title: SMOKING BAN REJECTED FOR MOST U.S. FLIGHTS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today rejected proposals to ban smoking on up to 85 percent of commercial flights in the United States, but agreed to prohibit it on planes with no more than 30 seats.

title: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of assets of $680,467 for the quarter and $55,732 for the year. c-After a loss of $191,614 for the quarter on the sale of a unit and a gain of $626,371 for the year from the sale of assets.

title: Norwegian Said to Spy For Iraq and Soviet
description: A prosecutor said in a statement today that a Norwegian Foreign Ministry official, already charged with spying for the Soviet Union, also spied for Iraq.

title: BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Bond prices opened the week sharply lower in relatively light trading in the credit markets yesterday.

title: 'SCHOOL PRAYER IS DISRESPECTFUL OF CHILDREN'
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Two key defensive players for the Michigan Panthers have been suspended because they missed a practice last Saturday. Larry Bethea, a lineman, and John Corker, a linebacker, will be out for an indefinite period. . . . Promoters have set June 8 as the date for the heavyweight title fight between Larry Holmes, the International Boxing Federation champion, and Gerrie Coetzee, the World Boxing Association titleholder, although no site has been determined.

title: BRITISH FASHION RISES AND SHINES
description: The British fashion scene, coming alive after a sleep since the 1960's, is drawing increasing numbers to check out the shops, the street people, the experimental designers and the established houses. It turns out also that in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher the British fashion industry has the best spokesman imaginable.

title: CLOSE SENATE VOTE EXPECTED ON PRAYER IN SCHOOLS
description: A handful of undecided senators hold the key to Tuesday's scheduled vote on a proposed constitutional amendment to sanction vocal prayer in the public schools, supporters and opponents of the measure agreed today.

title: WHITE HOUSE TO FIGHT SOME EXPORT BILL CURBS
description: The White House is going to battle what it sees as Congressional efforts to whittle down the President's foreign policy-making authority, Administration officials said today. The fight revolves around the House and Senate bills to renew the Export Administration Act that go soon to a House-Senate negotiating conference.

title: Vector Stock Deal
description: Vector Graphic Inc., the financially pressed maker of sophisticated desktop computers, said it had completed a private placement of 1.8 million shares that brought $2.75 million in additional financing to the company.

title: CUBANS AID NICARAGUA ARMY
description: Nicaraguan Army officers here say their troops are accompanied by Cuban military advisers in battle fatigues and armed with Soviet-made AK-47 rifles in operations against United States-backed rebels in northern Nicaragua.

title: TRAVELOGUES MOVE INTO VIDEO REALM
description: AS new media mature, they often branch out into unforeseen directions. For example, video may soon augment the familiar travel folder. Instead of handing out brochures, travel agents will invite their clients into comfortable screening rooms to take armchair journeys to pick the countries, regions, hotels, rooms, and even restaurants they might like to visit.

title: COURT BARS APPEALS ON GAS PRICING
description: In an action that could lead to substantial refunds for consumers of natural gas, the Supreme Court today refused to review a lower court's ruling that invalidated a controversial new pricing regulation for natural gas.

title: EATON VANCE INVESTORS FUND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov. 20, 1983.

title: Brazil's Navy Chief Resigns
description: Minister of the Navy Maximiano Eduardo da Silva Fonseca resigned today, becoming the first high-level official of President Joao Baptista Figueiredo's military Government to step down. Admiral Fonseca, 64 years old, resigned for ''personal reasons,'' according to an announcement from the presidential palace. He was a member of President Figueiredo's original Cabinet.

title: Caledonian Profit Rises
description: The Caledonian Aviation Group, owner of the British Caledonian Airways, announced today that it had more than doubled its profits in 1983, to $4.9 million, and plans to beat British Airways to the London Stock Exchange. Revenues for the year increased 6.5 percent, to $633 million. The airline, the major part of the group, made $4.7 million of the profit, having lost $969,000 the previous year after its South American networks were reduced as a result of the conflict over the Falkland Islands.

title: REAGAN'S DEFICIT PROPOSAL DISPUTED BY STUDY
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that President Reagan's $150 billion deficit reduction proposal, announced last week, would leave Federal deficits much higher than the Administration had projected.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
ALVARADO MEETS WITH ATTORNEY ON HIS FUTURE
description: Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado met with his lawyer yesterday to discuss whether he should resign, and a top city official said he thought that the Chancellor was very close to stepping down.

title: REBEL SAYS VOTE ISN'T A TARGET
description: A spokesman for the insurgents in El Salvador said today that the national election Sunday ''will not be a military target'' for guerrillas.

title: UNITED FIRE & CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Operating income. c-Net income.

title: Mura Kievman Sings 30 Songs
description: The soprano Mura Kievman's Saturday evening concert in the Abraham Goodman House was devoted entirely to 20th-century songs - 30 of them, to be exact, by Charles T. Griffes, Ernst Toch, Olivier Messiaen, Arnold Cooke and Dmitri Shostakovich, grouped into 5 cycles dating from 1918 through 1968.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revenue figures are net of interest expense.

title: Peru Cabinet Changes
description: Finance Minister Carlos Rodriguez Pastor resigned today, a Government spokesman said. The action came three days before a strike called to protest economic policies. President Fernando Belaunde Terry announced that Jose Benavidez Munoz, former Mines and Energy Minister, would replace Mr. Rodriguez Pastor and that Juan Inchaustegui would get the energy post. Mr. Rodriguez Pastor, who took office in January 1983, has been blamed by the opposition party for a deteriorating economy.

title: Ladd-Patrick Deal
description: The Patrick Petroleum Company said it had agreed in principle to sell most of its oil and gas assets for $202 million to the Ladd Petroleum Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company. Patrick said proceeds from the sale would be used to pay bank debts on which the company defaulted in January and would also be distributed to shareholders as part of a liquidation plan still to be adopted. Patrick said the agreement gives Ladd an option to buy 2.4 million of Patrick's 12.9 million shares outstanding.

title: HARLEM RESIDENTS GET TO BOTTOM OF MYSTERY
description: Since January, Elizabeth Mayo had been hearing and feeling what seemed like periodic muffled explosions deep in the ground beneath her town house at 40 Hamilton Terrace in Harlem.

title: CONCERT: LORIN MAAZEL AND FRENCH ORCHESTRA
description: LORIN MAAZEL is devoting his three Orchestre National de France concerts here this week to French and Russian music. A most interesting set of programs could be worked up on that theme - tracing French influences on Russian composers and vice versa, examining music composed in France by Russians in exile and the like. Unfortunately, this week's concerts are rather more conventional, concentrating on well-known French and Russian composers of the late- 19th and early-20th centuries, some with tangible links with the other country and some not.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: Foote, Cone Acquires Dutch Agency Interest

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Ich bin ein New Yorker.''- Archbishop John J. O'Connor. (A1:2.)

title:
FUTURES/OPTIONS ;
New Indexes to Track Phones, Transportation
description: Despite the spotty success record of many new narrow-based industry indexes, four new options indexes - two based on telephone stocks and two based on transportation stocks - will begin trading today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CARCINOGENS: A REVIEW OF 20 MAJOR CONTROVERSIES
description: The substances listed below, all of which have been found or are now present in the workplace or general environment, are among the most widely cited of the more than 100 chemicals known or suspected to have caused cancer in humans or animals. The chart indicates when and why these chemicals were banned or regulated and whether they remain under study. Text: Ben A. Franklin.

title: JUSTICES TO RULE ON THE RIGHT TO STATE AID IN INSANITY PLEA
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether an indigent defendant is constitutionally entitled to expert psychiatric assistance, paid for by the state, to help establish an insanity defense.

title: FROM FLIES TO FLEAS, SPRING STIRS A SMALL WORLD
description: Spring will arrive Tuesday, and somewhere a housefly will stir.

title: 5 Years of Book Awards
description: Chaim Potok will speak on March

title: Trilogy in Pact With Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation and Trilogy Ltd. said that they had signed an agreement allowing Control Data access to Trilogy's semiconductor technology. Control Data will pay $2 million initially plus future royalties from Control Data products that use the Trilogy technology.

title: MAY ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
'GETTING PHYSICAL' AND 'SHAPING UP'
description: A LONG with pasta makers, exercise machines are top candidates among current fads for eventual dumping in the domestic junk pile. Meanwhile, though, television is huffing and puffing to make the most of the biceps boom. Tonight, admirers of assorted bodies beautiful have two exhibitionistic treats on tap: A television movie called ''Getting Physical,'' on Channel 2 at 9, and the debut of a new situation-comedy series titled ''Shaping Up,'' on Channel 7 at 9:30.

title: SENATE PLAN ON GIFT-TAX EXEMPTION
description: The Senate Finance Committee is scheduled to consider on Tuesday a proposal that would exempt parents and others from the gift tax on interest- free loans made before February to children or relatives. At stake are millions of dollars in unpaid gift taxes.

title: Trial in Rape Case May End Tomorrow
description: The defense for two of four men in a gang rape trial ended their cases today after one of the defendants testified that a woman was ''laughing away'' as she had sex with several men on a barroom pool table.

title: 3 Programs of Dances By Montreal Company
description: Tangente Danse Actuelle will present three programs featuring work by seven Montreal choreographers on Friday through Sunday at 9 P.M. at P.S. 122, 150 First Avenue.

title: FLICKINGER ACCEPTS $34-A-SHARE OFFER
description: S. M. Flickinger Inc., the fifth-largest wholesale grocery company in the nation, said today that it had agreed in principle to be acquired for $34 a share, or a total of about $167.1 million, by a company to be controlled by the Riordan, Freeman & Spogli merchant banking firm of Los Angeles and its affiliates.

title: POCO PETROLEUMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Market Place; Diversification Profit and Peril
description: IN recent years many companies have changed

title: The U.N. Today March 20, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Williams Estate Blocks Renaming of Theater
description: Southeast Bank of Miami, which represents the estate of Tennessee Williams, was granted a temporary injunction yesterday in State Supreme Court prohibiting the new owner of the Playhouse on West 48th Street from renaming the theater in memory of the late playwright.

title: IF NON-VOTERS VOTED
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPPORT CONTADORA DIPLOMACY
description: The peace-making effort known as the Contadora process - it is named after the island where representatives from Colombia, Mexico, Venezuela and Panama first met to discuss the crisis in Central America - has not yet achieved much concrete success. It may, however, be the only promising avenue toward peace in the region.

title: TRADE GAP SETS RECORD IN QUARTER
description: For the final three months of 1983, the foreign trade deficit of the United States, measured on a current account basis, increased to a quarterly record of $15.3 billion, the Commerce Department reported today, topping the $12.1 billion in red ink posted in the third quarter.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: pages. Poseidon Press. $15.95. WITH his third novel ''Waterland,'' the young British author Graham Swift has written a highly ambitious book - a book that reads at once as a gothic family saga, a detective story and as a philosophical meditation on the nature and uses of history. In delineating the emotional geography of ''Fenland,'' a flat and magical place in the English countryside, he has created a fictional world as palpably rich as Thomas Hardy's Wessex, and he has populated that world with a motley crew of innocents and grotesques.

title: HART STRUGGLING TO KEEP SLIM LEAD FOR ILLNOIS VOTE
description: Gary Hart struggled today to protect what appeared to be a narrow lead among Illinois voters, in the face of a determined effort by Walter F. Mondale to catch up.

title: ILLINOIS VOTERS WARY ON THE CONTENDERS
description: After watching the Democratic Presidential candidates' television debate Sunday night,Mike Hellyer pronounced Walter F. Mondale ''stale and boring.'' But he said he would vote for the former Vice President anyway because he liked his ''common sense and experience.''

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of plants of $404,000 for the quarter and $579,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a gain on the sale of plants of $342,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Uruguayan is Freed After 9 Years in Jail
description: The military Government today freed Liber Seregni, a retired general and 1971 presidential candidate who was jailed, freed and jailed again after the armed forces coup in 1973.

title: N.A.A.C.P. LOBBYIST TILL'78
description: Clarence M. Mitchell Jr., long the Washington lobbyist of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died Sunday at Maryland General Hospital in Baltimore. He was 73 years old.

title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A WARNING FROM ALBERT SHANKER
description: ALBERT SHANKER, president of the American Federation of Teachers, sees public education in America in mortal danger. He senses a political climate that may lead to tuition tax credits for parents who send their children to private schools. If this happens, he fears, many parents, perhaps 30 percent or more, may take their children out of the public schools.

title: ESTROGENS MAY MAKE HEART DISEASE MORE LIKELY CONTRARY to the longstanding belief that estrogens given to postmenopausal women would protect against cardiovascular disease, new findings from the Framingham Heart Study indicate that estrogen users have a 50 percent greater risk than nonusers of developing heart disease or suffering a stroke.
description: The findings, reported recently by Dr. Peter W. F. Wilson to an American Heart Association conference on cardiovascular disease, contradict previous reports indicating lower death rates among women who took menopausal estrogens.

title: No Headline
description: Bomb Breaks Windows A

title: NBC Splits Up Duties Mulholland Had Held
description: Following the abrupt resignation Friday of Robert Mulholland as president of NBC, the network announced a reorganization of its top management yesterday.

title: AMID BABEL IN BRUSSELS, TOUGH TALK
description: The European Community is like a big multinational corporation whose board of directors meets only four times a year and whose chief executive officer changes every six months.

title: MUSIC: HANDEL'S 'SOLOMON'PERFORMED
description: THERE always is a strong public demand for entertainment disguised as religion. Shamans, medieval authors of mystery plays and television preachers all have been privy to that formula for success. Great composers, too, have understood this human need, and perhaps none exploited it more brilliantly than Handel, whose oratorios fulfilled - apparently still fulfill - the double requirement of pleasure and piety. However, his ''Solomon,'' which Musica Sacra presented last night at Avery Fisher Hall, would be a better example of the type if it were more consistently entertaining and more religious.

title: CANADA BETRAYS A WEAKNESS FOR WHITE ELEPHANTS
description: For more than afternoon, the workers at Mirabel International Airport vastly outnumbered the passengers, not an unusual occurrence at Canada's newest, largest, most modern and least-used air terminal.

title: Chinese Leader Visits Nepal
description: President Li Xiannian of China arrived here tonight on the first visit to the Himalayan kingdom by a Chinese head of state. The trip, during which Mr. Li will hold talks with King Birendra, is the last leg of a tour that included Pakistan, Jordan and Turkey.

title: MAVERICK RESTAURANT reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: HIGBEE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Occidental's China Talks
description: China and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation are continuing negotiations on a $500 million coal venture, despite reports that talks have fallen through, Chinese officials said today.

title: Buyout Talks Seen at Logan
description: Jonathan Logan Inc., one of the apparel industry's largest producers, has scheduled a special board meeting today to consider a leveraged buyout of the company at $32 a share, according to Wall Street sources. Reports indicate that Richard Schwartz, chairman, will be a principal in the transaction, but he could not be reached for comment yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Pawtucket, R.I., on March 6 incorrectly described the role of the National Council of Churches in connection with a ruling by the Supreme Court that the city government had the right to own and sponsor a nativity scene at Christmastime. The council filed a brief as ''friend of the court'' supporting lower court opinions that the practice was unconstitutional.

title: Debt Issues
description: * American Home Finance Corp., a subsidiary of American Continental Corp., a Phoenix-based home building concern, is offering $18,955,000 in Government National Mortgage Association collateralized bonds with a coupon rate of 12 1/4 percent. Underwriters are Bacon Stifel Nicolaus.

title: Key Rates
description: Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE WORD FROM UPDIKE
description: WINNING the National Arts Club's Medal of Honor lured John Updike to New York, but not for long. The angular author said he came because he had never been inside the club's venerable Gramercy Park townhouse. He thought the house and the presentation dinner might be interesting, and afterward he said they were.

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Thurmond Will Seek6th Full Term in Senate
description: Senator Strom Thurmond, who has been a mainstay of South Carolina politics for more than four decades, announced today he would seek re-election to his sixth full term.

title: HARVEST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West German Replaces Maazel at Vienna Opera
description: Claus Helmut Drese of West Germany will replace Lorin Maazel as director of the Vienna State Opera in the 1986-87 season, the Ministry of Culture announced today.

title: McMullen Challenged
description: John McMullen , the principal owner of both the Devils and the Houston Astros, is facing the possibility of ouster as chairman of the baseball team. The Houston Post reported that a strong challenge had been mounted by minority shareholders who, the newspaper said, feared that he would try to increase his part of the stock in the Astros and their parent company, the Houston Sports Association, to 51 percent. McMullen now controls 34 percent and is able to count on backing from an additional 8 percent held by 3 minority owners.

title: FOR A HIGH-RISK BANK PREMIUM
description: Brokered bank deposits? Until a few years ago, few people knew about the money brokers who divide large sums into $100,000 bundles and deposit them in federally insured bank accounts. But now that the Government proposes to strangle this tiny industry, Wall Street is mounting an all-out defense. What's going on?

title: AMERICAN BLDING MAINTEANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
STATE'S HIGHEST COURT HEARS REPORTER 'SHIELD LAW' TEST
description: New York State's highest court today heard the first case to come before it testing the 13-year-old law designed to shield reporters from being forced to disclose confidential sources of information.

title: A SMORGASBORD OF BASKETBALL
description: For the basketball fan, it was a

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: Sales for the latest quarter and 6 months include nonrecurring insurance commission income of $765,985.

title: 5 Killed in Philadelphia Fire
description: Fire swept through a two-story row house in west Philadelphia tonight, killing five people and injuring five others, the authorities said.

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Andres Soriano Jr., 58, Dies; Was Philippine Industrialist
description: Andres Soriano Jr., a Philippine industrialist, died Sunday night at his home in Madrid, his office here announced today. He was 58 years old.

title: POLAND QUESTIONS 2 REPORTERS
description: Polish authorities today questioned two news correspondents - an American and a Briton - in the investigation of a human rights lawyer who is accused of ''slandering the state.''

title: Cocoa Output Gain Is Seen
description: The International Cocoa Organization today cut its estimate of the shortfall between world production and consumption for the 1983-84 season to 168,000 metric tons from 180,000 tons forecast in December.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-After a loss of $871,094 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $3,304,943. c-Includes income of $146,530 from discontinued operations. Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid July 1983.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $570,000 for the quarter and $826,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,010,000 for the quarter and $1,006,000 for the 9 months. d-Net loss

title: MAY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SALVADOR VOTE: RISING FEARS ON OUTCOME
description: Government and military officials and politicians of various persuasions are becoming increasingly concerned that next week's presidential elections will lead to new instability here. In the short term at least, these people say, the prospect is for increased tension between rightist and moderate elements and possibly between the civilian and military authorities. The danger is that this could lead to increased political violence or possibly even a military coup.

title: ALTAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Injunction Halts Phillips Dismissal
description: Acting on a request made by a group of N.B.A. referees, a judge of the Court of Common Pleas granted an injunction today that prohibits the National Association of Basketball Referees from dismissing Richie Phillips as its legal counsel.

title: HIGHER HURDLES FOR MR. MEESE
description: Continuing disclosures about Edwin Meese's financial affairs raise serious questions about his ability to observe the laws, much less enforce them. The Justice Department's announcement that it will investigate President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General for failing to report an interest-free loan rightly knocks Mr. Meese's confirmation off the fast track. But even if Mr. Meese satisfies the prosecutors that he has avoided illegality, he must still persuade an increasingly skeptical Senate Judiciary Committee that he meets a higher standard.

title: LABOR ENDORSEMENT ASSAILED
description: Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters union, said today that labor organizations that have endorsed Presidential contenders were performing ''a great disservice to the working men and women in America.''

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $253,000 for the quarter and year from foreign tax credits and a loss of $12,468,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $1,139,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $321,000 from foreign tax credits. d-After a loss of $3,095,000 from discontinued operations and a foreign tax credit of $808,000.

title: BOMAINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $608,000 for the quarter and $1,798,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a tax credit of $695,000 and a writeoff of an intangible asset of $1,705,000. d-Includes a tax credit of $798,000 and a writeoff of an intangible asset of $1,705,000.

title: TWO OLD PROS IN NEW FILM FOR T.V.
description: ''This story is mystory,'' said James Cagney. ''I liked the part because in many ways it tells what happened to me.''

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the year-ago quarter was 14 weeks in duration, and the latest year was 53 weeks compared to 52 weeks a year ago.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
ROCKCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results for 1983 have been restated to reflect the pooling-of-interests accounting for the acquisition of a subsidiary during 1983.

title: THE 2,615 REPORTS PROPOSAL
description: Representative Henry J. Hyde calls it his ''Want Not, Waste Not Act of 1984.''

title: CHANGES PROPOSED FOR COAL LEASING
description: Interior Secretary William P. Clark, responding to recent reports of flaws in the Federal coal leasing program, said today that he would make sweeping changes in the program.

title: QUEENS GRANDMOTHER WINS $10 MILLION LOTTO
description: A 54-year-old Queens grandmother was announced yesterday as the winner of a $10 million New York State Lottery - the largest unshared lottery prize ever in the United States - and said she had no dreams to explore, no fantasies about what she would do with the money.

title: LEBANESE LEADERS BICKER OVER NEW PROPOSAL FOR POLITICAL CHANGES
description: Lebanon's eight main factional leaders debated a new Syrian-sponsored proposal tonight for national reconciliation, but their talks collapsed into bickering when Christian leaders refused to make any substantial concessions to their Moslem compatriots, conference sources said.

title: Former Aide Sued By Media General
description: Media General Inc. and its subsidiary, Media General Broadcast Services, filed suits in Federal and state courts in Memphis against the subsidiary's former president, William B. Tanner, and others. Mr. Tanner was also dropped as a consultant to the subsidiary, said Alan S. Donnahoe, vice chairman and chief executive of Media General, a communications and financial services company based in Richmond.

title: HOMECOMING FOR NEW INDIAN ENVOY
description: For Kayatyani Shankar Bajpai, who has recently taken up his assignment as India's Ambassador to the United States, Washington is more than just another diplomatic posting.

title: Archer-Daniels
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company said it had filed a shelf registration covering $200 million of debt securities. The company, which is involved in soybean processing, corn refining and flour milling, said it would use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, including additional working capital, repayment of debt, capital expenditures and possible acquisitions of, or investments in, assets and other businesses.

title: REAGAN AN '84 DEWEY?
description: If President Reagan, like most of us, is more at home with simple arithmetic than with sociological statistics, he must wonder why anyone should think he will be a shoo-in next November.

title: YONKERS COUNCIL REBUFFS SCHOOL PLAN
description: The City Council tonight voted to withhold funds to put into action a school desegregation plan now before the Board of Education.

title: DR. ALFRED A. ANGRIST, EXPERT PATHOLOGIST AT TRIALS
description: Dr. Alfred A. Angrist, founder and retired chairman of the pathology department of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died of complications resulting from liver failure yesterday at the Montefiore Hospital Medical Center. He was 82 years old and lived in Beechhurst, Queens.

title: STOCKS DOWN 12.98
description: Major banks across the nation increased their prime lending rates a half a point yesterday, to 11 1/2 percent, the highest level since January 1983. It was the first change in the key rate since last August, and some economists and bankers predicted it could go substantially higher.

title: Compaq Price Cut
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation is preparing to cut the price on its portable computer, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: WORRIES PILING UP FOR THE ISLANDERS
description: With the playoffs approaching, the Islanders have lost two straight games, some of the players are complaining about being benched, and their great goal-scorer, Mike Bossy, is concerned that his shots don't have ''eyes'' lately.

title: BAGGING THE BROWN BAG MOB
description: but never of being a crook. Until now. Over the weekend, he was unmasked as a member of the Brown Bag Mob.

title: PRIME RATE SPURS 12.98 DOW DROP
description: Stock prices slumped yesterday in the slowest trading this year after most major banks increased their prime lending rate.

title: BATS FIND OFFSPRING EVEN IN CAVES CHAOS
description: FOR those who love bats, or are fascinated by them, there are no more dramatic displays than their nightly emergence from their caves in the Southwest. It is estimated that as many as 70 million bats live in some caves in Texas, and at dusk they emerge in a fluttering black cloud to hunt insects.

description: Mayor Koch has no first deputy

title: Bridge:Kathie Wei's Team Is Upset In the Knockout Semifinals
description: In a stunning upset here Sunday night, the top-seeded team was eliminated in the semifinal of the women's knockout team championship at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals.

title: 'ON THE WATERFRONT' ADAPTED FOR STAGE
description: ON THE WATERFRONT,'' the 1954 film classic about dockside corruption, directed by Elia Kazan, has a new life. Budd Schulberg has transformed the story into a play.

title: KERR PACES FLYERS' VICTORY OVER DEVILS
description: Tim Kerr, the Philadelphia forward, and New Jersey mistakes were the keys to the Flyers' success tonight as they defeated the Devils, 4-3.

title: JURY TOLD OF COBB ADMISSION
description: A Federal agent testified yesterday that in 1980, Ernie Cobb, the star of the Boston College basketball team in the 1978-79 season, ''admitted his involvement in point-shaving activity'' that season.

title: O'CONNOR BRINGS HUMILITY AND HUMOR TO A DAY OF PAGEANTRY
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Archbishop John J. O'Connor's homily at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as recorded by The New York Times:

title: COWBOYS SALE, 49ER PROPOSAL APPROVED
description: Owners and executives of the 28 National Football League teams completed a busy first day of their annual meetings today by resolving two major issues.

CHATHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAPITAL BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
COLLEGE FRESHMEN BETTER IN BASICS
description: A DETAILED picture is beginning to emerge of the men and women who planned to enroll in this year's college freshman class. One of the more striking findings is that they arrived at college last fall with a stronger background in mathematics, sciences and foreign languages, suggesting that the current national emphasis on such basic courses is already showing results.

title: SYNERGISTIC COMMUNICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Plan by U.S. Steel
description: The United States Steel Corporation will ask shareholders at its May 1 annual meeting to approve several steps that would defend the company against takeover attempts. U.S. Steel said it knew of no current takeover efforts.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Washington Bullets , at Landover, Md. This one features the second- and third-ranked rebounders in the National Basketball Association: Buck Williams of the Nets and Jeff Ruland of the Bullets.

title: The Start of the Debt
description: ''We're the fellows who first got the government in debt - for better or worse,'' J. Carter Bacot said proudly, pausing in front of a handwritten document that is part of an exhibition at the New York Public Library.

title: MCLAIN INDICTED IN DRUG CASE
description: Denny McLain, the last major league pitcher to win at least 30 games in a season, was charged with racketeering and narcotics violations in a Federal indictment unsealed here today.

title: UMET PROPERTIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on the Style page March 4, with an article about new party givers, misidentified the woman shown with Nicholas VerPlank Beavers. She is Lisa McGovern.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; G.E. Credit Corp. Fills 2 Top Posts
description: The General Electric Company has named Robert C. Wright president and chief executive officer and Gary C. Wendt executive vice president for financing operations of the General Electric Credit Corporation, a subsidiary that is one of the largest financial services and leasing companies.

title: Jersey Mortgage
description: Commonwealth Financial Group Inc. said it had signed an agreement to acquire the Jersey Mortgage Company of Elizabeth, N.J., for approximately $30 million.

title: GREY MARTEL HALL
description: Grey Martel Hall, who was an American banker in China between the world wars, died Feb. 11 at a hospital in Nacogdoches, Tex. He was 89 years old and lived in Nacogdoches.

title: ;  DuPont Official Named Bell Canada President
description: Robert J. Richardson, an executive vice president of the E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and a member of its executive committee and board of directors, has decided to go home again. Mr. Richardson, who was born in Ontario, will return to his native land to become president of Bell Canada Enterprises.

title: COMEGYS ADJUSTING TO DEPAUL
description: LINCOLN, Neb.

title: PSYCHOLOGY IS REVISING ITS VIEW OF WOMEN
description: WOMEN'S psychology, which Freud called ''a dark continent,'' is finally being widely and energetically explored.

title: ;  A Westinghouse Unit Offers Notes
description: The Westinghouse Credit Corporation announced the offering of $100 million of extendable senior notes due 1996 at an offering price of 99.75, with an interest rate of 11.875 percent through March 14, 1987.

title: Anderson's Drug View
description: Sparky Anderson , the 50-year-old manager of the Detroit Tigers, says that the hard drinking by baseball players in the old days makes today's drug situation in the major leagues look tame by comparison. Anderson is aware that several ballplayers have admitted to drug problems and that a few have even gone to jail.

title: MEESE INQUIRY WILL AFFECT TRIAL OF LAWMAKER
description: A Federal district judge here said today that she would sequester the jury in the trial of a Congressman charged with falsifying his financial disclosure statements because of publicity comparing the circumstances of his case with the financial dealings of Edwin Meese 3d.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PACT IRKS SOME BLACKS
description: South Africa's newly signed nonaggression treaty with Mozambique has left some blacks here angry and frustrated that the Government seems ready to talk with black revolutionaries beyond its borders but not with their equivalent figures at home.

title: RELIANCE STUDIES BID FOR QUAKER
description: The Reliance Insurance Company, which is controlled by Saul P. Steinberg, disclosed yesterday that it was considering whether to seek control of the Quaker State Oil Refining Corporation. Reliance also said it already holds 1,962,000 shares, or 8.9 percent, of the big Pennsylvania company and may seek enough additional stock to give it 20 percent.

title: TARO INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $359,000 on sales of fixed assets.

Nichols, president and chief executive of the Home Life Insurance Company.

description: Yet another United States Football League team appears ready to change hands.

description: b-Net income

title: CITY'S STAGE HERITAGE SHOWN
description: THURSDAY will mark the second anniversary of the day a steel wrecking ball swung into the Helen Hayes and Morosco theaters and demolished them to make way for the Marriott Marquis Hotel. But while that day saw the end of the two playhouses, it also sparked the beginning of a complicated and often contentious debate about how to save the remaining Broadway theaters.

title: Basques Burn Alien Trucks
description: Basque fishermen burned three foreign trucks today to protest a French Navy gunboat attack this month on two Spanish trawlers that were fishing illegally in Common Market waters, the police said. French truck drivers retaliated with a road blockade at the Spanish border, paralyzing traffic between the French town of Hendaye and San Sebastian.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: PERSONAL INCOME IS UP AND SPENDING OFF 0.7%
description: Americans' personal income rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in February, but for the first time in seven months, their spending dropped, by a like amount, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International Inc. , a health care company in Beverly Hills, Calif., said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell five acute-care hospitals to Healthcrest Inc., an Atlanta-based hospital management company, for $22.8 million in cash.

title: BRITISH DEMANDS CAUSE FRICTION IN EUROPEANS
description: A conference on the future of the European Common Market began here today and immediately ran into difficulties when Britain again demanded far-reaching changes in the way the 10-nation trade bloc works.

title: WaCanalStreet
description: A major water main ruptured under Canal Street at Broadway early this morning, flooding the intersection with a foot of water and forcing the authorities to stop traffic between Lafayette and Church Streets.

title: Sinn Fein Chief Recovers
description: Gerry Adams, head of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, Sinn Fein, who was wounded in a shooting attack last week, left the hospital today.

title: JERSEY STATE PANEL FINDS INADEQUACIES IN BOXING CONTROLS
description: Mismatches, a lack of medical controls and slipshod licensing and auditing procedures have become commonplace in boxing in New Jersey, according to a report released today by the State Commission of Investigation.

title: THE parade of chemicals that cause cancer seems endless
description: Today, the focus of public and regulatory attention is EDB, or ethylene dibromide, a pesticide that was widely used to fumigate grain, citrus fruit and soil until residues were detected in drinking water and food products.

description: Guards smashed the window of an automobile outside the White House tonight and arrested the driver after deciding she was behaving suspiciously, the Secret Service said.

Or Rawley going to St. Louis for Bruce Sutter, whose arrival would put Righetti back in the starting rotation.

Ten of those listed had no liquor license - and was he surprised! ''When we saw that list,'' he said, ''we felt it was necessary to prosecute.'' The terrible ten must stop it, or face fines and prison.

Several female Democratic activists are wearing buttons that say ''Jane Wyman was right,'' a reference to the actress who was divorced from President Reagan.

description: FOR major contributions to understanding the genetics of human cancer, Dr. Robert A. Weinberg of Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been named winner of the Bristol-Myers Award for Distinguished Achievement in Cancer Research, the company announced yesterday.

title: REAGAN CALLS SALVADOR AID FOES NAIVE
description: President Reagan, facing a Senate debate on his request for new military aid for El Salvador, today denounced as ''naive or downright phony'' those who express concern for human rights ''while pursuing policies that lead to the overthrow of less-than-perfect democracies by Marxist dictatorships.''

description: The Justice Department has begun an investigation to determine if the company in charge of building the 63d Street subway extension made any improper structural modifications, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: CONCERT: ZUCKERMAN
description: PINCHAS ZUKERMAN is an eminently capable violinist, always coolly professional, but often dispassionate. Still, as he proved at his Sunday afternoon concert at Carnegie Hall, even when Mr. Zukerman has little to say, he says it beautifully.

title: WAR IN GULF: NEW IMPASSE SEEMS LIKELY
description: The war between Iran and Iraq appears to United States and other Western intelligence sources to be near another impasse, with the Iranians unable to rupture the long Iraqi frontier and the Iraqis unable to exploit their defensive successes. It is possible, these sources said, that the Iranians, by combining their remaining regular forces and tens of thousands of raw but eager teen-age volunteers, will be able to pierce Iraqi defenses at some point. But reports from representatives of NATO countries with embassies in Teheran, the Iranian capital, say that offensives appear to strain Iran's limited logistical resources.

title: Semiconductor Review
description: The Defense Department is conducting a review of the National Semiconductor Corporation in the wake of the company's guilty plea to charges that it had violated Federal rules concerning the testing of electronic chips used in military equipment, a company spokesman said yesterday. The review could result in the company losing its military contracts - which account for about $66.7 million in sales in the 1983 fiscal year, which ended last May 31. This possibility was discounted by a National Semiconductor spokesman, who characterized the review as ''a normal review after the other occurrence.''

Mullen's three goals established a record for most goals in a season by a United States-born player. Mullen has 39 goals, one more than the previous mark set by Neil Broten on Minnesota in 1981-82.

description: Brig. Gen. James H. Stratton, a flood-control specialist and designer of dams and tunnels with the Army Corps of Engineers and then as a partner in a New York firm, died Friday at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 85 years old and lived in Washington.

title: LOOKING AT PERILS OF TOXICITY
description: THE cinema of contamination, which has grown timely enough to have engendered commercial hits such as ''The China Syndrome'' and ''Silkwood,'' has two more hard-hitting documentaries to add to its roster. Jacki Ochs's ''Secret Agent,'' which was shown at last year's New York Film Festival, details the illness and the indignation of Vietnam veterans who were exposed to Agent Orange, and contends that the manufacturers of this chemical withheld evidence of its toxicity from the United States Government. Disturbing as ''The Secret Agent'' is, its co-feature at the Film Forum, ''SL-1,'' is even tougher.

title: CONNELLY CONTAINERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENGLISH DESIGNER'S 'CLEAN SLATE' CLOTHES
description: The Katharine Hamnett collection, which began the English showings last Thursday, is one of a handful here that most accurately reflect the giant step forward London fashion has taken in the past two years.

description: Students and teachers at the Fashion Institute of Technology will present the Leonard Bernstein musical ''On the Town'' this week and next to celebrate the institute's 40th year.

description: Larry Speakes, the White House spokesman, said today that Edwin Meese 3d met as usual this morning with President Reagan and other top advisers and remained the Presidential counselor while the Justice Department investigated his finances.

title: SENATE'S ROLL-CALL ON SCHOOL PRAYER
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected a constitutional amendment on school prayer: FOR THE AMENDMENT - 56 Democrats - 19 Bentsen, Tex.Boren, Okla.

title: INTERNATIONAL HARVESTER IS PLANNING STOCK SALE
description: The International Harvester Company said today that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed secondary stock offering of 12.5 million common shares. It also said it did not expect to earn a profit in the current fiscal year, which ends Oct. 31.

title: ;  Dayton-Hudson Names Chairman of New Unit
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation announced plans yesterday to combine its Dayton's and Hudson's department store companies into a single department store operation with P. Gerald Mills as its chairman and chief executive.

title: Wayne State's Fencers Gain
description: Wayne State is to collegiate fencing now what U.C.L.A. was to basketball in the days of Coach John Wooden.

description: Picture captions in some editions of Business Day yesterday, with an article in the Business People column about the General Electric Credit Corporation, were reversed. Gary C. Wendt appeared at the left and Robert C. Wright at the right.

title: CHIRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Revenue figures represent contract revenues.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; ;  V.A. Home Loan Ceiling Up to 13%
description: Reflecting rising interest rates throughout the economy, the Veterans Administration said today that it was raising to 13 percent the interest-rate ceiling on home loans it guarantees. The rate change, which goes into effect on Wednesday, will raise the rate one-half percentage point from the 12 1/2 percent set Nov. 1.

title: ON THE FAILURES OF DRAFT REGISTRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S., STATE AT ODDS OVER BANKING LAWS
description: In a battle over who regulates banks, a Federal banking board has told its member banks in New York State that they do not have to comply with a new state law requiring banks to clear checks within a fixed number of days.

title: NEWS WATCHDOG GROUP TO VOTE ON ITS FUTURE
description: The National News Council, a private organization that sought to be journalism's watchdog, will vote Thursday either to disband or to suspend operations, according to Richard S. Salant, the organization's president.

title: JAPAN'S DEFENSE EFFORT
description: Japan's defense effort comes into sharp focus each year at budget time just before the fiscal year begins on April 1. The 1984 defense allocation represents only a 6.55 percent increase - less than was hoped for in Washington. Yet the United States has not complained or hectored the Japanese - and rightly so.

title: TOFU TIME reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from interest and distribution agreements.

HOSPITAL'S DATA FAULTED IN CARE OF TERMINALLY ILL
description: A special grand jury in Queens reported yesterday that it had uncovered ''shocking procedural abuses'' in the way a Forest Hills hospital kept secret its withholding of emergency resuscitation from terminally ill patients whose hearts or breathing failed.

title: COMGEN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-After a loss of $171,000 from discontinued operations.

title: New Delhi Accuses Sikh Leader of Sedition
description: The Indian Government accused the country's top Sikh leader, Harchand Singh Longowal, of sedition today and banned the main Sikh student union.

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $136,000 from the amortization of negative goodwill.

title: Drug Intimations
description: The man acting as the drug connection for the four Kansas City Royals who pleaded guilty of cocaine-related misdemeanors last year says that cocaine use is widespread in major league baseball. ''There's a whole lot more teams involved than just the Royals,'' Mark Liebel told The Kansas City Times. Mr. Liebel, who was sentenced on Monday to six years in a Federal prison for conspiring to distribute cocaine, had been identified as the target of the investigation that led to the guilty pleas of Willie Wilson , Willie Aikens , Jerry Martin and Vida Blue , all of whom were sentenced to three-month prison terms.

title: U.N. AND POLAND TALKING ON SOLIDARITY DETAINEES
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is carrying out talks with Polish authorities for the release from prison of leading members of the banned Solidarity movement and other human rights activists, according to officials here.

title: BROADWAY DEBATES TONY AWARD RULES
description: BROADWAY is divided over whether ''Painting Churches'' and ''And a Nightingale Sang . . .'' should be eligible for the 1984 Antoinette Perry Awards. Representatives of the shows will plead their case to the Tony administration committee on April 2, and petitions of support are circulating among the casts of Broadway productions.

title: Ft. Hays Wins N.A.I.A. Title
description: Edgar Eason, whose steal and driving layup tied the game at 44- 44 at the end of regulation, sank both field goals in overtime to help Fort Hays State defeat Wisconsin-Stevens Point, 48-46, tonight for the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics basketball title.

title: Greedy for Power
description: If a giant oil reserve were discovered under the Pentagon, would the Government give it away to voters who live in nearby Maryland and Virginia? That, in effect, is what President Reagan and many members of Congress want to do with the more than $400 million worth of electricity generated annually by Hoover Dam. The last hope of stopping that 30- year sign-away of a public resource rests with the House.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Offer for Logan Of $29 a Share
description: Richard J. Schwartz, the chairman of Jonathan Logan Inc., and an investment group yesterday offered 29 a share, or about $205 million, for the large apparel company. Logan's board named a committee of outside directors to consider the proposal, which would take the form of a leveraged buyout.

title: The Debt Bomb Ticks
description: Britain in Dickens's time had a simple remedy for debtors: prison. Though morally gratifying, this was economic madness. Debtors denied a chance to produce can hardly repay their creditors. The lesson applies today to the otherwise different issue of third-world debt. Punishing poor or overextended peoples by burdening them with interest rates and repayments that exceed their income may be rough justice, but it damages creditors just as much.

title: COPLEY PLACE ADDS NEW DIMENSION TO BOSTON'S BACK BAY AREA
description: Copley Place is the kind of undertaking this city, which cherishes the buildings that symbolize its past and America's beginnings, is not known for.

title: AMERICAN JEWISH GROUPS FAULTED ON A REPORT ON HOLOCAUST VICTIMS
description: After two and a half years of studying a question that has weighed on the minds of American Jews for four decades, a group of prominent American Jews has concluded that the country's major Jewish organizations did not do all that they could have to save victims of the Holocaust.

title: Accounts

title: Mutiny Is Reported Among Afghan Troops
description: A Western diplomat said here today that Afghan soldiers had mutinied in and around Kabul, fought their officers and defected in large numbers to Moslem guerrillas in a revolt against a Government decision to increase their period of military service.

description: The Lebanese national unity talks ended in failure today after the country's eight main factional leaders were unable to agree on more than postponing a discussion of their differences into the indefinite future.

description: A former Salvadoran military official who recently implicated high-ranking Salvadoran officials and civilians in acts of terrorism was promised $50,000 by a group of critics of Reagan Administration policies in Central America if he would speak out.

TRIANGLE MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
LONG-TERM BONDS RISE A BIT
description: Prices of long-term bonds firmed slightly while short-term interest rates continued to rise in light trading in the credit markets yesterday.

title: Thousands Give To Kienast Fund
description: Thousands of people moved by the suicide of William Kienast, father of quintuplets, have donated more than $40,000 since a fund was set up to help the family.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Job Cuts at Atari Headquarters
description: Atari Inc., the video game and home computer unit of Warner Communications, said it was laying off about 200 white-collar workers from its Sunnyvale, Calif., headquarters in an effort to ''focus our marketing and development efforts.'' The company said it had decided to cease its direct- mail software sales operations and to trim administration in several departments.

title: A POPULATION PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: HANDEL'S 'SOLOMAN' ORATORIO
description: THERE always is a strong public demand for entertainment disguised as religion. Shamans, medieval authors of mystery plays and television preachers all have been privy to that formula for success. Great composers, too, have understood this human need, and perhaps none exploited it more brilliantly than Handel, whose oratorios fulfilled - apparently still fulfill - the double requirement of pleasure and piety. However, his ''Solomon,'' which Musica Sacra presented Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall, would be a better example of the type if it were more consistently entertaining and more religious.

title: A PORTRAIT IS SPURNED IN CALIFORNIA
description: Amid cheers and sneers, a portrait of former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has been ordered hung on the third floor landing of the refurbished Capitol, far from more dignified portraits of California's other governors.

title: 'M*A*S*H*' IS REALLY LEAVING KOREA
description: SEOUL, South KoreaThe Korean War, at least the war according to ''M*A*S*H,'' is finally winding down in Korea. The end is due in early April, and as far as the South Korean Government is concerned, it comes none too soon.

title: OPERA: 'MANON LESCAUT' BY PUCCINI AT THE MET
description: IT is difficult to get too emotionally attached to Manon Lescaut

title: Raymark Cutback
description: The Raymark Corporation said it plans to reduce its staff by 40 because of reduced sales and to sell its headquarters here. Raymark, which makes friction materials, industrial products and rivets, said its headquarters would move to smaller facilities in the area.

title: MITTERRAND LEAVING PROBLEMS BEHIND ON VISIT TO U.S. TODAY
description: President Francois Mitterrand, pressing a policy of economic austerity, has become the least popular French President since the Fifth Republic was established in 1958.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: NEW YORKERS ETC.
description: WHAT you do, said George Friedman, is get the right people in the right place at the right time. Why you do it, said George Friedman, is to add image, communicate prestige and enhance status.

title: MAKE MERCHANTS GIVE A DISCOUNT FOR CASH
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the New York Philharmonic in some editions yesterday misidentified the violinist Kyung- Wha Chung. She is the sister of the conductor Myung-Whun Chung.
