description: Hundreds of blow-dryers whirred at

title: WINE TALK
description: ALONG about the middle of September each year, eight Jewish wine makers board a plane in New York and head for California. There is no shortage of wine makers in California, but this crew is special. They are on their way to crush grapes for kosher wine that will be made here in New York by the Royal Kedem Winery.

title: CONCERT: POMERIUM MUSICES
description: SEVERAL years ago Joshua Rifkin gave us a Bach B minor Mass with one singer on a part and cited as his justification the tiny choir that Bach himself had at his disposal. Pomerium Musices followed the same path at Symphony Space Monday night with music by the Bach family.

title: Profits Off By 0.8% in 4th Quarter
description: The after-tax profits of United States corporations declined slightly in the fourth quarter of 1983 from the previous quarter, the Government reported today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AUTOMATIC VAUDEVILLE. Essays on Star Turns. By John Lahr. 241 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: CITY LOFT BOARD CHIEF IS APPOINTED BY KOCH
description: Jorge L. Batista, a former first assistant state attorney general, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Koch as chairman of the nine-member Loft Board, which regulates residential loft dwellings in the city.

title: TEMCO HOME HEALTH CARE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $14,816 from the termination of a pension plan.

title: DOW CLIMBS 4.39, TO 1,175.77
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in more active trading following the sharp selloff on Monday when rising interest rates weakened the list.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Ice Fells 2 Maine TV Towers
description: Two broadcast towers collapsed today under the weight of ice, and chunks of ice rained down from two other towers, knocking seven television and radio stations off the air statewide. No injuries were reported, but officials said damage was heavy. The two towers that collapsed were a 740-foot tower for station WVII-TV and a 550-foot tower serving WABI-TV, both in Bangor.

title: THE DANCE: 'IN CONCERT'
description: JENNIFER SACHS and Brenda Brilliant, who shared a program called ''In Concert'' on Monday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, could get their dances started. But they had trouble keeping those dances going in an interesting manner.

title: U.S. SAID TO DROP JORDAN ARMS SALE
description: President Reagan has decided to withdraw the offer to sell advanced antiaircraft missiles to Jordan and Saudi Arabia because of overwhelming Congressional opposition, Congressional sources said tonight.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CAMPAIGN PLANES AS STUDY IN CONTRASTS
description: Everyone calls him Gary, including his staff, the swarm of reporters who travel with him, flight attendants and strangers who shake his hand.

title: HART 2ND AFTER STIFF BATTLE; JACKSON,3RD, RUNS STRONGLY
description: Walter F. Mondale defeated Gary Hart in the Democratic Presidential primary in Illinois tonight, achieving a hard-fought victory he needed to put new life into his candidacy.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BEIRUT IS 2 SEPARATE WORLDS
description: An academic at the American University of Beirut once gave a test to young Moslems in West Beirut and young Christians in East Beirut.

title: Jersey Treasurer Sworn In
description: Michael M. Horn, New Jersey's Banking Commissioner, was sworn in today as the new State Treasurer. Justice Marie Garibaldi of State Supreme Court administered the oath of office in a ceremony in the Senate Chamber. The 44- year-old Mr. Horn, who lives in Morris Township, had served as Banking Commissioner since the Kean adminstration took office in 1982.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $157,000 for the quarter and $414,000 for the 6 months.

title: PHYSICIANS INSURANCE COMPANY (OHIO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Canada's Campaign
description: The Canadian national walk, Canadians joke, is south. To equalize that flow, the Government is starting a campaign to lure United States tourists north.

title: Iraqi Planes Attack Iranians Near Basra MANAMA, Bahrain, March 20 (Reuters) - Iraq said today that its jets and helicopter gunships had attacked Iranian positions east of the southern Iraqi port of Basra. Iran said it shot down an Iraqi MIG-23.
description: In Baghdad, the daily high command communique said Iraqi air attacks inflicted heavy losses on Iranian troop concentrations in positions in the east Basra sector.

title: SHAMIR PLANS TACTICS AS ISRAEL NEARS ELECTION
description: A move toward early parliamentary elections gained momentum today as Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir met with leaders of his governing coalition to consider tactics and timing.

title: Stock Trading From Home
description: Fidelity Brokerage Services Inc., the discount brokerage arm of Fidelity Investments, said it is introducing a service permitting customers to enter buy and sell orders using almost any personal computer equipment.

title: INTERMETCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $154,000.

title: 70 OLD-MASTER DRAWINGS TO BE SOLD
description: Seventy drawings from the Chatsworth Collection, reputed to be the finest private collection of old-master drawings in the world, will be sold at auction this summer in London.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a net gain of $2.8 million, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of an investment in Stokely-VanCamp common stock. c-Includes an $8.2 million provision for writedown of Burger King assets. The year-ago share earnings were restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split, effected by means of a 100 percent stock dividend, in November 1983.

title: EAST GERMAN DEFECTORS IN WEST
description: The niece of East Germany's Prime Minister and her family, who took refuge in the West German Embassy in Czechoslovakia on Feb. 24 demanding permission to travel to the West, arrived in West Germany today, officials said.

title: FDP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Cobb Admits Getting $1,000
description: Ernie Cobb, the star of the Boston College basketball team in the 1978-79 season, insisted yesterday he had not been part of a game-fixing conspiracy to benefit gamblers that season, even though he admitted taking $1,000 from a man who was later convicted of being in the conspiracy.

title: 2 Builders Guilty Of Tax Evasion
description: A couple that operate one of the city's largest construction companies pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that their company evaded income taxes, cheated an employees' welfare fund and helped employees illegally obtain unemployment benefits.

title: 60- MINUTE GOURMET
description: AMONG the herbs and spices I have developed a taste for since coming to this country, a particular favorite is fresh ginger. When I arrived in New York more than 40 years ago it could not be found anywhere but Chinatown; now it has become commonplace.

title: ADVERTISING
description: 2 New Tasks From Nestle

title: 'MR. ROBERTS,' A LIVE BROADCAST
description: TELEVISION will probably always retain a soft spot in its commercialized heart for the live production. It is a reminder of the early days when owning an expensive television set was chiefly a status symbol of the middle class and producers could cater to the presumably elevated tastes of this audience. The resulting ''golden age'' was top-heavy with dramatic presentations, nearly all of them broadcast live because of the new medium's technological limitations.

title: CROCKER BANK GETS NEW CHIEF
description: Frank V. Cahouet, vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Security Pacific Corporation, yesterday was named chairman and chief executive of the Crocker National Bank. Both banking companies are based in California, Crocker in San Francisco and Security Pacific in Los Angeles.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $481,030 for the quarter and $710,189 for the 9 months. c-Net income after a loss of $16,278 from discontinued operations. d-After a loss of $75,538 from discontinued operations.

title: Economic Scene; A Kind Word For Insiders
description: ''THE butcher, the baker, the candlestick maker.'' That's the pet phrase that the chief of enforcement at the Securities and Exchange Commission, John M. Fedders, uses to describe the scope of his agency's highly visible campaign against insider trading.

title: THE CITY
description: Drug Drive Hailed

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Sally Merrick, Former Official In Bronx Prosecutor's Office
description: Sally Merrick, a former assistant district attorney for Bronx County and the first woman to become a director of the county's bar association, died in her sleep Monday at her home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. She was 76 years old.

title: Firestone Tire Plans Divestiture
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said its board had approved a plan to divest the company of its businesses in steel products, phone products and passenger-restraint systems. It said the combined sales of the three businesses are about $450 million a year.

title: COMMERCIAL OIL & GAS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
CAKE AND COOKIE MOLDS
description: AUTHENTIC Scottish shortbread is not widely known in this country. The airy vanilla cake that is usually served in the dish called strawberry shortcake is a far cry from the real thing. In Scotland, shortbread is eaten all year round and it is de rigueur at such festive occasions as Christmas, weddings, birthdays and the like.

title: MAYOR WILL NOT GIVE UP BROWN-BAGGING OF WINE
description: Forced to choose between law and order and ''a little bargain,'' Mayor Koch served notice on state liquor officials yesterday that the price of wine and ''the cause of freedom'' were conspiring to lead him outside the law.

title: Dupree Responds
description: The Jacksonville Bulls gave Marcus Dupree of the New Orleans Breakers a sharp needling about his brief stay in college in pregame radio advertising for their United States Football League game in Jacksonville on Monday night. The rookie running back, who had dropped out of the University of Oklahoma and Southern Mississippi in the last year, signed a five-year contract worth a reported $6 million with the Breakers earlier this month.

title: WARSAW CONCESSION REPORTED IN DISPUTE ON SCHOOL CRUCIFIXES
description: The Minister of Religious Affairs reportedly announced a limited concession today when he met with a Roman Catholic bishop to discuss the dispute over the display of crucifixes in public schools.

title: TOROMONT INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results were restated to exclude discontinued operations.

title: MARS STORES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $125,000.

title: COURT SHUNS U.S. PRICE-FIXING VIEW
description: The Supreme Court, rejecting the Administration's invitation to relax the prohibition against vertical price-fixing, today upheld a $10.5 million antitrust judgment against the Monsanto Company for conspiring with some of its distributors to fix resale prices.

title: HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income includes a tax credit of $35,000 and a gain of $118,000 from an accounting change. Year-ago revenues include a gain of $537,400 from the sale of assets.

title: NEWEST CITY MEETING PLACES ARE IN COMPUTERS
description: There is something odd about the Pub, a popular meeting place on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. No drinks are served. It is open day and night, but is usually so crowded that no one can get in. You cannot reach it by taxi, on the subway or on foot.

title: 7.2% RISE ESTIMATED FOR G.N.P.
description: The nation's economy, in a surprisingly strong performance, is growing at a rate of 7.2 percent a year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: WHEN SOUP AT LUTECE WAS $2.25
description: NOT long ago I was invited to dine in one of Manhattan's fancier restaurants. Four of us were at the table; our host was a well-off man about town, which proved a good thing: When the bill arrived, it was about $300 before tips. That tab, of course, could have been equaled or exceeded in a score of similarly luxurious dining spots in this city. The meal, it must be said, was excellent. I had sauteed foie gras as an appetizer, roast pheasant with figs for a main course, a selection of sherbets for dessert and coffee. We had a round of drinks and consumed two bottles of wine, a M^acon-Lugny (one of the best and least expensive white wines from France) priced at $20 and a California cabernet sauvignon at $30.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
LILCO HEAD, IN WASHINGTON, PLEADS FOR AID ON SHOREHAM
description: The chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company said today that Congress must throw the financially troubled utility an emergency life preserver if it is to open the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: LAUTENBERG DROPS IN, VIA CABLE TV
description: In an experiment that could alter the relationship between politicians and constituents, Senator Frank R. Lautenberg spent an hour talking with people in their living rooms last night - without leaving a television studio.

title: U.S. Stork on Decline
description: The breeding population of the stork is being added to the list of endangered species by the Fish and Wildlife Service. The American wood stork, or mycetia Americana, or wood ibis, is found in Florida, Georgia, South Carolina and Alabama.

title: SALVADOR RIVALS FAVOR REBEL TALKS
description: Two of the three leading candidates in El Salvador's presidential race say that if elected they will open a ''dialogue'' with the left to bring the insurgents into the electoral process and end the four- year-old civil war. The proposals are more comprehensive than any offered by Government officials and politicians in the past.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
BOLD EFFORTS OF GOV. ANAYA MEET REALITY IN NEW MEXICO
description: The plans of Gov. Toney Anaya of New Mexico to be a strong Governor leading a bold new social program are being frustrated in his second year in office.

title: ON THE FARMS OF PORTUGAL, REVOLUTION IS IN RETREAT
description: South of the River Tagus, the plateau of the Alentejo sweeps east all the way to the Spanish border and south to the Algarve, an undulating plain of stripped ocher-red cork trees and twisted olive trees, rocky crags and baking, whitewashed villages.

title: GARRY WINOGRAND, INNOVATOR IN PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Garry Winogrand, whose animated, snapshotlike pictures helped change the nature of photography over the last 20 years, died Monday in Mexico, where he had gone for treatment of cancer. He was 56 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Herald of Spring

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Year-ago results are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in July 1983.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: FOR Ruth, a broadcaster in her 50's with a flashy smile, the 13 artificial teeth that were implanted in her upper jaw five years ago have transformed her life.

title: AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: High Court Hears Case On N.C.A.A. TV Rules
description: The Supreme Court of the United States heard arguments today on whether the National Collegiate Athletic Association's exclusive control of college football telecasts violates Federal antitrust law.

title: Senate Picks Members To Serve as Delegates
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale picked up nine delegates and Senator Gary Hart of Colorado two delegates today as Senate Democrats chose the senators they will send as delegates to the Democratic National Convention.

title: Switzer Trial Opens
description: The trial of a civil lawsuit brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Barry Switzer and six of his friends has opened in a Federal court in Oklahoma City. The S.E.C. charges that Switzer, the Oklahoma football coach, and the other defendants used insider information to earn a profit of $600,000 on Phoenix Resources Company stock for which they had paid $1.5 million less than a week before.

title: BIG TREMOR ROCKS CENTRAL ASIA AREA
description: A powerful earthquake centered near the ancient city of Bukhara rocked Soviet Central Asia early today, the press agency Tass said. It said some buildings were destroyed and residents required assistance, but it gave no report on casualties.

title: SOVIET TANKER DAMAGED BY MINE LAID BY REBELS IN NICARAGUAN PORT
description: The Soviet oil tanker Dulker hit a mine today that had been laid by rebels in one of Nicaragua's biggest ports, critically injuring five crewmen and badly damaging the ship, a Defense Ministry communique said.

title: U.S.I.A. AIDE'S ROLE IN BLACKLIST CITED
description: A Senate committee report says ''it seems hard to believe'' the explanations by a United States Information Agency official of his role in compiling an agency blacklist.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Comparable year-ago results were not available because the company changed from a fiscal year ended April 30 to a calendar year.

title: AIR TRAFFIC SHIFTED
description: The rehabilitation of a major runway at Kennedy International Airport will cause the rerouting of air traffic over surrounding communities through the summer, according to Port Authority officials.

title: Grey Unit May Get Chicago Sun-Times
description: After a 10-year relationship with D'Arcy MacManus Masius, Chicago, The Chicago Sun-Times is probably going to assign its account to Grey North, the local subsidiary of Grey Advertising, New York. Another subsidiary, Grey, Lyon & King, is ad agency for many of the Rupert Murdoch properties - a group The Sun- Times has joined.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: ONE LEADER CALLS FOR RETRIBUTION, OTHERS FOR ACCORD ON PRAYER ISSUE
description: Moral Majority called yesterday for retribution at the polls against senators who helped defeat the proposed constitutional amendment that would have permitted organized, spoken prayer in public schools.

title: Torch Dispute Is Ended
description: Los Angeles Olympic organizers have reached agreement with Greek officials to end a controversy over sponsorship of the the Olympic torch relay that is to be run across the United States before the Games this summer. The announcement of the agreement, between the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee and the Hellenic Olympic Committee, came at simultaneous news conferences in Los Angeles and Athens today.

title: Two New I.B.M. Display Terminals
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced two display terminals that hook into several of the company's largest computer systems.

title: SLALOM TO MISS WENZEL
description: Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein rallied to capture a women's slalom race today and maintain pressure on Erica Hess of Switzerland, the overall World Cup leader. Miss Wenzel earned 17 points for a total of 238, and trails Miss Hess by 9.

title: WHEN RUNNING IN PAIRS LEADS TO PAIRING OFF
description: PHIL WINEGARNER and Laura Leale were running in the New York Marathon last October when Mr. Winegarner realized that he wasn't going to reach the finish line. But he didn't drop out immediately. He had a mission to complete, and right there, in the middle of the Pulaski Bridge, he asked Miss Leale to marry him.

title: SAW AQUINO BLEEDING ON RAMP, GUARD SAYS
description: A private security guard who said he was at the airport when Benigno S. Aquino was slain last summer testified today that he saw the opposition leader fall to the tarmac from an airline staircase with blood on his back.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's the largest drug raid ever in the world. Never has anyone been found with that much cocaine.

title: DENVER BRONCOS ARE SOLD
description: The second day of the National Football League's annual meetings began today with the surprising disclosure that Edgar F. Kaiser, the owner of the Denver Broncos, had agreed to sell the majority interest in the team, about 60 percent, to Patrick Bowlen, a Canadian attorney.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Yankees, at St. Petersburg, Fla. In this first meeting of the spring between the New York teams, the Mets will take a look at the pitchers Ron Darling, Tom Gorman and Doug Sisk.

title: Some Deft Work Outside the Ring
description: Emanuel Steward, the manager of both Thomas Hearns and Mike McCallum, thinks he has maneuvered cleverly enough to place both his 154- pound division fighters in very favorable circumstances.

title: Real Estate; 2 Midtown Facelifting Projects
description: DEVELOPERS at two midtown locations have undertaken multimillion-dollar renovation projects to upgrade office buildings that have not yet reached even middle age but that seemed out of date and in need of major facelifts to attract more prestigious and higher- paying tenants.

title: GARTH TAKES ROLE IN MONDALE DRIVE
description: Walter F. Mondale, acknowledging the importance of a victory over Senator Gary Hart in the New York primary, has approved a major, if temporary, shift in command in his Presidential campaign.

title: PRETORIA OBJECTS TO HAVANA ACCORD
description: The South African Government objected today to a phrase in a joint communique issued Monday by Cuba and Angola setting out terms for a Cuban pullout from the former Portuguese colony. The Government's position seemed to put in jeopardy South Africa's promised withdrawal of troops from southern Angola.

title: BULLETS DEFEAT NETS
description: The Bullets' explanation for their 99-91 victory over the Nets was simple. With their top scorer sidelined, the rest of the Bullets had to lift the level of t their game to win.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PERCY WINS G.O.P. PRIMARY IN BID FOR 4TH SENATE TERM
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, won the Illinois Republican primary today in his drive for re-election to a fourth term in the Senate.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
POLICE PLAN SPECIAL HOMICIDE SQUAD
description: Acting after a flawed police investigation in Queens sent an innocent man to prison for more than two years, the New York City Police Department plans to establish a squad of detectives to handle only homicides.

title: ; THE FORGOTTEN WOMEN FARMERS OF AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Oil Demand Rise Seen
description: World oil demand is expected to rise by 1.5 million to 2 million barrels a day during the next three years, Kuwait's oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah was quoted as saying today by a local newspaper. He said output by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was expected to rise by 1 million to 1.5 million barrels a day during the same period.

title: LTV Contract
description: The AM General Corporation, a maker of specialty government vehicles that is owned by the LTV Corporation, received a $178.5 million contract from the Army for utility trucks, the Defense Department said. Separately, C3 Inc. was given a $69.9 million Navy contract for computer systems and software.

title: Mondale Slips to Second In the Mississippi Count
description: Walter F. Mondale slipped to second place behind a large uncommitted vote today in the continuing count of votes cast Saturday for delegate seats in Mississippi,

title: Palm Beach Sets Access For the Handicapped
description: The Palm Beach County Commission today passed an ordinance requiring that all new homes, hotels and motels be made accessible to handicapped people.

title: MAGNETIC TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Balboni Is Hitting for Royals
description: Steve Balboni, once a member of the Yankees' Columbus commuting club, instilled some cheer today into the once-potent Kansas City Royals, who are trying to restore the brightness to their royal blue uniforms.

title: 6 EASTERN STATES SUE E.P.A. OVERACID RAIN
description: Six Northeastern states, led by New York, filed a suit against the Federal Government today alleging failure to curb acid rain.

title: JONNY, 18, IS DEAD. STRANGERS BEAT HIM WITH A BAT.
description: I spent 18 years as an older sister, a friend, a holder of secrets. Now, Jonny is dead. He was the victim of a brutal and senseless beating by two strangers, people who robbed adulthood from a happy, sensitive teenager because of their own personal suffering.

title: RULING SET OFF FISHING BATTLE
description: George Hugo Boldt, a retired Federal district judge who wrote a far-reaching decision on Indian economic rights and served a stormy term as President Nixon's wage controller, died Sunday at the American Lake Veterans Administration Hospital near Lakewood, Wash. He was 80 years old and lived in Tacoma.

title: Medical School Closed On Island in Caribbean
description: The University of St. Lucia School of Medicine, a financially troubled medical school on that Caribbean island, has closed after less than six months in operation.

title: Rumor Lifts Disney Stock
description: Walt Disney Productions' stock climbed $2.25 a share, to $61, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as rumors circulated that the company might be a takeover target of Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher. The rumors, however, were flatly denied by Luther Marr, vice president of Disney, the Burbank, Calif., entertainment and recreation company. Mr. Marr said that Disney had had no contact with Mr. Murdoch and that reports that he would make an offer for the company were ''pure rumors and speculation.'' Mr. Murdoch, owner of the News Corporation of America, could not be reached for comment. Analysts said they doubted Disney would be a takeover target of Mr. Murdoch because of what it would cost - about $2.6 billion - and because the company had indicated that it would fight any takeover attempt.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 21, 1984 International
description: Lebanon's unity talks ended in failure as the nation's eight main factional leaders postponed discussions of their differences indefinitely. Delegates said a major reason for the breakdown was the refusal of the Christian leaders to give the Moslem majority more power. (Page A1, Column 3.)

title: AMENDMENT DRIVE ON SCHOOL PRAYER LOSES SENATE VOTE
description: The Republican-controlled Senate today rejected President Reagan's proposed constitutional amendment to permit organized spoken prayer in the public schools.

title: SCREEN: 'MUSICAL PASSAGE'
description: MUSICAL PASSAGE,'' directed and photographed by Jim Brown (''The Weavers: Wasn't That a Time!''), is a feature-length documentary that beautifully, and without seeming effort, translates the film maker's admiration and affection for his subject into dramatic, moving images.

title: GOURMET RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
TOP CHICAGO RACE IS FOR WARD BOSS
description: Forget Mondale. Forget Hart. Forget Jackson. Even forget the Senate races.

title: FROM VIETNAM, SUBTLE MIX OF FLAVORS
description: WHEN Huynh Qui Nanh became a United States citizen two years ago, he changed his name to Martin Wynn. It was both a tribute to his American sponsor, a Lutheran minister, and a recognition of the irreversible distance he had traveled since leaving Saigon on April 27, 1975.

title: PANDA AND PARTNER MATE
description: Ling-Ling, the giant panda, rebounding from a near fatal kidney infection, spent Monday mating with her partner, Hsing-Hsing.

title: The Medical Budget
description: Officials of the State University of

title: Unhappy Candelaria
description: The long-standing uneasiness between the Pittsburgh Pirates and John Candelaria is turning more severe again. The latest dispute cropped up at the Pirates' Florida training camp, where Candelaria, a left-handed pitcher, said that Dan Galbreath , the club's president, had promised to seek a trade but that ''nothing has happened - he did not keep his word.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A Manila dispatch yesterday on the death of Andres Soriano Jr., a Philippine industrialist, omitted a survivor. A third son, Andres Soriano 3d, also survives him.

title: ROLE IN EXPORT CONTROLS EXPANDED FOR PENTAGON
description: President Reagan has decided to give the Defense Department the advisory authority it has been seeking to try to stop the diversion to the Soviet Union of computers and other American- made high-technology products exported to non-Communist industrial countries. The department already has such an advisory role regarding exports to Communist countries.

title: Niagara Mohawk Gets 4.9% Increase
description: Niagara Mohawk Power was granted a 4.9 percent electric-rate increase today by the Public Service Commission.

title: GAINS FOR HART ARE SEEN IN NEW YORK
description: Two weeks before the New York Democratic Presidential primary, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado appears to be picking up more supporters in the state from the ranks of fallen contenders than either former Vice President Walter F. Mondale or the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Another Aide Leaves Amway
description: An Amway Corporation vice president said today that he will retire Friday, but that his departure is ''not particularly'' connected to a continuing management shake-up.

title: Board in Yonkers Backs School Plan
description: The Board of Education voted 8 to 1 tonight to approve as ''educationally sound'' a school desegregation plan that the City Council had refused to finance.

title: A SPOTLIGHT LIFE FOR YOUNG BOXER
description: In the center of the dressing room, Mark Breland turned idly on his spindly legs and spun himself in a lazy circle. The other boxers studied him. They watched as he let his long, thin arms go limp and as he slowly shook the stiffness from his narrow shoulders. A song with an angry rhythm played on his big radio.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: REAGAN AND MEESE
description: The fuss in the Senate these days over Ed Meese's memory and finances draws attention to a more important question. This is how President Reagan used his power of appointment to nominate Mr. Meese in the first place.

title: PENNSYLVANIA STUDYING FIXES
description: About 20 jockeys have been subpoenaed to testify before a state grand jury in Pennsylvania that will begin hearing evidence next week about attempted bribery and race-fixing at Keystone Race Track and Penn National Race Course, according to Clifford L. Wickman, the president of the Thoroughbred Racing Protective Bureau.

title: THE BLACK AND WHITE WASHINGTON
description: Statistically, Washington is a black city. Nearly three-quarters of the population of 650,000 and 93 percent of the public school enrollment is black.

East German in Moscow
description: East Germany's Defense Minister, Gen. Heinz Hoffmann, held talks today with Konstantin U. Chernenko, the Soviet leader, and Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov, the official press agency Tass reported. It said Mr. Chernenko and General Hoffmann, who is in Moscow at the head of a military delegation, reviewed the ''military-political situation'' in Europe, but did not elaborate. Tass said General Hoffmann and Marsshal Ustinov met separately.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,500,000 for the quarter and $16,150,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $2,050,000 for the quarter and $9,850,000 for the year.

title: SHAKE-UP AT KOREAN AIR LINES
description: Several serious incidents, dominated by last September's shooting down of a passenger plane in which 269 people died, have led to a series of shake-ups at Korean Air Lines.

CHRISTINE MCVIE: SINGLE IN TOP 10, NEW ALBUM
description: -10 single, ''Got a Hold on Me,'' has a comfortably familiar sound and feel, as well it might. Miss McVie has been a key member of Fleetwood Mac since 1971, and her singing and keyboard stylings helped make this band's ''Rumours'' one of the best-selling albums of all time, with sales of more than 15 million.

title: Ads by Democrats to Raise Ethical Questions on Meese
description: The Democratic party is producing television commercials focusing on what it calls ''ethical and moral'' violations of the Reagan Administration and calling attention to the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d to be Attorney General, according to Representative Tony Coelho, Democrat of California.

description: b-Net income

title: ALVARADO IS SAID TO DISCUSS RESIGNING WITH BOARD
description: Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado met privately for more than two hours yesterday with his lawyer and the Board of Education to discuss terms for his possible resignation, but the board rejected the Chancellor's proposals, according to city and school officials.

OQUENDO WINNING METS' SHORTSTOP JOB
description: Manager Dave Johnson, who has yet to announce his starting middle infield, is dropping hints to indicate that Jose Oquendo has won the job at shortstop, with Wally Backman and Ron Gardenhire sharing time at second base and Brian Giles available for a trade.

title: Oregon Rules On 2 Plants
description: The Oregon Supreme Court ruled today that 11 Oregon cities and public utility districts acted legally in 1976 when they agreed to help finance two nuclear plants in Washington state.

title: RESTAURANT PRICES: WHY ARE THEY SO HIGH?
description: WHEN a restaurant called the Palace opened on East 59th Street nine years ago it immediately gained a reputation as the country's most expensive dining spot. Its $50 prix-fixe dinner (not counting wine, tip and tax) prompted a hue and cry from some diners, who maintained that no meal could be worth so much money; one restaurant reviewer termed the price vulgar. The Palace eventually lowered its prices slightly and survived until earlier this year.

title: Manila's Plea on Sugar
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has asked the United States to increase its annual import quota of Philippines sugar by 100,000 tons, to 440,000 tons, the Government said today. Officials said the increase would help ease the country's foreign exchange crisis.

description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation has promoted John Tatta to be chairman and chief executive and William J. Bell Jr. to be president and chief operating officer.

description: A West German automobile mechanic was ordered held without bond today after he reportedly attempted to buy military secrets from an undercover agent for delivery to East German intelligence.

At the close, the spot March contract was down 14/32 for the day, at 69 7/32, after having ranged between 70 10/32 and 69 3/32. The Ginnie Mae contract for June delivery fell 11/32, to 68 17/32.

description: In Manhattan eating circles some years are worse than others. Last year was especially awful. That was the Year of the Goat Cheese.

description: NOT many creatures can match the egg's contributions to the ambiguity of human converse. We call one another good eggs, tough eggs or rotten eggs, depending on which of the egg's natural or acquired conditions best mirrors the assessment of the character in question.

description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS MINOR BUSINESS TAX CUTS
description: The Senate Finance Committee, working on the final items in its $74 billion deficit reduction package, approved several small tax cuts today for logging trucks and businesses that donate certain equipment to vocational schools.

description: A Pennsylvania judge, siding with supporters of Walter F. Mondale, is refusing to let six delegate candidates switch their preference to Senator Gary Hart in the state's April 10 primary.

Julius Erving of the Philadelphia 76ers won the Father Flanagan Award for Service to Youth. The award, honoring charitable activities, is presented by Boys Town of Omaha.

description: While staffs and advisers sometimes make the Presidential candidate, they are almost always a reflection of the candidate: his working patterns, his style, his ideology, perhaps even a glimpse of what his Presidency might look like.

description: - Disagreement between World Cup organizers and permanent holders of reserved seats has knocked Mexico's two largest soccer stadiums out of 1986 cup play, stadium managers said today.

description: b-Includes a gain of $7,100,000 from the sale of mortgage loans. c-Net income. d-Net loss.

title: HIGH COURT RULES LIBEL SUITS MAY BE FILED IN DISTANT JURISDICTIONS
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a publication may be sued for libel in any state in which it regularly circulates, regardless of where the plaintiff lives.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PARISH AND PARKS The Municipal Art Society's Urban Art Center, in the landmark building at 457 Madison Avenue, at 51st Street (935-3960), reflects city life, in our town and others, as the current spate of public attractions there indicates.

title: BRIEFS
description: * APW Dynalectron Corp., a technological services company based in McLean, Va., said it had received a $51.6 million contract, including options, to continue technical and engineering services in support of the Navy Fleet Analysis Center at Corona, Calif.

title: HART 2D AFTER STIFF BATTLE; JACKSON, 3D, RUNS STONGLY
description: In spite of an avalanche of black votes in Chicago for the Rev. Jesse Jackson, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale gained his victory in Illinois yesterday with surprising strength among affluent, suburban ''new generation'' white voters, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. His strength among those voters cut sharply into what had been Senator Gary Hart's base of support in previous primaries.

title: Pacers 123, Celtics 121
description: Butch Carter scored 14 of Indiana's 15 points in overtime, and had a game-high 28 as the Pacers beat the Celtics for the first time in six games this season.

Venezuela Shifts
description: Venezuela has reversed its position and decided to send a token team to the Olympics this summer in Los Angeles, the nation's Olympic committee said today.

description: The multibillion-dollar mergers reshaping the American oil industry may also offer new economies of scale that make the refineries of the merged companies more profitable, and exploration efforts more fruitful, according to industry experts.

description: The Economy

title: TRADE BLOC FAILS TO END CONFLICTS
description: A critical meeting of government leaders from the 10 European Common Market countries broke up in disagreement tonight. For the second time in four months, the participants were unable to resolve differences over Britain's demand for a refund of a large part of its contribution to the Community's budget.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for 16wks to Feb 19
ERNST & WHINNEY, JAPANESE FIRM LINK PRACTICES
description: Ernst & Whinney International announced plans yesterday to combine practices with Tetsuzo Ota & Company, Japan's second-largest accounting firm. Analysts said the agreement emphasized the growing importance of the Japanese market to American accounting firms.

description: b-Net loss after a charge of $7,000,000 related to Canyon Lakes, a joint venture project in Kennewick, Wash.

description: The American Express Company has hired Merrill Lynch & Company's chief financial officer, F. Gregory Fitz-Gerald, to be its executive vice president and treasurer.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Panel Backs Research Bill
description: The House Judiciary Committee today approved legislation to remove some antitrust obstacles to joint ventures in research and development.

title: Court Ousts Judge Who Took Bribes
description: The State Supreme Court today permanently ousted Judge Peter Coruzzi of Superior Court in Camden County, who was convicted of taking bribes in exchange for giving defendants lenient sentences.

title: ECONO-THERM ENERGY SYSEMS CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Utility Fault Cited At 3 Mile Island
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company was partly at fault in the accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, and the utility's shareholders may have to bear part of the cost, the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities ruled yesterday.

title: KENTUCKY RIVALS TO MEET AGAIN
description: Louisville against Kentucky? Again?

title: RUMBLES FROM STEINBRENNER
description: If the Florida Presidential primary had not already been held, George Steinbrenner could have passed for a candidate today. During and after the Yankees' exhibition game with the Mets, he shook hands, signed autographs, posed for pictures holding babies and smiled, smiled, smiled. He was not, however, smiling inside.

title: CHARGE IS DELAYED FOR PHONE ACCESS
description: The Federal Communications Commission today delayed for more than two months, until June 13, a charge of up to $6 a month that was to be added to the telephone bills of large businesses to pay for access to other phone networks.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 6 MILLION SHARES
BLACK IS CLEARED BY NEW ARREST IN TEXAS HOLDUP
description: Lenell Geter, a black engineer whose life sentence for armed robbery drew national attention, was cleared today of all charges against him.

title: E.E.C. Files Trade Protest
description: The Common Market has strongly protested proposed regulations by the Commerce Department that tighten licensing requirements for the export of sensitive high-technology products.

title: AMERICAN INTEGRITY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company went public in January 1984.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * BMC Industries, St. Paul, a maker of precision electronic interconnect components and systems, has appointed Charles J. Burns senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: A.T.& T. MAY TRIM FUTURE PAYOUTS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company will not earn enough money to cover its first-quarter dividend and might have to reduce its payouts in the future because of insufficient earnings, the chairman and chief executive, Charles L. Brown, said in a statement yesterday.

title: Borman Had A Salary Cut
description: The salary of Eastern Airlines' chairman, Frank Borman, dropped $59,778, to $282,224, last year as the Miami- based airline suffered its most turbulent year, according to a company proxy statement.

title: Head of Vector Resigns
description: A co-founder of the loss-plagued Vector Graphic Inc., Lore Harp, announced her resignation yesterday as president, chief executive and a director.

title: American Record
description: Tuesday night's 9-3 victory for the St. Louis Blues over the Winnipeg Jets was important to Joey Mullen of the Blues for three reasons. The triumph clinched a playoff berth for St. Louis, Mullen scored three goals to achieve his first National Hockey League hat trick and his final goal was his 39th of the season, giving him the league single-season record for an American-born player.

title: People
description: * Richard E. Swart has joined the Parker Pen Company, Janesville, Wis., as vice president of marketing for the Parker Writing Instrument Group.

title: Harness Driver Hurt
description: Jack Parker Jr. , a 28-year-old harness driver from Wilmington, Del., suffered severe head injuries Tuesday night in a five-horse accident during the 10th race at the Meadowlands track in New Jersey. According to a track spokesmen, Parker's horse, Hope Valley, stumbled during the backstretch drive and touched off a chain collision involving four other drivers. Parker, the only one seriously injured in the mishap, was taken to Hackensack Medical Center, where he was listed in critical condition.

title: OAK HILL SPORTSWEAR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $112,000 for the quarter and $448,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $113,000 for the quarter and $1,740,000 for the year.

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: HART TAKING HIS CAMPAIGN BACK TO ITS YALE ROOTS
description: It was a rally for John F. Kennedy on the New Haven Green in 1960 that awakened Gary Hart, then a Yale divinity student, to politics, according to his friends.

title: U.S. DEFENDING NOTIFYING PARENTS ON BIRTH CONTROL
description: The Reagan Administration is again defending its effort to require birth control clinics to notify parents of minors receiving prescription contraceptives, even though four Federal courts have struck down the rule as illegal.

title: Eight More Are Charged In Chicago Court Inquiry
description: Eight more people, including a Cook County judge, have been charged in the undercover investigation of corruption in the Cook County court system, the nation's largest, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today.

title: VOTE IS THWARTED ON SALVADOR AID
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, moved today to bring President Reagan's request for $114 million in emergency military aid for the Salvadoran Government and the Nicaraguan insurgents to the Senate floor. Mr. Baker argued that prompt approval of the aid package was necessary to send a positive signal to the people of El Salvador before the election there Sunday.

title: JACKSON ASSESSES LOW WHITE VOTE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, asked to explain the failure of most whites to support his Democratic Presidential bid, said today, ''Whites have developed over their history a lack of regard for the intelligence and hard work of black people.''

title: Casino Permitted To Build Depot
description: The Casino Control Commission today granted permission to Resorts International Inc. to build a train depot here for a planned Atlantic City-to- Philadelphia railroad line.

title: CBS SHUFFLES NEWS CHIEFS
description: Appointment of a new executive producer of ''The CBS Morning News'' was announced yesterday by Edward M. Joyce, president of CBS News. The move, CBS News sources said, is intended to improve the program's ratings.

title: Cuba Releases 2 U.S. Yachts
description: Cuba today released 19 Americans and 2 racing yachts seized when they sailed too close to Cuba. Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, had negotiated for their freedom and was informed of Cuba's action by the head of the Cuban Interest Section at the Czechoslovak Embassy in Washington, a spokesman for the Senator said.

title: A Recovered General
description: Danny Knight , a rookie from Mississippi State who had been injured since training camp with a severe groin muscle strain, is expected to play for the first time Sunday for the Generals against Washington.

title: ALVARADO TAKING LEAVE OF ABSENCE AS SCHOOLS CHIEF
description: Anthony J. Alvarado annnounced yesterday that he was taking an indefinite leave of absence as the New York City Schools Chancellor until questions about his finances were resolved.

title: LORNE ANDERSON
description: Lorne Anderson, a National Hockey League goaltender during 1951 and 1952 for the New York Rangers, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 53 years old. Anderson gave up 3 goals in 21 seconds to Bill Mosienko of the Chicago Black Hawks on March 23, 1952, at Madison Square Garden - the second- fastest three goals scored by an N.H.L. player.

title: Tied for Second
description: Jack Ramsay has been coaching in the National Basketball Association for 16 years with the Philadelphia 76ers, the Buffalo Braves and, since 1976, the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: THE PROMISE OF SPRING TURNS SOUR FOR REAGAN
description: At a time when President Reagan could have been expected to enjoy the spectacle of feuding Democratic Presidential candidates, the White House is instead hobbled by factionalism, difficulties with Congress and a crisis over how to handle the problems of Edwin Meese 3d.

title: REAGANASKS UNITY ON DEFICITS PLAN
description: President Reagan went to Capitol Hill today to sell his $150 billion plan to reduce the budget deficit and said he would veto any tax increase that came to him without matching cuts in spending.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS TAKEN
description: The New York Times/CBS News poll in Illinois is based on questionnaires completed by 1,283 Democratic voters as they left polling places in 67 randomly selected precincts in all parts of the state.

title: Miss McKinney Rallies to Win
description: Tamara McKinney of Squaw Valley, Calif., skied a daring second run on an icy slope today to edge Erika Hess of Switzerland, the World Cup leader, in the season's final giant slalom.

title: Technology; Will I.B.M. Shift Strategy?
description: ALMOST nothing about the innards of an International Business Machines Personal Computer is a secret, and that says almost everything, many believe, about the machine's success. By designing an ''open architecture'' system, made largely with off-the-shelf parts, the company enabled thousands of innovators to build small fortunes by writing programs for the computer, or making peripheral equipment that enhanced its powers.

title: Trade Gap in Denmark
description: Denmark's balance of trade swung to a deficit of $134 million in February after a surplus of $76 million a year earlier, the Government's Bureau of Statistics said in a preliminary report today. It was Denmark's third consecutive monthly deficit.

title: Officials May Overlook Caravan of Refugees
description: Federal immigration officials say they doubt they will take legal action against a group transporting a family of illegal immigrants to Vermont.

title: REGAN INITIALS TREATY WITH CHINA ON TAXES
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan initialed a new tax treaty today that will avoid double taxation of American companies and citizens working in China.

title: NEVADA GAINS NEW STYLE OF POLITICIAN
description: Lieut. Gov. Bob Cashell, chairman of the Nevada Commission on Economic Development and Diversification, says that ''overcoming the stigma of casino gaming is one of the biggest problems we have'' in persuading companies to locate in the state.

title: BEIRUT, GLOOMY AT TALKS' FAILURE, TRIES TO GUESS AT NATION'S COURSE
description: Many Lebanese reacted with resignation and gloom today to the breakdown of the national unity talks in Lausanne, Switzerland. Some politicians said a result would be a sharp increase in the fighting among the country's warring factions, but others disagreed.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Smith Burke & Azzam Gets PBS Account
description: Smith Burke & Azzam of Baltimore has been named agency for the Public Broadcasting Service with their assignment being the creation of an advertising campaign to increase the frequency of viewers of PBS programming.

title: EVENTS: CALIFORNIA ARCHITECTS
description: ''The Second Generation of California

title: BOTH SIDES CLAIM VICTORY IN CHICAGO WARDS
description: On the day after 50 hotly contested ward contests that could determine the future of the local Democratic organization, no one was quite sure who had won or lost. Votes were still being tallied and some results were being challenged in the effort by Mayor Harold Washington to wrest control of the party from Alderman Edward R. Vrdolyak.

title: HERNANDEZ GETS AN APOLOGY
description: Ken Moffett, the former executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, formally apologized to Keith Hernandez and Doug Bair today for having implied that the Mets' first baseman and the Detroit Tiger pitcher had been involved with illegal drugs while both were with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Utility Offering
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company increased its offering of preferred stock to 500,000 shares from 250,000 shares. The offering, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert, carries an annual dividend of 14 5/8 and a price of $100 a share. Reflecting the strain of its large nuclear construction program, the preferred stock carried speculative grade ratings of Ba-1 by Moody's and BB by Standard & Poor's.

title: MUSIC: LINTON AND RUSSELL
description: or perhaps vice versa - performed Monday night at the Kitchen.

title: Kidnapped Executive In Japan Manages to Flee
description: Katsuhisa Ezaki, a candy company executive, worked loose the ropes on his hands and feet and fled today, 65 hours after kidnappers had seized him from his bathtub and demanded a ransom of cash and gold.

title: MEESE'S TAX RETURNS VARY FROM DISCLOSURE FORMS
description: The following article is based on reporting by Jeff Gerth and Leslie Maitland Werner and was written by Mr. Gerth.

title: Barroom Rape Case Going to the Jury
description: Four men committed ''an explosion of violence and brutality against that small woman,'' a prosecutor said today in urging a jury to convict the men of raping a woman on a barroom pool table.

title: Tennesseans Acquitted In Deacon's Hanging
description: Two mountain men were acquitted today of hanging an elderly church deacon from an apple tree after he was said to have caught them trying to burglarize his home.

title: UNIFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: Unifirst Corp. was formerly called Interstate Uniform Services Corp.

title: Singer Thailand
description: The Singer Company said it had completed the sale of 51 percent of its Thailand subsidiary, Singer Thailand Ltd. The aerospace and sewing products company said a group of private investors led by the Thai Farmers Bank had purchased 21 percent and 9 percent had been sold to employees of the Thailand unit. Earlier, eight Thai underwriters agreed to sell 21 percent to the public.

title: Northeast Savings Withdraws Issue
description: The Northeast Savings and Loan Association of Hartford has withdrawn a planned $100 million debt issue in Europe because of technical reasons, the offering's manager, Goldman Sachs International, said today.

title: COURT RULING AIDS CIVIL RIGHTS SUITS
description: The Supreme Court, in an important civil rights decision, ruled unanimously today that a nonprofit legal organization that wins a civil rights case is entitled to compensation at the same rate as a private law firm.

title: The Next Chancellor
description: For Anthony Alvarado to take an indefinite leave from the job of New York City Schools Chancellor only complicates the questions raised by his tangled personal finances. He may well prove that he broke no laws.

title: I.R.S. GRANTED ACCESS TO CORPORATE TAX DATA
description: A unanimous Supreme Court decision today gave the Internal Revenue Service access to what the agency says is a necessary tool for auditing corporate income tax returns.

title: VALUE OF CHEMOTHERAPY DOUBTED
description: People with colon cancer, the nation's No. 2 cancer killer, do not live any longer if they receive chemotherapy along with standard surgical removal of the tumors, a study concludes.

title: THORATEC LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Panel Urges Coal Leasing
description: Congress should let the Government lease Federal coal again when the current leasing moratorium expires May 18 as long as fair market prices are paid, a special study commission told Congress today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The University of Hartford, which supplied figures for an article of colege tuition and other fees (''College Costs Rise a Bit More Slowly,'' march 25), reports now that the increase is $420, or 3.83 percent, for full-time undergraduate tuition, room and board and all required fees.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: PROBLEMS FACING HIGH-RISES ON GULF PERIDIDO KEY, Ala., (AP) - Anchored to pilings running 60 feet into the ground, high-rise condominiums, built to withstand hurricane-force winds, have spread from Fort Morgan to Perdido Key, long a showcase stretch of pristine Alabama beachfront.
description: There are 80 condominium projects either completed or under way on the 40 miles of Alabama Gulf of Mexico coastline in developments that began after Hurricane Frederic struck Sept. 12, 1979. Building permits in the last fiscal year were for $16 million, up $2.8 million from the year before. Little acreage is left for development in the town, sending builders west to Fort Morgan or east to the Florida line for future projects.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: WHOLE skyscrapers have been conceived, financed, built and rented in less time than it has taken the builder Sheldon H. Solow to construct a row of 11 five-story town houses on East 67th Street between Second and Third Avenues.

title: Southern Bell
description: The Southern Bell Telephone Company said it had been granted a $35.9 million interim rate increase by the Florida Public Services Commission. The company had asked for a $92.5 million increase.

description: TAKEOVER rumors tend to buoy the stock

title: SOVIET SUB AND U.S. SHIP COLLIDE
description: A Soviet nuclear-powered submarine collided in the dark today with the United States aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk in the Sea of Japan, Pentagon officials said.

title: COMPUTONE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After a charge of $679,000 from a writeoff for a discontinued product line. c-Net income.

title: Dow Off 4.92; Rates Still a Concern
description: Stock prices ended mostly with minor losses yesterday in moderate trading as concern over interest rates continued to curtail investors' enthusiasm.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss after the negative impact from the settlement of litigation with Mini-Technology Inc. of $810,000.

title: INTEREST RATES SHOW INCREASE

description: Fire broke out in debris along the BMT tracks in lower Manhattan yesterday, disrupting service for 10 minutes to five stations in Brooklyn and Manhattan, Transit Authority officials said. There were no injuries reported.

description: Southwest Forest Industries said it was holding talks ''relating to a possible friendly acquisition or merger.'' The integrated forest products company said no agreement had been reached and it did not identify the interested party.

description: A report issued today by the General Accounting Office contended that the Defense Department lacked a strategy for testing the four services' ability to fight alongside one another in battle.

title: Woman, 89, Raped On the East Side
description: An 89-year-old woman was raped in her Upper East Side apartment in what the police said was the fourth similar attack on women in the area since Jan. 10.

title: POOR FOUL SHOOTING COSTLY AS NETS LOSE
description: Although the Nets lost their second straight game tonight after a four-game winning streak, Coach Stan Albeck said their confidence has not diminished.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of the film ''Musical Passage'' yesterday misidentified the theater where it is playing. It is the Festival, 57th Street and Fifth Avenue.

description: Pressure for political and social changes that conflict with Roman Catholic teachings is dividing Irish society.

description: Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union cleverly fought his way to a draw Tuesday in the fifth game of the final candidates chess match with his countryman, Gary Kasparov. Smyslov, a former world champion, trails Kasparov by a 1 1/2-3 1/2 score.

title: Ex-Congressman Wins In Illinois Primary
description: Kenneth Gray, the flamboyant businessman who first hired Elizabeth Ray, the Washington secretary who couldn't type, has captured the Democratic nomination for the House seat he gave up 10 years ago.

title: A LEADER IN IRAN ASSAILS STRATEGY
description: An Iranian leader has criticized the military strategy being used against Iraq and said victory requires the preparation of ''correct plans.''

title: Convicted Killer Named In Two Racial Murders
description: A convicted killer, Joseph Paul Franklin, was charged today with two counts of first-degree murder in the Aug. 7, 1977, slayings of a black man and a white woman in the parking lot of a shopping mall here.

title: SALVADOR'S ELECTORAL FARCE
description: The Presidential election in El Salvador to be held on Sunday will not be free or democratic. Nor will it contribute to a resolution of the main problems of the country - war, military dictatorship, widespread violations of human rights, economic and political crises and foreign intervention.

title: Mitterrand in Washington
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France arrived tonight to begin an eight-day state visit to the United States. Mr. Mitterrand and his wife, Danielle, landed at Andrews Air Force Base and were met by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. Before leaving Paris, Mr. Mitterrand met with President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon for an hour to analyze the situation in Lebanon after the breakup of the Lebanese reconciliation talks in Switzerland.

title: Changed Law/Constant Love; Lobbyist for Principle
description: As Washington representative of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, Clarence Mitchell was more than just a lobbyist. He was a special pleader for a race - the human race.

description: Al Jensen, playing in his second game since recovering from a back injury, lost a shutout bid with 1 minute 20 seconds to play, but the Washington Capitals defeated the Minnesota North Stars, 5-1, tonight.

title: Advertising; Dwight Dental TV Spots Set
description: ON Monday Dwight Dental Care, one of about a dozen franchise companies that have exploded onto the health care scene, will begin its first television advertising down in the Tampa, Fla., area where it recently took root.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the Washington Talk page yesterday misidentified Barry Commoner. He is an environmentalist, author and educator. The head of Common Cause is Fred Wertheimer.

title: Pacific Gas Bonds
description: A $250 million issue of Pacific Gas bonds due in 1993 is offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company. The bonds, rated A-1/A, were offered with a yield of 57 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than for outstanding 10-year Treasury notes.

title: Miami Selects Foster
description: Bill Foster , who had a 156-106 record in 9 seasons as the head coach at Clemson, yesterday was named basketball coach at the University of Miami, which is reviving the sport next year after a 14-year-lapse. ''It'll be a challenge and a lot of fun,'' said the 47-year-old Foster.

title: CAMPAIGN 'REPORTING'
description: Our national press and television represent a wealth of talent, energy and political insight. Why then do they fail to use their great resources to inform and educate, rather than entertain, the public in their coverage of our Presidential primaries?

title: CHARGERS' OWNER REPORTED SET TO SELL
description: Gene Klein, the majority owner of the San Diego Chargers, plans to sell his interests in the team, a prominent National Football League executive said today. If Klein succeeds, the Chargers would become the third N.F.L. team to change ownership since the end of the 1983 season.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS HE WOULDN'T LET MEESE WITHDRAW HIS NOMINATION
description: President Reagan, defending Edwin Meese 3d from criticism about his personal finances, said his counselor ''had to make some pretty great economic sacrifices to come here and work for the Government.''

title: Toying With Jerusalem
description: And now that unguided missile called American diplomacy is aimed at Jerusalem. For reasons that have more to do with politics in the United States than the Middle East, Congress clamors to have the American Embassy in Israel moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. For reasons that sound cowardly but are rooted in prudence, the Administration clumsily pleads for the agitation to stop.

title: BIG VICTORY BY WEICKER DISPLAYS DISSENTER ROLE
description: When Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. met President Reagan face to face today in the aftermath of his victory over the White House on school prayer, Mr. Weicker had a salutation.

title: DANCE:LOTTE GOSLAR AND PANTOMIME CIRCUS
description: LOTTE GOSLAR and her Pantomime Circus have been clowning for 30 years. And Miss Goslar has developed a loyal and enthusiastic following. Those admirers turned out in force when she opened on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, where she will be performing with her company through Sunday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: JAZZ John Hicks is a jazz pianist whose talented hands have long been familiar to New York's night clubs, where he plays in intimate groups, usually with just a bass. For many years he was accompanist to the singer Betty Carter, and only occasionally has he ventured into larger ensembles, such as he is doing this week at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, near Bleecker Street (242-1785).

title: STUDY ASSAILS IDEA OF MISSILE DEFENSE
description: A space-based defense that would protect the population of the United States against an attack by ballistic missiles is technologically ''unattainable,'' a group of scientists asserted today. They said the Soviet Union could choose methods to defeat it that were simpler and cheaper than the space defense.

title: BRAMALEA LTD reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
GUIDELINES FOR GETTING A STREET TREE PLANTED ON YOUR BLOCK
description: THANKS to the mild February days that thawed the deeply frozen soil, commercial growers have already begun to dig the trees that will soon grace the sidewalks of New York. Planting of these street trees will begin early in April if there is no severe freeze and will continue until early June or whenever the weather becomes too hot.

title: TESTIMONY ENDS IN POINT-SHAVING TRIAL
description: Prosecution and defense lawyers at the trial of Ernie Cobb, the former Boston College basketball player charged with participating in a game- rigging scheme in the 1978-79 season, both contended yesterday that witnesses had given ''preposterous and unbelievable'' testimony at the trial.

title: BANKRUPTCY BILL PASSED BY HOUSE
description: With a court-imposed deadline looming at the end of this month, the House of Representatives passed legislation by voice vote today that would revise the bankruptcy court system and rescue it from the possibility of chaos.

title: Soviet Buys More Corn
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 400,000 metric tons of United States corn - about 15.8 million bushels - for delivery this year under a new long-term agreement that took effect last Oct. 1, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: CANADIAN JAIL TORTURE CHARGED
description: Amnesty International said today that there were grounds for believing that prisoners in a Canadian jail were tortured or ill-treated by guards after a riot there in 1982.

description: The head of El Salvador's Treasury police has been a paid informant for the Central Intelligence Agency since the late 1970's, according to American officials.

description: About 100 passengers and crew members are recovering from salmonella food poisoning from hors d'oeuvres served aboard 13 British Airways flights, according to Federal health officials and a spokesman for the airline.

title: Ship Sinks in Gulf; Crew Safe
description: A 285-foot cargo ship sank in the Gulf of Mexico about 170 miles off Key West this morning, but the 15 crew members escaped safely to a lifeboat, the Coast Guard said. Helicopters took crew members of the general cargo vessel Panky to the Coast Guard Air Station here.

title: RATES ISSUE: ALL EYES ON FED
description: On Tuesday, the Government estimated that the economy is growing at an annual rate of 7.2 percent this quarter, far faster than even the Administration says is healthy or wise. And one day earlier, the banks raised their prime interest rate for the first time since August. With that, a lot of nervous attention - in the marketplace, in the White House, in Congress, in the treasuries of other countries and the counting rooms of industry - turned to the Federal Reserve Board, with fears rising that the central bank is causing or tolerating a new move toward higher borrowing costs.

title: U.S. IS A TARGET AS 10 NATIONS SIGN ACID RAIN PACT
description: Environment and Health Ministers from nine European countries and Canada signed an agreement today committing their governments to reduce sulfur emissions by at least 30 percent in the next decade to limit environmental damage from acid rain.

title: SOUTH AFRICA WATERSHED
description: 21 - The nonaggression pact with Mozambique and the cease-fire with Angola, though still tenuous, look like a triumph for South Africa. Things are so bad in the neighboring Marxist countries that they have been obliged to seek respite from Pretoria's pressure.

The daughter agreed to pay her $80 a week in cash, an arrangement that continued for about a year and a half.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: HOMES that have wood siding frequently have problems with extensive peeling of the paint, especially older homes where many coats have been applied over the years. Although there can be many reasons for this, if the paint is peeling down to the wood, most of the times moisture trapped under the paint is the problem.

The two real-estate agents were not very encouraging. Their explanation was that it was a 'kind of shed' by the water, which had been owned by 'some guy named Steichen.' ''

MUSIC:SWEDISH NIGHT
description: THE generous concert at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday night offered many rewards. There was the American debut of the Swedish Chamber Orchestra, a 25-member ensemble made up of musicians from the Stockholm Philharmonic. There was a cleverly interlocking program of works that all related, one way or another, to the 18th century. There were four pleasing young Swedish opera singers. There was a new conductor, Ulf Bjorlin, who contributed 40 minutes of excerpts from an opera buffa he had composed. And there was a pianist.

title: DEMOCRATS AND RACE
description: The race for the Democratic Presidential nomination has become a contest within two separate electorates, with Walter F. Mondale battling Gary Hart for the white vote and the Rev. Jesse Jackson for the black vote. This pattern emerged even more strongly in Tuesday's returns from the Illinois primary and polls of voters in that state, as it had a week earlier in Georgia and Alabama.

title: Suntory in China Deal
description: Suntory Ltd., a leading Japanese whisky and beer maker, said today that it had signed a $31 million joint venture agreement with three Chinese companies to produce beer and malt in China. A spokesman for Suntory said the venture would produce 3.9 million gallons of beer a year initially and 7.8 million gallons annually by 1987.

title: Mavericks 102 Hawks 101
description: Rolando Blackman scored 30 points, including an off-balance 10-footer with two seconds left to give Dallas the victory. Trailing by one, Blackman took an inbounds pass from Mark Aguirre with nine seconds left, drove between two Hawks and fired the winning shot, which rattled around the rim before dropping in.

The running back Amos Lawrence , sidelined after undergoing orthoscopic knee surgery last year, was reactivated by the Pittsburgh Maulers.

title: Stake in Dorsey
description: An investors group that includes Shamrock Associates has increased its stake in the Dorsey Corporation to 454,000, or 14 percent, of the common shares outstanding, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

description: Celestial Seasonings, the company that turned the 1960's taste for herbal teas into a multimillion dollar enterprise, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to be acquired by a unit of Dart & Kraft Inc.

title: A BANKING RESTRICTION WILL END
description: C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, said today that he would not renew a moratorium, due to expire March 31, on the granting of national bank charters to securities firms and other non-banking businesses. However, Mr. Conover's office said his letting the moratorium lapse did not necessarily mean he would begin to grant such charters.

title: Poland Debt Talks Started
description: Officials from 15 Western governments and Poland met here today for the first major negotiations on Poland's official debts since earlier talks broke down more than two years ago, diplomatic sources said. They said the talks involved a possible rescheduling of government-to-government debts that fell due in 1982 and 1983.

title: KEAN CALLS FOR AN END TO NEW YORK-JERSEY FEUD ON FEDERAL AID
description: Governor Kean told New York business and political leaders yesterday that New York City's attempt to block a $40 million Federal development grant to Jersey City was ''unworthy and foolish'' and that continued feuding across the Hudson River would hurt the economy of the entire region.

description: Darryl Strawberry , whose 26 home runs as a rookie with the Mets last season included 10 at Shea Stadium, says he will donate $500 to a New York City public high school for each homer he hits at Shea this season. Forty schools were selected by lottery as recipients, with Far Rockaway in Queens the first on the list. . . . The Mets made their first roster cuts yesterday, sending eight players to the minor-league camp: the pitchers Jeff Bittiger , Wes Gardner and Rich Picket ; the third baseman Kevin Mitchell , and the outfielders Billy Beane , Terry Blocker , Len Dykstra and Herm Winningham .
