title: MODERN DESIGN DISPLAY
description: MURRY GELBERG, above left, who designed it, called the exhibition display he devised for ''The Product of Design,'' an industrial landscape. The lively and informative show of more than 70 American industrial objects from 1960 to the present is on view at the Katonah Gallery, 28 Bedford Road in Katonah, N.Y., through May 27. The idea on the part of the curators, Joan Wessel and Nada Westerman - who spent more than two years on research - was to present the process of modern design as well as its esthetic appeal. Among the objects is the lap- held telescope, above. Hours: Tuesday to Friday, 2 to 5 P.M.; Saturday, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sunday, 1 to 5 P.M. Admission is free. The telephone number is 914-232-9555.

title: TRW to Sell Unit
description: TRW Inc. said it had signed a letter of intent to sell its hand-tool division to a new company to be formed by Polaris Capital Group Ltd., a private investment banking group.

title: WHEN WINE CAN'T TRAVEL
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill Says Mondale Is Back on Track
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that he believed Walter F. Mondale's Presidential campaign was ''back on track'' and praised the Rev. Jesse Jackson's performance in demonstrating black political power.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Gasoil Inc., a diversified oil and gas company based in Cleveland, said it had agreed with Omnidentix Systems Corp. to provide financing for 30 franchise dental centers during the next five years in Illinois and Ohio.

title: CONCERT:BRASS QUINTET
description: THE American Brass Quintet's Monday evening concert, which took place in the glittering, modern St. Peter's Church at the Citicorp Center, was devoted to Renaissance and Baroque music. Using their given space in a creative and musicologically apt manner, the members of the quintet and several guest artists stationed themselves around the church; sounds rang from every corner, and the listener was made aware of the music's telephonic complexities.

title: Coca-Cola's Patriarch To Leave Board in April
description: Because of a change in bylaws by the board of the Coca-Cola Company, the company's patriarch, 94-year-old Robert Winship Woodruff, will not be able to stand for re-election in April.

title: New Dean Named At St. Vladimir's
description: An Orthodox Church history professor and author has been named dean of St. Vladimir's Orthodox Theological Seminary in Crestwood, N.Y.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, MARCH 22, 1984
description: The Economy

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Korean Air Lines misstated the extent of its operations in Anchorage. The line uses the city primarily as a refueling site. It is seeking Federal permission for a passenger destination there.

title: CHANGED LAW/CONSTANT LOVE; Show of Sentiment A pet gives its owner the chance to love unreservedly. The semifinals of the A.S.P.C.A. Most Wonderful Pet Contest on Tuesday were, therefore, more sentimental than a father's toast to the bride. The owners of Seamus, a tiger cat, and Deefer, a peekapoo, had written poems in their honor. The young man who entered his schnauzer, Buddy, and tabby, Chester, as the Most Dynamic Duo finished his encomium by handing round their cutest photos.
description: Another Dynamic Duo, a 205-pound mastiff named Teddy Bear and a 13- pound cat named Ajax came dressed in T-shirts and sweat pants.

title: Houston Lighting In Share Offering
description: The Houston Lighting and Power Company is offering 500,000 shares of $100 adjustable-rate preferred stock at a price of $100 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: The Deficit Strikes Back
description: ''There's no reason to think,'' said White House spokesman Larry Speakes, ''that the increase in the prime rate will hamper the recovery.'' Strictly speaking, Mr. Speakes is right. The uptick from 11 to 11.5 percent does not in itself presage economic decline. But the continuing pressure on interest rates does suggest that private and public borrowers are on a collision course. Unless Congress and the President soon agree on how to close the immense deficit, it will be extremely difficult to maneuver between recession and inflation.

title: A GUIDE TO STYLES OF ARCHITECTURE HOW can you tell if a building is Greek Revival, Gothic Revival or Queen Anne style? What is the difference between wattle and daub and egg and dart?
description: Questions such as these and many others pertaining to architectural styles are answered in a 112-page paperback entitled ''What Style Is It? A Guide to American Architecture,'' a newly revised 112-page paperback published by the Preservation Press.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Includes tax credits of $48,000 for the quarter and $733,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a tax credit of $456,000. d-Includes a tax credit of $1,490,000.

title: MISS WITT WINS SKATE TITLE
description: The Olympic champion Katarina Witt of East Germany delivered a compelling performance tonight to win the women's gold medal at the world figure skating championships.

title: THE VIENNESE PERFORM MUSIC IN THEIR OWN STYLE
description: THE Vienna Philharmonic came to town not long ago and reaffirmed its reputation for individual character, homegrown style and mistrust of change.

title: Alcoa, Continental Halt Can Project
description: The Aluminum Company of America and the Continental Packaging Company U.S.A., a subsidiary of Continental Group Inc., said they were ending a joint development project designed to demonstrate the economic, technical and manufacturing feasibility of aluminum food cans.

title: Retail Sales Off 0.1% in Month
description: Retail sales fell $155 million, or one-tenth of 1 percent, in February from the same month a year earlier, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Songs of Latter 30's
description: The actress Celeste Holm will be host of ''Broadway and Revue Songs of the Latter 30's,'' part of the 92d Street Y's ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series April 8 at 2:30 and 8 P.M. and April 9 at 8 P.M. Songs such as ''September Song,'' ''My Heart Belongs to Daddy,'' ''Spring Is Here'' and ''My Funny Valentine'' will be sung by Bobbi Baird, Irving Barnes, Priscilla Baskerville and Peggy King. Tickets can be obtained in advance by calling the Y box office at 427-4410 or Y-Charge at 831-8603.

title: SILENCING THE SOUNDS OF THE NOISY CITY
description: SELDOM does New York City's ecology seem more fragile than when a neighbor turns on the stereo: What is ''A"ida'' to one neighbor is noise to another. Even the most loved apartment can become unlivable when captured by the voice of an unwanted soprano.

title: MOSCOW HOLDS U.S. RESPONSIBLE FOR MINES OFF NICARAGUA'S PORTS
description: The Soviet Union blamed the United States today for an incident Tuesday in which a Soviet tanker hit a mine off a Nicaraguan port. A protest note called it a ''grave crime,'' committed with Washington's complicity.

title: Litton, Dynamics Get U.S. Contracts
description: Litton Systems Inc., a unit of Litton Industries, received a $276.3 million Navy contract for equipment for three guided-missile cruisers, the Defense Department said.

title: SUN CO. SHUNS AN ANTITAKEOVER LAW
description: The Sun Company, a leading oil producer often mentioned as a takeover target, said yesterday that it had decided not to avail itself of a new Pennsylvania law that would protect it against an unwanted takeover. It acted one day before a state-imposed deadline permitting Pennsylvania companies to exempt themselves from the law for their own reasons.

title: Turnpike Funds For Road Repairs
description: The New Jersey Turnpike Authority will refinance its debt to help raise $12 million this year for road and bridge repairs statewide, an authority spokesman said today.

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,381,000.

title: THEATER:'CARMEN' IN ENGLISH
description: TO create his thrilling, 80- minute theater piece, ''La Tragedie de Carmen,'' the director Peter Brook threw out much of the score, the orchestra, the cast and the physical trappings of Georges Bizet's opera ''Carmen.'' You'd think he'd gone about as far as he could go. But now, five months into the production's run at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Mr. Brook has thrown out something else: the French text of what remains of the opera's original Meilhac-Halevy libretto. In its place is an English libretto by Sheldon Harnick, the Broadway lyricist whose credits include ''Fiorello!,'' ''She Loves Me'' and ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' as well as a previous translation of the conventional ''Carmen'' for the Houston Grand Opera.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the Antoinette Perry Awards gave their date incorrectly. It is June 3.

title: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: HERS
description: RECENTLY a young man presented a bouquet to the secretary of the English department. She was astounded. ''But I don't even know you!'' she said. He quickly explained that he was just the florist's messenger; the card would tell her who had sent the flowers. They came, as it happened, from a grateful professor. But what strikes me is that for a split second she thought a complete stranger was offering her flowers, and although this surprised her it was not inconceivable.

title: PARTING FILM SHOTS:COPPOLA AND DUTCH
description: FRANCIS COPPOLA saved the violence for last. After seven months of production in New York, ''The Cotton Club'' is winding up with several brief, but important scenes, including the shooting of Dutch Schultz and his henchmen. The filming took place Tuesday in a bar and grill on East 23d Street, standing in for the Palace Chop House and Tavern in Newark, where the gangster was gunned down in 1935.

title: Bridge: New York Players Collected A Share of National Laurels
description: A substantial contingent of New York experts gained success at the Spring Nationals in San Antonio, which ended Monday.

title: LEADERS REASSESS TRADE BLOC WOES
description: Several European Common Market leaders said today that the breakdown of their conference Tuesday night might prove less serious than many had originally thought.

title: THE DEMOCRATIC QUANDARY
description: The Illinois primary results define the agonizing problem now faced by the Democratic Party. Each of the three candidates for its Presidential nomination has a strong appeal to a constituency that he has defined. But each is in trouble when he goes outside his base.

title: SALVADORANS ENDING QUIET CAMPAIGN
description: El Salvador's presidential campaign quietly drew to a close today, marked by more vicious words but less violent action than the country's election campaign two years ago.

title: VIEW OF PSYCHIATRY IN THECOURTROOM
description: -part ''Frontline'' public-television documentary, is an indictment of psychiatry in the courtroom. It is also an extraordinary look at a mass murderer, Kenneth Bianchi, who alone or with an accomplice, the police say, raped, tortured and killed 15 young women. The first of the two gripping segments will be shown on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: HEROIN TRADE: THIRD WORLD CUTS OUT MARSEILLES
description: Ten years after its high point, the French Connection heroin traffic between Marseilles and the United States is stilled. Narcotics investigators say much of its somnolence comes from the same kind of transfer of skills to the third world that has undercut Europe's steel, textile and shipbuilding industries.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Northwestern Bell Co. Sells Long-Term Debt
description: The Northwestern Bell Telephone Company yesterday offered $150 million in 40-year debentures, becoming the first of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's former operating units to come to market with long-term debt since last June.

title: '84 START ON CABLE T.V. IN BOROUGHS SEEN
description: After more than three years of visions and revisions, planning and negotiating, New York City officials and spokesmen for the companies with cable television franchises in the boroughs outside Manhattan say that residents of the boroughs should begin receiving cable television service by the end of the year.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Boston Celtics , at Madison Square Garden. The Celtics lead the Atlantic Division by a wide margin but have lost three of four games to the Knicks this season. (Television - MSG Cable, 8 P.M., and USA Cable, 1:30 A.M., live). Radio - WNEW, 1130; 8 P.M.)

title: CANCELLATION OF JORDAN ARMS SALE: U.S. POLICY ADRIFT?
description: By announcing today that it was canceling plans to sell advanced antiaircraft missiles to Jordan and Saudi Arabia, the Reagan Administration appears to have bowed to supporters of Israel in Washington. In the process, the Administration ignored the views of the State Department's own experts on the Arab world. The sudden cancellation, following the public denunciation of Washington by King Hussein of Jordan, climaxed a string of setbacks to American policy in the Middle East. On Feb. 7 President Reagan ordered American marines moved from the Beirut airport to ships offshore. On March 5 the American-sponsored disengagement accord of last May 17 between Israel and Lebanon was canceled by the Lebanese Government under pressure from Syria.

title: Boy, 3, Kills Father in Accident
description: A 3-year-old Queens boy accidentally shot and killed his father yesterday with a .38-caliber revolver, the police said.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. DENIES DISPUTE ON E.P.A. INDICTMENT
description: The Justice Department on Tuesday strongly denied news reports that senior officials overruled a recommendation to seek an indictment of a former top Environmental Protection official.

title: SENATE'S SELF-APPOINTED WATCHDOG
description: Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum is an anomaly: one of the few unvarnished liberals in a chamber dominated by conservatives. He is a natural irritant who refuses to go with the flow.

title: Taiwan President Gets A Second 6-Year Term
description: President Chiang Ching-Kuo of Taiwan was re-elected today to a second six- year term by the National Assembly with a nearly unanimous vote.

title: JOSEPH H. KELLER, 59, IS DEAD
description: Joseph H. Keller, co-chairman and chief operating partner of Ernst & Whinney, the international accounting and consulting firm, died yesterday after suffering a heart attack at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio. He was 59 years old.

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 22, 1984 International
description: Moscow blamed Washington for an incident Tuesday in which a Soviet tanker struck a mine off a Nicaraguan port. In a protest note, the Soviet Government deplored the incident as a ''grave crime'' that was committed with the complicity of the United States. Washington denied responsibility. (Page A1, Cols. 3-4.) A Soviet submarine collided in the dark with the United States aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk in the Sea of Japan, Pentagon officials reported. They said that the 80,000-ton carrier had suffered no damage, but that the 5,200-ton nuclear-powered submarine was dead in the water and being assisted by a Soviet cruiser. (A6:3-6.)

title: FREDA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Michigan Diver Takes Title
description: Kent Ferguson, a Michigan junior, easily won the 3-meter diving tonight as the National Collegiate Athletic Association's 61st annual swimming and diving championships began.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
No Headline
description: William S. Frates, 66; A Watergate Attorney

title: ISALY CO reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After a loss of $568,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid Feb. 7.

title: PHILHARMONIC: INCARNATIONS OF SPRING
description: THIS year it seemed as if it would never happen, but the sun did get around to crossing the equator and moving into our hemisphere. It's nice to have it on our side, finally. And, as inevitably as spring itself, musicians at this time of year turn to thoughts of things vernal. Violinists suddenly rediscover Beethoven's ''Spring'' Sonata and amateur pianists get ''The Rustle of Spring'' out of the piano bench, or at least they used to.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 23, 1984

title: Indictment In Steel Case
description: A Federal grand jury accused a Korean trading company today of conspiring to dump steel into the United States by using falsely inflated invoices.

title: ; OF ARCHBISHOP O'CONNER'S VIEW ON ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BEYOND A BOUNDARY. By C. L. R. James. Introduction by Robert Lipsyte. 255 pages. Pantheon. Hard cover, $16.95; paper, $8.95.

title: Unioil Sues Major Brokers
description: Unioil Inc., whose stock was a high flier in 1983 but plummeted this year, has filed a $68 million stock- manipulation suit against some of the nation's largest brokerage firms.

title: DEMOCRATS ERR ON ECONOMIC ISSUES
description: Most Democrats appear to have conceded the economy issue to President Reagan, chalking up their bad luck to the timing of the recovery. But the issue might have worked for the Democrats if they had dared to take up the two demands around which a substantial majority might be mobilized: full employment and industrial policy.

title: DURABLE ORDERS FELL LAST MONTH
description: The Government reported today that factory orders for durable goods fell in February for the first time in seven months, but analysts said the 1.2 percent decline was not a sign that the economic recovery had stalled.

title: GENERAL EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $705,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a tax credit of $671,000.

title: African at the Savoy
description: Tabu Ley Rochereau, one of Africa's most popular performers, will return tomorrow night at 8:30 to the Savoy (398-0662), 141 West 44th Street. He will be accompanied by the musicians and dancers of Orchestre Afrisa International, featuring the singer M'Bilia Bel. Tickets are $15.

title: SALVADOR AID VOTE PUT OFF BY SENATE
description: The White House agreed today to a bipartisan Senate compromise that would reduce an emergency aid package to El Salvador by one-third and delay a vote until after the Salvadoran presidential election Sunday.

title: Gap Acquisition
description: The Gap Stores Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire The Pottery Barn Inc., a closely held specialty rtailer of kitchen and household wares based in metropolitan New York.

title: Ambulance Driver Blamed for Death
description: An ambulance company is liable for damages for the death of a 40- year-old Army veteran who was ''merely dumped'' in a hospital lobby, a Federal judge has ruled in Manhattan.

title: ACCORD REACHED ON STATE BUDGET
description: The leaders of the Legislature said today that they had reached agreement on the outlines of a $35 billion state budget that would sharply raise spending on education.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Denver on Wednesday about the conflict between the governor of New Mexico and a conservative coalition in the state senate misidentified the state's first Hispanic governor. He was Jerry Apodaca, who served from 1974 to 1978.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT AND RESPONSE
description: Following are excerpts from an interim report on Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado issued yesterday by the New York City Department of Investigation and excerpts from a response by the Chancellor's lawyer, Thomas P. Puccio.

title: GENERAL TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $3,025,000 from discontinued operations.

title: THE TESTING ISSUE
description: In their fierce competition for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Walter Mondale and Gary Hart are nevertheless in essential agreement on one profound difference between them and President Reagan:

title: TRAVELODGE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
THE 'HANDMADE' BLOCKADE
description: The United States regrets that a Soviet tanker hit a mine off Nicaragua but insists the danger ''was well known from previous incidents.'' Superpower confrontations should not depend on surmise.

title: RUSSIAN EMIGRE PAINTS AMERICA
description: -styled authority on the Russian avant-garde as it flourished in the first quarter of this century. One of the other, earlier and far from disreputable Russian activities that have found few to defend them in this country is the school of realism that flourished in the second half of the 19th century. The realism in question was weighty in its execution, moralistic in its overtones and based upon the kind of exact social observation that we find in the great Russian novels of the same period (and in others, which, though not so great, are still wonderful). Symbol and metaphor had no place there, except by implication, and the paintings that resulted stood on their own two feet and told it how it was.

title: 3 Youths Are Indicted In a Fatal Derailment
description: A Bergen County grand jury indicted three teen-agers today on charges of causing the death of a train engineer by derailing a train that crashed into a Fair Lawn macaroni factory in 1982.

title: OF ARCHBISHOP O'CONNER'S VIEWS ON ABORTION
description: To the Editor: Bishop O'Connor has certainly found the formula for arousing maxi

title: U.S. PLANS LARGEST EXERCISE OF YEAR IN CARIBBEAN
description: The Defense Department announced today that a joint Navy, Marine Corps, Air Force and Army maneuver, the largest military exercise of the year in the Caribbean, was scheduled to begin April 20 and continue for 15 days.

title: 'POOR MAN'S PARADISE' FIGHTING TO SURVIVE IN JERSEY
description: Seagulls screamed in a brisk sea breeze, but the sun was hot on the tin-roofed tar-paper shacks, tipsy little sun decks and salvage-lumber docks at the Greene Street Boat Club Inc. A mile or so north is the Holland Tunnel and a billboard proclaiming, ''Welcome to the other side of New York.''

title: BRIEFS
CONCERT: ROSALYN TURECK ON HARPSICHORD
description: ROSALYN TURECK can impart more vital information about Johann Sebastian Bach's creative processes by going to the harpischord and playing two measures of music than she can in a 20-minute lecture. Therefore, her Wednesday evening presentation at Carnegie Recital Hall, titled ''J. S. Bach's Settings for Multiple Media,'' sponsored by the Tureck Bach Institute, was a mixed bag.

title: RECERTIFICATION OF TEACHERS IS A GOOD IDEA
description: DO current tenure laws and teacher certification requirements have a negative impact on education?

title: SENATE BACKS BILL TO REDUCE WHEAT
description: The Senate today approved a new plan to reduce wheat acreage, replacing a program that was becoming a political embarrassment to farm state Republicans and the Reagan Administration.

title: AROUND THE WORLDPeruvian Legislator Injured in Protest
description: The 81-year-old legislator who heads the Peruvian Communist Party was said to be in a coma tonight after he was hit by a tear-gas grenade in disturbances marking a 24-hour strike.

title: Prime Rate Suit Settled
description: An out-of-court settlement of a lawsuit against the First National Bank of Atlanta may cost the bank nearly $14 million to resolve a dispute over the prime rate, Jerome J. Froelich Jr., the Atlanta lawyer who won the case, said yesterday.

title: Norma Farber, 74, Is Dead; Author of Books for Children
description: Norma Farber, a poet and author, died of vascular disease Wednesday in Cambridge, Mass. She was 74 years old.

title: Cuts for Former Presidents
description: Legislation to slow the growth in the cost of benefits for former Presidents was approved today by the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee. The measure would put limits on funds for Presidential libraries and office allowances for former Presidents. It would also abolish automatic lifetime Secret Service protection and forbid former Presidents to use employees paid with public funds for money-making activities, including the writing of memoirs.

title: HART'S POSITION ON ISRAEL AND THE MIDDLE EAST
description: From a speech yesterday in Manhattan by Senator Gary Hart to the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations:

title: Seafirst to Sell Part Of London Branch
description: The Seafirst Corporation, a subsidiary of the BankAmerica Corporation, has agreed in principle to sell part of its bank branch here to Gotabanken for more than $80 million, Bank of America International Ltd. said as Seafirst's adviser.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $4,565,000, or 10 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $4,043,000, or 9 cents a share, from discontinued operations. Year-ago results were reclassified to account for discontinued operations in 1983.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to March 4
U.S., Japan In Yen Talks
description: The United States and Japan began a two-day meeting today to discuss ways to make the Japanese yen a more international currency and to open Japan's financial and capital markets to foreign investors.

title: CONCILIATOR FOR SCHOOLS: NATHAN QUINONES
description: When New York City's school system was forming its new high school for the humanities, which opened last fall, it seemed that the advisory committee of teachers, community activists and parents was so diverse that it would be impossible to agree on a plan for the school's operation. But Nathan Quinones, then executive director of the Board of Education's high school division, kept seeking areas of agreement and gradually helped the committee build an agenda around which the members could coalesce.

title: ART: VARIETY OF FORMS FOR DAVID SALLE IMAGERY
description: DAVID SALLE, along with Julian Schnabel, is the artist most identified with American Neo-Expressionism. He and Schnabel are also its most controversial figures. Salle has been acclaimed by one prominent art critic, Peter Schjeldahl, and referred to as ''David Silly'' by another, Robert Hughes. What is certain is that Salle, who is 32 years old, is a voice of his generation. For that reason alone, it is important to listen to what his art is saying.

title: KENTUCKY AND ILLINOIS GAIN IN MIDEAST
description: Sam Bowie, the tallest of the Kentucky Wildcats, had sounded the warning that the advantage of playing in their huge, frenzied home did not give the Wildcats ''a golden road to the Final Four.''

title: DALTON IS FAVORED IN TOURNEY OPENER
description: When the Dalton Tigers won their second straight Metropolitan Athletic Association of Private Schools championship last season, the team elected not to compete in the state high school basketball tournament.

title: Advertising; National Geographic Campaign
description: WHEN the National Geographic magazine breaks its first major advertising trade campaign in three years next week, the headline will tell the story: ''The National Holographic, Photographic, Cartographic, Oceanographic, Topographic, Psychographic, Demographic.''

title: 5 WIN THE MEDAL OF EXCELLENCE FROM STATE BOARD OF REGENTS
description: As part of the 200th anniversary celebration of the University of the State of New York, the State Board of Regents yesterday awarded Regents Medals of Excellence to five men and women at a colloquium on ''Communications as an Educational Force.''

title: MEESE MAKES PLEA FOR A PROSECUTOR TO PURSUE INQUIRY
description: Edwin Meese 3d, with President Reagan's endorsement, asked Attorney General William French Smith today to seek appointment of a special prosecutor to conduct a ''comprehensive inquiry'' into allegations against him. But he said he still intended to serve as Attorney General.

title: American to Offer More Coast Flights
description: American Airlines said today that it will increase the number of its nonstop coast-to-coast flights by 73 percent this summer.

title: ALVARADO VIOLATED ETHICS RULES, CITY INVESTIGATION DEPT. CHARGES
description: The New York City Department of Investigation said yesterday that Anthony J. Alvarado had repeatedly violated ethical standards, disregarded laws and regulations and ''failed to faithfully execute'' his duties as leader of the largest school system in the country.

title: Micropro Making Initial Offering
description: Micropro International Corporation, a microcomputer software company based in San Rafael, Calif., is making its initial public offering of common stock through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. The company is selling 2.2 million shares, which are offered publicly at $10.50 a share.

title: Records Tumble
description: For the third year in a row, the Edmonton Oilers are causing a lot of trouble for the people who print the N.H.L. record book.

title: MINNESOTA LAW SCHOOL SUED IN A SEXUAL HARASSMENT CASE
description: Eight women who are current or former employees of the William Mitchell College of Law here sued the school today, charging they had been sexually harassed by Geoffrey Peters when he was the school's president. The women also said the school's board of trustees held them up to public humiliation when they complained about being harassed.

title: Creditors to Get Nu-West Control
description: Nu-West Group Ltd. said its creditors would receive a controlling share of the stock in the real estate and natural gas company under a debt restructuring plan. The refinancing would require the creditors to convert a large part of their loans into common stock at a rate above the current market price.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Wednesday, with an article on oil mergers, omitted one company from a listing of domestic oil reserves held by major corporations. The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) had reserves of 1.66 billion barrels at the end of 1982.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Aaron Pryor , the 27-year-old unbeaten junior welterweight who announced last week that he would return to boxing, said he would fight as the International Boxing Federation champion and defend the title in late May or early June against an opponent to be named. . . . Larry Farmer has received a two-year extension of his contract as basketball coach at U.C.L.A.

title: BRITISH-AIRLINE LINKS POISONING CASES TO POWDER IN HORS D'OEUVRES
description: British Airways said today that a powder used in preparing hors d'oeuvres was believed to be at least one cause of the food poisoning that affected passengers on dozens of its flights this month.

title: Olivo Keeps Title
description: Joey Olivo scored a unanimous decision over Henry Brent of New York and retained the United States Boxing Association flyweight championship Wednesday night. Olivo, a 109-pound Californian, won handily on the scorecards of all three judges. There were no knockdowns and few solid flurries by either fighter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY FRIDAY, MARCH 23, 1984 International
description: American-Soviet talks are being held and ''could lead to some kind of progress on the more serious issues,'' according to Arthur A. Hartman, the American Ambassador in Moscow. Mr. Hartman said he hoped for an early resumption of negotiations on a new United States-Soviet cultural and scientific exchange agreement. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Israeli elections in May or June are sought by a narrow majority in Parliament. The governing coalition of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir is expected to delay action on the proposals to gain time to submit its own measure next week setting an election date this fall. (A1:5.)

title: 'LE BAL,' A COMEDY ADAPTED BY ETTORE SCOLA
description: IT is early evening. An elderly porter moves around a cavernous, dimly lighted Parisian dance hall preparing things for another night's revels. Chairs on table tops are placed back on the floor; bottles are set out on the bar. The bartender comes in, makes a few minor adjustments, turns on the gaudy lights and selects a disco number on the jukebox. A large, mirrored globe over the center of the dance floor begins to revolve.

title: 'Dracula' Closes
description: ''Dracula, or A Pain in the Neck,'' a play by Phil Woods and Michael Bogdanov that was scheduled for a one- week engagement through Sunday at the Beacon Theater, closed Wednesday after two performances. The show, directed by Mr. Bogdanov, was a spoof of the Dracula legend with audience participation. It was a New Vic Theater of London production presented by Kazuko Hillyer.

title: MONDALE OPENS NEW YORK DRIVE BY ATTACKING HART ON TWO FRONTS
description: Walter F. Mondale opened his campaign for the New York primary last night with sharp attacks against Senator Gary Hart on arms control and his position on the site of the United States Embassy in Israel.

title: CAMEL OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After special writeoffs of $9,520,608.

title: 7 BIDS ARE RECEIVED FOR TAKING CONTROL OF FEDERAL SATELLITES
description: Six corporate bidders and one individual have submitted bids to run earth surveillance satellites now controlled by the Federal Government, the Commerce Department announced today.

title: Economic Scene; Buying Out The Dissidents
description: EARLIER this month, when Texaco Inc. bought out the 9.9 percent of its stock owned by the acquisition-minded Bass Brothers investment group of Texas, Wall Street cheered. At a stroke, John McKinley, Texaco's chairman, had gotten rid of a potential adversary that some feared might have toppled Texaco the same way that investors led by T. Boone Pickens, the chairman of the little Mesa Petroleum Company, had defeated the Gulf Corporation not long before.

title: FIRE AT UNESCO IN PARIS IS CALLED ARSON
description: Police investigators said today that a fire that swept through a wing of the Unesco headquarters here Wednesday night was of criminal origin and had apparently been intended to burn down the building.

title: Arrow Electronics
description: A $70 million issue of Arrow Electronics 13 3/4 percent subordinated debentures due in 2004 is offered at a price of 90 to yield 15.369 percent through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The size of the issue was increased from $60 million. The subordinated debentures carried speculative grade ratings of B-2 from Moody's and B- from Standard & Poor's.

title: Dr. Nathan A. Shore, Dentist Specializing in Jaw Condition
description: Dr. Nathan Allen Shore, a New York City dentist for 40 years, died of Parkinson's disease on Wednesday at the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Veterans Hospital in Montrose, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SULPETRO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Year-ago results are restated.

title: 'GENTRIFICATION'OF 2 NEIGHBORHOODS FOUND BENEFICIAL
description: Privately sponsored renovations of town houses and apartment buildings on Manhattan's Upper West Side and in Brooklyn's Park Slope section between 1970 and 1980 had a broad ''positive influence'' on those areas, according to a report issued this week by the New York City Department of City Planning.

title: No Headline
description: Medical Dean Accused Of Plagiarism on Text

title: MICHIGAN TRIUMPHS, 63-62
description: The freshman Antoine Joubert sank two free throws with 21 seconds left tonight to help give Michigan a 63-62 victory over Xavier (Ohio) in the third round of the National Invitation Tournament.

title: RAYMOND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $44,000 for the quarter and $60,000 for the year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $378,000.

title: AVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
FLAVORS OF BRAZIL AND SPAIN
description: and there seem to be more every year - are particularly known for their energetic music, not necessarily their food. At the year-and-a-half-old Amazonas, 492 Broome Street in SoHo, however, you can have your sambas and eat well, too.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Full Disclosure
description: Robert MacVicar , president of Oregon State University, released a 35- page letter of inquiry from the National Collegiate Athletic Association accusing the school of 54 athletic rule violations, 51 of them citing the basketball program. Mr. MacVicar, who had released a summary of the charges three days after they were received on March 2, disclosed the full report - without names and other identifying data - under orders from the Oregon Attorney General, Dave Frohnmayer , who cited the state's freedom of information law. The university has been asked to respond to the charges by April 16. Most of the charges accuse university athletic officials and team boosters of providing student-athletes with improper ''extra benefits,'' including gifts, loans and free transportation.

title: Writing After Vietnam
description: ''Back in the World, Writing After Vietnam,'' on Sunday at 8 P.M. will focus on the work of 13 Vietnam-veteran writers in readings and a panel discussion sponsored by the American Arts Project, Fordham University and the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street, where the event will take place. Robert Stone (author of ''Flag for Sunrise''), John Del Vecchio (''13th Valley'') and Stephen Wright (''Meditations in Green'') will participate. Tickets are $5, to be purchased in advance by calling Jason Shinder at the Y.M.C.A., 787-6557.

title:
GARDENING;
ANNUALS VS. PERENNIALS
description: THE inexperienced gardener is attracted to flowering annuals by their ease of culture and long season of bloom. As experience is acquired, there is often a change in preference toward perennials. In fact, many sophisticated gardeners advanced in knowledge and taste eschew the use of annuals under the guise that they are not worthy of consideration.

title: THE STORY OF PETER RABBIT'S CREATOR
description: CHILDREN the world over are familiar with the tales of Peter Rabbit and Jemima Puddle-Duck and a host of other animal characters who began appearing in illustrated books around the turn of the century. Now, on ''Masterpiece Theater'' on Sunday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, devotees can learn about the extraordinary woman who created them. ''The Tale of Beatrix Potter,'' a two-part BBC dramatization based on biographies by Margaret Lane, has been written and produced by John Hawkesworth, the force behind such outstanding series as ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' ''The Duchess of Duke Street'' and ''The Flame Trees of Thika.'' His skills continue to be impressive.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LET NO ONE HALT PROGRESS IN CITY SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: STRENGTHENING SAMARITAN LAWS
description: ''Danger invites rescue. The cry of distress is the summons to relief.''

title: STEINBRENNER,BERRA CONFER ON SMALLEY
description: Roy Smalley saw panic and called it laughable. Yogi Berra saw the specter of George Steinbrenner and proclaimed his independence, mildly.

title: Bridge: The Old Guard Was Beaten For the Board-a-Match Title
description: The men's board-a-match team championship at the Spring Nationals in San Antonio last week proved to be a struggle between the Old Guard and the Young Guard.

title: Hamilton Wins Program
description: Scott Hamilton won the men's short program, and Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean of Britain continued to dominate the ice dancing today at the world figure-skating championships. The Olympic champions from Britain earned an unprecedented seven perfect marks of 6.0 for their rhumba and waltz compulsory dances.

title: OF ARCHBISHOP O'CONNER'S VIEWS ON ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: I.B.M. Offers Tape Cartridge
description: A memory system for largescale computers that uses a tape cartridge instead of the conventional tape reel was introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation. Data from a computer's central processor can be transferred to the new tape-drive storage system, called the 3480, or retrieved from it, at rates of up to three million characters a second - more than twice the speed of current I.B.M. tape drives, the company said.

title: '1984: Fact or Fiction?'
description: ''Orwell's Nineteen Eighty-Four: Fact or Fiction?'' will be the subject of Representative Ted Weiss's annual community conference Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. at Columbia University's Ferris Booth Hall, Broadway and 115th Street.

title: STAGE: 'HACKERS,' COMPUTER COMEDY
description: MIKE EISENBERG'S ''Hackers'' is a cybernetic comedy about identity crises in the lives of those who are victims of ''involuntary mind-slaughter.'' Written by an M.I.T. graduate student in computer science, the play, at the Manhattan Punch Line, is deftly designed to amuse theatergoers, even those who are not yet tuned to the computer age. For outsiders, ''Hackers'' will be informative. For insiders it should be of particular interest - if they can unplug themselves from their terminals. According to the teen-age expert who is resident in our household, the play is authentic and bug-free.

title: ANCIENT ICE FOR A GLACIAL GLASS
description: If William F. Baker were to take liberties with Ogden Nash's verse, he might say:

title: ; Chairman and Founder Of Caldor Calls It Quits
description: Carl Bennett, who founded the Caldor discount store chain in 1951 in a tiny second-floor loft in Port Chester, N.Y., yesterday announced his retirement on May 31 as the company's chairman and chief executive officer. Caldor, an acronym of the first names of Mr. Bennett and his wife, Dorothy, was acquired in May 1981 by the Associated Dry Goods Corporation and last year reached $1 billion in sales.

title: CELTICS BEAT KNICKS AS KING IS INJURED
description: During the opening eight minutes of last night's game, Bernard King did not miss a shot in five attempts from the field. He scored 12 points, and the Knicks had a chance against the Boston Celtics, the team with the best record in the league. Then King was injured, and without him, the Knicks had little chance as they were beaten, 108-100, before a capacity crowd of 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

title: ON THE NAMBIA FRONT, EVERYBODY SEEMS TO LOSE
description: -West Africa - The dirt road that winds to this northern outpost in Africa's last colony does not encourage too much overtaking.

title: Dining Out Guide: Antique Bars
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: New Director in Soviet Is Introduced to Actors
description: Anatoly Efros has been named artistic director of Moscow's avant-garde Taganka Theater, replacing Yuri Lyubimov, who was dismissed for remaining abroad too long, theater sources said today.

title: DOSKOCIL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $859,000 for the quarter and $1,950,000 for the year. c-Includes tax credits of $29,000 for the quarter and $294,000 for the year.

title: Belfast Man Arraigned In Harrods Bombing
description: A Northern Ireland man was arraigned under heavy guard today in the bombing of Harrods department store last Dec. 17. The blast killed 6 people and wounded 94.

title: WALDBAUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in May 1983.

title: Peabody Plans A Restructuring
description: The Peabody International Corporation said its board had approved a major restructuring to be accomplished through divestitures. It said it had made a provision of $18 million to be charged against earnings for its second quarter, ending March 31, that includes all anticipated costs in connection with the restructuring.

title: OHIO MATTRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Results for the latest quarter include the operations of Monterey Manufacturing Co., purchased in June 1983, and of Stearns & Foster Co., since its acquisition on Dec. 22, 1983. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in April 1983, a 3-for-2 stock split in July 1983, and a 5-for-4 stock split in January 1984.

title: JACKSON ADVISERS SEEK MORE DISCIPLINED DRIVE
description: Well before the returns were in from the Illinois primary Tuesday, top advisers to the Rev. Jesse Jackson met in a suburban hotel to ponder better ways to help their independent-minded candidate.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In the Path of the Vikings

title: STAGE:'TO GILLIAN' AT CIRCLE IN SQUARE
description: ON the eve of his wife Gillian's 37th birthday, David stands on the island beachfront of his New England cottage, lost in desultory thought. A year ago David had halfheartedly tried to kill himself with sleeping pills, and he's still not in great shape. He keenly misses his wife, and she's nowhere to be found. But just as David seems about to slip into terminal despair, Gillian at last does appear - bounding out of the bullrushes, as radiant as always. She jokes with her husband, then confides a secret. ''The secret is I'm dead,'' she says. ''I'm very, very, very dead.''

title: UNITED STATES SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Results include gains of 11 cents a share for the latest quarter and 2 cents a share for the year-ago quarter resulting from LIFO inventory adjustments.

title: Balloting by Women Backed in Mississippi
description: The Mississippi Legislature today ratified the 19th Amendment to the United States Constitution, giving women the right to vote.

title: SYRIAN WEAKNESS
description: President Hafez al- Assad of Syria has emerged from the latest round of the Lebanese conflict with both the aura and some of the actual fruits of victory. His regime is now said to hold the key to further developments in the Middle East. He is described as the vital actor in any prospective settlement in Lebanon, in an ominous alliance formed around Syria and Iraq and in the outcome of any future effort to promote an Arab- Israeli settlement. But a close look at his regime and its standing in Lebanon reveals weaknesses and ambiguities that raise serious doubts about its effectiveness in the future.

title: Coroner Assails System In Deaths of 4 Children
description: A faulty legal system allowed a young mother accused of killing four children and suspected in the death of a fifth to escape suspicion for years, Coroner Steve Nawojczyk said today.

title: TANO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: b-After a writedown of $1,500,000 in inventories. c-Net income.

title: HART, ADDRESSING A JEWISH GROUP, URGES U.S. EMBASSY IN JERUSALEM
description: Senator Gary Hart told a leading American Jewish group yesterday that he opposed the sale of sophisticated weapons to Arab opponents of Israel, that he considered Israeli settlements on the West Bank legal and that he would, if elected, move the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

title: CENSURING AN ARMS BUILDER
description: The Defense Department, in a rare censure of a major military contractor, has notified the Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation that the company's performance in building a $4.2 billion weapons system has been ''totally unacceptable.''

title: Art Sale Seen At $10 Million
description: CHRISTIE'S announcement Tuesday in London of a sale on July 3 of 70 old-master drawings from the Chatsworth Collection, said to be the most important collection of old-master drawings in private hands, was greeted in New York by surprise, excitement and some major questions. The auction, including works by Leonardo da Vinci, Hans Holbein the Younger, Raphael, Rubens, Van Dyck and Vasari, is expected by Christie's to bring about $10 million. The drawings will be on view at Christie's New York galleries, Park Avenue and 59th Street, from May 18 to 21.

title: FEMME FATALE
description: Marlene Dietrich and her director, Josef von Sternberg, gave the world some wonderful memories. Remember Lola-Lola, and how she sat on a barrel, in top hat and underwear, moaning ''Falling In Love Again'' in ''The Blue Angel?'' Or Shanghai Lily, the fastest thing on the ''Shanghai Express?'' And how about X-27 dressed for the firing squad in ''Dishonored''? Miss Dietrich wore a little black suit, a small veil and a compact tucked in the top of her stocking. Remember all that - and then regret that Mr. von Sternberg is not around to direct Nora Astorga.

title: Academic Question
description: A Boston College spokesman responded angrily yesterday to reports that Jay Murphy , the basketball team's leading scorer, was dismissed last June because of poor grades only to be readmitted in August, this time to the school's evening college. The Rev. Joseph Fahey , S.J., the academic vice president, said it was ''tragic'' that the school's letter to Murphy informing him of his expulsion had been made public.

title: Southern Cal Women Advance, 76-51
description: Paula McGee scored 22 points, and Cheryl Miller added 21 to lead Southern California to a 76-51 victory over Montana tonight in an N.C.A.A. West Regional women's basketball semifinal. Southern Cal took a 31-15 halftime lead and pulled out to a 60-28 advantage with 10 minutes to play.

title: INDIANAN STUNS TOP-RANKED NORTH CAROLINA IN EAST
description: In one of the biggest and most exciting upsets during a National Collegiate basketball championship tournament, Indiana led most of the way in a close game to beat North Carolina, the country's No. 1-ranked team, 72-68, tonight in the East Regional semifinal round.

title: DOW TUMBLES BY 14.97 ON INTEREST RATE FEARS
description: The stock market took a sharp downward lurch yesterday in moderate trading, with the depressed blue- chip and technology issues the big losers.

title: PANTRY PRIDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $382,000, tax credit of $686,000 and a Chapter 11 debt reduction of $1,150,000. c-After loss on discontinued operations of $98,000, tax credit of $1,965,000 and a Chapter 11 debt reduction of $300,000.

title: DRG INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Folk Dolls on Exhibit
description: ''Children's Children: American Folk Dolls,'' an exhibition of more than 125 dolls, has been extended through March 31 at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street.

title: Chicago Mayor Losing Party Fight, Tally Hints
description: Unofficial tallies today from Tuesday's ward contests in Chicago showed that Mayor Harold Washington fell short of the votes he needed to defeat Alderman Edward R. Vrdolyak as leader of the Democratic organization. The results will be certified next week.

title: A COZY INN WITHOUT THE CLICHES
description: THE Bee and Thistle in Old Lyme may be the quintessential New England inn. Its two parlors are cozy, with couches facing wood-burning fireplaces in each. Two dining rooms and a small closed-in porch are simply furnished with ladderback chairs, soft wall-sconce lighting and neatly napped tables.

title: NATIONAL NEWS COUNCIL WILL DISSOLVE
description: The National News Council, established in 1973 with the announced aim of increasing public trust in journalism by assessing complaints about the work of major news organizations, voted yesterday to dissolve itself. The group attributed its demise to ''a general lack of news media acceptance of the concept of a news council.''

title: WHEN ADMIRAL O'CONNER WENT TO DACHAU
description: To the Editor:

title: DEAR FRIEND: WHY DON'T YOU WRITE?
description: FEW things make me happier than finding a letter in my mailbox. Not a plea to support my college, buy Florida real estate or save the whales, but a real letter from a real person.

title: SALVADOR POLICE CHIEF DENIES HE GOT C.I.A. FUNDS
description: The head of El Salvador's Treasury police denied today that he had ever received money as an informant from the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: DorisHodgkins Monteux, 89, Singer and Music Memoirist
description: Doris Hodgkins Monteux, the widow of the conductor Pierre Monteux and the author of two books about music, died of natural causes at her home in Hancock, Me., on March 13. She was 89 years old.

title: JWT Chief Is Honored As Best Ad Executive
description: Don Johnston, chief executive of the JWT Group, who must have had the toughest row to hoe of any of his peers in the last couple of years, has been named the best chief executive in his industry for 1983 by The Wall Street Transcript.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes dividend income of $32,795,000, after income taxes, from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. and equity in unremitted earnings of $33,265,000 of Du Pont. c-Includes dividend income of $28,110,000, after income taxes, from Du Pont and equity in unremitted earnings of $3,205,000 of Du Pont. d-Includes dividend income of $117,130,000 from Du Pont, $96,847,000 from equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont, and a loss of $15,823,000 from interest expense related to share repurchases. e-Includes dividend income of $109,560,000 from Du Pont, $42,533,000 from equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont, a loss of $22,211,000 from interest expense related to share repurchases, and a non-operating expense of $8,099,000.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS ENDORSE A PLAN TO TRIM DEFICITS BY $200 BILLION
description: Senate

title: TEJON RANCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AUTHOR KOCH EAGER FOR BOOK FAIR
description: as did the Wicked Witch of the West, Peter Rabbit, a belly dancer and a human being dressed as a subway token last year - but this time around, Edward I. Koch is looking forward to September's annual ''New York Is Book Country'' fair with more than his usual enthusiasm.

title: FILM: WARTIME PRANKS, 'RACING WITH THE MOON'
description: ''RACING WITH THE MOON,'' directed by Richard Benjamin from an original screenplay by a fine new writer named Steven Kloves, is an exceptionally appealing movie about subjects you may think you've already had enough of - growing up, first love and the shouldering of arms and other responsibilities. However, ''Racing With the Moon'' demonstrates such intelligence and wit that the result is an unexpected pleasure.

title: REVIVAL OF 'PAY AS YOU GO'
description: When House Democrats proudly announced this week that they were endorsing a ''pay as you go'' budget, they made it sound like one of those new ideas that seem so fashionable in campaign circles this year. But in fact, they were appropriating one of the oldest phrases in the political lexicon, one that has served a variety of purposes and promoters for close to 200 years.

title: COMMON MARKET: AN ILLNESS LINGERS
description: They used to call France the ''sick man of Europe,'' but now it is Europe itself that seems sick.

title: Article 073132 -- No Title
description: Mr. Koch made the announcement on the refurbished first floor of the Men's Shelter at 8 East Third Street in the East Village, long a symbol of the worst aspects of the shelter system.

title: TOUGH MATCH FOR CLOSE RIVALS
description: One of the coaches was sitting at the front of the room, dominating as he always does. The other was in the back, ducking behind a crowd of reporters. He was taking his time about leaving.

title: MISSILE DEFENSE:NOW A GO-SLOW POLICY
description: A year after President Reagan proposed a a defense against ballistic missiles, advisers in his Administration seem to have succeeded in making it a go-slow effort with relatively limited goals. This has not stifled argument about the feasibility or desirability of Mr. Reagan's proposal, made in a televised speech March 23, 1983, to try to create a workable missile defense. The program now has an official name, the Strategic Defense Initiative. Some of the President's close advisers call it ''Star Wars,'' suggesting the exotic and presently unattainable technology that could zap missiles in flight.

title: SCREEN:'L'ARGENT,' ROBERT BRESSON;
description: ''L'Argent'' was shown in last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review in The New York Times of Sept. 24. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza 3, Broadway, between 62d and 63d Streets. Corrupted Morals L'ARGENT, directed by Robert Bresson; script (French, with English subtitles) by Mr. Bresson; camera, Pasqualino de Santis and Emmanuel Machuel; edited by Jean-Francois Naudon; production, Marion's Films and FR 3/Eos Films SA. At Lincoln Plaza 3, Broadway, between 62d and 63d Streets. Running time: 90 minutes. This film is not rated.
