title: RENTED OR REBUILT BUSES TO REPLACE GRUMMANS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to rent some buses and rebuild others as replacements for the 851 Grumman Flxible buses that were permanently removed from service for safety reasons.

title: OUR HIGH-TECH BUNDLE OF JOY
description: AT first we discussed it in hushed tones. Should we or shouldn't we? Would it be worth the initial outlay of money? Would it change our lives? After all, we had two children and two cats - did we have room in our hearts and pocketbooks to add to our family? And of course, where on earth would we put it?

title: 'HARD TIMES, GOOD TIMES' OF MARTY NAPOLEON
description: WHEN Dick Sudhalter began rehearsals this month for ''Hard Times, Good Times,'' the recollection of Depression-era songs at Michael's Pub that he adapted from a concert he produced last July for the Kool Jazz Festival, he asked the pianist Marty Napoleon, who had played piano and sung in the festival concert, if he remembered how some of the songs were introduced then.

title: Work Is Started On Indy-Car Oval
description: Construction is under way on a 1.68-mile temporary track for the United States Grand Prix, an Indianapolis-car race, at the Meadowlands on July 1.

title: RABBIS' DENVER PROJECT FUELS FIGHT ON CONVERTS
description: A debate over Jewish belief and practice is raging in the wake of a rabbis' experiment to counteract the rising rate of marriages between Jews and non-Jews.

title: 2 Charged in Hamburg In 'Hitler Diary' Fraud
description: The Hamburg prosecutor has filed fraud charges against two West Germans accused of peddling the bogus Hitler diaries to Stern magazine, a spokesman said today.

title: ANTHONY ALVARADO, TWISTING
description: Is there no decency, vision or just plain common sense left in Anthony Alvarado? Two days ago, the embattled New York Schools Chancellor put himself ''on leave'' until questions about his finances could be resolved. Yesterday's interim report by the city's Department of Investigation reinforces the conclusion that he has no business remaining anywhere near public office.

title: POPULARITY OF RACQUET SPORTS
description: Suzy Ganz often plays indoor tennis on Friday nights. Anthony Segales frequently bashes a squash ball on Saturday mornings. Cheryl Budd and Robert Rosenberg spend an hour or more at racquet ball on Saturday afternoons, and Sohail Hasan plays platform tennis Sunday mornings.

title: Death of a Goalie
description: Bill Mosienko was returning from a two-month vacation in Arizona, approaching his home in Winnipeg, Manitoba, when he and his wife heard over their car radio that Lorne Anderson, a goaltender for the New York Rangers in 1951 and 1952, had died on Tuesday of a heart attack at the age of 53.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,577,000, or 9 cents a share, on the sale of property. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $3,377,000, or 19 cents a share, on the sale of property. Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July 1983.

title: IN DESPERATE STRAITS
description: Let us think the unthinkable about a far- reaching American military commitment.

title: WARTIME PRANKS, 'RACING WITH THE MOON'
description: ''RACING WITH THE MOON,'' directed by Richard Benjamin from an original screenplay by a fine new writer named Steven Kloves, is an exceptionally appealing movie about subjects you may think you've already had enough of - growing up, first love and the shouldering of arms and other responsibilities. However, ''Racing With the Moon'' demonstrates such intelligence and wit that the result is an unexpected pleasure.

title: MONEY SUPPLY RISES $4 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's money supply rose $4 billion in the week ended March 12, an abnormally large gain that analysts said provided more justification for the Federal Reserve to tighten monetary policy a notch and encourage higher short-term interest rates.

title: NEW CHIPS FOR BANKRUPT COUNTRIES
description: Dollars will get you drachmas that not one American in a hundred has heard of Special Drawing Rights, the hybrid money irregularly created by the International Monetary Fund. An S.D.R. is money that exists only as an electronic entry in the accounts of government central banks. It is backed only by the agreement of the I.M.F. to accept S.D.R.'s in lieu of other money. Invented in 1970, to supplement gold and dollars, S.D.R.'s helped to grease the wheels of trade.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Update on 'Rigoletto'

title: PERSONALITY CHANGE FOR P.&.G.
description: In the 157 years since its founding, the Procter & Gamble Company has become a legend of marketing tenacity. It has been the envy of its competition with its $1 billion-a-year advertising budget, more than any other corporation, and its dazzling line of consumer products. Thoroughness has been its management motto; caution and extreme secrecy, its style.

title: 'ACCURATE, COMPREHENSIVE AND OBJECTIVE' VOICE OF AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTAURANTS
description: At first blush, the Coach House still looks as sparkling as it must have to the generation of food critics that has extolled its virtues for more than 30 years and to the thousands of patrons who have venerated it unquestioningly. But, sad to say, the bright lights hide faults that go to the core of the restaurant's being.

title: SOVIET TELLS DETAILS OF SEA BLAST OFF NICARAGUA
description: The Soviet press agency Tass today gave its first detailed account of the mine explosion that damaged a Soviet oil tanker in a Nicaraguan harbor Tuesday. Moscow repeated its charges that the United States was responsible for the incident.

title: U.S. ENVOY LOOKS TO SOVIET TALKS ON A NEW EXCHANGE AGREEMENT
description: Arthur A. Hartman, the United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said today that the two countries were involved in talks that ''could lead to some kind of progress on the more serious issues.''

title: Koppers Seeking Bar to Takeovers
description: The Koppers Company said its directors are asking shareholders to approve antitakeover measures at its annual meeting in April.

title: Cancer Therapy Offers Girl Hope, Doctors Say
description: Doctors said today that a cancerous tumor that grew to the size of a football in Pamela Hamilton's leg had almost disappeared.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Fannie Mae Offers Mortgage Debt
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association yesterday offered $200 million of 13 percent mortgage-backed securities at a price of 98 26/32, to yield 13.06 percent, through various securities dealers.

title: HOUSTON'S ATTITUDE IS STICTLY BUSINESS
description: During the regular season, they are Phi Slama Jama, an uninhibited, freewheeling basketball team that has continued the Houston Cougars' tradition of winning at least 20 games and placing among the top 10 in the country. During that time, the red-and-white- checked towel that Coach Guy Lewis clutches on the bench is an accessory - like a tie and handkerchief - rather than a security blanket. During the regular season, not many teams stand in Houston's way.

title: ENJOYING THE VIEW IN NEW YORK WINDOWS
description: THE window is the essence of the street, and the street is the essence of the urban experience. For while we may think of streets merely as places of traffic, as ways to get from here to there, they are also events in themselves - for the pedestrian, they are in some ways New York's most civilized urban experience of all. What greater pleasure is there than to walk up and down Madison Avenue on a Saturday afternoon, and what contributes more to that pleasure than looking in the windows?

title: Five Preschool Teachers Accused of Molestation
description: Five teachers at a suburban nursery school were arrested today after their indictment on 109 counts of felony child molestation involving an estimated 100 students over a 10-year period, the District Attorney said.

title: PHH Registers Debt Securities
description: PHH Group, a company in Hunt Valley, Md., that provides vehicle leasing and employee relocation services to corporations, filed a shelf registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $350 million of debt securities.

title: DRUSE CRUSH SUNNI MOSLEM UNIT AS REBEL FACTIONS CLASH IN BEIRUT
description: Druse and Moslem militiamen clashed before dawn today in gun battles that marked the first major confrontation among opposition fighters since they seized control of West Beirut from the Lebanese Army last month.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for 16wks to Feb 11
SUPERSCOPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $479,000 for the quarter and $671,000 for the year, and extraordinary gains of $5,547,000 for the quarter and $11,420,000 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,372,000 for the quarter and $2,263,000 for the year.

title: March Is Declared Eye-Donor Month
description: Mayor Koch yesterday declared March as Eye Donor Month. He also saluted the Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration at 210 East 64th Street for 40 years of service.

title:
Market Place;
Gains Seen For Bank In Texas
description: SOME Texas banks have been hard hit by problem loans resulting from the end of the oil and real estate booms in 1982, but Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. achieved an unusual distinction last week. It was the only common stock among all banks listed on the New York Stock Exchange to reach a 52- week high.

title: RANGERS TOP DEVILS;ISLANDERS EARN TIE
description: The point the Islanders and the Boston Bruins made in their 3-3 tie tonight was an emphatic one: regular-season play can be just as good as the playoff hockey that will begin in the next two weeks.

title: Change of Plans
description: A recent report from Caracas said Venezuela would not compete in the Los Angeles Olympics this year because of financial problems. According to Albert Mestre, Venezuela's best swimmer, there has been a change of heart.

title: WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $249,259. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $522,717.

title: Switzer Suit Dismissed
description: A Federal judge in Oklahoma City yesterday dismissed a civil suit brought against Barry Switzer and six of his friends by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The judge, Dale E. Saffels , said there was ''an absolute lack and paucity'' of evidence to support the S.E.C.'s contention that Mr. Switzer, the Oklahoma football coach, and the other defendants had improperly used insider information to earn about $600,000 in stock-trading profits. The S.E.C., seeking recovery of that profit, had charged that in 1981 George Platt , a director of the Phoenix Resources Company, deliberately leaked information to Mr. Switzer about the company's impending liquidation and that Mr. Switzer passed the information on to his friends. Mr. Switzer, who had denied the charge, described himself as ''relieved and elated.''

title: THE WAR WITHIN THE STATE
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. When I was a news reporter in Kentucky in the early 70's, one of the first things I learned was the utter futility of doing business on basketball nights. It did no good to interview coal operators or farmers in their homes on basketball night because their eyes would keep darting to the television set and their answers were likely to be: ''How about those Wildcats?'' The same was true of politicians or activists in the big city of Louisville, except their response to the television was likely to be: ''Look at those Cardinals.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday PANTOMIME CIRCUS IN CHELSEA

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: DUSTIN HOFFMAN was sitting at the table closest to the door, which in the restaurant world is the highest mark of status. He was sitting with Arthur Miller and a very small group of other friends, and a lot of the guests didn't recognize him because the top of his head was bald. But eventually faces began to stare and mouths began to frame the words ''Dustin Hoffman,'' and the procession began. Mr. Hoffman, who was the guest of honor at Le Vert-Galant restaurant after the first preview of ''Death of a Salesman'' on Wednesday, took it in good spirit. After all, this was a $250-a-person benefit for one of his favorite causes, Camps for Children With Cancer.

title: PUBCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,233,182 for the quarter and $2,628,182 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $3,208,885 for the quarter and $3,303,450 for the year.

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a life insurance benefit of $900,000. c-Includes tax credits of $35,000 for the quarter and $118,000 for the 9 months.

title: SUPER RITE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: The fourth quarter of fiscal 1984 was a 14-week quarter compared with a 13-week quarter in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1983. Fiscal 1984 is a 53- week year compared with a 52-week year in fiscal 1983.

title: EARLY-VOTE PLANS ADOPTED IN ISRAEL
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Government suffered a major defeat tonight when Parliament gave preliminary approval to three motions scheduling elections in May or June.

title: BERKSHIRE-HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $2,914,000 for the quarter and $45,298,000 for the year. c-After capital gains of $11,326,000 for the quarter and $14,877,000 for the year. The revenue for the 1982 quarter and year was restated to show revenue of subsidiaries consolidated in 1983.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: NOT every movie star jumps up to demonstrate his break dancing in mid-conversation, or pauses to complain about not being allowed to play Dungeons and Dragons as often as he would like. But then not every movie star is 12 years old. Henry Thomas, whose performance in ''E. T.'' has made him a household face (he says he's still apt to hear cries of ''Hey! There went that kid from 'E. T.!' '' in shopping malls), was experiencing severe cabin fever in his suite at the Hotel Pierre on Monday. So he bounced, wriggled and squirmed his way through questions about his latest film, ''Misunderstood.''

title: Paraguay Closes a Paper
description: President Alfredo Stroessner's Government today indefinitely closed ABC Color, a top-selling newspaper critical of the regime, newspaper sources said. An Interior Ministry resolution said the newspaper, which has a circulation of 70,000, had displayed a ''permanent will to undermine public order.'' The publisher of ABC Color, Aldo Zucolillo, has been detained since Friday although no charges have been filed against him, the newspaper sources said.

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $164,000 for the quarter and $750,000 for the year.

title: THE MEESE NOMINATION: ASSESSING THE DAMAGE
description: One day recently, when the news broke about Edwin Meese 3d's failure to report a $15,000 interest-free loan to his wife by a friend who subsequently got two Federal appointments, a senior Justice Department official was unable to conceal his outrage as he moved about the department cafeteria.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Hambrecht Leader Gets Diasonics Bid
description: Financially troubled Diasonics Inc. has asked Q.T. Wiles, chairman of Hambrecht & Quist Inc., an investment banking firm, to join the company as co-chairman with full responsibility for managing all the company's businesses, Albert S. Waxman, the current chairman, announced yesterday. The appointment is subject to approval by the company's board of directors.

title: AT OPENING OF THE PARIS SHOWS, THE JAPANESE TURN TO COLOR
description: After four years of showings here, the somber, enveloping styles of the Japanese designers seem a good deal less mysterious than they once did. Familiarity has diminished their shock value.

title: N.A.A.C.P. IS SAID TO BE FACING A FINANCIAL CRISIS
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is facing a severe financial crisis that threatens to cripple its activities as the leader of the civil rights movement, association officials say.

title: BROADWAY
description: ALL good things must come to an end, even Yul Brynner's solid-gold tour of ''The King and I,'' which has been traveling around the country trailed by a fleet of Brink's armored trucks the last three years. Mr. Brynner has decided that the end will come at the end of the year, and in the very place where he first played the King of Siam in the durable Rodgers and Hammerstein musical in 1951 - on Broadway. The production, which will be billed as Mr. Brynner's ''farewell tour,'' will open in late December or early January in the same theater that housed Mr. Brynner's 1977 triumphant return in ''The King and I,'' the Gershwin, which was called the Uris in those days.

title: ADVERTISING ; Diet Coke in Agreement On Nutrasweet Display
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York has caught up with the advertising industry's self-policing arm by going after Diet Coke for using ''Now with Nutrasweet'' on containers and in advertising, without giving equal display to the fact that the product still contains saccharin.

title: Hart Asks Greater Share Of Florida's Delegates
description: Senator Gary Hart is asking a Democratic Party commission for a ruling that could allow him to take more delegates from Florida to the party's national convention in San Francisco, officials said today.

title: ART: CHRISTOPHER WILMARTH'S 'LAYERS'
description: SOMEWHERE on the way to sculpture from painting there is the work of Christopher Wilmarth, who plays glass against steel in poetic constructions that make eloquent rapport between light and shadow. His restrained images, very human in scale, shun the stridency of some recent sculpture for a quiet lyricism that engages much more than the eye. Now, at Hirschl & Adler Modern, 851 Madison Avenue, at 70th Street (through April 19), a small retrospective of Wilmarth's work, aptly titled ''Layers,'' gives us the chance to see its development from his student days on.

title: Tribute to Broadway
description: The actress Kaye Ballard will be the host Sunday at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall for ''One Night Only,'' a musical tribute to Broadway, featuring Betty Buckley, Denny Dillon, George S. Irving, Maureen McGovern and Debbie Shapiro.

title: Swordplay at White House
description: A man was arrested by police outside the White House last night after he brandished a samurai sword, the authorities said. The man was identified as Anthony Leon Holbert, 22 years old, of Glen Arden, Md. The Secret Service said it happened at 8:20 P.M. while President Reagan was entertaining President Francois Mitterrand of France.

title: FALL RIVER JURY FINDS 2 MORE DEFENDANTS GUILTY OF RAPE IN BAR
description: A jury today convicted two defendants of aggravated rape of a young woman at a bar in nearby New Bedford. Two other defendants were found not guilty.

title: RUPERTSLAND RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-After writedowns of $21,360,000 on properties deemed uneconomic or without potential.

title: JAPAN'S PREMIER STARTS CHINA VISIT TODAY WITH LOAN PLEDGE
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan is due to start a four-day visit to China on Friday, carrying $2.1 billion in low-interest loans and possibly also suggestions for easing tensions on the Korean peninsula.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Celtics, at Boston. The Nets will be trying to end a nine-game losing streak at Boston Garden. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC, 660; 7:30 P.M.) Memphis State vs. Houston and

title: TRICENTROL PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings figures represent net income per American Depository Share.

title: Stake Increased
description: Leonard Levy, a Corona del Mar, Calif., investor, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had increased his holdings in the stock of Information Displays Inc. He said his recent purchases raised his total holdings in the company to 837,355 shares, or 28.1 percent of the total outstanding. Information Displays, based in Armonk, N.Y., makes computer systems.

title: MITTERRAND ADVISES CONGRESS ON LATIN AMERICA AND BUDGET DEFICITS
description: President Francois Mitterrand urged the United States today to allow each nation in Central America to ''find its own path'' to greater justice and democracy ''without interference or manipulation.''

title: NEW YORK BUSINESS PHONE BACKLOG
description: Telephone service for business customers in New York City is substantially worse than for the nation as a whole, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Volunteers for Central Park

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing in the Debt Issues column in Business Day on Monday gave an incorrect location for the Patlex Corporation. It moved last year from Ardmore, Pa., to Westfield, N.J.

title: The U.N. Today March 23, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: DESPITE AUSTERITY, FRENCH DEBT SOARS
description: France's huge foreign debt burden rose by a half last year and is still climbing despite President Francois Mitterrand's austerity measures, the Finance Ministry reported today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * C. D. Anderson & Co., a San Francisco-based discount brokerage firm, has named Patricia Love Anderson president and chief executive officer.

title: POSSIBLE LINK FOUND BETWEEN TINY VIRUS AND ARTHRITIS FORM
description: Scientists have found a tentative association between a virus and human rheumatoid arthritis, strengthening speculation that a virus may be involved in the crippling disease.

title: People
description: * John J. Grogan rejoins SSC&B as an executive vice president and a director. Also, Stephen W. Norcia and F. Stone Roberts, already executive vice presidents, were elected to the board.

title: Minnesota-Duluth In Hockey Final
description: Minnesota-Duluth defeated North Dakota, 2-1, in overtime tonight to advance to the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championship game for the first time.

title: European American Acquires a New Chief
description: In taking over the European American Bancorp and its two subsidiaries, the European American Bank and Trust Company and the European American Banking Corporation, Raymond J. Dempsey is inheriting an $8.7 billion bank that has encountered many troubles.

title: AUTOMATIX HEAD IN SALVADOR ROLE
description: The organizations that Philippe Villers, president of Automatix Inc., belongs to are not the usual chambers of commerce and business groups associated with a corporate executive.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased by $360 million, to $171.16 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: OF ARCHBISHOP O'CONNER'S VIEWS ON ABORTION
description: To the Editor: In your second editorial on Bishop O'Connor's views on abortion, you say he has now come to the considera

title: BRIEFING
description: New Paper for CapitalWashington is about to get a new newspaper, a colorful tabloid called The Washington Weekly scheduled to go to the newsstands late in May. A prototype copy that rolled off the presses this week attracted immediate attention because the cover story was headlined ''Ted Plots Late Entry,'' an announced exercise in political fiction whose lead paragraphs suggest that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is about to enter the Democratic Presidential competition at the behest of organized labor.

title: LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OTTO ECKTEIN, EDUCATOR WHO LED IN ECONOMIC FORECASTING
description: Otto Eckstein, the economist, educator and chairman and co-founder of Data Resources Inc., a leading economic forecasting concern, died of cancer yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 56 years old.

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $51,000 for the quarter and $100,000 for the 6 months, and extraordinary credits of $136,000 for the quarter and $180,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $158,000 for the quarter and $368,000 for the 6 months, an extraordinary charge of $14,000 for the quarter, and an extraordinary credit of $21,000 for the 6 months.

title: Ottawa Success For Elaine Zayak
description: If it was her final performance as an amateur, Elaine Zayak, the former women's world figure skating champion, ended her career on a positive note.

title: Pearson Hurt in Crash
description: A car driven by Drew Pearson of the Cowboys veered onto the shoulder of a highway in Dallas and hit a tractor-trailer truck early yesterday, injuring Pearson and killing his 27- year-old brother, Carey . Drew Pearson, a 33-year-old wide receiver, suffered back and internal injuries and was taken to Dallas Presbyterian Hospital, where he underwent exploratory surgery to stop internal bleeding and was listed in satisfactory condition. There were no injuries to the driver of the truck, which, the police said, was parked on the shoulder.

title: INVESTIGATORS SAY MEESE NOTE MAY NOT MATCH HIS '80 FILES
description: Edwin Meese 3d has given a House committee a copy of a Nov. 28, 1979, note in his handwriting referring to a Reagan campaign official as a self-described Watergate era ''bagman'' who kept his ''mouth shut.''

title: Freedom for Aikens
description: Willie Aikens , the baseball star who was sentenced to 90 days in prison for attempting to purchase cocaine, was scheduled to be released from a Federal corrections facility in Fort Worth today.

title: WEDDING ON AGAIN AFTER MISTAKEN LIFE SENTENCE
description: Lenell Geter, a black engineer who was sentenced to life in prison for an armed robbery prosecutors now say he did not commit, said today that he was looking forward to getting married and resuming his career.

title: 202 DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Debt Issues
description: * American General Corp. said its NLT Corp. unit would redeem all of its outstanding 8.80 percent notes due May 1, 1985, on April 27, 1984, at a price of 104.302 percent.

title: STATE TIGHTENS RULES ON EDB
description: New York State today ordered standards for the presence of EDB in food that are one third of the levels set by the Federal Government. The new standards went into effect immediately.

title: J. David Firms Are Liquidated
description: The financial empire of Jerry Dominelli, a currency trader, including entities in London, Switzerland and the Caribbean, has been declared bankrupt by a Federal judge.

title: DISNEY MOVES TO ADD CREDIT
description: Apparently in a move to defend itself against a takeover threat, Walt Disney Productions announced yesterday that it was seeking to more than triple its $400 million line of credit.

title: NEW INTEREST IN BACKGROUND CHECKS
description: Some balk at the 20-page questionnaire about their finances and employment record. Others are uneasy about being fingerprinted and photographed. But anyone who wants a management- level job in New York City's government has to pass the background check.

title: Troops and Police Told By Marcos to Guard Vote
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos ordered the Philippine armed forces and national police units today to help civil officials insure ''a free, orderly and peaceful'' parliamentary election on May 14 but to refrain from ''partisan political activity.''

title: F.T.C.PLANNING TO NARROW INQUIRIES ON ADS
description: James C. Miller 3d, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, is to announce Friday a policy that would eliminate industrywide checks of advertising and restrict investigations to specific businesses in which deceptive advertising is thought to be a problem.

title: LEGISLATORS ASSERT THEIR ROLE IN BUDDGET PROCESS
description: NewsAnalysis

title: FOR ENVOYS, ELECTION TIME IS TAXING
description: If the projections and the predictions of the political pundits and pollsters have been thrown into disarray this Presidential election year because of the unforseen blossoming of Gary Hart and the demise of John Glenn as a candidate, how is it possible for a Washington-based Ambassador to sort out for ''back home'' consumption the latest inside betting on the Presidential sweepstakes?

title: CHELSEA'S VIGOR OVERLOADS PHONE COMPANY
description: So many people and businesses have been moving into Manhattan's Chelsea section in the past few years that the New York Telephone Company says it has been unable to give them all telephones. Now, the company says, it is trying to catch up.

title: MOUNTAIN STATES FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ROZELLE ACTS TO STUDY U.S.F.L. EFFECTS
description: The National Football League's annual meeting ended today, a day earlier than scheduled, with Commissioner Pete Rozelle appointing a six-man committee to study the long-range future of the league, including an examination of the effects of the United States Football League.

title: FINDINGS RAISE MANY QUESTIONS FOR INVESTIGATORS
description: The City Department of Investigation's findings against Anthony J. Alvarado carry implications that could occupy Federal, state and local authorities for a long time.

title: Metromedia Settles Acquisition Suit
description: Metromedia Inc. said it had agreed in principle on a settlement with stockholders who filed a class- action suit challenging the proposed acquisition of the communications company. The purchase is planned by a corporation formed by certain officials of Metromedia and by Boston Ventures.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Back With Ziegfeld Girls

title: SUNSTAR FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Up to a Million Iranians Reportedly Mobilized
description: Iran has mobilized up to a million regular troops, Revolutionary Guards and volunteers for what could be its biggest offensive so far in the Persian Gulf war, Iranian officials and foreign diplomats said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MEESE STATEMENT AND LETTER
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, concerning his request for the appointment of a special counsel, and a letter from Mr. Meese to Attorney General William French Smith: Meese Statement

title: Food; CHOPS (VEAL, LAMB OR PORK): SOME OF LIFE'S SIMPLE COMFORTS
description: CHOPS make a quick economical meal for one or two people. There is no waste and the cooking is fast. At this time of year lamb and veal are at their most delicate, spring vegetables are starting to appear on the market while the weather is still brisk enough for pork. There are few things as comforting as a chop, cooked simply and served with boiled new or mashed potatoes and young fresh peas, carrots or cauliflower.

title: DANCE: ROBIN HERTLEIN UNIT WITH SUITE OF 10 SHORT PIECES
description: TRAINS have an evocative power that would be hard, one would think, to summon up in dance. But Robin Hertlein and Dancers did just that in ''Train Meet'' on Wednesday at the Collective for Living Cinema.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S MAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Steel Suspension
description: The United States said today that it would suspend two trade agreements involving Brazilian steel because of ''serious deficiencies'' in Brazil's compliance.

title: CLOTHESTIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
DICARLO SETS MARK IN 500-YARD FREESTYLE
description: Most swimmers go their fastest at the start of a race and become slower as the race goes on. George DiCarlo, a 20- year-old Arizona junior from Denver, does it the other way, and he does it well.

title: OF ARCHBISHOP O'CONNER'S VIEWS ON ABORTION
description: T o the Editor:

title: Manville Proposal Might Dilute Stock
description: The Manville Corporation said that, in connection with its Chapter 11 reorganization proceedings, an alternative concept proposed by a creditor is being discussed among creditor groups, equity representatives and company representatives. The proposal contemplates a potentially significant dilution of the company's equity securities.

title: FILM: 'POLICE ACADEMY' WITH NO ENTRANCE RULES
description: ''POLICE ACADEMY'' is a rude, crude, noisy, sometimes disarmingly funny, liberated-sexist low comedy. The movie, which opens today at the Warner and other theaters, is ''Animal House'' redecorated as a school for police officers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am anxious to respond to any charges raised against me in an atmosphere which will provide for a fair and complete hearing.

title: RAPIST SOUGHT IN 4 ATTACKS, ONE FATAL, ON THE EAST SIDE
description: The police said yesterday that one man was responsible for the rape and murder of a 78-year-old woman and three other rapes in an Upper East Side housing project.

title: WILDERNESS EXPERIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $6,000. c-After a gain of $72,200 on the sale of retail stores and a tax credit of $2,300.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Woman Held as Suspect In Helping a Fugitive
description: A police records supervisor has been arrested and placed on leave after being indicted on charges that she wired $200 to a convicted killer whose escape from prison started an intensive manhunt, the authorities say.

title: 'NONUSE OF FORCE' OFFERED TO NATO
description: Western diplomats attending the East-West security conference in Stockholm say the Soviet Union is sending signals about how the Soviet-American negotiations on nuclear arms could resume.

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ABOUT PHILIDELPHIA
description: Trolley buffs, of which there are many here, love Route 23 and its trail through Philadelphia, from the northwest to the southeast, traversing historic old neighborhoods, through Germantown, past the teeming Reading Terminal Market in Center City and the Italian Market and rowhouses of South Philadelphia.

title: PRODUCER SEEKS A THEATER NAMED WILLIAMS
description: Amid the Helen Hayes Theater and the Eugene O'Neill, the Gershwin and the Belasco, there now stands the Jack Lawrence. The namesake said he never planned it that way. Until a current flurry of legal activity, Mr. Lawrence had named the former Playhouse Theater on West 48th Street for Tennessee Williams.

title: RE-ENTRY TERM INSURANCE
description: Many life insurance buyers have become increasingly aware during the last five to ten years of a type of policy, popularly called re-entry term insurance, that offers the potential for significantly lower annual premiums. But such contracts also have the potential for substantially larger premiums in future years if the insured is unable to meet the insurance company's medical requirements.

title: SEEKING A NARROWER MANDATE
description: When James C. Miller 3d took over as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission in October 1981, he was a man with a mission: to end what he perceived as the agency's adversarial relationship with the business community and to return the commission to a narrower mandate in consumer protection and antitrust regulation.

title: OPERA: DONIZETTI'S 'DOM SEBASTIEN'
description: In her tireless search for rare operas to present in concert form, Eve Queler is like a big-game hunter whose aim is to bring 'em back alive. She beats her way through the jungles of the forgotten repertory and oftener than not captures and tames her prey. Now and then, however, the conductor of the Opera Orchestra of New York brings a specimen back half alive, or less.

title: REAGAN REPORTED PREPARED TO STOP CUTS IN DISABILITY
description: Under pressure from the courts, state governments and Congress, the Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to stop reviewing and cutting off Social Security disability benefits for 18 months, Administration officials said today.

title: Reagan Campaign Gets $3.5 Million From U.S.
description: The Federal Election Commission today approved more than $3.5 million in matching campaign money for President Reagan, the first installment on an amount that is certain to grow.

title: Masonite Stock Trading Halted
description: The board of directors of the Masonite Corporation met yesterday and trading in the company's stock was halted amid speculation that the company was considering moves to thwart a possible takeover bid.

title: ESTES LINKS JOHNSON TO PLOT
description: Billy Sol Estes, the convicted confidence man who bilked Texas farmers out of millions of dollars in the 1960's, has told a county grand jury that Lyndon B. Johnson ordered the murder of a Federal official to keep him from disclosing Johnson's purported involvement in the fraud, according to John Paschall, the Robertson County District Attorney.

title: MUSIC: BRENDEL SOLOIST IN BEETOVAN CONCERTOS
description: Alfred Brendel's very special New York audience was waiting for him at Carnegie Hall Thursday night. This was the first of three all-Beethoven concerts with the Y Chamber Symphony under Gerard Schwarz. Over the course of them, Mr. Brendel will be the soloist in the five piano concertos.

description: CYRIL CONNOLLY: JOURNAL AND

title: U.S. SAYS MOSCOW REFUSED A LETTER FROM PRESIDENT
description: A private American envoy carrying a personal message from President Reagan to Konstantin U. Chernenko in Moscow was not given the opportunity to meet with the Soviet leader or any other top Soviet official, according to Administration officials.

title: COBB NOT GUILTY IN POINT-SHAVING TRIAL
description: Ernie Cobb, the star of the Boston College basketball team in the 1978-79 season, was found not guilty yesterday of charges that he joined a game- rigging conspiracy to benefit gamblers that season.

title: ARDEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $308,000. c-After an extraordinary gain of $64,000.

PRO-ISRAEL LOBBY'S LOW KEY POWER
description: Once again Washington is talking about the influence of what critics and supporters alike consider the most effective foreign policy lobbying group in the capital, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee.

title: CAUCUSES LOOMING FOR THREE STATES By The Associated Press
description: Democrats in Virginia, Kansas and Montana will hold caucuses this weekend to begin deciding how 124 delegates to their party's national convention will be divided.

title: Mitterrand Says Unit Will Quit Beirut Soon WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) - President Francois Mitterrand said at a news conference here today that French soldiers had accomplished their mission in Lebanon and would soon be leaving.
description: He did not indicate a departure date. But his spokesman, Michel Vauzelle, told French reporters traveling with Mr. Mitterrand that it would be ''a question of days'' until conditions for replacing the 1,200 French soldiers in Beirut are arranged.

title: No Headline
description: Three Deaths in Jersey Linked to Fake Heroin

title: LOCAL COSTS UP BY 0.6% LAST MONTH
description: Local Costs Up by 0.6% Last Month

title: Reagan Picks Envoy For Eagleburger's Job
description: President Reagan announced today that he would nominate Michael H. Armacost to become Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs.

title: NORMAL PHONE SERVICE IN CITY SEEN BY JULY 1
description: The New York Telephone Company hopes to have telephone service back to normal by July 1, according to the chairman of New York Telephone's parent company, the Nynex Corporation.

title: L J N TOYS LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,275,000, or 25 cents a share.

title: RATE RISE APPROVED FOR UTILITY IN JERSEY
description: The Board of Public Utilities today authorized the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, to increase electric rates by between 9.2 percent and 11.4 percent and gas rates by between 4 percent and 4.7 percent.

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
ARCHBISHOP LAW SEATED AS BOSTON CHURCH HEAD
description: With this city's Roman Catholic Cathedral brimming with joy and song, Archbishop Bernard F. Law was seated today as the eighth bishop of Boston.

title: Eagle Expects Loss in Quarter
description: Eagle Computer Inc. said today that it expects to report a loss of $7 million to $9 million for the third quarter, ending March 31, compared with profits of $767,000, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Knicks in Playoffs
description: The Knicks had last night off, but gained a playoff berth when the Indiana Pacers defeated the Chicago Bulls. Eight teams from each conference advance to the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: SOUTHWEST FOREST TAKEOVER ACCORD
description: Southwest Forest Industries would be acquired by a group of investors organized by Morgan Stanley & Company and led by W.A. Franke, the chief executive of Southwest, under an agreement announced yesterday.

title: THE WOMAN SOLDIER'S PLACE IN AMERICA'S VOLUNTEER FORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: State of Emergency Reimposed in Chile
description: The military Government reimposed a state of emergency tonight that gives commanders power to order curfews, prohibit public gatherings and ban publications.

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,163,739 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change on the prior year and a gain of $628,997 from capital gains from the disposition of a subsidiary. c-After a loss of $440,993 from capital gains from the disposition of a subsidiary.

title: KENNEDY CENTER SEEKS TO AVOID DEBT INTEREST
description: The Kennedy Center today asked Congress to excuse the $30 million it owes in interest on construction bonds that were used to build the performing arts center on the banks of the Potomac River.

title: 'New Show' Is Canceled By NBC Over Ratings
description: ''The New Show,'' a weekly prime- time topical comedy series produced by Lorne Michaels, the creator of ''Saturday Night Live,'' was canceled yesterday by NBC for low audience ratings.

title: Paraguayan Editor Held
description: The authorities transferred the editor and owner of ABC Color, the nation's largest circulation daily newspaper, from jail to house arrest today. The editor, Aldo Zuccolillo, was arrested March 15, but no charges have been filed against him. ABC Color was ordered indefinitely closed Thursday by the Interior Ministry, which accused the paper of endangering the public peace and stability.

title: GIVE COMMUTERS A 'DASHBOAT' ALTERNATIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISERS PLEASED BY F.T.C. PLAN
description: Advertising executives today welcomed a planned policy shift at the Federal Trade Commission that would formally end the practice of industrywide checks in pursuit of deceptive advertising. Instead, individual ad campaigns would be investigated.

title: LARGE EXERCISE WITH HONDURAS TO START APRIL 1
description: The Defense Department announced today that it would begin large-scale maneuvers in Honduras on April 1, earlier than originally planned.

title: Prices Drop in Belgium
description: Wholesale prices in Belgium declined two-tenths of 1 percent in February from January, but were up 10.4 percent from February 1983, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: CHAMBERS, PATRIOT
description: On Monday, President Reagan will award a posthumous National Medal The news has been greeted with surprise and confusion in some quarters, with anger and outrage in others. In fact, the honor is more than deserved.

title: 4 Troupes' Dancers In International Bill
description: Dancers from the American Ballet Theater, Paris Opera Ballet, Pennsylvania Ballet and Stuttgart Ballet will be featured in an international dance program at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College tomorrow at 2 P.M.

title: DEATH SENTENCE FOR MAN WHO ADMITTED KILLING 5
description: Arthur Bishop, a bookkeeper who told the police he had killed five boys for fear they would expose him as a child molester, was sentenced early today to death by injection or firing squad.

title: UNIT DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss included a provision to reduce the carrying value of the company's inventory of undeveloped oil and gas leases by $20,514,000. The loss for 1983 is principally attributable to a $3.4 million provision to reduce the carrying value of the company's inventory of undeveloped oil and gas leases and to lower contract drilling utilization and rates which resulted in decreased operating margins.

title: OAK INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income after a tax credit of $17,160,000. The latest year results include charges of about $59,387,000, including $20,981,000 related to operations of its Oak-Adec Inc. unit, which designs and installs energy management systems.

title: MONDALE SAYS HART'S VIEWS ON MIDEAST ARE CONFUSED
description: Walter F. Mondale pressed his appeal yesterday for the sizable Jewish vote in the New York primary by deploring a Middle East policy of ''illusion'' or ''confusion.''

title: HERITAGE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $162,000 for the quarter and $477,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: Sharp Objects Found In Girl Scout Cookies
description: Girl Scout officials announced today that they had blocked the sale and distribution of about 700,000 boxes of cookies after reports this week that needles and paper clips had been found in some of the cookies.

title: Poll-Taker Issues a Warning On Relying on Early Results
description: Walter F. Mondale's pollster says the lesson of the primaries thus far is to beware of public opinion polls.

title: KNIGHT'S TRIUMPH WAS ONE OF TACTICS
description: North Carolina came into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament ranked No. 1 and favored to move to the title game behind three of the best players in the nation - Michael Jordan, Sam Perkins and Matt Doherty.

title: Radioactive Gas Escapes At South Carolina Plant
description: Radioactive gas escaped today from the Savannah River Plant, the largest producer of plutonium and tritium for the nation's nuclear arsenal, but officials said the release posed no danger to health.

title: A PACT ON RADIOACTIVE WASTE NOT FOR NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Perez Is Guilty, Receives Fine SANTIAGO, Dominican Republic, March 23 (AP) - Pascual Perez, the Atlanta Braves' pitcher, was convicted today of a reduced charge of cocaine possession, fined $1,000 and ordered released from prison. But the prosecutor, who had sought a conviction for trafficking and a minimum sentence of two years, filed an immediate appeal of the verdict, an action that resulted in Perez being returned from the courthouse to jail.
description: The prospect that the 26-year-old right-hander could rejoin Atlanta in time for the opening of the season was in doubt.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS
description: Dollar Mostly Lower; Gold Prices Also Fall

title: SCOUTING
description: Happy as Hoosier

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page A1 Thursday, identifying the New York Board of Education, misstated the meeting time. It was before Anthony J. Alvarado announced that he was taking a leave as Schools Chancellor.

title: ADVANCE EDUCATORS BY MERIT
description: Allegations about the finances and conduct of Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado, illustrate vividly why responsibility for giving supervisory examinations should remain with the Board of Examiners rather than be invested in the Chancellor's office. The appearance of favoritism in selecting educators for advancement into supervisory positions damages schools and our children.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
DENNY MCLAIN'S STAR
description: fans followed Denny McLain's

title: FOUL-HUMORED RHINOS GOING TO TEXAS HAVEN
description: Five angry black rhinoceroses arrived in blustery cold weather at Kennedy International Airport yesterday after an 18-hour flight from Johannesburg. They demonstrated why humans and other animals usually give them a wide berth.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-After tax credits of $424,000 for the quarter and $492,000 for the 9 months, and a gain of $152,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of the company's Santa Ana manufacturing facility. c-After tax credits of $272,000 for the quarter and $824,000 for the 9 months.

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $255,000. c-Net loss.

title: MITTERRAND BIDS U.S. NOT RILE MOSCOW
description: President Francois Mitterrand, at the end of two days of talks with Administration officials, warned today against ''creating new causes of dissension'' in East- West relations at a time when the Soviet Union may be reassessing its position on arms control talks.

title: RIVERSIDE SHAKESPEARE IN FINANCIAL TROUBLE
description: Leaders of the Riverside Shakespeare Company say they are not sure that the company can continue operating after its production of ''Caesar'' closes tomorrow.

title: Flute-Guitar Recital
description: The flutist Jean-Pierre-Rampal and the guitarist Alexandre Lagoya will present a joint recital at Carnegie Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. The program will include works by Bach, Telemann, Carulli, Legnani and Ravi Shankar. Tickets are $10 to $17.50, at the box office.

title: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
CORRECTIONS
description: A dispatch by United Press International from Jackson, Miss., in some copies yesterday, on Mississippi's ratification of the women's suffrage amendment to the Constitution, incorrectly described Delaware's action on the amendment. Delaware ratified it.

title:
PATENTS;
'Talking Micrometer'
description: A device called a ''talking micrometer,'' patented this week, is able to describe the measurements of objects in words, such as a train of numbers. Jerome H. Lemelson, who received patent 4,437,241, says the instrument will be particularly useful for people who are blind or have poor eyesight, and will offer advantages over conventional micrometers such as reducing eye fatigue and reading errors. Mr. Lemelson, who operates a licensing management corporation in New York, expects to license production of the device.

title: MONDALE , IN CONNECTICUT CALLS ITS VOTE 'IMPORTANT'
description: Walter F. Mondale made a 99- minute airport stop here late today to assure his supporters that he had not forgotten Connecticut and its Democratic Presidential primary election on Tuesday.

title: No Headline
description: The Board of Public Utilities today authorized the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, to increase electric rates by between 9.2 percent and 11.4 percent and gas rates by between 4 percent and 4.7 percent.

title: Southern Union Settlement Bid
description: The Southern Union Gas Company has offered to sell its New Mexico gas utility for $173.5 million to settle a price- fixing lawsuit, Southern Union officials said, while not conceding any wrongdoing. The proposal calls for Southern Union to sell Gas Company of New Mexico, the state's biggest gas company, to the Public Service Company of New Mexico, the biggest electric company, Southern Union's treasurer, Ronald Endres, said.

title: DAYTON GAINS IN WEST BY 64-58
description: The Dayton basketball team dubbed this season ''the Year of Dreams.'' For now, the dream endures.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: SCOUTING
description: Moving Ahead

title: Hebert Plans Shift
description: Bobby Hebert , the quarterback who led the Michigan Panthers to the first United States Football League championship last year, said he was deep in negotiations with five National Football League teams and expected to jump to the N.F.L. when his U.S.F.L. contract expires after the 1985 season. ''It's really been serious talks, and something could happen within a couple of weeks,'' said Hebert, who identified his N.F.L. suitors as the Giants, the Dallas Cowboys, the New Orleans Saints, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
U.S.-China Data Link
description: ITT World Communications Inc. has established a major high-speed data communications link between China and the United States, company officials said. The two countries had previously been limited to telex service, which provides information at a considerably slower pace, the company said Thursday.

title: VOLCKER CITES INFLATIONARY PRESSURES
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, suggested today that the Fed would stick to its commitment to moderate growth of the economy and stable prices.

title: 'Calypso Comes to Harlem'
description: ''Calypso Comes to Harlem'' will be presented tonight at 8 in the Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street. The concert will feature three of Trinidad's best-known soca (soul-calypso- performers - Penguin, Explainer and Lord Nelson. Tickets are $12 to $15, and the number for more information is 661-3344.

title: HAROLD RAY
description: Harold Ray, a retired New Jersey banking executive, died Thursday in Mercer Medical Center in Trenton.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $78,000 for the quarter and $145,000 for the 6 months.

title: JUDGE, IRATE AT DRUG SALES, CALLS FOR ORDER IN THE PARK
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan was designed to be a temple of the law. Its facade includes statues of Moses, Confucius and Justinian. Murals in its courtroom salute ''The Power of the Law'' and ''The Reign of Law.''

title: UNION'S STRUGGLE RAISES TENSIONS AT YALE
description: Yale University clerical and technical workers and the university administration are engaged in a labor dispute over the workers' demands for a contract.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Triple Whammy

title: HELEN OF TROY CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $62,389. c-Includes a tax credit of $381,972. Year-ago revenues are restated for accounting changes.

title: AN OLD WASHINGTON TOOL IS TURNED AGAINST DEATH SQUADS IN EL SALVADOR
description: For the last two months a small, cluttered apartment in a middle-income neighborhood of Washington has served as the nerve center of a campaign aimed at altering the political landscape of El Salvador and the course of American policy in Central America.

title: CHERRY VALLEY CAN DO WITHOUT A POWER LINE
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWSUIT SEEKS TO BAR INCREASE IN HOMELESS SHELTERED IN ARMORY
description: A suit to block a proposed increase in the number of homeless men housed in the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue was filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday by the Veterans of the Seventh Regiment.

title: THE STRONGEST CONTENDER, SOME SAY, IS NOT IN SALVADOR RACE
description: In a country that has been polarized by its presidential campaign, the man who moderates and conservatives agree might have been able to bridge the differences between them is not a candidate.

title: Scouts Join Search For Killer's Victims
description: Explorer Scouts joined homicide detectives today in a search of a thickly overgrown area for victims of a killer who apparently preys on prostitutes.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Brussels dispatch yesterday on the Common Market incorrectly suggested the origin of the phrase ''sick man of Europe.'' While the phrase was applied to France in the 1950's by Paul Reynaud, a former Prime Minister, it was coined by Czar Nicholas I in 1853 in reference to Turkey.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH TO PROTESTBAR RAPE CONVICTIONS
description: Thousands of people marched here today to protest the conviction of four men of raping a young woman in a bar in nearby New Bedford.

title: Newsprint Prices
description: Consolidated-Bathurst Inc., following the lead of two other newsprint producers, said it will increase its newsprint price 7 percent, to $535 a metric ton, from $500, effective July 1. A spokesman for the company, which is based in Montreal, said the increase was needed to offset costs in all areas of manufacturing and distribution, particularly energy, maintenance material, labor and operating supplies. Similar price increases were announced Wednesday by Great Lakes Forest Products of Thunder Bay, Ontario, and Reed Inc. of Quebec.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes income of $46,000 from discontinued operations.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G, CO INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 27
description: Results for the latest year reflect a $60,000 reduction in net income in the second quarter to correct an error and defer recognition of a gain on the sale of property.

title: QUEENSTAKE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ARGENTINE PLAN RAISING, DOUBTS ON AID BY BANKS
description: The Argentine Government has presented an outline of its economic program to the International Monetary Fund, amid widespread conjecture that the draft may not be specific enough to secure the release of vital bank financing.

title: HARLEM HOUSING FAILURE: JAILED LANDLORD SAYS HE LOST TO SYSTEM
description: Riding the train between his home in Bronxville in Westchester County and his real-estate company on Park Avenue, Clinton W. Blume Jr. used to look out the windows at the lengthening stretches of abandoned buildings in Harlem.

title: REGAN ASKS BOARD TO MEET TODAY ON ALVARADO'S STATUS
description: The Board of Education will meet today to consider Anthony J. Alvarado's standing as head of the New York City school system, the board's president said yesterday.

title: COMPUTER IDENTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Warner Unit Sale
description: Warner Amex Cable Communications said it had agreed to sell its Pittsburgh cable system to Tele-Communications Inc. The sale, which had been expected for weeks, is for a combination of cash and notes totaling $93.4 million. The Pittsburgh system, which passes 165,000 homes, has 74,000 basic subscribers.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A report in the Weekender Guide column yesterday about a square dance at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine gave the day incorrectly. It takes place tonight.

title: LAST OF COMPOSER'S 65 OPERAS
description: ''Dom Sebastien, Roi de Portugal,'' the last of Donizetti's 65 operas, had its premiere at the Paris Opera on Nov. 11, 1843, with Rosine Stoltz as Zaida and Gilbert-Louis Duprez in the title role. Composed a year after one of his most popular comedies, ''Don Pasquale,'' and in the same year as the more serious ''Maria di Rohan,'' it was enthusiastically received by contemporary audiences but disparaged by most critics.

title: FOR SAFETY, BUCKLE UP 6-YEAR-OLDS
description: and seven-year olds, prepare

title: PUBLIC ACCESS TV RATINGS DISPUTED
description: Only a small fraction of cable-television viewers watch public-access channels, according to research recently released by a major operator of urban cable systems.

title: A.T.& T. Limit On Credit Calls
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, faced with a growing problem of telephone fraud, received special permission today from the Federal Communications Commission to stop accepting credit-card phone calls to 18 nations.

title: BRELAND GETS 5TH GLOVESTITLE
description: It took Mark Breland only 42 seconds last night at Madison Square Garden to become the first five-time champion of the New York Golden Gloves Tournament.

title: Article 074105 -- No Title
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it had completed the placement of a record $1 billion bond offering abroad. When the 10-year, convertible bond issue was announced on March 15, it was set at $800 million, but Texaco said the size of the issue was increased because of investor interest. Texaco plans to use the proceeds to help restructure its debt following the $10.1 billion purchase of the Getty Oil Company in February.

title: Cocoa Price Talks Set
description: Formal negotiations on a new international agreement aimed at stabilizing world cocoa prices will be held in Geneva in May, the International Cocoa Organization Governing Council said today.

title: Return Engagement
description: Nevada gambling authorities have agreed to reinstitute a limited betting ban that will allow the Utah Jazz of the National Basketball Association to continue playing up to 11 games a season in Las Vegas, according to Sam Battistone , the Jazz's owner. To clear the way for the Jazz to play in Las Vegas this season, the Nevada Gaming Commission had banned betting on Jazz games played in Las Vegas, but under pressure from local bookmakers the ban was lifted last week, prompting Battistone to announce that the Jazz could not fulfill a commitment to play in Las Vegas next season.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Bowling Green In Hockey Final

title: ANXIETY STRIKES A STEEL TOWN
description: Larry Couch, the third generation of his family to work at the Republic Steel Corporation's mill here, says he has felt lost since Wednesday, when he learned that the mill must be sold as a condition for Republic to merge with the LTV Corporation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Public Mass

title: No Headline
description: The Arts at St. Ann's (834-8794) is presenting ''A Cappella,'' a weekend of music for unaccompanied vocal groups. Today at 3 P.M., the Georgia Sea Island singers will lead a ''Rhythm and Gamesong Workshop,'' featuring the singing, stamping and clapping games of the African-American folk tradition. They will also perform a concert of shouts, work songs, spirituals, hollers and slave songs tonight at 8, sharing a bill with the Harmonic Chroir, which has adapted the sacred chanting techniques of Mongolia and Tibet to produce many notes at once.

title: JIFFY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KASPAROV FORCES DRAW IN SIXTH CHESS GAME
description: Careful defense got Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union a draw yesterday against his countryman Vasily Smyslov in the sixth game of their final candidates chess match.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Nick Fotiu , the Ranger left wing who tried to climb into the stands to attack heckling fans during last Tuesday night's game against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden, was fined $500 and suspended for three games after a National Hockey League hearing. . . . Paul Phipps resigned as general manager of the San Diego Clippers to open a sports media business. . . . Carl Lewis , the long jumper, and 47 other American track and field stars who were recently tested for drugs in the first such testing of athletes in the United States have all passed the tests.

title: Brokerage Sues Houston Gas
description: Prudential-Bache Securities yesterday sued the Houston Natural Gas Corporation, along with M.D. Matthews, its chairman and 14 other directors, on charges that they breached their fiduciary duties to stockholders in refusing to seriously consider takeover bids for the company. Prudential, a brokerage, said it owns 90,000 shares of Houston Gas.

title: LTV AGREES TO PAY A RECORD PENALTY FOR POLLUTION
description: The Justice Department reached a settlement today with the LTV Corporation and its subsidiary, Jones & Laughlin Steel Inc., requiring the companies to spend $30 million to control air pollution and pay $4 million in civil penalties for violating the Clean Air Act and three court orders.

title: AMERICAN WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SPEX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Spex Industries became a wholly owned subsidiary of Spex Group Inc. in February 1984.

title: REGENTS ADOPT STRICTER STANDARDS FOR HIGH SCHOOL DIPLOMAS IN STATE
description: After two and a half years of deliberations, the State Board of Regents yesterday adopted new high school graduation requirements that are among the most rigorous in the country.

title: PRICES MIXED IN SLOW TRADING
description: Credit market prices were mixed yesterday after trading erratically in a narrow range. Activity was slow and yields fluctuated, amid growing concern that an increase was imminent in the discount rate, which the Federal Reserve charges on loans to member banks.

title: NEW RULES PUZZLE SALVADOR VOTERS
description: New regulations intended to reduce fraud in presidential elections Sunday have produced confusion among voters over the location of polling places and concern among Salvadoran and United States officials here.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ECLECTIC There's a new exhibition at Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street (535-8810), that is designed to illustrate guidelines of what might be considered the very best standards for those who collect as an avocation. This exhibition, ''The Art of Collecting,'' through April 21, includes 46 works by American artists from the 1750's through the 1940's.

title: A SPECIALIST ON U.S. INDUSTRY
description: Dr. Louis C. Hunter, a retired professor of economic history and an internationally-known authority on the industrial development of the United States, died Thursday at the Harvard Community Health Plan Hospital in Boston. He was 85 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass., and Thetford, Vt.

title: Report on Mark Denied
description: West Germany's central bank today denied a newspaper report that said central bankers in the United States, Germany and other countries were ready to prevent the dollar from falling under an exchange rate of 2.50 West German marks. The West German newspaper Neue Presse, quoting informed central bank sources, had said that the German central bank considered a dollar exchange rate of 2.60 marks ''ideal.''

title: CUOMO PRAISES LEGISLATORS FOR STRONG ROLE IN FORMING BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo, who was bypassed in legislative talks on a new state budget, praised the Legislature yesterday for ''suggesting changes'' and said he expected the budget to be adopted on time for the second year in a row.

description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

Louisiana Will Appeal Order to Hold Primary
description: Louisiana will appeal to the Supreme Court an order Wednesday from three Federal judges to hold a Presidential primary the state says it cannot afford, the chief election planner said Thursday.

title: NOTRE DAME WINS, GAINING SEMIFINALS
description: Joe Howard hit a driving layup and added four key free throws as Notre Dame broke open a tight game in the final three minutes to defeat Pittsburgh, 72-64, in the National Invitation Tournament today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Times Tower Contest

title: Colt to Miss Wood
description: Angel Penna, trainer of Time for a Change, says the colt has recovered from a virus but will miss the Wood Memorial Stakes on April 21 and may have to miss the Kentucky Derby May 5 because of time lost in training. Time for a Change became one of the Derby favorites after beating Dr. Carter and Devil's Bag in the Flamingo Stakes March 3.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
MONDALE TACTICS FAULTED BY HART
description: Senator Gary Hart charged today that Walter F. Mondale had not set forth a positive program in their contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but had instead ''dedicated his recent campaign to tearing me down.''

title: 12 Danish Fishermen Hurt by Mustard Gas
description: Twelve fishermen have been blinded and burned in less than a week by mustard gas dragged up by their trawlers from stockpiles of German weapons dumped in the Baltic Sea at the end of World War II, Danish maritime authorities said today.

title:
PATENTS;
A Procedure to Permit Hydroponic Farming
description: A method of cultivating plants by placing their roots in liquid fertilizers rather than in soil was patented this week by Richard S. Carlisle of Rye, N.Y. He has said that the hydroponic apparatus and procedure, covered by patent 4,437,264, will allow commercial farmers and hobbyists alike to produce top-quality vegetable and ornamental crops without electricity.

title: Pizza Time Cites Default on Bond
description: Pizza Time Theater Inc. said it is in default on a $50 million bond issue and must pay in full by next Friday.

title: PERSISTENT QUESTION ABOUT DISCREPANCIES ON HART BACKGROUND
description: Senator Gary Hart's candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination continues to be dogged by a number of questions about his personal background.

title: Christ the King And Truman Gain
description: Truman High School of the Bronx, the New York City Public Schools Athletic League champion, and Christ the King of Queens, the Catholic Schools Athletic Association champion, advanced to the Class A semifinals of the New York State basketball tournament tonight and will meet Saturday.

title: SCOUTING
description: Winning Recipe

title: Wintry Storms Blamed In 27 Deaths in West The Associated Press
description: Thunderstorms pounded Texas and Oklahoma yesterday with heavy rain and hail, while a Rockies snowstorm moved east. The storms have been blamed for 27 deaths this week.

title: A SHAKEOUT IN COFFIN INDUSTRY Manufacturers of coffins in the United States, beset by changing demographics, the increasing use of cremations and new Government regulations, are trying to improve their marketing strategies to generate more revenue from what has become an essentially stagnant, $600 million industry.
description: They are installing computers, hiring more sales personnel and putting more decorative moldings and finishes on their coffins. In addition, they are improving their product presentations to funeral directors - their main customers - and speeding up delivery times.

description: Coca-Cola has agreed under pressure from New York State to change its advertising and its labeling for Diet Coke and Diet Sprite. But it is not the only company making claims that are not so precise.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.4% IN MONTH
description: The increase in consumer prices slowed to four-tenths of 1 percent in February as rises in food prices abated and gasoline and clothing prices declined, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: DELAY CONTINUED ON SECURITY RULE
description: The Reagan Administration has retreated another step from its plan to impose lifelong censorship and expanded polygraph, or lie-detector, testing of officials to guard national security secrets, according to correspondence made public this week.

Quotation of the Day

title: NAMING OF MEESE PROSESCUTOR HELD UP
description: The Justice Department will probably not apply for a special prosecutor to investigate Edwin Meese 3d until next week at the earliest, Reagan Administration officials said today, because the law requires a preliminary inquiry first.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, MARCH 24, 1984 International
description: President Reagan's envoy carrying a letter to Konstantin U. Chernenko was ignored in Moscow, Administration officials said. The officials said the envoy, Lieut. Gen. Brent Scowcroft, retired, chairman of the President's Commission on Strategic Forces, told Soviet officials when he was in Moscow two weeks ago that he had a letter from Mr. Reagan and some additional authorized comments, but they made no response. Administration officials said they could not recall a similar instance in Soviet-American relations. (Page 1, Column 1.) Major U.S. maneuvers in Honduras will begin April 1, earlier than planned, the Defense Department announced. They will take place a week after the first round of the presidential election in neighboring El Salvador. American officials in San Salvador have said they do not expect the election to result in a clear winner and that they believe a runoff election is likely, with an increase in violence during the runoff campaign. The Pentagon said the maneuvers would continue during the campaign for the second vote. (1:2.)

'Mime and Movement'
description: ''New Mime and Movement Performance Series,'' the fourth mime festival of the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association Inc., begins this weekend at the Downtown Cultural Center, 111 Willoughby Street, where it can be seen Fridays and Saturdays at 8 until April 14. Tickets are $5. Reservations and information: 596- 2222.

title: WAKE FOREST UPSETS DEPAUL IN OVERTIME IN MIDWEST
description: Ray Meyer's sentimental journey came to an end tonight. The 70-year-old coach of DePaul fell three games short of his retirement goal when a layup by Danny Young gave Wake Forest a surprising 73-71 overtime victory in the Midwest Regional.

title: NETS WIN AS DAWKINS GETS 33
description: The four- year spell Boston Garden held over the Nets came to an end tonight, helped by the absence of Robert Parish but despite the strong presence of Larry Bird.

title: Virginia Tech 72 Tennessee 68
description: Virginia Tech combined opportunistic defense with 27 points from Dell Curry to earn a berth in the National Invitation Tournament semifinals.

title: YANKS UNSURE OF ROBERTSON'S CONDITION
description: Andre Robertson has begun to sound like a stuck record. ''I'm ready,'' he said today. ''That's the only two words I can say - I'm ready.''

title: Bridge: Drew Casen Outwitted Foes In a Deal at Spring Nationals
description: The younger generation of New York experts was well in evidence during the recent Spring Nationals in San Antonio. On the diagramed deal, from the Vanderbilt knockout teams, Drew Casen had to play a tricky three no-trump and survived in a difficult end position.

title: 4TH WORLD TITLE FOR HAMILTON
description: Scott Hamilton of the United States, the Olympic champion, won his fourth straight world figure skating title tonight with a medley of triple jumps, dizzying spins and lightning-quick footwork.

title: Times Square as a Living Stage
description: The 42d Street redevelopment plan opens on Broadway Monday night. The big, bold plan, intended to rescue Times Square from tawdry vice and violence, needs no formal public approval. That means the hearing at Town Hall Monday will be the first and the most important chance the public will have to comment. We hope people will turn out to applaud the plan enthusiastically - but also to insist that the sponsors put some life into it.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks are without Bernard King, who has a dislocated finger, and Marvin Webster, suffering from a viral infection. title: U.S. ELECTION SEEN AFFECTING MOSCOW
description: Despite gestures by the Reagan Administration toward breaking the impasse in Soviet- American relations, Western diplomats and visitors who have talked with senior Soviet officials believe that a number of factors, including uncertainty over the Presidential election, are likely to persuade the Kremlin to remain cool toward Washington's overtures for some time to come.

title: Briton Jailed for Leaking Memo on Cruise Missile
description: A 23-year-old Foreign Office clerk was sentenced today to six months in prison after she admitted in court that she leaked to the press a secret memorandum on the scheduled arrival date of cruise missiles in Britain.

title: COURT PERMITS A TRANSFUSION FOR INFANT BOY
description: Doctors at the State University Hospital at Stony Brook obtained a court order today authorizing a blood transfusion during surgery for the 4-month-old son of a Jehovah's Witness.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Bad News for Burleson
description: He made a limited comeback last year and hoped to resume full-time duty this season, but it now appears that Rick Burleson 's hopes have been dashed once again. The 32-year-old California Angel shortstop, who suffered a serious rotator cuff injury at the beginning of the 1982 season, suffered severe shoulder pains during an exhibition game Wednesday.

title: Two Rodgers Awards AnnouncedforMusicals
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letter yesterday announced the winners of two prizes in musical theater, which were created and endowed by Richard Rodgers.

title: BRITISH FASHION: HOW IT SHIFTED INTO HIGH GEAR
description: Geraldine Stutz, president of Henri Bendel, was standing in a crush of taffeta at Harvey Nichols, the London department store, where a formal dinner was being given to celebrate the last day of the British fashion collections. Waiters carried trays of pink Champagne as they navigated around such guests as Viscountess Rothermere, whom everyone knows as Bubbles; Sir Nicholas Henderson, Zandra Rhodes and Terence Conran. The room buzzed with the news that the Princess of Wales had just visited Olympia, the cavernous exhibition hall where the British designers had exhibited their clothes for four days.

SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
