title: BIG BATTLE CLEARS STREETS OF BEIRUT
description: Druse and Moslem militiamen fought fierce battles in West Beirut for a second day today, transforming the city's western neighborhoods into ghost towns as most civilians abandoned the streets to the young fighters.

title: 3 Children Killed in Explosion Of Antitank Shell in Carport
description: Three children died and a fourth was seriously injured when a 66-millimeter antitank shell they were playing with exploded in a carport, officials say.

title: RIGHTS MOVEMENT LEADERS GATHER IN MEMORY OF ONE OF THEIR OWN
description: The nation's battle-weary civil rights movement closed its ranks today to pay a moving farewell to one of its own.

title:
PATENTS;
New Enzyme Material Aids Blood Filtration
description: Patients with blood diseases, including leukemia and other forms of cancer, can be treated by passing their blood through an outside artificial filter for cleansing.

title: A GROWTH INDUSTRY
description: New York, the Empire State, can be proud to be No. 1 in many accomplishments. Of recent and unheralded note, however, is the success of the Experimental Sumac Plantation developed along the Henry Hudson Parkway (between the George Washington Bridge and the northern tip of Manhattan) by the New York State Department of Highways.

title: Jackson Group Contests Alaska Caucus Tally
description: The Jesse Jackson for President Committee has filed a complaint in Superior Court in Anchorage alleging that the Democratic Party in Alaska made a mistake in the counts in last week's precinct caucuses, causing their candidate to lose votes.

title: ILLINI MUST CONQUER ARENA,TOO
description: It was beginning to look a lot like Christmas. In fact, on the night of last Dec. 24, the last time Kentucky played a basketball game against Illinois, the city of Champaign, Ill., was beginning to look a lot like the North Pole.

Bail Set in Molestation Case
description: The owner of a beach city nursery school and six other people were jailed today under bonds of up to $1 million on 115 counts of child molestation.

title: Repayment Set At Baldwin
description: The Pulaski County Circuit Court in Little Rock, Ark., approved a plan under which investors in Baldwin-United annuities would receive their money back over a maximum period of three and a half years and most likely at a below-market interest rate.

title: NAMING OF VICTIM IN RAPE TRIAL ON T.V. AND IN NEWSPAPERS PROMPTS DEBATE
description: Yesterday morning the NBC News ''Today'' program named the woman raped by four men in a bar in New Bedford, Mass., last year. One of the prosecutors used the name in a live interview, and the producer of the program said he saw no reason to edit it out.

title: IN THE MODERN CHINA: DIETS, MAIDS AND NOSE JOBS
description: Women who want to firm their figures and shed a few pounds have hied themselves to Qi Yufang's exercise class in the Caltdi Gritchongwen workers' district in central Peking. The class promotes ''jianmei,'' which means health and beauty in Chinese, and hundreds of women ranging in age from 16 to 54 have sought it by attending the short courses run by the 44-year-old former gymnast.

title: GARCIA'S OF SCOTTSDALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After nonrecurring expenses of $515,000 relating to the acquisition of Famous Restaurants Inc., the estimated loss on disposals of land, and relocation expenses for recently hired officers.

title: MID-MARCH AUTO SALES UP BY 33.7%
description: New-car sales in mid-March rose 33.7 percent over the same selling period last year, the nation's six major manufacturers reported today.

title: BOARD'S RETICENCE
description: News Analysis

title: OUR SAMURAI SPRING
description: Even if the professional football season weren't in full bloom, there are a lot of other ways you can tell spring has arrived. Knowing the season is important, because we're expected to behave accordingly. Winter, for instance, is for dormantly lying. As in the Meese case.

title: Nomination Criticized
description: Representative James Florio, Democrat of New Jersey, says that Gov. Thomas H. Kean should withdraw his nomination of Robert W. Lee for state athletic commissioner because a recent report charged that regulation of boxing in New Jersey is inadequate and inappropriate. Lee, the deputy commissioner of the state Athletic Commission and president of the International Boxing Federation, was nominated last week to succeed Jersey Joe Walcott , the former heavyweight champion, who retired as commissioner in February. The State Commission of Investigation charged in a 72-page report released Monday that the Athletic Commission has been ''demonstrably unable to cope with its regulatory obligations or keep pace with its workload.''

title: 27 Injured in High-Rise Fire
description: Fire broke out in a first-floor restaurant at a high-rise apartment building early today, spreading smoke through the 13-story building and trapping scores of people for about an hour, the authorities said. Twenty-seven people were treated at hospitals, a fire department spokesman said, most of them for smoke inhalation.

title: CARRYING HEAVY METAL
description: I am organized and proud of it. When people ask the secret of my success, I say, ''I owe it all to staying organized.'' Show me a failure and I'll show you somebody who forgot to get his building permit, neglected to file an environmental impact statement and hasn't had his engine oil changed in the past ten months.

title: Computervision Financial Data
description: The Computervision Corporation said its auditors had qualified their opinions on the company's financial statements for 1981 through 1983 in light of the large damages sought by the Perkin-Elmer Corporation in a pending suit. The litigation stems from a suit filed in 1977 by Perkin-Elmer against Computervision's former Cobilt division that charged patent infringement.

title: Stocks Down Slightly; Rate Fears Cited Again
description: Investors' fears that interest rates will move higher sent stock prices down a bit more yesterday in slower trading.

title: DUTCH GOVERNMENT IN QUANDRY OVER STATIONING OF NATO MISSILES
description: After deferring the question several times, the Dutch Government faces an imminent decision on whether to accept the 48 American cruise missiles assigned to it by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. All available evidence suggests that it will not be able to carry out a full deployment on schedule.

title: DINERS SITTING OUT 'GREAT WINE WAR'
description: Restaurant owners who traditionally have allowed customers to brown-bag wine or beer say their business has dropped dramatically this week as state and local officials quibble about a law that prohibits the practice. The issue arose last week when the State Liquor Authority said it planned to investigate and, if warranted, prosecute 10 New York City restaurants that do not have liquor licenses but allow patrons to bring their own wine or beer.

description: Gastineau Dance: Jets No Partner

title: Business Digest SATURDAY, MARCH 24, 1984
description: The Economy Rises in consumer prices slowed to 0.4 percent in February, after increasing 0.6 percent in January. Most of the increase in the Consumer Price Index was caused by a sharp rise for home heating oil and smaller increases for food and local telephone rates. The moderate February rise, which works out to an annual rate of 4.4 percent, was hailed by the Administration as a sign that inflation was still in check. (Page 1.) Prices rose 0.6 percent in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area. (32.)

title: BRIEFING
description: Reagan's School DaysOne of the soft-sell tactics President Reagan used to try to lobby the Senate for passage of a constitutional amendment to permit officially sanctioned prayer in public schools was to recall his boyhood in Illinois's public schools.

title: Wines of California For the French Visitor
description: Guests at the White House dinner Thursday for President Francois Mitterrand were served smoked Columbia River salmon with cucumber sauce, tenderloin of veal with truffle sauce and a selection of California wines.

title: 3 SEIZED IN WOOLWORTH'S HOLDUP AT 59TH AND 3D
description: Three holdup men armed with knives and a rifle invaded an East Side Woolworth's store at closing time last night, but they were captured in the basement after holding several employees briefly and taking $30,000 from the manager's safe, the police said.

description: A Brooklyn automobile repairman was arrested yesterday and charged with fatally shooting a city marshal who was serving him an eviction notice for not paying his rent.

Paul McGrath, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, has reversed field and approved the proposed merger between LTV and Republic Steel. It's a decision that looks a lot like a political accommodation.

Jonassen of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Dr. Ricardo Mesa- Tejada, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eduardo Mesa of Woodside, Queens. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery and the Rev. Hugh O'Donnell, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
LOST SKIING IN THE WILDS OF SUFFOLK COUNTY
description: SEVERAL years ago, friends of mine in Connecticut, way up by the Massachusetts border, got me to try a new winter sport called cross-county skiing. I'd never taken to downhill skiing, perhaps because of one amazingly long afternoon spent dodging hundreds of speeding bullets on an experts' trail that a beloved friend of mine pushed me down.

title: SWIMMER'S GOALS IN RANGE
description: Ricardo Prado says the Brazilian Olympic Committee has made the message clear. He says he is constantly reminded that he is expected to win a swimming gold medal this summer at the Los Angeles Olympics.

title: MX SEEN AS FACING TROUBLE IN HOUSE
description: The MX missile has seen more political ups and downs than most major Pentagon weapon programs. This spring Congressional odds-makers are saying it is in deep trouble again, but for reasons that have more to do with budgets than military technology or doctrine.

title: ESSENTIALS FOR THE WEEKEND
description: Planning In general, weekends can be divided into two types: those spent in the city and those spent in the country. The cosmopolitan weekend may be a fringe benefit, tacked on to a business trip, or a long-planned foray into the city to enjoy the museums and restaurants. The country weekend's activities may include biking or hiking in the mountains, long leisurely hours by the seaside, tending a vegetable garden or a splashy black-tie dinner party.

title: THE DEMISE OF THE CANCELED CHECK
description: ONE of these days, your bank may quit returning your canceled checks to you, unless you ask for those you want to see and perhaps even pay for the privilege. That change will be yet another part of the dramatic transformation taking place in the American financial services industry.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A LEGACY OF WINDSOR CHAIRS
description: OF all the 18th-century makers of that favorite, the New England Windsor chair, the name of Col. E. B. Tracy of Lisbon was synonymous with the finest design and workmanship between 1785 and 1800. Almost as well-known today is the name of a member of the extended Tracy household, Abner Denham Allen. Mr. Allen was Colonel Tracy's only apprentice of record. He married the colonel's daughter, Lydia.

title: SAD FAREWELL FOR RAY MEYER
description: They milled in the lobby of the Holiday Inn well past midnight - friends, family and fans - all hoping for a chance to shake Ray Meyer's hand, kiss him on the cheek and wrap their arms around him in sympathy. The end to Meyer's 42-year coaching career at DePaul University had been so abrupt and unexpected, and it would be a week or more, he said, before he would get over the last and in many ways, most painful loss. Still, he smiled and shook their hands and even posed for photographs.

description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that he was ''very disapppointed'' about the lack of movement by the Japanese Government in opening its capital markets to foreigners and permitting the yen to be more widely used in international transactions.

description: -morning appointment in the city, which precluded going to the office until afterward, I boarded the 10 A.M. train at White Plains, fully prepared to daydream away the 37 minutes to Grand Central Terminal.

description: The Government started extradition proceedings in the United States and Canada on Friday against a former Mexico City Police Chief accused of tax evasion, extortion, illegally importing contraband and possessing illegal weapons, a spokesman in the Attorney General's office said.

description: Mat Boy, the Argentine sensation who almost broke a Hialeah Park track record in his North American debut last month, was even more impressive today as he set a track record while winning the $144,500 Gulfstream Park Handicap by 12 lengths.

title: WOOING THE GREEN THUMB CROWD-BY MAIL
description: WHEN Ruth M. Owades, 39, was a student at the Harvard Business School, she told her fellow students - who talked longingly of starting their own businesses - that entrepreneurship held no fascination for her. A good, secure corporate job, with regular hours, was all she wanted. Three years later, Mrs. Owades was the first of her friends at Harvard to go it alone.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Lou Vairo , coach of the 1984 United States Olympic hockey team, has been hired as a scout by the Devils . . . Earl Jones , a 7-foot center from the University of the District of Columbia, was named Division II college basketball player of the year for the second year in a row. Clara Eades, a senior forward who led Central Missouri State to the final of the women's Division II tournament, was named female player of the year.

title: PHILANTHROPIES FOCUS CONCERN ON ARMS RACE
description: The nation's philanthropies, which in the past have concentrated on domestic social and educational projects, are now beginning to devote significant time and money to seeking ways of slowing the arms race and reducing the threat of nuclear war.

title: Devils Are Routed In 52d Loss, 6 to 0
description: The Buffalo Sabres handed the Devils their 52d loss of the season today in a fashion that impressed Tom McVie, the coach of the Devils, who rarely has praise for opponents.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: Any new program by Pilar Rioja is eagerly awaited by the ever-growing number of fans this star of Spanish dance has attracted in recent years with successive seasons in New York. Miss Rioja, who has been performing this month under the auspices of the Repertorio Espanol at the Gramercy Arts Theater, will now offer a different bill beginning Tuesday night.

description: The American policy failure in Lebanon and, more recently, a rebuke in Jordan, have punctured our record as mediator in the Middle East. We have suffered a major setback in the short run, but this need not mean irreparable enfeeblement of American diplomacy in the long haul.

description: At the Circular Congregational Church in Charleston, S.C., yesterday, Mary Williams, former personnel administrator for Anne Klein & Company, the fashion concern in New York, was married to Nicholas Hayes Ney, who is completing doctoral studies in clinical psychology at the California School of Professional Psychology in Berkeley. The Rev. Albert Kellar performed the ceremony.

description: Lois A. Zarembo, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John E. Zarembo of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven L. Gottlieb, a son of Stanley I. Gottlieb of Delray Beach, Fla., and Hackensack, N.J., and Mrs. William McElgun of Dix Hills, L.I. The Rev. Harris Riordan, a Unitarian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: Japan's Growth Rate Down
description: Japan's population rose by 0.67 percent in 1983, the lowest population growth rate in the postwar era, the Statistics Bureau said today.

description: The vast ecological disruption that Jonathan Kandell describes may have disastrous consequences for both Bolivia and the world.

description: Margaret Ringo Tobin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Tobin of New Haven, was married yesterday to Mark Joseph Segall, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Segall of Midwood, Brooklyn. J. Michael Grupp performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, where he is the leader.

description: Congress, acting under its constitutional powers to regulate foreign commerce and appropriate money, has been invading the foreign economic policy domain of the executive branch. title: Barbara A. Hutchison, U.S. Aide Seized in '74
description: Barbara A. Hutchison, a career foreign-service officer of the United States Information Agency, died of cancer Thursday at the home of a sister in Tequesta, Fla. She was 57 years old.

title: FRANCE ANNOUNCES TROOPS WILL LEAVE BEIRUT BY SATURDAY
description: The Defense Ministry announced today that French troops in Beirut, the last unit of the multinational force, had been ordered to withdraw from the city by next Saturday.

title: A SECRET TREASURE FOR ALL TO SHARE
description: NOT everyone has a private sanctuary worth more than $50 million, but I do. Paid for by New Jersey taxpayers, it is mine alone from November to March.

title: FOR DE MILLE, MOSES' EGYPT WAS REALLY AMERICA
description: This has been a week for catching up - with ''Splash,'' the mermaid comedy that's fast becoming one of the biggest live-action hits in the history of the Walt Disney empire, with ''Seeing Red,'' the Oscar-nominated documentary by Julia Reichert and James Klein, and with the formidable shade of the late Cecil B. De Mille, specifically with his 1956 ''Ten Commandments,'' which is being rereleased to coincide with the religious holidays.

title: A Legal Periodical Devoted to Women
description: based periodicals for women neglected to mention the Women's Rights Law Reporter, the oldest and foremost legal periodical in the country focusing on women's rights law. Founded in 1971, it is a nonprofit, student-run publication housed at the Rutgers University School of Law in Newark.

title:
GARDENING;
ANNUALS VS. PERENNIALS
description: THE inexperienced gardener is attracted to flowering annuals by their ease of culture and long season of bloom. As experience is acquired, there is often a change in preference toward perennials. In fact, many sophisticated gardeners advanced in knowledge and taste eschew the use of annuals under the guise that they are not worthy of consideration.

title: BREAKING NEW GROUND
description: While condominium communities have increased in favor in many Nassau County communities, the villages that make up the area known as the Five Towns on the South Shore have only recently accepted them. Last year, the village of North Woodmere approved a plan for the construction of Vanderbilt Park, a 35-residence condominium community on a three-acre parcel at Rosedale and Heatherfield Roads.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY OFFERS SPECIALISTS A FLURRY OF JOBS
description: AT Genetics Institute, a Boston biotechnology company in its third year, the laboratories are overflowing with equipment, everyone seems to be under 30 and jeans are the corporate uniform. Among the jeans- wearers who chose to work there rather than do academic research is J. David Rozzell, an organic chemist with a doctorate from Harvard.

title: DEMOCRATS IN PRIMARY BEGIN COUNTY EFFORT

title: FASHION AND MEN'S LIVES
description: In her recent book on Conde Nast, the well-known magazine publisher, Caroline Seebohm tells the story of one of Frank Crowninshield's legendary confrontations with Edna Woolman Chase. Crowninshield was the dashing and irreverent editor of Vanity Fair for 21 years, with a taste for good cigars, pin-stripe suits and private cars. Chase was the fastidious editor of Vogue, given to wearing lace collars and cuffs. Despite the difference in their personalities, each was inexorably wedded to style. Nevertheless, when Chase once suggested that Vanity Fair add space to the publication's ''Well-Dressed Man'' pages, she was met with a wall of masculine resistance.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS March 25, 1984Fiction
description: 1 SEEDS OF YESTERDAY, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $3.95.) Concluding volume of a horror series about the Dollanganger family.

title: GEARING UP FOR WINDSURFING
description: One of the fastest- growing sports in the world, windsurfing is drawing more and more enthusiasts, from youngsters and teen-agers to senior citizens. This summer, it will be a new event at the Olympics in Los Angeles.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: HEADLINERS
description: If Ingrid Berg got any of the ''perks'' that often accrue to relatives of top-ranking Soviet bloc officials, they weren't enough to make life in East Germany attractive. Last month, Mrs. Berg, the niece of East German Prime Minister Willi Stoph, showed up at the West German Embassy in Czechoslovakia demanding asylum.

title: RAPE PROSECUTOR IN THE MIDDLE OF A PUBLIC CONFLICT
description: When a jury announced its verdict Thursday in the trial of four men accused of raping a young woman in a New Bedford bar, Ronald A. Pina, the prosecutor, bowed his head with relief.

title: MEESE SAYS HE NEVER CONSIDERED THAT LOAN MIGHT LOOK IMPROPER
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, said today that the only thing he would do differently, given the opportunity, would be to list a $15,000 interest- free loan on his financial disclosure forms.

title: LECTURES MARK MUSEUM'S 10TH YEAR
description: A FULL house is expected this afternoon when Carlos Fuentes, the author and diplomat, offers his perspective on the future at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York at Purchase.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH LAWYERS
description: Many thanks to Charles Fried (''The Trouble with Lawyers,'' Feb. 12).

title: MONDALE CAMPAIGN TIGHTENS BELT FOR TOUGH FIGHT
description: Walter F. Mondale has cut his staff's salaries, laid off workers and begun staying in the homes of supporters rather than in hotels in an effort to save money as the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination moves into the most expensive states on the calendar.

title: Enzyme Treatment For Heart Attacks
description: Regarding the article ''Enzyme Battling Heart Attacks'' (Feb. 12), if I were to be stricken with a heart attack, I would do everything possible to see to it that I was taken to a hospital that does cardiac catheterization and has streptokinase available.

title: ON EVE OF SALVADORAN VOTE, NEW RULES CAUSE CONFUSION
description: Salvadoran officials are convinced they have a stronger antifraud system for the presidential election Sunday than was used here in the elections two years ago. But several of the changes appeared today to be creating problems of their own.

title:
STAMPS;
FOR MARYLAND'S 350th ANNIVERSARY
description: On this day 350 years ago 200 English colonists disembarked from the two ships that had brought them across the Atlantic and set foot on the land near the mouth of the Potomac River that was to become their new home, the colony of Maryland. The 350th anniversary of the founding of Maryland is being commemorated by a 13-cent postal card issued today in a first-day ceremony that is taking place in conjunction with a special session of the Maryland legislature. The place of the ceremony is St. Mary's City, where the colonists established the first settlement, but the first-day cancellation will read ''St. Clement's Island,'' the actual site of the first landing.

title: CRIME
description: Robert Barnard used to be a professor of English literature. It is true that he taught in Norway, but perhaps academics are alike everywhere. In Mr. Barnard's latest novel, SCHOOL FOR MURDER (Scribners, $12.95), the locale is a private school for boys in England. It is a terrible school, thanks to a pompous headmaster and his avaricious, stupid wife. If not out of ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' it is only a cousin thrice removed. The headmistress even doses her boys with vile nostrums.

title: DIRT AND DENIM: YOUTH'S ECONOMIC INDEX
description: GROWING up in Bethlehem, Pa., in the early 30's, I learned a couple of economic indexes that I've never seen mentioned in the financial pages of any newspapers: the windowsill index and the denim- fade index. Reading of the layoffs in the American steel industry during the recent recession brought them back to me with the bittersweet nostalgia of a good childhood remembered with almost painful clarity.

title: FAIRS TO OFFER HEALTH SCREENINGS
description: -awareness project called ''The Channel 3 Health Expo'' will be providing a wide range of screening tests, as well as information about health and social services, at 43 locations throughout Connecticut and western Massachussetts starting Saturday.

title: WATERLOO MAPS OUT ITS SUMMER MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: STANHOPE ALTHOUGH remnants of winter still dotted the landscape, a news conference at Waterloo Village here last week focused on summer and the 16th annual Waterloo Music Festival.

title: HART, IN BUFFALO, PLEDGES AID FOR EAST
description: In his first campaign foray into upstate New York, Senator Gary Hart today pledged Federal help for smokestack industries and a federally financed rebuilding of the nation's infrastructure that would start in the East.

title: SITUATION COMEDIES COME TO GRIEF
description: The situation comedy, for more than three decades one of the most popular and financially successful forms of television programming, is in trouble.

title: UNION CITY THEATER TAKES ON NEW LIFE
description: -by, the Park Theater in this Hudson County community looks like a typical movie house - the kind that have known better days.

title: Feminist Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarasota
description: To the Editor:

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER ; BREAKING DOWN BARRIERS FACED BY DISABLED
description: One of the aims of those who feel that handicapped people have as much right to travel as the able-bodied is the removal of barriers - both physical and social. Narrow doorways that impede wheelchairs and narrow attitudes that impede acceptance of the handicapped as travelers like everyone else are being replaced by wider entrances and wider recognition of the fact that almost anyone, save those confined to bed, can experience the pleasures of a change of place. And accompanying greater awareness is a growth in the number of tours designed for handicapped travelers.

title: NEW PLANTS MAY NOT MEAN NEW JOBS
description: IN Fremont, Calif., Apple Computer Inc. just opened a new factory that could be a flagship for high-technology manufacturing in this country. The plant manufactures the Macintosh, perhaps the hottest consumer-oriented computer since International Business Machines unveiled its Personal Computer in 1981.

title: TERRORISTS BLAMED
description: Five people identifying themselves as Red Brigades terrorists robbed the vaults of a security company today, netting the equivalent of $21.8 million.

title: Eastwood Leads by 3 Strokes
description: Bob Eastwood, a nonwinner in 13 years on the PGA Tour, shot a four- under-par 68 today and stretched his lead to three strokes after three rounds of the $400,000 USF&G Classic.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: THEATER ON THE HIGH SEAS, WIMBLEDON CLASSIC
description: Adding Drama To Alaska Trip

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: LIKE the streaming flag of Elizabethan times announcing ''The play is about to begin,'' the wide, red banner flying in front of the Englewood Public Library these days leads the way to a celebration of Shakespeare that is being held through April 15 to commemorate the playwright's 420th birthday.

title: UNFINISHED SKYSCRAPER ALREADY HUMS
description: the tallest building between New York and Boston - is not yet completed, 12 of its 38 stories are already occupied.

title: MARATHON MEN
description: WASHINGTON A FTER a rapid-fire succession of primaries and caucuses, the campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination has shifted to a less hectic but potentially decisive phase. In the coming weeks, the political calendar provides the three remaining candidates with more running space between the major contests but less margin for error.

title: THE BODY IN THE RIVER LEEM
description: WATERLAND

title: LAW'S NEW VENUES: COMPUTERS AND SPACE
description: IN Shanghai, a group of American lawyers attending a conference earlier

title: CANEEL BAY AND ITS ALLURE
description: CHARLOTTE CURTIS is associate editor of The New York Times.

title:
ART;
4 ARTISTS' WORKS SELECTED FOR NATIONAL SHOW
description: EXPO III, the third national invitational exhibition sponsored by the Northport Galleries, departs slightly from its usual format by featuring four artists instead of three. Entries, in the form of slides, were received from 35 states, and the selection, made by Rae Ferren, associate curator of the Guild Hall Museum in East Hampton, includes landscape paintings from Texas, welded steel sculpture from Connecticut, color photographs from New Jersey and drawings by a Cold Spring Harbor artist.

title: EDUCATION BOARD TO MEET ON ACTION AGAINST ALVARADO
description: The president of the New York City Board of Education announced yesterday that the board would meet today to consider suspending Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado.

title: MAKING OPERA LIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICANS IN BUSINESS IN EL SALVADOR: JUGGLING RISK, FEAR AND RETURNS
description: SAN SALVADOR

title: STATE CALLED LAX ON ENVIRONMENTAL VIGILANCE
description: The chairman of the Assembly Environmental Conservation Committee has charged that the Cuomo administration is ''creating the next generation of toxic-waste problems'' by failing to enforce environmental laws.

title: The Caribbean
description: To the Editor:

title: PACIFIC NORTHWEST BALLET FINDS AN IDENTITY OF ITS OWN
description: The New York debut of the Pacific Northwest Ballet on Tuesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music will be a homecoming for its directors, Kent Stowell and Francia Russell, remembered fondly from their dancing days with the New York City Ballet in the 1950's and 1960's. The casual advance word has even been that the Seattle-based company is ''a City Ballet satellite,'' with a repertory crammed with ballets by George Balanchine and a roster of dancers trained at the City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet, where Miss Russell taught in the 1960's.

title: CROWDED SKIES SPUR DISPUTE OVER USE OF MILITARY AIRFIELDS
description: A few years ago Edwin Colodny, chairman of USAir, offered an idea for easing the pressure on Washington's crowded National Airport. He proposed shifting some of the traffic, especially small private planes, to underused Andrews Air Force Base.

title: NEW STATE RULES POSE A HURDLE IN TERMITE FIGHT
description: THE termite season is about to arrive on the Island, but a group of exterminators say they are unable to fight the pests properly.

title: A June Wedding Is Being Planned By Miss Davisson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hendrickson of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hendrickson's daughter Lacy Davisson to Kevin Lawrence Doyle, the son of Mary Doyle of New York and the late Lester T. Doyle. Miss Davisson's father is Arthur A. Davisson of San Juan, P.R. A June wedding is planned.

title: Howe Escapes Injury In Fatal Two-Car Crash
description: A 20-year-old Fairfield man was killed early this morning after a two-car accident on the Merritt Parkway in which Gordie Howe, the hockey Hall of Fame member, and his wife escaped injury.

title: HAIG CITES ADVICE TO PRESS HAVANA
description: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. says in his forthcoming memoirs that he advocated bringing maximum political, economic and military pressure to bear on Cuba in 1981 ''to force the issue early'' in El Salvador, even if it brought a Soviet response.

title: THE PERSONAL TOUCH
description: THE BRITISH WINE merchant and writer David Peppercorn recently put forth a selection of what he considers to be among the best wine lists in the world. He is pretty much on the mark: the Four Seasons and Sparks Steak House in New York, Boston's Pier Four, Taillevent in Paris, San Domenico in Imola, near Bologna, and Gidleigh Park in England. This last is the only one on Mr. Peppercorn's list I don't know, but if, as he says, a rigorous pruning of the list left ''a scant 358 wines,'' I'm willing to accept it on his word.

title: Jennifer Sherman Engaged
description: The engagement of Jennifer Anne Sherman to Nicholas J. Torbick of Atlanta has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Michael S. Sherman of Stamford, Conn., parents of the bride-to- be. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Torbick of Lynchburg, Va. A June wedding is planned.

title: WHY BROOKLYN NEEDS A DOME...AND HOW TO GET IT
description: The following article has been excerpted from testimony given by State Senator Tom Bartosiewicz, Democrat of Brooklyn, before the New York Senate Task Force on Professional Sports and the Economy. Senator Bartosiewicz has introduced legislation to create a Brooklyn domed stadium corporation and a Brooklyn National League baseball club that would provide community ownership of a stadium and a major league baseball team in the borough.

title: CO-OP TAX MEASURE DRAWING FIRE
description: FEDERAL legislation that would allow

title: INSTRUMENTS ARE NEEDED
description: INSTEAD of gathering dust in

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: The St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Leonard Slatkin, has turned into one of the most exciting ensembles in the United States, and combines the sonic opulence we associate with the Philadelphia Orchestra with the flash and vigor of the Chicago Symphony. This week, the St. Louis Symphony will present two concerts at Carnegie Hall. Friday night's program will feature Johannes Brahms's rarely heard ''N"anie,'' - a hauntingly beautiful elegie composed entirely in major keys; Elgar's ''Enigma'' Variations, and the New York premiere of John Adams's ''Harmonium.''

title: SHADES OF 'THE GRADUATE': IT'S PLASTICS AGAIN
description: ''THE plastics industry did so much business last year that it was considered astounding,'' according to an expert in the field, and as a result some companies are on a hiring spree that has made job prospects in plastics brighter than they have been for years.

title: Count and Countess
description: Jean deRo chefort of New York and Chester Depot, Va. have announced the engagement of their daughter Ghislaine Anne de Rochefort to Nichaolas Charles Frederick Shrady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fredick Charles Shrady of Easton, Conn.

title: OF HIGH COURT JUSTICES' ACTIVISM, RESTRAINT...
description: To the Editor:

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Found guilty of murder in a 1979 abortion, Dr. Raymond Showery was sentenced last Sept. 28 in El Paso, Tex., to 15 years in prison. Five former employees of Family Hospital, a small clinic that the 55-year-old doctor operated in the city, testified that he had smothered and drowned a 5-to- 7-month-old fetus.

title: MORE BUSINESS WITH CHINA SOUGHT
description: CONNECTICUT companies are already doing more than $100 million in business each year with China, but officials at the State Department of Economic Development say there is a potential for much more.

title: KNICKS DOWN BULLETS, 107-99
description: The Knicks needed a leader last night to replace the injured Bernard King, and Ray Williams stepped forward in the final 2 minutes 28 seconds to spark a 107-99 victory over the Washington Bullets at Madison Square Garden.

title: TRACKING DOWN AND CURING INTERFERENCE
description: As our homes grow overpopulated with electronic gadgets, it seems that these gizmos sometimes get in each other's way. For example, the current proliferation of home computers has given rise to complaints that display terminals sometimes interfere with television reception if the computer is too close to the television set. What happens is that the computer radiates frequencies which are picked up by the television set and which then appear on the screen as shafts of flickering light cutting across the picture.

title: FULL, VARIED CONCERT CALENDAR
description: MUSIC lovers with the desire, not to mention the resources, to help a deserving cause in the county, could consider attending a number of unusual benefit concerts over the next couple of weeks. On the other hand, even if your wallet is empty you can take advantage of other's generosity at several fine programs that have no admission charge at all.

title: VIRGINIA, IN UPSET, AND KENTUCKY GO TO FINAL FOUR
description: The Kentucky Wildcats, pushed by the force of their home-court crowd and the challenge of a surprising Illinois team, protected a slim lead in the final minutes and prevailed by 54- 51 today to win the Mideast Regional and a spot in the Final Four.

title: A Decade Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Drew to LeadThird Campaign Debate
description: Elizabeth Drew, a New Yorker correspondent, will question the three Democratic Presidential candidates April 5 in Pittsburgh in the third debate this year sponsored by the League of Women Voters.

title: THAI FOOD: TANTALIZINGLY EXOTIC
description: YOU could say that Siam Palace in Port Washington is the best Thai restaurant on the Island as long as you limit the definition of the Island to Nassau and Suffolk Counties and do not include Queens. Siam Palace may be the only restaurant in this area serving the aromatically pungent, complex and interesting cuisine of Thailand with its combination of fiery hot, sharply acidic or sweetly mellow flavors.

title: Anti-Rape Program Praised
description: A campaign to prevent sexual attacks on schoolgirls is working so well that the police have not confirmed one such assault report in nearly two months, Mayor Coleman A. Young of Detroit says. From the beginning of September to the end of January, 47 schoolgirls were assaulted on the way to or from school, the police said. Mayor Young told community leaders Tuesday that there had been no confirmed reports of assault on a schoolgirl since Feb. 1.

title: ELAPSED EXPECTATIONS
description: ELAPSED EXPECTATIONS Alan P. Lightman

title: LICENSED PORNOGRAPHY
description: To the Editor:

title: COURSES ON MONEY EXPAND FOR ADULTS
description: '' FANTASIZE,'' the instructor said. ''If you could have the ideal investment, what would you want most?''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a picture caption on page 1 of the Arts and Leisure section March 4 misidentified the director of Henry James's ''Aspern Papers'' at the Haymarket Theater in London. He is Frith Banbury.

title: A BISTRO LOVER'S CHOICE
description: After falling head over heels in love in the 1970's with haute cuisine, ancienne as well as nouvelle, Americans seem ready in the 1980's for a more varied diet on their epicurean wanderings. At least my friends and acquaintances are, to judge from their eagerness to swap the names of European restaurants that provide old-fashioned, unadorned regional cooking, and especially the names of good bistros in Paris. Happily, the places are still there, waiting to be discovered.

title: President Visits Monticello
description: President and Mrs. Reagan flew by helicopter to Charlottesville, Va., today to visit the home of Thomas Jefferson. Peter Roussel, a White House spokesman, said the Reagans were making use of ''a nice spring day and doing some touring down there,'' highlighted by a stop at Monticello, home of the nation's third President.

title: CITY U. WILL TRAIN DOCTORS IN QUEENS
description: The Cuomo administration and the City University of New York have agreed to create a medical education program in Queens that borough officials hope will be the first step in establishing a medical school there.

title: NEW LINES IN COMMUNICATIONS
description: ''IT USED TO BE,'' said Hank Schoening with a trace of nostalgia, ''that if a guy had 20 years in the Bell System, you could assume he must be a communications expert. Now you can't do that. Things are changing too quickly. He might have to be completely retrained.''

title: THE TROUBLE WITH LAWYERS
description: The middle class is entitled to representation along with the rich and poor. This cannot be accomplished if banks write wills, real-estate brokers handle estate closings and divorces are mediated.

title: THE WINNING FORM OF DICK FRANCIS
description: Edward Zuckerman is the author of ''The Day After World War III,'' to be published in June by Viking. THE FLAMINGOS WERE LISTLESS NEAR the starting gate at Hialeah. It was a chilly Florida day and raining - bad weather for flamingos. The bettors didn't mind. Snug inside the clubhouse, they could watch the races on television. A horse named Gorytus was set to run in the eighth. There was some curiosity as to how he would do. ''He was very good as a 2-year-old, but he didn't develop at all,'' said Dick Francis. ''They couldn't make out what the trouble was.'' Francis, the Welsh-born author of mystery novels, was lunching with friends in the clubhouse restaurant. He had taken the day off from writing his 24th novel to go to the track. He could take the rest of the decade off if he wanted.

title: Iraq Reports Destroying Four Ships in Gulf
description: Iraqi jet fighters and navy vessels destroyed four oil tankers and commercial ships today near Iran's oil terminal of Kharg Island in the Persian Gulf, an Iraqi military spokesman said.

title: A MODERN TRADGEY'S ROAD TO MATURITY
description: T he original production of Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman'' opened Feb. 10, 1949, at the Morosco Theater to rapturous applause. The playwright who, up to then, had experienced one Broadway failure and one sturdy success, was 33, suddenly rich, famous, important and awash in controversy. Dispraise followed hard on approval. If the first wave of reviews almost unanimously welcomed ''Salesman'' as a major work of the theater, possibly a modern American masterpiece, the second tier of critics from the intellectual journals were at times savagely negative. At best,

title: Artificial Flipper Experiment Fails With a Giant Sea Turtle
description: Lucky, a 350-pound loggerhead turtle who made medical history after having two artificial rubber flippers attached, has lost the second limb and probably will spend the rest of her life in captivity, her doctor says.

title: NEW VERSACE STORE
description: The interior of the new Versace boutique on Madison Avenue looks at first glance more like a hotel lobby than a store. A center aisle of highly polished gray granite is defined by four steel-sheathed columns and topped by an artificial skylight. At the end of the aisle is what looks like a reception desk. One must look to the sides to find the clothing - women's on the left, men's on the right.

title: SUMMER STYLE
description: If this spring and summer are to be remembered for a certain style, it will be that of easy, less-formal sophistication. Warm-weather clothes this season are elegant without being restrictive and comfortable without being overly carefree.

title: INSECTICIDE MISHAPS REPORTED
description: ONE of every three farm workers in southern New Jersey has been accidentally sprayed with unsafe levels of chemical pesticides, according to a health researcher and a spokesman for a farm workers' rights project.

title: Sports of The Times; IMPERFECT IMAGE
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.

title: SEEKING TO RESTORE THE MAGIC OF VW
description: WOLFSBURG, WEST GERMANY BEFORE dawn each day, a Volkswagen employee pulls up to Carl H. Hahn's white stucco villa in a suburb of Wolfsburg and delivers one of the company's shiny new cars - a different model each morning. Mr. Hahn test drives the cars as he commutes to work.

title: GREELEY THEATER CONTINUES GROWTH
description: THE tenuous state of professional nonmusical theater in the county has received a couple of booster shots of late. First, the nomadic New Globe Theater began to settle into its new Port Chester home. Then the Greeley Street Theater, in search of room, announced a move from Chappaqua to White Plains - and dropped the middle word of its name. ''We sounded like a street theater, and we appeared to be up in the woods, which we're most emphatically not,'' emphasized the producing director, Nancy Hall.

title: TOPS ON JOB LIST: COMPUTER FIXER
description: THE man's personal computer quit working and he called for help. Within minutes a repairman arrived, tools in hand, and examined the lifeless machine.

title: Kitty Schirmer, James Cochrane Exchange Vows
description: Katherine Prince Schirmer and James Louis Cochrane were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. The bride, known as Kitty, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Austin Schirmer of New Canaan. Mr. Cochrane is a son of Anne Cochrane of Allentown, Pa., and the late Thomas Cochrane.

title: Barbara Berger Weds Marc Tartell, Teacher
description: At Temple Beth Torah in North Miami Beach, Fla., yesterday Barbara Gay Berger, an institutional saleswoman with Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb in New York, was married to Marc Sorrel Tartell, an account executive with Morton Goldberg Associates in New York. Rabbis Stuart G. Erdheim and Max A. Lipschitz officiated.

title: SCIENCE PARK GIVES PLAN FOR JOBS
description: AFTER Science Park, an industrial complex in New Haven, opened last fall, residents of the high-unemployment area where it is located expressed concern that its high-technology businesses would not actually bring jobs.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Amira Acre, a Canadian pianist, began her studies at the age of 3, and later worked with Dorothy Morton at McGill University in Montreal, and with Abbey Simon at the Juilliard School, where she is currently a candidate for a master's degree. Last Sunday afternoon, Miss Acre made her formal New York debut in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: GOODEN IMPRESSIVE AS METS TOP YANKS
description: George Steinbrenner and Dwight Gooden, residents of Tampa on the other side of Florida, have never met, but they know about each other.

title: Welfare Cheat Is Sentenced
description: A man convicted of bilking the county of $377,458 in a welfare fraud case has been sentenced to three years in prison and ordered to give back more than $300,000. John Woods, 52 years old, and his wife, Dorothy, 41, illegally received the money by opening 12 separate welfare cases from 1971 to 1981 and claiming 49 children as dependents. Mr. Woods was sentenced Thursday on 24 felony counts of welfare fraud and forgery. Mrs. Woods was sentenced to eight years in state prison after she pleaded guilty to 41 felony counts.

title: THE CONTRADICTIONS IN PRIVATE EXECUTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: UCONN STARTS ITS FIRST FUND DRIVE
description: AS the University of Connecticut started the first fund drive in its 103-year history last week, a single pledge by a company that has two of its officers involved in the campaign doubled the school's endowment.

title: Romero Out of Race
description: Randy Romero, who leads the nation's jockeys in victories this year, broke a leg in a mishap at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans and will miss today's $200,000 Louisana Derby.

title: THE 1984 NATIONAL LEAGUE BASEBALL SCHEDULE CHICAGO
description: HOME GAMES April 13, 14, 15dMets 17, 18, 19Cardinals 20, 21, 22dPirates May 4, 5, 6dPadres 7, 8Giants 9, 10Dodgers 18, 19, 20dAstros 22, 23, 24Braves 25, 26, 27d, 28Reds June 11, 12, 13Expos 14, 15, 16, 17dPhillies 22, 23, 24dCardinals 25, 26, 27Pirates July 12, 13, 14, 15dDodgers 16, 17, 18Padres 19, 20, 21, 22dGiants 30, 31Phillies August 1Phillies 2, 3, 4, 5dExpos 6, 7, 8Mets 20, 21, 22Astros 24, 25, 26dBraves 28, 29Reds

title: BULLIES TOP WORRIES OF PUPILS
description: A survey of some of the best middle schools has found that students listed the bullying and disruptive behavior of their classmates as their main concern and nice teachers as the main reason they like school.

title: TESTS TAKE A DIFFERENT TACK
description: graders took the state's new High School Proficiency Test in early March, they finished only half of what they will face in this year's standardized testing program. They must still take the Minimum Basic Skills Test Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: FOUNDATION TO FOCUS ON ELDERLY
description: THE Travelers Corporation is setting up a foundation that will focus on helping the elderly to remain employed and to lead healthy, active lives.

title: To the Editor
description: Mr. Bay's article stimulated a lot of interest on Anguilla. However, there was an error regarding meals at the Rendezvous Bay Hotel.

title: THE GENIUS AS MAN ABOUT TOWN
description: John Bayley is the Warton Professor of English in the University of Oxford. ALEXANDER PUSHKIN

title: HELPING OUR WORLD TO COME CLEAN
description: OF America's 1.4 million engineers probably no more than about 15,000 call themselves environmental engineers. But as the relatively new problems posed by toxic chemicals, acid rain and other pollutants multiply across the nation, that proportion, experts say, is likely to change markedly in the years ahead.

title: STATE TO INVESTIGATE ASBESTOSIS IN 2 COUNTIES
description: Citing ''major public health concerns,'' the State Health Commissioner has ordered an investigation into an outbreak of 58 confirmed and suspected cases of asbestosis, a lung disease, in two upstate counties.

title: Ex-Gov. Moore to Enter Race in West Virginia
description: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr., a Republican, has announced he will run for the governorship of West Virginia instead of challenging Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th, a Democrat, in the race for a United States Senate seat.

title: CAMPAIGN TAKING TOLL OF CANDIDATES' TEMPERS
description: Ever since the advent of airport-to-airport campaigning, the task of a Presidential candidate has become one of the most physically exhausting ordeals in American public life. The 1984 contest for the Democratic nomination seems to be setting a new standard when it comes to putting the candidates through an emotional wringer, as well.

title:
About Westchester;
DANCING FOR SPORTS
description: HARRISON IT may look like a simple exercise class, but this is serious

title: Finding Artisans
description: To the Editor:

title: FAME IS THE BEST REVENGE
description: Frank Rich is chief drama critic of The New York Times. AUTOMATIC VAUDEVILLE

title: ROBOTS IN THE BARN
description: -D2 and C-3PO - those lovable humanlike robots from the ''Star Wars'' movies - won't be taking the place of Joe the hired hand anytime soon.

title: FINDING ARTISANS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE KITCHEN'S HIS OYSTER
description: THE KITCHEN'S HIS OYSTER

title: ON THE TRAIL OF LONDON'S SLOANE RANGERS
description: Caroline is squeaky clean, freshfaced and easy to identify by the string of (real) pearls, which she wers at all times. Henry is cleancut and pink-cheeked, and can be spotted from a distance by his too-large coat (handed down from his father). closer inspection will reveal either a red- or blue-and-white boldly-striped shirt (during business hours) or a good, plain, but frayed, one (in off-duty hours). Both are Sloane Rangers.

title: BANKERS SEE SLOW PROGRESS CONQUERING ARGENTINA'S DEBT
description: Representatives of 330 American banks that are struggling to work out a deal with Argentina face the unpleasant likelihood that agreement will not be reached by the March 30 deadline. If President Raul Alfonsin's Government does not come up with $610 million, the banks will have to admit that nearly $10 billion in loans are ''nonperforming.'' That means the banks would have to deduct the accrued interest from their earnings for the last six months.

title: CITIES ARE KEY IN CONTEST FOR DELEGATES
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT'S Democratic Presidential primary election on Tuesday promises some favorable headlines for the winner and some consolation prizes for the losers - that is, delegates.

title: TEANECK DROPS STRATEGY ON TEACHER SENIORITY
description: Officials of the public schools here have decided to abandon plans to wage a legal battle against seniority rules involving the layoff of teachers.

title: NEW YORK AREA HAS NOT BEEN LEFT BEHIND
description: ALMOST from the time New York City emerged as a manufacturing center, a classic pattern emerged in the way young businesses took shape and grew. In the last seven years, one entrepreneur, Elazar Rabbani, has followed this pattern to a tee: He came up with a salable idea and turned to family members, his brother Shahram and his brother-in-law Barry W. Weiner, to help him find a market niche and financing.

title: FIBER-OPTIC GLASS, THE LONG PULL AHEAD
description: Analytical and physical chemists are working on techniques that will reduce the impurities in a glassy substance made of fluorine to an amount measured in parts per trillion.

title: AID IN THE EIGHTIES
description: Jeffrey E. Garten, who was deputy director of the State Department's Policy Planning Staff in 1978-79, is now vice president of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: WOMAN ON THE MOVE
description: Women in the West have a hard time being taken seriously as chess players. In their formative years they are looked down upon by boys, who often refuse to play with them. Thus, they cannot get the practice and experience needed to become champions and cannot make this up by training with other girls because too few play the game as anything more than a parlor amusement.

description: TO many, Lanford Wilson is modern America's premier playwright, if not our most prolific. Indeed, the Missouri- born Wilson has been called the theatrical poet who ''hears America singing.''

description: Facing new opposition protests, the Government has reimposed the state of emergency under which it had ruled for 10 years.

title: EMBRYO-TRANSFER BABY BORN
description: A ''beautiful little girl'' is the world's second baby delivered by an infertile woman who received an embryo donated by another woman, doctors announced today.

title: Andrew Doyle Carson To Wed Miss McCain
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Hutchinson McCain of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Point 0'Woods, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Hutchinson McCain, to Andrew Doyle Carson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Doyle I. Carson of Dallas.

title: TO SIDNEY, AN EXPRESSION OF HEARTFELT REGRET
description: Open Letter to Sidney Lumet: Dear Sid: May I call you Sid, even though we have never met hand to hand, so to speak? This is hard for me to write. I know how sensitive you artists are, and I don't want to unnerve you to the point where you won't be able to get your work done, but Sid, I can't help you out.

title: DRUGS AT U.S. BASES AN ISSUE IN BRITAIN

title: CAMERACREATING PORTRAITS THAT HAVE GREATER IMPACT

Eugene Smith and Henri Cartier Bresson.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SOMEWHERE over Jeremy Gerber 's rainbow monotone birds fly. You see, Jeremy Gerber, a 17-year-old inventor and senior at Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua, prefers his rainbow black and white.

title:
ART;
IN MUSEUM, 'KRAZY KAT' LIVES
description: M ANY cartoon scholars agree that ''Krazy Kat'' is the greatest comic strip of all time, and through April 29 the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook is providing ample evidence to support that accolade. More than 50 original ''Krazy Kat'' episodes plus memorabilia and supporting material make this the largest exhibit of George Herriman's creation ever mounted.

title: A PIONEER SPIRIT SWEEPS BUSINESS
description: AMERICA has long been the land of the entrepreneur. It was born of an entrepreneur - Christopher Columbus - who, with his venture capital backer, Queen Isabella, developed a strategic plan to exploit business opportunities in distant lands. Isabella's investment in Columbus paid off handsomely - Spain gained a dominant hold on new world markets well ahead of its competitors. For Columbus, the tale was less happy. A poor manager, Columbus was replaced in 1499 as administrator of the Indies and died several years later, frustrated, humiliated and looking for work.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Some passages from current and recently published books that we find particularly appealing.

title: FILIPINOS START SIGNING UP FOR NEW VOTER LIST
description: Filipinos began reporting to registration centers throughout the country today for the compilation of a new voter list for the parliamentary elections scheduled in May. The roll will replace an earlier one used in past elections that some have charged contained fraudulent information.

DINING OUT;
NEW KITCHEN IN AN OLD HOUSE
description: -turned-restaurants are not the most likely candidates for good food. It sometime seems that the owners of such places expect the charm of the building to compensate for carelessly prepared meals.

title: Vivian Golding and Joseph G. Robinson Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Y. Golding of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Vivian Golding, to Joseph Glenn Robinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Robinson of Metuchen, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Cordless Phones Ruled Not Immune to Taping
description: The police may lawfully monitor and record cordless telephone conversations heard over an ordinary FM radio and use the recordings as evidence in court, the Kansas Supreme Court ruled today.

title: A CHORUS VENTURES INTO OPERA
description: Conventionally, choruses sing choral music: masses, oratorios, a cappella choral songs and the like. Less conventionally, they tackle actual operas. This Wednesday, Robert Bass and the Collegiate Chorale will present what is apparently the American premiere, in a concert performance, of Dvorak's ''Dimitri'' at Carnegie Hall.

title: A Bomb Explodes in Jordan Before Queen Elizabeth's Trip
description: A bomb blast in a hotel parking lot wounded two people today and a second was defused amid heightened security before a planned visit by Queen Elizabeth II, Government officials and witnesses said.

title: BANKS FINALLY RAISE THE PRIME
description: The upward push of interest rates finally forced the nation's banks to lift the prime lending rate for the first time since last August. Bankers said the one-half percentage point increase, to 11 1/2 percent, was justified in light of the rising cost of their own funds on the credit markets. And some expressed concern that the prime could go substantially higher. If the grim predictions were to come true, it would further aggravate third world debt problems, threaten to abort current economic growth and trouble the still-shakey thrift industry. Reaction from the White House was placing the blame for rising rates on the Congress, urging adoption of President Reagan's $150 billion budget cut proposals. The prime is currently at the highest level since January 1983. Reaction in the stock market was predictable - share prices fell through most of the week as investors continued to fear the effects of higher interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average lost almost 30 points, ending at 1,154.84. Bond prices also fell moderately. Late in the week, the Federal Reserve reported that M-1, the basic measure of the money supply, jumped an unexpected $4 billion.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: -year tenure as director of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford's Office of Radio and Television, the Rev. Edmund S. Nadolny developed a reputation for unusual fund-raising techniques. Now, in his new post as pastor of St. Vincent Ferrer's Church in Naugatuck, Father Nadolny has become a part-time Oriental rug merchant in an attempt to reduce a $3 million debt incurred in building the 2 1/2-year-old church.

title: Quake Damage Bill Signed
description: President Reagan signed a bill Friday authorizing $138 million in spending over two years on a study aimed at reducing the damage earthquakes cause. The bill authorizes funds at a slightly higher level than the Administration sought for a variety of programs for developing engineering standards for earthquake-resistant construction and studying and possibly predicting earthquakes.

title: TWO VIEWS OF THE PEI PYRAMID DESIGNED FOR THE LOUVRE
description: To put some king of perspective back into the current controversy about I. M. Pei's plan for the future of the Louvre, it is important to remember that the Louvre is not just a museum in the sense that the Metropolitan in New York and the National Gallery in Washington are museums. Not only is the Louvre a former royal palace, but it is in a real sense the art of Paris, and has been so ever since the Middle Ages. For this reason every Parisian feels that he has to have an opinion of the Louvre, even if he has never been inside it.

title: Kelsey Kerr to Wed May 5
description: Kelsey Allen Kerr and Walter Clifton Pascoe, graduates of St. Lawrence University, plan to be married May 5. Mr. and Mrs. John Kerr Jr. of Mantoloking, N.J., have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald C. Pascoe of Southbury, Conn. The future bride's father is secretary-treasurer of the Elizabethtown Water Company in Elizabeth, N.J.

title: 'STAR-WARS' DEFENSE HAS A FUTURE
description: A YEAR ago President Reagan announced a ''vision of the future'' in which defensive weaponry would make the nightmare of nuclear holocaust obsolete. Since then his ''Star Wars'' speech has inspired furious debate about whether powerful lasers placed in orbit could shoot down enemy missiles, how much such a system would cost, and whether it would trigger yet another round in the arms race.

description: More than 230 masterpieces from the Vatican Museums have been returned in ''perfect condition'' after a yearlong tour of the United States, the director of the museums said today.

title:
Dining Out;
FOR CHILDREN OF ALL AGES

The old station waiting room - taller than its length or width - and the baggage room connect a wooden Baltimore & Ohio caboose (brought from the old yards at Chillicothe, Ohio) dating to 1910 and a more dignififed 1896 ''presidential'' car, a perquisite of railroad presidents in the steam engine's heyday.

title: 'BEST FRIEND,' TRIANGLE IN SNOW
description: The story of two buddies whose friendship is altered by an accommodating woman, a creature who is luscious but either passive, duplicitous or dim, is practically a staple for Bertrand Blier, the director of ''Going Places'' and ''Get Out Your Handkerchiefs.'' That Mr. Blier's casual misogyny continues to have its light side is really no small accomplishment.

title: WHERE TO LOOK WHEN IT'S NOT ON THE DEALER'S SHELVES
description: This is our day for odds and ends - for catching up with small topics that don't really deserve an entire column to themselves. Topic No. 1 is The Wild Goose Chase or Where to Find it. Readers tell me that they often have trouble finding audio equipment discussed in these pages at their local hi-fi stores. This is not surprising, for each store carries only a limited number of brands. In fact, many manufacturers deliberately confine their distribution to one outlet in a given area to prevent discounting of their product by rival dealers serving the same market. This is especially true of the better products, whose manufacturers prefer to have their wares shown only in suitable settings and demonstrated with care, patience and understanding. Such manufacturers are not likely to entrust their franchise to the numerous shops whose merchandising philosophy is based on volume sales and quick turnover.

title: The Resistible Rise of Major Bob
description: Today's election in El Salvador is dismissed as a fraud by guerrillas who want to boycott or disrupt it. It's not. It may be a gamble, even a foolish one, but the presidential vote is not just a sham. Thousands of democratic party workers are defying cutthroats of the right and the left in a laudable attempt to count votes instead of bodies. Their main champion is a decent and tested Christian Democrat, Jose Napoleon Duarte, who was robbed of victory in 1972 and whose enemies do him honor.

title: RELATIVE CALM RESTORED IN BEIRUT, BUT FRENCH STEP STIRS NEW WORRY
description: Relative calm returned today to West Beirut after two days of clashes between Druse and Sunni Moslem militiamen. But the announcement from France that its troops would leave created new concern over possible violence.

description: WHEN Patricia Snyder and her husband moved to Boerum Hill 20 years ago, many of the deteriorating brownstones in the neighborhood just south of downtown Brooklyn were scheduled for demolition. The old families were either moving out or dying off, to be replaced by absentee landlords or real-estate speculators, and banks were writing mortgages there only reluctantly, if at all.

title: PATH TO MIDEAST FAILURE BLAZED WITH MISTAKES
description: Donald H. Rumsfeld is touring the Middle East these days on what may well be his last mission as President Reagan's special envoy to the region. Instead of brokering a diplomatic initiative, which was his original mandate three months ago, he is telling the Israelis and the Arabs that Washington is moving to the sidelines. The message is this: America has made an honorable effort to bring stability to Lebanon and peace to the region, but there is not much more it can do now without more cooperation from them.

Meanwhile, the Hoyas were feeble, opening the contest in a 2-1-2 zone defense, not the trademark man-to-man trap that had dissected so many opponents this season.

JAKARTA: INDONESIA'S TREASURE TROVE

title: THERE'S REAL ACTION IN SIMULATION FIELD
description: It all started in 1929 in the basement of the organ factory that Edwin A. Link's father ran. Using an organ's bellows to blow air against the bottom of a suspended box, Mr. Link found that he could approximate the motion of an airplane in flight. And the flight simulator was born.

title: COMPUTERS PRINT OUT A BRAND NEW INDUSTRY

The design and testing of these circuits have traditionally been done only by mechanical means, almost by hand, with only partial help from mainframe computers.

title: Jet Stairway Opens in Flight
description: A Continental Airlines 727 made an emergency landing at Stapleton International Airport Thursday because the rear stairway on the plane came open in flight. The inner door to the cabin remained closed throughout the flight, keeping the cabin pressurized, according to Bill Knox, an airport spokesman. No one was injured in the incident, he said.

Helfrich of the Superior Court of New Jersey and Mrs. Helfrich of Chatham, N.J. The wedding is to take place in November.

title: SHORT-TERM FINANCING FOR A MOVE

In such a situation, the answer often is a short-term financing known as a bridge loan that will cover the down payment and closing costs on the new home.

title: FINAL OPERA BY DONIZETTI
description: ''Dom Sebastien, Roi de Portugal,'' the last of Donizetti's 65 operas, had its premiere at the Paris Opera on Nov. 11, 1843, with Rosine Stoltz as Zaida and Gilbert-Louis Duprez in the title role. Composed a year after one of his most popular comedies, ''Don Pasquale,'' and in the same year as the more serious ''Maria di Rohan,'' it was enthusiastically received by contemporary audiences but disparaged by most critics.

title: Miss Dwight Wed To Thomas Hess

Hess Jr. of New York and Louise Dann of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed by Jean S. Kotkin, a leader of the American Ethical Union, at the English-Speaking Union in New York.

title: ISRAEL AFTER LEBANON
description: WHEN MOSHE ARENS ASSUMED office as Israel's Defense Minister a year ago, the nation was at war with neighboring forces, at war with itself and at odds with its closest ally. Twelve months later, the moral agony has subsided and, in the face of the latest disaster in Lebanon, Israe turn inward and rely more than ever on itself. Lebanese President Amin Gemayel, under Syrian pressure, has cancelled the May 17, 1983 security agreement with Israel that called for the withdrawal of all foreign troops abruptly washed its hands of the pact, has withdrawn its forces from Lebanese soil and has approached Jordan in an effort to fashion a new Middle East strategy - an overture that Jordan has rejected. Egypt, in continuing protest of Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon, refuses to return its ambassador to Tel Aviv. And Yasir Arafat, who was forcibly evicted from Lebanon with his Palestine Liberation Organization troops, has been huddling with King Hussein of Jordan over possible ways to coordinate policies to regain the occupied West Bank.

title: Cajun Attire
description: When the coaches of the National Invitation Tournament's semifinalists gathered at Madison Square Garden for a news conference yesterday, Bob Paschal of Southwestern Louisiana was the only one who showed up without a jacket and tie. His sports shirt, however, was not an example of Cajun country casualness, the assembly was told, but a concession to an urban calamity. It seems that when Paschal and other Cajun coaches flew here from Lafayette, La., Friday night, they made a plane change in Dallas, but their luggage didn't.

title: CONCERT: ENTREMONT AND NEW ORLEANS SYMPHONY
description: The opening of Shostakovich's Ninth Symphony in E flat still has the power to shock, as its performance by the New Orleans Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra conducted by Philippe Entremont showed in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. But the shock is not in harsh revelations of the deprivation and pain of war, or in exuberant celebration of that war's end in 1945. The shock - particularly for a symphony bearing that historically significant number - is of its utter triviality.

description: Anne Earl, the 19-year-old daughter of Gov. Anthony S. Earl, has been charged with disorderly conduct for reportedly waving a cap pistol at a motorist on an interstate highway.

title: TORVILLE-DEAN TRIUMPH
description: Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean, the royal couple of figure skating, won a record 13 perfect marks of 6 for their freestyle routine tonight to breeze to their fourth straight world ice-dancing championship.

title: 2 SCENIC AREAS STUDY STATION CHANGES
description: STONY BROOK, a community that prides itself on its esthetic as well as practical concerns, has long struggled with the condition of its railroad station, which to many has become a hazard as well as an eyesore, and now is confronting a nettlesome parking problem.

title: ART IN ADVERTISING
description: Advertising transformed much of our visual environment after the 1850's, thanks to the developments in lithography, the greatest tool known in the history of advertising until television came into being. The explosion in commercial graphics from the Civil War through World War II has, in recent years, been studied by scholars, exhibited by galleries and museums, reviewed by critics, documented in books, and collected by enthusiasts.

title: CUSTOM SOFTWARE: THE PERFECT FIT

''Our office is right across from the cows and the pigs and the corn,'' said the founder of FBS Systems in Aledo, Ill., one of the first and most successful of software houses catering to farmers and agribusinesses.

title: COMPUTER SPECIALISTS ARE SINGING THE BLUES
description: EXPANDING on a rhyme that Gilbert & Sullivan created a century ago to describe the plight of the policemen in ''The Pirates of Penzance'' might well describe that of a growing number of today's computer-science specialists:

He defeated Mark Roth of Spring Lake Heights, N.J., 232-227, in the semifinal.

title: OPERA: EVE QUELER CONDUCTS 'DOM SEBASTIEN'
description: In her tireless search for rare operas to present in concert form, Eve Queler is like a big-game hunter whose aim is to bring'em back alive. She beats her way through the jungles of the forgotten repertory and oftener than not captures and tames her prey. Now and then, however, the conductor of the Opera Orchestra of New York brings a specimen back half alive, or less.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball

title: Newspapers Replace Ink Containing PCB's
description: Several newspapers in California, Arizona and Alaska have replaced yellow ink suspected of containing cancer- causing polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, while others around the nation are having their supplies tested.

title: WHEN CHILDREN HAVE 2 HOMES
description: Every two weeks, Mara Frank, 15 years old, and her sister, Tamar, 13, pack up their favorite outfits, their schoolbooks and their equipment for dancing school and leave their mother to live with their father 23 blocks uptown in Manhattan. Two weeks later they pack up and move back with their mother.

title: THE IRISH ON TV - ERSATZ AND OTHERWISE
description: How do you like your Irish? They have been omnipresent on television recently, a bundle of images, sometimes conflicting. Last week-end, for example, there was the St. Patrick's Day parade; tonight, on Channel 13 at 11, there is ''The Bronx Irish at the Ramparts,'' a half-hour documentary that looks at an Irish-American neighborhood. Television also has offered, among other things, programs as Irish, or as semi-Irish, as John Ford's enchanting 1952 film ''The Quiet Man,'' the ''Frontline'' documentary ''The Old Man and the Gun'' and ''The Irish R. M.'' on ''Masterpiece Theater.'' Some of the programs are about the Irish and some are about Irish-Americans. The telecast of the St. Patrick's Day parade creates a genre of its own.

title: MANHATTAN-BOUND TRAFFIC STALLED BY BRIDGE REPAIRS AND ACCIDENTS
description: Manhattan-bound traffic backed up for miles in Brooklyn and Queens yesterday after city and state officials closed a bridge for repairs, and then several accidents and an oil spill closed a total of 17 traffic lanes into the borough.

title: No Headline
description: THEY have been at it for two years, researching, organizing and refining. They talked to 150 designers, traveled to corporations, design schools and offices, listened to a special panel of advisers, sent out questionnaires and considered nearly 200 modern design objects before selecting the 74 pieces on exhibit in ''The Product of Design,'' a lively and informative show at the Katonah Gallery through May 27.

For many American scientists, however, there are equally important nonpolitical reasons why the United States should remain in the organization. They say that if Washington withdraws at the end of this year as threatened, it will forfeit a leading role in Unesco's global research projects and cut Americans off from important scientific developments.

Starting with the little boy's attachment to a particular pair of raggedy sneakers

title: 'HUMAN' COMPUTER IS COMING OF AGE
description: FOR two decades the development of artificial intelligence - the use of computers to imitate learning and reasoning processes and solve problems - was largely confined to a few university computer centers. Now artificial intelligence, or A.I., is making its way into the research and development laboratories of Fortune 500 companies across the nation.

title: CHOPS (VEAL, LAMB OR PORK): SOME OF LIFE'S SIMPLE COMFORTS
description: CHOPS make a quick economical meal for one or two people. There is no waste and the cooking is fast. At this time of year lamb and veal are at their most delicate, spring vegetables are starting to appear on the market while the weather is still brisk enough for pork. There are few things as comforting as a chop, cooked simply and served with boiled new or mashed potatoes and young fresh peas, carrots or cauliflower.

title: 67 STUDENTS CHOSEN FOR HUMANITIES PROGRAM

title: SEPARATING WHEAT FROM THE EDB
description: For the food industry, this has fast become the winter and spring of discontent, as state after state sets its own standards for the presence of the pesticide ethylene dibromide, or EDB, in foods. The latest source of frustration is New York, which last week set EDB levels lower than those suggested by the Federal Government. ''To have individual states going off in individual directions is crazy,'' said Austin Sullivan, a spokesman for General Mills in Minneapolis, making the case for national standards.

title: DANCE: ANNE DREYFUS TROUPE FROM PARIS
description: Compagnie Anne Dreyfus, a modern-dance group from Paris, made its American debut Wednesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church in three works choreographed by Miss Dreyfus in a sharp, driving style of movement. These works were admirably serious and each contained moments of interest.

title: N.F.L. ADOPTS A WAIT-AND-SEE ATTITUDE
