They voted to approve the sale of a team; they learned that a second team had been sold and a third might be sold. They tempered dancing after sacks and agreed to change a few other rules and to condense the draft to one day, May 1. They formed a committee to study current problems in the league and to minimize them in the future.

title: The Mayor and 'Mayor'
description: To the Editor:

title: SALVADOR SEEKING A WAY OUT IN VOTE TODAY
description: E L Salvador will vote for a President today. The effort to establish democratic procedures and institutions in a country racked by leftist and rightist violence, begun with the election of a Constituent Assembly two years ago, has enjoyed the backing of the Reagan Administration but has met with skepticism in Congress and in much of Latin America, where critics have held that nothing is possible until there is a consensus to end the strife. Last week, such consensus was conspicuously absent as the insurgents sought to discourage voters up to the last moment by seizing their identity cards and by acts of violence that reached the capital and the second largest city, Santa Ana. The skepticism was reflected in a decision by the Senate, accepted by the Administration, to put off a vote on further emergency aid until after the election and to reduce the amount from $93 million to $61.75 million. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, of Massachusetts, who blocked the Administration drive for a quick vote, said the money would be better used ''when we see what kind of regime we are dealing with.'' Up to now, the Senator and other critics have seen the regime as less than democratic and as closely involved in rightist death squads. One target has been Col. Nicolas Carranza, the head of the Salvadoran Treasury Police, which has a reputation for being particularly brutal. He was said by American officials to have been in the pay, at $90,000 a year, of the Central Intelligence Agency but he denied such a connection.

title: SOVIET JAZZ HAS SURVIVED POLITICS
description: S oviet jazz has long come out of the closet. The music is no longer assailed from ideological pulpits, and musicians who once spent their days as engineers and dusted off dented saxophones for private parties at night now give regular concerts, replete with posters, press reviews and regular pay. The stalwart jazz lovers who sustained their faith through the lean years with an ear glued to Willis Conover's ''Music U.S.A.'' on the Voice of America or hunched over a scratchy Count Basie disk off the black market now give lectures at conservatories, write articles on jazz for Pravda and read learned dissertations on bop. Soviet musicians who jammed excitedly with Benny Goodman's sidemen during his historic visit to Moscow in 1962 now export their own brand of sophisticated jazz, and Soviet ensembles like the Vyacheslav Ganelin Trio from Lithuania have developed an admiring European following all their own. There's even an annual jazz poll compiled by Soviet critics and published each year by the Riga newspaper Sovetskaya Molodezh (Soviet Youth). This year the Ganelin Trio is expected to rate first again, followed by first-class groups like Nikolai Levinovsky's Allegro and German Lukianov's Cadence, and musicians like the pianist Leonid Chizhik, saxophonist Alexei Kozlov or the singer Larissa Dolina - and about 170 other musicians and ensembles.

They are human gymnasts, acrobats, dancers and actors no more than 5 feet 6 inches tall who were taught and trained for months to act like chimps.

title:
ART;
JAPANESE LOCALES AT YALE ART GALLERY
description: AT a time when Japanese culture seems especially displaced - when, for example, Japanese fashion designers are the toast of Paris - an exhibition such as ''The Spirit of Place,'' at the Yale University Art Gallery (through May 6) has special force. The thesis of this exhibition is that Japanese art has traditionally been anchored by specific hallowed and revered locales.

Conversation takes the importance, the seriousness, the truth, out of everything I think.'' - Franz Kafka, from his diaries, 1918.

title: NEW STRICTURES END A MIDWIFERY CASE

She missed her opportunity to appear in a story she wrote then, but at 4:30 P.M. Tuesday, she will fulfill her ambition. She will appear in the CBS-TV ''School Break Special'' based on her novel, ''Welcome Home, Jellybean.''

title: A HIGH TIDE OF HOMELESSNESS WASHES OVER CITY AGENCIES
description: The desperation of New York City's homeless families is communicated in spiraling statistics. The city sheltered an average of 1,560 families a night in dilapidated welfare hotels in January 1983. By last week, the figure had risen to more than 2,800 families - enough men, women, and children, about 10,300, to establish a good-sized town. Because of the staggering numbers, the city has been forced to place some families in higher- priced hotels where rooms cost as much as $121 a night.

title: ENTREPRENEUR OF TRADE SHOW
description: WHEN he was 10 years old in his native Tunisia, Emile Tubiana experienced life caught between the German Army and the Allies. The Americans, he says today in French-accented English, ''saved our life.'' So he grew up with two principal ideas about where he wanted to live and what he wanted to do.

I wish to point out that Mr. Kandell's characterization of the ''largest of rodents,'' the capybara, is not completely accurate.

title: New Offer in Strike in India
description: The Indian Government made a new pay offer today to leaders of a nine-day- old dock workers' strike as formal talks began in an effort to end a stalemate that has shut the country's 10 major ports. The Press Trust of India, a news agency, quoted union leaders as saying the dock workers had been offered a minimum basic wage of $55 a month, the same as in the steel industry. Parity with steel workers has been a major objective of the strikers.

title: GEORGIA TO CONTEST CHARGES OF BIAS IN KEY COLLEGE TEST

title: A Trade and a Release
description: Rick Leach, the former Michigan quarterback who has been a utility infielder with the Detroit Tigers for the last three years, was given his outright release yesterday only hours before the Tigers made a trade with the Philadelphia Phillies involving four players. Detroit gave up the catcher John Wockenfuss, one of the better hit-and-run batters in baseball, and the outfielder Glenn Wilson, who was hitting .320 this spring.

description: The Foreign Ministers of China and Japan met here today and ruled out an early improvement in relations with the Soviet Union. They expressed hopes for improved ties with the United States.

title: CONQUERING BOLIVIA'S FRONTIER
description: I was an economic adviser in Bolivia in 1964 and 1965 and already, at that time, beef was moving from Trinidad on the Beni River to the market in La Paz by plane (''Conquering Bolivia's Frontier,'' by Jonathan Kandell, Feb.19). Old World War II bombers were the cargo carriers, the principal supplier of fresh meat to La Paz.

title: EARLY MUSIC FURNISHES AN EMBARRASSMENT OF RICHES
description: One of the happiest artistic advancements of our time involves the growing public awareness of early and Baroque music. Who could have foreseen the day when two integral recorded surveys of Bach's 200-odd cantatas would be under way, offering the listener a chance to get to know what have been called the greatest undiscovered treasures in music? The operas of Handel and Rameau are gradually being recorded and, ever so slowly, are making their way into the repertory of the world's opera houses. Several recent albums - of keyboard music, orchestral works and operas - add to what is becoming a joyful embarrassment of riches.

title: A TALK WITH MARK HELPRIN: 'I MAY BE AN ANOMALY'
description: THERE seems something daredevil about a novelist who is willing to go on record as a ''a Roosevelt Republican.'' But Mark Helprin, 36, has an A.B. and M.A. from Harvard University, has studied under Hugh Trevor-Roper at the University of Oxford, served in the Israeli infantry and Air Force, won the National Jewish Book Award, received a Guggenheim Fellowship and the Prix de Rome (for study at the American Academy in Rome) and written four books, and chooses his labels with care.

title: A BUSY TIME FOR VATICAN COINS AND MEDALS
description: Events in Vatican City normally move quite slowly, but this is a fast-paced period insofar as Vatican numismatics is concerned. Two different medals honoring Pope John Paul II have recently been released by the Vatican, and on Thursday a set of seven coins will be issued to commemorate the fifth year of John Paul's reign.

title: Greta Marie Heil To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. James H. Heil of North Caldwell, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Greta Marie Heil, to Kenneth Lloyd McElwee, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Andrew A. McElwee, also of North Caldwell. The wedding is planned for May.

title: THE WORLD
description: Unsafe Passage In Nicaragua

title: STATE LAWS ON SMOKING
description: THE state's Clean Indoor Act, passed in 1979 and strengthened last year, restricts smoking in certain places.

title: Central Missouri State Wins Division II Titles
description: Ron Nunnelly scored 38 points and Carla Eades had 22 as Central Missouri State won both the men's and women's Division II National Collegiate Athletic Association men's basketball championships.

title: Colonel Defends High School R.O.T.C.
description: I take emphatic exception to the Rev. Raymond J. Pontier's ill-conceived Opinion Page article of Feb. 26 on R.O.T.C. in high schools. The confused minister somehow concludes that the Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps offers instruction in militarism, war-making and the taking of a human life.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE NAPPING HOUSE

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
WHY 20-YEAR DEPRECIATION WON'T HURT
description: THE Senate Finance Committee

title: Correction
description: A caption on page 7 of the Real Estate section last Sunday incorrectly identified a member of the Municipal Arts Society's panel on commercial rent control. The panelist, shown at right, was Herb Rothman, chief executive officer of the New York Small Busines Association.

title:
GARDENING;
ANNUALS VS. PERENNIALS
description: THE inexperienced gardener is attracted to flowering annuals by their ease of culture and long season of bloom. As experience is acquired, there is often a change in preference toward perennials. In fact, many sophisticated gardeners advanced in knowledge and taste eschew the use of annuals under the guise that they are not worthy of consideration.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline

title: No Headline
description: Coffee Is Said to Work As Asthma Treatment

title: Working Mothers Are Defended
description: Joanne Bonwick's Opinion Page diatribe against ''working and otherwise absent mothers'' (March 4) is offensive to all parents, fathers included, who are attempting to successfully integrate their family and work duties.

title: CASUAL CLOTHES FOR SUMMER
description: Stripped of the gimmicks that have become all too pervasive in the past several seasons, sportswear-from serious active wear to relaxed weekend clothes-has a more sophisticated look. Now, quite simply, shape, color and pattern are the most important factors in sportswear design.

title: THE LOST IDEALS OF YOUTH
description: Paul Johnson, a former editor of The New Statesman, is the author of ''Modern Times: The World From the Twenties to the Eighties.'' THE GREAT JOKE here,'' said a freshman at the University of Glasgow in Scotland, ''is to take the mickey out of the third world.'' By that he meant making fun of the people of underdeveloped countries. A recent article in the Jericho Bugle, one of Oxford University's student magazines, does exactly that, with a savagery the students of the 1960's would have found horrifying.

title: KasparovDelaysChessGame ToMarkOpponent'sBirthday
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union, in an act of courtesy unusual these days in top-flight chess, requested and obtained a postponement of the seventh game of the final candidates match in honor of his opponent's birthday.

title: SHIPBUILDERS TAKE A NEW TACK IN RACE
description: Too many merchant ships are chasing too little cargo in the world, American shipbuilders say. And yet, the nation's shipbuilding industry is trying everything from robots to lasers to build them even faster.

title: James
description: The engagement of Mary Teresa Pearce, an account executive with the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample advertising agency, to James Polk Rutherfurd, an associate with the New York law firm of Rogers & Wells, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan Thompson Pearce of Short Hills, N.J. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Rutherfurd of New York and Fishers Island, L.I.

title: MUSIC: NYGAARD CONDUCTS JUPITER SYMPHONY
description: If all conductors planned concerts as imaginatively as Jens Nygaard, our musical life would be far livelier. Mr. Nygaard had the Jupiter Symphony at his disposal for the entire evening at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday, but that did not mean to him that the whole orchestra had to play throughout the program.

title: Margaret E. Gracey Marries Jose Guillermo Brena
description: Margaret Ellen Gracey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Donald Gracey of Longmeadow, Mass., was married yesterday to Jose Guillermo Brena, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Guillermo Pacheco Brena of Bedford, N.H. Msgr. Thomas Devine performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Longmeadow.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think there is absolutely nothing wrong, and if they viewed the facts, there is no appearance of something wrong.'' - Edwin Meese 3d. (32:6.)

title: 174 Million Old EnoughTo Vote in November
description: Nearly 174 million Americans will be old enough to vote in the November's Presidential election, the Census Bureau says.

title: LIFE'S COMFORTS CARRY THE DAY AT GREENBRIER
description: Naming itself for a thorny green vine is, for a quintessential resort like the Greenbrier, in White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., a masterpiece of diffidence. Its Swiss counterparts proclaim the grandeur of their status from the tips of their mountain realms, sometimes in neon lights: They would have all the world know they are

title: RHYTHMIC FUSION PROPELS A NEW POP COLLABORATION
description: Of all the arts, popular music is proudest to be a social entity. Its performers rarely work alone; that's not the point in music that depends on connections between musicians as they work and between performers and audiences. Jazz and rock bands, and any group that doesn't depend on written music, agree on what to play in a cooperative process that changes from song to song. And even a solo performer has to consider who will be listening.

title: BEING OUPTSPENT EARLY COULD RESULT IN DIVIDIENDS FOR HART
description: While the limelight shone on Walter F. Mondale's victory in Illinois last week, his campaign organization quietly furloughed 65 of its 200 staff members and field workers. He has also been using long-distance satellite news conferences with some states to save on travel money. In the days leading up to the New York primary next week, Mr. Mondale's top aides will pass up hotels for private homes.

description: Christine Yelavich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Yelavich of Cedar Grove, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Richard Hanmer Miers, the son of Dr. Suzanne Miers of Athens, Ohio, and London and the late Brigadier Richard C. H. Miers of the British Army. The Rev. Howard O'Shea, a Roman Catholic chaplain at Brown University, performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Church in Cedar Grove.

title: ; A Long Month of Being Powerless
description: MY Buick Century died in the middle of 42d Street the other day, and as I stood there in the drizzle, helpless and doing more than my share for the Midtown miseries, I remembered Paul Miller.

title: Ada Meloy, a Lawyer For N.Y.U., Marries
description: Ada Meloy, the associate general counsel of New York University, and Richard Thomas Muller, an independent tax lawyer in Bethlehem, Pa., were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: RESEARCH CENTERS GET PRIORITY RATING
description: AT Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's Center for Industrial Innovation, students and faculty members are working on large- scale integrated circuit design, interactive graphics and manufacturing processes projects, whose results will be shared by the high-technology companies that contributed to the center's founding or pay an annual fee. And the building that is to house the center at this private university in Troy, N. Y., is being underwritten with a $30 million state loan.

title: JACKSON ADVANCES ON MONDALE LEAD
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale held a slim lead in delegate strength in the opening round of Virginia's Democratic caucuses over the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who was ahead in the popular vote in one of his strongest showings to date.

title: ONE-MAN SHOW ZALOOMS ALONG
description: IN kindergarten at the Stratford

title: PARKING PROBLEMS IRK HUNTINGTON
description: WHEN merchants and shoppers talk about the traffic and parking problems in the village of Huntington on a busy shopping day, they wince a little. When they think about two dozen more stores opening, with no additional parking, they wince a lot.

title: By Herert Mitgang Lincoln Conspiracy Starring Bradford Dillman, John Dehner and John Anderson; directed by James L. Conway, 1977 VidAmerica 87 minutes. $34.95
description: For many years, sensationalist writers have theorized that John Booth's assassination of President Lincoln was part of a vast conspiracy fostered by Secretary of War Edwin Stanton, other Union officials and businessmen. In ''The Lincoln Conspiracy,'' this unsubstantiated theory is presented as gospel.

title: Miss Sheard To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Charles Sheard 3d of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Wendy Alice Sheard to Wayne Rockwell Geyer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Rockwell Geyer of Stamford, Conn. The wedding is planned for June.

title: No Headline
description: Arab Group Sees Peril If U.S. Moves Embassy

title: INMATE-WORKERS BUILD NEW PRISONS
description: Under normal circumstances, Phillip Eaton would be at the pinnacle of his trade. He is serving as the general contractor on a state construction project. But these are not normal circumstances. Mr. Eaton is also serving a life sentence for murder.

title: ON ART, FILM AND ODETS
description: To the Editor;

title: INDIA IS REVIVING TRIBAL VALUES IN NORTHEST
description: The Government has quickened the pace of economic development in the troubled hills of northeast India to curb insurgents and open up the isolated region. At the same time it is encouraging tribespeople to revive ancient traditions.

title: Reds Lower Fence
description: The Cincinnati Reds, who have finished last in the National League Western Division two years in a row, are in a rebuilding effort, one not limited to the roster. They are also rebuilding the outfield wall at Riverfront Stadium by trimming 4 feet from its 12-foot height. ''It's designed to make the game more exciting offensively and defensively,'' said the club's spokesman, Jim Ferguson, who insisted that the effort was not designed solely to improve the club's home-run output, which was a disappointing 107 last year.

title: THE WORLD
description: Dublin Extradites A Terrorist

title: ISLANDERS TIED BY NORTH STARS
description: The rookie coach of the Minnesota North Stars, Bill Mahoney, looked over at the bench of the Islanders tonight as overtime loomed with the score tied at 4-4.

title: CONSUMERS STILL COMING ON STRONG
description: From oil price shocks to recessions and wild swings in interest rates, the United States economy has undergone considerable trauma in the past decade. But that economic bulwark, the American consumer, appears to have emerged relatively unscarred. ''There just don't appear to be any fundamental changes in consumer behavior,'' says Thomas Juster, director of the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan. ''Consumers appear to be behaving more or less as always.'' Nowhere is that more evident than in the consumer lending market where, as in most economic expansions, individuals are taking on considerable new debt.

description: Ronald De Feo is a freelance critic and short-story writer. THE WANDERING UNICORN

title: JACKSON ADVISERS ARE DIVERSE GROUP
description: In keeping with its reputation of being untraditional, the campaign of the Rev. Jesse Jackson lacks multiple layers of staff responsible for organization, scheduling, strategy and policy or any well-defined inner circle of top decison makers.

title: HOPE FOR OSTEOPOROSIS VICTIMS
description: WHEN she was in her late 50's, Carol Garvin drove across Vermont, etching a trail along the state's narrow, twisting roads. By the end of her vacation, she returned to her Long Island home in deep pain. She had fractured several vertebrae in her spine.

title: Babette Rose Weil Marries Marc Cole in White Plains
description: Babette Rose Weil, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Louis Weil of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to Marc Stephen Cole, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard C. Cole of Jericho, L.I. Rabbi Arnold M. Belzer performed the ceremony at Stouffer's Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: HIGHER IN THE HEIGHTS
description: The Watchtower Bible and Tract Society drew considerable opposition from the Brooklyn Heights community in 1960 when it demolished several row houses to put up a pre-Landmark Law high-rise dormitory. Now the Society, which has extensive holdings in the Heights, is seeking a zoning variance for part of its property outside the neighborhood's historic district to construct a 34-story residence and garage that would incorporate part of its 12-story, 100,000-square-foot headquarters building at 30 Columbia Heights.

title: FOCUS IS ON ETHIOPIA RUNNERS
description: The three Ethiopian runners, small, almost-frail men with eyes that suggested a bit of bewilderment, stood together sipping tea. In the next room of their Manhattan hotel, their competitors told how they feared and how little they understood them.

title: FEDERALS: LOSING CASE SO FAR
description: Since the United States Football League was formed almost two years ago, Berl Bernhard has had plenty of opportunity to ask, ''Where did I go wrong?'' Bernhard is the principal owner of the Washington Federals, whom the Generals play today in Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: STUDY CITES SHARP INCREASE IN BREAST FEEDING
description: Breast feeding increased dramatically in the 1970's, and better-educated mothers were more likely to breast-feed their babies, a Federal survey shows.

title: 4 BASQUE COMMANDOS KILLED IN HARBOR AMBUSH
description: Spanish security forces have wiped out what they described as a five-man commando team of Basque terrorists who were trying to slip into Spain from southern France by rubber boat. The action came in a dramatic police ambush Thursday night in the harbor of the northern town of Pasajes San Juan.

title: David P. Dunne Engaged To Margaret Ellen Leahy
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David J. Leahy of Yonkers of the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Ellen Leahy, to David Patrick Dunne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Dunne of Rye, N.Y.

title: FEMINIST FICTION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SUFFERING BINDELS
description: Robert Greenfield's most recent novel, ''Temple,'' won the National Jewish Book Award for Fiction in 1983. BROTHERS

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ATHENS
description: PAUL ANASTASI contributes to The New York Times from Athens. The attraction of being in Athens in spring or early summer is not just to sightsee or observe the events, but also to enjoy the time of year itself. This is Greece at its best, with nearly uninterrupted sunny weather, blossoming flowers and the festivities of Orthodox Easter.

title: COLLEGE COSTS RISE A BIT MORE SLOWLY
description: STUDENTS setting out this fall for a year at a private Connecticut college or university can expect to pay between $9,500 and nearly $14,000 for tuition, room and board.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
'HEIFETZ' OF THE SINGING GLASSES
description: PLAYING glasses, Gloria Parker is the first to admit, is an unusual way to make a living as a musician. In fact, she says there are only ''one or two gentlemen who do it these days, but I'm the only lady in the world as far as I know.''

title: Westchester Opinion; FREEWHEELING: PLEASURE SEEKING
description: ONE of the arguments offered in any put-down of the suburban life is that we suburbanites ''don't know how to have fun.'' Our denigrators say that we middle-aged country mice aren't as adventuresome as city mice, that we settle for bland, stereotypical cocktail parties rather than seeking out kicky new entertainment forms.

title: Drop the Clock In Basketball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHERE DOES THE MET'S DUTY TO OPERATIC HISTORY END?
description: The Metropolitan Opera's extravagant staging of ''Francesca da Rimini,'' one of only three new productions the company has offered in its centennial season, has raised basic questions about repertory aims and priorities that should be addressed before the memory of Riccardo Zandonai's opera fades. Though I was not one who found this relic of the verismo style worth the time and money (reportedly $1.5 million) lavished on it by the Metropolitan, I recognize that such events can have value as studies in historical perspective. The question is how much energy and expense the Metropolitan can afford to spend on such ephemeral projects, especially in light of the recent report of its financial belt-tightening efforts.

title: FUNDS DENIED FOR LANDMARK OAK
description: ROY G. DEWEY, 90 years old, peered up at the Granby Oak, which spreads its nine branches more than 100 feet over town property and his family's land on Day Street in Granby.

title: CIRITIC' CHOICES
description: On Wednesday night, public television's ''Live from the Met'' reduces one of operas' most gargantuan works to the dimensions of a television screen. Hector Berlioz's ''Les Troyens'' opened the Metropolitan Opera's centennial season last fall, and this performance, taped October 8, will sprawl across an evening of viewing on Channels 13 and 49, beginning at 8 P.M. and ending a half hour after midnight.

title: PREPARING THE OUTSIDE OF THE HOUSE FOR A PAINT JOB
description: -it-yourselfers will soon be tackling the job of painting the outside of their houses. To insure a good-looking job that will also last as long as it should, many will rightly decide to buy a top-quality paint and most will be reasonably careful about following the manufacturer's directions as to mixing and applying that paint.

title: VALUE OF STATE'S FARM GOODS UP 23% FROM '78, STUDY SAYS
description: New York State produced $2.4 billion worth of agricultural products in 1982, a rise of 23 percent from 1978, according to a new Federal agriculture study.

title: EXCEPTIONAL TIMING
description: Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of The New York Times. At the turn of the century, Alberto Santos-Dumont, a wealthy young Brazilian living in Paris, captivated the populace with his daring flights in gas-filled balloons and the newly invented airplane. One evening, while sipping aperitifs at Maxim's with his good friend Louis Cartier, he complained about the difficulty of ''pulling a watch from one's waistcoat while trying to steer a dirigible being buffeted by high winds.'' Although women sometimes wore watches - set in heavy, gold bracelets encrusted with precious stones - on their wrists, men shunned them because they were considered too effeminate. Cartier reasoned that the watch, not the bracelet, should be of prime importance and he set about designing one for his friend. The resulting ''Santos'' watch with its simple gold case, white face, black Roman numerals, plain leather band and gold buckle became the world's first wristwatch for men. Some three decades later, Cartier brought forth another first. El Glaoui, Lord of the Atlas Mountains and Pasha of Marrakesh, had called him and complained, ''I like to be able to cool off in my pool and not lose track of time.'' This conversation led to the invention of the first water-resistant watch.

title: PAGING PHYSICIANS' ASSISTANTS
description: BECAUSE of rapidly rising medical costs, the buzzword in health care today is productivity, and that is good news for the career prospects of physician assistants: persons whose two-year training program prepares them to perform about 70 percent of the clinical procedures traditionally completed by physicians in general practice.

title: TV'S CONTINUING OBLIGATION TO CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT TO ADD FOR THE SEASON
description: Designers on both sides of the Atlantic agree that the look of men's wear for the coming warmer months is more elegant than it has been in several seasons. Urbane, sophisticated clothing, devoid of gimmicks, has turned up as the top priority for spring. Just what item will add the proper touch to the wardrobe is a matter of individual choice. But the designers, at least many of them, advise that the sports coat is the pivotal point in the wardrobe. Sweaters are a near second, but even in this casual form of dressing the look remains uncluttered and pared down.

title: HOFSTRA GETS A 'FOREST'
description: HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY will be a little greener this spring, thanks to the Johnny Appleseed of the school and one of his former students.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Anniversary Sale On the Road Westchester Road Runner in White Plains is celebrating its fourth birthday in April with an anniversary sale, but until then the winter clearance has dropped some prices to 20 to 60 percent off the retail charge. One sale rack contains long- and short-sleeved shirts and warm-up jackets and pants, all at 40 percent off.

title: JOB OUTLOOK FOR THE 80'S IS GENERALLY OPTIMISTIC
description: AT THE START of the decade, with the automobile and steel industries reeling from foreign competition, it was thought that high technology would be the savior of the United States' economy and employment. Many states and cities scrambled to recruit electronics and biotechnology companies, each hoping to become the next ''Silicon Valley.''

title: THE TROUBLE WITH LAWYERS
description: Professor Fried's article is a masterful example of the conservative view that lawyers are inefficent, a lot of law is unnecessary and that what we need is less law and fewer lawyers.

title: NEW CABLE FARE GETS DOUBLE EXPOSURE
description: Recent developments at two advertiser-supported services suggest that costly original programming on cable demands the wider audience that only broadcast television can provide. A four-part, seven- hour documentary, underwritten by Ted Turner and featuring Jacques- Yves Cousteau exploring the Amazon, is being marketed to TV stations throughout the country for broadcast at the same time or even earlier than it is shown on the Turner-owned ''SuperStation,'' WTBS. This ''double exposure'' is considered necessary to generate the larger advertising revenues needed to defray the $6.5 million cost of the project.

title: No Headline
description: Headliners Nice Day's Work When Lula Aaron counts her blessing from now on, she may need the aid of an accountant. Last week, the 54-year- old Queens resident won $10 million in the New York State Lottery, the largest such prize in the United States ever taken by a sole winner. Mrs. Aaron, whose five grown children have seven children of their own, described her life with her husband, Robert, as ''comfortable'' - he works two jobs to pull down $36,000 a year - and said the winnings probably wouldn't change it very much.

description: An 108-year-old man sprayed pistol shots wildly around his bedroom and killed his invalid wife of 60 years Thursday.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH LAWYERS
description: Corporate clients look to outside counsel principally to provide a broader and more diverse experience than the corporation can itself generate in most areas of law, independent judgment not likely to be available from employees climbing their way up the greasy pole of corporate success. They look to outside counsel to provide objectivity and credibility useful to resolve internal disputes and to advance positions which courts will accept as coming from independent professionals and not from corporate employees.

description: Salvadorans were urged to vote in today's presidential elections. They were told by Government officials that the elections were the most important and decisive in the country's history. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: PERSONALIZING THE BASICS
description: One of the most comfortable of woolens, worsted gets its name from the village of Worstead in Norfolk, England, where the fabric was first woven. Because it is put through the least amount of surface finishing (as opposed to a flannel, for example, which is brushed so that the weave is virtually unidentifiable), it is highly porous and unusually lightweight; it weighs an average of six to 11 ounces per square yard for most tropical weights.

title: ISLAND ADVANTAGES IN OFF SEASON
description: he French, who know how to take a vacation, also know how to keep a secret. They think the Caribbean is just as nice, if not nicer, in summer than in winter. So come Bastille Day, they begin to flock to their Antillean outposts, where they roost happily through their strictly traditional holiday month of August. A lot of the rest of us, not knowing what the French know, have tended to treat the Caribbean as if it disappeared sometime in April, like Brigadoon, to reappear only after the first frost of autumn. Isn't it too hot there in summer? Too expensive? Who needs it? We have plenty of outdoor activities closer to home.
