description: A Federal judge here has blocked an attempt by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to deport the daughter of a man described as this country's top spy in the Philippines in World War II.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE 10th anniversary of a Town of Babylon center for the elderly could also mark a temporary halt in nearly all of its programs if a new site cannot be found before the end of the month.

title: Nancy K. Poundstone to Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Bruce Poundstone of Upper Nyack, N.Y., formerly of Rye Brook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Katrina Poundstone to Bradley Neil Opdyke, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Neil Donald Opdyke of Gainesville, Fla.

title: ; THE MAGICAL MARTHA GRAHAM
description: In her article ''Martha Graham'' (Feb. 19), Anna Kisselgoff mentioned Miss Graham's love for animals.

title: Sports of The Times; From Intramurals to Final 4
description: HE'S not even a walk-on. He never even asked to try out for Virginia's basketball team. He's that rarity - a come- on. Almost a put-on.

title: Damaged Soviet Ship Set to Leave Nicaragua
description: A Soviet tanker damaged by a mine off the coast of Nicaragua is ready to start a return trip to the Soviet Union and its injured crewmen are in good condition, two Soviet newspapers reported today.

title: COLLAGES THAT GLORIFY THE ABSURD
description: IT is inspiring to watch a mind

title: No Headline
description: Karen Cure Is Married

title: Future Events
description: Hymns of Praise BY CARTER B. HORSLEY

title: Schub on Y Workshop
description: The pianist Andre-Michel Schub will be the guest at the April 2 session of the ''Conquering Stage Fright'' workshop at the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue.

title: 29 Troops Believed Dead In Korean Copter Crash
description: Eighteen American and 11 South Korean marines are believed to have been killed Friday in a crash of a United States Marine Corps helicopter during a military exercise.

title: Weapons Seller Sentenced
description: Gerald Tartaglio, 46 years old, was sentenced in Federal District Court Friday to six months in prison and four years' probation after he pleaded guilty to trafficking in automatic weapons that he said were meant for El Salvador. The Government charged that from March 4 to Aug. 16 last year Mr. Tartaglio and Suenobu Yamaguchi, 57, sold guns. Mr. Yamaguchi drew a suspended five-year sentence and was fined $1,000.

title: FAKE HEROIN THAT APPARENTLY KILLED 3 LINKED TO SINGLE SELLER
description: A single drug dealer in the Essex County area is believed to have provided the heroin substitute that apparently killed two young men and a young woman last week, a New Jersey health expert said yesterday.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: With no fanfare, ''Mr. Hobbs Takes a Vacation,'' ''Nurse Edith Cavell'' and ''Baby, It's You'' make worthy, varied film watching on cable this week.

title: Eliot's Novel
description: To the Editor:

title: MATT GRIBBLE IS PRIMED FOR A GOLD IN BUTTERFLY
description: CLEVELAND MATT GRIBBLE does not like to get up early in the morning. When the University of Miami swimming team scheduled workouts for 9 A.M., he often missed them, showed up at 10 A.M. and did the workout on his own.

title: SUFFOLK CONSIDERING LIMITS ON SMOKING
description: A LAW to limit smoking in offices, restaurants and public places is near a vote in the Suffolk County Legislature, where legislators who smoke have already cut down on lighting up during meetings.

title: No Headline
description: Times Sq. Is Dimmed In Concern Over Plan

title: THE LAND OF APHRODITE
description: SARAH CAUDWELL, who lives in Britain, is the author of ''Thus Was Adonis Murdered (Scribner's). ''The Shortest Way to Hades'' is to be published this year.

title: GENES AND BABY'S HEALTH
description: KRISTOFER ARNOLD was born on Dec. 6, 1981, almost eight weeks prematurely and with a somewhat larger than normal skull, but physicians did not see much to worry about.

title: A DISPATCH FROM THE WAR ON CANCER
description: Andrea Barnet is a contributing editor of Saturday Review. LIFE AND DEATH ON 10 WEST

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: New Pressures On Acid Rain

title: NEW ISSUES POSED FOR ENVIROMENT
description: Reports from the Environmental Protection Agency's regional offices show that while progress is being made in dealing with air and water pollution, a new set of problems, largely involving toxic substances, must now be addressed.

title: U.S.EXERCISE BEGINS IN HONDURAS
description: Government officials urged El Salvador's 2.5 million voters today to take part in the presidential election Sunday, describing it as the most important election in the country's history.

title: TWO VIEWS OF THE PEI PYRAMID DESIGNED FOR THE LOUVRE
description: Is Paris Williamsburg? Far from it. In fact, the worst thing of all that can be done to Paris is to try to preserve it just as it is, to freeze it from future change.

title: SAM JAFFE, A CHARACTER ACTOR ON STAGE AND FILM, DIES AT 93
description: Sam Jaffe, a character actor who displayed a commanding stage and screen presence over a career of six and a half decades, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 93 years old.

title: ON THE STREETS WHERE THEY LIVED
description: HERBERT MITGANG is cultural correspondent of The New York Times. By HERBERT MITGANG

title: Jane Hammerslough and Ezra Palmer Will Marry
description: Jane Hess Hammerslough, who does film public relations for Reid Rosefelt Publicity in New York, and Ezra Palmer, a freelance writer, plan to be married May 26.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: ALL GOD'S DANGERS: The Life of Nate Shaw, by Theodore Rosengarten. (Vintage, $8.95.) ''One does not read this book - one listens to it . . . Nate Shaw strides directly off the page,'' H. Jack Geiger declared in 1974 in a review that called Shaw ''a black Homer, bursting with his black Odyssey'' and able to tell it with passion and awesome intellectual power. A National Book Award winner, ''All God's Dangers'' is the autobiography, constructed by Theodore Rosengarten from extensive interviews, of ''a strong, tough, autonomous, powerful rural Southern black man'' whose life spanned nearly 90 years, ending in 1973. NEVERLIGHT, by Donald Pfarrer. (Dell/Laurel, $4.95.) Swinging back and forth between battleground and home front, ''Neverlight'' centers on Richard Vail, who chooses to return to Vietnam after being wounded and sent home to his wife in New England. ''The author's sense of place is as sharp throughout as his portrayal of (a) couple caught in a personal and national tragedy . . . his tragic sense of life and ability to charge language with philosophical feeling never waver,'' Alan Cheuse said in his review.

title: Lisa P. Harbach, Andrew G. Setos To Marry in June
description: Fay Caulkins Harbach of New York and Quogue, L.I., and William Otto Harbach of New York and Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Prosser Harbach to Andrew George Setos of New York, the son of Mrs. George Setos and the late Mr. Setos of Yonkers. A June wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: Legislators Reapportion Cuomo's Pie

title: Bowling Green Wins Hockey Title
description: Bowling Green University won the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey championship in an incredible 5-4, four-overtime contest against Minnesota-Duluth tonight in the Olympic Arena.

title: N.Y.U. TRAINS DISABLED HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS
description: Carmelo Delgado wants to be a computer technologist. Roseabel Parra says she wants to be a word processor and Arnold Contreras wants to combine journalism and computer science.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FOR YEARS, Terminal C has just sat at Newark International Airport. It was built 11 years ago, when Terminals A and B went up, but remained unfinished, waiting for crowds that never arrived. It came to symbolize dashed hopes that the airport would become a busy new gateway to the metropolitan region.

title: VOYAGING INTO 'FEN'
description: When Polonius rattles on about a species of drama called ''tragical-historical-comical- pastoral,'' the audience usually laughs. After all, there never was such a play, not even in the Jacobean period, which delighted in yoking together improbable opposites. But Caryl Churchill's ''Fen,'' though as modest and unpretentious a piece as you would care to find, stretches even Polonius's classification at its edges. Stamp its dossier ''tragical-historical-comical-pastoral-sociological-political.''

title: GUATEMALAN FAMILY REACHES REFUGE
description: With church bells resounding over the snow- covered landscape and hundreds of people looking on, 12 Benedictine monks welcomed a family from Guatemala to the sanctuary of a hilltop monastery here today.

title: Thousands Still Lack Power A Week After Midwest Storm
description: Thousands of people here remained huddled around fireplaces and gas stoves today, a week after an ice storm tore down power lines serving 235,000 homes in the Middle West.

title: MAGAZINE ANGERS PRINCETON STUDENTS
description: PRINCETON A GROUP of undergraduates at Princeton University, upset over an article in a conservative alumni magazine that makes allegations about the personal life of a female freshman, is circulating a petition asking that the magazine no longer be delivered to their dormitory rooms.

title: VOTING OBSERVERS LAND IN SALVADOR
description: A United States delegation of observers arrived here this afternoon to join nearly 300 other observers from 28 nations who will monitor Sunday's presidential election here.

title: DEALING WITH OVERSEAS JOB COMPETITION
description: LOS ANGELES THE Tandon Corporation is the nation's largest maker of data-storage and retrieval devices for personal computers, a booming business that barely existed five years ago.

title: ENTERPRISE,PUBLIC AND PRIVATE
description: Upscale Ice

title: VETO BY NEWS FORMAT
description: To the Editor:

title: FANTASY TIME
description: Fantasy Time PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: HATS A TIPTOP ACCESSORY
description: -TOP ACCESSORY Hats may not be the most necessary of accessories, but they are among the most becoming. Consequently, many leading designers showed big, broad-brimmed styles in striking colors with their spring clothes, further proof that hats are an almost universally attractive addition to a woman's wardrobe.

title: CUT DEFICITS BY USING A LOTTERY
description: What better, or less painful, way to put a dent in the Federal deficit than to run a national lottery? The revenue potential is considerable: Over a five-year period, net income could easily amount to $40 billion or $50 billion. Conceivably, it could be twice as much.

title: STATE TIGHTENING REGULATIONS FOR SCHOOL ATHLETES
description: TRENTON

title: Westchester Opinion; AFTER COUPLE'S MONTHS OF FRUSTRATION, A MIRACLE OF PREGNANCY
description: MY wife is sitting beside the fire knitting, her legs wrapped in a blanket, and I have just put down my book to watch her. She has never knitted before and until a few weeks ago never expressed interest in learning. But three months from now our first child is due and much has begun to change in our lives, particularly the frequency with which tears well up in my eyes.

title: 'GIN GAME' PROVES TO BE NO BIG DEAL
description: THE Queens Theater in the Park opened its season with Lanford Wilson's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Talley's Folly'' and has followed that with D. L. Coburn's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''The Gin Game.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cadbury Schweppes Inc., Stamford, Conn., a subsidiary of Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., an international food, beverage and confectionery company, has named James P. Schadt president and chief operating officer, succeeding Robert E. Ix, who remains chairman and chief executive officer.

title: NEW NO. 1 IN PUBLIC RELATIONS
description: Harold Burson, the soft-voiced chairman and chief executive of Burson-Marsteller, cannot resist some discreet crowing. After years of being the second-largest public relations firm after Hill & Knowlton, Burson- Marsteller recently edged into the No. 1 spot on the strength of continuing strong gains in revenues.

title: U.S. Official Comments on Vote
description: Langhorne A. Motley, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said tonight that initial reports reaching the State Department indicated that the election in El Salvador had not been seriously disrupted by violence or bureaucratic mixups.

title: WALKER AND GENERALS ROMP
description: The time had come to get Herschel Walker into the offense in a big way, and the celebrated running back responded today after four tentative games. Executing a game plan tailored to his abilities, Walker carried 27 times for 116 yards and 4 touchdowns as the Generals routed the Washington Federals, 43-6.

title: A 5TH CUP PRESENTS NEW CHALLENGES
description: T HE Islanders are tired, battered and often emotionally frazzled. Some of them, even with their Stanley Cup rings still sparkling, complain about being benched. Some moan that no matter how successful they are, it is never enough for Coach Al Arbour.

title: CONNECTICUT SPLIT ON EVE OF PRIMARY
description: Connecticut's big moment in the making of a Democratic President was 1960, when its leaders were in the vanguard of John F. Kennedy's election.

title: No Headline
description: Question Box

title: OF CHURCH AND STATE AND THE FOUNDING FATHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Marilyn Crispell Plays Solo Jazz Piano

title: Dr. Laurie Grant Marries Physician in New Rochelle
description: Dr. Laurie Grant, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Joel A. Sender, a specialist in pulmonary diseases, in New York. Rabbi Amiel Wohl and Rabbi Jacob Shankman and Cantor Helene Reps officiated at Temple Israel in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Leslie Hamerschlag Weds
description: The marriage of Leslie Hamerschlag, the daughter of Blanche Hamerschlag of New York and the late Leonard Hamerschlag, to Robert Sterk of Amsterdam took place at the Spanish Institute in New York yesterday. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony. The bridegroom, a son of Carl Sterk and Tonia van Daalen, both of Utrecht, the Netherlands, is chief pilot for CACI N.V. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: HART CAMPAIGN UNDERGOES A TOUGH DAY IN QUEENS
description: Senator Gary Hart courted Irish- Americans yesterday in Queens. But he learned that campaigning in New York is a lot more complicated than in New Hampshire and Iowa.

title: MIYAKE AND MONTANA GIVE DASH AND VARIETY TO THE SHOWS IN PARIS
description: Halfway through the two weeks of fall and winter openings, the fashions presented here were far less than incendiary. More creative energy seems to have been expended on the presentations than on the clothes, many of which seemed developed for life on another planet or at least in another time frame.

title: EDUCATION BOARD PLACES ALVARADO UNDER SUSPENSION
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, who became Chancellor of the New York City school system less than a year ago, was suspended with pay by the Board of Education yesterday and directed to answer an array of charges at a formal trial-like hearing.

title: GIBBONS, PROMISING MET CATCHER, IS HURT
description: The Mets suffered their first disabling injury of spring training today when a fractured cheekbone sidelined John Gibbons, the rookie who had been rated a good chance of opening the season as the No. 1 catcher.

title: ; FOSTER HOME CARE: QUESTIONABLE ASSUMPTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: O'Neill Theater Center Marks 20th Anniversary
description: The Eugene O'Neill Theater Center's 20th anniversary year will begin March 29 with a premiere film screening of ''Romancing the Stone'' followed by a party at the Limelight.

title: Burning Plane Crashes In Jersey, Killing Pilot
description: A 47-year-old pilot was killed yesterday when his single-engine plane burst into flames, struck power lines and crashed on a heavily-traveled road near the airport in East Hanover, N.J., the state police said.

title: GOYA SALES TARGET: NOT JUST HISPANIC
description: Supermarkets in the 1950's were reluctant to stock the canned and packaged Caribbean foods produced by Goya Foods Inc. In those days the Hispanic market was negligible, Latin food was not yet fashionable, and few people cared that Goya's beans were cholesterol- free.

title: John Thompson's Wall
description: LOS ANGELES E VER since John Thompson recruited Patrick Ewing three years ago, Georgetown has become the team some fans love to hate. The emotion is not because of Georgetown's considerable ability and discipline but because of its image of hostility and aggressiveness.

title: THE BATTLE OVER AUTO PARTS
description: Cecil Thompson, who runs a Shell service station in Mesa, Ariz., used to buy auto accessories from the Shell Oil Company to supply his highly profitable service and repair business. ''Fan belts, hoses, spark plugs,'' Mr. Thompson recalls, ''shock absorbers, radiator chemicals, polishes and waxes.''

title: HARDY MARYLANDERS COMMEMORATE A MASS BY EARLY SETTLERS
description: A few hundred hardy Marylanders gathered here today in a cold, windy rain to commemorate the arrival 350 years ago this month of 140 passengers from two little ships to found a colony they named after Henrietta Maria, wife of King Charles of England.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  Long-Running Hit
description: Engine Company 54 was founded in

title: Many in Coast Roundup Are Freed on Bail
description: More than half the 2,121 fugitives arrested in the Federal Government's 10- week roundup of suspected criminals in California have been released on bail, freed on their own recognizance or placed on probation, officials say.

title: Status Is Unclear For Miss Budd
description: Zola Budd, who unofficially posted the fastest 5,000-meter time in the world by a woman, has arrived in Britain and been given permission for ''settlement,'' officials said today.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*10.01

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: Waste Management Hires Ex-Borg Aide

title: TO INVESTIGATE A SUSPECT
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICER TESTIFIED WHILE HE FACED MENTAL TESTING
description: The Queens police officer whose 1981 murder investigation led to the arrest of an innocent man was under psychiatric observation when he testified at the man's trial, according to police records.

title: MAUNA LOA ERUPTS WITH HEAVIEST LAVA SINCE '50
description: Mauna Loa, the world's largest active volcano, erupted with its biggest lava outpouring in nearly 35 years today, but scientists said there was no immediate danger to lives or property. Hawaii, the largest island in the state, slept through the initial blast.

title: JOSEPH SCHRANK, BROADWAY WRITER
description: Joseph Schrank, who wrote for Broadway, the movies and for television for more than 40 years, and was the author of several children's books, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: SHUTTLE PARTS' WEAR REPORTED
description: The main rocket engines for the reusable space shuttles are wearing out so fast that major components may have to be completely redesigned, the space agency says.

title: DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR
description: PAUL TAYLOR brought back one of his best melodramas Saturday night with the revival of ''Nightshade,'' the niftiest of his dark pieces. The same program by the Paul Taylor Dance Company at the City Center illustrated the fantastic range of the Taylor dancers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Casco-Northern Corp. , a Portland, Me., bank holding company, said shareholders had agreed to the company's acquisition by Bank of Boston Corp. for about $55 million.

title: Arab Leader Derides Bids For Jewish Votes
description: Arab League Ambassador Clovis Maksoud has said that Americans are witnessing ''a pathetic sight'' as Democratic Presidential candidates compete for Jewish votes.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  A Young Entrepreneur And Man of Letters
description: When John Stephens read a magazine article by Harry Hoffman, president of the Waldenbooks stores, he promptly wrote Mr. Hoffman. He asked for a discount on the Webster's Third New International Dictionary in his local Waldenbooks store.

title: DANCE: PROGRAM BY RUSH
description: THEY did this step and that step and another step and a lot of other steps. The members of the Rush Dance Company did indeed rush through some animated but disjointed works by Patrice M. Regnier on Friday night.

title: DANCE: EXPERIMENTAL CHOREOGRAPHY
description: ''DANSECHANGE MONTREAL/ NEW YORK,'' a dance exchange program that opened in New York on Friday at Performance Space 122, sounded a little institutional when first announced. Experimental dance choreographers from Montreal and New York would perform in alternative theaters in each city. The program would be supported by departments in the Canadian and Quebec governments, though not by comparable American funding sources.

title: Miss Zimmerman Weds Robert Kotloff, Physician
description: Debra Beth Zimmerman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Zimmerman of Laurel Hollow, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Mark Kotloff, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon Kotloff of Wynnewood, Pa. Rabbi Daniel Fogel performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: TOOL ORDERS ROSE BY 7% IN FEBRUARY
description: Machine tool orders rose 7 percent in February from January and were more than double the level of February 1983, an industry association reported yesterday. The rise reflected a somewhat slower expansion for the industry, which has been growing through most of the last year after being severely hurt in the recession.

title: ALVARADO STORY MOVED FAST FROM START
description: It was just under a year ago, after a protracted, only-in-New-York drama complete with accidents, coincidence and luck, that Anthony John Alvarado found himself Chancellor of the largest school system in the country. And New York City seemed to find itself with a happy ending.

title: KEACH SUCCESSFUL IN 'HAMMMER' ROLE
description: The distance from Shakespeare to Mickey Spillane may seem enormous, but Stacy Keach refuses to view his passage from theater classics to television pulp as a comedown. All at once, the actor who played Hamlet, Falstaff and Peer Gynt at the New York Shakespeare Festival and Eugene O'Neill's ''Hughie'' at Britain's National Theater has become a hot television star.

title: COLLEGE TAX BREAKS REPORTED AIDING HIGHER EARNERS MOST
description: The Federal Government forgoes nearly $2 billion a year in revenue because of tax policies that help families pay for college, and a disproportionate share of these breaks go to families with incomes above the national median, the College Board reported today.

title: Flyers 4, Devils 1
description: Brian Propp scored two goals and added an assist to pace the Flyers' victory over the New Jersey Devils.

title: Sony Picks Marschalk; Borden's Drake at Venet
description: The biggest account news on this side of the country Friday was from Marschalk, which picked up the Sony Corporation business that was with Backer & Spielvogel - about $7 million worth of it.

title: NEW PAPERS APPEAR TO CLASH WITH CASE FOR BOEING IN CRASH
description: Documents have been uncovered that contain apparent conflicts with a key element of the Boeing Company's defense in a negligence suit growing out of the crash of an Air India Boeing 747 in 1978.

title: IN ALBANY, EMPLOYEES GO POLITICAL
description: May Duncan, Cleatrice Thompson, Betty Couser, Mary Burnetter and Joe Daley spend their days in the State Capitol catering to the needs of the political people, carrying the Governor up in an elevator or serving a senator a grilled-cheese sandwich.

title: OUTDOORS: ANTICIPATION HIGH AS TROUT SEASON NEARS
description: A S celebratory as the earthworms already thrusting up through lawns in the Northeast, anglers who have long wished to squirm from winter's cold embrace will be abroad next Sunday for the April 1 opening of the New York State trout season.

title: CONFERENCE EXPLORES O'NEILLS'S WORLD INFLUENCE
description: Liu Haiping, a 40-year-old scholar from China's University of Nanjing, sat in a small restaurant here on Beacon Hill the other day explaining why some Chinese intellectuals have lately been drawn toward the plays of Eugene O'Neill.

title: Kennedy to Sponsor Event to Help Hollings
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, will sponsor a fund-raising event next month to help Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina pay off an expected debt of $60,000 from his unsuccessful Presidential campaign.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Secret Is Out

title: The Poison Went Thataway
description: New York's Governor Cuomo has decided to set stricter standards than the Federal Government's to protect against EDB, the carcinogenic pesticide that's been turning up on oranges and in cake mixes. Before breathing thanks for that courageous rescue, New Yorkers might ponder whether this peril is still so grave as to merit the exertion.

title: HART CARRIES MONTANA DEMOCRATIC CAUCUSES
description: Gary Hart captured Montana's Democratic county caucuses Sunday, taking most of the state's rural areas and splitting the vote with Walter F. Mondale in several labor strongholds.

title: TRIAL OF OFFICIAL IS SET IN NEBRASKA
description: Nebraska's Attorney General, Paul L. Douglas, who was impeached by the Legislature this month, goes on trial Monday before the State Supreme Court.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 26, 1984
description: The Economy

title: OPERA: GOLDEN FLEECE
description: GOLDEN FLEECE LTD., the Composer's Chamber Theater, is a worthy, New York- based organization that has been responsible for the local premieres of many new operas. On Saturday afternoon, at the TOMI Theater, three brief new works were added to this roster.

title: ARNOLD LEHMAN WED TO MISS VOGELFANGER
description: At the Park East Synagogue in New York yesterday Nina Vogelfanger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Vogelfanger of New York, was married to Arnold Samuel Lehman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin R. Lehman, also of New York. Rabbis Arthur Schneier, Max Ticktin and Martin Zion officiated.

title: SOVIET FIGHTS FRAUD WITH CREDIT-CARD GUZZLER
description: The Soviet Union, in a tough new drive against a black market in gasoline, is testing a computerized accounting system that does not just reject credit cards, but swallows them as well, if any fraud occurs.

title: NEW RANGER GOALIE REPELS CANADIENS
description: The Rangers can't say for sure what their lineup will be next week when the Stanley Cup playoffs begin. But John Vanbiesbrouck made certain last night that he'll be in uniform.

title: MONDAY, MARCH 26, 1984 International
description: Salvadorans turned out to vote for President in large numbers, but voting for the eight candidates was hindered by shortages of ballots and ballot boxes and by widespread confusion over election rules. Officials of the Christian Democratic Party charged that there were serious problems in about one-quarter of the voting places in El Salvador, the capital, where their party is believed to be strongest. They said they might move to have the elections annulled. (Page A1, Column 6.) Guerrillas tried to foil the elections in eastern El Salvador. In the guerrilla- controlled town of Meanguera, people who rose early to vote were confronted by roadblocks and then had to wade across a river to get to a voting booth. (A1:3.)

title: LOPES OF PORTUGALWINS WORLD CROSS-COUNTRY TITLE
description: The Meadowlands Race Track was used today for strange and unnatural purposes: races were run, but by two-legged creatures; bales of hay were on the premises, but they were jumped over and not eaten, and the tote boards, those electronic devices that are the lifeblood of certain segments of our citizenry, remained dark, except for the one in the middle that held the television monitor.

title: Jackson Backers Ease View on Arkansas Result
description: Supporters of the Rev. Jesse Jackson will let the national Democratic Party decide the fate of caucus systems before challenging them in court, campaign workers said Friday.

title: A Timely Look At 'Nineteen Eighty-Four'
description: Vartan Gregorian celebrated his

title: Mrs. Thatcher's Son Takes Job Promoting Cars in U.S.
description: Mark Thatcher, the 30-year-old son of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, has taken a $65,000 job promoting British Lotus sports cars in the United States.

title: NETS TOPPLE KNICKS BY 107-94
description: With Bernard King sitting on the bench in a three-piece suit, the Nets had little trouble with the Knicks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight en route to a 107-94 victory.

title: BETSEY KING WINS
description: Betsy King, a non-winner in seven years on the L.P.G.A. tour but always among the leaders in earnings, captured her first title today when she held off Tatsuko Ohsako of Japan to win the $200,000 women's Kemper Open by three shots.

title: JACKSON'S VIRGINIA SHOWING RODE ON SURGE OF SUPPORT IN TIDEWATER
description: At the Garden of Prayer Temple Church today, Bishop L. E. Willis was preaching, the congregation was saying ''amen'' and both were remembering the day ''the dream came true.''

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp and Citicorp Person-to- Person Inc. , a subsidiary, filed for a shelf offering of up to $400 million in guaranteed subordinated capital notes.

title: The U.N. Today March 26, 1984
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: ; President Is Appointed At Jardine Unit in U.S.
description: Timothy A. Westinghouse has been named president and chief executive of Jardine Matheson (North America) Inc., which has interests in distribution, trading, petroleum, insurance and transportation in the United States.

title: Brazil Grand Prix Taken by Prost
description: Alain Prost of France, in a turbo- charged McLaren, won the season- opening Brazilian Formula One Grand Prix auto race today, averaging 111.5 miles an hour.

title: RAN AGAINST MARCOS IN '69 VOTE
description: Sergio Osmena Jr., an exiled Filipino politician and businessman, who ran against President Ferdinand E. Marcos in his campaign for re-election in 1969, died yesterday of respiratory failure at Cedars Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 67 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: Ghana Reports Defeat Of an Attempted Coup
description: Government soldiers killed eight rebels and ''executed'' three others during an attempted coup against Ghana's military Government, according to reports today from the state-run Accra radio.

title: WAKE FOREST BEATEN, 68-63
description: Once again, the Houston Cougars are going to the Final Four, in celebration of a successful season and to quiet the critics who continue to harp about past promises they did not keep. But the Cougars said they were not afraid of failure this time.

title: FROM A STREET PEDDLER, VISION OF THE CITY
description: For years, George Forss spent his days on the streets of Manhattan, peddling his photographs. His sidewalk display showed the city in all of its power and beauty: the Brooklyn Bridge and the World Trade Center sparkling in sunlight, the Avenue of the Americas in the rain, Central Park at dawn.

title: Ruling Party Is Ahead In Turkish Elections
description: First results from today's local elections throughout Turkey showed Prime Minister Turgut Ozal's Motherland Party in a commanding lead over parties challenging the legitimacy of Mr. Ozal's victory in the general election last November.

title: CUBA ACCUSED BY SALVADORAN WASHINGTON, March 25 (Reuters) - Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Christian Democratic candidate in El Salvador's presidential elections, has accused the Cuban Government of plotting to assassinate him.
description: Mr. Duarte said he had information that ''some kind of death squad organized in Cuba has just arrived to make a suicide attempt to kill me.''

title: PLAN TROUBLESOME FOR BANK REGULATOR
description: By most accounts, when Edwin J. Gray was nominated as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in March 1983, his chief assets were his close ties with President Reagan and the Administration's inner circle.

title: NEW BUILDINGS ARE BENEFITING CITY U. SCHOOLS
description: For more than a decade, the City College campus was so overcrowded that the English and mathematics departments found themselves squeezed into makeshift metal buildings, where as many as four faculty members had to share a single office.

title: FRENCH SET SAIL FROM WAR-WEARY BEIRUT
description: French troops began withdrawing from Beirut today, and representatives of the local warring factions discussed ways to keep the departure from heightening the violence here.

title: SALARY CAPS CLOUD N.B.A.'S FREE-AGENT MARKET
description: The last time Ray Williams was a free agent, after playing with the Knicks in 1980-81, he was earning $130,000 a year. Williams received an offer sheet from the Nets, joined them, and increased his salary to $500,000.

title: WHAT EXPERTS DON'T KNOW ABOUT INSANITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Futures/Options; Mocatta Metals Offers 2 Plans
description: WHILE gold has always served as a security blanket to people living in unstable places or experiencing anxiety about economic conditions, investing in the metal has always been, paradoxically, fraught with dangers of its own.

title: Iran Denies Sinkings by Iraq
description: Iran denied today that Iraq had destroyed four oil tankers and commercial ships near the Iranian oil installations at Kharg Island Saturday. A Greek Merchant Marine Ministry spokesman in Athens said the captain of a Greek tanker at Kharg Island also reported having seen no attack by Iraqi ships or planes. Iraq said today that it would directly attack the Kharg installations if Iran opened a new offensive in the Persian Gulf war.

title: USE OF SHORT HOE ON FARMS IS DEBATED IN ARIZONA
description: Since early morning, dozens of farm workers have been hunched over in a dusty field, thinning rows of lettuce at a farm in this agricultural valley 35 miles northwest of Tucson.

title: Italian Police Skeptical On Rebel Role in Theft
description: Police officials investigating a $22 million robbery from an American-owned security company in Rome said today they were skeptical of claims that the thieves were left-wing Red Brigades guerrillas.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page March 17 about the high price of cabbage misidentified Fredric T. Pfaff. He is executive vice president of the American Institute of Food Distribution in Fair Lawn, N.J.

title: Trading In Principles on Westway
description: Should New York State be proceeding with the preliminaries for Westway even though the fate of the highway project still depends on Washington's decision about whether dredging and filling the Hudson River would harm striped bass? A Federal appeals court recently ruled that it should, overturning a lower court's ban on any Westway spending before final approval.

title: Soccer Replay Set After a 0-0 Draw
description: Everton and Liverpool played a 0-0 overtime tie in the English Milk Cup soccer final today. They will replay the match Wednesday.

title: 'COMPLETE DISORDER,' POLL WATCHER SAYS
description: Salvadorans in this guerrilla-controlled town had to rise early, try to slip past guerrilla roadblocks and wade across the Torola River to reach a voting booth.

title: THYSSEN'S DIFFICULTIES WITH BUDD
description: When Thyssen A.G. paid $295 million for the Budd Company in 1978, Dieter Spethmann, Thyssen's chairman, said he had not bothered to inspect Budd's factories. Just by meeting the Budd executives, he said, ''I knew we could make the merger work.''

title: 2 Inmates Still at Large After Chicago Jailbreak
description: A murder suspect who escaped from Cook County Jail after a paramedic allegedly smuggled in two handguns was recaptured today by police, who continued their city-wide search for two inmates still at large.

title: RESEARCHERS FIND MORE CHILDREN SURVIVING CANCER
description: The survival rate of children with cancer has dramatically increased in the past 30 years, although new cases still occur at the same rate, according to the National Cancer Institute.

title: South African Rate Up
description: Barclays National Bank, South Africa's largest bank, raised its prime rate a full percentage point Friday, to a record 21 percent.

title: FOR DEMOCRATS, PRIMARY LESSONS
description: Senator Gary Hart still faces a long climb toward the Democratic Presidential nomination, but his surprisingly strong showing in the early primaries has already left an important imprint on Capitol Hill.

title: MARYLANDERS' CASE AGAINSTLINCOLN
description: To the Editor:

title: AMONG THE POOR, JACKSON BEGINS CONNECTICUT EFFORT
description: Fresh from his strong showing in the first round of Virginia's Democratic caucuses Saturday, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today campaigned in Connecticut, stopping in the morning at a public housing project and for the night at the home of ''a poor Puerto Rican family'' near New Haven.

title: No Headline
description: Dividend Meetings

title: Fali Time Wins At Santa Anita
description: Fali Time held off the closing challenge of Gate Dancer to win by a head today in the $132,700 San Felipe Handicap for 3-year-olds at Santa Anita.

title: UNTROUBLED BY WAR, BABYLON SLEEPS
description: All is quiet in Babylon.

title: JUDAH CAHN, FOUNDING RABBIOF METROPOLITAN SYNAGOGUE
description: Rabbi Judah Cahn, the founding rabbi of the Metropolitan Synagogue of New York and past president of the New York Board of Rabbis, died of complications from diabetes on Saturday at Doctors Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 71 years old and lived in New York.

title: MUSIC: NOTE IN BRIEF;
description: Duran Duran Performs 2 Shows at the Garden

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Real Treasure of 47th Street
description: Industries develop around available resources, willing labor and plentiful capital. But often there's a less tangible glue that holds them together: mutual trust.

title: TRUMAN TAKES STATE TITLE
description: Truman High School of the Bronx today completed its best season ever by defeating Sweet Home High School of Amherst in overtime, 67-65, to win the Class A New York State championship.

title: U.S. Paratroops Stage Exercise in Honduras
description: United States paratroopers today staged a mock airborne intervention in Honduras against a hypothetical invasion by Nicaragua, military sources said.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball National Invitation Tournament , semifinals, at Madison Square Garden, 6:30 P.M. In the first game, Virginia Tech plays Michigan, and then Notre Dame faces Southwestern Louisiana. (Television - MSG Cable, 6:30 and 8:30 P.M.) Boxing Gary Hinton vs.

title: The Cecil B. De Mille Of Commercials at Work
description: Like a well-oiled machine, 300 people, a dozen cars and vans, 4 oil tanker trucks and 8 computers on wheels moved, on cue, slowly down Broad Street yesterday.

title: NATIVITY RULING INSULTS JEWS
description: The United States Supreme Court's decision in the Pawtucket, R.I., cr eche case insults American Jews and all others who do not share what the Court's majority perceives as the country's dominant belief, Christianity.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: KID STUFF Over at the Humanities Institute of Brooklyn College they are starting a four-day conference today on ''Fantasy and Social Values in German and American Children's Literature,'' a topic that will, among other things, embrace the long-debated question of how those horrifying fairy-tale classics influence young minds.

title: ;  Lincoln Savings Chief Starting Third Career
description: Alton G. Marshall, after long careers in state government and as head of Rockefeller Center Inc., has begun a third career as a banker.

title: HOYA DEFENSE LIMITS DAYTON
description: Before making his final exit from what had been a dream season for him and his Dayton teammates, Roosevelt Chapman was asked to describe what it had been like to be bounced about, battered and beaten today by monstrous Georgetown, 61-49, in the West Regional final.

title: UNTIDY CAVALIERS MOVE AHEAD
description: Virginia has reached the Final Four of the 46th National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament without a perfect performance so far. Most of the time, the Cavaliers played poorly in their upsets over Syracuse, 63-55, in the East Regional semifinal, and over Indiana, 50-48, in the final.

title: ITT Sees Spanish Contracts
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that the Spanish Government had approved a plan to modernize its national telephone network that should bring orders of about $1.2 billion to the company's Spanish subsidiary.

title: CITY PLANS TO REVAMP BANK TAX
description: New York City officials have made a sweeping proposal to restructure taxes on banks in the city. Officials said they hoped the proposal would make the system more equitable.

title: AT THE WHITE HOUSE AND THE CAPITOL, FACE LIFTS
description: When workmen finish scraping away nearly two centuries of layers of paint, the world will finally know: the White House, in truth, is the Brown House.

title: IRISH SEMIFINAL FOE IS A DARK HORSE
description: They are, by one reckoning, the 54th, 55th, 56th and 57th best teams in college basketball.

title: DEATH TOLL IN BRAZILIAN FIRE IS NOW PUT AT 508
description: At least 508 people, most of them young children, died last month in an oil pipeline explosion that razed a swampland shantytown, according to a prosecutor's report published in Brazilian newspapers today.

title: Allison Seidner Is Wed To.
description: The marriage of Allison Seidner, a third-year law student at New York University, to Dr. John B. Robbins, a resident in neurological surgery at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine/Montefiore Medical Center, took place yesterday.

title: Advertising; Quality Stressed for Yachtsmen
description: THIS month marks the launch of

title: THEATER: A MAMET PLAY, GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS
description: THE only mellifluous words in David Mamet's new play are those of its title - ''Glengarry Glen Ross.'' In this scalding comedy about small-time, cutthroat real-estate salesmen, most of the language is abrasive - even by the standards of the author's ''American Buffalo.'' If the characters aren't barking out the harshest four-letter expletives, then they're speaking in the clammy jargon of a trade in which ''leads,'' ''closings'' and ''the board'' (a sales chart) are the holiest of imperatives. There's only one speech in which we hear about such intimacies as sex and loneliness - and that speech, to our shock, proves to be a prefabricated sales pitch.

title: Three Democrats to Join Debate at Columbia
description: A one-hour debate among the three main candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination will be held at Columbia University Wednesday night and will be broadcast nationally on radio and television by CBS News.

title: OLD HABITS FALL VICTIM TO CLEANUP
description: The favors are different, but like ward politicians in a big city, county supervisors in rural Mississippi have a long history of knowing how to take care of their constituents.

title: Coming Unstuck in Europe
description: Prime Minister Thatcher says she won't approve this year's European Common Market budget unless Britain gets a $1.3 billion rebate. President Mitterrand of France counters that it should have something less . . . Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald warns that not a penny of it can come from Ireland's dairy supports . . .

title: AUSTRALIAN EXCELS IN CORPORATE RAIDS
description: One day last August, Australian stock traders were astounded when an unknown company named Wigmores made a takeover bid for the country's biggest corporation, the $5 billion (Australian) Broken Hill Proprietary Ltd. Who, the brokers asked one another, is Wigmores?

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Cowboys in Sneakers

title: Atlanta Ballet Season
description: The Atlanta Ballet's first season as the five-year resident dance company of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College will take place from April 6 through 8 at the center. Featured will be the New York premieres of ''Arensky Dances,'' by company director Robert Barnett, and Peter Anastos's ''Palm Court.''

title: Article 079057 -- No Title
description: A New York couple have given $100,000 to help insure free outdoor concerts by the Goldman Band this summer in the city.

title: Busy Week Ahead for U.S. Issues
description: Activity in the credit markets will be dominated by four consecutive days of Treasury auctions starting with today's regular sale of three- and six-month bills, and followed by four- year notes, seven-year notes, and 20- year, one-month bonds.

title: Edberg Topples Wilander in Final
description: Stefan Edberg, an 18-year-old rookie pro, upset top-seeded Mats Wilander by 6-4, 6-2 today in the all-Swedish final of the $365,000 Cuore Cup tennis tournament at the Sports Palace.

title: U.S. EASING ON BROKER DEPOSITS SEEN
description: Under pressure from Congress, the Reagan Administration and the securities industry, two Federal banking agencies are moving to soften the impact of a proposed regulation that would restrict the placement of deposits by money brokers.

title: HENRY MOORES SET FOR APRIL DISPLAY
description: LITTLE more than a year ago, a Wichita, Kan., millionaire who owned more than 30 Henry Moore sculptures met the artist at his home in England. When Mr. Moore, who is now 85 years old, remarked that he visualizes his works in woods and pastures, and designs them to be exhibited outdoors, the collector, George Ablah, was seized with an idea that became an obsession.

title: SALVADORANS VOTE BUT MIXUPS SPOIL POLLING FOR MANY
description: Salvadorans surged to the polls today to cast their vote for President, but their efforts were hindered by shortages of ballots and ballot boxes and by widespread confusion over election rules.

title: UTILITIES SAY 1% OF USERS ARE STEALING POWER
description: As the price of electrical power has risen, so has the number of people stealing it, and power company officials estimate that as many as one of every hundred electric power users may also be an electric power thief. The lost revenue runs as high as 3 percent.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: ANALYSTS WORRIED BY FED PARLEY
description: Credit market participants - faced with Treasury note and bond auctions totaling $15 billion this week - are concerned over the outcome of the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee today and tomorrow. The committee is the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve.

title: MUSIC: NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Suzanne Vega Presents Her Own Folk Songs

title: BIRTH RANK: EFFECTS ON PERSONALITY
description: IT was probably no accident that

title: SOUTH KOREA CHRISTIANITY CREEPS UP ON BUDDHISM
description: Among the first sights to catch the visitor's eye are the crosses.

title: GWENDOLYN HORN IS A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Gwendolyn Horn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Horn of Beechwood, Ohio, and Stuart Prager took place yesterday. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Prager of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Daniel Schur performed the ceremony at the Academy Party Center in South Euclid, Ohio. Mrs. Prager graduated from New York University and her husband from Columbia College and New York University Law School.

title: The Democrats: A Delegate Update
description: caucus selection of 19 delegates in Montana, 37 delegates in Kansas and 25 of 68 delegates in Virginia.

title: Offer for Grand Central
description: Grand Central Inc., which operates mass merchandise retail stores in five Western states, said Saturday that it had agreed to be acquired by Fred Meyer Inc. of Portland, Ore., for $11 per share of common stock, or about $26 million.

title: OPERA: PREMIERS OF TWO WORKS BY PHILIP GLASS
description: The very notion of a critically applauded, popularly successful composer of new operas might seem to exist only in the nostalgic past. But Philip Glass is enjoying a career right now that seems unparalleled since the glory days of Puccini, 75 years ago. This past weekend saw not one but two premieres of full-length Glass operas commissioned and performed by major European opera houses, both created in conjunction with visionary director-designers. And both are meant to appear in the United States and New York later this year.

title: Marine Dead Recovered In Korean Copter Crash
description: The bodies of all 29 American and South Korean marines killed in a helicopter crash have been recovered, officials said today.

title: 60 Rebels Said to Die In Philippine Flare-Up
description: An army commander said today that about 60 rebels had died and 1,000 villagers had fled their homes in guerrilla warfare that swept the southern Philippines over the last three weeks.

title: Spring Has a Wintry Chill for Nettles
description: The captain is spending an inordinate amount of time in the training room these days. He sits on the counter reading the newspaper, takes treatment for a groin pull and avoids reporters.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Queens Youth, 18, Is Slain
description: A young Queens man was stabbed and killed early yesterday in an argument over a car, authorities said. The victim, Dennis Bryant, 18 years old, was found with a knife wound in his back at 3:15 A.M. in front of his home at 80-21 252d Street in Bellerose.

title: CELTICS BEATEN BY 76ERS
description: Julius Erving scored 5 of his 29 points in the second overtime today as the Philadelphia 76ers edged the Boston Celtics, 119-114.

title: OLD WOUNDS REOPENED BY MEDAL FOR CHAMBERS
description: In choosing Whittaker Chambers to receive, posthumously, a Medal of Freedom, the Government's highest civilian award, President Reagan has added a dash of ideology to what is usually a ceremonial occasion and a dash of fuel to a controversy three decades old. The award is to be made at the White House today.

title: ISLANDERS RALLY TO TOP SABRES
description: In the dizzy, fast, screaming milieu of a hockey game, is it possible for a team to turn it on when it must?

title: PBS OFFERS 'CORIOLANUS' TONIGHT
description: THROUGHOUT its run, now preparing to enter the seventh and final year, the BBC's mammoth project of ''The Shakespeare Plays'' has proved especially successful with the lesser- known, infrequently produced works. They don't carry as much preconceived baggage as the familiar vehicles and they are more likely to surprise and delight audiences with their indisputable treasures. This is once again the case with ''The Tragedy of Coriolanus,'' being broadcast from 8 to 10:30 tonight on Channel 13.

title: No Headline
description: Phi Slama Redeema

title: NURSE HELPED TO EXPOSE MEDICAL DEGREES FRAUD
description: Her cover name was Odette Bouchard, and her cover address was 575 Main Street, Roosevelt Island, N.Y.

title: MUSIC: MODERN WORKS
description: THE music presented by the Group for Contemporary Music in Symphony Space on Tuesday night was written during the last 10 years, but it is a measure of our peculiar era that all of it could easily have been written in earlier decades. In fact, the most successful moments of the evening were the most traditional and the least venturesome. The audience, however, was typical of the most contemporary concert - with a high percentage of composers in attendance and a low percentage of seats filled.

title: MITTERRAND SEEKS THE FUTURE IN SILICON VALLEY
description: President Francois Mitterrand began a three-day visit to California today that was expected to focus on enterprises that in the French view have pioneered a revolution in technology.

title: Pins Found in More Cookies
description: Half a dozen sewing pins have been found in Girl Scout cookie boxes in central Maine, the authorities said today.

title: JAPAN'S CORPORATE RECRUITMENT GAME
description: Japan's current crop of male college graduates is enjoying one last fling, basking on the beaches of Okinawa, cruising the highways of California or sightseeing in Europe.

title: 23,000 HOMELESS IN BURMA FIRE
description: More than 23,000 people lost their homes and about 2,700 buildings were destroyed Saturday when a vast fire raged through Mandalay, Burma's second biggest city, the Government said.

title: Market Place; Analysts See No Rally Soon
description: THERE is little reason to suspect that the

title: Rex Humbard's Mother Dies
description: Martha Belle Humbard, the mother of the television evangelist Rex Humbard and a preacher herself, has died at the age of 88. Mrs. Humbard, who continued preaching until she suffered a stroke about three years ago, died Saturday after a long illness.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Government, in its zeal to protect against possible fraud, may have devised a system too sophisticated for the average voter to understand.

title: FOSTER HOME CARE: QUESTIONABLE ASSUMPTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Relatively on National Swiss Teams
description: The last-day Swiss teams at the Spring or Fall Nationals is always a tough event in spite of the fact that some of the top players in the tournament are otherwise engaged, simultaneously fighting for a major title.

title: THE FRUSTRATION ENDS FOR BEAL
description: The white cord that had once been attached to a rim at Rupp Arena was now hanging around Dicky Beal's neck, and a light brown elastic bandage dangled from his right knee.

title: ;  Isacsson Back at Y.& R.
description: Paul Isacsson, 47-year-old former head of advertising sales of the CBS- TV network, has returned to Young & Rubicam as executive vice president and director of network programming.

title: SSC&B Will Buy Vos For Direct Marketing
description: SSC&B, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, is going to join the pack of agencies with direct marketing capability.

title: IF I FORGET THEE...
description: Four years ago, in the heat of the Republican primaries, Ronald Reagan came to New York to assure supporters of Israel of his firm conviction that (a) Jerusalem must remain an undivided city and (b) that ''the sovereignty is Israel's.''

title: MOZAMBIQUE SEIZES SOUTH AFRICA REBELS
description: The Mozambican authorities ordered armed police raids Saturday and today on the homes of activists from the African National Congress, officials of the Mozambican Government and the Congress said. Four people were reported detained and some weapons seized.

title: FORMER WIFE OF DODGE HEIR WAS STRANGLED, TESTS SHOW
description: An autopsy has revealed that Martha Devine Gerlach, the former wife of the late automobile heir Horace Dodge Jr., was strangled last week in her home.

title: Tornado Hits School; No Injuries Reported
description: A tornado that smashed into a south Alabama school ripped apart most classrooms but ''skipped over the gym'' where more than 350 juniors and seniors were dancing at a prom, officials said today.

title: Capitals Defeat Penguins
description: Mike Gartner's third-period goal gave the Washington Capitals a 4-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins today.

title: MONDALE IS CHEERED AND BOOED ON DAY IN THE CITY
description: Walter F. Mondale was applauded in a Harlem church yesterday, treated to deli food at Zabar's and alternately booed and cheered at a reception held by an Orthodox Jewish group.

title: AIR RAID DAMPENS CRITICISM IN SUDAN
description: The air raid last week on the Sudanese city of Omdurman, which the Sudan, Egypt and the United States say was carried out by Libya, has dampened criticism of President Gaafar al- Nimeiry's policies and diverted attention from a revolt in the southern part of the country, according to Sudanese and Western officials.

title: Chile Expects A Refinancing
description: Chile and its international creditor banks will sign an agreement in New York on Friday to refinance $130 million in debts, senior Chilean officials said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: State Dept. Renovation

title: THE CANDIDATES, THE TELEVISION COMMERCIALS AND THE MESSAGE
description: News Analysis

title: Dance Festival Planned At City College in April
description: Carolyn Adams, Dianne McIntyre and the Clive Thompson Dance Company will participate in ''Dance Weekend Uptown'' festival April 6 to 8 at the Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts on the campus of the City College of New York, Convent Avenue and West 133d Street.

title: Malaysia Elephants Rescued
description: The Malaysian Army has rescued 15 elephants stranded by rising waters at a new dam, the national press agency reported.

title: Students' Bank Is Reopened After Appeal to Legislature
description: A group of sixth graders have won their appeal to the Legislature to rescind an order closing a bank they started.

title: MusicNoted in Brief; Priscilla Baskerville, Ellington and Gershwin
description: When Priscilla Baskerville sang Duke Ellington's ''Solitude'' in ''Sophisticated Ladies'' and ''I Love You Porgy'' in the recent Radio City Music Hall production of ''Porgy and Bess,'' her full soaring soprano was an electrifying show-stopper. In the more intimate surroundings of Sweetwater's, Amsterdam Avenue at 68th Street, where she sang through Saturday night, she still emphasized Ellington and Gershwin, but in a more constrained manner that is in keeping with such songs as ''Do Nothing Till You Hear From Me'' and ''Someone to Watch Over Me.''

title: CIVILIAN TRIALS FOR ARGENTINE OFFICERS
description: An Argentine judge has challenged a new law under which the trials of army officers would come under the jurisdiction of military courts, and has ordered that an action against Argentina's last military president be taken up by a civilian court.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PAPER MEN. By William Golding. 191 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $13.95.

title: French Aerospace Sales
description: The French aerospace industry saw its exports plummet 46 percent in 1983 to $2.9 billion, the industry's trade group reported this weekend.

title: No Headline
description: Gotham Switched To Inner Track

title: A RESEARCH SCIENTIST IN TREATING OF CANCER
description: Dr. Frederick S. Philips, a leader in developing chemotherapy treatments for cancer, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67 years old.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Manhattan Life

title: Washington Watch; Administration Split on Tools
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Administration is split over demands of the machine tool industry for protection against imports.

title: TEN BLIND MEESE
description: The Edwin Meese affair throws light on a curious feature of the Reagan Administration. A number of its ranking officials, not only Mr. Meese, have had financial dealings of a kind that troubles the public but that evidently give them no feeling of wrongdoing. They seem insensitive - that is putting it gently - to traditional expectations of ethical behavior.

title: BALTIMORE BOOKSELLER WAS 88
description: Siegfried Weisberger, the Baltimore bookshop owner who gained national attention in 1954 when he sold his store with the words ''the age of the boob is upon us,'' died Friday after a brief illness at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 88 years old.

title: FACING ISSUES OF TIMES SQ.
description: After three years of planning, formal public debate begins this afternoon on the most ambitious plan ever offered to rebuild Times Square.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: TAKING SMALL STEPS TO LOWER TENSIONS
description: Reports last week that American and Soviet diplomats are seriously discussing the isssues that divide us are welcome indeed. But we should be wary of inflated expectations and pressures for daring initiatives. The change in Soviet leadership and American election-year politics do not in themselves create the basis for a dramatic breakthrough.

title: KOHL'S PARTY WINS IN LOCAL VOTE
description: The Christian Democrats retained their majority today in local elections in the southern state of Baden-W"urttemberg. The Green Party made striking gains, establishing itself as the state's third largest political force.

title: RATES CAST PALL ON HOUSING BOOM
description: Housing sales are booming, reaching their best levels since the late 1970's. For the country generally and for builders, manufacturers of home appliances and related industries, the upturn is heartening news.

title: Digest Editor Resigns
description: The editor in chief of Reader's Digest, Edward T. Thompson, resigned Friday because of what the company called ''fundamental differences of editorial philosophy'' with the magazine's board of directors.

title: Georgetown's Key Could Be Graham
description: As a fan, John Thompson says Kentucky is ''a great team.'' He also says that the Wildcats' coach, Joe B. Hall, ''has done a great job.''

title: Florida Coast
description: In Barnett Deal Florida Coast Banks Inc. of Pompano Beach agreed to be acquired by Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. for $27.50 a share in cash, or a total of $74.2 million, ending a six-month bidding war by several suitors. In announcing the merger, Florida Coast backed out of a March 8 agreement with the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., also at $27.50 a share, that would have become effective whenever laws were changed to allow bank ownership across state lines.

title: SUIT OVER CALIFORNIA PLANT'S 1979 TOXIC STEAM IS GOING TO TRIAL
description: Nearly five years ago, what appeared to be smoke billowed out of a plastics factory in nearby Orange, across the street from two schools and a day care center, which were evacuated for fear of a fire. The cloud was toxic steam, and scores of people were exposed.

title: DANCE: 2 ART CENTERS IN COLLABORATION
description: THE series of performances called ''Dansechange Montreal/New York'' concluded with performances Saturday and Sunday nights at Performance Space 122. It was a collaboration between that lively art center and Tangente, an equally lively art center in Montreal. The project introduced New Yorkers to several interesting Canadian choreographers, all of whom deserve applause, as do the exchange program's coordinators, Dena Davida, Barbara Scales, Barry Laine and Tim Miller.

title: Michala Petri Trio At the 92d Street Y
description: Michala Petri plays a recorder with inordinate grace and fluidity, and her Saturday night performance at the 92d Street Y, in tandem with her mother, the harpsichordist Hanne Petri, and her brother, the cellist David Petri, was in all ways a triumph. The Michala Petri Trio, as this ensemble has been christened, offered a program that ranged from the ornate Baroque fancies of Corelli, Telemann and Handel, through some recent music by Vagn Holmboe and Frans Brueggen.

title: King to Miss A Week More
description: The dislocated middle finger on his shooting hand will cause Bernard King, the Knicks' leading scorer, to miss a third consecutive game tonight when the Dallas Mavericks arrive at Madison Square Garden. Michael Saunders, the Knick trainer, said after the finger was examined yesterday that King was not likely to return until the home game next Monday night against the Chicago Bulls, following the team's trip to Indiana, Washington and Atlanta. Meanwhile, Marvin Webster was released from Lenox Hill Hospital after having been treated over the weekend for dehydration that resulted from a viral infection.

title: NOTRE DAME, MICHIGAN GAIN N.I.T. FINAL
description: Notre Dame and Michigan, noted for their bruising style and rebounding, gained the final of the 47th annual National Invitation Tournament last night at Madison Square Garden. Both teams used late surges to beat their opponents, who relied on finesse and speed.

title: Peru Rebels Said to Attack Ex-Cabinet Minister's Home
description: Guerrillas attacked the home of a former finance minister with submachine guns, but were driven away by security forces guarding the house, the police said today.

title: YOUNG ACTIVISTS AND CAPITAL'S ALLURE
description: A stroll through the Dupont Circle neighborhood suggests that reports of the death of youthful idealism may have been greatly exaggerated.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Stallions Triumph
description: Cliff Stoudt ran for one touchdown and set up another with a 47-yard pass to Joey Jones tonight as the Birmingham Stallions easily defeated the Tampa Bay Bandits, 27-9.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: March Direct Founder Joins Barry Blau

title: IN WASHINGTON, A FIRST FOR NEW YORK ON BUILDING A PLATFORM FOR DEMOCRATS
description: Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro of Queens, chairman of the Democratic Platform Committee, said today that New York City would be the site of the first of the party's six regional platform hearings.

title: Setback for Punter
description: The Supreme Court of the United States refused yesterday to review a California court's ruling that exempted the National Football League from state antitrust law. The High Court thus ended a challenge mounted by Dennis Partee , a punter who was dropped by the San Diego Chargers in 1976, after he had injured his back.

title: ACTING SCHOOLS CHANCELLOR PLANS TO REVIEW OPERATIONS
description: The Acting Chancellor of New York City's school system said today that he had ordered a sweeping review of the system's administration, including personnel structure and new programs.

title: WHEN COMMUNITY WORK BECOMES PUNISHMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: ERBAMONT N V reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results were translated at the rate of 1,612 lire equals $1 for the latest year and 1,482 lire equals $1 for the previous year.

title: VALEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Condec Offer
description: The Condec Corporation said a newly formed company controlled by members of its management had begun a cash tender offer for all of Condec's common shares outstanding at $28.25 each.

title: Dow Declines 1.89 in Slow Trading
description: Stock prices ended mainly with minor losses yesterday in slower trading, with several reported takeover candidates posting impressive gains.

title: 2 Pitchers on Spot
description: Pete Vuckovich and Rollie Fingers , Cy Young Award winners trying to make comebacks from arm miseries, face important tests with the Milwaukee Brewers this week. Vuckovich, whose torn rotator cuff allowed him to appear in only three games last year, after he was voted the American League's best pitcher the season before, has allowed 15 hits and 10 earned runs in 10 innings this spring.

title: FED BACKS 2 MERGERS IN REGIONAL BANK PACT
description: In a move that signals a go-ahead for regional banking pacts across the United States, the Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved interstate mergers involving two sets of banks in Massachusetts and Connecticut.

title: Las Vegas Hotels Face Strike Deadline Monday
description: The 26,000-member Culinary Union has set a strike deadline for next Monday and the hotel owners here say they will fight the union.

title: CURB IS PUT ON BROKER DEPOSITS
description: Bank regulators, in the face of opposition by the Treasury, the Justice Department and large segments of the financial community, acted today to restrict Federal insurance coverage of deposits placed by brokers in the nation's 18,000 federally insured banking institutions.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After tax credits of $87,000 for the latest quarter and $41,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Calendar column of the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly listed the announcement date for the formation of a Coalition for the Peaceful Uses of Space. The meeting will be held Wednesday at 9:30 A.M. in Room 2325 of the Rayburn House Office Building.

title: ELIZABETH IN JORDAN UNDER TIGHT GUARD
description: Amid heavy security, Queen Elizabeth II arrived in Jordan today on a state visit.

title: Cone Mills Plan
description: The Cone Mills Corporation said its shareholders had approved a reorganization plan under which they will receive $70 in cash for each share outstanding and the diversified textile concern will be taken private.

title: Breathalyzer Tests Upheld in Jersey
description: In a precedent-setting decision, the State Supreme Court ruled today that breath tests were ''scientifically reliable and accurate'' and may be used to secure drunken-driving convictions.

title: ABROGATING TRADE CONTRACTS
description: What seems like a technical amendment to a dry and complicated piece of legislation under consideration this week would in fact strip the President of one of the few nonmilitary options he has to respond to international crises - his power to abrogate American export contracts with countries that are responsible for terrorism, gross violations of human rights, military aggression or nuclear weapons tests.

title: YANKS SHUFFLED BY STEINBRENNER
description: One week before the season opener in Kansas City, the Yankees reversed today some of the most critical decisions they made during their winter of pennant planning. They moved Ken Griffey back to first base from center field and made Roy Smalley a player without a position.

title: No Headline
description: Crop Plan Brings Out Grain Tainted by EDB

title: MODERATE LEADING BY EARLY COUNTS IN SALVADOR VOTE
description: The moderate Christian Democrats and the rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance were leading today in returns from El Salvador's presidential election, according to Salvadoran and United States officials.

title: A.T.& T. MAY DISPLAY COMPUTER LINE TODAY
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expected to announce its long-awaited entry into the computer business at a news conference scheduled for today.

title: DESIGN PROFESSIONALS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Getting Attention
description: The top-echelon high school senior track and field athlete generally has little trouble drawing college scholarship offers. But what about the second- or third-echelon athlete? How does he or she get the attention of the college coaches?

title: ADVERTISING;
description: New Zealand Interest Added by Foote, Cone

title: Market Place; Kroger Still Has Problems
description: THE Kroger Company, through aggressive

title: Japan Steel Exports Up
description: Japan exported 2.8 million tons of steel in February, up 7.9 percent from January and up 7.5 percent from a year earlier, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today. Steel exports to the United States were 501,596 tons, up 16.8 percent from January and up 109.3 percent from a year earlier.

title: TINY MITE STANDS ON HIND LEGS AND REACHES FOR THE WIND WHEN tiny, wingless scale insects decide the time has come to move on, they deliberately stand on their hind feet, catch a breeze and take off like miniature wind surfers, microscopic observation has revealed.
description: The prevailing view has been that such minute insects are involuntarily dispersed through the environment by gusts of wind that snatch them from their perches on vegetation.

title: ARGENTINA REPAYMENT IS DOUBTED
description: Argentina's last-minute negotiations over interest payments due in five days to 330 United States banks shifted today to the seaside gambling resort here where the Inter- American Development Bank has begun its annual meeting.

title: Ratings Lowered For Hanover Units
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday reduced its ratings on nearly $2.2 billion of long-term securities of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and for $2 billion of bonds backed by by letters of credit from the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: HAMILTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After loan loss provisions of $500,000 for the quarter and $1.4 million for the 9 months and tax credits of $163,500 for the quarter and $729,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after a loan loss provision of $1,251,481 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: REAGAN'S TERRORISTS
description: Here's one clear and welcome issue between Ronald Reagan and either of his likeliest challengers: Both Walter Mondale and Gary Hart say they would put an end to Mr. Reagan's support for the ''contras,'' who are trying to overthrow the recognized Government of Nicaragua.

title: 14 LOVE POEMS BY FAULKNER TO BE PUBLISHED
description: A lengthy cycle of unpublished love poems by William Faulkner, which the author bound by hand in 1921 and presented to his future wife shortly before he abandoned poetry for the novel, will be published on May 26 by the University of Texas Press.

title: Light Quake Hits Bay Area
description: An earthquake jolted the San Francisco Bay area at 7:36 P.M. today, rattling windows but causing no damage, the authorities said. The quake was estimated at 4.25 on the Richter scale and was centered about 14 miles southeast of Berkeley, the University of California Seismographic station said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 27, 1984

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption Sunday on philanthropies' efforts to reduce the threat of nuclear war misstated McGeorge Bundy's connection with the Ford Foundation. He is a former president.

title: GIFTS TO 2 LEADERS ROSE IN FEBRUARY
description: New Federal Election Commission reports show that Senator Gary Hart's Presidential campaign received more contributions in February, when he finished second in the Iowa caucuses and won the Democratic primary in New Hampshire, than in the preceding four months.

title: THE SPLITS IN LEBANON GET FINER
description: The political situation here, already tangled, is becoming so complicated that Lebanese officials were talking today about two separate cease-fires.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: NOTEBOOKS 1960-1977. By Athol Fugard. 238 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: Shultz to Meet Canadian
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet Canada's Secretary for External Affairs, Allan J. MacEachen, in Washington next Sunday and Monday, the State Department announced today.

title: MEXICAN EX-POLICE CHIEF IS HUNTED IN MONTREAL
description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police have staked out a suburban Montreal house owned by the wife of a former chief of police of Mexico City, who faces charges in Mexico involving weapons, tax evasion and smuggling.

title: TIMES SQUARE HEARING DRAWS ARRAY OF VIEWS
description: The plan to rebuild Times Square, making its formal debut at a public hearing yesterday, received warm endorsements mixed with concerns that it would mute the liveliness of the area and cause crime and prostitution to move elsewhere.

title: MONDALE STRESSES HIS EXPERIENCE TO STUDENTS
description: Every day that he was Vice President, a man with a briefcase followed him, Walter F. Mondale told a group of college students today.

title: PROVINCETOWN-BOSTON AIRINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp. said it expects 1984 capital spending of $160 million, down from $261 million last year.

title: F Train Service To Be Adjusted
description: Subway service will be adjusted on the IND F line, beginning today and lasting through April, to permit track and structural repairs, the Transit Authority has announced.

title: BETTER PROSPECTS SEEN FOR RAISING AID TO SALVADOR
description: Some Congressional Democrats, back from observing the presidential elections Sunday in El Salvador, said today that, despite problems, the size of the voter turnout had improved the prospects in Congress for President Reagan's request for more military aid to El Salvador.

title: TINSLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25

title: German General Retires, Bitter but Satisfied
description: Gen. G"unter Kiessling retired from the West German military with full honors today, expressing satisfaction that he had been reinstated after reports were circulated that he was homosexual and thus a security risk.

title: Palestinian Wins Injunction
description: A Palestinian who completed a 15-year prison sentence in l982 for organizing a Fatah branch in Hebron obtained a temporary injunction today against his expulsion from the Gaza Strip.

title: Panthers Romp
description: Bobby Hebert passed for 444 yards, a United States Football League record, and threw for four touchdowns to lead the Michigan Panthers to a 52-34 victory tonight over the Houston Gamblers. The Panthers (5- 0) have won 11 in a row. The Gamblers fell to 3-2.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HART ENDS CONNECTICUT RACE WITH NOSTALGIC NOTE AT RALLY
description: Senator Gary Hart tonight brought his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination back to the New Haven Green where, he said, ''we got our entry into Democratic politics.''

description: FESTIVAL

title: N.V. Philips-Grundig Merger
description: The proposed merger of Europe's two largest electronics concerns, N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken and Grundig A.G., was approved today by West Germany's Federal Cartel Office.

title: THE PHONE SUPPLIER SHAKEOUT
description: It looked like an astute move in 1982 when Phone-Mate Inc., a leading supplier of telephone answering machines, decided to enter the developing market for telephones.

title: OFFICIALS UNEASY ON FED POLICY
description: Reagan Administration officials are concerned, they said today, that the Federal Reserve's senior policy-making body may be about to bring a slight new rise in interest rates.

Mississippi Valley
description: The Mississippi Valley Gas Company said it had received a $33- a-share offer from the Yazoo Investment Corporation.
