title: GYPSUM TO ACQUIRE MASONITE
description: The United States Gypsum Company and the Masonite Corporation, the country's leading producer of hardwood, announced yesterday that U.S. Gypsum would acquire Masonite for about $380 million in cash.

title: COURT CLEARS WAY FOR NEW RULE ON STRIKER CONDUCT
description: The Supreme Court, acting at the request of the National Labor Relations Board, today dismissed a pending case so that the board could apply a new policy on misconduct by striking workers.

title: PRIMARY SURPRISES ASCRIBEDTO GAP BETWEEN POLITICAL SPECIALISTS AND VOTERS
description: The unexpected results in some of the Democratic Presidential primaries, especially Senator Gary Hart's victory in New Hampshire last month, are being attributed by a number of political specialists to a gap between many voters and the professionals who shape the campaigns.

title: BTR REALTY INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Military Contracts
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a unit of the Grumman Corporation, received a $100.9 million Navy contract for work on six EA-6B aircraft, the Defense Department said. It also said that the Navy had awarded a $40.5 million contract to the Raytheon Company for torpedo launching systems and one for $30.9 million to the RCA Corporation for work on the Aegis radar combat system for ships.

title: Jesse Jackson May Enter West Virginia Primary
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson now is likely to enter West Virginia's Presidential primary on June 5, his state coordinator has said.

title: SMALL WAR BETWEEN STATES PITS NEW YORK AGAINST JERSEY
description: For New York and New Jersey, the Hudson River is more than a common border. These days it is a back-yard fence over which there has been a great deal of shouting. Neighbors and rivals, the Big Apple and what John Gunther called that ''raucous little state'' across the river are engaged in a war of words. But behind the barbs and bombast, the states are vying for some important prizes: billions of dollars in development, thousands of jobs and that illusive but all important commodity: image. The most recent focal point of the war is a $40 million grant from the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to help redevelop the waterfront in Jersey City. New York City officials are contesting the award.

title: ACTION ON PLANT IN CALIFORNIA DELAYED AGAIN BY U.S. PANEL
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today postponed a decision on whether to allow a California utility to start up the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant after nearly a decade of delays.

title: KILEY URGES HIRING MANAGERS WITHOUT CIVIL SERVICE
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority revealed plans yesterday to put the hiring of 1,250 high-level supervisors under exclusive management control.

title: Inflation Dips In the E.E.C.
description: The average annual inflation rate in the 10 nations of the European Economic Community was 7.9 percent last month, the lowest since December 1978, the Common Market statistical agency, Eurostat, said today.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DELOREAN CAN SELL OR LEASE RANCH TO PAY COUNSEL
description: John Z. DeLorean can sell or lease the 48-acre ranch he used to obtain his freedom in order to raise money for attorneys' fees, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: 11 Firefighters Hurt in 2 Incidents
description: Eleven Brooklyn firefighters were injured yesterday in a three-alarm fire affecting six buildings in the East New York area and a wall collapse in the Red Hook section, the authorities said.

title: A Caveat for Memoirs
description: With what is surely record speed, former Secretary of State Alexander Haig has published a memoir about service to a President still in office concerning diplomacy still unfinished and still deemed top secret.

title: ;  Chief of BellSouth Gets Chairman's Duties, Too
description: John L. Clendenin, president and chief executive of the BellSouth Corporation, was named yesterday to the additional post of chairman. Mr. Clendenin, 49, will succeed Wallace R. Bunn on April 1.

title: JACKSON VISITS ELDERLY COUPLE ON A CHILLY NEW HAVEN NIGHT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson stayed Sunday night with Victor and Irma Sepulveda on Dover Street. He talked about his visit with the elderly couple today as he campaigned for support in the Democratic Presidential primary Tuesday in Connecticut.

title: Senate Republicans Changing Bankruptcy Bill
description: Senate Republicans said today that they were drafting a new version of a bill that has to pass by the end of the week in order to keep the bankruptcy court system functioning.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: President Resigns At Goldhirsh Group

title: AHMED SEKOU TOURE, GUINEAN PRESIDENT, 62, DIES Conakry Guinea, March 26 (UPI) - President Ahmed Sekou Toure, who led Guinea to independence and was known as the ''Elephant'' for his strength of rule over three decades, died tonight in the United States of an apparent heart attack, Radio Guinea reported. He was 62 years old.
description: Mr. Toure died in Cleveland, Ohio, after undergoing emergency treatment at the Cleveland Clinic, the West African nation's official radio said in a brief report.

title: ARE PILOTS PROTECTED FROM CONTAMINATED FOOD?
description: Hailey and John Castle, an airline passenger becomes ill with what at first appears to be air sickness. When other passengers fall ill with similar symptoms of sweating, vomiting and stomach cramps, it is clear the airliner has been struck by food poisoning due to contaminated fish served on the in-flight dinner.

title: Japan Scales Cited by E.E.C.
description: The European Economic Community has imposed provisional antidumping duties on imports of electronic scales from Japan, the community's commission said today.

title: Reforms Signed On Aid for Jobless
description: Legislation to overhaul New Jersey's debt-plagued unemployment insurance system was signed into law today by Governor Kean.

title: Jobless Record in Spain
description: Unemployment in Spain rose to a record 19.4 percent in January, the Economics Ministry said today. A month earlier it was 19 percent, and in January 1983 it was 17.5 percent.

title: Charter Spinoff
description: The Charter Company said it had asked the Internal Revenue Service to rule on the tax consequences of the proposed spinoff of its insurance operations.

title: On Insuring Fairness for Women
description: It's time for the country to unite behind the idea that men and women should be treated as a single group in setting insurance premiums and benefits. But that worthy goal does not justify ignoring the costs of the adjustments required.

title: S.E.C. Disclosure Complaints
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today filed more than a dozen complaints in its pursuit of corporate officials who are purportedly late in disclosing their transactions in their companies' stock.

title: BARROOM RAPISTS ARE GIVEN SENTENCES OF UP TO 12 YEARS
description: The case of a rape in a neighborhood tavern that captured the nation's attention came to an end today as four young Portuguese immigrants were sentenced and sent away to prison in a heavily escorted police van.

title: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
HUSSEIN'S ANNUAL SHOW
description: It has become an annual event, a sort of Middle Eastern Ground Hog Day. Every year at about this time, King Hussein of Jordan emerges from his palace, squints at the assembled diplomats and correspondents, sees his own shadow - and then announces that he still won't talk to the Israelis. This year he outdid himself, noting that not even a freeze on Israeli settlements in the West Bank would bring him to the conference table. Quite unwittingly, he may also have decided the future of the West Bank by removing that issue from the approaching Israeli election campaign.

title: SMALLER CADILLAC MODELS ARE INTRODUCED BY G.M.
description: After months of delay caused by production problems, the General Motors Corporation today introduced the first of its new generation of smaller, front- wheel-drive luxury cars.

title: American Can
description: The American Can Company said it had terminated negotiations for the sale of its Canadian and British packaging operations to the First City Financial Corporation, a financial services company based in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: AMERICAN EMBASSY IN ISRAEL: THE RUNAWAY ISSUE
description: The Congress and the Administration are engaged in a kind of election year game with possibly dangerous implications if it is not handled with proper sensitivity.

title: CHANEL, VALENTINO ENLIVEN PARIS
description: Perhaps the French should leave the tailoring to the Italian designers and the adventurous breakthroughs in fashion to the English. And where does that leave them? With the grand old names, of course. The old established houses have helped to pull the present showings back on course.

description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $5,259,000 and an extraordinary tax credit of $3,138,000. c-Net loss including income from discontinued operations of $2,865,000. FMI Financial has changed its fiscal year-end from one ended Jan. 31 to one ended Dec. 31. Results for the latest year are for the 11 months ended Dec. 31, 1983. Year-ago results are for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1983.

title: Frances DuBose Batiste, 41, Official of Civil Service Union
description: Frances DuBose Batiste, president of the Civil Service Employees Association's Region 2, which covers New York City, died of a heart attack on March 18 at Coney Island Hospital. She was 41 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Two Anniversaries: One in Celebration . . .
description: The Queensboro Bridge was once

title: Teamster Complains About Stand on Mondale
description: Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, has said that the support of Walter F. Mondale by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations has created ''an embarrassing situation for all of labor.''

title: Article 080201 -- No Title
description: A United States-owned security company offered a $1.5 million reward today for information leading to the recovery of $22 million in cash and checks stolen over the weekend.

title: C.I.A. LINK DENIED
description: A gunman, firing five times at close range, shot and wounded the United States consul general in Strasbourg today as he left his home there.

title: GUNMAN AND 2 OFFICERS ARE WOUNDED
description: A gun battle erupted in a playground adjoining a Harlem schoolyard yesterday afternoon when a young man opened fire on three Housing Authority police officers, wounding two of them before he was shot by the officers.

title: YONKERS SCHOOL PACT
description: The prospects of an out-of-court settlement of a four-year-old Federal school desegregation lawsuit against this Westchester County city seemed more remote than ever this week after the City Council voted against financing a tentative agreement. It marked the second time in the last three months that lawyers for the Justice Department, the Yonkers Board of Education and the Yonkers branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had worked out a plan to desegregate the city's schools, only to see it collapse under political haggling.

title: LARGE DEPOSITS OF FOSSILS IN FLORIDA MAY BE AMONG RICHEST
description: WHAT is believed to be the richest deposit of early Ice Age fossils ever found in North America has been partly uncovered in a quarry near Apollo Beach, Fla. It is expected that the deposit will ultimately yield as many as 60 species.

title: IS GREAT ATOM SMASHER TOO COSTLY?
description: FOLLOWING their bold proposal to embark on the biggest and costliest project in the history of pure science - a multibillion-dollar atom smasher big enough to encircle an area the size of Rhode Island - American physicists are being asked to answer one of the toughest questions of all: Is it worth it?

title: 4 Soviet Ships Reach Cuba
description: The Soviet helicopter carrier Leningrad, the guided-missile destroyer Udaloy, a diesel submarine and a supply ship arrived in Havana today on what the Soviet Embassy caled a good- will mission. The four ships will stay until Friday.

title: Population Loss Cited in the City
description: The Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn are among the counties that have lost the most population, a three-year study indicated yesterday. Nine of the 10 fastest-growing counties are in the Sun Belt.

title: Bridge: A Player Doesn't Need To Be an Expert in Zoology
description: Those ignorant of zoology often believe that crocodiles stick to the Old World and alligators to the New World. But several visiting bridge experts were able to inspect an American crocodile at the magnificent San Antonio zoo recently.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Dallas Mavericks , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks will still be without the injured Bernard King, who scored 50 points against the Mavericks at Dallas the last time he faced them.

title: HYBRITECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: AN OLYMPIAN TASK
description: Bobby Knight didn't even stop dribbling. After a two-day timeout following Indiana's elimination from the National Collegiate Athletic Associaton tournament, he was on display yesterday as the United States Olympic basketball coach with a philosophy as blunt as he is.

title: 2 GREEK NEWS EXECUTIVES GUILTY OF LIBELING WRITER
description: A Greek court sentenced the publisher and the editor of Greece's largest newspaper today to four months in jail for libeling the author of a book that characterized them as Soviet ''agents of influence,'' a court spokesman said.

description: * Amalgamated Sugar Co. of Ogden, Utah, filed for an offering of 50,000 units each consisting of $1,000 principal amount of senior subordinated notes due 1994 and 14 common stock purchase warrants through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: THE RAPE TRIAL
description: Not many court cases foster the kind of public discussion that the just- concluded rape trial in Massachusetts has stirred. This is true, I think, not only because large segments of the trial were carried live by a national cable television network, but also because the issues in the case forced us all to grope with our notions of right and wrong in a climate where they are so often blurred.

title: Berry on a Roll
description: The basketball season ended resoundingly for Walter Berry , the former New York high school star whose eligibility problems prevented him from playing at St. John's this winter.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ; Control Data Forms Post for Caribbean
description: The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it had formed a company for the Caribbean Basin and Central America and had named Robert C. Chinn to be its president.

title: New Latin Envoy Sworn In
description: Harry W. Shlaudeman, who was executive director of the Kissinger commission on Central America, was sworn in today as special envoy to Central America. He succeeds Richard B. Stone, who resigned.

title: F.T.C.'S POLICY ON ADS CRITICIZED AS TOO WEAK
description: The Attorneys General of Vermont and Iowa said today that a new Federal Trade Commission policy about deceptive advertising would make it difficult for states to protect consumers.

title: THE QUIET COUGAR REGAINS HIS TOUCH
description: ST. LOUIS On a team of basketball break dancers, Michael Young's style is understated, which means that sometimes he is unnoticed. He is the quiet Cougar, the player who has led Houston in scoring the past two seasons, although that statistic can be easily overlooked in light of all the attention given the number of slam- dunks that Houston boasts of as if they were straight A's.

title: COUNCIL BACKS AN '85 BUDGET $65 MILLION OVER KOCH'S PLAN
description: The City Council asked Mayor Koch yesterday to increase the budget for the next fiscal year by $165 million, largely to hire 1,500 additional police officers and 400 more sanitation workers.

title: A SAMPLER OF POETRY
description: The following excerpt is from ''The World and Pierrot. A Nocturne,'' one of the cycles in Faulkner's ''Vision in Spring.'' It is strongly suggestive of ''The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock,'' written in 1911 by T. S. Eliot.

title: JEWISH BROADCASTS PRESERVED
description: THE scribes of the 20th century, the recorders of history of our days, are a far cry from the painstaking penmen of centuries past. Accounts now are told not only in print but in terms of television and radio, fleeting forms that only in recent years are being preserved in a serious, methodical way.

title: JOB WORLD OUTSIDE ACADEMIA
description: STORIES about Ph.D.'s driving taxi cabs have become a favorite cliche to dramatize the plight of unemployed academics. There probably are some cabbies with doctorates, but the implication that unemployed scholars have no better job opportunities distorts the issue.

title: 4 U. S. Jews Charged In Palestinian Attacks
description: Four American Jewish immigrants were formally charged in a district court today with carrying out attacks on Palestinians in the occupied West Bank.

title: ADVERTISING;
description: Brant Publications Buys Art in America

title: Awacs Diplomacy in Africa
description: Libya's renewed threat to the Sudan fully justifies the dispatch of two American Awacs reconnaissance planes, but not all the Sudan's problems are external. Washington's help will make a lasting difference only if Khartoum abandons the insensitive policies that invite Libya's troublemaking.

title: Midlands Stake For Shearson
description: Shearson/American Express Inc. said it had acquired 613,200, or 7 percent, of the shares outstanding of the Midlands Energy Company, an oil and gas exploration concern based in Lakewood, Colo.

Canada Refinery to End
description: Petro-Canada will dismantle its mothballed Come-by-Chance refinery in Newfoundland, it said today.

title: Home Knitting to Be Allowed
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan said today he would permit certain people to continue knitting-for-hire work in their homes for the next four months.

title: SOME VIRGIN ISLANDERS OBJECT TO A HUGE PUBLIC WORKS PLAN
description: Prominent business and civic groups here are protesting the award of approximately $100 million in public works projects to a small West German company, saying the territorial government should rescind or modify the agreement.

title: ; WHY NEW YORK WINE FOR NEW YORK SUPERMARKETS
description: T o the Editor:

title: ALBANY AGREEMENT SETS INCREASE IN AID AT PRIVATE COLLEGES
description: As part of an agreement to hold the line on tuition at the state's public universities, legislative leaders agreed today to a large increase in aid to students at private colleges in the state.

title: Fanny Farmer
description: The Amoskeag Company said it had agreed in principle to sell Fanny Farmer Candy Shops Inc. to Poulain Industries of France, a multinational food company.

title: METS' PITCHING STAFF STILL NOT SETTLED
description: With only one week left before opening day, Frank Cashen said today that he doubted the Mets would trade Mike Torrez or any other established player. But he also said the Mets did not yet know who would pitch the opening game in Cincinnati next Monday.

title: Bangor Hydro
description: Directors of the Bangor Hydro-Electric Company, owner of 2.17 percent of the financially troubled Seabrook, N.H., nuclear project, voted to join a growing effort to cancel the project's second reactor because of soaring construction costs.

title: JUDGE SETS HEARING ON BID TO REOPEN TRIAL ON FATAL JET CRASH
description: A Federal district judge yesterday set April 27 for a hearing on a plaintiffs' motion to reopen the trial in a negligence suit resulting from the 1978 crash of an Air India Boeing 747 in which all 213 people on board were killed.

title: Reduced Elk Hunt Is Ordered To Rebuild Grand Teton Herd
description: The Wyoming Game and Fish Commission has ordered a sharp reduction in the number of elk to be harvested next season in Grand Teton National Park.

title: Buffalo Bond Issue Carries Insurance
description: The City of Buffalo is selling $17 million of bonds through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. The bonds were tentatively priced to yield from 5.5 percent for the 1985 maturity, to 7.25 percent in 1989, 8.4 percent in 1994 and 9.1 percent in 1999.

title: D A B INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOVIET AND CHINA END TALKS THAT TASS SAYS WERE 'USEFUL'
description: The latest in a series of Soviet-Chinese talks that began in October 1982 ended here today, and the Soviet press agency Tass said they had been held in a ''frank and calm atmosphere'' and proved ''useful.''

title: Kodak Job Cuts
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it will reduce its work force by 820 people at the end of this month instead of the 1,250 planned in its original reduction program announced in January.

title: $200 Million Filing
description: The Greyhound Leasing and Financial Corporation has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of two issues of zero coupon notes totaling $200 million. Underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets said they planned to offer the notes, divided equally between 1994 and 1996 maturities, late next week. Greyhound Leasing also filed a shelf registration statement for $150 million of senior debt securities to be sold from time to time.

title: NOT ON TOP, JUST ON TAP
description: ''I'd even like to go to a midweek movie,'' he said.

title: DOUGHERTY BROTHERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Smith Repays U.S. in Car Use
description: Attorney General William French Smith, who is a millionaire, recently reimbursed the Government about $11,000 for his wife's use of a Government car, the White House said today.

title: SYSTEMS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MUSIC COPYRIGHT CASE TAKEN BY JUSTICES
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to settle a copyright question of substantial importance to the music industry.

title: '85 CADILLAC FACES GAS GUZZLER LABEL
description: The 1985 Cadillac Fleetwood Brougham model may be the first American automobile to be sold to the public that would be labeled a ''gas guzzler'' by the Federal Government.

title: G.M.-Toyota Deal Gains
description: The Federal Trade Commission staff has recommended that the agency grant final approval to the proposed joint car-making venture between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation, an F.T.C. source said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Marines Seeking Help

title: VLI CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-The company had no sales in 1982.

title: Conwood in Talks Over Acquisition
description: The Conwood Corporation announced yesterday that it was holding discussions on its possible acquisition for $33.50 a share by the Gulf Broadcast Company. Conwood has about 11,145,000 shares outstanding, which would put the value of such an offer at some $373 million.

title: Gilbert Finds Room On a Famous Line
description: It is known simply as the Trottier- Bossy line, as if it had only a center and a right wing.

title: T.V. IS KEEPING AN 'EYE' ON DANCE WORLD
description: Merce Cunningham wondered why cameras can't be wireless, since dancers are. Johanna Boyce and John Bernd, young modern-dance choreographers, and Richard Williams and Matthew Caban, New York break dancers, discussed dance as a reflection of gender, sexual identification and urban violence. The program it all happened on was ''Eye on Dance,'' which has just celebrated its third anniversary.

title: JOHN K. EMMERSON, U.S. DIPLOMAT,76
description: John Kenneth Emmerson, a retired Foreign Service officer and specialist on Japan and Northeast Asia, died Saturday at Stanford University Hospital after a stroke. He was 76 years old and lived in Los Altos Hills, Calif.

title: Louisiana Legislature Raises Varied Taxes
description: Louisiana Legislators last night ended a special session in which they enacted a tax increase projected to yield $727 million.

title: Associated Hosts, K Mart End Talks
description: Negotiations for the acquisition of Associated Hosts Inc. by the K Mart Corporation have been called off, the companies said.

title: Prices Rise in Denmark
description: Denmark's consumer prices rose 1.1 percent during February, the Government said today, and were up 6.3 percent from a year earlier.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''My father

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: The year-ago figures conform to change in fiscal year to the last Sunday in January from Sept. 30.

title: Entertainment Events Music
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Mozart's ''Entfuehrung aus dem Serail,'' 8. NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC, Leonard Bernstein, conductor, Avery Fisher Hall, 8. PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA, Erich Leinsdorf, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8. VIKTORIA MULLOVA, violinist, 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, 8.

title: A VICTORY IS SEEN FOR TURKS' LEADER
description: Turkey's civilian Prime Minister appears to have won a plurality in municipal elections Sunday, a development that is widely seen as a vote of confidence in his Government.

title: 'AUTOEROTIC DEATH' OF YOUTHS CAUSES WIDENING CONCERN
description: FORENSIC and psychiatric scientists are becoming increasingly concerned about the use by teen-age boys and others of an extremely dangerous sexual practice in which self-induced erotic pleasure is enhanced by near asphyxiation, usually induced by a noose around the neck.

title: SELIGMAN & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GURNEY PLAY DELVES INTO PAST
description: SEATED at a table, the three actors in A. R. Gurney Jr.'s new comedy, ''The Golden Age,'' looked up from scripts open before them. Irene Worth beamed at Jeff Daniels, who regarded Stockard Channing and exclaimed, ''You

title: FOR ISRAEL, IT'S A DAY TO MUSE ON TIES WITH EGYPT
description: Today was the fifth anniversary of the signing of the peace treaty between Israel and Egypt, but there were no celebrations.

title: L.I. Doctor to Pay $750,000 to Girl
description: A neurologist has been ordered to pay $750,000 in damages to a 10-year-old brain-damaged girl despite testimony from the girl's mother that she tried to suffocate her three days before she was taken to the hospital in 1975, court records showed today.

title: CONSTITUTIONAL MANDATE ON JUDICIARY BUDGETS
description: To the Editor:

title: Official Distinctions
description: Robert Esnard, the former Commissioner of Buildings, is now just one of three Deputy Mayors. So when he was sworn into office yesterday at City Hall, he made a point of playing up his distinctions.

title: MORE TEMPTATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW STUDY AFFIRMS LINK IN CANCER AND DIET
description: FREQUENT consumption of fruits and vegetables seems to protect against developing cancers of the mouth and throat, according to a new study among 632 women in North Carolina.

title: Search by UAL's GAB Narrowed to 3 Agencies
description: GAB Business Services, a subsidiary of UAL Inc., is expected to announce its new agency today, having last week narrowed its search for its $2 million account to three shops: Doremus & Company, which has served GAB for 14 years; Epstein, Raboy Advertising, and Marsteller.

title: Judge Clears Black Engineer
description: A judge dropped the charges today against Lenell Geter, a black engineer who had spent more than 16 months in prison for a 1982 robbery. Prosecutors announced last week they would not pursue a second trial for Mr. Geter. His attorney said today that a suit alleging that Mr. Geter's rights had been violated was still being considered.

title: ;  Cable TV Campaigns
description: The Council for Cable Information has announced that its board has approved the advertising proposal of its agency, McCann-Erickson, and that the $6 million national effort should begin in January. Its purpose is to promote cable television with consumers. Meanwhile, a campaign to promote it with advertisers, sponsored by the Cable Television Advertising Bureau and created by LPG/ Pon, is under way.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There were some problems admittedly, but the consensus was that it was a very, very impressive event.'' - Senator William V. Roth, Republican of Delaware, on El Salvador's election. (A6:6.)

title: FRENCH FARMERS SET UP BLOCKADES IN PROTEST
description: Farmers blocked roads across France today with tractors, burning tires and straw, demanding higher prices for their produce and protesting cuts in milk production.

title: HALF OF DEMOCRATS IN POLL ASSERT CHOICE FOR NOMINEE HAS SHIFTED
description: In a year of fragile and shifting political allegiances, almost half the nation's Democrats have changed their choice for their party's Presidential nomination in the last month, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: ;  Pay 'n Save's Choice For Auto Supply Unit
description: Howard E. Jones has been named president of Schuck's Auto Supply, a Northwest retail chain recently acquired by the Pay 'n Save Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: Mauna Loa Lava Flow Heads Toward Prison

title: ;  Accounts
description: * United States Playing Card Company, Cincinnati, to Sive Associates, a Young & Rubicam company.

title: IMPLANT BRINGS SOUND TO DEAF AND SPURS DEBATE OVER ITS USE
description: WHEN the doctor addressed him by name, the patient quickly turned his head. Everyone was overjoyed, because the man had been totally deaf for more than a year. Now he had been brought back into the world of sound at least sufficiently to respond to the human voice, although he did not quite recognize the sound as ''Charles.''

title: COLORFUL GRAPHICS AREN'T FOR EVERYBODY
description: NOT only is it fashionable to have a personal computer these days, but the electronic industry is every bit as trendy as the haute couture. This year's spring showing appears to focus on colorful graphics.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ; INTEREST RATES EDGE DOWN
description: On the eve of this week's major Treasury financings, interest rates fell slightly for short- and long-term issues.

title: ASKING THE REAL QUESTIONS
description: ''CBS News Sunday Morning'' comes into our living rooms at 9 o'clock on little cat's feet. It is primarily devoted to news features. But, though it is generally a quiet, leisurely 90 minutes, befitting the godly day and the ungodly hour, there is often a little claw on the segments that can scratch our sensibilities, if not our complacency.

title: Libya Threatens the British Over Deportation of Libyans
description: Libya has threatened to retaliate against British companies for what it calls intimidation of Libyan nationals, a spokesman for the Libyan Embassy said today.

title: WEIN'S JAZZ FESTIVAL LIST GROWING
description: An international series of jazz festivals, including one in the United States, will be produced this summer by George T. Wein, who originated the Newport Jazz Festival, which was shifted to New York and is now called the New York Kool Jazz Festival.

title: Rider Hurt in Fall
description: Sharon Gassert , a 26-year-old apprentice rider at Aqueduct, broke her right hip and five ribs yesterday when she fell off her mount, Lake Luzerne, midway through the seventh race. Miss Gassert was taken to Long Island Jewish Hospital, where her condition was listed as guarded.

title: Chile Imposes Curfew As Rallies Draw Near
description: The Government today decreed two nights of curfew in the capital on the eve of scheduled protests against military rule.

title: Man Is Charged In Stepson's Death
description: A Bronx man was charged with second-degree murder yesterday in the death of his 18-month-old stepson, the authorities said.

title: HARTE-HANKS OBTAINS TRADING HALT
description: Trading in common shares of Harte-Hanks Communications, a Texas-based media company, was halted yesterday at the company's request pending an announcement to be made before the start of business tomorrow.

title: U.N. TEAM SAYS CHEMICAL ARMS WERE USED IN IRAN
description: A team of United Nations specialists who visited Iran reported today that there was substantial evidence that ''chemical weapons, in the form of aerial bombs'' had been used in the areas they inspected.

title: NEW LIFE AT AN OLD GOLD MINE
description: For the better part of a century, the 90 miles of tunnels and shafts that honeycomb a gold-laced mountain near this one- time boom town were a prospector's paradise.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Comings and Goings

title: STUDY SAYS PLAN TO REDUCE NUCLEAR WEAPONS MAY SAVE $30 BILLION
description: The Reagan Administration's proposal for reducing strategic nuclear weapons by retiring more old warheads than it replaces could save the Government nearly $30 billion through the end of the century, according to a study released today by the Congressional Budget Office.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WHY NEW YORK WINE FOR NEW YORK SUPERMARKETS
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Business; Fighting Fraud In Credit Cards
description: Credit card fraud has grown significantly, and banks all over the United States have been taking steps to reduce it. One of the leaders in this effort is the Bank of New York. Last November it became the first bank in New York City to make available the new Mastercards with built-in safety features. The bank also issues Visa cards.

title: TRANSPLANTED UNION TRIES TO SURVIVE
description: For years, the headquarters of the United Furniture Workers of America was in an old red sandstone building in lower Manhattan. Today it is in a modern, one-story red brick building in an industrial park in a Nashville suburb.

title: Bangladesh Frees 215 And Ends Ban on Politics
description: The military Government today marked the 13th anniversary of Bangladesh's independence from Pakistan by lifting a ban on political activity and freeing 215 political detainees, including three former Cabinet ministers.

title: TUESDAY, MARCH 27, 1984 International
description: The moderate Christian Democrats and the rightist Nationalist Republican Alliance were leading in returns from El Salvador's presidential election. But Salvadoran and United States officials said a runoff election would probably be necessary since neither Jose Napoleon Duarte nor Roberto d'Aubuisson appeared likely to win more than 50 percent of the votes. (Page A1, Column 6.) The size of the voter turnout in El Salvador impressed some Congressional Democrats who observed the presidential election. The United States Embassy estimated that 1.2 million Salvadorans cast ballots. As a result, the legislators said, Congress will be more likely to approve President Reagan's request for more military aid to El Salvador. (A1:5.)

title: ADULT ILLITERACY CITED AS PROBLEM
description: The State Board of Regents has largely failed in its responsibilities to the more than two million functionally illiterate adults in New York, according to a report released yesterday by the State Senate Committee on Investigations.

title: Boca Raton Mayor Backs Week of No Alcohol
description: Bartenders are being asked to cooperate this week in a campaign by the Mayor and a hospital to put this town on the wagon.

title: 'OUR JOB IS TO BUILD'
description: To the Editor:

title: . . . And One in Solemnity
description: The building is part of New York

title: POE & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,400,000 for the quarter and $2,700,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $1,700,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $1,256,000 from discontinued operations. The company noted that revenue has been restated from previously reported revenue to reflect a foreign subsidiary on an unconsolidated basis.

title: ALVARADO, BREAKING SILENCE, CALLS CITY'S TREATMENT 'GROSSLY UNFAIR'
description: For the first time in almost a week, Anthony J. Alvarado spoke out yesterday on the allegations of unethical conduct that led to his suspension as Schools Chancellor. He complained about ''grossly unfair'' treatment and the absence of due process.

title: RUTH PATT SILVERMAN
description: Ruth Patt Silverman, a longtime leader in Jewish and community affairs in Yonkers, died of a heart attack last Friday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers. She was 71 years old and had been a resident of Yonkers all her life.

title: Sun Spending
description: The Sun Company said it plans to increase its 1984 capital budget by more than $500 million, to $1.8 billion, from its 1983 budget. Sun's worldwide crude oil and condensate reserves increased to 711 million barrels at the end of 1983, up five million barrels from 1982, the company said in its annual report.

title: Advertising; Buick Campaigns On Pricing
description: -based Shiffman/

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 17
PRIMARY IS TODAY
description: Democratic voters in Connecticut will cast ballots in the state's Presidential primary today with party leaders divided between Gary Hart, who has won caucuses or primaries in five New England states, and Walter F. Mondale, who comes into Connecticut fresh from an apparent victory in the Virginia delegate count.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Stouffer's Is Sued By Waiter in Fire
description: Luis Marin, the coffee waiter who was freed after being convicted of setting the 1980 fire at Stouffer's Inn of Westchester, is suing the hotel and its former manager, Eric Ewoldt, for withholding information about the possible origin of the blaze to avoid ''culpability.''

title: Sales of Homes Increase 22.7%
description: The National Association of Realtors said today that 200,000 existing homes were sold in February, up 22.7 percent from the same period a year ago and 12.4 percent more than in January.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BULLETPROOF VEST SPURS LEGISLATION
description: Criminals convicted of wearing bulletproof vests when they commit violent crimes would be subject to additional prison sentences under legislation given final approval by the Assembly today.

title: COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $329,000 for the quarter and $604,000 for the 6 months. Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective April 29.

title: 'TERRIBLE JOE MORAN' STARRING JAMES CAGNEY
description: WATCHING ''Terrible Joe Moran,'' on CBS at 9 tonight, can be an unsettling experience. The star, the very reason for the production being done at all, is James Cagney, making his 64th movie and his first for television. At once the ultimate tough guy (''Angels With Dirty Faces'') and spunkiest entertainer (''Yankee Doodle Dandy''), Mr. Cagney has become a beloved national institution. Unfortunately, as is evident from scattered interviews, his health, at the age of 84, is also precarious.

title: LATIN VOTE: MAKING DO
description: What both Salvadoran officials and the Reagan Administration wanted from the voting here Sunday was an election without major fraud or mix-up, one that would lead to a Government with an aura of legitimacy. For the Reagan Administration, officials made it clear that it was important to demonstrate to Congress and the world that the Government the United States is supporting here is the same one that the people of El Salvador are supporting and is therefore worthy of continued help.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bundy Corp., Warren, Mich., a maker of steel tubing and engineered plastic, has named Donald J. Meador to head the company's newly formed Performance Plastics Group.

title: Getting Stronger
description: Coach Tom McVie was proud of his work with the New Jersey Devils yesterday.

title: German Gasoline Rules
description: West German auto makers and oil companies have agreed on standards that may bring unleaded gasoline in 1986, Interior Minister Friedrich Zimmermann said today. West Germany is the first European country to follow American antipollution rules.

title: Andrew Cuomo's Job Hunt
description: Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son

title: STUDY OF CANADA COMES TO FORE IN U.S.
description: THE shift of power and world interests over the last few decades has resulted in an expansion of course offerings in colleges and universities in such areas as Russian, Far Eastern, African and Latin American studies. Now, say those in the teaching field, Canadian studies are coming to the fore with the realization in this country of the economic, political and cultural importance of the nation along its 5,000-mile northern border.

title: ANOTHER GANDHI SEEMS TO TAKE A LIKING TO POWER
description: On the day before Mohandas K. Gandhi was assassinated in 1948, so the story goes, three women from Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's family dropped in for a friendly visit. One was Nehru's daughter, Indira. While the women and the Mahatma chatted, Indira's 3-year- old son, Rajiv, played with the great man's feet, decorating his big toe with a garland of flowers.

title: CELEBRITY FLIES NORTH VIA CARGO CLASS
description: Capt. Richard Peterson was having trouble understanding the relative value of speeding objects.

title: SIM-KAR LIGHTING FIXTURE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
State Aims to Bar Tax On Benefits for Elderly
description: Unlike the Federal Government, New York State is not planning to tax the Social Security benefits of its more affluent residents, legislative aides say.

title: CONCERT: 17TH CENTURY ANDREA VON RAMM, the early music singer, joined a lutenist, Hopkinson Smith, at the Metropolitan Museum Friday night in vocal and instrumental music written near the turn of the 17th century. The evening included two Monteverdis - Claudio and his son Francesco - Kapsberger, Piccinini and Sigismondo d'India; and in the songs and, indirectly, even in the purely instrumental pieces, one felt the power and the flow of the spoken word.
description: It is the lamenting, amorous texts of these songs, in other words, that principally guide their progress, while the music takes care always to bend to the wishes of the poet. Mr. Smith's playing of Kapsberger and Piccinini echoed this great freedom of meter and phrase.

title: EUROPE'S COMMON CURRENCY
description: As bitter as the wrangling has become within Europe's Common Market, it has not stopped the organization's European Currency Unit, the cocktail of European currencies it created just five years ago, from becoming the success of the international financial marketplace.

title: GENIAL ENVOY FROM VATICAN: PIO LAGHI
description: Archbishop Pio Laghi was named yesterday by Pope John Paul II to be the Vatican's Ambassador to the United States. He has become known as an artful church diplomat in the 32 years he has served as a papal representative abroad. Formal diplomatic ties between the United States and the Vatican were restored on Jan. 10 after more than a century of unofficial relations. President Reagan's appointment of William A. Wilson as the United States Ambassador to the Holy See was confirmed and Mr. Wilson was sworn in on March 9.

title: BORA LASKIN, 71, CHIEF JUSTICE OF CANADA'S SUPREME COURT
description: Bora Laskin, Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Canada, died today in an Ottawa hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO EASE REVIEW OF DISABILITY BENEFITS
description: Prompted by the cutoff of disability benefits for thousands of people, the House, vote of 410 to 1, has approved a bill designed to ease the review process and assure payment of benefits while a case is in appeal.

title: No Headline
description: Novelist Plans Appeal In Suit Against Times

title: Game With All-Star Guests
description: On Monday night, 50 of New York City's best high school athletes gathered in Columbia University's Levien Gym for an all-star basketball game. Although the sellout crowd was dotted with college scouts and coaches, it was the 30 or so people sitting along the baselines in specially reserved seats - wheelchairs - who were the star guests.

title: ZUBIN MEHTA OUT FOR SEASON
description: ZUBIN MEHTA underwent surgery yesterday morning to correct a severe chronic inflammation of the muscles in his right elbow and will be unable to conduct his final six weeks of subscription programs with the New York Philharmonic this season.

title: THEY NEVER KEPT A PAIR OF GLOVES ON HIM
description: EVERYBODY'S good at something. I lose gloves. I don't mean to. In years past I have had gloves I liked - a baseball glove, for instance, with which I snagged a line drive off my shoe top and which was softer than a diaper. I had a pair of handball gloves that protected me reasonably well; the few black-and-blue marks I received were treated as war wounds and I was proud of them. There were rabbit-lined gloves for winter wear, pigskin gloves for driving, wool gloves with a leather shell that the Government gave me for spending three months without women and trees and fresh vegetables.

title: Dissident Holder Controls Displays
description: Information Displays Inc. said it had settled its lawsuit with Leonard Levy, a dissident shareholder.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: No-Frills Passover

title: Duriel Harris Traded
description: The Cleveland Browns, who have long searched for a legitimate deep threat, appeared to find one yesterday when they acquired the wide receiver Duriel Harris from the Miami Dolphins for a 1985 draft choice.

title: METS ALERT TORREZ TO PITCH IN OPENER
description: In a training camp smitten with job jitters, one old pitcher and one young pitcher may have won jobs with the Mets today.

title: ELECTRONIC OFFICE CONJURING WONDERS, LONELINESS AND TEDIUM
description: Rebecca Alford arrives each weekday at 7 A.M. for her job processing health claims at a life insurance company in Syracuse.For the next nine hours, except for breaks and lunch, her day is dominated by a computer.

title: Miss Budd's Status
description: Although Zola Budd, the 17-year-old South African track star, has applied for British citizenship, the move may not qualify her to compete for Britain in the Olympics this summer. The Olympic Charter imposes a three- year waiting period before a naturalized citizen can compete for an adopted country, according to an official of the International Olympic Committee, who noted that the waiting period could be reduced or eliminated only by agreement between the international committee and its national affiliate.

title: CARROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Share earnings for the latest periods reflect the issuance of 1.5 million shares of common stock in January.

title: Record $1,185,800 Paid For a Balthus Painting
description: Balthus's 1957 ''Stepping out of the Bath'' brought an auction record price of $1,185,800 yesterday at Sotheby's in London when it was sold to an unidentified collector bidding over the telephone.

title: CAMPAIGNING UPSTATE, HART ATTACKS REAGAN ON DEFICITS
description: Senator Gary Hart traveled to this small upstate community today and declared that President Reagan was vulnerable on two issues, arms control and the deficit.

title: Accounts
description: * WLTW-FM, New York, to Robbins & Ries Advertising.

title: SEABROOK UNIT 2 MAY BE HALTED
description: The lead participant in the Seabrook nuclear power project in New Hampshire bowed to intense pressure from the other owners yesterday and said it would agree, under certain conditions, to cancel the second Seabrook reactor.

title: Legislators Seek Curb On Westway Outlays
description: Legislative leaders told Governor Cuomo tonight that they planned to limit sharply spending on the Westway highway project next year.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: PARALLEL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
BUSINESS PEOPLE ; The New Yorker Elects a President
description: The New Yorker Magazine Inc. said that J. Kennard Bosee, a longtime company executive, was elected president yesterday at a board meeting after the annual shareholders meeting.

title: CHICAGO'S HISPANIC PARENTS PROTEST 70% DROPOUT RATE
description: The figure seems high, but Hispanic parents and community leaders insist it is accurate: More than 70 percent of the Hispanic children in the Chicago public school system never graduate.

title: Raid on Pol Pot Rebels By Vietnamese Reported
description: Vietnamese tanks and infantry advanced on rebel positions in northern Cambodia today, forcing thousands of refugees to seek shelter in Thailand, Thai military officials said.

title: RISE IN STATE SCHOOL AID TO SET RECORD
description: The Legislature's leaders announced a formal agreement today on the largest increase in aid to education in the state's history.

title: FROM LATVIA, FOODS OF HEARTY CONTRAST
description: POTATOES,

title: BALLET: THE NEW YORK DEBUT OF PACIFIC NORTHWEST
description: THE Pacific Northwest Ballet from Seattle made its New York debut Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The company, which will present a second program in a run that ends on Sunday afternoon, found itself in a house filled with well wishers.

title: HART PLAN WOULD SUPPORT ALLIES IN EVENT OF MIDEAST OIL WAR
description: Senator Gary Hart said in an interview released today that if war broke out over Middle East oil supplies the countries that needed the oil, Japan and those in Europe, should bear ''the brunt of the direct land combat.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: IN THE LAND OF NYX. Night and Its Inhabitants. By John Bowers. 180 pages. Anchor Press/Doubleday. $13.95. NYX, according to John Bowers, was the goddess of night of the Greeks. She had been born, together with Erebus (Darkness), out of Chaos. After bearing a couple of innocuous children with Erebus, she independently produced a large and generally unpleasant brood that included Moros (Doom), Thanatos (Death), Hypnos (Sleep), the Fates and Nemesis.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Farmer Out, Hazzard In
description: Larry Farmer, who only last week agreed to a two-year extension to coach the U.C.L.A. basketball team through the 1986- 87 season, suddenly submitted his resignation today. Walt Hazzard was named to replace him, the school announced.

title: HIS TALLY IS 54.9%
description: Senator Gary Hart scored a decisive victory last night over Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson in Connecticut's Democratic Presidential primary, completing a sweep of primaries and caucuses in the six New England states.

title: Iraq Says Its Jets Claimed Two 'Naval Targets'
description: The Iraqi military announced today that its Super-Etendard planes attacked and destroyed two naval targets southwest of the Iranian oil terminal of Kharg Island.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: GOING to the dentist is rarely an experience people relish, but for some 50 million Americans it is akin to a nightmare.

title: Market Place; The Capital Spending Rise
description: WHILE many sectors of the stock market face an uncertain future, a developing boom in capital spending means that selected suppliers of new plant and equipment stand to enjoy increased sales and profits. ''This is the time, fundamentally, to focus on capital spending,'' the First Boston Corporation said recently.

title: Diplomat Leaves Hospital
description: Robert Onan Homme, the United States consul general who escaped an assassination attempt on Monday with only slight wounds, left the hospital today and returned to his Strasbourg home, the police said. He was grazed on the face, neck and chest by three of five bullets fired into his car by a gunman.

title: Brink's Defendant ToGetMentalTest
description: The judge in the Brink's murder and robbery trial today ordered a full psychological evaluation of Samuel Brown, one of the defendants, to determine if he is an ''incapacitated person.''

title: U.S. YOUTHS SEE NO EDUCATION CRISIS
description: Educators may be worried about the quality of teaching in American schools, but students in today's secondary schools give their schools a solid B.

title: AHMED SEKOU TOURE, A RADICAL HERO
description: To Ahmed Sekou Toure, the President of Guinea, who died Monday in a Cleveland hospital, it was better for his western African country to live in poverty than to accept what he denounced as ''riches in slavery'' as part of the French Community.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline last Friday on a dispatch from Stanford, Calif., about plagiarism allegations gave an incorrect title for Kenneth Melmon, who is under investigation by a university ethics committee and two publishing concerns. As correctly identified in the article, Professor Melmon is chairman of Stanford Medical School's department of medicine, not the school's dean.

title: NASSER'S SUCCESS IN PROMOTING ARAB GOALS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;  Souvenirs From the Statue
description: Any day now, workmen will begin

title: Phillies And Cubs In Trade
description: The Philadelphia Phillies acquired the right-handed relief pitcher Bill Campbell and the catcher Mike Diaz from the Chicago Cubs today in a trade for the outfielders Gary Matthews and Bob Dernier and the relief pitcher Porfi Altamirano.

title: INFIELD CHATTER: IDLE AND OTHERWISE
description: Baseball is, by nature, a gabby sport with plenty of time for the exchanging of pleasantries, recollections and fish stories. Between games, before, during and after, chatter abounds in the clubhouse and dugout, around the batting cage and in the bullpen.

title: HERITAGE GROUP INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Feb 18
DMG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After income from discontinued operations including net gain on disposition in 1984 of $940,000, or 14 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $1,058,000, or 16 cents a share, for the year-earlier quarter. The results for the year-earlier quarter have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: CONCERT: IVAN MORAVEC
description: THE pianist Ivan Moravec supplied most of the interest to Musica Aeterna's Sunday afternoon concert in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Moravec, in tandem with the Musica Aeterna orchestra under the direction of Frederic Waldman, offered clean, deliberate and extroverted performances of two familiar piano concertos.

title: Virginia Delegate Race Is Still Seesawing
description: Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson remained in a seesaw battle today over who would have the larger number of Virginia Democratic delegates.

title: Reagan Poll Popularity Found Slightly Improved
description: Twice as many registered voters have a favorable opinion of President Reagan as have an unfavorable view, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. The ratio of 58 percent favorable to 29 percent unfavorable represented a slight improvement for Mr. Reagan over February, when 54 percent had a favorable view and 31 percent an unfavorable opinion.

title: Gas Fumes Fell 9
description: A firefighter and eight residents of a small apartment building in the East Village were overcome by carbon monoxide yesterday when the flue of a gas furnace became blocked, Fire Department officials said.

title: STATESMAN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After investment gains of $742,291 for the quarter and $834,545 for the year. c-After investment losses of $57,019 for the quarter and $2,231 for the year. The latest year and quarter nets include nonrecurring gains of $1.2 million and $700,000, respectively. Both year-ago periods include a $1.3 million nonrecurring gain.

title: POLISH BISHOP VOWS PARTIAL FAST IN CRUCIFIX BATTLE
description: The Roman Catholic Bishop of this central region of Poland announced today that he would restrict himself to bread and water until the authorities allowed crucifixes to be displayed again in classrooms of a state-run agricultural school.

title: 15 Afghan Communists Are Reported Slain
description: At least 15 Afghan Communist Party officials were slain in the last 10 days as rebels conducted a series of assassinations in Kabul, Western diplomats here said today.

title: LATE RALLY BY NETS FALLS SHORT
description: Cliff Robinson, who hit only 4 of his first 14 shots from the field, sank an 18-footer for the go-ahead basket with 26 seconds left tonight to spark the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 106-103 victory over the New Jersey Nets.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about young activists incorrectly identified the editor of People & Taxes, a monthly publication of Public Citizen, which is affiliated with Ralph Nader. The editor is Tyler Bridges.

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $146,000 for the quarter and $199,000 for the year. c-Net loss

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Notre Dame vs. Michigan, National Invitation Tournament, championship game, at Madison Square Garden, 9 P.M. The title game will be preceded at 6:30 by Southwestern Louisiana vs.

title: 2 SHORT STORIES BY FREDERICK FORSYTH
description: TONIGHT'S ''2 X Forsyth,'' on Channel 5 at 8 o'clock, offers dramatizations of two short - very short and very insubstantial - stories by Frederick Forsyth, the author of such action-adventure novels as ''The Odessa File'' and ''The Day of the Jackal.'' These stories, adapted for television by Michael Feeney Callan, were plucked from a collection entitled ''No Comebacks.''

title: STEEL UNION VOTE SET FOR TOMORROW
description: The United Steelworkers of America will vote Thursday on a new president, choosing between Lynn R. Williams, the union's secretary and acting president, and Frank McKee, the treasuer.

title: 'MILESTONES OF WESTERN COOKING' IN PRINT
description: ABOUT the time of the Roman Emperor Tiberius (42 B.C. to A.D. 37) there lived a wealthy epicure, Apicius who, according to one historical account, ''spent myriads of drachms on his belly.'' He spared no effort seeking out the finest food and drink. On hearing that the crayfish in Africa were purported to be superior to those in his native southern Italy, Apicius ''sailed thither, without wasting a single day,'' according to the third-century writer Athenaeus.

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SOVIET HELP TO SANDINISTAS: NO BLANK CHECK
description: One day earlier this month, Government security officers closed the Atlantic port of El Bluff, preventing fishing boats from entering the harbor and barring civilian workers from the docks. Soon a freighter arrived and large unmarked cases were placed aboard military trucks.

title: Avon Makes Offer For Foster Medical
description: Avon Products Inc., the world's largest cosmetics and fragrance company, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Foster Medical Corporation in an exchange of stock valued at $250 million.

title: OLD FASHIONED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
Two Propose Gas Pipeline
description: The ANR Pipeline Company, a subsidiary of the American Natural Resources Company, and the Northern Natural Gas Company, a subsidiary of Internorth Inc. of Omaha, announced today that they are seeking Federal approval for a $1 billion, 663-mile pipeline to carry Canadian natural gas to the Northeastern United States.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Includes a pretax gain of $469,000 on the sale of the Hennepin Paper Company.

title: Ranger Returns
description: Gilles Villemure, weighing 208 pounds, or about 20 more than when he and Eddie Giacomin handled the goaltending duties for the Rangers from 1967 until 1975, will be back on the ice Sunday at Madison Square Garden for the first time in seven years.

title: MARKS & SPENCER CANADA INC reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After store closure costs of $212,000 for the latest year and $172,000 for the earlier year.

title: O'NEILL SAYS REPUBLICANS' MORAL CHARACTER WILL BE AN ISSUE
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said today that the financial troubles of Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's nominee for Attorney General, had ''opened a Pandora's box'' at the White House and that the moral character of the Republicans would be a campaign issue in the fall election.

title: STANLEY B. WILDRICK
description: Stanley B. Wildrick, chairman of Wildrick & Miller, a New York advertising agency, died Sunday at his home in Chatham, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,451,000. c-Net income.

title: LAGERFELD:SLOW START, BIG FINISH
description: Karl Lagerfeld chose the largest tent of the four that house the French fall and winter ready-to-wear shows in the Tuileries Garden to introduce his first collection under his own name this morning.

title: Court Dismisses A Suit by Iran
description: An appeals court in Manhattan yesterday dismissed a $3 billion lawsuit brought by the Government of Iran against the sister of the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: S & K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-After a gain of $1,188,000 from nontaxable insurance proceeds resulting from the death of an executive officer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has elected Leigh M. Miller president of its American Express Export Credit Corp. subsidiary.

title: DESPITE POOR GATE, IRISH LOVE N.I.T.
description: Not even the magic of Notre Dame's name in New York, with the university's traditional subway alumni, will more than half-fill Madison Square Garden tonight for the National Invitation Tournament final, Coach Digger Phelps said yesterday as his team prepared for its showdown with Michigan.

title: Changes at Lincoln West
description: The first brick has not been laid for

title: CURBS ON SMOKING VOTED IN SUFFOLK
description: The Suffolk County Legislature today passed an antismoking bill that supporters said was one of the most restrictive in the country.

title: LILCO FINANCES SPUR DEBATE ON PLAN
description: The effort by the Long Island Lighting Company to develop an emergency plan for its Shoreham nuclear power station has triggered a debate in Washington. The argument is over whether the utility's financial condition should be considered in making safety judgments.

title: Phone Fee Order Sought
description: Bell Atlantic today asked the United States District Court to order the Federal Communications Commission to restore an April 3 effective date for a monthly $6 service charge to business customers. Bell Atlanic is one of seven regional companies spun off from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.M.'S LUXURY-CAR GAMBLE
description: General Motors' latest and perhaps most important gamble, analysts and company executives say, is that buyers will accept the smaller size and wedge shape of its top-of-the-line luxury cars being introduced this week.

title: Japanese Output Up
description: Production at Japan's factories and mines rose 12.4 percent last month from February 1983, for the second consecutive double-digit increase after nearly four years without such gains, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The year-to- year rise in January was 10 percent.

title: Town Plagued by Fire Gets Federal Assistance
description: The Federal Government gave the State of Pennsylvania nearly $39 million today to start buying out homes and businesses in Centralia, Pa., a coal town threatened by a 22-year-old underground fire.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income. Results include capital gains of $6,268,241 for the latest year and $5,802,607 for the previous year.

title: Celtics 106, Bullets 93
description: Dennis Johnson scored 24 points and Kevin McHale came off the bench to add 22 to lead Boston. It was the Bullets' fourth straight setback.

title: Title Fight Wobbling
description: The World Boxing Association has ordered its heavyweight champion, Gerrie Coetzee, not to fight Larry Holmes. But promoters of the title unification bout, scheduled for June 8 in Las Vegas, Nev., say it will be held with or without W.B.A. approval.

title: Careers; The Rise Of Imaging Sciences
description: SUBSPECIALTIES in science and engineering have been developing rapidly. Astro science, robotics engineering and genetic engineering are all relatively new, for example. And now there is imaging - not to be confused with imagining.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;
description: This week's largest tax-exempt financing - a $325 million bond sale by the North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency - was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 11.30 percent for bonds due in 2018 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: HOMELESS CLEANING SUBWAYS IN EXPANDED WORK PROGRAM
description: A work program for homeless men and women is being expanded to provide a dozen crews from municipal shelters to clean subway stations nightly near their lodgings, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: VOICES

title: Addenda
description: * Sports Illustrated is increasing is circulation rate base 5.15 percent, to 2.55 million, from 2.42 million, with the April 2 issue; its advertising rates 4.6 percent with the Sept. 3 issue, and its subscription price 8.3 percent, to $52, on June 1.

title: SOVIET SAYS IT OFFERED TALKS TO REAGAN ENVOY
description: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass today described as a ''deception '' reports from Washington that a private American envoy carrying a personal message from President Reagan to Konstantin U. Chernenko was not given an opportunity to meet with the Soviet leader or any other top Soviet official.

title: RESIDUES IN FOOD CAUSE MUCH CONCERN
description: More than three-quarters of the food shoppers surveyed earlier this year said they worried about chemical residues in their food, a national association of food retailers reported Monday, adding that the total was larger than the number concerned about salt, sugar or cholesterol.

title: Bowater Splits Its Operations
description: The Bowater Corporation, a leading producer of newsprint and paper products, said that it would split into two companies - one based in the United States and one in Britain. Bowater said the United States-based company, to be named Bowater Inc., would operate Bowater's North American paper and pulp business.

title: CARTWRIGHT'S 38 SPARK KNICKS
description: After a stumbling start last night, during which the Dallas Mavericks bumped and double-teamed him and the crowd booed him, Bill Cartwright recovered and turned in his highest- scoring performance - 38 points - since he entered the league in 1979.

title: 'OUR SOCIAL SPENDING IS THE REAL CULPRIT'
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN SUGGESTS RULES BE EASED ON LATIN LOANS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan suggested today that the Administration might relax regulations requiring that American banks reduce their reported earnings to reflect overdue interest payments from Argentina.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Du Pont Spending
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company plans to increase capital spending to $3.4 billion in 1984 from $2.6 billion in 1983, its annual report said.

title: ;  Financial Officer Moves From G.E. to Travelers
description: Thomas O. Thorsen is moving from the post of chief financial officer at the General Electric Company to the same position at the Travelers Corporation.

title: MCFARLANE CARVING HIS NICHE
description: After almost six months on the job as national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane has made his staff into a more powerful bureaucratic instrument on day-to-day affairs, but he remains far less powerful personally on major policy issues than his predecessor, William P. Clark, according to White House and other Administration officials.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corp., Pittsburgh, said it had aquired the assets of Guterl Specialty Steel Corp. for $9.5 million.

title: The Shame in New Bedford and Dallas ; The Bad and Good Luck of Lenell Geter
description: The criminal justice system works poorly enough for blacks in America, but in the case of Lenell Geter it hardly worked at all.

title: A A IMPORTING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
NEW STUDY ORDERED ON SAFETY OF A CALIFORNIA NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission indicated Tuesday that it would not allow test operations at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant until a panel of the nation's top atomic scientists resolved new questions about its safety.

title: RECITAL: KANOFF ON CLARINET
description: STEVEN KANOFF is a clarinetist who succeeds admirably in making his instrument a powerful, as well as a beautiful, one. Mr. Kanoff's forcefulness took several directions in his recital at the Merkin Concert Hall Monday night. In the Brahms F minor Sonata, his muscular and intense style stripped away needless fat without ever damaging the music's sensibilities.

title: Bankrupt on Bankruptcy
description: For two years Congress has had the simple but important task of establishing efficient, constitutionally sound bankruptcy courts. Both political parties are failing that assignment, shabbily surrendering to special interests led by unions and the consumer credit industry.

title: New President At Pizza Time Financially troubled Pizza
description: Time Theater Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., this week replaced its president of less than two months with Henry C. Montgomery, 48 years old, who joined the company as executive vice president and chief financial officer at the end of January. Before joining Pizza Time Mr. Montgomery served as executive vice president of the Micropro International Corporation, a software company in San Rafael, Calif.

title: 3 Special Prosecutors Were Named Earlier
description: The request for a special prosecutor in the controversy over Edwin Meese 3d marks the fourth time that the law providing for an independent Federal investigator has been invoked.

title: TRIANGLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. c-After an extraordinary gain of $2,795,000. The 1982 results reflect a nonrecurring gain of $4.6 million for termination of the company's pension plan for salaried employees, an extraordinary gain of $2,795,000 from the restructuring of debt, and an expense of $1.7 million for operating losses and provisions for closedown costs of certain operations.

description: Barbara W. Tuchman was feted at
