title: The U.N. Today March 28, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: A Clinic That Caters To Foreign Celebrities
description: The Cleveland Clinic Foundation, where the President of Guinea, Ahmed Sekou Toure, died of a heart ailment on Monday, is known for having treated more dignitaries, both foreign and domestic, than almost any other clinic in the world.

title: Y.&R. Unit Gets Casino
description: was Wunderman, Ricotta &

title: Pornography Is CitedIn California Abuse Case
description: Children who attended the Virginia McMartin Preschool told the authorities they were forced to play games in which they were photographed nude, raped and touched by strangers, court documents indicated today.

title: A STOVE TOP GRIDDLE
description: large griddle in the kitchen

title: Marble Hill Switch Is Called Feasible
description: Converting the incomplete Marble Hill nuclear power plant to a coal- fired plant is feasible, according to a study for the Wabash Valley Power Association. Wabash Valley, which owns 17 percent of the project in southern Indiana, has yet to decide whether to proceed with the plant as a nuclear or coal-fired plant, or to bow out.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
FOLKS RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because 1983 was the company's first year of operation.

title: 3 DESIGN PLANS BEING CONSIDERED FOR PROPOSED PARK OVER THE WESTWAY
description: If the Westway, the covered highway along the Hudson River in lower Manhattan, is ever built - still, after a dozen years, an unanswered question - it will have on top of it a 93- acre park that will go a long way toward removing the curse of the urban highway. To open up the waterfront by covering the roadway with usable land was the basis of the Westway plan from the beginning, but until the actual designs were made public recently it was impossible even to begin to judge how worthwhile all the complexities and expense of the Westway might be.

title: GUINEA'S PRESIDENT, SEKOU TOURE, DIES IN CLEVELAND CLINIC
description: Ahmed Sekou Toure, the President of Guinea for 26 years and a symbol of African independence and defiance, died Monday in a Cleveland heart clinic. He was 62 years old.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net loss

title: 6 Islamic Ambassadors In Protest on Jerusalem
description: The ambassadors of six Islamic nations today expressed concern to Secretary of State George P. Shultz about proposed legislation to move the United States Embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Dr. Joseph G. Cohen yesterday omitted part of his career. He was a professor of education at Brooklyn College from 1932 to 1949 and director of its division of graduate studies from 1935 to 1939.

title: Synalloy's Intent
description: The Synalloy Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it will seek additional representation on the board of the Wolverine Aluminum Corporation and will continue buying the company's stock.

title: Selling the Apple at Lunch
description: It was billed as a ''sales blitz'' by the

title: Sherpa Killed on Everest
description: An avalanche killed one Sherpa and injured four others on Mount Everest on Monday, Nepal's Ministry of Tourism announced today. The Sherpa was the 61st person to die on Mount Everest since it was opened for climbing in the early 1950's. The Sherpas were part of an advance party for an Indian expedition.

title: 60 MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE wine importer and writer Frederick S. Wildman Jr. once told an anecdote about a French wine expert who was asked which he considered superior, Burgundies or Bordeaux. He replied that pondering the question was so enjoyable that he postponed his decision from day to day.

title: Bridge: Victor Mitchell, at 60, Stays Busy and Retains Sharpness
description: Some questions about the top- ranked players are easier to ask than to answer. For example, which of them has played the most hands of bridge in his lifetime?

title: EX-ATLANTIC CITY MAYOR INDICTED ON FEDERAL CHARGES OF EXTORTION
description: Former Mayor Michael J. Matthews of Atlantic City, who was recalled by voters two weeks ago, was indicted today on Federal extortion charges. He is accused of promising to help organized-crime figures in return for money.

title: MOTHER AND BABY BUNNIES, SWEATER SET AND TOTE BAG
description: 1.*Newsy Sweater Set

title: Pistons 111, Bulls 83
description: Bill Laimbeer and John Long each scored 22 points to lead Detroit to its fourth straight victory and a first-place tie in the Central Division with Milwaukee. Detroit led, 53-41, at the half, but the Bulls managed to cut the margin to 57-51 on a basket by Steve Johnson with 6:45 left in the third quarter. Detroit then scored 7 straight points to open a 64-51 lead and the Pistons led 71-61 after three quarters.

title: Concert: A Program With Cello and Piano
description: Sunday's evening of cello and piano music at the Merkin Concert Hall offered two different kinds of talent placed together in uneasy partnership. First was Eric Bartlett, possessor of an enormous cello sound and an equally grand approach to a variety of musical styles.

title: GIRL HIT BY BALL AT SHEA LOSES SUIT
description: A 14-year-old girl who was struck in the face by a line drive at Shea Stadium in 1979 may not collect damages for her injuries, the State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

title: MUSIC: VIKTORIA MULLOVA PLAYS VIOLIN IN DEBUT
description: FOR the last 20 years, the cultural life of the West has been enriched by a steady stream of defectors and emigres from the Soviet Union, a phenomenon comparable in some ways to the rush of European refugee artists to escape the Nazis in the 1930's. The most recent Soviet arrival is Viktoria Mullova, a 24-year-old violinist who made her New York debut Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y. Miss Mullova sought political asylum at the United States Embassy in Stockholm in July of 1983, not long after winning first prize in the 1982 Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow, and now lives in this country.

title: DEMOCRATS' BUDGET PROPOSAL MOVES AHEAD IN HOUSE PANEL
description: The House Budget Committee today gave tentative approval to an overall budget plan sponsored by the House Democratic leadership to reduce the budget deficit by $182 billion over three years.

title: Jenrette to Appeal Verdict
description: John W. Jenrette Jr., former Democratic Representative of South Carolina, says that this Friday he will file an appeal of his 1980 Abscam conviction with a Federal appeals court in Washington. Mr. Jenrette, who was defeated in a 1980 re-election bid, made the announcement Monday at the Horry County Democratic Convention.

title: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 28, 1984 International
description: The Common Market's crisis worsened as the 10 member countries failed again to settle their differences over finances and farm subsidies. Britain was again isolated at the end of an emergency foreign ministers' meeting over its demand for a refund on its contribution to the trade bloc's budget. (Page A1, Columns 3-4.) Soviet arms aid to Nicaragua is critical because Moscow supplies most of Managua's military equipment. The Soviet Union also supplies economic aid that Western diplomats estimate will total at least $100 million this year, an increase of at least 25 percent over last year. (A1:2-4.)

title: Knight Recalls His Army Days
description: Army's basketball team went to the National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden in 1964 and 1965, the two years that Bobby Knight served as an assistant coach at West Point. Then Knight took four Army teams (1966, 1968, 1969, 1970) into the N.I.T. during his six years as head coach, 1966-1971.

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS ; A Quiet Day in Silver As Traders Watch Fed
description: The normally volatile silver futures market was subdued yesterday, as the spot March contract expired. At the close of the Commodity Exchange in New York, the spot delivery went off the board at $9.53 an ounce, up only 0.8 cent on the day, while the active May futures were unchanged at $9.61 an ounce.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
MARCOS AT RALLY TO OPEN CAMPAIGN
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos officially opened his party's campaign for the May 14 parliamentary elections today at a political rally attended by tens of thousands in Manila's main public park.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Boise Cascade Corp. said it had filed for a shelf offering of up to $250 million in debt securities through underwriters that may include First Boston Corp. Terms will be determined at the time of the sale.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2.7 million for the quarter and year from discontinued operations.

title: Holmdel Sale Uses Book-Entry Basis
description: Holmdel, N.J., broke tradition with normal business practices in the municipal bonds market and sold $6.19 million of general obligation bonds to be bought on a book-entry basis, where records of bond ownership are kept electronically and no printed bonds are available to investors.

title: FINAL TALLY IN SALVADOR BY WEEKEND
description: Salvadoran officials said today that it would be at least four more days before the Election Council could tally all the votes in the presidential election Sunday.

title: Vector Stake Held
description: A group including two limited partnerships and three individuals said it holds 6.1 percent, or 436,760 common shares, of Vector Graphic Inc., a maker of microcomputer systems based in Thousand Oaks, Calif. The group, which filed its statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, includes Alta II, a limited partnership based in Boston; Alta II Management Partners, a second limited partnership that acts as the general partner of the first, and three individuals, Wiliam Egan and Craig Burr, both of Boston, and Jean Deleage of San Francisco.

title: INDIA VOTE COULD BRING CONSTITUTIONAL CHANGE
description: In an election that could pave the way for basic changes in India's form of government, state legislators throughout the country are to vote Thursday to replace one- third of the members of the upper house of Parliament.

title: AND A SUCCESSFUL NEWCOMER
description: In a sun-splashed, high-rise suite of rooms overlooking the Potomac River in Georgetown, there is the insistent beat of soft-rock music as artists bend over their easels, editors meet in story conferences and typesetters go about their job.

title: Hijacker Is ArrestedAfter Flight to Cuba
description: A man claiming to be a member of the Black Liberation Army hijacked a Piedmont Aviation jet with 58 people aboard and forced it to fly to Havana today.

title: U.S. CUTS LIST OF DUTY-FREE IMPORTS
description: The Reagan Administration, responding to protectionist pressure, has cut deeply into the list of goods that developing countries are permitted to sell in the United States without paying a tariff.

title: BANKS RESIGNED TO CUTBACKS
description: The nation's major banks have become resigned to the likelihood that some of them will have to report sharp earnings declines in the first quarter as the result of their loans to Argentina.

title: 111 Evacuate Smoky Jet
description: An overheated air-conditioning unit sent smoke into the cabin of a United Airlines 727 jet, forcing the evacuation of 111 people aboard the plane as it prepared for takeoff Monday at Los Angeles International Airport. No injuries were reported.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 28, 1984

title: ALBANY ACCORD ADDS $8 MILLION IN HOMELESS AID
description: After a last- minute behind-the-scenes battle, legislative leaders agreed today to a request by Governor Cuomo to provide $20 million in the next year to house homeless people. But the leaders tied the money to instructions on who should oversee the programs.

title: A.T.&.T. OFFERS ITS COMPUTERS
description: The title bout has been postponed. The challenger isn't ready yet.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
BIOTECHNOLOGY DEVELOPENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-The company went public in December 1983 and had no comparable year-ago results.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
PAYCHEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
ANTITRUST BAR TO 'TYING' OF SALES EASED BY COURT
description: The Supreme Court today eased the antitrust barriers to ''tying arrangements'' that require consumers who want a particular product or service to also buy a second, related product.

title: A TALK WITH SHULTZ
description: You can't read the world press these days on the conduct of American foreign policy, and then listen to the officials here who are responsible for it, without wondering about the fundamental difference between the two.

title: 7TH CHESS GAME DRAWN IN FOURTEEN MOVES
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union and his countryman Vasily Smyslov played to an early draw in the seventh game of their final candidates chess match Monday. The score is now Kasparov 4 1/2, Smyslov, 2 1/2.

title: TWO-WAY CABLE T.V. FALTERS
description: It was heralded as the future of television, the transformation of passive viewing into active involvement. It captured headlines and helped its owner, Warner Amex Cable Communications, secure exclusive cable television franchises in major cities around the country.

title: Suit Over Film 'Sadat' Is Dismissed in Cairo
description: An Egyptian court Monday dismissed a suit against Columbia Pictures and six Americans over a controversial film about President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: ; WHEN A FOREIGN ECONOMY AIMS AT A U.S. INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SCREEN:'COMPERES'
description: IN ''Les Comp eres,'' the frenetic

title: BRIEFING
description: And Jackson Makes 3

title: Angolan Rebels Claim A Provincial Capital
description: Angolan rebels said today that their forces had overrun a provincial capital in a day long battle in which 500 Government soldiers and 86 foreigners were killed.

title: CARE ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1.5 million.

title: 4-YEAR NOTE IS SOLD AT 12.07%
description: The United States Treasury yesterday sold $6 billion of new four-year 12 percent notes at an average yield of 12.07 percent, the first time a Treasury note or bond auction has pierced the 12 percent level since last August.

title: SUDAN ASKS ACTION BY U.N. IN BOMBING
description: The Foreign Minister of the Sudan called on the Security Council today to condemn Libya for its aerial attack earlier this month on the town of Omdurman in which five people were killed.

title: Lava Follows Old Track At Hawaii Eruption Site
description: Scientists flew over a ''curtain of fire'' more than a quarter of a mile long today and saw lava pouring down the flanks of the Mauna Loa Volcano in four streams.

title: MONDALE AND HART CLASH ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart have become ensnarled in a sharp dispute over Mr. Mondale's stance on United States policy in Central America.

title: Vote Delayed On Oil Mergers
description: The Senate took up legislation today to impose an 11-month moratorium on large oil-industry mergers but adjourned without a vote after more than four hours of debate. The measure was offered as an amendment to an appropriations bill for military aid to El Salvador, which is supported by President Reagan.

title: SALVADOR REBELS SAID TO USE U.S. ARMS
description: A top Defense Department official said today that roughly half of the arms used by Salvadoran guerrillas were United States-supplied weapons taken from the armed forces of El Salvador.

title: REAGAN CHALLENGES CRITICS ON SOVIET ARMS TALKS
description: President Reagan, accusing those who criticize him over arms control putting the nation ''behind the eight ball'' with the Soviet Union, today challenged ''would-be leaders'' to specify what incentives they would use to get the Russians to return to arms negotiations.

title: PAIR OF COUNTRY SLICKERS
description: It is late at night, but maybe not as late as it seems. Maybe it seems later than it is because Walter Mondale is bowling. The spectacle of a man running for President by bowling can leave you disoriented.

title: INQUIRY CITES JOB COERCION IN LIBERAL PARTY DISPUTE
description: Both sides in a Liberal Party leadership struggle threatened to dismiss party members from their state jobs last year if they voted for the opposition group, the State Commission of Investigation said yesterday.

title: ENSTAR SALE IS PLANNED
description: The Enstar Corporation, a Houston- based oil and gas producer facing a fight for control by a dissident stockholder, said yesterday that it was putting the company up for sale.

title: PROPER ISRAELI CITY FOR A U.S. EMBASSY
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS ROUT CANADIANS
description: The playoffs are coming, and the revived Islanders continued their sudden surge with a performance tonight that was flawless on offense, on defense, and in the nets. It produced a 7-0 rout of the Montreal Canadiens, who were, it appeared, simply stunned into submission.

title: New Editor Appointed At Advertising Age
description: Fred Danzig, 53-year-old executive editor of Advertising Age, has been promoted to editor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's about time to get serious and ask these would-be leaders what they expect to use as incentives with the Soviet Union.

title: New Plea for Perez
description: Joaquin Balaguer, a former President of the Dominican Republic, has renewed his plea for quick action to free Pascual Perez, the Atlanta Brave pitcher who has been in a Santiago jail since his arrest on a charge of cocaine trafficking on Jan. 9. ''It's a shame they insist on trying to destroy the career of this young player,'' said Balaguer, an opposition leader heading a group of prominent Dominicans who have been calling for clemency for Perez.

title: PRACTIONERS OF THE SOMMELIERS ART
description: THERE was a time when Victor Puppin and Mario Ricci had the sommelier business sewed up in New York. For decades, Mr. Puppin presided over the wine list at the Brussels on East 54th Street, while Mr. Ricci did his best to convert the ''21'' Club's crowd from Scotch to wine.

title: TO HELP PROSECUTE CHILD MOLESTERS
description: In 1983, there were 4,300 reported instances in which children were sexually abused in New York State. Sadly, the prosecution of these crimes has been effectively handcuffed by an anomalous law that dates back to the 19th century.

title: Hartford Settles Roof-Collapse Suit
description: The Hartford City Council has unanimously accepted a settlement in a lawsuit over the 1978 collapse of the Hartford Civic Center roof.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss

title: UTAH SLAYER, SENTENCED TO DIE, CHOOSES INJECTION
description: Arthur Gary Bishop, after being sentenced to die for murdering five young boys, was given his choice of deaths today. He chose lethal injection, and his execution was set for May 3.

title: THE SMITHS, NEW BRITISH QUARTET
description: To the bemused American observer, today's British pop scene appears to be an endless parade of new faces, new haircuts and new clothes, a race to see who will come up with the week's silliest group name and most outrageous new style of androgyny. There's plenty of novelty, but when it comes down to looking for original stylists, for bands or performers with something new to say and a new way of saying it - well, to be charitable, the pickings are slim.

title: REAL ESTATE WORLD A MODEL FOR MAMET
description: DAVID MAMET'S new play, ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' is a scathing comedy about the life of salesmen, in this case real estate agents operating out of a high-powered Chicago office. The agents do anything to make a sale: They lie, cheat, swindle their clients and stab one another in the back. As with most of Mr. Mamet's work, the play, which opened this week at the Golden Theater, derives from personal experience. In 1969, as an unemployed actor, he spent a year working in a Chicago real estate office. He was the assistant office manager, a job very much like that held by the actor J. T. Walsh in ''Glengarry Glen Ross.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: FOREIGN MINISTERS UNABLE TO SETTLE COMMON MARKET BUDGET DISPUTE
description: The crisis gripping the European Common Market deepened further today after the 10 member nations again failed to settle their differences over finances and farm subsidies.

title: EX-MENTAL PATIENTS UPHELD ON SUING
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that patients discharged from mental hospitals had the right to sue the state to obtain continued housing and care.

title: A WORTHWHILE CAUSE SERVED PAINLESSLY
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Reuters dispatch from London in some editions on Monday incorrectly described the job taken by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's son, Mark. He is an associate director of Lotus Cars, the British company, and will not be a director of Lotus Performance Cars in the United States.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GULF BROADCAST GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,208,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,521,000.

title: Flaws in the Navy's Magic Shield
description: The aegis was the magical shield used by the ancient Greek gods. Just to look at it made opponents tremble. The Navy has chosen the name for its new shipborne defense against aircraft and missiles. The modern Aegis, alas, has a way to go before it makes anyone tremble, except maybe the taxpayer. In its first combat-like tests, it intercepted only one out of the seven sea-skimming missiles fired at it.

title: Military Contracts To Convair, Litton
description: The Convair division of the General Dynamics Corporation received a $115.2 million Navy contract to produce sea- and ground-launched Tomahawk cruise missiles, the Defense Department said.

title: Economic Scene; New Fears On Latin Debt
description: AMERICAN and other foreign bankers are pressing Argentina strenuously to come up with $650 million in overdue interest by a crucial March 31 deadline. But Bernardo Grinspun, the Argentine Finance Minister, has indicated at the annual meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank in Punta del Este, Uruguay, that these payments will not be made. Thus, on Saturday, many of the banks say, they will have to take first-quarter losses on the unpaid interest and may have to reclassify billions of dollars in loans to Argentina as nonperforming.

title: THE FIGHT AT MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE
description: The winner in the battle for seats on the board of Management Assistance Inc., a maker of computer systems for small and medium-sized businesses, will be announced next Monday. But longer-range questions about just how to make the company a more attractive takeover candidate may not be settled for some time.

title: Computer Concern Rating Is Reduced
description: Moody's reduced its rating on $223 million of debt of the Storage Technology Corporation. The rating on the company's senior debt was reduced to a speculative grade Ba-2, from Baa-3, and that on its subordinated debt to B-1, from Ba-2.

title: Jackson Group Files Suit Over Caucuses on Coast
description: The Jesse Jackson for President Committee of Washington filed a suit Monday in the King County Superior Court charging that ''irregularities'' in the recent Presidential precinct caucuses hurt their candidate.

title: A CAPITAL ABUNDANCE: MAGAZINES
description: The nation's capital is known for its never-ending paper flow: documents, position papers, regulatory announcements, pamphlets and press releases. It is not as well known, however, for the dozens magazines that are published here.

title: JACKSON TELLS SYRACUSE STUDENTS THEIR VOTES IN PRIMARY ARE VITAL
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson told 700 Syracuse University students today that ''your time has come'' to help change the direction of American politics and bring about social justice at home and peace abroad.

title: ATLAN-TOL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including net non-operating income of $1,374,000.

title: ARGENTINA PLANS DEBT ACCORD SOON
description: Argentina intends to reach a settlement over its arrears with creditor banks by mid-April, senior Argentine officials said today.

title: Coaching Change
description: With the Olympic Games in Los Angeles only four months away, the United States Soccer Federation has replaced Manfred Schellscheidt, who has been coaching the United States Olympic team for the past year.

title: New Moves Unsettle Yankees
description: The Yankee clubhouse was an unsettled, uneasy place today as various players considered the impact of Monday's lineup shuffle and assumed that more changes would follow in the final five days of spring training.

title: INTERNATIONAL CAPITAL EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: CANDIDATES' CAMPS RACE TO KEEP UP WITH EVENTS
description: In the month since the New Hampshire primary, the Hart campaign has had to mushroom from a two-state operation to a national organization, and Walter F. Mondale's campaign has had to readjust to a difficult and possibly lengthy contest rather than breezing through a coronation. A burst of frantic activity has been the result, and nowhere more so than in New York State, where the primary next Tuesday is considered crucial by both candidates.

title: MAX ARONS, LEADER OF MUSICIANS' LOCAL IN CITY FOR 17 YEARS
description: Max Arons, who headed Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians here for 17 years, died Monday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old and had lived in Queens for many years.

title: GREAT AMERICAN RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Beneficial Board Seeks Liquidation
description: The Beneficial Standard Corporation said its board had proposed a complete liquidation, subject to shareholder approval at the annual meeting on May 21. The company had previously agreed to sell its life insurance and related subsidiaries, without their real estate assets, to Calfed Inc. for $125 million.

title: Rent Challenges Facing Deadline
description: Tenants in rent-stablized apartments who suspect that they are being charged a higher rent than the law allows have until Friday to file challenges, before a change in state law grants landlords amnesty for most such overcharges.

title: Suit by Casino Dismissed
description: The Nevada Supreme Court on Monday dismissed a suit filed by the Circus Circus casino in Las Vegas that sought to avoid paying benefits to two blackjack dealers who asserted that they suffered inflammation of the hands because of their continuous shuffling of cards. The occupational injury, carpal tunnel syndrome, is an irritation of the tendons in the hand.

title: MONDALE TV ADS BEGIN IN STATE
description: Walter F. Mondale's image looked out from television screens last night and said that when the Chrysler Corporation faced bankruptcy ''some people said let them go.''

title: GENERAL TO HEAD MISSILE PROGRAM
description: An Air Force general who has directed the space shuttle program was appointed today to manage a program to explore the feasibility of building a space-based defense against nuclear ballistic missiles.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PROPER ISRAELI CITY FOR A U.S. EMBASSY
description: To the Editor: Moving the U.S. Embassy in Israel to Jerusalem need not involve the in

title: A TASTE OF JAPAN, BUT MADE IN CALIFORNIA
description: IT is a surprising setting for the

title: No Action Seen On Tin Prices
description: The Association of Tin Producing Countries does not intend to act as a cartel to stabilize tin prices, Malaysia's Primary Industries Minister, Paul Leong, said today.

title: SMITH ASKS JUDGES TO NAME COUNSEL ON MEESE DEALINGS
description: Attorney General William French Smith today asked a special judicial panel to appoint an independent counsel to investigate whether Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential Counselor, has committed any Federal crimes.

title: IN FASHION, THE SHOW'S THE THING
description: Backstage at the Thierry Mugler fashion show last Friday utter madness reigned. Racks of clothes with the names of models attached to them filled the cavernous dressing area.

title: ON BLEAK ISLES, RESENTMENT OF SEALERS SPILLS OUT
description: -AUX-MEULES, Quebec, March 22 - For the 14,000 residents of the windswept Magdalen Islands in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, virtually all of life's necessities must be imported and the only industry is a money-losing, Government-subsidized salt mine. Fully 70 percent of the population is unemployed this time of year.

title: St. Louis Publisher May Open a New Paper
description: The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, the morning newspaper that nearly closed earlier this year, will start an afternoon paper in about three weeks, according to the publisher, Jeffrey M. Gluck.

title: 4 DEMONSTRATORS DIE
description: Chileans demanding an end to military rule banged on pots and pans in their homes in three cities today and army troops fired into crowds of demonstrators, killing four of them.

title: WHAT U.S. CAN DO IN LEBANON
description: The last soldiers from the multinational force are to be withdrawn from Beirut this week, ending a chapter in Lebanon and posing some stark questions for Washington: What next? What if anything can the United States do now to foster peace within Lebanon and among its neighbors? How does anyone start to pick up the pieces?

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: The sun shines An amber legend Through winter's last gasp Longing the longest distance.RICHARD LEVINE

title: The Shame in New Bedford and Dallas; It's Not the Victim Who Should Be Tried for Rape
description: When the four men found guilty of raping a customer in a Massachusetts bar left the courthouse after sentencing Monday, they were cheered. ''She should have been home in the first place,'' one woman yelled about their accuser.

title: TEXT OF PLEA TO JUDICIARY FOR COUNSEL
description: Following is the text of the application of Attorney General William French Smith to a special judicial panel requesting appointment of an independent counsel in the case of Edwin Meese 3d:

title: Market Halts Decline; Dow Up 1.36
description: The stock market yesterday halted its four-day losing streak by posting a small gain in moderate trading.

title: BOWATER CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BEIRUT GUNMEN BADLY WOUND FRENCH ATTACHE
description: A carload of unidentified gunmen shot a French cultural attache four times today as he was walking to work in West Beirut.

title: ; The Irish Clear Out For Sluby
description: Tom Sluby looks like a football

title: ;  Officers Shifted At Gannett
description: John J. Curley was named yesterday as president and chief operating officer of the Gannett Company. The publishing company also elected Douglas H. McCorkindale vice chairman of the corporation and William J. Keating president of the newspaper division. Mr. Keating succeeds Mr. Curley.

title: REBELS CALL VOTE A U.S. DEFEAT
description: The political leaders of El Salvador's guerrilla opposition said today that Sunday's presidential elections ''constituted the biggest political failure of the Reagan Administration in El Salvador.''

title: Yorkshire Ripper Is Moved
description: A Briton convicted of murder in the slaying of 13 women from 1975-80 has been moved from prison to a mental hospital, authorities said today. They said Peter Sutcliffe, 37 years old, who was known as the Yorkshire Ripper in the British press, had been transferred from Parkhurst prison on the Isle of Wight to Broadmoor top-security mental hospital because his state of mind had deteriorated.

title: COMMERCIAL PROJECT IN LONG ISLAND CITY
description: Long Island City has long been a predominantly industrial area, with the advantage of being just across the East River from Manhattan.

title: Suburban Papers
description: The Ingersoll Publications Company of Lakeville, Conn., said it had agreed to acquire Suburban Newspapers of Greater St. Louis, the largest group of free-distribution suburban newspapers in the nation.

title: Advertising; Political Campaigns And Cable
description: CAMPAIGN managers in Congressional races should be taking a hard look at the possibilities of cable television advertising. Or so the cable industry hopes.

title: British Trade Surplus
description: Britain recorded its best trade performance in 15 months in February, the Department of Trade and Industry said today. The country had an international payments surplus of $:819 million, or about $1.2 billion, the best performance since November 1982. Exports were a record $:6.03 billion.

title: FREE MARK GASTINEAU
description: Quick, tell me who won the Super Bowl. Not bad. Now, tell me the score. Ah-hah. And can you remember more than one play from that game, only two months ago? I thought so.

title: FILM: 'REVOLT OF JOB,' OSCAR NOMINEE
description: WHAT recourse could there be for a Hungarian Jew in 1943, able to anticipate his fate but powerless to save himself? In ''The Revolt of Job,'' the Jewish farmer of the title attempts the illicit act of adopting a Christian child, hoping that the boy will be able to carry on his tradition and possess his legacy. The latter involves more than mere worldly goods, although Job is a prosperous man. During the course of the story, Job (Ferenc Zenthe) teaches young Lacko (Gabor Feher) as much as he can about his life, his values and his God.

title: Founder of IBH Is Arrested
description: Horst-Dieter Esch, the founder of IBH Holdings A.G., a bankrupt West German construction machinery company, has been arrested to prevent him from fleeing the country, a prosecutor said today. Mr. Esch said he is not guilty of any wrongdoing.

title: 'Obscene' Prices
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Chris-Craft May Add Warner Seats
description: Chris-Craft Industries and affiliated companies told the Securities and Exchange Commission that they and Warner Communications Inc. are discussing adding up to three Chris- Craft representatives to Warner's board, which has 16 members.

title: CIRCUS CIRCUS ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Comings and Goings
description: Michael Jordan of North Carolina was named the winner of the Eastman Award as the top college basketball player of the year. . . . Dave Buss, citing ''personal reasons,'' resigned as basketball coach at Long Beach State after compiling a 9-19 record in his single season there.

title: MORE THAN A DOZEN IN ADMINISTRATION ACCUSED OF IMPROPRIETY
description: Edwin Meese 3d is not the first Reagan Administration official to face charges of improper financial dealings.

title: SCREEN: 'GOOD FIGHT,' SPANISH WAR
description: THE spirit of the old American Left remains undiminished, at least on movie screens. Already in the middle of a successful New York first run is the Oscar-nominated ''Seeing Red.'' Now comes another equally fine documentary, ''The Good Fight,'' which features the moving testimony of 11 veterans of the Lincoln Brigade, that small force of very young American volunteers who went to Spain to fight for the Loyalist cause in the Spanish Civil War (1936-39).

title: Gretzky Passes 200
description: Wayne Gretzky surpassed the 200- point plateau for the second time in his career, and Mark Messier scored two short-handed goals to spark Edmonton to a 9-2 victory over Calgary.

title: Richard Is Released
description: J. R. Richard, the Houston Astro pitcher who had not played in a major league game since suffering a nearly fatal stroke in 1980, was given his unconditional release yesterday after having failed in a comeback bid. ''The situation and the circumstances have just not worked out the way everybody had hoped,'' said the Astros' owner, John McMullen, who said that in the end it had been Richard's decision to leave baseball to pursue a career in another area. The 34-year-old Richard, who was not available for comment, had been at the Astros' training camp in Cocoa, Fla., under a conditional contract that required him to make the team.

title: CONCERT: THE ROCHESTER PHILHARMONIC
description: DAVID ZINMAN, who is completing his 10th season as music director of the Rochester Philharmonic Orchestra - he moves on to the Baltimore Symphony in 1985-86 - brought his upstate ensemble to Carnegie Hall Monday night, as part of an eight-city tour of New York, Pennsylvania and Connecticut.

title: ;  $90 Million Bond Issue From Illinois
description: Illinois sold $90 million of high- grade general obligation bonds to underwriters led by Citibank, which reoffered the bonds with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for the 1985 maturity to 8.6 percent for bonds due in 1994 and 9.75 percent for those due in 2009. By late afternoon, underwriters said, about $25 million of the issue was unsold.

title: Kostoff Captures 800 Freestyle
description: Jeff Kostoff and Tiffany Cohen were winners today at the United States indoor swimming championships, the last major meet before the Olympic trials here in June.

title: Brazil Reports New Oil Find
description: Brazil has discovered more oil in the Campos Basin off the Atlantic coast, the country's richest oil-producing area, the Government's petroleum company, Petrobras, said today.

title: CREDIT CARD SURCHARGE BAN GAINS
description: A House of Representatives subcommittee voted today to extend a ban on credit card surcharges until May 31, 1985.

title: STAGE: WOMEN'S PROJECT PRESENTS THREE WORKS
description: NOW in its sixth season, The Women's Project is presenting an ambitious series of one-act plays, written, directed and, for the most part, acted by women. Three of these plays may currently be seen in a single evening at the American Place Theater.

title: A WORTHWHILE CAUSE SERVED PAINLESSLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Body Is Identified As Indicted Man's
description: A body recovered from the Hudson River was identified today as that of a Mahopac man who had been indicted in the shooting deaths of his wife and her lover and was suspected of faking a suicide leap from the Tappan Zee Bridge, the Yonkers police said.

title: WINCORP REALTY GROUP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The net income and revenue for 1983 include a nonrecurring insurance gain of $243,000 and a gain of $2,268,000 from the sale of racing assets. Wincorp Realty Investments Inc. and Western Harness Racing Inc. have paired capital shares.

title: DR. E.J. SACHAR, PSYCHIATRIST AND HORMONE EXPERT, DEAD
description: Dr. Edward J. Sachar, a psychiatrist and authority on the roles of chemicals in mental illness, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He suffered a stroke three years ago.

title: Wilson Debt Plan
description: A bankruptcy judge approved the Wilson Foods Corporation's reorganization plan. The company said unsecured creditors would be fully repaid in installments and with interest at 9 1/2 percent over a 48-month period.

title: ROAD AHEAD FOR EUROPE
description: The renewed failure on Tuesday of the Common Market countries to resolve their budget differences suggests that Western Europe is denying itself the one thing it really needs - a credible strategy for economic recovery. Because 10 major European nations cannot agree on dividing up their community's cost, these countries are now unable to start carrying out a two-stage strategy they have devised for breaking out of the recession that has gripped their economies for the last 10 years and sent unemployment to record numbers.

title: Jet Is Ordered to Cuba In 2d Hijacking in 2 Days
description: A man threatening to ignite a bottle of liquid hijacked a Boeing 727 with 26 people aboard to Cuba tonight, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Northeast Appeal
description: Northeast Bancorp said it had filed a notice of appeal of a decision by the Federal Reserve System to allow the merger of the CBT Corporation of Hartford and the Bank of New England in Boston. Northeast, a New Haven-based bank holding company, said it and its subsidiary, Union Trust, would suffer ''irreparable harm'' if merger took place.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 16
No Longer Amateurs
description: Scott Hamilton , the 25-year-old figure skater who just won his fourth world championship after capturing a gold medal at the Winter Olympics, announced his retirement from amateur competition. . . . Kitty and Peter Carruthers , the sibling skaters who won a silver medal at Sarajevo, have signed a multiyear contract with the Ice Capades.

title: Advertising; Cable TV's Growth in Ad Spots
description: agencies and advertisers about

title: Standoff in El Salvador
description: Prematurely, even before the returns were in, President Reagan proclaimed El Salvador's election a victory of freedom over tyranny. The more realistic reading of a continuing process is that the first round was a standoff for democracy. The candidate most committed to democracy failed to get a majority; he'll be tested again in a tricky runoff next month and, if he wins, by the leadership he can provide.

title: HOW TO RUN THINGS, OR RUIN THEM
description: One Too Many Graig Nettles, the captain of the New York Yankees, said something the other day that transcends the sour atmosphere among his teammates, transcends sports altogether and compresses into one sentence a superior philosophy for dealing with people. Discussing the managerial approach of George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, he said:

title: EDWARDS, A G, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Results for the latest fourth quarter reflect a charge of $12 million for contingencies.

title: TIBER ENERGY reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
SHOPWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a credit of $1,330,000, or $1.01 a share, which represents the cumulative effect of an accounting change on prior years. The share earnings were adjusted for 10 percent stock dividend in January 1983.

title: Article 085404 -- No Title
description: Harte-Hanks Communications announced yesterday that a group of investors led by two company officers and three Harte and Hanks family heirs had offered to purchase the company's outstanding stock in a leveraged buyout.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Amdahl's Earnings Expected to Slide
description: The Amdahl Corporation said yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter will be below those of a year earlier.

title: France, Citing 'Leaks,' Bars Press From Detective Offices
description: The Government closed all journalists' offices at the police detective division yesterday and suspended reporters' accreditations because of what officials called ''too many leaks'' to reporters.

title: MACY'S, LORD & TAYLOR TO ENTER NEW ORLEANS
description: R. H. Macy & Company will enter the New Orleans market, beginning in 1986, with two stores in new shopping centers, principals in the negotiations said yesterday. One of the centers will also include a Lord & Taylor store, according to the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, which is building one of the projects.

title: STUDENTS FROM BRONX GET THEIR DAY IN HIGHEST COURT
description: For six months, the students in Joel S. Seidenstein's law class at the Bronx High School of Science have studied the United States Supreme Court. They have read its opinions, discussed their impact and considered the institution's crucial role in American history.

title: Streisand Guards Arrested
description: Two of Barbra Streisand's bodyguards were arrested today on charges of assaulting a photographer who tried to take pictures of the actress outside a clothing store and a security guard who tried to help the photographer, the police said. A police spokesman said the two men were released on their own recognizance after being charged with two counts each of assault and battery.

title: RETROACTIVITY STRUCK
description: A Congressional committee today took the first step toward enacting legislation to put into effect a 1983 Supreme Court decision holding that it is illegal to pay smaller monthly pensions to women than to men.

title: Reagan Suggests He Would Veto Bill to Put Embassy in Jerusalem
description: This is the last of a series of interviews with candidates for the Presidency. Excerpts are on page B11.

title: 13 INDICTED AFTER INVESTIGATION OF MAJOR LOAN-SHARKING RING
description: Thirteen men were indicted yesterday on charges of having refused to give testimony or having evaded questions before a Manhattan grand jury investigating a major loan-sharking and extortion ring.

title: HUMPHREY S. FINNEY
description: Humphrey S. Finney, chairman of the Fasig-Tipton Company, the horse-auctioneering concern, died of a heart attack Tuesday.

title: SCOUTING ;
description: Who's Faking?

title: CITY TO DROP COMPETITIVE BIDDING IN SALE OF SOME PUBLIC PROPERTIES
description: Mayor Koch has announced that the city will drop competitive bidding in the sale of some municipally owned sites in an effort to maintain jobs in Manhattan and develop unused areas in other boroughs.

title: LEATHER FURNITURE: CARE AND CLEANING
description: THERE was a time when leather furniture was reserved for board rooms and executive suites. Today it is not unusual to sit in a chair of supple leather, recline on a suede couch or rest one's feet on a leather ottoman.

title: SCM Shortage
description: The SCM Corporation said about 1,000 of the 2,200 workers at its plant here are being laid off for the last three days of this week because of a parts shortage.

title: STANDARDS DEBATED AT BOSTON COLLEGE
description: The faculty and administration of Boston College, one of the nation's largest Roman Catholic universities, are embroiled in a dispute over whether the school gave special treatment to a star basketball player who flunked out but was allowed to continue playing.

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? TO THE JAPANESE, EVERYTHING
description: Before long, there may be Japanese named Smith.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS: CREDIT CARD BIDS
description: Bankers yesterday were eagerly awaiting the outcome of an auction of the Continental Illinois Corporation's credit-card operations, the fifth largest in the country. The deadline for bids was Tuesday, and a spokesman for the bank said the buying interest was ''heavy.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 11 on School Bus Hurt in Accident
description: Eight children, a driver and two teachers were injured when a school bus in Brooklyn was cut off by a car and veered into a light post yesterday, the police said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article March 20 about Budd Schulberg's stage adaptation of ''On the Waterfront'' incorrectly suggested the order in which his script for the 1954 film and his novel ''Waterfront'' appeared. The film, based on Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper articles by Malcolm Johnson, appeared before the novel.

title: Armenians in Teheran Wound Turkish Aides
description: The Turkish Embassy in Teheran said today that Armenian gunmen had wounded two Turkish diplomats during a series of attacks.

title: ROLFITE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a income tax benefit of $1,028,479.

title: '80 Reagan Groups Pay For Campaign Violations
description: A political action committee and President Reagan's 1980 campaign committee have agreed to pay $5,000 in penalties to settle charges that they violated Federal election laws, the Federal Election Commission said Tuesday.

title: MORE DATA SAID TO LINK YELLOW RAIN TO BEES
description: Two American scientists who recently returned from Southeast Asia say they are more convinced than ever that the ''yellow rain'' there, which has been described as a form of chemical warfare, was actually nothing more than ''massive defecation flights by wild honeybees.''

title: REPORTS OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York and American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: AT LEAST 18 DIE
description: Fierce, random shelling of civilian areas by Christian and Moslem militiamen over a wide area of Beirut today sent terrified residents racing through the streets and left at least 18 people dead and more than 100 wounded.

title: WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $971,984 on the sale of plant and equipment in the fourth quarter. The latest year and fourth quarter results also include pro-rated earnings of the company's 51 percent- owned subsidiary, Welmoore Industries, which are accounted for under the equity method. The share earnings were restated to reflect 3-for-1 stock split on Aug. 8, 1983.

title: DEVELOPMENT BANK REJECTS GUARANTEE
description: Antonio Ortiz Mena, president of the Inter-American Development Bank, today rejected an Argentine proposal that the bank guarantee Latin America's $366 billion of foreign debt.

title: LONDON'S TRANSPORT FROZEN BY STRIKE OVER THATCHER PLAN
description: Transport workers paralyzed London's buses and subways today in a 24-hour strike challenging a Government plan to scrap the capital's metropolitan council.

title: BRIEFING
description: Burger Court: One View

title: DR. HOMER BABBIDGE JR., 58, NOTED CONNECTICUT EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Homer D. Babbidge Jr., president of the Hartford Graduate Center since 1976 and long a major figure in Connecticut higher education, died of cancer Tuesday at the University of Connecticut Health Center in Farmington. He was 58 years old and lived in Hartford.

title: CHECKER MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
People
description: * Howard Berg named an executive vice president and William Lyons chairman of the executive committee at Nadler & Larimer.

title: China Reports Firing On Vietnamese Plane
description: China said its air force gunners fired on a Vietnamese spy plane today, damaging the intruding aircraft and forcing it back to Vietnam.

title: MCFADDIN VENTURES reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Comings and Goings
description: Brendan Malone , a six-year assistant at Syracuse and a well-connected recruiter in New York City, has been named head basketball coach at Rhode Island. He replaces Claude English , whose contract was not renewed. . . Dave Cowens , the former Boston Celtic, has signed a one-year contract as coach of the Bay State Bombardiers of the Continental Basketball Association.

title: HART AND MONDALE CLASH REPEATEDLY IN SIXTH DEBATE
description: Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale criticized each other heatedly on foreign policy and arms control issues last night in a nationally televised debate marked by sharp accusations about campaign tactics in the Democratic Presidential contest.

title: JARDINE OF HONG KONG PLANS SHIFT TO BERMUDA
description: Jardine, Matheson & Company, one of this British colony's oldest and biggest corporations, announced today that it planned to reorganize as a Bermuda holding company.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Allied Stores Corp. has appointed Jack N. Curtis chairman and chief executive of its Cain-Sloan division in Nashville, and has named Ronald Lane president of Cain-Sloan.

title: Lotto Winner Picks 6 Numbers 'Blindly'
description: A Long Island man who picked his Lotto numbers ''blindly'' has become the state lottery's 200th millionaire.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective March 1, 1984.

title: PIZZA TIME FILES FOR PROTECTION
description: Pizza Time Theater Inc., a six- year-old specialty-restaurant company based in Sunnyvale, Calif., announced yesterday that it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: ENERSERV PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $1,574,338 for the quarter and year from inventory and a provision of $783,308 for the quarter and year for doubtful accounts.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 29, 1984

title: Reporter's Notebook: A Mellow Mitterrand
description: President Francois Mitterrand was having lunch yesterday with members of the Economic Club at the Pierre Hotel, and seemed particularly sensitive to the concerns that many Americans seemed to have when his Socialist Cabinet came to power three years ago.

title: TAPE OF AQUINO SLAYING: 'HERE HE IS,' 'SHOOT HIM'
description: The recorder tape begins with cabin music from China Airlines Flight 811 shortly after it landed at Manila International Airport last Aug. 21 with the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. among the passengers.

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Arab Group Is Critical Of Mondale and Hart
description: A group of Arab-Americans charged today that Walter F. Mondale and Senator Gary Hart were currying political support from Jewish voters by ''trying to prove their enmity for the Arab people.''

title: Boxer Who Lasts Against All Odds
description: When he was 16 years old, Andres Tena was riding a bicyle in the Bronx and ran into a pillar supporting an elevated subway line. He lost four teeth and badly damaged his right shoulder.

title: RATE DROP SENDS DOW UP BY 20.31
description: Stock prices and trading volume soared yesterday, propelled by declining interest rates and accelerated buying from pension funds and other large institutional accounts.

title: Caps Defeat Devils, Stay in Contention
description: Bob Carpenter and Craig Laughlin had one goal and two assists apiece as the Washington Capitals defeated the Devils, 6-2, tonight and remained in contention for the Patrick Division championship.

title: BROWN UPSET
description: The book on the Indiana Pacers used to be: Concentrate defensively on the front line of Clark Kellogg, Herb Williams and Steve Stipanovich and let the backcourt alone.

title: AT WESTWEEK IN CALIFORNIA, CRISPER DESIGN
description: THE California way of life has always been synonymous with wide-open spaces - and, suitably, a good proportion of the furniture seen last week at Westweek seemed larger than life. The three- day event, at which furniture manufacturers and importers presented new products for offices and homes, was attended by architects and interior designers from across the country. The show, which ended last Saturday, took place at the Pacific Design Center, one of the modern landmarks in Los Angeles.

title: MUSIC: TUCK
description: hand avant-gardisms were the stuff of ''Polarplatz,'' a program Tuesday at Dance Theater Workshop. Andrew Tuck, a pianist, mimicked Keith Jarrett's touch and mannerisms; Scott Lehrer ran electronic devices and played tapes of birds, laughing children and dripping water.

title: The U.N. Today March 29, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: REGAN WON'T 'BEND' RULES ON LATIN LOANS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that ''we're not going to bend the rules'' requiring banks to reduce their profits to reflect delinquent Argentine loans.

title: IF THE CHOICE IS SAFE BORDERS OR DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW TO SPREAD OUR WEALTH OF DOCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: INDOOR POLLUTION IS HIGH
description: A Government study indicates that air pollution may be 10 times worse inside American homes than it is outdoors, the Consumer Product Safety Commission was told today.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A map on March 16 with a dispatch from Bainville, Mont., about the derailment of the westbound Amtrak train Empire Builder, showed an incorrect route across North Dakota. The track runs north from Fargo to Grand Forks, then almost due west across the northern part of the state.

title: CBS REVISING 'MORNING NEWS'
description: ''The CBS Morning News'' will undergo substantial changes in the coming weeks in an attempt to make the program more attractive to the millions of Americans who watch television in the early-morning hours.

title: Judy R. Heuman Marries Bruce Listhaus in Bronx
description: Judy R. Heuman, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Fred S. Heuman of Flatbush, Brooklyn, and Bruce Listhaus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Listhaus of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the Marina Del Rey in the Bronx. The bride's father, rabbi of the Austrian Congregation in New York, and her brother, Rabbi Azriel A. Heuman, officiated, together with Chief Rabbi Pinhas Hirshprung of Montreal and 12 other rabbis.

title: Reasoning Ability of Experts Is Codified for Computer Use
description: Almost no college teaches it, but a new kind of engineering has burst on the American scene. Many people believe it may ultimately exert as profound an influence on the workplace as factory automation did decades ago.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: Christening in the Port

title: THEATER: 'THE ACTORS' DELICATESSEN'
description: CAN any play that begins with an ''Oy'' groaned upward from the soul, even before the lights illuminate the characters, as happens in ''The Actors' Delicatessen,'' which opened Monday at the Provincetown Playhouse, fail to go to the heart of the human condition? Can a show that earnestly and nostalgically recalls old days and old routines from vaudeville and Jewish acts past go wrong? Is life like a glass of tea?

title: SETBACKS FOR WOMEN ARE FOUND IN STUDY OF REAGAN POLICIES
description: Seventy-eight private organizations said today in an analysis of the impact of President Reagan's economic programs that women and children were bearing the brunt of three years of Federal budget cuts.

title: LTV and Republic File Joint Proxy
description: The LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation, which are planning to merge, have filed a joint preliminary proxy statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, an LTV spokesman said.

title: Setback for Vuckovich
description: Pete Vuckovich of the Milwaukee Brewers, the 1982 Cy Young Award winner in the American League, has been trying to make a comeback from last season's rotator-cuff injury. But the shoulder pains are persisting, and yesterday the club placed him on the disabled list and sent him to Milwaukee for medical examination.

title: U.S. PANEL URGING CONGRESS TO ALTER CIVIL RIGHTS POLICY
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights today recommended that Congress allow the Government to penalize an entire institution for unfair discrimination when only part of the institution is found guilty.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: The fourth quarter and year share earnings for both fiscal years reflect a 7 percent stock dividend to be paid June 25.

title: NUCLEAR INDUSTRY IS ASSAILED BY JACKSON AT 3 MILE ISLAND
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson stood in an early morning rain in the shadow of the Three Mile Island atomic plant today and called upon the nuclear power industry to end what he termed a ''callous disregard'' for public rights in the operation of its plants.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
description: 17-Minute Tour

title: T.P.C. Course Is Modified
description: When Tom Weiskopf referred last year to competitive golf on the first Tournament Players Club course as being similar to ''playing inside a pinball machine,'' he was voicing the opinion of the majority of PGA Tour golfers.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Banca Nazionale de Lavoro, Italy's largest bank, issued $100 million of seven-year floating-rate depository receipts through Credit Suisse.

title: OPERA: 'DIMITRI' OFFERED
description: ANTON Dvorak's ''Dimitri'' is a perfect example of a forgotten opera that deserves to be given exposure in concert form, and so it was last night at Carnegie Hall by the Collegiate Chorale under the direction of Robert Bass.Dvorak's is not the first name to spring tomind when we think of composers for the voice, but he was an industrious writer of operas , several of which compare favorably with his best instrumental music. ''Dimitri'' is an especially fascinating work, though less than first-class, and its virtues stood out vividly in this performance , believed to be its American premiere.

title: Small Earthquakes Rock Mount St. Helens
description: Earthquakes rocked Mount St. Helens an average of 10 times an hour Tuesday and scientists said lava could soon emerge, accompanied by small explosions.

title: Cosmos Win, 4-3
description: Even among their devoted fans, there were not many who figured the Cosmos would do well in the indoor season of the North American Soccer League. But the Cosmos won 20 of 32 games in the regular season and tonight they defeated the Chicago Sting, 4-3, in the first game of the playoffs.

title: S.&P. Ratings Up For Boeing Debt
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation raised its ratings on about $550 million of outstanding and proposed long- term debt of the Boeing Company. Senior debt was raised to AA- from Ax and subordinated debt was raised to Ax from A. The rating on the aircraft manufacturer's short-term commercial paper was increased to the highest A-1x from A-1.

title: MONDALE TAKES CAMPAIGN TO QUEENS
description: Walter F. Mondale paid a breakfast visit yesterday to the middle-class homeowner neighborhood of South Jamaica, Queens, where he hopes to collect a substantial number of black votes in the Democratic Presidential primary in New York next Tuesday.

title: HOW WAR POWERS ACT WORKS
description: The War Powers Act of 1973, passed in the aftermath of the Vietnam War, puts limits on the ability of the President to send American troops into combat areas without Congressional approval.

title: TORSTAR CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,192,000 from discontinued operations and a special charge of $4,080,000. c-After a loss of $2,615,000 from discontinued operations and a $3,316,000 special gain.

title: EGYPT PREPARING TO FACE A THREAT
description: Egypt took special precautions today after reports that Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, might order a mass march across the frontier to press his goal of a merger with Egypt, security officials here said.

title: 2 in Bronx Killed In Apartment Fire
description: A man and woman in the Bronx were killed early yesterday when a blaze begun by a toddler playing with a broom that caught fire resumed, the authorities said.

title: JUSTICE ON THE BRINK OF ULTIMATE TRAGEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH DIPLOMAT IS SHOT TO DEATH IN ATHENS
description: An unidentified gunman, believed to be an Arab, killed a British diplomat in his car in downtown Athens today and seriously wounded one of three Greek women riding with him.

title: AN INTERVIEW WITH PRESIDENT REAGAN ON CAMPAIGN QUESTIONS
description: Following are excerpts from a White House transcript of an interview with President Reagan today by Francis X. Clines and Steven R. Weisman:

title: THE SUBTLE CHARMS OF PLATFORM TENNIS
description: Doug Russell is 39 years old and about 6 feet tall and lean and plays platform tennis for a living.

title: 5 in Copter Land In Prospect Park
description: A shuttle helicopter on its way to Kennedy International Airport made a precautionary landing yesterday in Brooklyn's Prospect Park because a malfunctioning panel light indicated the craft was on fire, the police said.

title: Technology; Trading Stock By Computer
description: WHEN Sam Liberto travels, his broker usually tags along - tucked under Mr. Liberto's arm.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SLOW LEARNER. Early Stories. By Thomas Pynchon. 193 pages. Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: RATES DOWN ACROSS THE BOARD
description: After more than two months of trading dominated by rising interest rates and weak investor demand, the credit markets did an about-face yesterday as interest rates fell in all sectors amid signs of improved demand for this week's auctions of Treasury notes and bonds.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA WAR RISK
description: In appealing before Congress this week for an emergency military appropriation of some $100 million for El Salvador, the Reagan Administration has claimed that Central America is a region of vital national interest directly menaced by the expansion of Cuban and Soviet influence. In this and in its broader request for an enormous package of economic aid for the isthmus, the Administration is basing its approach on the report of the Kissinger commission. Before Congress assents, it should understand that this approach sets us firmly on a path toward direct military involvement in the region.

title: Death Toll Rises to 5 In Chilean Protests
description: A teen-age girl died today from a gunshot, raising to five the death toll from anti-Government protests Tuesday.

title: Oil-Merger Curb Rejected by Senate
description: The Senate, after more than eight hours of debate over two days, today rejected legislation that would have placed an 11-month moratorium on mergers of the 50 biggest oil companies.

title: DETENTE IN THE EAST
description: Probably the people most worried about currently bad Soviet-American relations are the Eastern Europeans. They are the ones most pinched when the climate chills.

title: ARBITER CHOSEN TO RUN HEARING ON CHANCELLOR
description: The Board of Education announced yesterday that it planned to ask the city's chief administrative law judge to conduct the board's hearing on misconduct charges against Anthony J. Alvarado, the suspended Schools Chancellor.

title: CARMEN DRAGON, A COMPOSER
description: The composer-conductor Carmen Dragon, who for four decades made music on film, radio, television and records, died of cancer today. He was 69 years old.

title: ROBERTSON SENT TO MINORS
description: Despite Andre Robertson's belief that he is ready to begin the season with the Yankees next Monday, the Yankees decided tonight that he should start the season with their Columbus farm club in Ohio.

title: SURPRISE STORM BRINGS SNOWFALL TO CITY REGION
description: A wind-whipped storm that forecasters described as a springtime freak dumped as much as six inches of snow from Trenton to Poughkeepsie last night, snarling traffic and knocking out electric power in some communities and forcing the cancellation of horse racing at two tracks.

title: VALLEY FORGE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $873,645. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $195,214 and an extraordinary credit of $115,205.

title: HART, IN THE CITY, USES CUOMO THEME
description: Senator Gary Hart invoked ''the family of New York'' theme of Governor Cuomo yesterday, even though the Governor has endorsed Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination and is running his campaign in the state.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Anheuser-Busch Cos ., a St. Louis- based brewer, said its board had approved a plan to repurchase up to 4.8 million shares, or about 10 percent of its shares outstanding, periodically over the next four years.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN NEBRASKA OFFICIAL'S IMPEACHMENT TRIAL
description: The prosecution rested its case today in the impeachment trial of Paul Douglas, the Nebraska Attorney General, and the State Supreme Court rejected his request for acquittal and dismissal of the proceedings.

title: Mr. Meese Should Withdraw
description: If Edwin Meese were magnificently qualified to be Attorney General of the United States, it might be worth keeping his nomination on hold while a special prosecutor decides whether he should be charged with a crime. But he's not.

title: PEP BOYS EXECUTIVE IN EARLY RETIREMENT
description: Pep Boys (Manny, Moe, & Jack), a Philadelphia-based auto parts company, announced yesterday that its president, Morton A. Krause, had resigned for personal reasons. Benjamin Strauss, chairman and chief executive, will assume the duties of president.

title: PRIVATELY PROVIDING PUBLIC SERVICES
description: For the many municipalities facing grave fiscal problems, privatization may be the wave of the future. Wisely, New York City has latched on to the trend.

title: Sony Videodisk Players
description: The Sony Corporation said today that it would start marketing optical-format home videodisk players produced by the Pioneer Electric Corporation under Sony's brand name.

title: Market Place; Uncertainties Faced by MCI
description: THE MCI Communications Corporation,

title: MICHIGAN ROMPS IN N.I.T. FINAL
description: New York belonged last night to the Wolverines of Michigan. With one sweeping 24-4 offensive spurt early in the second half, they went on to defeat Notre Dame by 83-63 and win the National Invitation Tournament championship at Madison Square Garden.

title: AS TRUDEAU, ITS ALLY, LEAVES, BILINGUALISM SUFFERS SETBACK
description: A month after Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau announced that he would resign, his vision of a bilingual Canada has started to unravel.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: Warner Software Goes to D.D.B. Unit
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach's direct- marketing subsidiary Rapp & Collins has been named to handle Warner Software, which as the name would indicate is in the computer field.

title: Landmarks Panel Backs Tower Plan
description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission has unanimously approved a plan to build a 51-story office tower in lower Manhattan by transferring unused development rights from a 148-year-old landmark bank building across the street.

title: BANKS ADD SEABROOK DEMANDS
description: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire said yesterday that the commercial banks providing short-term loans for constructing Unit 1 of the Seabrook nuclear power project had demanded that the utility find back-up sources of credit.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including capital gains of $13,080,000 for the quarter and $107,485,000 for the year. c-Including capital gains of $17,383,000 for the quarter and $27,588,000 for the year.

title: SAINT LAURENT: POLISHED PROFESSIONALISM
description: Yves Saint Laurent presented his usual slick, polished ready-to-wear collection today. The clothes were colorful and varied and the evening segment was especially well done. If the show didn't have the sharp focus and dramatic impact of his fall and winter couture collection introduced two months ago, it was still a crowd pleaser. Mixing familiar themes from the Saint Laurent repertory with some new elements, it contained few hazards. Almost everything worked - and worked beautifully. Saint Laurent is by far the most professional designer here, rivaled only by Valentino of Rome.

title: LACK OF FUNDS IMPERILS ONE-ACT PLAY MARATHON
description: The Ensemble Studio Theater is on the verge of canceling its 1984 marathon of new, one-act plays, one of the major annual events in the Off Broadway season.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PAY-AS-YOU-GO BUDGET PLAN IS APPROVED BY HOUSE PANEL
description: The House Budget Committee today gave final approval to a pay-as-you-go budget plan that would for the first time require the House to match spending increases with equal increases in taxes or spending cuts.

title: Occidental Plans $350 Million Notes
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commissioon for the sale of $350 million of subordinated variable-rate notes through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert.

title: Below the Glasshouse
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Disney Credit
description: Walt Disney Productions said it had reached agreement with Bank of America and 15 other lending institutions to increase its line of credit to $1.3 billion, from $400 million, but continued to withhold information on how the funds would be used. It has been speculated that Disney may be the target of a takeover attempt and that it may seek to acquire another company that would give it substantial debt and make it less attractive to a hostile suitor.

title: LUNDQUIST ON COMEBACK ROAD
description: According to the record book, Steve Lundquist is a wonder - the world champion and record-holder in the 100-meter breast-stroke and the winner of 11 national, seven national collegiate and four Pan American Games swimming titles.

title: I C H CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

description: To the Editor:

title: SPRINGTIME TIPS: SOWING SALAD GREENS
description: IT'S time to think about salad

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
HOUSEHOLD ORGANIZERS
description: THE urge to organize closets and storage space often seems to arrive with spring. Fabrications, 146 East 56th Street, has a collection of storage units that simplify the job. Most come in an assortment of bright colors, among them red, blue, yellow and green, as well as black and white.

title: A Former Marine, 90, Given a Purple Heart
description: A 90-year-old nursing-home resident was awarded a Purple Heart today, almost 70 years after he was wounded during a Marine Corps operation in Haiti.

title: THE BOX-OFFICE FIGHT SANCTION
description: They had arrived without a nod at
