title: McDonnell Wins 2 Navy Contracts
description: The Defense Department said the McDonnell Douglas Astronautics Company had received a $101.4 million contract for cruise-missile equipment for the Navy and McDonnell Douglas received a $25 million contract from the Navy for work on F-18 and A-18 aircraft.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Bridge: A Kibitzer Cannot Applaud Maneuvers He Doesn't See
description: Kibitzers often end a session of expert-watching and say to themselves: ''He did not do anything I could not have done.''

title: TWO DAYS OF TEMPORARY GRANDEUR
description: THIS is a story about a Cinderella loft. It was transformed from an ordinary white- walled, white-floored space to a glamorous antiques-filled environment with jade- green walls and a black ceiling. Then after two days, it was bereft of all but a few pieces, the carpeting and the paint job, leaving its owners with a spruced-up but empty pumpkin.

title: BRINK'S CONVICT IS FOUND GUILTY IN QUEENS SHOOTOUT WITH POLICE
description: A man convicted of conspiracy in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery was found guilty yesterday of six counts of trying to murder police officers in Queens three days after the robbery.

title: Civil Rights Group Imposes Tight Control on State Units
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights voted Tuesday to tightly control the release of reports from the 50 advisory committees that study discrimination in each state. The action was approved by a vote of 4 to 3.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CALENDAR: GARDENING AND INTERIOR DESIGN
description: Three Monday Mornings, Museum of

title: Who'll Mind America's Children?
description: To deny the need for a comprehensive child- care policy is to deny the revolution in American life. Yet the Reagan Administration clings to policies that perpetuate the denial.

title: Phoenix Drops Bid
description: Harry Cavanagh , an attorney who is a member of a group of Phoenix businessmen, says the group has withdrawn its offer to bring the Baltimore Colts to Arizona.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE CHINA TOUCH Among the assortment of college eclectic architecture on the campus of St. John's University, in Jamaica, Queens, at Union Turnpike and Utopia Parkway, is a structure that looks as though it had journeyed through the earth to its present situation. It is a gold and red, classical Chinese- style building atop a campus knoll, the Institute of Asian Studies, which also houses the spacious Chung- Cheng Art Gallery.

title: A SOURCE WHOSE SPECIALTY IS ANTIQUE METAL AND BRASS BEDS
description: ''TWELVE years ago there were a lot of dealers around like us but not anymore,'' says Anthony O'Hara, co-owner of Hob Nail Antiques, a small, ramshackle establishment about 70 miles north of Manhattan in Pawling, N.Y. For Mr. O'Hara and his partner of 17 years, his brother-in-law Jerry Winrow, the stacks of tarnished and rusty metal bedsteads crowding the shop's front yard and lending it a certain ''Tobacco Road'' ambiance are the results of years of stockpiling.

title: Comsat May Sell Its Interest
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation said today that it has been discussing the idea of reducing or selling its one-third interest in Satellite Business Systems.

title: Dissident Holder Is Suing Enstar
description: Roy M. Huffington, a Houston oilman who owns 8.5 percent of Enstar Inc., said he had sued the oil and gas company in Delaware Chancery Court for changing its annual meeting date to June 21, from May 24, contending that the revision helped directors enrich themselves.

title: WNCN TO OFFER CARNEGIE CONCERTS
description: ''A.T.&T. Presents Carnegie Hall Tonight,'' a new series of weekly, one-hour, nationwide radio broadcasts of taped live performances, will begin next week, executives of the hall and A.T.&T. announced yesterday.

title: MGF Debt Plan
description: The MGF Oil Corporation said it would defer filing its 10-K annual report for 1983 pending completion of negotiations with its secured lenders related to the restructuring of $156 million of secured bank debt. MGF also said that if the negotiations were successfully concluded, it expected to present a debt restructuring plan to its unsecured creditors.

title: No Headline
description: White House Reviews Use of U.S. Limousines

title: THOUSANDS MOURN DEATH OF TOURE
description: Thousands of mourners reportedly crowded the airport at Conakry, the capital of Guinea, today as the body of President Ahmed Sekou Toure arrived from the United States, where he died on Monday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;
description: Flow General Fills Post of President

title: A NATURAL-HISTORY MUSEUM OF THE MIND
description: Years hence, if there is a grand museum here - an exhibition hall of natural history near a pond with an outdoor patio and wide galleries and a collection that is the envy of universities nationwide - those who reflect on its beginnings will probably remember the great white fiberglass shark, the blue-footed boobies in silver frames and Carl W. Rettenmeyer, who gave up chasing army ants because he wanted to have some fun.

title: Y.& R. Unit's New Chairman
description: Gerald I. Wood, 42-year-old

title: No Headline
description: Plea to Dismiss Counts Against Judge Rejected

title: Yields Up On C.D.'s
description: Annual effective yields on six- month certificates of deposit and money market accounts showed sharp rises across the country yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor said.

title: High Nicaraguan Aide To Visit Soviet Union
description: Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra will leave Thursday for the Soviet Union and North Korea, a spokesman said today. He said no details were available about the duration or purpose of the trip.

title: 10 Die in Sri Lanka As Troops Fire at Crowd
description: Sri Lanka Air Force troops fired on a Tamil crowd in a northern town today, killing at least 10 people and wounding 25, official sources said.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Detroit Pistons , at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 8:05 P.M. The Pistons continue battling Milwaukee for the Central Division lead.

title: Congressmen and Activists Ask a Halt to Space Testing
description: The United States should stop testing antisatellite weapons and research into a futuristic defensive shield against nuclear attack, a group of Congressmen and arms control activists said today.

title: THURSDAY, MARCH 29, 1984 International
description: A dispute over the War Powers Act has deeply divided members of Congress and the Reagan Administration. A Republican Senator said that some leaders of the Senate and White House officials had discussed petitioning the Supreme Court to rule on the constitutionality of the disputed statute. (Page A1, Column 1.) At least 18 Lebanese were killed and more than 100 were wounded as heavy, random shelling of civilian neighborhoods erupted in a wide area of Beirut. The shells, fired by Christian and Moslem militiamen, crashed into apartment blocks and onto the streets and sent terrified residents racing for cover. (A1:2.)

title: MUSIC: JOSEPH SMITH
description: IN playing Brahms's Opus 39

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH most municipal systems provide an adequate water supply, many communities have water with an undesirable taste, color or odor or water that is never as clear and pure as it should be. Even in localities where the water usually tastes fine and looks clear, repairs or breakdowns can introduce odor-causing chemicals or undesirable sediment.

title: DEMOCRAT SAYS SENATE WILL APPROVE SALVADOR AID
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy declared today that the Senate ''should not be stampeded'' into ratifying Reagan Administration policies toward Central America. But another influential Democrat, Daniel K. Inouye of Hawaii, predicted that the Senate would vote nearly $62 million in emergency military aid for El Salvador this week.

title: Hazzard Is Happy
description: '' John Wooden made this a very difficult job, but I don't mind being in it. In fact, I love sitting here right now.''

title: NIELSEN, A C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
MUSIC: HATTIE WINSTON
description: HATTIE WINSTON, who is currently appearing on Broadway in ''The Tap Dance Kid,'' is a boldly dramatic pop-gospel singer who, whenever the choice presents itself between sounding pretty or making a grand theatrical gesture, will almost always do the latter.

title: A SEQUEL TO 'GODUNOV'
description: Of Anton Dvorak's operas, only ''Rusalka'' has gained anything like a foothold in the international repertory, although ''Kate and the Devil'' and ''The Jacobin'' also are known to enthusiasts of Central European opera.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The caption yesterday under a front-page picture of Senator Gary Hart on Long Island incorrectly described the E-2C Hawkeye airplane built by the Grumman Aerospace Corporatiion. It is propeller-driven.

title: Side Effects of an Acne Drug Prompt Warning to Doctors
description: Hoffmann-La Roche Inc. is issuing another warning to doctors and patients saying a drug that combats severe acne could have harmful side effects, especially for pregnant women, company officials said today.

title: 3 Shiite Protesters Killed
description: A pro-Israeli Lebanese military unit today fired into a crowd of Shiite demonstrators in a village in occupied southern Lebanon, killing three people and wounding 10, Israeli military sources said.

title: Cookie Tampering Query Is Joined by F.B.I.
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today joined the Food and Drug Administration in a nationwide investigation of apparent malicious tampering with Girl Scout cookies.

title: WHEN THE FAMOUS ARE EXTRAS
description: HALSTON said he came because he used to make hats for Greta Garbo. John Lindsay said he came ''to help the film business in this town.''

title: U.S. OFFICIALS URGE MORE AID TO HELP THE SUDAN
description: Reagan Administration officials urged Congress today to continue the flow of economic and military aid to the Sudan, warning that the Government there faced serious economic problems and military threats from neighboring Libya and Ethiopia.

title: 9 NEW PLAYS AT LOUISVILLE FESTIVAL
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

title: Neuharth to Get Award
description: Allen Neuharth, the chairman of the Gannett Company, will receive the first Annual Communication Award from the Center for Communication on April 5 at a luncheon in the Plaza Hotel. The award is in particular recognition of Mr. Neuharth's role in introducing USA Today, which the center called ''the nation's first national newspaper designed for the general public.'' The center describes itself as a forum in which university students and professors can exchange information with communications professionals.

title: A NEW ERA FOR COACH OF VIRGINIA
description: The suggestion was first made a little over a year ago, after one of the saddest times for the basketball team at the University of Virginia. Terry Holland, the coach of the Cavaliers, was standing in the bright lights in Ogden, Utah, discussing the end of an era.

title: A Filing by Parent Of Texas Utilities
description: The Texas Utilities Electric Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of $100 million of first mortgage bonds due in 2014 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: JUNO LIGHTING reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
HERS
description: SPRING brings many good things: baseball, daffodils, longer days and lower heating bills. Yet I greet it with ambivalence. For when the daffodils bloom windows open and the silence of winter is gone, the sound of stereo is heard in the land.

title: Elly Ameling Master Class
description: The soprano Elly Ameling will give a master class April 7 at 2 P.M. in the Hayden Auditorium of Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street. The class is open to the public for $7. For information: 242-4770.

title: Shell Expected To Reject Bid
description: The Shell Oil Company is expected to reject as inadequate a $5.2 billion takeover bid from the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, Wall Street analysts said yesterday. They said the rejection was expected soon after a Shell Oil board meeting today.

title: DANCE: BUCKET TROUPE
description: GARTH FAGAN's Bucket Dance Theater roared into the Joyce Theater on Tuesday for a week's engagement, and the audience responded as if it were famished for dance. There's plenty of that around New York City these days. But the 11 Bucket dancers perform with extraordinary warmth and commitment. And Mr. Fagan has a choreographic style that is entirely his own.

title: RECALLING A QUIXOTIC RACE FOR MAYOR
description: Only three men have carried the Republican banner into an election for Mayor since the District of Columbia won limited home rule from Congress 10 years ago.

title: PANDERING FOR VOTES
description: Walter Mondale and Gary Hart are slugging it out right now on one key issue: who can do the most for Israel. Each promises to move the American Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem if elected. Though both have been admirably faithful in their support for Israel over the years, each accuses the other of perfidy.

title: IRAQ IS IMPROVING LINKS TO BOTH U.S. AND SOVIET
description: Diplomats say Iraq has performed the difficult feat of improving relations with Washington while also repairing a strain with Moscow.

title: Judith Baum Marries Neil Halpern, Doctor
description: Judith Baum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Baum of Antwerp, Belgium, was married yesterday to Dr. Neil A. Halpern, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. David Halpern of Brooklyn. The bridegroom's father, rabbi of the Flatbush Park Jewish Center in Brooklyn, officiated at the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. He was assisted by Dr. Bernard Lander, president of Touro College, and Rabbi Israel Miller, vice president of Yeshiva University.

title: F.C.C. TO REEXAMINE PHONE PROFITS
description: The Federal Communications Commission disclosed late today that it would re-examine and possibly lower the authorized rate of return, or profit margin, that it established in 1981 for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN MILITARY OUTLAYS TO GROW
description: South Africa announced a 21.4 percent increase today in military spending for the coming year and said hopes of a cut because of regional peace initiatives would be ''unrealistic.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Top Tampa Yield 9.8%
description: About $39 million of Tampa Performing Arts Center bonds were offered yesterday, priced with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.4 percent in 1999 and a maximum yield of 9.8 percent for bonds due in 2008, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company. Proceeds of the issue will be used partly to pay for the design, construction and equipping of an arts center to be built in downtown Tampa, Fla.

title: A SPACE FOR FABRIC
description: IT'S a surprisingly spare and

title: 'ARAFAT'S CARD' IS HELPING TO BUILD GREATER ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSIT AND HOUSING POLICE SET UP CIVILIAN PANELS
description: New Civilian Complaint Review Boards - nearly identical to the one that monitors the New York Police Department - have been created in the Transit and Housing Police Departments, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Steroid-Cancer Tie Seen By The Associated Press A 26-year-old weight lifter who took anabolic steroids to help build

title: Right Motivation
description: Helen Carroll, the women's basketball coach at the University of North Carolina at Asheville, says a hustling defense and strong psychological motivation from the coach can produce a winning basketball team.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We did not burn the churches. We haven't closed the factories.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS A LOAN TO KEEP YONKERS GOING
description: Governor Cuomo today offered to advance Yonkers enough money to keep it from running out of cash in May, but only if the city accepted an emergency financial control board to supervise its finances.

title: Supreme Court Refuses To Bar Louisiana Vote
description: The Supreme Court today refused to block a court order forcing Louisiana to hold a Presidential primary May 5.

title: WAR POWERS TEST BY SUPREME COURT WEIGHED IN SENATE
description: Some Senate leaders and White House officials have discussed petitioning the Supreme Court to rule on the constitutionality of the War Powers Act in the aftermath of the Lebanon crisis, a Republican senator said today.

title: White House Fence May Be Strengthened
description: The Federal authorities, alarmed by recent near breaches of security, told a House subcommittee today that they were studying new ways of protecting the White House.

title: ON THE 'ROAR OF MICE' IN THE PRESIDENTIAL SELECTION PROCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Olympic Plea Pushed
description: Renaldo Nehemiah , the San Francisco 49er wide receiver who was once the world's top high hurdler, has renewed his legal effort to compete in the Olympics this summer.

title: Nautilus Museum
description: Ground-breaking ceremonies were held today for the Nautilus submarine museum and memorial.

title: No Headline
description: House Supports Funds For U.S. Space Station

title: FUTURES/OPTIONS Precious Metals Gain As Funds Rate Drops
description: Precious metals and interest-rate futures were buoyed today by a drop in the Federal funds rate, the rate at which banks lend money to one another.

title: AN ARGENTINE MINISTER KNOWN FOR: BERNARDO GRINSPUN BLUNT TALK
description: Bernardo Grinspun, Economics Minister of Argentina, is known as an unusually blunt speaker. Earlier this week, at the annual meeting of the Inter-American Development Bank in Punta del Este, Uruguay, he lived up to his reputation. When reporters asked about United States regulations that may force American banks to reduce their first-quarter earnings to reflect payments overdue from Argentina, Mr. Grinspun replied sharply: ''Banks' accounting problems are not the obligation of this Government.''

title: Clips of Jewish History
description: So many guests showed up Tuesday

title: Bonn Party Demands Ban on Nazi Reunions
description: West Germany's leading opposition party today demanded a ban on Nazi reunions, and European Jewish groups announced that they would join a demonstration outside a reunion this weekend.

title: HAWAII'S SEARCH FOR BUSINESS
description: The whalers, the Pacific traders, the sugar planters, the Navy and the tourists have all had their influence on Hawaii's economy. Now tourism, a business that brought more than four million visitors to the islands and poured nearly $4 billion into the economy last year, is maturing and slowing down.

title: JUDGE SENTENCES LAWYER WHO FLED
description: A judge sentenced Mary Evans, a lawyer, to three years in prison today because she refused to apologize for engineering the escape of a killer she said she believed could rid her of demons that had beset her since childhood.

title: Chilean Exile Is Suicide
description: A Chilean seeking refugee status committed suicide before he was to testify at an immigration hearing. The Chilean, Raul Rivadeneira, hanged himself on Monday and left a note asking that his lawyer, John House, send his belongings to his wife and four- year-old son in Chile. Mr. House said Mr. Rivadeneira was dreading the prospect of recounting the torture he was subjected to after being arrested during the military coup in 1973.

title: PRODIGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $32,000 for the year from discontinued operations and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $65,000 for the quarter and $183,000 for the year. c-Net income including gains from discontinued operations of $5,000 for the quarter and $35,000 for the year and extraordinary credits of $4,000 for the quarter and $21,500 for the year.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income.

title: Republicbank's Adjustable Stock
description: The Republicbank Corporation of Dallas is selling 750,000 shares of adjustable-rate preferred stock with an initial dividend rate of 10.40 percent at a price of $100 a share through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: WYOMING GAS UTILITIES FACE CONSUMER REVOLT
description: It started with some City Council members wondering if the local gas company would give Casper a break on its municipal gas purchases, and it may end in a consumer revolt against high natural gas prices across one of the country's biggest gas-producing states.

title: LLOYD WEBBER MUSICAL OPENS
description: After weeks of ballyhoo and a reported expenditure of more than $2 million on the sets alone, the composer Andrew Lloyd Webber's new musical, ''Starlight Express,'' opened Tuesday night to decidedly mixed notices.

title: GAYLORDS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
DEMOCRATS PICK OTTINGER'S AIDE TO REPLACE HIM
description: Westchester Democratic district leaders, meeting in convention, took six hours and four ballots early today to endorse a candidate to replace Representative Richard L. Ottinger, who is retiring this year. They chose Oren J. Teicher, a former aide who ran Mr. Ottinger's campaigns.

title: CONCERT: NEW ORCHESTRA OF BOSTON IN TULLY HALL
description: AFTER writing, a few years ago, about the powerful connections between mathematical and musical activity, I received passionate objections from a number of correspondents who were outraged that anything as supple, as emotive and as humanly intricate as music should be spoken of in the same breath with the rigid laws, arcane facts and logical progressions of mathematics. But mathematics, and any sufficiently deep scientific research, is also an esthetic activity, with its own cadences, phrases, modulations, beauty and charm; and music bears within its fabric mathematical logic and combinatorial regulations, matters given and matters to be proved - a universe out of which sense is to be made.

title: METZENBAUM'S SLEUTH IN THE MEESE CASE
description: On the day two weeks ago that Senate Democrats called for additional hearings on Edwin Meese 3d's nomination to become Attorney General, a reporter caught up with Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum and asked to see the list of witnesses the Democrats would seek to summon.

title: MCGOVERN TO DO 'SATURDAY NIGHT'
description: For George McGovern the year 1984 has meant, if nothing else, a change of public image, the former South Dakota Senator and his aides have said. Despite dropping out from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Mr. McGovern has emerged, in his opinion, as a respected senior statesman of his party.

title: GOV. LAMM ASSERTS ELDERLY, IF VERY ILL, HAVE 'DUTY TO DIE'
description: Elderly people who are terminally ill have a ''duty to die and get out of the way'' instead of trying to prolong their lives by artificial means, Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado said Tuesday.

title: Shultz Acknowledges 'Mess' in Cairo Project
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz acknowledged today that a plan to build a new ambassador's residence in Cairo had turned into ''a mess'' that will end up costing nearly $4.5 million, about double the original estimate.

title: Carolina Agency's Offering Modified
description: A $325 million issue of North Carolina Eastern Municipal Power Agency bonds was modified by underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham to increase slightly the yield on some long-term bonds and to adjust the size of some maturities.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES' DEBATE IN NEW YORK
description: Following is a transcript of a Democratic Presidential debate at Columbia University last night by Senator Gary Hart, Walter F. Mondale and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of CBS News. Dan Rather, the CBS News anchor, was the moderator.

title: 8 GET PRESENT TENSE AWARDS
description: Eight authors of books on Jewish themes published during 1983 yesterday received the $1,000 Kenneth B. Smilen Present Tense Literary Awards, sponsored by the American Jewish Committee and Present Tense magazine, a journal of Jewish public affairs. The winners were: Fiction: Aharon Appelfeld, for ''Tzili: The

description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: THEATER: POETRY PAIR
description: THE Talking Band, a collaborative ensemble of artists and musicians that grew out of Joseph Chaikin's Open Theater in the mid-1970's, specializes in performance collages that attempt to synthesize texts with vocal and instrumental sounds into a non-narrative theatrical poetry. The scope of the ensemble's ambitions is suggested by the revivals of two pieces being presented in repertory at La Mama through April 8.

title: CONTROL LASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SERVED AS INSPIRATION TO DR. KING
description: Dr. Benjamin E. Mays, a nationally known educator who was an early champion of the civil rights movement, died in an Atlanta hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: STAGE: ''ALL NIGHT LONG''
description: THE SECOND STAGE is one of the most exciting companies to emerge Off Broadway in recent seasons. During its brief existence, it has given New York exemplary productions of such vivid plays as ''How I Got That Story,'' ''My Sister in This House,'' ''Pastorale,'' ''Painting Churches'' and, this season, Lanford Wilson's ''Serenading Louie.''

title: POTATO FARMS PLOWED UNDER BY EASTERN L.I. GROWTH
description: After farming this loamy soil for a century, the Demarest family have called it quits.

description: Film Industry Veteran New Chief of Four Star

title: No Headline

title: CONCERT: SOME RECENT COMPOSITIONS
description: SEVERAL years ago, a man in New Orleans gave composers commissions to write quiet music. He felt that something soothing to listen to was needed in our troubled times. That man would have liked Robert Moran's ''Lullaby,'' a work of 1982 that was given its first New York performance in Cooper Union Tuesday night by an organization named Musical Elements.

title: WOLF, HOWARD B, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $10,299 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $28,060.

title: SHAMIR-PERES CONTEST SEEN
description: After a week of negotiation and compromise, the governing Likud bloc and the opposition Labor Party agreed today on July 23 as the date for new parliamentary elections.

description: b-Including tax credits of $10,000 for the quarter and $29,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $810,000 for the quarter and $1,350,000 for the 6 months and a tax credit of $143,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: COLECO TO LAY OFF 1,300 AND TRIM ADAM OUTPUT
description: Coleco Industries said yesterday that it was cutting back production of its Adam computer and laying off 1,300 employees at the upstate New York plants where the product is made.

title: FINAL ACCORD SET ON STATE BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo announced tonight that he had reached agreement with the legislative leaders on a budget of more than $35 billion.

title: Heights Finance
description: The Heights Finance Corporation said it had acquired 17 branches in Wisconsin from the Thorp Finance Corporation for $70 million in receivables. The sale involves loans and installment contracts.

title: B.A.T Profits Up 14%
description: B.A.T Industries P.L.C., a diversified British tobacco group, said today that strong profits in retail and other businesses offset falling tobacco-related income in 1983, raising its profit to $1.41 billion, up 14 percent from 1982. Revenue rose 3 percent, to $17 billion.

title: A 2-TIERED TRUCKING SYSTEM
description: Richard S. Apple, the president of the Central Storage and Transfer Company, remembers clearly the financial beating he took when truck freight rates collapsed as the industry exploded with new entrants after it was deregulated in 1980.

title: CENTRAL PARK VOLUNTEERS
description: Community groups and individuals who want to help maintain and restore Central Park can sign up for a one-day-a-week program beginning April 25, sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy.

title: SALVADOR TALLY MOUNTING SLOWLY
description: The Elections Council today continued its slow work of counting the votes from the presidential elections as a right-wing death squad threatened its members.

title: 'SCANDALS' ON CINEMAX, IN AN AFTER-HOURS CLUB
description: CABLE television is having a devil of a time trying to be adult. What used to be called the new permissiveness, and is now reaching a meaningless plateau of just-about-anything-goes, has escalated the battle to see which entertainment medium can claim to be the most ''mature.'' That's the buzz word for what used to be simple prurience.

title: ISRAEL VIEW OF EMBASSY ISSUE
description: Israeli officials have applauded suggestions that the United States Embassy be moved from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, but they attributed the effort to election-year politics in the United States and do not expect that the embassy will be moved.

title: LawyersWinFees On Silent Minute
description: A Federal judge today ordered the State Legislature to pay nearly $82,000 in lawyers' fees and expenses incurred by the American Civil Liberties Union in successfully challenging New Jersey's moment-of-silence law.

title: Required Reading; Death Wish?
description: Representative Buddy Roemer, Democrat of Louisiana, in remarks to the House:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Air Florida, Miami, has named H. Charles Wedel executive vice president, Ann Yanulavich vice president/personnel and labor relations, Robert Reding vice president/flight operations, Robin J. Cohn staff vice president/public relations, Ron Clark staff vice president/domestic sales and services, Michael Brooks staff vice president/Latin American/Caribbean sales and services and Paul Rishell staff vice president/ reservations sales and services.

title: ON THE DAY OF THE BIG STORM, FLOODS, ANGER AND RESIGNATION
description: Long before the hearty voice of the radio announcer. Well before the the first lifting of the blinds. As if part of a dream, the sound seeps into the waking consciousness, a portent of the day to come: Scrape. Scrape. Scrape.

title: M.T.A. TO BUY 400 NEW BUSES FOR $68 MILLION
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to spend $68 million to buy 400 new buses. The decision is part of a plan to replace the 851 Grumman Flxible buses taken out of service last month for safety reasons.

title: Narragansett Deal
description: The Narragansett Capital Corporation said it had agreed to merge into Narragansett Capital Associates, a partnership formed by management, for $50 a share.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Poignant Anniversary

title: Trader Admits Shelter Fraud
description: A securities trader pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to Federal charges that he helped carry out a vast tax-shelter fraud involving Sentinel Government Securities. The trader, John G. Lane, was president of Gill & Duffus Securities Inc. of 67 Wall Street, which traded in money market securities.

title: Film on Spanish War
description: ''The Good Fight,'' a feature film by Noel Buckner, Mary Dore and Sam Sills will be shown through April 10 at Film Forum, 57 Watts Street.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Party Gains in Parliament
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's governing Congress-I Party gained 20 seats in indirect elections for the upper house of India's Parliament today, bringing the party close to a two-thirds majority needed to institute constitutional changes.

title: TWO COACHES, ONE TEAM
description: LOS ANGELESWhen Sonja Hogg was asked to start a women's basketball team at Louisiana Tech 10 years ago, she was a physical education teacher who had never coached basketball or even played the game on an interscholastic level.

title: B. Kenneth Anthony, 77, Dies; United Church of Christ Aide
description: The Rev. B. Kenneth Anthony, former general secretary of the Division of World Service of the United Church of Christ's Board for World Ministries, died of a stroke Tuesday at the Pilgrim Place Health Center in Claremont, Calif. He was 77 years old and lived in Claremont.

title: Florida Opposes K Mart C.D. Sale
description: Florida's Comptroller, Gerald Lewis, again moved to prevent the K Mart Corporation from selling certificates of deposit at three Florida stores. Mr. Lewis filed a cease and desist order, sayng the sales violated Florida law because K Mart had not applied to his office to become a licensed broker.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $878,000 for the quarter and $621,000 for the year and extraordinary credits of $56,000 for the quarter and $5,747,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $835,000 for the quarter and $3,446,000 for the year and extraordinary credits of $1,960,000 for the quarter and $24,192,000 for the year.

title: FRIDAY, MARCH 30, 1984 International
description: U.S. reconnaissance planes are providing almost instant intelligence on rebel movements before and during combat operations, according to the commander of Salvadoran forces battling insurgents in the eastern part of the country. Washington has said the reconnaissance missions were stepped up to look for rebels who might try to disrupt the country's elections. (Page A1, Column 1.) Iraq has used nerve gas in its war with Iran and is nearing completion of up to five extensive sites for the mass production of the lethal chemical warfare agent, according to United States intelligence officials. They said they had obtained what they believe to be incontrovertible evidence of the findings. (A1:2.)

title: A Premier of Bangladesh Named by Military Ruler
description: Lieut. Gen. H. M. Ershad, the nation's military ruler, today appointed the leader of a small political party as the Prime Minister.

title: Bridge
description: At national championship tournaments, knockout team play has generally been the prerogative of the top- ranked players, who feel thay have a chance to do well in the Vanderbilt or Spingold events. Those with less experience or talent have had to be content with Swiss team events.

title: Guerrilla Is Killed In Santiago Gunfight
description: A leftist guerrilla was killed and a policeman was wounded today when a gunfight erupted in the capital, the Government press agency said.

title: Rematch Recalls Darling's Big Day
description: When Ron Darling starts tonight in an exhibition game for the Mets against Frank Viola of the Minnesota Twins, it will be the first encounter between the two young pitchers since their memorable meeting in the 1981 National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

description: b-There are no comparable year- ago resuls because the company went public last year.

description: Brian Kelley, the Giant linebacker, was traded to the San Diego Chargers yesterday for an undisclosed choice in the National Football League's draft May 1.

title: MEDALS OUTNUMBER G.I.'S IN GRENADA ASSAULT
description: Army officials said today that about 50 of the achievement medals went to personnel who got no closer to the fighting than the Pentagon.

title: MARATHON WILL BUY HUSKY UNIT
description: The Marathon Oil Company and Husky Oil Ltd. of Canada announced yesterday that they had reached a definitive agreement for Marathon to buy Husky's United States subsidiary, the Husky Oil Company, for $505 million in cash.

description: 'Inside Story' Views Argentina's Press

title: ATICO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Tank Parts Are Seized; Reported Bound for Iran
description: Customs agents have seized $7 million worth of tank parts bound for Iran in a rail yard and at the headquarters of a small exporting company, the authorities said.

title: NEW WEST 84TH ST. RENTAL APARTMENTS
description: Long ago, at 215 West 84th Street, the Borden Milk Company had a dairy. When it left, it left behind a decorative eagle in stone relief above the building's entrance.

title: ETHICAL CONFLICTS IN BUSINESS JOURNALISM
description: The disclosure that a Wall Street Journal reporter may have given some stock traders a jump on the market by disclosing the contents of coming articles provides an example of a problem that editors usually treat as purely hypothetical. In interviews yesterday, news executives said instances of reporters' bending the rules to make money for themselves or friends were once-in- a-decade occurrences - there was a case at Time magazine in 1961 and one at The Los Angeles Herald-Examiner in 1972. But they agreed that some instances might be unreported because there was no effective way to monitor the private interests of business writers.

title: Kelly Award to D.D.B. For Weight Watchers
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach, which had four print campaigns among the 11 finalists chosen for the third annual Stephen E. Kelly Award of the Magazine Publishers Association, took the top prize of $25,000 with its effort for Weight Watchers.

LOUIS SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, Leonard Slatkin, conductor, Carnegie Hall, 8. JOHN DENVER, Radio City Music Hall, 8.

MONDALE SAYS HE IS FRIEND OF CITIES
description: Walter F. Mondale told a friendly panel of big-city mayors yesterday that he had been ''up front fighting'' for cities while his principal opponent for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Gary Hart, had ''turned his back.''

title: ART: OPEN JURIED SHOW AT ACADEMY OF DESIGN
description: AS anyone familiar with a cross section of New York galleries knows, a great many artists are pursuing their own paths independent of trends, fashion and the tradition of the new. There is a need for places where young or unknown artists working in directions that are excluded by alternative spaces and the vicissitudes of the marketplace can show, sell and test their work against the success of others.

Stocks End Mixed; Dow Off by 3.87
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday when hopes faded for a further easing of interest rates.
