MOOD TO TRADE NETTLES GROWS
description: Toby Harrah, one of the Yankees' several third basemen, would like Graig Nettles to remain part of the group, but others in the organization are eager to have the team trade its captain before the start of the season.

title: THE MEESE MESS
description: The nominee for Attorney General is making a vigorous defense of his probity. Ed Meese has vowed to ''pursue the vindication of my name, the honor of my family and the confidence of the President.''

title: FILM: 'GREYSTOKE,' TARZAN IN AFRICA AND ENGLAND
description: FROM the most unlikely source material comes the season's most unexpected, most invigorating surprise, ''Greystoke: the Legend of Tarzan, Lord of the Apes,'' a huge, lavishly produced period film that is part adventure, part comedy of manners and part somber melodrama.

title: Stocks Plunge In Hong Kong
description: Share prices plunged today following the surprise announcement late Wednesday that Jardine, Matheson & Company had decided to become a Bermuda holding company, because of political uncertainty over Hong Kong's future. But the stock market closed above the day's lowest levels.

title: 'BROAD' INQUIRY ON MEESE PLANNED
description: The independent counsel to investigate Edwin Meese 3d should conduct a ''broad inquiry,'' the presiding judge of the selection panel said today.

title: Nets Defeat Pistons
description: This was a change. After winning so many games during their recent surge by playing tough, stingy defense in the final minutes, the Nets suffered a rare fourth-quarter collapse against the Detroit Pistons tonight and saw a 9-point lead disappear in the last five minutes.

title: WHAT THEY DID IN JERSEY WHEN SEA CAME CALLING
description: Steve Henderson looked out of his Ocean Avenue apartment in nearby Sea Bright yesterday and realized that the Atlantic Ocean was no longer across the street, behind a sea wall. It was all around him.

title: A Computer Show
description: A personal-computer show begins today at Madison Square Garden, and continues through Sunday.

title: THE POISONS OF YPRES
description: To the Editor:

title: John Denver Concert
description: The singer John Denver will appear in concert at Radio City Music Hall, the Avenue of the Americas and 50th Street, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets, $20 to $25, may be purchased at the box office, Ticketron outlets or by calling Chargit, 944-9300, or Teletron, 947- 5850.

title: TORNADOES KILL 60 OVER WIDE AREAS OF THE CAROLINAS
description: At least 60 people were killed and hundreds injured by a string of tornadoes that roared through the small towns and greening countryside of the Carolinas Wednesday night.

title: Gotham Stakes Off for Week;  Storm Puts Track in Bad Shape
description: ''I can train a horse to run but I can't train the rain to stop,'' Woody Stephens said yesterday after being told by Aqueduct officials that the Gotham Stakes, a key Kentucky Derby prep in which Stephens will saddle Devil's Bag, has been postponed from tomorrow until April 7 because of sloppy track conditions.

title: Buckner's Reaction
description: Bill Buckner says that if all the Chicago Cubs need him for is pinch-hitting, ''that means this team must be a pennant winner.'' ''I'll collect my paycheck and sit on the bench,'' the first baseman said after a trade the Cubs made with the Philadelphia Phillies that apparently relegates Buckner to a part-time role with Chicago.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
description: b-Net income.

title: Advertising; Moving Up In Direct Marketing
description: EMILY SOELL and Bruce L. Albert, who were both promoted to executive vice president at Rapp & Collins last September, yesterday were designated as ''second generation management'' by Stan Rapp, founder and worldwide chairman and chief executive. He announced that Miss Soell had been named president and executive creative director and Mr. Albert vice chairman and chief operating officer, both of the domestic company.

title: Emigre Dancers
description: Anachnu Kan, a 100-member Russian-emigre dance troupe from Israel - the name means ''We are here'' - will perform tomorrow at 9 P.M. in the Hunter College Assembly Hall, 695 Park Avenue, at 68th Street. Tickets, $10 to $15, may be purchased at the door an hour before the show or by calling 736-4477.

title: JUDGE FINDS I.B.M. IS NOT GUILTY OF DISCRIMINATION AGINST BLACKS
description: The employee promotion system of the International Business Machines Corporationdoes not discriminate against black professionals and is a ''standard for the industry,'' a Federal district judge ruled here today.

title: Israel's Minister of Science Deplores Chemical Warfare
description: Israel's Minister of Science and Development says allegations of Iraqi use of chemical warfare against Iran should be of concern to Israelis.

title: State Schedules Spring Borrowing
description: New York State's spring note borrowing, traditionally the largest tax- exempt financing of the year, is scheduled for the week of April 9 and will total about $4.3 billion, according to the State Comptroller's office.

title: Thais Report Capture Of 40 Vietnamese
description: The army command said today that Thai troops had captured 40 Vietnamese soldiers and retrieved five bodies after battling a battalion-size force that crossed into Thailand from Cambodia Sunday in pursuit of guerrillas loyal to the Communist Government that was ousted in 1979.

title: JACKSON URGES A NEW COURSE FOR U.S.
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said yesterday that his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination were not advancing a needed ''redirection'' on a host of domestic and foreign policies.

title: ANOTHER BOOST FOR PAN-AMERICAN FUSION MUSIC
description: THE Brazilian percussionist Airto Moreira made his first concert appearances and recording with Miles Davis's influential electric-jazz band almost 15 years ago. With the help of hindsight, we can now see clearly that this event, more than any other, signaled the beginning of the Latin-jazz fusion, as it is understood today.

title: New Policy on E.P.A. Fines
description: Corporations found guilty of pollution may be fined as much as they made by violating the environmental laws under a new enforcement policy announced today by the Environmental Protection Agency. Courtney Price, the environmental agency's assistant administrator for enforcement and compliance, said the new policy was designed to serve as a deterrent while providing ''fair and equitable treatment'' of regulated companies.

title: Argentine Roulette
description: Argentina and its creditors, the largest of them American banks, are playing chicken with that nation's imminent default on interest payments. They may think that is shrewd bargaining, but they're not the only ones that stand to be seriously hurt.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $625,000.

title: 3 Frenchmen describe their U.S. ventures.
description: -man movie industry is branching out: Gerard Depardieu is one of the producers of ''Les Comp eres'' as well as one of its stars. Mr. Depardieu's D. D. Productions shares a producing credit with Fideline Films, the company of his co-star Pierre Richard, and with Efve Films, the company of the screenwriter and director Francis Veber. All three were in New York last week to attempt something they say is often difficult: making a French film a success with American audiences.

title: STORM BATTERS EAST WITH SNOW, WIND AND FLOODS
description: The East's biggest storm of the year battered the metropolitan area with snow, sleet, hail and hurricane-force winds yesterday, disrupting travel, commerce, education and the lives of hundreds of thousands of people.

title: PARISIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
Drunken Seamen Start a Fire On Soviet Fish-Factory Ship
description: The newspaper Trud said today that drunken seamen trying to cover up a binge had started a 12-hour blaze that gutted a Soviet factory ship in the Sea of Japan, 90 miles from Vladivostok.

title: Nuclear Blast in Soviet
description: The Hagfors Observatory, which is run by a branch of the Swedish Defense Ministry, today reported a presumed underground nuclear blast in the Soviet testing ground west of Semipalatinsk in eastern Kazakhstan.

title: SCOUTING Salute to Smith
description: Red Smith, the former sports columnist for The New York Times who died on Jan. 15, 1982, always seemed to enjoy the arrival of April. The opening of the trout-fishing season, the start of the major league baseball season and the final weeks of preparation for Kentucky Derby hopefuls were often noted with pleasure and grace in the columns that won a Pulitzer Prize for Mr. Smith in 1976.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Golden Nugget Inc. said it planned a debt offering of up to $200 million in principal amount to help finance the construction and opening of a second hotel in Atlantic City.

title: U.S. Workers Fight Bar To Campaign Buttons
description: A Federal employees' union filed a suit Wednesday against the Department of Housing and Urban Devolopment and the Veterans Administration because workers were barred from wearing campaign buttons while on the job.

title: HUNTERDON PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
AT WHITNEY, 5 NEW YORK PAINTERS
description: IN the 1960's days of Minimal austerity, when

title: Glenn Would Consider Second Spot on Ticket
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio, who dropped out of the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination after a poor showing in early primaries, says he would consider the No. 2 spot on the party's ticket if it was offered to him.

title: HART ASSERTS MONDALE DRIVE IS USING PAC CONTRIBUTIONS
description: Senator Gary Hart said yesterday that the campaign of his chief rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, was using political action committee money for Mondale delegate candidates despite his pledge not to accept such contributions.

title: THEATER: NEW YORK IS ENDED
description: ''AHELL OF A TOWN'' is nothing less than a comedy about the end of the world, or to be specific, the end of New York, which the playwright, Monte Merrick, treats as the sophisticated center of the universe. Mr. Merrick can write funny lines and is a crafty observer of the ups and downs of an acquisitive society. At the same time, in search of laughs, the play necessarily trivializes the most important subject. The situation is, to say the least, contrived.

title: Yield Data Delayed
description: Data on the short- and long-term yields of the funds were not available yesterday from Donoghue's Money Fund Report in Holliston, Mass. A storm in the Boston area caused power failures that prevented transmission of the data for publication by The New York Times.

title: Two Nicaraguan Ships Strike Mines Near Port
description: Two Nicaraguan cargo boats struck mines today near the port of Corinto, the state radio said, and Defense Minister Humberto Ortega Saavedra left for the Soviet Union and North Korea in search of military aid.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ; Stock or Cash Choice Given on Chase Notes
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation yesterday announced a new kind of floating-rate note that may pay interest in the form of common stock or cash, at the investor's option.

title: WORKER WHO WON RIGHT TO REGAIN JOB MAY FACE NEW FIGHT
description: Walter J. Slaughter won a five-year court battle to regain his job as a laboratory technician for E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, but victory still eludes him. The National Labor Relations Board, which helped him in his long and often lonely struggle, has changed its mind and Mr. Slaughter now faces the possibility of a battle with his former ally.

title: TRADE GAP WIDENS TO RECORD
description: The United States foreign trade deficit widened to a record $10.1 billion in February, the Commerce Department reported today, providing fresh evidence that 1984 may be the worst trading year ever.

title: CLUETT, PEABODY FORMS NEW 3-EXECUTIVE PANEL
description: Cluett, Peabody & Company, which makes Arrow shirts and other apparel, announced the formation of a three-member office of the chairman. It chose Richard Q. Armstrong, former president of the Dr Pepper Company, to be a member of the triumvirate. Mr. Armstrong, who was also named to the new position of executive vice president, will assume his duties Monday.

title: AMPAL-AMERICAN ISRAEL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
DIONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $61,000. c-Net loss.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January 1984.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
U.S. STEPS UP USE OF SPYING PLANES IN SALVADOR WAR
description: A Salvadoran Army commander said today that United States planes on reconnaissance missions were providing almost instant intelligence on guerrilla movements before and during combat operations.

title: PENGUINS LOSE GAME AND CLINCH CELLAR
description: Through 58 seasons, the Rangers have never canceled a regular-season home game, and the storm that hit the Northeast threatened to end that record last night.

title: No Headline
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md. Although Bill Cartwright has scored 68 points in his last 2 games, the Knicks have been held to under 100 in each of their last 3 and have lost 2 of them. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.)

title: THE DEMOCRATIC DEBATE: MONDALE STRATEGY AIMED AT MIRING HART IN DETAILS
description: NewsAnalysis

title: TV WEEKEND
description: 'Generic News,' Channel 13 Parody

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Children's Zoo Opening

title: Economy Off In Mexico
description: Mexico's economy contracted by 4.7 percent in 1983, the worst performance in the country's modern history, a Bank of Mexico official said today.

title: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: IRAQ SAYS ITS FORCES SET FOUR SHIPS ABLAZE IN GULF BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 29 (AP) - A military spokesman said today that Iraqi warplanes and naval vessels had set four ships on fire in an attack at dawn off the Iranian coast at the head of the Persian Gulf.
description: The spokesman said Iraqi jets later shot down two Iranian helicopters that had been sent to rescue the crews of the stricken ships, which he identified only as ''enemy naval targets.''

title: Bankruptcy Bill Is Stalled
description: Legislation to prevent the nation's bankruptcy court system from going out of business next Monday was stalled in the Senate today by an impasse over a proposal to make it harder for ailing companies to breach union contracts.

title: LATIN DEBT CUTS BOSTON BANK'S PROFIT
description: The Bank of Boston yesterday became the first major bank to announce that its first-quarter earnings would be reduced substantially as a result of Argentina's failure to meet its debt obligations.

title: THORPE LEADS T.P.C. BY SHOT
description: A steady wind of nearly 30 miles an hour and gusts close to 50 turned the first round of the $800,000 Tournament Players Championship into a treacherous and costly occupation today. A record 64 golf balls splashed into the lake surrounding the little island green at the famous 132-yard, par-3 17th hole.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX UP STRONG 0.7%
description: The index of leading economic indicators, which is the Government's main economic forecasting gauge, rose a healthy seven-tenths of 1 percent in February, prompting the White House to assert that the economy was ''still on a roll.''

title: Thrift Unit Recovery
description: Net after-tax income of federally insured thrift institutions in 1983 was about $2.1 billion, a sharp turnaround from the $1.1 billion loss in 1982 and record $1.7 billion loss in 1981, according to preliminary Federal Home Loan Bank Board data. The board chairman, Edwin J. Gray, released the preliminary figures during testimony before the House Committee on Appropriations.

title: Greek Hurt in Shooting Dies
description: A Greek employee of the British Council who was wounded in the assassination of a British cultural attache Wednesday died today, a Government spokesman said. Artemis Economidou, 59 years old, a librarian, was sitting next to Kenneth T. Whitty, 44, in his car when he was shot in downtown Athens.

title: U.S. MAY DEFY '79 ARMS PACT TERMS
description: The State Department left open the possibility today that the United States might decide not to abide by the limits set in the 1979 strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union.

title: Appeal Denied Texan Scheduled for Execution
description: A Federal judge and an appeals court rejected requests today from attorneys for Ronald Clark O'Bryan that his scheduled execution Saturday be halted because death by lethal injection is cruel and unusual punishment.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday JAPANESE-STYLE BECKETT

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES LTD reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including income of $124,116 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change on prior years and a capital gain of $628,997 from the disposition of a subsidiary. c-After a capital loss of $440,993 from the disposition of a subsidiary. Corrected from Saturday, March 24.

title: Former Officials Warn Candidates on Oratory
description: Two former Presidents and six former Secretaries of State have endorsed a statement warning Presidential candidates to take care with their campaign oratory about foreign policy so as not to cause ''risk for this nation.''

title: SWEET ABSIL AND SOCIETY SALUTING ELLINGTON
description: APRIL has always been a Duke Ellington month because it includes his birthday, April 29, which is regularly celebrated by the Duke's aficionados. This year, however, April has a confluence of Ellington anniversaries: not only does it mark what would have been the 85th birthday of the pianist, composer and orchestra leader, it is also the 25th anniversary of the Duke Ellington Society.

title: BROADWAY
description: Little Flower to be replanted on Broadway.

title: COAST NURSE GUILTY OF KILLING 12 PATIENTS WITH HEART DRUG
description: A coronary care nurse was found guilty today of murdering 12 elderly patients at two Riverside County Hospitals three years ago by giving them lethal doses of a drug designed to control the heartbeat.

title: What Price Home Taping?
description: Inexpensive recorders and blank tapes now allow anyone to preserve a rare old Mozart recording without buying a new one, or to copy a Eurythmics album borrowed from a friend, or to collect Mary Tyler Moore shows snatched from the air. But the technology that gives consumers such pleasure is eroding the income of the producers of these entertainments - the studios, writers, violinists and drummers who depend on royalties from each performance or recording sale. And they are pressing Congress for compensation.

title: Tidewater Stake
description: A group led by the investor Irwin Jacobs said it had increased its holdings in the common stock of Tidewater Inc. to 7.1 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: OPERA: CHORALE IN DVORAK'S 'DIMITRI'
description: ANTON Dvorak's ''Dimitri'' is a perfect example of a forgotten opera that deserves to be given exposure in concert form, and so it was Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall by the Collegiate Chorale under the direction of Robert Bass. Dvorak's is not the first name to spring to mind when we think of composers for the voice, but he was an industrious writer of operas, several of which compare favorably with his best instrumental music. ''Dimitri'' is an especially fascinating work, though less than first-class, and its virtues stood out vividly in this performance, believed to be its American premiere.

title: IN CONGRESS, LITTLE TALK OF THE REAGAN MANDATE
description: There is little talk on Capitol Hill these days of President Reagan's ''mandate'' to change the direction of Government. Nor is there much fear of Mr. Reagan's taking reprisal against recalcitrant members by going into their states and districts and campaigning against them.

title: PHONE BIDS ADD TO DRAMA
description: ''IT looked like a scene out of 'A Chorus Line,' '' Barbara Strongin said, describing a moment in an auction at Christie's last Friday. She said she and nine other staff members were lined up at the front of the main gallery taking bids by telephone for a 1930's American painting, ''Indian Women Making Pottery'' by Catherine Carter Critcher, which sold for more than five times what the house expected. ''Everyone was on the telephone bidding against each other, and no one was bidding in the room,'' Miss Strongin reported.

title: 'Monster Is Back'
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler , who defends his undisputed middleweight title tonight in Las Vegas against Juan Domingo Roldan of Argentina, says, ''I want to show the monster is back.''

title: Olympic Trial List Down to 64
description: The invitations should be out shortly. Approximately 64 amateur basketball players should receive notice by Monday that they have been invited to the Olympic trials at Bloomington, Ind., from April 17 to 22.

title: 'MY BROTHER'S WEDDING' FROM COAST
description: THE obvious amateurishness of the acting in Charles Burnett's ''My Brother's Wedding'' and the director's own very stiff, rudimentary technique don't damage the film as much as they might, perhaps because of the innocence and clarity with which Mr. Burnett approaches his material. The locale is south central Los Angeles, and the action takes place in neat, clean settings populated by a cast that sounds very genteel. Actually, most of them are supposed to be struggling and impoverished, with the exception of the rich, unpleasant woman whom Pierce Mundy's brother plans to marry.

title: A Delay for McLain
description: The arraignment of Denny McLain , the last major leaguer to win 30 games in a season, was postponed yesterday for one week to give him time to hire an attorney.

title: N.I.T. FORESEES FEW CHANGES
description: In the wake of Wednesday night's final at Madison Square Garden that was more of an artistic than financial success, Peter Carlesimo shrugged off new suggestions yesterday that the National Invitation Tournament would have to undergo drastic alterations to survive.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE national company of the Fren musical ''Nine'' gave itself a bon

title: AFRICAN POET JOINS THE IMMORTALS OF FRANCE
description: John Vinocur

title: TREASURY PROPOSES A RESCUE LOAN FOR ARGENTINA
description: Officials of the Treasury Department said today that it had proposed a short-term rescue loan that would let Argentina make overdue interest payments to American banks.

title: HART SAYS CAMPAIGN CHARGES STRAIN HIS FRIENDSHIP WITH MONDALE
description: Senator Gary Hart makes it plain that the personal friendship he had with Walter F. Mondale has been chilled, perhaps even severed, over the increasingly bitter campaign advertisements and charges that have marked the drives of the two candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination in recent weeks.

title: PARIS SHOWS: FEW PEAKS AND MANY VALLEYS
description: The French ready-to-wear collections reached a low mark, almost everyone agreed, as two weeks of fall and winter fashion openings ended today. There were a few heights, but more valleys as the showings unfolded.

title: FRENCH WORKERS RIOT OVER STEEL CUTBACKS
description: Widespread violence broke out in eastern France today after the Government approved a tough plan for restructuring the region's money-losing steel industry. Under the plan, 25,000 jobs would be eliminated by 1987, leaving one of every four steelworkers unemployed.

title: SENATE DEFEATS ATTEMPTS TO LIMIT U.S. TROOP USE IN LATIN AMERICA
description: The Senate late tonight technically approved the Administration's request for $61.75 million in new military aid for El Salvador, but senators opposed to the bill were promised an opportunity next week to try to cut the aid and impose conditions on the package.

title: Notes Are Priced At 99 7/8 for Rainier
description: The Rainier Bancorporation of Seattle is selling $100 million of floating-rate notes due in 1996, which are offered at a price of 99 7/8 through underwriters led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc.

title: 'NEW DIRECTORS/NEW FILMS' LOOKS AT THE WORLD FAMILY
description: THE 1984 ''New Directors/ New Films'' series could just as well be titled ''All in the Family.'' From Hong Kong to Hungary, from Southern California to East Germany, family relationships seem to be obsessing film makers. At least two-thirds of the 18 feature- length films from 14 countries in the series this year focus on this topic. ''We didn't plan it - it just happened,'' said Joanne Koch, executive director of the Film Society of Lincoln Center. ''Sometimes common themes seem to surface spontaneously, everywhere at once.'' This is one of those years.

title: PLAN FOR MARKET ON QUEENS SITE BACKED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration awarded New York City a $23 million urban-development grant today for a marketing center intended to revitalize the city's wholesale furnishings and interior decorating industry.

title: UNIVERSAL DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Burl Ives in Concert
description: The balladeer and actor Burl Ives will make his first New York concert appearance of the season in Carnegie Hall Sunday at 8 P.M. Tickets, $12.50 to $20, are available at the box office. Information: 247-7459

title: HOWDY, HOUSTAN! HOW'M I DOIN'?
description: Mayor Koch, a quintessential New Yorker who tries not to wander west of the Hudson if he can help it, made his first sortie into Texas today and took Houston the way Santa Anna took the Alamo, except the Mayor left them laughing.

title: Midcon Project
description: The Midcon Corporation said its Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America unit had filed with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to build and operate a 185-mile pipeline joining its two major pipeline systems.

title: 'THE WHOLE TRAILER WENT UP INTO THE SKY'
description: Carolyn Bass was standing at the front door and watching the boiling sky to the west when she saw the low black funnel, whipping back and forth below the clouds like the tail of a snake and moving straight toward her house trailer.

title: Export Act Due to Expire
description: The House Democratic leadership said today that it will let lapse on Saturday night the statutory authority for the President to declare grain embargoes and otherwise control exports. The Senate on Tuesday voted to extend that authority to May 16 because the House and Senate are deadlocked over a renewal of the Export Administration Act.

title: ABC'S 'SAMSON AND DELILAH' REMAKE
description: MOST people might think it foolhardy to tamper with a camp classic, but ABC is doing just that Sunday at 9 on Channel 7, and the remake manages to be even sillier than the original. Cecil B. De Mille's ''Samson and Delilah,'' starring Victor Mature and Hedy Lamarr, was released in 1949. The new version, starring Antony Hamilton and Belinda Bauer, was adapted by John Gay from a novel by Eric Linklater. Presumably, Mr. Gay, normally a television writer of some substance, was paid well.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IN the hyperbole-prone food arena of New

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After charges for interest on debentures, legal and administrative costs associated with bankruptcy and litigation settlements totaling $2,730,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''And all of sudden the trailer started to shake, and the hail started to pound down like stones. My mother and I grabbed my daughters and got out the door just as the whole trailer went right up into the sky.'' - Carolyn Bass of Bennettsville, S.C. (A1:4.)

title: ALVARADO'S AIDES REASSIGNED
description: The Acting Schools Chancellor, Nathan Quinones, yesterday reassigned top aides to Anthony J. Alvarado, the suspended Chancellor.

title: The U.N. Today March 30, 1984
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
No Headline
description: Because of a transmission error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about the conduct of Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado quoted him incorrectly. He said the planned Board of Education hearing would prove him ''a fallible human being, not a venal one.''

title: REAGAN ADVERTISING TEAM IS FORMED
description: After searching for five months for an advertising agency to handle President Reagan's re-election campaign, and being rejected by a number of Madison Avenue concerns, the Reagan- Bush '84 committee has decided to form an independent group of writers and artists to produce the President's commercials.

title: LEHMAN MAY SELL A STAKE
description: Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., one of Wall Street's few remaining private partnerships, is seeking to raise capital and says it would be willing to sell a minority equity interest. But the firm denied that the entire partnership - or a majority interest - is for sale.

title: THEATER: A PORTRAIT OF LOUISA MAY ALCOTT
description: KATHARINE HOUGHTON is both playwright and performer in ''To Heaven in a Swing,'' a gentle monodrama about Louisa May Alcott that is part of the Women's Project this season at the American Place Theater. Miss Houghton has attempted one of the most demanding theatrical forms for author and actor - creating the illusion of dialogue with unseen characters while holding a stage alone. Her dual roles may seem inseparable during the course of the evening, yet Miss Houghton's touching abilities as an actress come across somewhat better than her rather wandering play.

title: New Eruptions Begin At Mount St.  Helens
description: Molten rock began erupting from the lava dome in the crater of Mount St. Helens early today after an ash plume rose 6,000 feet above the 8,300-foot peak, scientists said.

title: A POSTSCRIPT ON PRAYER
description: The day after defeating the proposed Constitutional amendment to allow officially sanctioned prayer in public schools, the Senate began its session as usual last week, with a prayer by the chaplain, the Rev. Richard C. Halverson.

title: U.S.I.A. CRITICAL OF ITS MOVES IN INQUIRY OVER THE 'BLACKLIST'
description: A report by the United States Information Agency's own office of investigations, released today, is highly critical of the agency's management for creating a blacklist of people banned from an overseas speaking program.

title: ONLY ONE BOOZER
description: Booze and driving don't mix, so the

title: COLTS' MOVE TO INDIANAPOLIS IS ANNOUNCED
description: The Colts, a fixture in Baltimore since 1953, abandoned the city yesterday and prepared to relocate in Indianapolis after reaching a tentative agreement to play in the new, 60,000- seat Hoosier Dome.

title: Freestyle Proves Her Style
description: For years, Nancy Hogshead was a good loser. In her 17 previous national swimming championships, she gained seven second places and six thirds, but only three victories.

title: GROUP REMINDS CONTENDERS JEWS WATCH NON-ISRAEL ISSUES
description: Presidential contenders should understand that Jews care about a wide range of domestic and foreign issues as well as the security of Israel, officials of the American Jewish Committee said yesterday.

title: PUBLISHING:TV TALK LEADS TO BEST-SELLER LIST
description: FEW novelists are invited to appear on television talk shows because discussions of literary style or the creative imagination are considered too abstract for so visual a medium. But television can do wonders for certain books, one of the most striking recent examples of which is ''Eat to Win'' (Rawson Associates) by Dr. Robert Haas, a sports nutritionist.

title: THEATER: HOFFMAN, 'DEATH OF SALESMAN'
description: AS Willy Loman in Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman,'' Dustin Hoffman doesn't trudge heavily to the grave - he sprints. His fist is raised and his face is cocked defiantly upwards, so that his rimless spectacles glint in the Brooklyn moonlight. But how does one square that feisty image with what will come after his final exit - and with what has come before? Earlier, Mr. Hoffman's Willy has collapsed to the floor of a Broadway steakhouse, mewling and shrieking like an abandoned baby. That moment had led to the spectacle of the actor sitting in the straightback chair of his kitchen, crying out in rage to his elder son, Biff. ''I'm not a dime a dozen!,'' Mr. Hoffman rants, looking and sounding so small that we fear the price quoted by Biff may, if anything, be too high.

title: PORSCHE PLANNING TO GO PUBLIC
description: Porsche A.G., the premier West German sports car manufacturer, which is run by an American and sells most of its cars in the United States, today announced plans to go public.

title: Clifford W. Henderson , Founder of Air Races
description: Clifford W. Henderson, a colorful figure in the early days of aviation and later a prominent California land developer, died on Monday at the Eisenhower Medical Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 88 years old and lived in nearby Palm Desert.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Plan Corp. said it had ended discussions on its proposed acquisition of Columbia National Life Insurance Co. from Armco Inc.

title: The Worm and the Apple Safety Second
description: Stalled Stalls The best way to patrol Central Park is on a horse, which permits ready access to the most remote parts of the park without posing any threat to lawns or shrubs. That's why the Parks Department would like to move six patrol horses, which now reside in a costly commercial stable, into a corner of an ancient park building north of the 96th Street transverse.

title: 'ANTARTICA,' NOMINEE OF JAPAN FOR ACADEMY AWARD
description: ''ANTARCTICA,'' Japan's nominee for the Academy Award for best foreign film, is a beautiful movie, which is not to say that it is a fine one.

title: Dome Accord May Be Near
description: A consortium of international banks led by Citibank is reported to be nearing agreement on rescheduling its $1.8 billion loan to Dome Petroleum Ltd., the Calgary, Alberta, oil and gas group that has debts of $4.84 (United States).

title: Lava Flow Slowing On Way Toward Hilo
description: The flow of lava from the Mauna Loa volcano toward the city of Hilo slowed today, but cloud cover made it impossible for the authorities to fix its exact position.

title: REAGAN DENIES O'NEILL'S CHARGES OF UNFAIRNESS BY ADMINISTRATION
description: President Reagan today accused House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of assuming ''guilt by accusation'' in describing the Administration as steeped in ''greed and unfairness.''

title: U.S. OPPOSES CANADIAN BETS ON BASEBALL
description: Canadian plans for a Government-run betting pool on sports events have raised jeers and squawks from the United States Department of State, the commissioner of baseball and 9 of the 10 Canadian provinces.

title: U.S. AIDES SAY IRAQIS MADE USE OF A NERVE GAS
description: United States intelligence officials say they have what they believe to be incontrovertible evidence that Iraq has used nerve gas in its war with Iran and has almost finished extensive sites for mass-producing the lethal chemical warfare agent.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
A.T.&T. Chooses Finance Officer
description: Robert M. Kavner, formerly a general practice partner in the accounting firm of Coopers & Lybrand, has been elected a senior vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. He will become the company's chief financial officer on May 1.

title: As Good as Gold
description: In 1972, Mark Spitz won seven gold medals in swimming at the Olympic Games in Munich.

title: About Beetle Bailey
description: Mort Walker, creator of the cartoon character Beetle Bailey, will lecture at the Museum of Cartoon Art Sunday in celebration of April Fool's Day. During the program, which begins at 2 P.M., Mr. Walker is likely to discuss Bailey's 33-year evolution, to talk about his new book, ''The Best of Beetle Bailey,'' and to demonstrate cartoon techniques. The museum, which is on Comly Avenue in Rye Brook, N.Y., one mile south of the King Street-Port Chester exit of the Hutchinson River Parkway, is open Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M.; Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission is $1.50; 75 cents for children and the elderly Information: (914) 939-0234.

title: CRIME VICTIM AID WORTH FEDERAL RE-FUNDING
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET JOINS ETHIOPIA IN CRITICIZING U.S.
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko pledged continued aid to Ethiopia today and joined the visiting Ethiopian leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam, in accusing the United States of interfering in African affairs.

title: No Headline
description: Japan asked the United States today to stop a reduced-fare package offered by United Airlines to trans-Pacific passengers, a Transport Ministry official said. Beginning Sunday, United passengers on flights from Tokyo or Hong Kong to Seattle will be able to fly to four other American cities within a 45-day period for an additional $115.

title: Military Contracts
description: The Raytheon Company received two Navy contracts totaling $218.6 million for 1,560 Sparrow missile guidance sets, wings and fins and for software, the Defense Department said. In addition, it said Texas Instruments Inc. had got a $96.2 million contract from the Air Force to design and make improved parts for aircraft radar.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $100 MILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply declined by $100 million in the week ended March 19, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: TECHNOLOGIST WITH A WEATHER EYE
description: The sofa bed was still out, its sheets and blanket tangled. A fresh shirt lay waiting on a bookcase. It was 1:30 P.M., and Harold Gibson, New York City's chief meteorologist, had been on the job in the Weather Service offices in Rockefeller Center for 30 hours straight. Back at his desk after checking the path of the storm on the service's sophisticated computers, Mr. Gibson opened his curtains to peer past skyscrapers at a patch of slate sky. ''The best weather instrument yet devised is a pair of human eyes,'' he said. ''Looking out the window is the most important thing if you want to know what's going on.''

title: UNWISE PROPOSAL TO CURB MERGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: DESPITE CAMPAIGN ORATORY, SOME DIFFERENCES ARE SUBTLE
description: Gary Hart and Walter F. Mondale have been emphasizing their differences on a wide range of foreign and domestic issues.

title: Coaches Back A Shot Clock
description: For the first time, a majority of

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 30, 1984

title: RELIANCE UNITS BUY 6.3% OF DISNEY
description: Several subsidiaries of the Reliance Group Inc. disclosed yesterday that they had acquired a 6.3 percent stake in Walt Disney Productions, whose stock price has soared in recent weeks in a swirl of takeover rumors.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $6 million for the quarter and year for restructuring and consolidation and a gain of $200,000 for the year from the termination of benefit plans. c-After a charge of $4.4 million for the quarter and year for resturcturing and consolidation and a gain of $4.7 million for the quarter and year from the termination of benefit plans.

title: McCarthy Compares '68 To Hart's Campaign
description: Eugene J. McCarthy, whose 1968 Presidential campaign was based on his opposition to the Vietnam War, says similarities exist between his race and the campaign of Senator Gary Hart.

title: 8TH GAME IN CHESS IS DRAWN
description: Vasily Smyslov and Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union agreed to a draw in the eighth game of their final candidates chess match Wednesday. The score now stands at Kasparov 5, Smyslov 3.

title: Economic Scene; A Crucial Time For Argentina
description: THE central fact of Argentina's immediate

title: 'A YING,' A STORY FROM HONG KONG
description: ALLEN FONG'S ''Ah Ying'' attests to the Westernization of Hong Kong society, and is itself a striking illustration of that process. While David Bowie posters and American songs occupy the attention of the film's title character, Mr. Fong (whose real name is Fong Yuk-ping) shapes a film around her that in its own way, while revealing much about the character and her friends and family, has a second-hand feeling.

title: JENSEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
No Headline
description: Court Weighs Evidence In Impeachment Trial =

title: ART: CALIFORNIA SCHOOL
description: BAY AREA Painting, like Fauvism, was over almost as soon as it had begun, and it left no issue. It came out of Abstract Expressionism, as that mode had belatedly developed in San Francisco, was a representational reaction to it and, for a few moments, seemed about to fill the void it had left. But the school, a Californian manifestation, proved no match for Pop and other more cerebral trends such as hard-edge abstraction.

title: A Seabrook Partner To Vote to Kill Unit
description: The owner of the third-largest share of the twin Seabrook nuclear reactors said yesterday that it would vote to cancel Unit 2. The Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Electric Company, a group of 34 of the state's municipal utilities, said the estimated costs of completing the facility, and the eventual cost of the power, were too high.

title: AIR CANADA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CAPITALS ARRIVE VIA DEFENSE
description: The cherry blossoms, although tinged from today's light snow, are budding and will soon be in full bloom. Bus loads of schoolchildren arrive daily from the suburbs, ready for tours of the Smithsonian Institution and maybe a side trip to the National Zoo.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Precaution

title: THE WRONG APPEAL TO JEWISH VOTERS
description: The question of where to situate the United States Embassy in Israel is a legitimate policy issue. How candidates for public office feel about this is a legitimate political issue - not only for Jewish voters but also for all Americans who care about the legitimacy of Israel and its indisputable right to designate its own capital.

title: INDUSTRY, NOT GOVERNMENT, IS OVERSPENDING
description: To the Editor:

title: CHANGES AT THE TOP FOR POPE & TALBOT
description: William A. Whelan, president and chief operating officer of Pope & Talbot Inc., a wood products company based in Portland, Ore., has been named vice chairman. He will be succeeded as president by R. Steven Mason, a vice president of the Potlatch Corporation, a San Francisco wood products company.

title: RESTAURNATS
description: French cuisine in a classic style.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
IN BAROQUE, WELL-FED PRAGUE, THE SPIRIT IS NUMB
description: There is a wall in the heart of Prague, not far from the Vltava River, where intrepid spirits once scrawled graffiti against the Soviet-led invasion that 16 years ago crushed a spring of hope in Czechoslovakia.

title: JOURNAL SAYS A REPORTER IS UNDER S.E.C. INQUIRY
description: The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that one of its reporters was understood to have told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he periodically leaked sensitive information on articles he wrote.

title: PANDICK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed Jan. 16.

title: HOUSE REPUBLICANS OUTLINE THEIR PLAN TO TRIM DEFICITS
description: The House Republican leadership today agreed on a budget package it estimated would trim deficits by about $200 billion over three years.

title: By Le Anne Schreiber;
description: CHILDHOOD. By Nathalie Sarraute.

title: McDonnell Tender Hits Court Snag
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said it had issued a restraining order to keep the McDonnell Douglas Corporation from completing its tender offer for Tymshare Inc. It said the order stays ''until further notice'' completion of the transaction as approved by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: School Cited
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association accused the men's basketball program at Alaska-Anchorage, a Division II school, of recruiting violations, the university said today. The N.C.A.A. said coaches improperly arranged for plane tickets for potential recruits, players and their relatives and friends, and provided transportation, meals and lodging for them.

title: FRITZ AND GARY
description: George McGovern presciently warned Walter Mondale and Gary Hart that if they argued too heatedly over ''where's the beef?'' in each other's candidacy, they'd make hamburger of themselves. Their most recent debate suggests that that's just what's happening.

title: REAGAN'S CHALLENGE IN CHINA
description: In the last week of April, President Reagan and his entourage will go to the People's Republic of China, treading what has become a well-worn election-year path to the Great Wall, the Forbidden City and the Temple of Heaven. Nancy Reagan will, no doubt, emulate Pat Nixon and Rosalynn Carter in visiting day-care centers, dance schools and collections of Chinese art.

title: FILM: 'MISUNDERSTOOD'
description: NED RAWLEY (Gene Hackman) becomes the newly widowed father of two boys at the beginning of ''Misunderstood,'' a film whose emotional territory is as familiar as its geography is exotic. The Rawleys live in a palace in Tunisia, which (we are told in passing) happens to be a byproduct of Ned's phenomenal success in the shipping business after World War II. The house, attention getting enough to occupy center stage in another movie, is treated quite casually in this one, presumably because the Rawleys have other things to think about: Ned's coolness toward his older son, the need of both boys for parental attention and everyone's memories of Mom.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ON THE BEACH
description: This privileged playground at the confluence of the great River Plate and the Atlantic Ocean seemed an unlikely setting to talk about crumbling economics and unpaid debts. But finance ministers, central bank presidents and bankers from 43 nations this week took over its villas, limousines, discoth eques and beaches for the conference billed here as the largest gathering ever to discuss Latin America's huge debt.

title: SHELL OIL'S REBUFF TO DEAL BY PARENT
description: A Wall Street investment banker punched a few buttons on his computer and up popped the fact he was seeking: the Shell Oil Company has some 309 million shares outstanding.

title: CASHEN CHANGES STANCE ON ROOKIES
description: Frank Cashen is known in baseball circles as an uncommonly conservative man who frowns on rushing youngsters into the big leagues. He argued against opening the 1981 season with Tim Leary on the major league roster and was even more adamant about Darryl Strawberry in 1983.

title: HIGHER PAYOUT AT I.B.M. SEEN
description: WITH shares of the International Business Machines Corporation faring a bit better lately, there is growing conjecture that this stock market bellwether could have further good news for shareholders sometime this year in the form of an increased cash dividend.

title: UNUSUSAL SET OF EVENTS LED TO SEVERE WEATHER
description: The tornadoes and unusually severe winds and snowy thunderstorms that struck the East Coast Wednesday and yesterday were part of a gigantic storm system of near-hurricane intensity that came about because of an unusual set of meteorological conditions.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Opera Leader Arrives

title: A BIAS THAT HURTS WOMEN SCIENTISTS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE-SENATE CONFERENCE AGREES ON PLAN FOR WHEAT PRICE SUPPORTS
description: A House-Senate Conference Committee agreed today on a new wheat price support program that the Reagan Administration and farm state Republicans hope will reduce the size of the 1984 crop and bring farmers better prices.

title: 2 Awarded Bancroft Prizes in History
description: Louis R. Harlan, professor of history at the University of Maryland, and Paul Starr, associate professor of sociology at Harvard University, were awarded the 1984 Bancroft Prizes last night by Michael I. Sovern, president of Columbia University, at a dinner sponsored by the Friends of the Columbia Libraries.

title: Court Reverses Nicor Unit Award
description: The Northern Illinois Gas Company, a unit of Nicor Inc., said an appellate court had reversed and vacated a $305.5 million judgement against it in a suit brought by Energy Cooperative Inc. The Illinois Appellate Court for the Third District acted on a suit brought by Energy Cooperative arising from a Northern Illinois Gas termination of purchases of naphtha feedstock for its supplement natural gas plant.

title: FERRONICS INCORPORATED reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $22,000.

title: CENTRONICS DATA COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $634,000.

title: BRIEFING
description: The McGovern Connection

title: New Unemployment Claims Rose Slightly for Mid-March
description: New claims for unemployment insurance payments totaled 361,000 for the week ended March 17, up 4,000 from a week earlier, the Labor Department reported today.

title: FILM: 'GREYSOKE,' TARZAN IN AFRICA AND ENGLAND
description: FROM the most unlikely source material comes the season's most unexpected, most invigorating surprise, ''Greystoke: the Legend of Tarzan, Lord of the Apes,'' a huge, lavishly produced period film that is part adventure, part comedy of manners and part somber melodrama.

title: SCREEN: 'ROMANCING THE STONE,' ACTION-COMEDY
description: ''ROMANCING THE STONE,'' which opens today at the Gotham and other theaters, is an elaborately produced, mostly charmless adventure-comedy that intends to make fun of a kind of romantic fiction that's one step removed from what the movie is all about.

title: Dining Out Guide: Wine by the Glass
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: GERMAN DENIES IT SOLD A PESTICIDE FACTORY TO THE IRAQIS
description: A spokesman for the Economics Ministry said today that an investigation had determined that the Karl Kolb company, a supplier of industrial laboratories, had sold a pesticide plant to Iraq that would go into operation in September. But a senior executive of the company denied that such a transaction had taken place.

title: ASBESTOS COMPANIES' QUESTIONABLE TRIUMPH
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA-AUDITION STARS SING AT MET ON SUNDAY
description: Some of the world's brightest young operatic hopefuls will make it to the top this weekend. They are the 11 vocalists who will participate in the Metropolitan Opera National Council's 1984 Auditions at the Metropolitan Opera House on Sunday afternoon at 2:45.

title: CANADIAN CLAIMS VICTORY IN STEELWORKER VOTE PITTSBURGH, March 29 (AP) - Lynn Williams, holding a commanding lead over Frank McKee, tonight claimed victory in their race for president of the million-member United Steelworkers of America union.
description: An Associated Press survey of incomplete returns from the union's 23 districts in the United States and Canada showed Mr. Williams, a Canadian, with 137,619 votes and Mr. McKee, a former United States millhand, with 79,111 votes in early returns.

title: Selling Soccer
description: On Wednesday night at the Kemper Arena in Kansas City, Mo., which has a seating capacity of 15,925 for indoor soccer, a crowd of 13,917 turned out to watch the Comets defeat the Los Angeles Lazers, 6-5.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Ehrhart , the United States Football League's director of administration and chief counsel, was named the league's first executive director, with responsibility in the operations, communications, financial, legal and marketing areas. . . . Rick Reuschel , the 34-year-old right- hander of the Chicago Cubs, was placed on the 15-day disabled list because of a muscle spasm in his right shoulder. . . . Tom Ramsey , the quarterback who became expendable when the Los Angeles Express signed the rookie Steve Young , was traded to the Oakland Invaders for an undisclosed draft choice.

title: A QUIET DAY FOLLOWS VIOLENT SPASM IN BEIRUT
description: This weary city enjoyed calm today after a spasm of violence Wednesday that included fierce, random shelling of civilian neighborhoods. Many here sought solace in promises by Government and militia officials that such shelling would not be repeated.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: Results include operations of Basco and Modern Merchandising since dates of acquisition in July 1982 and October 1982, respectively.

title: THE PRESIDENT'S CHANGING FORTUNES: AT WHITE HOUSE, A MATTEROF DIRECTION
description: For three years the White House's legislative strategy group has worked well as the political balance wheel in the Reagan machine. This group of ranking Administration strategists capitilized on the President's election mandate in the early budget victories in Congress and fashioned bipartisan tactics for neutralizing such threatening issues as Social Security.

title: Modular Marketing
description: -year-old ad agency, has been retained by the Berlitz Schools of Languages of America, a subsidiary of Macmillan, to create its advertising. According to Robert Leach of the agency, media buying will be handled by Customized Media Services, a subsidiary of Canter & Achenbaum. The account was handled previously and briefly by Nadler & Larimer.

title: Price Philosophy
description: The Los Angeles Lakers have announced that their top price for a courtside seat will rise from $90 to $100 next season.

title: NEW-HOME SALES UP BRISK 7.8%
description: Sales of new homes climbed 7.8 percent in February as a strong market in the South compensated for lower sales in the North Central states, the Government reported today.

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR STUDENTS, REBIRTH OF THE BLUES
description: R. SHIPP

title: WHEELED COACH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
EDWIN FORSYTHE, CONGRESSMAN, DIES
description: Representative Edwin B. Forsythe, a New Jersey Republican who served in the House of Representatives for 14 years, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Moorestown, N.J. He was 68 years old.

title: CORPORATE VICTORY DISGUISED AS DEFEAT
description: To the Editor:

title: GAMESMANSHIP FIGURED IN ACCORD ON THE BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo was satisfied. The budget was done. Now, he suggested, it was time for the formal announcement. What about a news conference in the historic Red Room, the Governor asked, just like the one he held last year with legislative leaders.

title: MYTHS FADE AS AGED VISIT F.D.R. HIGH
description: Sixteen elderly men and women arrived at a Brooklyn High School yesterday with a message. ''We are swingers,'' they told the students, in a visit intended to dispel myths about the aged.

title: UNIVERSITY GRAPHICS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary net gain of $17,275. c-After an extraordinary net loss of $20,402.

title: STATE PRIMARY PUTS BLACK AND HISPANIC VOTERS IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Response to the Rev. Jesse Jackson's Presidential campaign has dramatized the political diversity both among New York's black leaders and within its broader minority community.

title: FILM: 'TOO SHY TO TRY,' 1978 COEMDY FROM FRANCE
description: ''TOO SHY TO TRY,'' which opens a two-day run today at the Thalia, is a 1978 French comedy starring - and directed by - Pierre Richard, the tall blond man who co-stars with Gerard Depardieu in ''Les Comp eres,'' a slightly newer French comedy, which opened Wednesday at the Paris.

title: NERVE GASES AND PESTICIDES: LINKS ARE CLOSE
description: Since before World War II, the development of certain pesticides and the creation of nerve gases for chemical warfare have gone hand-in-hand.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE INNING OF THE DOLPHIN
description: The Dolphins won today, 35-24: No, it wasn't a spring football game, it was a record-setting college baseball game.

title: Clash in Syracuse
description: A Long Island businessman has applied to the United States Football League for a Syracuse franchise, but Syracuse University's Vice Chancellor, Clifford Winters , says that no professional team will be allowed in the Carrier Dome. Ken Feldman , who heads a six-member group hoping to gain a U.S.F.L. franchise next season, said the proposal hinged on access to the 50,000-seat dome. Mr. Winters said February-through-July football would be a detriment to the campus and Syracuse sports programs.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: The total assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $460 million in the week ended yesterday, to $171.7 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported.

title: Ramsay Wins His 700th
description: Coach Jack Ramsay won his 700th game in the National Basketball Association tonight as the Portland Trail Blazers beat the Kansas City Kings, 120-113, tonight.

title: NEW YORK POST IS STRUCK BY THE NEWSPAPER GUILD
description: Nearly 400 employees of The New York Post went on strike at 12:01 this morning after negotiations with the newspaper's management over a new three-year contract broke down, union officials said.

title: BONN BELIEVES IRAQI LAB ISN'T MAKING NERVE GAS
description: West German officials said today that they believed that a pesticide laboratory exported to Iraq was not now producing nerve gas for the war with Iran. But they acknowledged it was theoretically possible the project might, when completed, be changed to produce chemical weapons.

title: MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dooley Cancels Tour
description: Vince Dooley , the University of Georgia football coach, canceled a planned booster-club tour of South Africa that had drawn protests from civil rights leaders. In calling off the tour, however, Dooley said he was not responding to the protests, which focused on South Africa's racial policies.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Majority In Election Falls Short
description: Indirect elections for the upper house of Parliament left Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party 11 seats short of a two-thirds majority that would enable the Indian leader to make constitutional changes. Her party did gain 20 seats, however.

title: O'NEILL ASKING IF U.S. VIOLATES LAW IN SALVADOR
description: The Speaker of the House asked the Foreign Relations Committee today to investigate whether the Administration had violated the War Powers Act by not reporting to Congress on recent activities by American military personnel in El Salvador.

title:
PATENTS;
Reducing Air Pollution Through Fast Burning
description: As part of a program to reduce emission of air pollutants, a device has been invented under contract with the Environmental Protection Agency that can expedite combustion in stationary furnaces or gas turbines.

title: SALVADOR FREES WITNESS IN SLAYING OF 2 AMERICANS
description: Salvadoran Army officials said today that a key witness in the slayings of the head of the country's land redistribution program and two American labor advisers was released from jail last week.

title: Meals on Military Wheels
description: Some homebound elderly people in

title: A Winning One-Liner
description: Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the

title: 'SALESMAN' GIVES RISE TO A STAR
description: Making his Broadway debut playing opposite Dustin Hoffman in ''Death of a Salesman,'' John Malkovich has become one of the season's most acclaimed young actors. The day after opening, instead of basking in the spotlight, he went to the Circle Repertory Company to check out the stage. In three weeks, while still acting in ''Salesman,'' he will go into rehearsal with Lanford Wilson's ''Balm in Gilead,'' re-directing the award- winning production he first did at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago.

title: Board Backs T.W.A. Moves
description: The Trans World Airlines board of directors has endorsed the airline's decisions regarding several strategic moves. Jerry Cosley, T.W.A.'s vice president of public affairs, said in an interview yesterday that at its meeting on Wednesday the board endorsed the concept that the airline should expand on the international level instead of domestically to improve its profitability.

title: TRP ENERGY SENSORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
A SECOND VOLCANO ON HAWAII ERUPTS
description: Both the Kilauea and Mauna Loa volcanoes on the island of Hawaii were erupting today, marking the first time they had gone off together since 1868.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The U.S. is committed to the goals of the restoration of a sovereign, independent and united Lebanon, the withdrawal of all foreign forces, and the security of Israel's northern border. However, the continuation of our participation in the M.N.F. is no longer a necessary or appropriate means of achieving these goals.'' - President Reagan. (3:2.)

title: No Explanation
description: Pat Riggin, who will be in net tonight for Washington when the Capitals face the Islanders in their showdown for first place in the Patrick Division, doesn't know the reason for his late-season success.

title: Worth the Effort
description: Bill Morris reported that his lower back was very sore yesterday morning, but the 35-year-old international controller for Kidder Peabody & Company said he was pleased that his physical discomfort had helped contribute more than $2,500 to the New Jersey Special Olympics, to be held at Piscataway June 8 to 10.

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results have been translated from Italian lire into U. S. dollars at the exchange rate prevailing on Dec. 31, 1983.

title: BULL & BEAR GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $138,315 for the latest year and $8,252 for the previous year.

title: TOURE IS BURIED IN TOMB IN GUINEA
description: The body of President Ahmed Seku Toure, one of the first leaders of independent Africa and a major figure in the movement for African unity, was laid to rest today in a simple thatched roof mausoleum.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday on the ''Salsa-Samba All Star Ensemble'' show at the Beacon Theater gave the day incorrectly. The concert takes place tonight.

title: 7 Not Guilty of Raping Michigan State Student
description: Seven men accused of raping a 17-year- old woman student at Michigan State University in a dormitory room were found not guilty today by a jury in Ingham County Circuit Court.

title: WHERE TO FIND NOTIONS
description: Even the person whose needlework is limited to sewing on a

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Journal Case Denial Cited
description: An attorney in the Manhattan law firm representing R. Foster Winans, a former reporter for The Wall Street Journal, said yesterday that Mr. Winans had denied making statements ''inconsistent'' with an article in Thursday's Wall Street Journal.

title: Borg Sees Mayor, Is Doin' Just Fine
description: Bjorn Borg was wielding a tennis racquet as he stepped out of a pearl gray stretch limousine at City Hall yesterday, but the 27-year-old former champion was there to give his racquet away, not to resume the career he ended a year ago.

title: YANKEES AND SAN DIEGO AGREE ON DEAL FOR NETTLES
description: The Yankees, loaded with third basemen and disenchanted with Graig Nettles, said they had reached agreement tonight with the San Diego Padres on a trade for their team captain. The deal, however, was still subject to approval by Nettles, but he has said in the past that he wanted to play for the Padres.

title: Comsat Rate Cut Sought
description: The Federal Communications Commission, continuing its bid to inject competition into the international communications field, moved today to force a reduction in the rates charged by the Communications Satellite Corporation, known as Comsat.

title: PRIMARY TAKES BACK SEAT AT L.I. MALL
description: When the Roosevelt Field Mall was built here in 1956, it was considered a risky venture and was met with a ''wait and see'' attitude.

title: PARIS PNEUMATIQUE IS NOW A DEAD LETTER
description: The epistolary tradition, which has been steadily running out of breath in this country since Madame de Sta"el, took another very hard blow on Friday at 5 P.M. Afer 117 years of service, the Government has done away with la lettre pneumatique.

title: Republic Health Deal
description: The Republic Health Corporation said it had acquired two California hospitals for about $40 million: the 142-bed Vesper Memorial Hospital in San Leandro and the 166-bed Vesper Society Hospital in Hayward.

title: Life, Death and Governor Lamm
description: When Richard Lamm was elected Governor of Colorado in 1974, a writer for The New York Times Magazine observed that ''Sometimes his fast-moving tongue becomes tied up by his faster-moving mind.'' This week that fast-moving tongue was responsible for turning him into an apparent ogre.

title:
PATENTS;
Increasing the Output Of Food Supplements
description: Two inventions in biotechnology, a science that promises to increase production of food supplements for animals and man, were patented this week for the Phillips Petroleum Company of Bartlesville, Okla.

title: UTILITIES APPROVE PLAN TO DROP SEABROOK UNIT
description: The 16 utilities that own the Seabrook nuclear power plant voted today to cancel the plant's second reactor if agreement can be reached by Dec. 1 on a way to help the principal owner, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, recover its $293 million investment.

title: IMRE CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-No comparable year-ago results are available because the company went public on Dec. 14, 1983.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption accompanying an article in Weekend in some editions yesterday on ''Salutes to the Duke,'' a Sunday series of Duke Ellington concerts at Sweet Basil, gave the wrong date for Norris Turney's appearance. He will play April 29.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Newspaper Drops 2 Editions
description: The Boston Globe ceased publication of its two afternoon editions today in a change company officials said would save more than $1 million. A spokesman for Affiliated Publications, publisher of The Globe, said the action would eliminate no jobs and that the combined circulation of 35,000 would be added to the Globe's morning editions, which have a combined circulation of 445,000.

title: WORK ON $35 BILLION BUDGET COMPLETED BY STATE SENATE
description: The State Senate completed action early today on a new state budget that would add up to $200 million in additional spending above levels proposed by Governor Cuomo.

title: COLTS' LEGACY IS BITTERSWEET
description: Inside John Unitas's Golden Arm Restaurant and Bar in Towson, a northern suburb of Baltimore, large black and white photographs of the Colts in their glory years adorn the walls. Now those pictures are evoking bittersweet sentiment among the fans who gather there.

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $72,028,000 for the quarter and year from the sale of Manley-McGinn Oil properties and a pretax charge of $9,601,000 for the quarter and year for expenses related to a terminated exchange offer.

title: SWEDES' SEABED SPY HUNT: NO STONE IS UNTURNED
description: After more than a month and a half in which it has deployed everything in its antisubmarine arsenal in a vain effort to capture apparent underwater intruders around a top-secret naval base, Swedish military officials remain mystified but convinced that the search should continue.

title: TENSION BUILDS AT OCCIDENTAL
description: David H. Murdock, a West Coast multimillionaire, disclosed yesterday that he had increased his stake in the Occidental Petroleum Corporation to 4.8 million shares, or 5 percent, and that he might buy more.

title: GULL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: AFTER STORM, THE CLEANUP GETS STARTED
description: Schools reopened, utility crews restored power, evacuees returned to their homes and cleanups and damage assessments got under way across the metropolitan area yesterday as the harshest storm of the year churned out to sea.

title: FED BARRED A MOVE TO CUT RATES
description: The Federal Reserve, although noting that a bellwether short-term interest rate had moved above the central bank's target range, decided at a special meeting last week against acting to bring rates back down.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'DON CARLO' AT THE MET
description: Opera is such a complex enterprise that it is a wonder anything ever goes quite right. But now and then, just often enough to keep faith alive, the pieces all fall into place and something remarkable and almost inexplicable happens. That was how it was last night at the Metropolitan Opera, where the season's first ''Don Carlo'' set off sparks and flares intermittently all evening and then burst into flames in the Grand Inquisitor scene, the dramatic and musical crux of this grandest of Verdi operas.

title: Jet Foils 600-M.P.H. Chicken
description: The Goodyear Aerospace Corporation now knows what happens when a four- pound chicken hits a jet fighter's windshield at 600 miles per hour. Officials say the impact only grazed the windscreen being developed at the company's Litchfield Park center for McDonnell Douglas F-4 jet fighters to provide better visibility and protection from birds. The dead chicken, fired at the jet from an air gun, produced only small cracks in the windshield.

title: Explosive Issue
description: Ever since the Twins and the Vikings moved out of Metropolitan Stadium in Bloomington, Minn., and into the Metrodome in Minneapolis, Bloomington officials, eager to see the stadium site developed and returned to the tax rolls, have been trying to figure out a way to get rid of the publicly owned facility. A plan to dismantle the stadium and move it to Fort Wayne, Ind., was rejected as too expensive, but now the city has received a proposal that could keep the demolition costs to a minimum. According to Larry Lee , an assistant city manager, a movie company has submitted preliminary plans to blow up the stadium for a scene in a movie about a rock concert.

title: 3 in Ohio Family Killed As Daughter Sleeps
description: A 5-year-old girl apparently slept peacefully through the night while her parents and older brother were stabbed to death, the police said today.

title: YOUNG'S PRO DEBUT MAY HELP EXPRESS
description: In Los Angeles, the nation's second- largest market, the United States Football League needs help. The team there, the Express, has established little identity and has a 2-3 record, and the crowds for home games last year and this have averaged 20,000, leaving the spectacle of more than 70,000 empty seats in the Coliseum.

title: Export Rules Won't Lapse
description: President Reagan today signed an executive order continuing export control regulations that otherwise were to lapse at midnight because of an impasse in Congress over renewal of the Export Administration Act.

description: International

title: X-RAYS AID DRIVE ON TAINTED GIRL SCOUT COOKIES
description: Members of Girl Scout Troop 2205 in Annandale, Va., took 20 cartons of cookies to a local hospital Thursday, not to sell them, but to have them X-rayed.

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP 0.7%
description: Orders to United States factories rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in February, in large part because of a 6.2 percent surge in orders for nonmilitary capital goods, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: A.M.C. Lifts Prices; G.M. Rise Indicated

title: Hosea Williams to Run For Congress in Georgia
description: State Representative Hosea Williams, saying that black Georgians needed a representative on Capitol Hill, has announced he would seek the Fifth Congressional District seat held by a third-term Democrat, Wyche Fowler Jr..

title: RELIEF WORK IS BEGUN IN CAROLINAS AFTER STORMS THAT KILLED 61
description: Nearly 3,000 people were without homes and thousands more had no electrical service today in the wake of a string of tornadoes that swept North and South Carolina Wednesday night.

title: GEORGETOWN-KENTUCKY: GIANTS CLASH
description: The combination of size, speed and power in the game of college basketball could reach new heights Saturday afternoon when Georgetown meets Kentucky in the semifinals of the national collegiate tournament.

title: Money Fund Yields Higher
description: Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday that yields on the 252 money market mutual funds that it surveys rose further in the week ended Wednesday.

title: Cosmos' Playoff Tied, 1-1
description: Karl-Heinz Granitza scored three goals and Pato Margetic added two to lead the Chicago Sting to a 7-3 victory over the Cosmos tonight, evening their semfinal playoff series at one game apiece.

title: Train Carrying Acid Derailed
description: A train carrying chromic acid hit a gravel truck, burst into flame and derailed today, forcing evacuation of a mile-wide downtown area here, the police said. The acid, used in chrome plating and engraving, is toxic, corrosive and highly flammable. The truck driver was missing, the police said.

description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Champion's 9th Defense
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, blending speed and deadly combinations, successfully defended his world middleweight title tonight with a 10th-round technical knockout over Juan Domingo Roldan of Argentina.

title: ELLY THUMMLER LEWIS
description: Elly Thummler Lewis, manager of sales promotion at Lockheed Aircraft Corporation from 1936 to 1940, died Thursday at New York Hospital. She was 74 years old and lived in New Milford, Conn.

title: Evmar-Midlands
description: The Evmar Oil Corporation said it had increased its holdings in the Midlands Energy Company to 1.4 million common shares, or 15.63 percent of the total outstanding. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Evmar said it bought 123,600 shares of Midlands, of Lakewood, Colo., between March 14 and 28. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Midlands rose 87.5 cents, to $29.375.

title: A Poisoned War
description: Iraq denies that it has used chemical weapons against Iran, in violation of a 1925 Geneva treaty that both signed. But the United States Government reiterates that it has. And a United Nations team, after inspecting battle zones, concluded that someone had employed mustard and nerve gas. Now it appears that Iraq has acquired West German equipment for mass-producing chemical weapons. On present evidence, Iraq is breaking its word and compounding the offense by denying it.

title: BARBARA HALL
description: Barbara Hall, who was an NBC television correspondent in the Soviet Union during the mid-1950's, died in Manhattan on Feb. 15.

title: CANADIAN EXPRESSES CONFIDENCE IN A STEEL FACTORY
description: Lynn R. Williams remained confident today that his claim of victory in the race for president of the United Steelworkers of America would hold through the official tabulation of votes.

title: Final Day for Filing On Rent Overcharges
description: Tenants in rent-stablized apartments have until midnight tonight to complain of rent overcharges prior to 1980, or give up the right to any refunds, housing officials said yesterday.

title: U.S.C. WOMEN WIN BY 62-57
description: Cheryl Miller scored the last 5 points as Southern California broke a 57-57 tie and defeated Louisiana Tech, 62- 57, in the Division I semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball tournament tonight.

title: WILLIAM BRIDGES, WRITER, DIES
description: William Bridges, editor and curator of publications for the New York Zoological Society from 1935 to 1966 and the author of 19 books on animals, died in his sleep Wednesday night at his home in Pleasantville, N.Y. He was 83 years old.

title: 6 Foods Recalled Because of EDB
description: Six more products have been recalled from New York stores because of contamination from the pesticide EDB, according to Joseph Gerace, State Agriculture and Markets Commissioner.

description: The lights burned late Thursday night in Apartment 7E at the Forest Houses in the South Bronx.

title: 18 State Labor Chiefs Endorse thePresident
description: A group of New York building-trade union officials endorsed President Reagan today during a meeting with him at the White House.

title: French Workers Strike To Protest Cutbacks
description: Thousands of steel and shipyard workers staged strikes across France today to protest the Socialist Government's decision to cut 25 to 30 percent of jobs in the state- run industries.

title: U.S. RESTRICTS SALE OF 5 CHEMICALS TO IRAQ AFTER POISON GAS REPORT
description: The United States announced today that it was imposing stringent restrictions on the sale to Iraq of five chemical compounds that can be used in making the poison gases Iraq has been accused of using in its war with Iran.
