Nehemiah Repulsed
description: A Federal judge in Newark yesterday rejected a request by Renaldo Nehemiah of the San Francisco 49ers, the former high-hurdles star, that national and world track officials be required to arbitrate his claim that he should be regarded as an amateur in track. Early arbitration of the matter might have allowed Nehemiah to compete in the Olympics this summer, as he sought.

title: BIG FORD BONUSES DISCLOSED
description: Philip Caldwell, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, was paid $1.42 million in salary and bonuses for 1983, the company's proxy statement disclosed today. He also exercised stock options worth an additional $5.89 million in net pretax value during the year.

title: STREAKING FLYERS TOP DEVILS
description: After tonight's 6-2 victory over the Devils at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Philadelphia Flyers appeared to be in peak form for the National Hockey League playoffs next week.

title: LAWMAKER'S TRIAL NEARS CONCLUSION
description: The criminal case against Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, who is charged with submitting false financial documents to Congress, is likely to go to the jury Monday.

title: COLONIAL COMMERCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: Bomb Kills Policeman On a Bus in Santiago
description: A bomb shattered a police bus tonight in downtown Santiago, killing one riot policeman and wounding 11 others, the police said.

title: Arabs Warn the U.S. On Embassy in Israel
description: Arab ministers meeting in Tunis decided today to warn the United States of unspecified retaliation if it moved its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, conference sources said.

title: MAKING THE MOST OF SHAD ROE
description: Usually it is on one of those late- February days when the world has turned to slush that I see the first sign in a fishmonger's window offering shad roe. It is as pleasant a harbinger of spring as forced hyacinth or paper narcissus. Although spring will be a little late this year, the shad do not seem to have noticed the recent awful weather and have made their presence felt all over town. Not as keenly, however, as in the part of the world in which I learned most of my cooking, Bethesda, Md., where the best seafood comes from Chesapeake Bay.

title: FOR BUYERS IN PARIS, THE HOUR OF DECISION
description: The founder of Charivari, the New York chain of high-fashion boutiques, was bending over a heap of sweaters Thursday in the high-tech Paris showroom of Yohji Yamamoto. ''Just look at those sweaters,'' Selma Weiser said. ''I adore those sweaters.''

title: CHANGED RULES IN MARGIN DEBT
description: Buying on margin is a risky business that calls for stock market sophistication, the resources to absorb a substantial loss when the price of the securities declines and the temperament to handle debt. Nevertheless, margin debt by customers of New York Stock Exchange member firms amounts to more than $22 billion, indicating that this technique is widely used by many individuals.

title: Goldwater Sees Kennedy As Democratic Nominee
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, predicted today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts would be the Democratic nominee for President this year.

title: Poisoner of Son Dies By Injection in Texas
description: Hours after the Supreme Court rejected arguments over the drugs being used in executions, Ronald Clark O'Bryan was put to death by lethal injection early today for poisoning his 8-year-old son with cyanide-laced Halloween candy.

title: U.S., 4 LATIN NATIONS AND BANKS AGREE ON ARGENTINE DEBT PACKAGE
description: Government negotiators and Argentina's 11-bank commercial advisory group tonight reached an 11th-hour agreement on a $500 million package to help Argentina make long-overdue interest payments to the banks.

title: Award for Darling
description: Ron Darling , the 23-year-old right- hander from Yale, has been named winner of the Johnny Murphy Award, which honors the top rookie in the Mets' spring camp. Murphy was general manager of the Mets until his death in 1970.

title: P.S.C. SEES PERIL OF POOR SERVICE IN LILCO'S CUTS
description: Many of the recent cuts imposed by the Long Island Lighting Company as cost-saving measures ''could have substantial adverse effects on service if continued for an extended period of time,'' a staff report of the Public Service Commission said today.

title: MANY WHO LOST AID STAY POOR, STUDY SAYS
description: People removed from the welfare rolls in 1981 have generally increased their work efforts and their earnings but have not earned enough to make up for the loss of welfare and food stamp benefits, the General Accounting Office said today.

description: Shimon Peres was left as the unchallenged head of the opposition Labor Party today as two potential rivals announced their decisions not to compete for the leadership.

description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, seeking a firm commitment on United States military bases in Greece, opened talks with Greek leaders today as thousands of people protested his two-day visit.

description: Senator Gary Hart leads Walter F. Mondale in North Dakota in their contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination, according to results of precinct caucuses in this state.

title: Libel Suit by South Dakotan Is Dismissed Without a Trial
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed a $10 million libel suit brought by Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota against Newsweek magazine for reporting an unfounded rape assertion made against the Governor 15 years ago.

description: The son of a former State Senator was sentenced today to nine years in prison for shooting a teen-ager from his bedroom window here last year.

description: Congress today passed a stopgap measure extending the authority of the nation's bankruptcy court system by one month to prevent it from closing down as of midnight Saturday.

description: The New York Coliseum, a prime property at the southwestern corner of Central Park, will be offered for sale or lease by September 1984, state and city officials announced yesterday.

description: Walter F. Mondale poked fun at the pageantry of summit conferences yesterday and then made an emotional plea for annual meetings between the President and the head of the Soviet Union.

title: Man Kills Himself In a Jersey Court
description: A man about to be sentenced for embezzlement shot and killed himself today in a courtroom, officials said.

description: Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the Republican national chairman, said today that the American people would not tolerate ''the recent attempt by the Democrats to sling mud on President Reagan and the Republican Party.''

description: The Federal Election Commission voted 5 to 0 Thursday to declare Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. conditionally eligible for Federal matching funds for his Presidential campaign. He is seeking the Democratic nomination.

title: Bridge: Albatross Brings Bad Luck, Or So a British Expert Finds
description: Traditionally, sailors have been superstitious about the albatross. That name has been given by Jeremy Flint, a British bridge expert, to a hand with a distribution of 8-4-1-0 - a bird that he views with dread.

description: President Reagan today formally ended the United States participation in the international force in Lebanon.

description: A panel of administrative judges of the Public Service Commission recommended yesterday that the cost of a call from most pay telephones in New York State be increased to 25 cents from 10 cents.

title: 2 Killed on L.I. In Fiery Collision
description: A loaded gasoline tanker truck collided with an automobile here early today, causing an explosion a few minutes later that killed two people who had been pulled from the car and thAT caused extensive damage nearby, the Nassau County police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY SATURDAY, MARCH 31, 1984 International
description: United States participation in the multinational force in Lebanon was ended by President Reagan. In a report to Congress, Mr. Reagan said that United States ''foreign policy interests in Lebanon have not changed'' but that United States participation in the international force ''is no longer a necessary or appropriate means of achieving these goals.'' His announcement released American marines aboard ships offshore for duties elsewhere in the Mediterranean. The number of United States warships off Lebanon had recently been reduced from about 25 to 15. (Page 1, Col. 6.) French soldiers in Lebanon withdrew from positions along the Green Line dividing East and West Beirut. They were the last remaining contingent of the multinational force that was sent to Lebanon to restore order. As they left, shelling started again in the port area and in the mountains east of the capital, breaking a 24-hour-old cease- fire arranged by a special security committee. (3:5.)

title: Phone Rate Bid
description: The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company, a unit of the BellSouth Corporation, said it had filed a request for a $112 million rate increase with the Georgia Public Service Commission because of the loss of three revenue-generating areas. It said that as part of the divestiture of Southern Bell from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, it had transferred its interstate long-distance revenues, its equipment revenues and 50 percent of its intrastate long-distance revenues to its former parent. Southern Bell said that resulted in a loss of 20 percent of its interstate revenues and operating expenses, and 12 percent of its investment.

description: Three of London's major cultural institutions, the Royal Court Theater and the Hayward and Serpentine Galleries, won reprieves today when the Arts Council unexpectedly renewed their Government grants.

description: The Senate today approved an additional $60 million in emergency food relief for drought-stricken African countries and $5 million in food aid for the Philippines through September 1985.

title: THE 'COM' IN COMPUTER IS ALSO IN COMMUNISM
description: In 1951, Harvard sociologist David Riesman published an essay called ''The Nylon War.'' In it, he suggested that the easiest way to vanquish our Soviet adversaries would be to drop consumer goods on them from airplanes.

description: The Knicks reached new lows tonight in a 107-79 loss to the Washington Bullets at the Capital Centre.

title: Albany to the Bank on Time
description: Impressively, for the second year in a row Governor Cuomo, the Republican Senator Warren Anderson and Speaker Stanley Fink, a Democrat, have met the April 1 deadline and agreed on a budget for New York. That clears the way for the annual dash to the banks for a $4.3 billion loan needed to pay leftover bills until new revenues are collected. All the more reason to welcome this budget's modest start at reducing the costly ''spring borrowing.''

title: Prodding the Pentagon
description: A Republican Congressman from New Jersey, sponsor of a bill that is apparently an irritant to the Pentagon, is beginning to think the military is deliberately malingering by not providing requested comments on the draft legislation.

title: REAGAN PROCLAIMS HE'S IN GOOD SHAPE
description: President Reagan, in an interview on the third anniversary of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s attempt to assassinate him, proclaimed himself in ''excellent shape'' today and predicted that his age would not be an election issue.

title: AIR FLORIDA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lord Brooke, 80, Dies; British Official in 60's
description: Lord Brooke of Cumnor, a British politician of the 1950's and 1960's who was often the target of popular protest, died Thursday at his home in Mildenhall, England, after a long illness. He was 80 years old.

title: RETRENCHMENT AT MARY KAY
description: At 200,000, the number of women selling Mary Kay skin-care and makeup products exceeds, by some 30,000, the global payroll of the mammoth Exxon Corporation. Indeed, their numbers almost match the population of Syracuse.

title: Official Says DeLorean Wasn't Suspect at First
description: John Z. DeLorean was not suspected of narcotics dealings when Government agents opened an undercover operation against the automobile maker, a prosecutor said today.

title: Vigil of Parents Ends With Morgue Discovery
description: The body of an emotionally disturbed teen-ager whose parents held a 107-day vigil after his disappearance lay unclaimed for months at a morgue because a pathologist misspelled his name, the authorities said today.

title: PRICES PAID FARMERS UP BY 1.4%
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products rose by an estimated 1.4 percent in March and averaged 9 percent above levels a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Novelist's Son Dies in Crash
description: The son of the novelist Joseph Wambaugh was killed Wednesday night along with another man in an accident on the Ensenada toll road, the Federal police reported. Mark Christopher Wambaugh, 21 years old, of Pasadena, Calif., and Michael John Hoy, 21, of San Marino, Calif., were killed when their Jeep collided with a car on a curve, a police spokesman said.

title: OLYMPIC ARTS FESTIVAL CANCELS 'CIVIL WARS'
description: Robert J. Fitzpatrick, director of the Olympic Arts Festival in Los Angeles, announced yesterday that because of insufficient funds, Robert Wilson's massive operatic-theatrical epic, ''The Civil Wars: A Tree Is Best Measured When It Is Down,'' would not be presented in California June 6-9.

title: OBSERVER ; Invaded By the Gentry
description: Our neighborhood is going uphill fast. The meat-packing plant next door has just been reamed out and turned into condominium apartments. Hanging plants have suddenly turned up in the window of what used to be a beer joint in the next block.

title: Miss Cohen Wins Again
description: Tiffany Cohen, a 17-year-old senior at Mission Viejo (Calif.) High School, became a two-event winner tonight in the Phillips 66/United States indoor swimming championships.

title: REAGAN REPORT PESSIMISTIC ON SATELLITE-KILLER PACT
description: A Reagan Administration report to be given to Congress concludes that a ban on specific antisatellite weapons may be possible to verify but that Administration experts have yet to figure out how to do it and doubt that it can be done, officials said today.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Trustee For J. David
description: A trustee has been named to oversee liquidation of J. David Securities Inc., a brokerage subsidiary of the J. David & Company investment and currency trading concern that was declared bankrupt on March 21.

title: GENERAL BUILDERS CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
A Degree for Bob Hope
description: Bob Hope was one of three recipients of the honorary degree of doctor of humane letters from Columbia University yesterday. The comedian was honored for his contributions to the Children's Tumor Clinic at the Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: ON-LINE SOFTWARE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income. c-Including a non-operating gain of $201,000.

title: Gambino Group Seen As Country's Biggest
description: Law enforcement authorities have long considered the Gambino crime group, which they say is headed by Paul Castellano, to be the largest and most powerful underworld organization in the United States.

title: I'M NOT INTO GROWTH; I'M INTO CONTRACTION
description: I awoke one morning recently and realized that I was shrinking. It was nothing I could see or measure; it was a product of deduction. Whether in person, in print or on radio and television, most people around me proclaimed that they were growing. They were ''maturing emotionally,'' having ''fascinating insights'' into themselves and realizing that nothing is as thrilling as observing their own growth.

title: A WOMAN WITHOUT A NAME
description: When an unidentified homeless woman died in the cold on a sidewalk outside Grand Central Terminal on Feb. 1, city officials handled her demise as a bureaucratic problem, not a human issue.

title: SYRACUSE SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: CREWS WORK TO RESTORE POWER IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Emergency crews were working today to clear away trees and restore electric power to thousands of Massachusetts residents after a spring storm Thursday that was responsible for at least two deaths.

title: BROOKLYN SHOWS HOUSE WHIP NEED FOR U.S. AID
description: A Congressman from Brooklyn took a fellow Congressman from Spokane, Wash., on a tour of his district yesterday and showed him what it was like to represent 516,000 people - all within 18 square miles.

title: DIAGNOSTIC DEVICE ALLOWED FOR SALE
description: A Federal agency yesterday allowed two companies to sell a medical diagnostic device that produces cross-sectional images of the body and its internal chemistry.

title: Democrats Lose Redistricting Plea
description: The Supreme Court refused today to order New Jersey voting officials to drop a Republican redistricting plan for an upcoming Congressional primary election.

title: Joseph G. Solari, Former Head Of Great Lakes Carbon Corp.
description: Joseph G. Solari, former president and chief executive officer of the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation, died of a heart attack Tuesday while playing golf in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 65 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: FIRST SPACE TEST OF YOGA SET FOR INDIAN ON SOVIET MISSION
description: India's first man in space is to perform yoga while strapped to sensitive instruments that measure weightlessness and motion sickness, Soviet space officials said today.

title: I.B.M. Japan Posts Gain
description: Strong sales of large computers helped increase I.B.M. Japan Ltd.'s profits in 1983 to a record 44.73 billion yen, or $200 million, up 25.3 percent from 35.69 billion yen in 1982, the company said today.

title: Freemans at Blue Note
description: The father-and-son tenor saxophonists Von and Chico Freeman will lead a quintet through tomorrow at the Blue Note (475-8592), West Third Street, at the Avenue of the Americas. Sets begin at 10 P.M., midnight and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, a $5 cover and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

title: Inco Sets Layoffs
description: Inco Ltd. said it will permanently lay off 415 hourly employees and 75 salaried personnel at its Port Colborne operations effective June 24. The resources concern said the layoffs follow a decision to cease production of electrolytic nickel at the Port Colborne refinery. The company, which had employed 800 people here, said the action had been taken to remain competitive in the international marketplace.

title: TRADING SLOWS
description: Stock prices fell moderately in slower trading yesterday when further evidence of the surging economy increased concern that interest rates would rise.

title: Couples Leads T.P.C. by Two
description: When Fred Couples said goodbye to his wife, Deborah, on Sunday night, she said she expected to see him back home in La Quinta, Calif., tonight. Neither one expected Couples to make the cut at the $800,000 Tournament Players Championship this week because he had not come close to making the cut in this tournament in 1982 or 1983 on the difficult Tournament Players Club course.

title: St. Louis Will Allow Trash-Picking by Day
description: Poor people crowded into City Hall today and won a victory from the Board of Aldermen, who agreed to change a proposed ordinance that would have banned scavenging in trash containers. The measure was amended to permit rummaging through the containers in the daytime.

title: Reagan Assures Marcos On Philippine Election
description: The Government said today that President Reagan has told President Ferdinand E. Marcos that the United States will not intervene in the Philippines parliamentary elections in May.

title: CHEMICAL BID CREDIT-CARD UNIT
description: The Chemical Bank has won the bid for the credit-card business of the Continental Illinois Corporation, the banks announced yesterday. The acquisition represents a major shift in Chemical's consumer-banking strategy, at a cost of almost $1 billion,

title: American Equity
description: American Equity Investment Trust said it had entered into a memorandum of understanding with George K. Baum Properties Inc. to sell all of its assets, including 18 real estate projects, some mortgage receivables and other items for $62.4 million. The sale is contingent on, among other things, the buyer's inspection of the assets and a definitive agreement by April 30. In over- the-counter trading today, American Equity jumped $1.75, to $20.50 bid.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: RINGERS

title: FOR MANY IN FLUSHING, U.S. POLITICS IS FOREIGN
description: In his jewelry shop on Main Street in Flushing, Queens, Sam Rhee was talking politics. He was explaining how some of the community's 30,000 Koreans view next Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary in New York.

title: REPUTED LEADER OF A CRIME FAMILY IS INDICTED BY U.S.
description: Paul Castellano, the reputed head of the Gambino organized-crime family, and 20 other people were charged in Manhattan yesterday with operating a group that committed 25 murders and scores of other crimes.

title: CONSUMERS' STAKE IN UTILITY CONSTRUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: MILTON B. FREUDENHEIM
description: Milton B. Freudenheim, retired president of Freudenheim Brothers Inc., a wholesale watch and jewelry company in Manhattan, died yesterday at Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital.

title: HART ASSAILS THE PRESIDENT ON ARMS AND LATIN POLICY
description: Gary Hart accused the Reagan Administration yesterday of pursuing ''a mindless accumulation of nuclear weapons'' and of ''focusing on the wrong enemy in Central America.''

title: No Headline
description: Cruise Liner Aground With 1,200 Stranded

title: MANGOOD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan 30.

title: POLISH BISHOPS RENEW DEMANDS IN CRUCIFIX CASE
description: Poland's Roman Catholic bishops demanded again today that crucifixes remain in public school classrooms, but the Government showed little sign of yielding.

title: Of Precincts and Parking
description: ''It's no picnic living in the city,'' Jasmine Melzer said. ''This is a quality-of-life thing.''
